DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president attends Nauru national day celebration
DOC.DATELINE: Yaren, Nauru, Jan. 31 (CNA) 02/01/08 11:01:58 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu attended a ceremony Thursday marking the 40th anniversary of Nauru's independence as part of a diplomatic tour to cement Taiwan's ties with three of its six South Pacific diplomatic allies that have seen new leaders elected in recent weeks.

Lu, who had just wrapped up a two-day visit to the Marshall Islands before arriving in Nauru early Thursday, told reporters that prior to her departure from Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian had asked her to invite the leaders of the diplomatic allies to visit Taiwan as soon as possible.
The heads of state of the Marshall Islands and Nauru have promised to visit Taiwan in March, Lu went on, adding that the governor of Guam might visit in April.
Lu made a transit stop in the U.S. territory of Guam on her way to the Marshall Islands.
Lu's tour will also take her to the Solomon Islands, one of Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, prior to her return to Taiwan Feb. 2.

Addressing a dinner party in Nauru, Lu expressed her appreciation to Nauru for its staunch support for Taiwan and for speaking at the U.N. General Assembly in favor of Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

She also noted that three Nauru fishermen who had been left adrift at sea for 11 days when their boat's engine malfunctioned and who were rescued by a Taiwanese fishing boat and taken to the Marshall Islands would be brought to Nauru from the Marshall Islands on her plane the following morning.
Lu added that she will meet the fishermen and their families after they arrive in Nauru.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$200 billion in loans to aid city renovation projects

TEXT.P: The government is urging housing developers to make use of a NT$200 billion (US$6.22 billion) loan program to engage in city renovation projects, Ministry of the Interior officials said Thursday.

The officials with the ministry's Construction and Planning Agency disclosed that the Interior Ministry has granted a total of NT$2.7 billion in loans to applicants since the program began in May 2006.

They added that the joint program between the government and 27 banks is intended to serve the dual purpose of helping property developers cope with their financial difficulties and stimulating domestic market demand.

According to the officials, applicants can borrow up to 80 percent of their costs for municipal renovation projects. All loans carry an interest rate of less than 2 percent per annum and should be repaid over six years.

Homeowners who can present a renovation plan are also elegible for a loan, the officials said, adding that homeowners in a block of apartments are encouraged to talk with their neighbors to work out a plan to renovate the entire building and increase their property value.

The officials compared the construction industry to a locomotive driving the nation's economic development and expressed hope that the low-interest loans will generate more business for domestic construction companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: New buildings required to be disabled-friendly from February

TEXT.P: New buildings must be equipped with facilities for disabled people from February or they will not granted licenses, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Thursday.
The announcement came after the ministry approved amendments to regulations governing the establishment of such facilities within public buildings at a meeting earlier in the day.
The amendments are part of the ministry's efforts to expand the current scope of the regulations to create a more friendly environment for disabled people, the official noted.

Under the amendments, the definition of public buildings will be extended to include convenience stores and hypermarkets, as well as cram schools and day care centers occupying an area of over 500 square meters, the official went on.

Contrary to the ministry's previous regulations that only required public buildings to establish disabled-friendly facilities, the amendments will make specific requirements on what such facilities should consist of, the official explained.
In addition, the new amendments will require schools to equip their buildings with disabled-friendly facilities, the official went on.
Beginning in April, the ministry will conduct comprehensive inspection tours of all public buildings' disabled-friendly facilities all over the country, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 1, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1650: Rene Descartes, French mathematician and philosopher known as the "father of French philosophy," dies at the age of 54. His philosophy is based on the rationalistic premise: "I think, therefore I am."
1893: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who patented more than a thousand inventions, opens the first film studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
1901: Clark Gable, American film actor who became an international heart throb, is born. He played Rhett Butler in "Gone With the Wind."
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games are held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of the 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the United States following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The U.N. General Assembly condemns the Chinese Communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The U.N. General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1958: The first U.S. satellite, the Vanguard-1, is successfully launched into orbit.
1963: Taiwan's `king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is named secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu- tung is named deputy secretary-general.
1973: One hundred and four members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan, 20 mayors and magistrates and the 73 members of the fifth Taiwan Provincial Assembly are sworn in.
1974: An economic mission headed by Economic Affairs Vice Minister Chang Kwang- shih leaves for Saudi Arabia for a five-day visit.
1978: The Central Daily News, the oldest newspaper in the country, marks its 50th anniversary.
1979: Iranian religious leader the Ayatollah Khomeini ends 16 years of exile, returning from Paris to a frenzied welcome at Tehran airport.
1980: Taiwan's North Link (Suao-Hualien) Railway is opened with ceremonies in Nanshenghu, near Ilan, and Hualien. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1982: Alfred Britain III, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, opens the bank's branch office in Taipei.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1991: An earthquake rocks Pakistan and Afghanistan, killing more than 1,200 people.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin sign the Camp David declaration stating that their two countries no longer regard each other as adversaries.
1995: Communist Vietnam and the United States begin a new chapter in their relationship by opening liaison offices in each others' capitals.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
2000: Premier Vincent Siew presides over a ceremony to unveil the name plaque of the newly established Coast Guard Administration and swear in CGA Director- General Yao Kao-chiao.
2001: Nobel laureate Gao Xingjian, at the invitation of the Taipei City Government's Cultural Affairs Bureau, arrives in Taiwan from Hong Kong.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: Mercury to drop with new cold snaps approaching

TEXT.P: The mercury is expected to drop to around 11 degrees Celsius in northern and eastern Taiwan over the weekend with the approach of a new cold snap caused by a continental arctic air mass, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Friday.

Another arctic air mass is forecast to approach Taiwan around Feb. 6 -- Lunar New Year's Eve -- bringing down the temperatures to as low as 9 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

The next cold snap is expected to hit Taiwan Sunday, bringing further cold and wet weather to central, northern and eastern Taiwan Feb. 3-5, with temperatures in the north dropping to 11 degrees and 12 degrees in central and northeastern parts of the island.

For Friday, the forecast was for temperatures fluctuating between 12-16 degrees in the north, 13-20 degrees in central areas, 15-24 degrees in the south and 17-23 degrees in the east of Taiwan proper, while temperatures will be much lower in the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu -- between a chilly 4 degrees and 10 degrees, the CWB forecasters said.

They predicted that while the whole area will be shrouded by another cold spell Feb. 6-7, with temperatures dropping to as low as 9 degrees in the north. Residents in northern and northeastern areas should also expect wet days, while mountainous areas in central, eastern, southern and southeastern Taiwan will have sporadic rain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Legislative speaker re-elected

TEXT.P: Incumbent Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who has served as legislative speaker for three consecutive terms, was re-elected Friday as head of the 7th Legislature, which is a restructured, downsized 113-member lawmaking body.
Wang, a heavyweight of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who served as a KMT vice chairman from 2000-2005, won the re-election with 85 votes out of 112 ballots cast.
Wang, 66, who has also served as a whip of the KMT legislative caucus and as deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan, was to be sworn into office shortly after being elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Palace Museum treasures to be shown in Vienna

TEXT.P: A collection of 116 ancient Chinese artworks from the National Palace Museum (NPM) in suburban Taipei are being painstakingly packed for shipment to the Austrian capital Vienna for a three-month exhibition set to begin Feb. 25, the museum's curator said Friday.

"The collection is not the largest the museum has ever sent abroad, but it is the most comprehensive, including masterpieces that connect the 5,000 years of China's history and demonstrate the vitality and fusion of Chinese culture, " said NPM Director Lin Mun-lee.
Among the precious items, 88 are ancient artifacts, 23 are paintings and calligraphy, and five are rare books and documents, Lin explained, adding that 55 of them have never left Taiwan before.

One of the most famous is a scroll painting titled "Along the River on the Chingming Festival." The 11-meter handscroll masterfully depicts life and customs in China's Soong Dynasty capital, Bianjing -- today's Kaifeng.
"The Vienna exhibition will mark the first time the 270-year-old painting has ever been shipped abroad," Lin said.
It took four years to prepare for the exhibition, to be staged at the Kunsthistorishches Museum, Lin said, paying tribute to her colleagues for their strenuous efforts to make the show possible.

According to Lin, the exhibition is part of a cultural exchange project between Taiwan and Austria. The first phase of the program is an exhibition of Great Habsburg collectors masterpieces of the Baroque period that opened at the NPM last October and will run until the end of February.
Austria is the fourth foreign country to engage in cultural exchanges with the NPM, home to the best of the 1,000-year-old art collection of China's emperors.

The museum, which is often compared to leading Western institutions like the Louvre in Paris and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, has cooperated with the United States, France and Germany in showcasing some of its magnificent art treasures in the past decade or so.

Lin said Belgium has also reached a consensus with the museum on a collaborative exchange program. Belgium has followed the example of the other countries in passing legislation to guarantee that none of the NPM's priceless artworks will be impounded due to China's sovereignty claim over Taiwan, according to Lin.
Meanwhile, she said, Japan has also shown keen interest in showcasing the museum's art collection.
At a Wednesday news conference, NPM staffers explained to the media how the works will be packed for shipment overseas using advanced technology and materials.
Lin said the collection has been insured for US$220 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Geneva Black Movie festival features Taiwanese films

TEXT.P: Taiwanese films will be featured in the Black Movie film festival that opened Friday in Geneva, Switzerland and will run through Feb. 10.

The festival, launched in 1991, is focusing on Taiwanese films for the first time this year. The series, titled "Taiwan plus 25, "conveys the idea that 25 years have passed since the first emergence of the Taiwanese New Wave film movement.
It's true that the New Wave is over," said Kate Reidy, assistant director of the festival, "but in the small country there are still lots of really interesting films being made today.
"Twenty-five years after, what remains?" That is what the festival expects its audience to find out, Reidy said.

Four sub-sections relating to Taiwan include a selection of 10 films by director Tsai Ming-liang, four works by Edward Yang as a homage to the director who died last summer, eight recent movies by Chang Tso-chi, Cheng Wen-tang, Chung Mong- hong, Lee Kang-sheng, Yao Hung-I and Lin Jing-jie, and 15 short films by cinema students of the National Taiwan University of Arts (NTUA).
"Tsai Ming-liang is probably one of the most important and innovative directors working today, we really believe he's some sort of a genius," Reidy said.

Starting with interest in Tsai's work and receiving assistance from the Taipei Cultural and Economic Delegation in Switzerland, Reidy visited Taiwan last autumn and the idea of featuring Taiwan in the festival began to take form.

She said she and her colleague discovered the work of Chang Tso-chi during the trip to Taiwan and added that many of the NTUA students' works are quite promising. Taiwanese films form one of the eight sections in this year's Black Movie festival, with Africa, Iran and Malaysia also featured.

DOC.HEADLINE: Armored vehicle robbed in Taipei, suspect flees

TEXT.P: A cash transporting van was robbed Friday morning by a motorcyclist who sprayed an unidentified substance into the eyes of the van's driver and three other security guards before making off with NT$1.04 million (around US$30,600), according to the Taipei Municipal Police Department.
The man, who was wearing rain gear, fled with the bag of cash after incapacitating the four workers -- three Weifong Security Services Co. guards and a Changhua Bank security officer.

The heist occurred when the guards carried the cash bag from the van to a Changhua Bank branch located on the intersection of Zhongshan North Road and Jinzhou Street in northern Taipei City, the police said.
The biker first sprayed the two guards who were holding the cash bag and when the van's driver and the bank security guard ran to their rescue, they were also sprayed, the police said.
All four were rushed to nearby Mackay Memorial Hospital for treatment to their eyes, where doctors later said their injuries were not serious.

The robber ran off on foot. Criminal investigators from the Taipei Municipal Police Department have begun investigating the case, examining the motorbike left behind by the robber and surveillance cameras installed near the scene.
The investigators believe the robber was whisked away by an accomplice soon after he dodged into a nearby lane.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bankers' group issues tips to ATM cardholders ahead of holidays

TEXT.P: The Bankers Association of the Republic of China (BAROC) reminded the public ahead of the Chinese New Year holidays to be on guard against ATM card scams when withdrawing cash from their accounts.
BAROC officials said Friday that ATM card swindlers have developed a variety of new scams for tricking cardholders into revealing their PIN numbers and other personal information.

The officials reminded people to first seek verification of the authenticity of any organization requesting their ATM card information or to call the National Police Agency's anti-fraud hotline on 165 before divulging any information.
As banks will be closed for six straight days between Feb. 6-11, the BAROC officials also offered some reminders to the public to avoid problems when using ATM services during the holiday period.

Noting that there is a daily limit on the amount that can be withdrawn from an ATM machine, the officials urged people to work out their budget beforehand to ensure that they have ample cash available for the holidays.
They also suggested that people try to refrain from using ATM machines between 2 p.m. and 4: 30 p.m. during the three days before the start of the holidays in order to avoid long lineups.

ATM cardholders were urged to hold on to their transaction receipts as proof if they experience any problems while using an ATM machine and to call the emergency service number posted by the machine to explain their situation immediately.
If they cannot get through to anyone at the service number listed by the ATM machine, they can call the Financial Information Service Co. on (02) 2630-1222 for assistance, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese American woman seeks bone marrow donor
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Jan. 31 (CNA) 02/01/08 14:35:48 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Chinese American woman suffering from leukemia is looking for a suitable ethnic Chinese donor for a bone marrow transplant, members of a Taiwanese expatriate group in the United States said Thursday.

All ethnic Chinese aged 18-55 who are physically fit and who are willing to help are urged to receive blood tests to see if they are a match for 35-year-old Hsu Ya-shih, according to the U.S. east coast chapter of the National Women's League of the Republic of China.

Potential donors can have their blood samples collected for testing at the following locations in New York: Central Islip Campus, New York Institute and Technology (1: 30 p.m. Feb. 3); Boon Church of Overseas Chinese Mission, Flushing (1 p.m. Feb. 10) ; and Chung Hwa Book Inc., Flushing (4 p.m. Feb. 10).
They can also contact Cammy Lee Leukemia Foundation Inc. located at 16 West 32nd Street, Suite 10D, New York. Web site: www.cllf.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unique butterfly greenhouse inaugurated in Chiayi

TEXT.P: An Insect Ecology Hall (IEH) , featuring a unique ventilated Living Butterfly Greenhouse Garden -- Taiwan's first -- was inaugurated Thursday in the southern city of Chiayi.

Located on the campus of National Chiayi University, the IEH contains a butterfly greenhouse equipped with seven ventilators that circulate the air and greatly reduce the butterfly mortality rate, according to IEH staff.
The inauguration ceremony was highlighted by the release of 600 butterflies of about 20 different species that fluttered around the guests and even alighted on their shoulders.

They included the idea leuconoe Clara, better known as "big stupid butterflies" in Taiwan, for they fly more slowly than their relatives of the same family. They are the biggest butterflies in the danaidae family found in Taiwan.
According to the staff, 100 new mature butterflies or pupae will be placed each week in the greenhouse, with the varieties changed in accordance with the seasons.

The greenhouse designers tried to provide the butterflies and other insects housed there with the same living conditions they have in nature, the staff noted, adding that all the vegetation the larvae feed on is cultivated in the greenhouse garden. An estimated total of 5,700 butterflies and other living insects will be raised in the greenhouse per year.
Besides the greenhouse, the IEC includes other sections, such as the Living Aquatic Insect Zone and the Taiwan-Protected and World-Rare Living Insects Zone.

During the trial operation from February 1-5, visitors to the IEC can benefit from a 50 percent discount on the admission fee. The IEC will begin formal operations Feb. 7 and will be open year-round, except for Chinese New Year's Eve.

DOC.HEADLINE: Online job searching increases ahead of Chinese New Year

TEXT.P: A total of 220,000 job seekers had their resumes posted with online employment broker 104 Job Bank a week before Chinese New Year, a marked rise from 2007, the company said Friday.

The number is 13.4 percent higher than at the same time last year, indicating that the job search frenzy that usually occurs after the Chinese New Year holiday has arrived early this year, the company said.

The high-tech industry remains the most popular target of job applicants, with the largest number of them looking for openings in the fields of electronic components, semiconductors, software and Internet-related services, the company said.
The second-most popular target is the retail and restaurant sector, following by traditional manufacturing industries, 104 Job Bank said.

The top five companies attracting the most active job seekers are Carrefour, Epistar Corp., AU Optronics, ASUSTek Computer Inc., and the company running the new sports lottery, with each receiving 4,000 resumes per week from active job seekers in January, the company said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President presents awards to agricultural firm, expert

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented the third Presidential Agriculture Awards to a local seed company and the former head of an agricultural research body Friday to recognize their long-term contributions to Taiwan's agricultural sector.
At a ceremony organized by the Council of Agriculture (COA), Chen hailed Known- You Seed Co., the country's largest producer of seeds, for demonstrating a humanitarian spirit over the years.
Chen explained that the company has established a social welfare fund for local farmers and helped farmers buy new seeds and fertilizer when they suffered setbacks due to natural disasters.
In addition to its efforts on behalf of farmers at home, the company also set up a hospital for agricultural workers in Myanmar, Chen noted.
Chen also praised Wan Hsiung, former director of the Taiwan Agricultural Research Institute (TARI) , for dedicating himself to Taiwan's agricultural sector over the past 60 years.
Chen said that back in 1960, Wan developed an anti-disease tobacco species, which helped combat a disease that had affected Taiwan's tobacco crop on a large scale.
In his capacity as TARI director, Wan also conducted a series of reforms to improve the institute's facilities, recruit more talent and increase international exchanges, Chen said.
After retiring, Wan committed himself to educating the next generation of experts, setting a good model for Taiwan's people, the president noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group calls for 'transparent' legislature

TEXT.P: A local activist group called on members of the Seventh Legislative Yuan Friday to sign a petition pledging to build the new, restructured legislature into a transparent lawmaking body and clean up legislative politics.

Citizen Congress Watch Chairman Ku Chung-hua urged Legislative Speaker Wang Jin- pyng, who was re-elected to his post earlier in the day, to lead the campaign to turn the new 113-member legislature into a clean, transparent lawmaking body.
With over half of the 113 legislators yet to endorse the petition since it was proposed last month, Ku's group called on all lawmakers to sign the petition by March 10.
Those who do not will have images of their faces paraded in public at the group's rally on March 15 and earn the condemnation of Taiwan's citizens, Ku insisted.

Members of the watchdog group -- made up of 40 civic groups around Taiwan -- sent newly sworn-in legislators bouquets of carnations, sunflowers, narcissus, tulips and lilies as symbols of their five requests to lawmakers to protect the public interest, pass sunshine laws, and be transparent, civilized and efficient.

Ku said the group hopes that members of the new legislature will do away with the shenanigans pulled by their predecessors, who made a habit of putting on shows, disrupting sessions with violence, and trading favors.
Ku also urged the new legislature to open itself to the public by providing an online feed, allowing viewers access to legislative sessions and enabling them to monitor the body more easily.
In addition, the group called for an end to the practice of holding closed-door caucus negotiations as a way to solve major controversies among rival parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPSU urges not to hold U.N. referendums along with March election

TEXT.P: The chairman of the opposition Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) urged the Central Election Commission (CEC) Friday to keep two planned referendums on Taiwan's bid for a seat in the United Nations on hold and let the new president handle the issue.

Lin Ping-kun, who is also a legislator representing Penghu County, said the NPSU believes economic issues related to the people's welfare and livelihood are the top priority at present, and the referendums, therefore, should be less of a focus for the administration.

If the CEC does not push the referendums back, Lin said, the initiators of the two referendums -- the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the largest opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- would be politically responsible for possible "ethnic conflicts and Taiwan's suffering from international isolation caused by the controversial polls."

The DPP's question asks voters if Taiwan should enter the U.N. under the name "Taiwan" while the KMT's question asks if the country should return to the U.N. under the name "Republic of China" or any other feasible name.
Taiwan lost its seat at the U.N. to China in 1971.

Lin made the call at a press conference he held along with the NPSU's two other lawmakers, Yen Ching-piao and Kao Chin Su-mei, at the party's office at the legislature, ahead of a CEC meeting scheduled later in the day to decide on the date of the referendums.

Lin suggested that the CEC not post the voting date for the referendums on its bulletin announcing election procedures, which would open the door for them to be postponed until after the March 22 presidential election.
Under the Referendum Act, the announcement and publication of the voting date 28 days ahead of the vote is the final official step that has to be completed before the polls are carried out.

"If the CEC does not publicly announce a date, there will be more time for discussion on the U.N.-bid issue, " the legislator argued. He suggested a broader public consensus on how to pursue a seat in the international organization was needed before taking the issue to a popular vote.
"Such a move should be taken in a cautious manner on the basis of maintaining Taiwan's national dignity," he said.
Lin, Yen and Kao won re-election in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, the only NPSU lawmakers to emerge victorious.
The Seventh Legislative Yuan opened earlier in the day, beginning its four-year term.

The NPSU, established June 15, 2004, emerged as a major player on the national political scene during the 2004 legislative elections, when 26 candidates ran for local constituency and aboriginal seats and six others were nominated for proportional representation seats.
It won six seats that year, and three seats in the 2008 elections. Although non- partisan in name, the union generally is considered to be part of the KMT-led pan-blue camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA to list Taiwan's first protected rodent

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) will soon list the Asiatic water shrew, only a small number of which can be found in western, central, and northern Taiwan, as the country's first protected rodent, a local scholar said Thursday.

The council's Forestry Bureau paved the way for the decision by approving a proposal to list the Asiatic water shrew as a protected species at a commissioners' meeting on the preservation of wild animals in early January.

Lin Liang-kong, a professor in Tunghai University's Department of Life Science, said that the Asiatic water shrew -- one of Taiwan's 19 kinds of rodents -- was not discovered until 1971 when it was found along the Mei River in central Taiwan.

The polluted river and a river treatment project have resulted in a sharp decline in the rodent's population in the area. Lin said he had been able to find only a dozen of them over the past two years.
The Asiatic water shrew weighs a maximum of 50-60 grams and feeds on water insects, small fish, and small shrimps. It lives close to the water, with snakes being its natural enemy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate promises free vocational high schools

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said in Taichung Friday that if elected, he will push for free vocational high schools to provide high quality talent for the domestic machinery equipment industry.

Ma made the pledge while meeting with industry representatives at the headquarters of precision machinery component maker Hiwin Technologies Corp. during a visit to the Taichung Industrial Park in central Taiwan.

Ma expressed optimism over the prospects of Taiwan's machinery equipment industry, and promised to promote cooperation between the government and private sector to help it become Taiwan's "third trillion-Taiwan dollar industry."
The domestic semiconductor and flat panel display industries both surpassed NT$1 trillion (US$31.22 billion) in revenues in 2006.

During the meeting, the representatives raised several suggestions on boosting the machinery industry's development, including setting up an international research and development alliance and a joint equipment and service center.

After listening to the suggestions, Ma said that innovation is the heart of the industry's survival and development, and he said he would implement policies to encourage innovation in the industry if elected in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT councilor wins Changhua deputy speaker by-election

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) councilor in central Taiwan's Changhua County won a landslide victory in a by-election Friday for the county council's deputy speaker post.

Yang Fu-ti won 37 votes out of the ballots cast by the 50 county councilors present for the by-election. He will replace Hsiao Ching-tien, who resigned to make a successful run for a seat in the new legislature elected on Jan. 12.

Liang Chen-hsiang, a veteran county councilor of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, won 12 votes, while Chao Hui-ju, a Taiwan Solidarity Union county councilor, won one vote as she voted for herself.
Shortly after winning the by-election, Yang was sworn in by Changhua District Court judge Wang Chang-hsin.

Meanwhile, Changhua County Council Speaker Pai Hung-sen offered Yang his congratulations, and said he hoped the county government could work with the council for the benefit of Changhua County's residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange surged Friday, with the weighted Taiex index, the market's key barometer, gaining 152.86 points, or 2.03 percent, to close at 7,673.99.

Rebounding after two consecutive losing sessions, the market opened at 7,613.58 and fluctuated between 7,706.03 and 7,583.65 during trading. A total of 4.12 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$123.13 billion (US$3.84 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground. Foodstuff issues advanced by 6.2 percent, the most of any sector. Construction issues and cement stocks both rose 5.6 perent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 3.8 percent, textile stocks increased 3.4 percent, paper and pulp issues gained 2.5 percent, banking and financial shares grew 2.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares advanced 1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,485 to 418, with 376 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: All new lawmakers except one report to the legislature

TEXT.P: All 113 newly elected lawmakers reported to the Legislative Yuan Friday, with one exception, as the weather and the lower number of lawmakers put a damper on the usual opening day festivities.
Legislator-elect Lu Chia-cheng of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) was the only one who did not register, as the Seventh Legislature marked the start of its four-year term.

Lu, the incumbent mayor in Taipei County's Tucheng, spent the day visiting elderly residents of his city instead. He said earlier he will report to the legislature March 1 to avoid a mayoral by-election.

By reporting to the legislature next month, Lu will pass the halfway point of his four-year tenure and negate the need for a by-election to fill his vacated seat. Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei will appoint a replacement for Lu instead.

Meanwhile, incumbent Legislature Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, arrived early at the lawmaking body and expressed the hope that the new legislature would step up its service to the public and help improve its image.

Hoping for an end to the serious gridlock from incessant partisan bickering that plagued the previous legislature, he also called on the ruling and the opposition parties to show "rationality" in reviewing major development projects and budget bills.

The traditional ritual of new legislators walking up the red carpet was not as lively and bustling as in the past, the festivities dampened by the dreary rainy weather and the lower number of lawmakers who will be seated in the restructured assembly.

KMT Legislator Chiu Ching-chun of Hsinchu County, who won 127,892 votes in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, the most of any candidate, expressed the hope that a downsized legislature will help upgrade the lawmaking body's efficiency.
KMT Legislator Chang Chia-chun, the youngest legislator at age 27, registered in the company of her husband.
Chang, the eldest daughter of former Yunlin County Magistrate Chang Jung-wei, admitted there was a lot of pressure on her as a newcomer but said she would work hard to learn her job.
The KMT has 81 seats to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's 27 in the new legislature, which was halved in size from the previous 225 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices higher on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 206 points to close at 7,669, with 57,730 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 214 points to finish at 7,645, with 1,253 contracts traded, while June futures increased 181 points to close at 7,636, with eight contract transactions.
September futures increased 196 points to finish at 7,468, with 16 contract transactions, while December futures gained 144 points to end 7,407, with two contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 152.86 points Friday to finish at 7,673.99, with market turnover amounting to NT$123.13 billion (US$3.84 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,463 for February; 7,431 for March; 7,455 for June; 7,272 for September and 7,263 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

February TE futures increased 4.5 points to close at 294.5, with 5,175 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 4.55 points to finish at 293.55, with 39 contract exchanges. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

February TF futures gained 34.8 points to close at 1,020.8, with 4,745 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures moved up 25.8 points to finish at 1,017, with 49 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded June, September and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: World-class exhibition on biological clock held in southern Taiwan

TEXT.P: An interactive exhibition on the biological clocks of fauna and flora designed by a British museum continued its tour of Taiwan Friday when it opened at a Pingtung museum, where it will run until May 4.
The exhibition dubbed "Rhythms of Life" was produced by the Natural History Museum in London, and is now on its world tour.

Targeting both young and old visitors, especially families with children aged seven to 12 and student groups, the exhibition was designed with many interactive features, cartoon characters, and other displays to convey and explain the science of biological clocks to visitors.
The exhibition contains different exhibition areas with the themes "Day and Night, " "Seasons, " and "Lifecycles" to bring a theatrical and educational touch to the biological rhythms of nature.
It explains why birds sing in the morning, frogs croak in the evening, and cereus buds always bloom at night, an official at the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau said Friday.

Visitors will learn about tidal rhythms, sleep patterns and circadian cycles for all living beings, and also see the influence of the biological clock on micro- organisms and small living things, like bacterium, fungus, and fleas.

"Kids are surprised to learn that polar bears do not really hibernate and that myoxidae, a type of mouse in Britain, hibernate for up to seven months, " said Chen Hsin-chun, a National Taiwan Museum (NTM) exhibition guide who provides assistance to Pingtung County's museum.

The exhibition has also traveled to the NTM in Taipei City, the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung City, central Taiwan, and the Chiayi Performing Arts Center in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.
Its latest stop is a museum in Pingtung City that opened in December and is being tentatively called the Pingtung Art Gallery in English, according to the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau.
The exhibition will run until May 4 at the Pingtung museum, which will be closed from Feb. 6- 9 for the Chinese New Year holidays, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese university successfully cultivates cuttlefish

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Penghu University has successfully cultivated a batch of cuttlefish in a fully controlled environment -- a first-ever achievement that could increase the population of the species suffering from dwindling numbers.

"The birth of the fish, kept in an artificially controlled environment, is the first program of its kind in Taiwan, " Wong Chin-ping, a researcher at the university on the outlying island of Penghu, said Thursday at a ceremony to celebrate the university's accomplishment.

Wong said last spring, the research team successfully cultivated 1,500 cuttlefish from 2,000 eggs collected from the wild, of which 100 were raised in a tank at a laboratory and were fed blue Buddha shrimps.

The little fish grew rapidly and weighed 500 to 800 kilograms at nine months old, Wong said. They later lay eggs and gave birth to more than 1,000 fish at 1 to 3 centimeters in size, with some 500 died before maturity.
The project's aim is to enable Taiwan to mass produce cuttlefish -- a popular seafood for consumers. In Taiwan, cuttlefish are made into fish balls, stirred fried or added to soup.
However, in recent years, the number of cuttlefish in the natural environment has been sharply dwindling and there are only a small number of people working on artificial breeding.

The project is not only considered an academic achievement but also a great milestone for stimulating the regeneration of cuttlefish stocks and developing the marine and aquaculture industries, Wong said.

The fish species used in the study is the pharaoh cuttlefish. Its normal life expectancy is about one year and it lays eggs only once in its lifetime, with the number of eggs at approximately 300 to 500, Wong said.
"Normally, the female cuttlefish would die once after giving birth and the male fish would take over the job to care for their babies." Wong added.
The breeding and growth of the two generations of cuttlefish have been kept in a fully controlled environment.

Under "full cultivation" conditions, the survival rate of the cuttlefish species reached 80 percent, far higher than that in a natural environment, said Hsue Yung-lin, a university student participating in the program. Hsue added that with the feeding methods and procedures of raising the cuttlefish all under human control, the fish showed more rapid growth than ordinary ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.178.
A total of US$2.326 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.198 and fluctuated between NT$32.002 and NT$32.233.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tseng Yung-chuan elected as deputy legislative speaker

TEXT.P: Legislator Tseng Yung-chuan, who was nominated by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to serve as the deputy speaker, was elected as expected Friday.

As the KMT and its allies control 85 seats in the 113-member restructured, downsized legislature, Tseng's election was almost assured. He beat his rival, Wong Chin-chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), 84-27.

Tseng received one less vote than Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who was re- elected in an election earlier the same day, because a member of the KMT-led "pan-blue alliance" cast a vote for Wang instead of Tseng.
KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said tongue in cheek that this may mean that some wanted Wang to concurrently serve as deputy speaker.
Wong received the votes of all 27 DPP lawmakers.
All but one of the 113 legislators registered Friday and cast votes to elect the new speaker and deputy speaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former lawmaker indicted for buying votes to seek re-election

TEXT.P: Former Legislator Lin Chung-te of the opposition People First Party was indicted Friday for buying votes during his re-election compaign in the round-up to the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

The Nantou District Prosecutors Office in central Taiwan requested the court hand down a sentence of five years' imprisonment plus a fine of NT$5 million (US$155,900) to Lin, a prosecutor said Friday.

Ten other people were also indicted for their suspected roles in the vote-buying offense, including Lin Hsin-yi, chief of Fuhsin township in Taoyuan County near Taipei, and his secretary Chang Chin-huei.

Also indicted were Ko Wu-yung, chief of Taian township in northern Taiwan's Miaoli County; Lin's son Lin Cheng-chi; four staff members at Lin's office at the Legislative Yuan; a travel agency operator; and Tsai Pao-lien, wife of the chief of Jenai township in Nantou County.

According to the prosecutors office, Lin and the other indicted were suspected of organizing tour groups to travel to China for sightseeing between July 7 and Nov. 2, 2007 as a treat for people in exchange for their votes for him.
Lin was seeking re-election as a legislator representing mountain aboriginal tribes in the Jan. 12 elections.
Nearly 100 eligible voters were found to have profited from the illegal offer.
Lin was defeated by Kao Chin Su-mei of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union in the just-concluded elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Head to Head, Clinton, Obama Shelve Rancor
Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama set aside personal hostilities here Thursday night but sharply disagreed on who has the better combination of leadership and experience to defeat Republicans in November and lead the country as president.
The Washington Times:Top-tier al Qaeda leader killed A senior al Qaeda leader responsible for numerous attacks on American troops in Afghanistan and elsewhere was killed several days ago in Pakistan in a missile attack that an Islamist Web site blamed on the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Kurds' Power Wanes as Arab Anger Rises
As a minority group in Iraq, the Kurds have enjoyed disproportionate influence in the country's politics since the ouster of Saddam Hussein in 2003. But now their leverage appears to be declining as tensions rise with Iraqi Arabs, raising the specter of another fissure alongside the sectarian divide between Sunnis and Shiites.
The Wall Street Journal:Chinalco, Alcoa Buy Rio Tinto Stake
Aluminum Corp. of China said it has teamed up with Alcoa Inc. of the U.S. to purchase an approximately 12% stake in mining giant Rio Tinto, marking one of the boldest investments overseas by a Chinese company and injecting China in the middle of one of the world's biggest takeover battles.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGPapers show Ken Livingstone used public servants in vote battle
Ken Livingstones campaign instructed public servants to write articles in support of his last reelection as Mayor of London in a breach of rules forbidding political abuse of taxpayerscash.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign ministry's suboffices will help promote overseas ties: MOFA

TEXT.P: Three new offices set up by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) outside Taiwan's capital are aimed at helping local governments and residents explore ties with other countries and promote Taiwan's presence on the world stage, the top ministry official said Friday.
Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang made the remarks while presiding over the establishment of the ministry's newly opened office in Taichung City, in central Taiwan.
Two other MOFA offices were also opened Friday in Hualien City in eastern Taiwan and Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan.

Huang said the three new offices will help local governments strengthen Taiwan's international relations through growing exchanges with foreign companies and governments and civic groups based overseas.

The offices are also expected to make it more convenient for local residents to apply for passports to go overseas. Instead of going through the ministry's office in Taipei, applications can be processed locally.

Former Ambassador to the Dominican Republic Adolfo Sun will serve as head of the Taichung office. Shyu Gaung-pu, director of the Hualien City's office of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs will lead the office for the time being, while former Ambassador to Honduras You Tien-der will head the Kaohsiung office.

According to Shyu, the Hualien office was an existing office that was upgraded to reflect the greater importance that the foreign ministry attaches to having a representative office in the eastern region.
In past years, the region saw some 15,000 applications for passports each year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 cross-strait agricultural trade up 40%: Chinese statistics

TEXT.P: Two-way agricultural trade between Taiwan and China totaled US$800 million last year, growing a whopping 40.3 percent over 2006, according to statistics released Thursday by China's Ministry of Commerce.

Chinese agricultural exports to Taiwan reached US$610 million in 2007, representing an increase of 46.6 percent over the previous year, according to statistics on the website of the ministry's Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs.
Meanwhile, China's agricultural imports from Taiwan in 2007 totaled US$190 million, up 23 percent from 2006, the statistics showed.
The top five Chinese export items to Taiwan were duck feather and down filling, unsweetened milk solids and butter, shrimps, malt and sea laver.
Top import items included cuttlefish and squid -- frozen, dried, salted or in brine -- duck feather and down filling, seedlings for plant breeding, frozen fish and cotton waste.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made chip which traces origin of food attracts global interest

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-developed technology which uses radio frequency chips to trace where live food, such as chickens and fish, come from has attracted attention from breeding industry representatives around the world, local officials said Friday.
Live spotted groupers implanted with the Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) chip hit the market for the first time in southern Taiwan's Tainan City in January.

Since then, the technology has attracted attention overseas, with breeding industry representatives from several countries, including the United States, Japan and Germany, sent to Taiwan in recent months to learn more about the system, according to officials of a local company which developed the technology for commercial use.
Tekho Group officials added that the company hopes to begin exporting the live food traceability technology within the next two years.
The RFID chip was developed by the quasi-official Institute for Information Industry (III), which later transferred the technology to the Tekho Group for commercial application.
Tekho Group then cooperated with a restaurant in Tainan to cater the technology for widespread use.
Institute officials said that the system allows the history of an individual spotted fish to be traced from the breeding grounds all the way to the restaurant table.
If a customer wants to know about a spotted breeder's history before purchasing it, a simple scan of the RFID chip implanted below the fish's gill reveals its complete history, they said.
"This allows the consumer to enjoy the spotted breeder without any concerns about safety," one Institute official said.
They expressed hope that with the new technology, a comprehensive nationwide live food traceability system will eventually be established to ensure consumer safety.
Currently, the RFID traceability chip is only available in Tainan City, Tekho officials said, adding that it will spread to the rest of Taiwan in the near future.
Annual output for Taiwan's spotted grouper industry is about NT$3 billion, with about 80 percent of the fish being exported to Hong Kong and China, according to the Tekho officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's southern city to be fully prepared for dengue fever

TEXT.P: Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair instructed city officials Friday to be ready by mid- March to stem any possible outbreaks of dengue fever in the southern city later this year.
Tainan City was the area hardest hit by the disease in Taiwan last year, with 1,468 residents contracting the disease, accounting for 73.5 percent of the country's 1,998 dengue fever patients.
Hsu made his request at a meeting held to review the city government's efforts to control the epidemic last year.

The mayor stressed that health officials should be particularly on the alert for dengue hemorrhagic fever, and said that the recruiting and training of personnel to fight the disease should be completed by mid-March.
All necessary equipment and facilities should also be ready before then, he added.

Meanwhile, Hsu ordered city officials to collect the medical records of last year's dengue fever victims and monitor their health conditions as the data could be provided to the city's hospitals in the event of a dengue fever outbreak.

He also called for the comprehensive control and management of the city's environmental quality, demanding that empty houses be dismantled and unused land be cleaned up to remove possible breeding grounds for disease-spreading mosquitoes.
The city's health bureau will set up stations and small units within the city to tighten the control of key areas, and expand the city's reporting system to stem the disease, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP caucus vows to increase transparency of new legislature

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus has vowed to promote bills aimed at increasing the transparency of the new legislature and the professionalism of new lawmakers, DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said Friday.
Ker made the remarks at a press conference held after newly elected legislators elected in the Jan. 12 elections reported to duty at the new 113-member legislature.
Despite holding only a minority of seats, Ker stressed that DPP legislators will still focus on "quality" over "quantity" in their performance.
The DPP only grabbed 27 legislative seats in the Jan. 12 elections, a humiliating defeat compared to the 81 seats won by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Ker explained that the DPP caucus will first ask the legislature to review the Political Donation Act, the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Act, and other bills that are designed to establish a clean government.
In addition, the caucus will push for putting the assets of all lawmakers into trust, and requiring lawmakers to explain unusual increases in their assets, Ker said.
To increase the professionalism of lawmakers, the caucus will promote a regulation barring lawmakers from serving as on the board of directors for companies, Ker noted.
Meanwhile, the caucus will also push for the transparency of negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties as well as live broadcasts of meetings at the legislature, he said.

Furthermore, the caucus will push for the passage of amendments aimed at increasing the efficiency of the legislature, better protecting the rights of laborers, providing better care for disadvantaged children, and carrying out land tax reforms, according to Ker.

Other legislators, William Lai, Yeh Yi-jin, and Kuan Bi-ling, also pledged at the press conference that they will work hard to win the hearts and minds of the people despite the party's minority power.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local banks' nonperforming loan ratio drops to three-year low

TEXT.P: The ratio of nonperforming loans on the books of locally owned banks stood at 1.84 percent as of the end of December 2007, a new low since the ratio was redefined in July 2005, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Thursday.
The nonperforming loan ratio registered at the end of December was 0.29 percentage points lower than that of a month earlier, the commission said.
The three-year low indicated that banks have become more adept at liquidating or writing off nonperforming assets and were accelerating their disposal, said an FSC official.

Bank loan expansion also helped lower the ratio of nonperforming loans, with outstanding loans at domestic banks increasing by NT$180 billion in December to reach NT$17.87 trillion (US$530.78) at the end of the month, the official said.
Of the amount, nonperforming loans totaled NT$328.1 billion at the end of December, down from the NT$377.6 billion on the books at the end of the previous month.

Prior to July 2005, any loan that was overdue by more than six months in Taiwan was considered a nonperforming loan. But the FSC tightened the standard to include loans overdue by more than three months in the "nonperforming" category, increasing the bad loan ratios of domestic banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gasoline, diesel fuel prices to remain unchanged in February: CPC

TEXT.P: The state-run CPC Corp., Taiwan, the country's largest oil refiner, announced Friday that gasoline and diesel fuel prices will remain unchanged in February.

Prices of natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas and fuel oil will also be maintained at the current level to help stabilize consumer prices and boost industrial competitiveness, CPC said in a statement.

As a result, prices will remain at NT$32.2 per liter for 98-octane unleaded gasoline, NT$30.7 per liter for 95-octane unleaded, NT$30 per liter for 92-octane unleaded, and NT$27.5 per liter for super diesel fuel.
Had it followed a floating price mechanism the government introduced in January 2007, however, CPC would have raised the price of gasoline by more than NT$2 a liter.

The mechanism was adjusted in September, though, as crude approached US$80 per barrel. Gasoline prices in the future would be adjusted on a monthly rather than weekly basis and would not be permitted to exceed 15 percent of the September price.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs adjusted the 15 percent cap to 12 percent in November when crude appeared on its way to breaking the US$100 per barrel barrier and fears of inflation had gripped consumers.

Calculating the current price level of oil based on a 70/30 mix of Brent and Dubai crude, CPC said gasoline prices should be 23.39 percent higher than those of September 2007, well above the 12 percent threshold -- forcing the oil giant to keep prices steady.

The pricing mechanism raises gasoline prices by about 80 percent of the crude oil price increases in the previous two months, so the per liter increase would have been about NT$2 per liter had the old mechanism remained in effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stateless immigrants from Thailand, Myanmar to be granted residence

TEXT.P: The government will grant residence to stateless persons from Thailand and Myanmar who entered Taiwan with fake passposts before May 21, 1999, as long as a local court has processed their case, National Immigration Agency officials said Friday.

If the stateless persons have turned themselves in to authorities and a court has decided not to indict them, commuted their indictment or settled their case, those court documents can be used as verification of their stateless status as part of their application for permanent residence.

Under the Immigration Act that took effect on May 21, 1999, the stateless persons were not only required to turn themselves in to authorities but also get a document from their home country attesting to their inability to return home.
That documentation proved nearly impossible to get, leaving the cases of many of the illegal immigrants in limbo. Under Friday's decision, that documentation is no longer necessary.

Those individuals from Thailand and Myanmar who arrived with fake travel documents before May 21, 1999 but did not turn themselves in and had no contact with local courts, can still report to authorities to obtain court verification of their stateless status.

The new measure is intended to find a solution to the long-stalled issue concerning the dilemma faced by ethnic Chinese refugees in northern Thailand and Myanmar who have entered Taiwan with fake travel documents.
Many of them are descedents of Kuomintang soldiers who retreated to the region after losing the civil war in China in 1949.

The problem remained unanswered after the implementation of the Immigration Act, which stipulates that stateless people coming to Taiwan from Thailand, Myanmar or Indonesia before the law's implementation shall be granted residence in the country.
Applications for permanent residence are being accepted at any agency service center, and those who need further information are advised to call the agency at (02) 23889393 ext. 2551 or 2553.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei flower exposition expected to generate NT$10 billion

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei International Garden and Horticulture Exposition, Taiwan's first flower exposition certified by the International Association of Horticultural Producers (AIPH) , is expected to generate over NT$10 billion (about US$310 million) for the city, the Taipei City Government said Friday.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin introduced the expo logo and mascot at apress conference, where he announced that preparations for the event are officially underway.
"Holding a world-acclaimed event like this will boost Taipei's visibility in the international community, and upgrade the country's flower industry, " Hau boasted.
Taiwan will become the fourth Asian country to host the highly regarded event, which is expected to attract 300,000 foreign visitors.
Hau said 1,669 logo designs from all over the world, including Germany, the U.S. and Japan, were submitted to the organizer, reflecting the worldwide appeal of the show.
A logo design by Taiwanese designer and mascot design by local designer Li Kai- an were chosen for the event.

The AIPH is a coordinating body representing horticultural producers' organizations throughout the world to stimulate the international marketing of flowers, plants and landscaping services. Its committee classifies flower fairs into 4 categories -- A1, A2, B1, and B2 -- based on country's capability and experience in hosting events.

Taiwan joined the AIPH in 2004, and was awarded the right to host the show in 2007, said Hsiung-Wen Chen, the commissioner of Taipei City's Department of Economic Development, the organizer of the fair. He said the Taipei fair is classified as an A2/B1 event and will run for 171 days from November 2010 to April 2011,
"The AIPH will evaluate the overall performance of the organizer and decide if Taiwan should be qualified to hold an Al event, " Chen said.

In recent years countries like Germany, Belgium, Canada have organized flower fairs certificated by the AIPH, and each saw revenues that amounted to 270 percent to 400 percent of their overall investment, according to a report filed by the International Bureau of Exhibition, a Paris-based organization that monitors international exhibitions.

DOC.HEADLINE: General Scholastic Ability Test begins with Chinese exam

TEXT.P: The two-day General Scholastic Ability Test (GSAT) for more than 150,000 college-bound seniors began Friday with the Chinese exam, College Entrance Examination Center (CECC) spokeswoman Hung Tung-kui said.
Hung said 2,490 of the 150,014 students enrolled for the test did not show up for the Chinese exam, an absentee rate of 1.66 percent.
The Chinese exam included some trendy questions, taking materials from the movie "Lust, Caution" directed by Taiwanese director Ang Lee, and comic books, as well as lines from several pop songs.

Hung also said that four examinees -- National Taiwan University freshmen who took the Chinese exam at the invitation of the center, said the exam's difficulty ranged from median to high, and that students were able to get good grades if the questions were answered carefully.
Held once a year, the GSAT is the first college entrance examination students can take and serves as the primary measuring stick for admission into colleges or universities in Taiwan.
Students who are not satisfied with their GSAT results can enroll in a second test, the Department Required Test, which is usually held in July.
The CECC arranged 30 exam locations this year for examinees, who included 185 students with physical disabilities, Hung said.
The Chinese exam was followed by mathematics and social sciences, with absenteee rates of 1.7 percent and 1.73 percent, respectively, Hung said.

According to those who took the tests, most questions on the mathematics exam tested basic concepts, with some problems dealing with complex ideas, and students had to think carefully before giving their answers on social sciences in order to get good grades, Hung said.
Other subjects to be tested Saturday are English and natural sciences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of paintings by contemporary masters to open in Matsu

TEXT.P: An exhibition of paintings and calligraphic works by big-name contemporary Chinese artists is to open Feb. 2 at the Matsu Folklore Culture Museum and will run until March 2.
The exhibition, the most important ever hosted on the outlying island, is titled "Glory on the Voluminous Sea." Altogether 65 masterpieces -- insured for NT$40 million -- will be on display.
The event is jointly sponsored by the National Museum of History in Taipei, the Matsu County government, and seven private organizations.

The works in the exhibition were all painted by noted contemporary master artists, including Chi Pai-shih (1863V1957), known for the often playful style of his watercolor works, and Chang Da-chien (1899-1983), who created a whole new style of modern Chinese painting in his later years by combining a unique splashed-ink technique with the masterly texture strokes of his early years.

Also on display are works by Hsu Pei-hung (1895-1953) , who combined Chinese brush and ink techniques with Western realism and was particularly famous for his dynamic paintings of horses, and by Fu Pao-shih (1904-1965), whose landscape paintings employed skillful use of dots and inking methods, and traditional Chinese water-and-ink artist Huang Chun-pi (1898-1991).

Other famed artists featured at the exhibition are Wu Chang-shou (1844-1927), renowned for his paintings of bamboos, pine trees, plum blossoms and chrysanthemum; Lin Feng-mian (1900-1991) , who combined the essence of Occidental art with that of traditional Chinese art; and ink painter Chiang Chao-shen (1925-1996) , who was noted for his excellence in Chinese ink painting, calligraphy, poetry and the carving of seals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker willing to contribute to cross-strait exchanges

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday he is willing to contribute to cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges if the newly elected president feels there is a need.
Wang contended that the interests of Taiwan's people lie in reaching out to enhance cross-strait exchanges and reconciliation so the country can continue to thrive in a globalizing world.
He said there is a team in the legislature dealing with cross-strait affairs, with him serving as a convener, that can help fulfill this mission.

"After the March 22 presidential election, if the new president feels the need, the legislature and I are willing to work according to his wishes to contribute to cross-strait rehabilitation and exchanges, " he said.

Speaking at a news conference after his swearing-in ceremony, Wang also said that he will respect the views of the minority party and preside over the legislature with impartiality, even if the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has an absolute majority in the body with 81 seats while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has only 27.
He said many people have harbored high expectations of the new legislature, and vowed to push for a spate of "sunshine" bills so as not to let down the public.
The efficiency of the legislature and the quality of the bills should also be upgraded, and the functions of the disciplinary committee strengthened, Wang said.

He also said that the eight committees in the legislature should enhance their ability to review bills and budgets and reduce the need for "closed-door" coordination that has created misgivings among the public.
Wang expected a live broadcasting system for legislative proceedings should also be ready at an early date.

In view of a legislative committee entrusted with the investigation of the controversial shooting on the eve of the March 20, 2004 presidential election that made few inroads into the case, Wang expressed the wish to push for the institutionalization of the investigative rights of the legislature.
He stressed that the Council of Grand Justices have ruled that the legislature should have investigative rights to effectively exercise its legislative power under the Constitution.

The March 19 shooting has been widely regarded as having polarized Taiwan's people, with the KMT accusing President Chen Shui-bian, who won the election by a razor-thin margin, of staging the shooting to win sympathy votes. The KMT has not been able to provide substantive evidence to support its claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expects strong development of sports industry

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the Sports Affairs Council's (SAC) move to Kaohsiung will lead to a marked improvement in the output value of Taiwan's sports industry and the upgrading of its sports capabilities.

Chen also indicated that the government will evaluate the performance of the relocated council, and continue to promote the relocation of other government organizations to bring more balanced development between northern and southern Taiwan.

The president made the remarks while presiding over the inauguration ceremony of the relocated SAC, which was moved from Taipei City to the National Sports Training Center in the Zuoying District of Kaohsiung City.

The inauguration will be followed by the first group of approximately 30 SAC employees moving into their new offices after the Chinese New Year holidays. Other staff members will complete the move by Sept. 1.

The government hopes the move will improve the training of Taiwan's top athletes ahead of the 2008 Olympic Games and the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and help integrate the selection, training, counseling, and competitive programs of the country's top athletes.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate launches new book on 'blessed state'

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , published a new book Friday that highlighted his concept of turning Taiwan into a "blessed state."

Hsieh introduced the book to the public at his campaign headquarters, with representatives from cultural and academic circles taking part, including Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih and Lee Min-yung, a well-known poet.

In his book, Hsieh argues that Taiwan and China should join together to iron out an approach that works for both sides to resolve their rifts over Taiwan's sovereignty, instead of resorting to the controversial "1992 consensus" as the Kuomintang (KMT) has suggested.

The "1992 consensus" refers to a supposed verbal agreement reached by officials from the two sides in Hong Kong in 1992 accepting the idea of "one China" with different interpretations as a formula to overcome sovereignty disputes.

According to Hsieh's book, Taiwan and China should first seek a method accepted to both sides to break their decades-old political impasse by stepping up communications and understanding in a peacemeal fashion, as there is no "imminent" need to achieve the aim in a short period of time.
In addition, procedures should be observed by the two sides in seeking a way out of their existing estrangement.
"The willingness of Taiwan's people must be taken into account and fully respected if both sides were to work on a procedural consensus, " he stressed.
In terms of cross-Taiwan Strait trade and economic relations, Hsieh contended that a balance must be maintained between Taiwan's national sovereignty and business competitiveness.

Hsieh wrote that in light of continued flows of Taiwanese investment to China, he favors broader economic exchanges across the strait, including permitting Taiwan-based banks to open branches of affiliates in China and in turn allowing Chinese banks to set up offices in Taiwan, as the first step toward a greater opening.

The DPP presidential candidate also broached his ideas of authorizing multiple point-to-point direct charter flights across the Taiwan Strait and permitting up to 3,000 Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan per day -- an increase over his and the Democratic Progressive Party's government current position of allowing 1,000 visitors per day.

He also proposed a string of measures to prop up Taiwan's economy and take care of youth and the underprivileged, such as lowering Taiwan's inheritance tax rate to 10 percent and building cheaper housing for young adults.
Hsieh will face KMT rival Ma Ying-jeou in the March 22 presidential election.
Ma has focused his campaign theme on economic issues and put forward several major economic policies aimed at improving the people's livelihood and reinvigorating the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative session to open Feb. 22

TEXT.P: The ruling and the opposition lawmakers decided after consultations Friday that the first session of the new legislature will be held Feb. 22 with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung delivering an administrative report and accepting questions from legislators.
The legislators did not decide, however, on when to go into recess prior to the March 22 presidential election. The matter will be left for discussion after the session opens.

On the live broadcasting of legislative proceedings in a bid to make the operations of the lawmaking body more transparent, the lawmakers decided to send a team to observe the operations of parliamentary bodies in other nations.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said in the consultations that legislator Daniel Hwang of the main opposition Kuomintang and others are interested in traveling to the United States and Japan to understand the live broadcasting systems used in those countries, according to participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three Kaohsiung city government officials indicted for vote buying

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Public Prosecutors Office indicted three Kaohsiung city government officials and 18 other individuals Friday on charges of vote buying in an attempt to help a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator get re- elected in the Jan. 12 elections.

The prosecutors are seeking a 14-year sentence for Hsiao Yu-cheng, director of the Kaohsiung City government's Bureau of Environmental Protection, plus stripping his civil rights for 10 years after serving the sentence.

Also indicted were Shih Tao-kun, an inspector of the Environmental Protection Bureau, and Wang Kuo-chuan, a sanitation squad leader. The prosecutors are seeking 13 years and six and a half years in prison for them, respectively.

Hsiao was detained Nov. 24 last year and held for more than one month for alleged vote-buying activities. The prosecutors charged that he had spent NT$14,400 of his office funds to treat 17 of his subordinates -- mostly heads of street cleaning squads in the Sanmin District -- to a dinner in a restaurant in November, asking them to vote for DPP Legislator Lee Kun-tse, a candidate in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
Hsiao insisted he was innocent, saying that he was merely entertaining the sanitation workers in appreciation of their efforts in helping the city to bring a dengue fever outbreak under control.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu declined to comment on the prosecution of the three city government officials, saying that she needed to read the indictment first.
Hsiao served as spokesman for Chen's election campaign office before she won the Dec. 9, 2006 Kaohsiung mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dates set for TV platform presentations for presidential candidates

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Friday that there will be four live TV platform presentations for the presidential and vice presidential candidates starting at the end of this month.

CEC officials said the first of three platform presentations for the presidential candidates -- Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- will be held Feb. 29.

The second one will be held March 7, while the third one will be for the two vice presidential candidates -- DPP's Su Tseng-chang and KMT's Vincent Siew -- on March 7, and the fourth will be held March 14 for Hsieh and Ma again.

Meanwhile, the CEC announced Friday that two referendums -- one initiated by the DPP to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan and the other initiated by the KMT on returning to the world body under the nation's official name, the Republic of China, or any other practical name -- will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.

The format of distributing the ballots for the presidential elections and referendums will be patterned after the Jan. 12 legislative elections, meaning that the ballots for the presidential election and the referendums will be distributed at tables set apart but will then be cast in separate boxes at the same time.
The CEC will also sponsor five presentations or debates for the referendums, which will be held Feb. 27, March 1, 2, 5 and 8, respectively.

CEC officials said that the leader of the DPP-initiated referendum will represent the side arguing in favor of its referendum, while the Legislative Yuan or the Executive Yuan will represent the opposite view.
Those who are interested in becoming representatives of the side opposed to the referendum should apply to the CEC before Feb. 14. If not, there will only be presentations and no debates.
