DOC.HEADLINE: New private investment surpasses target: MOEA

TEXT.P: New private investment projects launced in 2007 amounted to NT$1.11 trillion (US$343.65 billion), exceeding the projected target of NT$1.0065 trillion, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Friday.
Chen predicted that private investment is expected to reach NT$1.08 trillion this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 2, or the 26th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is founded by Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoz.
1556: An earthquake rocks the provinces of Shensi, Henan and Shansi in mainland China, killing an estimated 830,000 people.
1665: A British fleet captures New Amsterdam, the center of the Dutch colony in North America and the flourishing trading settlement on the island of Manhattan, renaming it New York in honor of the Duke of York.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the U.S.-Mexico War, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1878: Greece declares war on Turkey.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central Station, is formally opened.
1915: Germany begins U-boat blockades of British waters, while the United States warns Germany against attacking American ships.
1926: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, French president from 1974 to 1981, is born.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan Zoo is opened.
1953: The U.S. government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in their raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along the mainland coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1967: Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle is elected president of Nicaragua.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-U.S. flight services with its inaugural flight, by a Boeing 707, to San Francisco.
1970: British philosopher and Nobel Prize-winner Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1972: Protesters in Dublin burn down the British Embassy in an act of revenge for the "Bloody Sunday" shooting in Londonderry the previous weekend in which British troops killed 13 Catholic youths and wounded another 17.
1975: Gen. Gamad Shumaimari, chief of the general staff of the armed forces of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1986: Oscar Arias Sanchez is elected president of Costa Rica.
1989: A coup in Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled the South American country for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine- year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: Rafael Caldera is sworn in as president of Venezuela.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which were suspended for 21 years.
1998: A Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 crashes into a mountainside 65 kilometers northeast of Cagayan de Oro airport in the Philippines, killing all 104 people on board.
2000: The U.S. House of Representatives passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, a bill aimed at strengthening military ties with Taiwan, despite warnings from Beijing and the White House.
2001: Exiled mainland Chinese-born Nobel laureate writer Gao Xingjiang meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
2003: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian offers condolences over the loss of space shuttle Columbia and the seven astronauts aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there were a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to pursue it. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Democrats save barbs for the GOP.
The debate, sponsored by The Times, CNN and Politico and held at the Kodak Theatre in Hollwood, was the first one-on-one meeting between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama . It was also the last before Democrats in 22 states, including California, vote Tuesday. Unlike their most recent session in South Carolina--replete with mudslinging and insults-- Thursday's debate played out as if they were two talk show guests trading jokes as they worked around the edges of a number of domestic policies. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

Condemned trio sent to the gallows

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , published a new book Friday that highlighted his concept of turning Taiwan into a "blessed state."

Hsieh introduced the book to the public at his campaign headquarters, with representatives from cultural and academic circles taking part, including Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih and Lee Min-yung, a well-known poet.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expects strong development of sports industry

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the Sports Affairs Council's (SAC) move to Kaohsiung will lead to a marked improvement in the output value of Taiwan's sports industry and the upgrading of its sports capabilities.

Chen also indicated that the government will evaluate the performance of the relocated council, and continue to promote the relocation of other government organizations to bring more balanced development between northern and southern Taiwan.

The president made the remarks while presiding over the inauguration ceremony of the relocated SAC, which was moved from Taipei City to the National Sports Training Center in the Zuoying District of Kaohsiung City.

The inauguration will be followed by the first group of approximately 30 SAC employees moving into their new offices after the Chinese New Year holidays. Other staff members will complete the move by Sept. 1.

The government hopes the move will improve the training of Taiwan's top athletes ahead of the 2008 Olympic Games and the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and help integrate the selection, training, counseling, and competitive programs of the country's top athletes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker willing to contribute to cross-strait exchanges

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday he is willing to contribute to cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges if the newly elected president feels there is a need.
Wang contended that the interests of Taiwan's people lie in reaching out to enhance cross-strait exchanges and reconciliation so the country can continue to thrive in a globalizing world.
He said there is a team in the legislature dealing with cross-strait affairs, with him serving as a convener, that can help fulfill this mission.

"After the March 22 presidential election, if the new president feels the need, the legislature and I are willing to work according to his wishes to contribute to cross-strait rehabilitation and exchanges, " he said.

Speaking at a news conference after his swearing-in ceremony, Wang also said that he will respect the views of the minority party and preside over the legislature with impartiality, even if the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has an absolute majority in the body with 81 seats while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has only 27.
He said many people have harbored high expectations of the new legislature, and vowed to push for a spate of "sunshine" bills so as not to let down the public.
The efficiency of the legislature and the quality of the bills should also be upgraded, and the functions of the disciplinary committee strengthened, Wang said.

He also said that the eight committees in the legislature should enhance their ability to review bills and budgets and reduce the need for "closed-door" coordination that has created misgivings among the public.
Wang expected a live broadcasting system for legislative proceedings should also be ready at an early date.

In view of a legislative committee entrusted with the investigation of the controversial shooting on the eve of the March 20, 2004 presidential election that made few inroads into the case, Wang expressed the wish to push for the institutionalization of the investigative rights of the legislature.
He stressed that the Council of Grand Justices have ruled that the legislature should have investigative rights to effectively exercise its legislative power under the Constitution.

The March 19 shooting has been widely regarded as having polarized Taiwan's people, with the KMT accusing President Chen Shui-bian, who won the election by a razor-thin margin, of staging the shooting to win sympathy votes. The KMT has not been able to provide substantive evidence to support its claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's Internet users total 14.76 million: III

TEXT.P: The number of Internet users in Taiwan reached 14.76 million in 2007, an increase of 1.7 percent over the year-earlier level, the Institute for Information Industry (III) estimated Saturday.

The estimate was based on a survey conducted last August by the institute's Foreseeing Innovative New Digiservices, which revealed that 64.4 percent of individuals in Taiwan have access to the Internet, up 0.6 percentage points from the previous year.

Internet use is more common among residents in northern Taiwan than in other parts of the country, with 66 percent of northern Taiwan residents and 73.6 percent of those in Taipei City being Internet users, the survey results show.

Home was mentioned by 88.2 percent of users as where they usually use the Internet, compared with offices by 33.7 percent of users and schools or research institutes by 25.5 percent of users. Less than 16 percent of users said they use Internet cafes or other public establishments for surfing the Web.

Respondents who had used the Internet at home during the month before the survey was conducted went online on 21.8 days of the month on average, with each spending an average of 16 hours online per week.

Classifying home Internet users according the amount of time they spend online, 43 percent are defined as heavy users who are online more than two hours per day and 31.9 percent are light users who are online no more than one hour per day.
The survey, carried out last Aug. 4-23, was part of a study on the status of broadband, mobile and wireless use among Taiwan households in 2007. A total of 2,751 households responded to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers cautioned against bird flu outbreaks overseas

TEXT.P: The Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) cautioned travelers planning to visit Britain, Saudi Arabia, Poland, South Korea and Benin in the near future to pay attention to bird flu outbreaks in these countries.
Travelers should avoid contact with birds or poultry and should take care to avoid eating undercooked poultry while in these countries to protect their health, CPC officials said.

Citing a recent notice passed on by Taiwan's representative office in the United Kingdom, the officials pointed out that three wild swans recently found dead on Chesil Beach in Dorset, southern England have been confirmed to have been infected with the virulent H5N1 bird flu virus.

In South Korea, an outbreak of the less virulent H7N3 bird flu virus was reported last December, they went on, adding that bird flu outbreaks have also been reported in Saudi Arabia, Poland and Benin recently.

These five countries are not listed by Taiwan as non-infected areas of the highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu virus, and Taiwan has not imported any live poultry or poultry meat from these areas, the officials said.

: The Straits Times: 10-year plan to give workers high-quality training.
Singapore has drawn up a masterplan to train workers for the next 10 years so that they will keep pace with economic change.

Singapore government will promote the Continuing Education and Training Plan for local workers to encourage workers to have lifelong learning and into their normal life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Book fair held at Huashan Culture Park

TEXT.P: A book fair opened at Taipei's Huashan Culture Park Saturday as a prelude to the annual Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) slated for Feb. 13-18, according to the fair's organizer, the Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF).

The two-day "Book Fair at Huashan" fair, the first TIBE activity of this kind since the exhibition was born in 1987, introduces a "publishing carnival" to the park for art and leisure activities, the TBFF said in a news release.
The foundation hopes visitors will feel "the joy of meeting books everywhere" at the fair, the news release said.

The fair is decorated with installation art created by nearly 20 local artists that features the fun of travel and includes an exhibition of picture books and a colorful market selling posters, paintings and hand-made artworks related to books.
There is also a series of workshops giving handicraft lessons such as making puppet gloves, lanterns and paper photo frames.
The 2008 TIBE will be held at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum not an attempt to `swindle votes': DPP whip

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin said Saturday that the decision to hold the U.N.-bid referendum in tandem with the March 22 presidential election is meant to save administrative costs and is not an attempt to "swindle votes."

Yeh made the comments in response to main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun's accusation the day before that the DPP is aiming to garner more votes for its presidential candidate, Frank Hsieh, by moving to hold the referendum and presidential election simultaneously.

The Central Election Commission announced Friday that two referendums -- one initiated by the DPP on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan and the other initiated by the KMT on using the name Republic of China when applying to return to the world body -- will be held alongside the presidential poll.

In response, Kuo said the KMT is mapping out countermeasures to the move to hold the referendums and presidential poll together and that the party will make a final decision on the matter before the first session of the new legislature opens Feb. 22.

Speaking to reporters Saturday, Yeh said that although the KMT has an overwhelming majority in the new legislature which gives it the power "to do whatever it wants, " she hopes the party will remember that Taiwan gaining entry into the United Nations is the desire of the people.
Yeh said the KMT should "respect the will of the people " and expressed the hope that the party will not move to oppose the referendum.

In January, the KMT launched a boycott of the two referendums -- one launched by itself on giving the legislature the power to investigate government corruption and the other initiated by the DPP on recovering the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets -- that were held in tandem with the legislative elections. Both referendums were a resounding failure, with only a quarter of the voters even bothering to participate.
Yeh said that holding the U.N. bid referendum alongside the presidential election is not the key issue.
"The key issue is that Taiwan entering the United Nations is the will of the majority of the public, " she said, adding that the KMT should think twice before opposing the referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Guest House to hold year's first open house Feb. 3

TEXT.P: The year's first open house of the Taipei Guest House is scheduled for Feb. 3, Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials said Saturday.
Visitors can make appointments to visit online through the ministry's Web site at www.mofa.gov.tw or register on-site, the officials said.

The building will be open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and visitors will be divided into seven groups and allowed entry in turns to avoid overcrowding, they said, warning visitors not to take photos or enter areas not open to the public.
Visitors are also advised to use public transport to travel to the Guest House, they said.
The magnificent Baroque-style mansion located near the Presidential Office was built by the Japanese colonial government in 1901 as the official residence of then-Taiwan Governor Kodama Gentaro.
After Japan surrendered Taiwan at the end of World War II in 1945, the mansion was renamed the Taipei Guest House and used by the MOFA for receiving foreign dignities and other state activities.

The building, which was designated a historical monument by the Ministry of the Interior in 1998, served as the venue for President Chen Shui-bian's 2000 inaugural reception, as well as his meetings with former U.S. President Bill Clinton, former South Korean President Kim Young Sam and former Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Kuan-yew.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT against `hijacking elections with referendums': chairman

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung expressed regret Saturday over the Central Election Commission's (CEC's) decision the day before to hold two U.N. bid referendums in tandem with the March 22 presidential election.
Speaking with reporters after meeting with KMT youth volunteers at the Legislative Yuan, Wu said the KMT "is not opposed to referendums, but rather to hijacking elections with referendums."

On Friday, the CEC announced that the two referendums -- one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name Taiwan and the other launched by the KMT on the Republic of China applying to return to the world body under its official title -- will be held alongside the presidential poll.
During a rare meeting with Chen in January, Wu recalled that he had reminded Chen of the importance of the CEC remaining an impartial body.

He further expressed the hope that Chen will make personnel changes at the CEC to achieve this goal, saying the commission "should not be run as an organization that is controlled by a particular party."
"Unfortunately, I have still not received a response from the president on this matter," he added.

As to whether the KMT will move to boycott the referendums in response to the CEC's decision as it did with the two referendums held alongside the legislative elections Jan. 12, Wu said this depends on how the situation unfolds, adding that the KMT headquarters had yet to make a final decision on the matter.

In the legislative polls, the KMT called for voters not to cast ballots in the two accompanying referendums -- one launched by itself on giving the legislature the power to investigate government corruption, and the other initiated by the DPP on retrieving the KMT's "ill-gotten" assets.

Earlier Saturday, KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun said the party is mapping out countermeasures to the CEC's move to hold the referendums and presidential poll together and it will make a final decision on the matter before the first session of the new legislature opens Feb. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's petrochemical exports to China given boost: BOFT

TEXT.P: A recent Chinese tax reduction on ethanolamine products might help Taiwanese petrochemical exports to China outplay foreign competitors in the red-hot Chinese market, a senior official of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday.

China cut an anti-dumping tax imposed on ethanolamine imports from Taiwanese petrochemical manufacturer Oriental Union Chemical Co. to 5.3 percent from 20 percent, according to a Jan. 31 announcement issued by China's Ministry of Commerce (MOC).

Oriental Union Chemical filed an appeal with the MOC in 2006 pleading for a reversal of the ministry's previous decision to impose a 20 percent anti-dumping tax on the company. After a year of investigation, the Chinese ministry decided that the company showed no trade dumping inclinations and thus awarded a massive tax reversal in its favor.
Describing the ruling as an opportunity, BOFT Deputy Director-General Wu Hsin- hua called for more Taiwan companies to ask the MOC to reduce its anti-dumping tax rates.

From 2004, China has imposed heavy anti-dumping taxes on ethanolamine products imported from foreign countries, such as Japan, the United States and Taiwan, with tax rates ranging from 20 percent to 74 percent, to prevent foreign products monopolizing the market and boost burgeoning Chinese petrochemical companies.
Japan's Nippon Shokubai Co. was also given a tax reduction on its ethanolamine products, down to 7.3 percent from its previous 74 percent, according to the same Chinese statement.

Taiwan's petrochemical industry is facing raw material shortages because of soaring global oil prices and a number of manufacturers have begun to develop value-added product lines such as ethanolamine manufacturers that focus on pesticides and pharmaceutical products to diversify their investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shihlin community sports center inaugurated

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin cut a ribbon Saturday along with his predecessor Ma Ying-jeou, the opposition Kuomintang's presidential candidate, to inaugurate a sports center in the Shihlin district of Taipei.
At the ceremony, Hau urged citizens to take advantage of the premium modern facilities at the brand-new community sports center -- the sixth of its kind built and operated by the city government.

An avid jogger, Ma, who served as Taipei mayor from 1998-2006, said he took measures during his mayoral tenure to encourage citizens to take physical exercise as a way to keep healthy, which included building community sports centers.

He also instructed more than 130 public schools with outdoor playgrounds to be opened to the public as exercise areas and outlined a policy aimed at equipping every district of the city with a community sports center.
Taipei now has six such facilities and in the next year, the Xinyi and Neihu districts will each also get their own sports centers, Ma said.
Touting the facilities in the Zhongshan, Zhongcheng, Beitou, Nankang, Wanhua and Shihlin districts, Hau described the charge for using the facilities as cheap.
Citing the Shihlin Sports Center as an example, Hau said users of the center's modern swimming pool have to pay just NT$110 for entry.

In addition to the pool, the center, built in a 10-floor building with two underground floors serving as parking places, is also equipped with facilities for archery, shooting and golf, the mayor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese film awarded at Rotterdam film Festival

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese film titled "What on Earth Have IDone Wrong? " has beatten out almost 80 movies from Asia to receive the Network for the Promotion of Asian Cinema (NETPAC) Award at the 37th Rotterdam International Film Festival, movie industry sources said Saturday.
Director Niu Chengze, who also wrote the screenplay and took the lead role in the film, accepted the award in person at the presentation ceremony Friday, the sources said.
Extending his appreciation to those involved in the production, Niu was quoted as having said at the ceremony that he was sharing the award with all his friends in Taiwan's film industry.

"Their enthusiasm for the film really helped open a window for Taiwan's film industry, " Niu said, adding his hope that people will exert more efforts to make Taiwan's film industry a shining star internationally.

Reflecting the difficulties one may encounter in life and discussing Taiwanese people's social and political lives in ironic and humorous ways, and focusing on the importance of honesty in relationships, "What on Earth Have I Done Wrong? "stole the limelight at the festival premier.
Niu is scheduled to return to Taiwan Feb. 5, while the film is slated to be screened in Taiwan from April 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most unaware of economic policies of presidential candidates: poll

TEXT.P: Although improving the economy is one of the main themes of the March 22 presidential election, a great majority of the electorate are unaware of the economic policies of the two presidential candidates, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

Taiwan Thinktank, which conducted the survey, said that 72.9 percent of the respondents said they do not know about the economic vision for Taiwan held by Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, when he "advocated a thriving economy."

Meanwhile, up to 91.8 percent of the respondents said they have no idea about the economic policies of Ma Ying-jeou, the presidential candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang, other than that he advocates a further opening of cross- Taiwan Strait trade.
Taiwan Thinktank conducted the survey Jan. 24-25 among eligible voters. A total of 1,087 effective samples were collected with a margin of error of 3.2 percentage points.

Asked if direct postal, trade and transportation links -- commonly known as the three links -- between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are pivotal to promoting cross-strait economic development, 50 percent said they are, while 35.7 percent said they are not.

On whether a further opening of cross-strait relations will bring about substantive assistance to their personal economic situations, 31.3 percent of the respondents answered in the affirmative, compared with 54.8 percent who did not.

Hsieh's advocacy of "mitigating the burden on youth by helping them buy houses, including building public housing complexes for young people" received 71 percent support from those polled, compared with 15.8 percent who disapproved.

His proposal of "normalizing cross-strait charter flights to avoid disputes over whether they are domestic or international routes" received support of 57.9 percent of the respondents, compared with 18 percent who expressed opposition to the suggestion.
At present, charter flights across the Taiwan Strait are launched for four holiday period -- Chinese New Year, Tombsweeping Day, the Dragon Boat Festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival.

Asked whose economic policies -- Hsieh's or Ma's -- will best advance the wellbeing of the Taiwanese, 29.8 percent said Hsieh's are better, while 30.2 percent said Ma's are more acceptable, while 40 percent refused to comment.

Asked about their attitude if Taiwan cooperates with China and sees an economic turnaround, but has to accept Beijing's "one China" principle like Hong Kong has done, 60.7 percent said they would be opposed to such an approach, compared with 24.4 percent who said they would be in favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese New Year a rarity for many migrant workers in Taiwan

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter
Taipei, Feb. 2 (CAN) In Chinese societies, the most important festival is the Lunar New Year, when families reunite in a holiday atmosphere.
Many migrant workers in Taiwan, however, do not have the luxury of a holiday.

Lunar New Year's day falls this year on Feb. 7 and most people have six days off, although many workers from Southeast Asia will see their workloads increased, particularly the 160,000 domestic workers and caregivers who make up almost half of the 360,000 foreign laborers in Taiwan.

Such is the case for Mary, a young Indonesian who came to Taiwan one-and-a-half years ago. Working as a domestic helper, she starts her day at 6 a.m. by preparing breakfast, then goes to market, cleans the house and takes out the garbage. She doesn't get to call it a day until after 11 p.m. Ostensibly hired to take care of an elderly member of her bosses family, in reality that is only a small portion of her strenuous workload.
Asked if she is allowed any days off, Mary said her employer deducts her daily wage of about NT$500 if she takes any time off, so she usually takes only two days off per month.
Chinese New Year is not a holiday for her. On the contrary, as family members of her employer get together for the traditional reunion, she will have an even heavier workload.
"What can I do? I came here to make money. Others (her compatriots) are in the same situation," Mary said resignedly, adding that a year-end bonus of just NT$5,000 is her only consolation.

Another Indonesian, Tina, came to Taiwan also to look after an old stroke victim. Every night she has to turn the old person's body to prevent bedsores and do regular medical checks every 90 minutes, so she has hardly had any normal sleep in the past three years, not to mention the housework she must do in the daytime. However, she still believes she made the right decision to come to work in Taiwan, saying that "it's easier to earn money here."

Another girl from the Philippines who has taken care of an old person in Taiwan for more than two years without a break, received this year a red envelope containing a bonus of NT$10,000. But she confessed that she would prefer some days off instead.

Not all the guest workers have the luck to be hired by a generous or wealthy employer. Another Filipina, who requested anonymity, has just finished her three-year contract taking care of a sick elderly person and received a bonus of a paltry NT$300. Asked why she does not want to renew her contract, she laughed: "I don't want to come back anymore! I really need a rest."

"Migrant caregivers are not covered by the Labor Standards Law, " a social worker of the Taiwan International Workers' Association (TIWA) noted, adding that "the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) has promised to apply the law to these workers in two years, but as the CLA personnel have changed several times in recent years, we are not sure if the promise will be kept."

Last December, TIWA organized the third "I Want Days Off" demonstration with the participation of 1,600 demonstrators, to express their frustration and anger at not being protected by the Labor Standards Law.

While it is true that not all Southeast Asian people celebrate Chinese New Year, migrant workers are also deprived of vacations on other occasions as well, such as Christmas for Catholics from the Philippines, Songkran for Thai and Cambodian people, and Al Hijra for Indonesian Muslims.
As people in Taiwan celebrate Chinese New Year, a little care or love for their foreign workers might make their celebrations more significant.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged to delete personal data in discarded mobile phones

TEXT.P: People should be sure to delete their personal data before recycling old mobile phones or optical discs, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) officials said Saturday.
The step is crucial to protecting their privacy and ensuring the information stored in the devices is not misused by criminals, the officials said.
The EPA officially listed mobile phones and optical discs as recyclable in April 2006.

By the end of 2007, approximately 2.04 million mobile phones with a total weight of 310,000 metric tons were discarded by the public for recycling, while the number of waste optical discs for recycling amounted to 67 million units with a total weight of 1.11 million metric tons, EPA tallies show.
According to the EPA, in addition to the plastic covers, mobile phone parts made of metals such as copper, gold, silver and palladium can also be reused.

However, as harmful materials such as lead, cadmium and arsenic can also be found in mobile phones, they can pollute the environment and threaten human health if they are dumped in landfills or incinerated, EPA officials said.
Optical discs are mainly made of polycarbonate and plated with precious metals such as gold and silver, which can all be reused, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Year's first festival charter flight from Beijing arrives

TEXT.P: The first direct charter flight between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait for this year's Chinese New Year holiday landed at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday, carrying 141 Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, along with their families.
The flight from Beijing was offered by China's Hainan Airlines to bring Taiwanese people home for the Feb. 6-11 holiday.
Several hours later, a similar holiday charter flight from Shanghai to Taipei arrived, delayed by an hour because of heavy snow at the Shanghai airport.

Gao Ling-feng, a pop singer who was on the flight, said recent snowstorms have caused severe damage in southern China and the Yangtze River Basin. Power systems and road traffic were mostly cut in those regions, he said, noting that it took him a lot of effort to board a train from Nanjing to Shanghai to catch the flight.
"Many Taiwanese entertainers are still trapped in China, " he added.

The cross-strait charter flight services are being operated by 12 carriers from the two sides offering a total of 93 flights during the holiday period that will end Feb. 12, according to a consensus reached among airline operators on both sides of the strait.
Chinese New Year's Day falls on Feb. 7 this year.

Direct flights between Taiwan and China are prohibited due to the two sides' political differences, except on major holidays such as Chinese New Year when they provide ease of travel for many of the more than 1 million Taiwanese citizens living in China, many of whom wish to spend the holiday in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taoyuan County most physically challenged-friendly area in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County and Kaohsiung City are among the most physically challenged- friendly areas in Taiwan in terms of public infrastructure and facilities, according to the results of a study released Saturday by the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
The agency launched a project last summer aimed at creating an obstacle-free environment for physically disabled citizens islandwide.

As part of the project, the agency formed a task force made up of experts and members of several organizations, including the Eden Social Welfare Association, the Republic of China League of Welfare Associations for the Disabled, the National Association of Architects, ROC and the MOI's Architecture and Building Research Institute.
The task force dispatched personnel to each of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties to conduct the survey between Aug. 20 and Sept. 7.

Agency officials said that because of differences in terms of scale of resources and stage of development, the various regions of Taiwan were divided into three categories -- metropolises, townships and villages, and remote areas and outlying islands -- for the purposes of the study
In the metropolises category, Taoyuan County, Kaohsiung City and Taipei City were rated the three most physically challenged-friendly places, in that order.

In the townships and villages category, Kaohsiung County, Taichung County and Yilan County finished in the top three spots, while in the remote areas and outlying islands category, Lianchang County was rated the most physically challenged-friendly place, followed by Kinmen Island and Penghu County.

In the survey, two areas were found to not be up to par in terms of adequate public facilities catering to the needs of the physically challenged. Both were in the township and villages category -- Yunlin County, which received a lowly score of 47.33 out of a possible 100, and Hsinchu County, which received a score of 58.17.

Agency officials said the results of the study will be sent to the Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics for reference in making adjustments to fund allocations to various government programs aimed at creating an obstacle-free environment for Taiwan's physically challenged citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Thousands flood Taipei's Dihua Street

TEXT.P: Thousands of people packed shoulder to shoulder into Taipei City's Dihua Street to attend a food festival Friday just before the last weekend prior to the Lunar New Year.

The festival, now in its 10th year, is being organized by the Taipei city government for the first time this year in several areas of the city to offer the public alternative locations to buy traditional food for the Lunar New Year holiday, which starts Feb. 6 this year.
Traditionally, local residents would store food supplies for the Lunar New Year holiday, as most stores, restaurants and markets used to close for the holiday period.
Today, local residents do not really need to store food because they can easily purchase fresh or frozen meals from convenience stores, which never close.
The festival began Jan. 18 and will run through Feb. 5.

Last years event attracted at least 700,000 visitors from home and abroad keen to take part in the frenzied and colorful atmosphere of shopping for treats and delicacies for the holiday, things such as dumplings, peanuts, grilled sausages, dried shredded squid, stir fried chestnuts and sticky milk candies, many of which are handed out in the form of free samples by vendors eager to get one up on the competition.
To quench their thirst, visitors to the festival also find themselves with a wide range of choices from sweet grape wine, cold sugarcane juice, hot ginger herbal tea, starfruit juice and coffee.

Taiwan Post Co. and President Transnet Corp., which manages the Japanese fast- delivery service Takkyubin in Taiwan, has also set up stands to help visitors who want to deliver newly purchased goods to their homes or those of their families and friends.
An absence of English signs at the street apparently did not stop some foreigners from getting a taste of Taiwanese life.
Dmitri Detwyler, a 28-year-old who working as an English teacher, was spotted among a few foreign visitors to the street that day.

Describing the festival ascrowded and noisy, Detwyler said it is particularly special in that it sells mostly food, rather than the clothes and bags that usually feature at other night markets in Taiwan.
Asked if he would recommend the festival market to other foreign visitors to Taiwan, Detwyler, clutching a plastic bag of dried fruit and crackers, replied:Sure, if they love to eat.

Bill Gates, the worlds richest man, yesterday went to war with Google, the most powerful company on the web, over the future of the internet.

Italian Senate Speaker Franco Marini urged former premier Silvio Berlusconi, who is also leader of the largest opposition party Forza Italia, to listen to the voice of the society and to accept a revision to the electoral law.

Four years after President Bush called for Americans to return to the moon and then voyage on to Mars, NASA is spending hundreds of millions of dollars to design, build and test the spacecraft that would make it possible.

The White House, responding to what it considers rumors being spread by MoveOn.org, liberal blogs such as DailyKos.com and Democratic lawmakers, this week tried to persuade key lawmakers that President Bush is not attempting to bind his successor to a long-term military presence in Iraq.

Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft and a global philanthropist, called upon fellow business leaders at the World Economic Forum last week to pursue a kinder form of capitalism.

The battle for supremacy in the Internet era is entering a tumultuous new phase.
Microsoft Corp. placed a bold $44.6 billion bet that buying Yahoo Inc. can transform both companies' flagging efforts to catch Google Inc.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor has faith official is innocent

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said Saturday that she has "every faith in the integrity" of a Kaohsiung city government official and that she will not consider replacing him for the time being.

She was referring to Hsiao Yu-cheng, director of the Kaohsiung city government's Bureau of Environmental Protection, who Kaohsiung prosecutors have indicted on charges of vote-buying. The prosecutors have demanded a 14-year jail sentence plus the stripping of his civil rights for 10 years after he serves the sentence.

Hsiao was detained Nov. 24 last year and held for more than one month for alleged vote-buying. The prosecutors accused him of spending NT$14,400 (US$436.36) of his office funds to treat 17 of his subordinates -- mostly heads of street cleaning squads in the city's Sanmin district -- to a dinner in a restaurant earlier that month, during which he asked them to vote for ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Kun-tse, a candidate in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.

Chen noted that after Hsiao was detained, the Taiwan High Court's Kaohsiung branch twice revoked the detention ruling by the Kaohsiung District Court, which she claimed "proves the stark differences in the interpretation of the case."
She claimed that Hsiao's integrity is "beyond doubt, " as is the integrity of his subordinates.

Chen claimed that prosecutors have been "specifically" targeting Hsiao, adding that Taiwan society is full of people who view things from "a certain political viewpoint, so that they can give rulings that do not live up to the public's concept of right and wrong."
Hsiao served as spokesman for Chen's election campaign office before she won the Dec. 9, 2006 Kaohsiung mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president returns from South Pacific diplomatic tour

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu returned to Taiwan Saturday from a tour of three of Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific -- the Marshall Islands, Nauru and the Solomon Islands.

Lu, who departed Taipei Monday on the diplomatic tour, said she envies the three allies, who have become independent since World War II and asked why Taiwan, who was freed from Japanese colonial rule in 1945, cannot become independent like them.

Lu said all three nations have seen leadership changes in recent weeks and that she met with their new leaders and invited them to visit Taiwan in March or April to help cement bilateral diplomatic relations.
She said the visit was "not only for President Chen Shui-bian, but for the new president to be elected in the March 22 election."
According to Lu, the country's new president might take one year or two to become as "well-versed in diplomatic, internal, economic and financial affairs" as Chen.
"We are worried about the situation, as it will give rise to a Chinese diplomatic coup in this diplomatic vacuum period," she said.
She was referring to Chinese tactics to use "checkbook diplomacy" to undermine relations between the Republic of China and its allies.

Touching on the recent controversy over whether main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has a U.S. green card, Lu said that rather than getting mired in a war of words, the public should demand that new leader unequivocally say if he is committed to the independence and sovereignty of Taiwan, claiming that "this is the issue that the voters are most concerned with."

Frank Hsieh, the standard bearer of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, has accused Ma over the past week of lacking integrity and loyalty because Ma held a green card in the 1970s when he was a student. Ma pointed out, however, that he has not used the green card to enter the U.S. for more than two decades and that it has therefore long since become invalid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiping Island runway mainly for humanitarian concerns: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that construction of a runway on the remote Taiping Island in the South China Sea is mainly for humanitarian purposes.
Chen was quoted as having made the remarks while presiding over the inauguration ceremony for the runway on Taiping Island earlier in the day.

According to a report released by the Military News Agency, Chen flew in a military aircraft to Taiping Island at around noon to officiate at the airstrip inauguration ceremony and extend his regards and concerns for personnel stationed there ahead of the Lunar New Year festival.
Chen praised the military officers and enlisted men for their high efficiency in completing the airstrip construction in just 273 days, the report said.

A total of 581 service personnel were involved in the runway construction project, and the two top leading officers -- Col. Chen Huang-cheng and Capt. Lin Hung-chieh -- have not taken a single day off since last August, the report added.

The new Taiping runway is transformed from a central road on the island. The road was extended and expanded into a 1,150-meter-long, 30-meter-wide cement path that will be used as the main traffic trunk most of the time and as an airstrip during emergencies so that transport planes can land and take off.

Chen expressed his admiration for close cooperation among various military units and the Coast Guard Administration in carrying out the tough construction project which covered land preparation, shipment of construction materials and equipment from Taiwan to the remote island, weather forecast, navigation route evaluation, equipment maintenance, geological survey and building wrok.

MND officials said only C-130 transport planes can make landings and take-offs on the island, which is located some 1,600 kilometers southwest of Taiwan proper. It takes three to four days for a one-way voyage between the island and the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

Taiping is the largest islet of the Nansha or Spratly island group in the South China Sea. With surrounding countries increasing their activities in the region in recent years, the number of shipwrecks and cases involving fishermen getting injured or missing has increased, making it necessary to build an airstrip on the Taiping Island to facilitate emergency response and humanitarian relief, Chen said.

Last November, Chen went on, scores of Chinese, Philippine and Vietnamese fishing boats were stranded in the Spratlys area. The Philippine military authorities sent a trainer on a sear and rescue mission, but the military plane lost contact. The Philippine authorities then sought the help of Taiwan personnel stationed on Taiping Island. The case highlighted the need to enhance the island's humanitarian relief capacity, Chen noted, adding that the construction of an airstrip on the island is for humanitarian purpose only.

DOC.HEADLINE: President proposes Spratly Initiative on Taiping Island visit

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian came up with a Spratly Initiative Saturday during a visit to the Taiwan-held Taiping Island in the South Chin Sea, urging all surrounding countries to cooperate in regional environmental protection instead of bickering over sovereignty claims.

Taiping is the largest in the Spratly island chain which is composed of a string of rocky outcrops possibly holding large oil and gas deposits. Besides Taiwan, five other countries -- China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei -- also claim sovereignty over the Spratlys.

Speaking at the inauguration ceremony for a 1,150-meter airstrip on Taiping Island, Chen said Taiwan is willing to accept the principles and spirit of the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea signed between ASEAN member states and China in 2002 on an equal footing. The declaration calls for resolving sovereignty disputes with peaceful means and formulating a code of conduct for the South China Sea.
In the face of the threat of global warming, Chen said exploration of natural resoruces in the South China Sea should give priority to maritime ecological conservation and sustainable development.

He promised that Taiwan will invite international ecologists and representatives of major environmental groups to visit Taiwan-held islands in the South China Sea, including Dongsha (Pratas) Islands, the Taiping Island and Chungzhou reefs, for survey and research purposes.

To shun the sensitive sovereignty issues, Chen suggested that a non-governmental South China Sea research center be established to facilitate international cooperation in protecting natural ecology and resources in the region.

Chen made the half-day visit to Taiping Island to preside over the inauguration of the airstrip which was completed in January to supplement coastguard facilities on the island for emergency and humanitarian relief operations.

Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu, Interior Minister Lee Yi- yang, Coast Guard Administration Minister Wang Chin-wang and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai on the unpredecented visit to the Taiping Island aboard an Air Force C-130 transport plane.

Noting that construction of the airstrip is mainly for humanitarian purposes, Chen praised the military officers and enlisted men for their high efficiency in completing the airstrip in just 273 days.

A total of 581 service personnel were involved in the runway construction project, and the two top leading officers -- Col. Chen Huang-cheng and Capt. Lin Hung-chieh -- have not taken a single day off since last August.

The new Taiping runway is transformed from a central road on the island. The road was extended and expanded into a 1,150-meter-long, 30-meter-wide cement path that will be used as the main traffic trunk most of the time and as an airstrip during emergencies so that transport planes can land and take off.

Chen expressed his admiration for close cooperation among various military units and the Coast Guard Administration in carrying out the tough construction project which covered land preparation, shipment of construction materials and equipment from Taiwan to the remote island, weather forecast, navigation route evaluation, equipment maintenance, geological survey and building wrok.

Only C-130 transport planes can make landings and take-offs on the island, which is located some 1,600 kilometers southwest of Taiwan proper. It takes three to four days for a one-way voyage between the island and the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

With surrounding countries increasing their activities in the region in recent years, the number of shipwrecks and cases involving fishermen getting injured or missing has increased, making it necessary to build an airstrip on the Taiping Island to facilitate emergency response and humanitarian relief, Chen said.

Last November, Chen went on, scores of Chinese, Philippine and Vietnamese fishing boats were stranded in the Spratlys area. The Philippine military authorities sent a trainer on a sear and rescue mission, but the military plane lost contact. The Philippine authorities then sought the help of Taiwan personnel stationed on Taiping Island. The case highlighted the need to enhance the island's humanitarian relief capacity, Chen noted, adding that the construction of an airstrip on the island is for humanitarian purpose only.

Chen was originally scheduled to make a visit to Dongsha Island following the Taiping trip to extend regards and concerns for service members posted there ahead of the Lunar New Year. But inclement weather forced Chen to cancel the travel plan. Chen extended his Chinese New Year greetings to service members in Dongsha via phone after his return to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 3, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity. His "Mazarin Bible" (1455) is believed to be the first book printed with such type.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartolomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1830: Greece is declared independent under the protection of Britain, France, and Russia at a London conference.
1867: Prince Mutsuhito becomes Emperor Meiji at the age of 14. His reign in Japan lasted until 1912.
1913: The 16th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified, giving the government the power to impose and collect taxes on income.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts Hawks Bay in New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1943: British bombers pound the German city of Hamburg.
1945: U.S. troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces during World War II.
1960: British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan tells the astonished white politicians in the Cape Town parliament that they should accept racial equality.
1966: The unmanned Soviet spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1973: Fighting in Vietnam comes to a halt when a cease-fire goes into effect.
1974: Dr. Arthur A. Kimball, director of the International Training Section of the U.S. Agency for International Development, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Indian Ocean satellite communications ground station in Taiwan begins operations, providing improved telephone service to Europe and Africa.
1974: The ROC's agricultural technical cooperation with Honduras is extended for two years.
1977: China Steel Corp.'s Kaohsiung mill begins operations.
1978: The European Economic Community and Communist China initial their first trade agreement.
1989: P.W. Botha resigns as chief of South Africa's ruling party.
1989: A military coup topples strongman Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay, ending his eight successive presidential terms and 35 years of rule.
1992: A fight breaks out in a camp for Vietnamese boat refugees in Hong Kong, resulting in 18 deaths.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo against Vietnam.
1996: An earthquake rocks Lijiang in southwestern China, killing more than 302 people.
2000: An A300-600R airbus of China Airlines, carrying 225 passengers, departs Taipei for Manila, formally resuming direct air links between Taiwan and the Philippines after they had been suspended for four months.
2001: One hundred and fifty practitioners and supporters of Zhong Gong, a form of Chinese kung fu which emphasizes the use of inner strength to toughen one's body, stage a parade around Guam to call for the release of founder Zhang Hongbao.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with cold water for drink and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

A total of 581 service personnel were involved in the runway construction project, and the two top leading officers -- Col. Chen Huang-cheng and Capt. Lin Hung-chieh -- have not taken a single day off since last August.

The new Taiping runway is transformed from a central road on the island. The road was extended and expanded into a 1,150-meter-long, 30-meter-wide cement path that will be used as the main traffic trunk most of the time and as an airstrip during emergencies so that transport planes can land and take off.

Chen expressed his admiration for close cooperation among various military units and the Coast Guard Administration in carrying out the tough construction project which covered land preparation, shipment of construction materials and equipment from Taiwan to the remote island, weather forecast, navigation route evaluation, equipment maintenance, geological survey and building wrok.

Only C-130 transport planes can make landings and take-offs on the island, which is located some 1,600 kilometers southwest of Taiwan proper. It takes three to four days for a one-way voyage between the island and the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

With surrounding countries increasing their activities in the region in recent years, the number of shipwrecks and cases involving fishermen getting injured or missing has increased, making it necessary to build an airstrip on the Taiping Island to facilitate emergency response and humanitarian relief, Chen said.

Last November, Chen went on, scores of Chinese, Philippine and Vietnamese fishing boats were stranded in the Spratlys area. The Philippine military authorities sent a trainer on a sear and rescue mission, but the military plane lost contact. The Philippine authorities then sought the help of Taiwan personnel stationed on Taiping Island. The case highlighted the need to enhance the island's humanitarian relief capacity, Chen noted, adding that the construction of an airstrip on the island is for humanitarian purpose only.

Chen was originally scheduled to make a visit to Dongsha Island following the Taiping trip to extend regards and concerns for service members posted there ahead of the Lunar New Year. But inclement weather forced Chen to cancel the travel plan. Chen extended his Chinese New Year greetings to service members in Dongsha via phone after his return to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news

The Japan Times: 'Gyoza' plant sage, China official says
A quality-control official in Hebei Province said Saturday that a probe into the factory that made the frozen meat dumplings suspected of causing the food- poisoning outbreak in Japan had turned up no problems and that the factory chief was surprised by the incident.

International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Microsoft's Yahoo bid aims at Web
Acknowledging it can't beat Internet juggernaut Google Inc. on its own, Microsoft Corp. on Friday lashed its online fortunes to another Web also-ran with an unsolicited $44.6-billion bid for Yahoo Inc. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers to be frugal while refurbishing offices

TEXT.P: Newly sworn-in legislators of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will strive to build "new image" for the Legislative Yuan by not being extravagant, among other things, a KMT official said Sunday.

KMT Central Policy Committee Executive Director Lin Yi-shih said that all newly elected KMT legislators have been told to stick to legislative regulations by controlling spending on refurbishing their research offices at the Legislative Yuan building and keeping it under NT$100,000 (US$3,106)

The lawmakers of the KMT -- which now holds an absolute majority with 81 seats in the downsized, restructured 113-member legislature after the Jan. 12 legislative polls -- should be particularly careful in their behavior so as to help build a "new and clean" image of the Legislative Yuan, to which the voters have given the KMT a clear mandate to continue its program of reform, Lin said.

Lin called for all new KMT lawmakers to observe the regulation, pointing out that all members of the KMT legislative caucus voted to pass a "no more than NT$100,000 refurbishment spending" resolution Feb. 1, when the 7th Legislature was sworn in.
Lin said that if some KMT legislators cannot prevent their spending from exceeding NT$100,000, they will have to pay for the excess themselves.

Meanwhile, he said, the KMT legislative caucus will suggest, if necessary, to have a list of spending by all legislators from all parties for refurbishment of their research offices published to allow the general public to better understand the operations of the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Philippines reaffirms close partnership with Taiwan

TEXT.P: Philippines representative to Taiwan Antonio Basilio said recently that the Philippines "will continue to enhance its relationships with Taiwan, " downplaying controversy over the disputed Spratly Islands.

President Chen Shui-bian visited Taiping Island Saturday -- the largest of the Spratly islands -- to inaugurate a new airstrip there, arousing concern and protest from the Philippine government. Basilio expressed concern over the visit but said Taiwan will remain a very important economic partner of the Philippines.

Noting that the Philippines and Taiwan are in the final stage of completing the negotiations for an "Economic Corridor, " Basilio expressed confidence that it will help Taiwanese businesses tap markets in Southeast Asia when the member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) implement a Free Trade Agreement (FTA), from which Taiwan is excluded.

The Economic Corridor, based on a bilateral Memorandum of Understanding signed Dec. 6, 2005, aims at linking the Subic and Clark Special Economic Zones in the Philippines with the Economic Processing Zones in Taiwan.

By linking the economic and export processing zones and allowing easier product and manpower movement, Taiwan and the Philippines will be able to further expand trade relations, creating a win-win situation, Armand Arreza, administrator and CEO of the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority, was quoted as saying while visiting Taiwan in May 2007 to review the progress of the Economic Corridor.

Tallies from various sources suggest that Taiwanese products will lose their competitiveness in the ASEAN market as tariffs on all products within ASEAN member countries are set to be completely eliminated by 2015.

Basilio said that if Taiwanese businesses meet the "local content" criteria of the Philippines, their products will be considered products of the Philippines and will therefore be eligible for duty free treatment in ASEAN, adding that Subic Bay and Clark are working hard to improve infrastructure, with the hope that the plan can be accomplished later this year.
Referring to Taiwanese business interests in setting up production bases in Southeast Asia, Basilio said that "we want to offer the Philippines as a location."

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and the Philippines reached US$7.2 billion in 2006, with Taiwan ranking as the Philippines' sixth-largest trading partner, according to statistics from Taiwan's Bureau of Trade.

Meanwhile, Basilio encouraged Taiwanese tourists to visit his country during the Lunar New Year holiday amid increasing worries that snowstorms hitting China might hamper their plans of visiting China.
As Taiwan is the fifth-biggest source of tourists to the Philippines, Basilio also promised to help eliminate visa requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan works to ease concerns over Spratly Islands dispute

TEXT.P: Taiwan is continuing to communicate with and explain to countries that have expressed concerns over a trip by President Chen Shui-bian to Taiping Island in the disputed Spratly islands and Taiwan's construction of a runway there, a top foreign official said Sunday.

Claiming that Chen's visit to the island in the South China Sea and construction of the airstrip there is mainly for humanitarian purposes, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh made the remarks in the wake of a protest lodged by the Philippines a day earlier.

Citing a Spratly initiative broached by Chen stressing that "the sovereignty dispute should be replaced with environmental protection and depletion of resources should be replaced with sustainable ecology, " Yeh called on all countries concerned for a peaceful solution to the disputes by setting a strategic dialogue mechanism and including Taiwan in the mechanism.
Chen visited the Taiwan-held Taiping Island, the largest island in the Spratlys group, to preside over the inauguration ceremony for a 1,150-meter airstrip on the island a day earlier.

The move immediately drew protests from other countries that claim all or part of the potentially oil-rich islets. A written statement issued Saturday by Manila branded Chen's visit as "lamentable" and "unfortunate."
Taiwan, China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei all claim sovereignty over all or parts of the Spratly Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC urges China not to `misinterpret' U.N. bid referendum

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong urged Beijing Sunday not to "twist" Taiwan's referendum on the country's U.N. membership bid to be held along with the March 22 presidential election.

Chen made the call after the Chinese communist party's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs and the Taiwan Affairs Office of State Council issued a statement the previous day objecting to the referendum initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
In the statement, Beijing accused Taiwan of seeking to alter the status quo across the Taiwan Strait and of moving toward de-jure independence by having the referendum.
"It is no surprise at all that China would issue such a statement now to set the tone for Taiwan's U.N. membership bid," Chen said.

According to the MAC head, Beijing would have chosen the timing probably because the Central Election Commission maintained its decision last Friday to hold the DPP-proposed referendum and another by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) alongside the presidential poll.

Chen called on Beijing to face up to Taiwan's public opinion in this regard and not to "misinterpret" the DPP's referendum aimed at gauging public opinion on the country's pursuit of U.N. membership under the name of Taiwan.
"Beijing's twisted interpretation viewing the DPP's referendum as a covert move toward de-jure Taiwan independence will only further push Taiwan's people away from China," he said.
"Taiwan only hopes to transmit its people's strong desire for a U.N. seat to the international community through the referendum," he went on.

China and the United States have voiced opposition to the DPP's U.N. cause referendum out of fear of further complicating the sensitive cross-strait situation, but not the one proposed by the KMT, which seeks public endorsement for U.N. membership in the name of Republic of China or other appropriate designations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children's 'English village' opens in Taichung County

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first "English village" for children featuring a total language immersion environment opened Saturday at Taichung English and Art Museum in Dali City in Taichung County.

The "village" occupying 15,206.61 square meters is comprised of 21 theme rooms to give students a simulated experience of life in English, including a model flight cabin, a mock immigration agency, an airport lobby and a restaurant.
Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng said at the inauguration ceremony that the most important function of the village is providing an all-English learning environment for students.

"The learning center, touted as the first of its kind in Taiwan, is aimed at stimulating children's natural ability to learn English in an all-English learning environment and allowing them to improve their English without going abroad," Huang said.

To celebrate the village's inauguration, more than 300 children were provided with the chance that day to experience the full English environment in which they can learn and practice English through language immersion classes.
"It's funny because I felt like I was in a foreign restaurant and that learning English was just like playing a game, " one seven-year-old girl said.

The learning institution will design 15 simulated English learning situations, each lasting for 40-50 minutes, for students in varying age groups. Children wishing to attend the classes can apply online or by telephone at 04-24860069 ext. 3510, according to Chen Shu-man, chief executive of the institution.
