DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Montezemolo: Go to polls if there is no agreement on electoral reform.
Italian industrial sector leader Luca Montezemolo called for revisions to the existing electoral law. He said however that it would be better to go to polls if there is no agreement on electoral reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate will drop out of race if contribution confirmed

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Sunday that he will drop out of the presidential race if he is found to have received NT$500,000 (US$15,528) allegedly given by a biopharmacists association as a political donation.

Speaking during a rally marking the establishment of his campaign headquarters in the eastern county of Hualien, Hsieh said that although it is legal for candidates to receive donations from supporters during campaigns, he has not received the NT$500,000 from any domestic biopharmacists association as alleged by Ma Yi-nan -- the elder sister of his election rival, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) standard-bearer Ma Ying-jeou.
Ma Yi-nan claimed recently that the biopharmacists association donated NT$1 million to Hsieh's campaign group and that Hsieh had taken half of the amount.
Hsieh said that if the association had made the donation, it must have receipt from his campaign office. He challenged the person who made the claim to come up with the receipt.
Meanwhile, Hsieh challenge Ma Ying-jeou to bow out of the race too if he has received any political contributions he has kept secret.
Hsieh claimed that the KMT is now "much richer" than ever after it won a landslide victory in the Jan. 12 legislative polls.

He claimed that the KMT -- which now holds an absolute majority with 81 seats in the downsized, streamlined 113-member legislature -- will have greater "ill- gotten" party assets and much more resources at its disposal.

He added that the KMT spent "a fortune" late last year to run television commercials "on a daily basis" to "drive a wedge" between himself and Su Tseng- chang, who is now his running mate but was a rival during the DPP presidential primaries.

Claiming that the situation is "worse than the days of martial law, " with the KMT sitting as a single dominant party in the legislature while small parties have no voice at all, Hsieh called on the public to vote for him "as the only way to turn around the situation."

Meanwhile, Hsu Kuo-yung, a spokesman for Hsieh's campaign headquarters, acknowledged an Apple Daily report Sunday that the campaign subsidies that Hsieh's headquarters has been able to distribute to local campaign centers around the country are about 60 percent less than what was given out by President Chen Shui-bian's re-election campaign headquarters in 2004.

Noting that the DPP has always had much less campaign funds than the KMT, Hsu said that despite financial constraints, the DPP has always been adept in using funds efficiently and added that the DPP is confident of winning the March 22 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP camp accuses China of rigging presidential election

TEXT.P: The camp of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh accused China Sunday of "brazenly interfering" in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election by offering preferential plane tickets to help Taiwan businessmen to return home and vote.

Hsu Kuo-yung and Sheng Fa-hui, both former lawmakers, and ex- Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-Tseang, who work as spokesmen for Hsieh's presidential campaign, made the accusation in a news conference.

According to Sheng, China has been encouraging Taiwan businessmen to return home to vote in the presidential election by offering discounted plane tickets and hinted that they should vote te for "a certain candidate" as part of its efforts to "rig" the event.

Displaying a notification issued Jan. 28 by the China-based Taiwan Compatriot Investment Enterprises Association, Sheng said that Chinese state-run carriers are providing Taiwan businessmen with cheap plane tickets to achieve the aim.

Normally, a ticket from Shanghai to Taiwan via Hong Kong or Macau costs NT$18,000 (US$565) , but Chinese aviation companies are providing Taiwan businessmen with tickets for about NT$12,150 -- even more affordable than prices for Lunar New Year charter flights.

China has been exploring all possible means to push Taiwan businessmen to go home to vote, Cheng said, claiming that China' s "behind-the-scenes" maneuvering is aimed at affecting the result of the election.
"China must respect the free will of each Taiwan businessman operating in China in this regard," Cheng argued.

Asked whether the Communist Party of China has been colluding with the Kuomintang (KMT) , Taiwan's largest opposition party, Hsu, however, denied that he was making his insinuation and voiced his hope that such a collusion does not exist.

Meanwhile, more than 3,000 Taiwan businessmen based in the Shanghai area have booked the cheap tickets -- organized by a Taiwan businessman's association in Shanghai and the local branch of a Taipei-based tour agency -- ahead of the presidential election.
According to a Taiwan businessman surnamed Huang, his ticket cost 2,700 Chinese yuan -- 100 yuan cheaper than the price in 2004.
A tour agency official said that more charter flights will be arranged for Taiwan businessmen wishing to go home prior to the presidential race.
According to a local media report, some 250,000 China-based Taiwanese businessmen are planning to return to Taiwan for the presidential election.
Hsieh faces KMT rival Ma Ying-jeou in the approaching presidential election, who has vowed to relax restrictions on Taiwanese businessmen operating in China.
According to public opinion polls in the past few months, Ma is steadily enjoying a lead over Hsieh by a wide margin of more than 20 percent in terms of public support rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAPA chapter chief named OCAC adviser
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 2 (CNA) 02/03/08 18:04:02 (By Lilian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An American citizen who began to head the Indiana Chapter of the pro- independence Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) a year ago was appointed as an adviser to Taiwan's Cabinet-level Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) Saturday.

John Conklin, who has served as chief of the FAPA Indiana Chapter since early 2007, was presented with a certificate by Cheng Chieh-sung, director of the OCAC office in Chicago, during a Lunar New Year celebration held at the Taiwan Association in Indiana Saturday.

Lauding Conklin at the party, Cheng said that over the past year, Conklin, who is married to a Taiwanese citizen, has spared no efforts to make the voice of Taiwan heard in the Indiana state legislature and relevant organizations.

Conklin has also helped boost Taiwan's diplomatic efforts in the United States, including being instrumental in arranging for speeches made by Taiwan's top representative in the U.S., Joseph Wu, at an educational institute and a public affairs organization in Indiana last month, Cheng said.

For his part, Conklin said it is a great honor for him to be appointed by the Cabinet-level OCAO as an adviser. The appointment is a token of the Taiwan administration's recognition of members of the Taiwanese community in Indiana for their efforts, he said.
He added that the FAPA Indiana Chapter will strive harder in the future for the cause of championing Taiwan's hard-earned democracy.
Meanwhile, Cheng gave the thumbs up to the Taiwan Association in Indiana for its staunch support shown to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration over the past year.
The association organized a Week of Taiwan Traditions last May, showcasing various colorful aspects of Taiwanese folklore, including a lion dance performed by a troupe from Taiwan, Cheng said.

Last August, he went on, the Taiwan Association in Indiana invited more than 30 representatives of Taiwanese civic groups from 10 major cities in seven Midwestern states to speak for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations as a full member under the name Taiwan. Those representatives also traveled to New York to take part in activities to champion the Taiwan cause there, he said.

Last November, he added, the Taiwan Association took part in an international Cultural Festival sponsored by the Indiana state government and won the champion of the festival with an entry on Taiwan's education and traditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: I-Shou University to open international school

TEXT.P: I-Shou University in the southern county of Kaohsiung will set up an international school and begin to enroll foreign students for the 2009 academic year in an effort to nurture international talent and boost the university's international competitiveness.
The university is now studying what departments, courses and subjects will be covered by the school, I-Shou University President Fu Shen-li said Sunday.
The international school, featuring an all-foreign language learning environment, will have all courses taught in foreign language at the university transferred to the new school, Fu added.
"We are planning to open management classes next academic semester on a trial basis for 25 undergraduate students who will be selected from various schools except management schools," Fu noted.

In light of a severe lack of nursing professionals in many Western countries, the university has also decided to set up a department of global health and international nursing, with relevant courses to be taught in foreign languages, according to Fu, who added that students will also be recruited from Southeast Asian countries.
The construction of the international school complex is expected to be completed by the end of this year, according to Fu.

The establishment of the new school is part of the school's measures to respond to the Ministry of Education's call for promotion of campus internationalization, which also includes conducting exchanges with foreign sister-schools, encouraging students to engage in overseas studies, enlisting foreign students and the creation of an international affairs division.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seminar aims to cash in on oil dollars

TEXT.P: The Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) is slated to sponsor a seminar Feb. 27 on how to explore business opportunities in the Middle East, CNAIC officials said Sunday.

According to the CNAIC officials, government officials, experts and academics, including Wu Fu-cheng, deputy chief of the international research department under the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, will publish their reports at the seminar to share their research and information.
Taiwan businessmen interested in exploring the promising markets in the region are welcome to take part in the seminar, they added.

Countries in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf are keen to diversify their development with the huge fortune they have earned from crude oil, prices of which hit a record high of over US$100 per barrel last year on the international market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction of joint office buildings to begin in November

TEXT.P: Construction of joint office buildings in Hsinchuang City, Taipei County for agencies under the Executive Yuan is slated to begin in November, officials in charge of the issue confirmed Sunday.

According to officials at the Construction and Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, construction of two 18-story office buildings and a seven-story conference center will start by that time and is slated to be completed in 2013, based on a project approved by the Executive Yuan Secretariat.

The construction plan is expected to help bolster development in areas adjacent to the compound where the three buildings will be erected, the officials said. They added, however, that they had no knowledge of which agencies will move into the buildings.

The Executive Yuan announced last year that it was mulling whether to relocate some central government agencies lacking fixed offices to Hsinchuang to save on rental that amounts to more than NT$1 billion (US$31.3 million) per year.
It has been speculated that the Public Construction Commission and the Council of Labor Affairs have been included by the Executive Yuan in the relocation program.

DOC.HEADLINE: 140 students from China to study at I-Shou University

TEXT.P: Some 140 students from 13 Chinese universities with sisterhood ties with I-Shou University in the southern Taiwan county of Kaohsiung will study at the university from the end of February for four months, marking a record high number of students from China studying in Taiwan at the same time, university President Fu Shen-li said Sunday.
Under the student exchange program, the students, all from key universities in China, will study with Taiwanese students in various departments at the university, according to Fu.

"We hope that the participation of the Chinese students will help improve local students' learning attitude and broaden their horizons, while increasing bilateral understanding between universities on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Fu said.
He added that students from the university will also visit sister schools in China during summer or winter break.
As China recognizes Taiwanese degrees, Chinese students who complete credit hours at the university will be accepted by Chinese universities, Fu noted.
Forty-six Chinese students from six of the university's 18 sister universities have completed their credit hours in the just-concluded semester and have returned to China, Fu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese spouses in Taiwan longing for families across the strait

TEXT.P: Most Chinese spouses of Taiwanese citizens are anticipating the approaching Lunar New Year holiday with the same excitement as people in Taiwan, tinged with a little disappointment that they cannot be reunited with their relatives in China to celebrate the year's most important festival.

Despite the company of the family of her husband and friends, Yin, a Chinese woman married to a Taiwanese man who has lived here for eight years, cannot stem her yearning for her daughter, who studies in Zhejiang, a southern province of China.

Yin had her daughter in an earlier marriage. When she decided to remarry a Taiwanese and move to the island, her daughter was only a teenager and she had to consign her to her relatives' care. During the past eight years, Yin has returned a few times to her hometown, yet her greatest desire -- to live close to her daughter -- will not be realized soon.

In contrast to the cheerful atmosphere of the Chinese New Year, Yin's regret seems to be more intense than usual. " However happily you live here, the sorrow over the separation from your close relatives remains inconsolable," Yin said.

Yin is not alone. Feng, a young woman from the eastern province of Anhui, who had been hoping to see her parents, ditched the idea after realistic considerations. "Procedures for applying for a family visit visa are too complicated and the maximum permitted time is just one month, at most two," Feng said.

The way to a family reunion is long because it is difficult for Chinese spouses to receive an identity card. They often have to wait eight years to be naturalized and according to government statistics, until November 2007, only 44,493 out of 250,160 Chinese spouses (17.8 percent) had been granted an identity card, while 59,906 out of 137,353 spouses from other countries (43.6 percent) were naturalized Taiwanese.
In addition, Chinese people can only come to Taiwan on a group tourist visa and can only stay for a maximum of 10 days.
Although Chinese spouses suffer from the separation from their families in China during the Lunar New Year, they are excited nevertheless about the most important festival in Chinese societies.

"In the province of Guangdong, well-off families prepare `Dragon-Phoenix soup' made with snake and chicken or `turtle-snake soup, '" noted a young woman originating from the city of Shenzhen, adding that in general, Taiwan celebrates the Lunar New Year with much the same traditions and customs as in China.

"But I was surprised that people in Taiwan keep the tradition of worshiping gods and ancestors during the Chinese New Year. In China, this kind of tradition is no longer popular after the Cultural Revolution," she explained.

"We people from Chaozhou do not have the custom of eating pineapple and fish like in Taiwan or in other provinces in China, " another woman said, explaining that in their dialect, the two indispensable ingredients for Chinese New Year do not have fortuitous meanings in way they do in Mandarin Chinese.

Another woman from northeastern China said that in Taiwan, people can afford sumptuous meals, but the ambiance is not animated enough. "In my hometown, Chinese operas are performed in our community for a whole week, and children play hobbyhorses in the street, " she said, adding that "in Taiwan we just play mahjong and visit relatives and friends."
Asked about their New Year wishes, the new Taiwanese mothers said they wish for health and academic performance for their children.

Some non-governmental organizations (NGOs) make efforts to help foreign spouses adapt to life in Taiwan. The Taipei-based Chinese Association for Relief and Ensuring Services, for instance, organizes English, dancing and cooking courses for Chinese spouses, while on Jan. 20, the Pearl S. Buck Foundation invited low- income families of foreign spouses for an early celebration of the Lunar New Year.
These NGOs do not want their activities to be tagged as charity for foreigners, since they do not want to differentiate between Taiwanese and foreign spouses.

DOC.HEADLINE: Drill to be held for avian flu prevention

TEXT.P: A drill codenamed "Black-faced Spoonbill Operation No.2 " will be conducted late this month or in March to get the nation ready for a fight against a possible outbreak of the deadly H5N1 avian flu, an official said Sunday.
National Science Council Minister Chen Chien-jen, who concurrently heads a Cabinet task force on avian flu prevention and control, made the remarks in an interview with CNA.

Chen said the planned drill will be the second of its kind following a similar exercise in 2007. In that drill, some public functionaries were required to work from home as response measures were practiced in a simulation in which that Taiwan was hit by a human-to-human bird flu epidemic.

This year, Chen said, the private sector will join government agencies in the drill, particularly those in the transportation service and public utilities sector as well as some high-tech companies in the country's three science-based industrial parks.
Chen said the policy of prohibiting live poultry slaughter in traditional markets will be put into force April 1 as scheduled.

"The government's stance on carrying out this policy remains unchanged, " Chen said. Nevertheless, he acknowledged that certain complementary measures must be reinforced before the new slaughtering ban takes effect.

On a suggestion by local poultry farmers associations that Taiwan follow the example of Hong Kong in using glass to separate consumers from slaughtering areas in traditional markets, Chen claimed that the proposal is "not feasible in Taiwan."

In Hong Kong, each poultry vending booth covers an area of about 15 pings (one ping equals 3.31 square meters) , which makes it possible to have glass erected to separate shoppers from poultry slaughtering areas. In Taiwan, each booth usually covers an area of just 5 pings, which he claimed is too small to accommodate any separating structures.

Chen said he will invite officials from the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Economic affairs, the Department of Health and other relevant agencies to discuss other feasible alternatives and consult with chicken farmers associations, electric slaughtering and processing service providers, poultry transport service industry associations and poultry vendor representatives.
"Despite some technical difficulties that are pending a solution, the policy of banning poultry slaughter in traditional markets from April 1 remains intact," Chen reaffirmed.

Thanks to collaborative efforts of the public and private sectors, Taiwan is still free from H5N1 bird flu infection. As a result, the country has been able to continue chicken meat exports to Japan, Hong Kong and South Korea. "We must remain on guard, as the consequences of an H5N1 outbreak could be detrimental," Chen said.

As of mid-January, warnings against possible massive outbreaks of bird flu infection among poultry had been issued in Vietnam, Bangladesh, India, Israel, Iran, Egypt and Portugal. In Egypt, 64,000 poultry were infected with bird flu, leading to a cull of 1 million birds.

On Jan. 24, more than 4,000 chickens died on a poultry farm in northern Thailand and subsequent laboratory tests confirmed that all the birds were infected with the virulent H5N1 virus. More than 10,000 chickens raised at the farm were culled to prevent a further spread of the disease.

As for H5N1 infection among humans, the number of cases reported in China remains limited. In comparison, Indonesia faces a far more serious threat of the outbreak. Chen said avian flu infection among humans has almost become a local disease that will not abate simply because of seasonal changes.

In Taiwan, Chen said quarantine officials have checked 4,026 samples of migrant birds, 572 chicken farms, 569 goose farms and 105 duck farms for avian flu virus, but no traces of H5N1 have been discovered.

Quarantine officials found low-pathogenic H7N7 avian flu virus in wild bird feces collected from the Suchao wetlands in Tainan City, Chen went on, adding that there are no poultry farms within three kilometers of the wetlands. Nevertheless, he said, quarantine officials have heightened alert over the finding.
"Fighting avian flu is a constant challenge and we cannot afford any momentary lapse of attention," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major German auto part maker to purchase in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A delegation from Germany's top-notch auto parts manufacturer Kirchhoff Automotive is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later this month to seek suppliers, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) reported Sunday.

Kirchhoff maintains manufacturing and business operations in Germany, France, Hungary, Ireland, Poland, Portugal, Spain and Mexico. With 2,500 employees on its payroll, the company posted an annual turnover exceeding 500 million euros last year, with annual purchases overseas exceeding US$130 million.
The company has aggressively sought new suppliers around the globe in recent years in a bid to further hone its international competitiveness.
The Kirchhoff delegation is scheduled to arrive Feb. 25 for a procurement mission that will include a one-on-one discussion session with Taiwanese manufacturers, TAITRA officials said.

Its shopping list in Taiwan is expected to include wire bending (over 2 million pieces a year), turned parts, welding wire (over 380 tons a year) and transport boxes (annual demand ranging from 300 to 500).

A major supplier of metal structures to the automobile industry, Kirchhoff Automotive is involved in pressing/stamping, joining, assembling and surface treatment. The company offers bumper systems, mounting plates and interior components, including cross car beams, seat frames and front ends.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT disputes DPP candidate's claims about Chinese interference

TEXT.P: DPP presidential candidate Fran Hsieh's claims that China is helping Taiwanese businesspeople in China return to vote in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election has betrayed his "ignorance" of commercial practice and his "attempts to hinder these businesspeople to vote", a Kuomintang (KMT) official said Sunday.

Chang Jung-kung, deputy chief of KMT Policy Coordination Committee and director of KMT Mainland Affairs Department, argued in a statement that it is a common practice in China for air carriers to sell tickets at a discount between 40 percent and 70 percent, and it is nothing unusual for them to offer a discount of 60 percent on flight fares to Taiwanese businesspeople.

Hsieh was apparently ignorant of this practice when he accused, through his aide, China of trying to interfere in Taiwan's election by offering flight tickets at a discount of 60 percent to Taiwan businesspeople in attempts to help them return and vote, Chang went on.

Furthermore, Chang said, the ticket prices for chartered flights to be lined up exclusively for the March 22 election were set by the many associations of Taiwan businesspeople and aviation authorities on both sides of the strait, rather than by Chinese authorities alone.
The accusation only exposed Hsieh's attempts to prevent these Taiwan businesspeople from voting in the presidential election due to his concerns that they probably won't vote for him, Chang claimed,
Hsieh's distrust in these people, calls call into questions his campaign promises that he would push for direct chartered flights across the strait if elected, Chang said.

Noting that these Taiwan business people and their family members in Taiwan number about four million, Chang said Hsieh should encourage their enthusiasm for the election, or "face their backlash prompted by his attempts to exclude them from the election."

Chang issued the statement after three of Hsieh's campaign spokesmen claimed Sunday that China is trying to meddle with March 22 election by offering unreasonable cheap flight tickets to Taiwan businesspeople working in China to return and vote for a certain candidate.
They denounced the alleged Chinese scheme as bribery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 4, or the 28th day of the last month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is elected as the first president of the United States.
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its te0ritories.
1810: Tsar Alexander I of Russia refuses to grant Napoleon I his sister Anna's hand in marriage. The Russian tsar's plans to liberalize the government were forestalled by wars with Napoleon I.
1899: Fighting breaks out in the newest U.S. protectorate, the Philippines, which declared itself a republic the previous month.
1902: Charles Lindbergh, the American aviator who made the first solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out.
1906: The New York Police Department adopts fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shantung dispute.
1938: Joachim von Ribbentrop becomes foreign minister of Germany while Hitler assumes the office of war minister.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach the so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, taken by Japan in 1904, are to be restored later.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 of the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes at Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 people aboard.
1969: Liao Ho-shu, Communist China's charge d'affaires in the Netherlands, arrives in the United States and requests political asylum.
1973: The Asian Relations Association opens its Japan office in Tokyo.
1976: Dr. Raymond Jallow, senior vice president of the United California Bank, Los Angeles, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1976: Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs H.K. Yang decorates Dr. Tare Takemi, president of the Japan Medical Association, with the Order of Brilliant Star with Special Cordon.
1978: Junius Jayawardene becomes the first president of Sri Lanka.
1978: Fan Yuan-yen, the defecting Communist Chinese pilot who flew a MiG-19 to Taiwan the previous July, writes an open letter to the United Nations condemning human rights violations by the Beijing regime.
1980: Abolhassan Bani-Sadr becomes the first elected president of Iran. He is expected to follow the line of the country's de facto ruler, religious leader Ayatollah Khomeini.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed in Taiwan for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1988: The Executive Yuan passes a bill allowing high school graduates to study abroad.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1997: Two military helicopters collide in mid-air in a storm in northern Israel, killing 73 Israeli soldiers.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
2000: Three Indonesian workers at the sixth naphtha cracking plant owned by Taiwan Plastic Corp. are killed in an accident while cleaning gas pipelines.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold Lunar New Year holiday anticipated

TEXT.P: A cold Lunar New Year holiday is expected around Taiwan with the mercury likely to drop to as low as 9 degrees Celsius Feb. 6-9 due to the approach of a continental arctic air mass, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Monday.
The next cold snap is forecast to hit Taiwan Feb. 6 -- Lunar New Year's Eve -- bringing low temperatures and wet weather to northern Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said.

Temperatures dropped to this winter's record low of 10.6 degrees in Tamsui in the northwest coastal suburb of Taipei County, northern Taiwan during the wee hours Monday, while Taichung in central Taiwan hitting a low of 10.8 degrees and Tainan in southern Taiwan seeing a low of 12.2 degrees, according to the weather bureau.
Later Monday, the forecast is for temperatures to rise slightly to between 14-15 degrees in the north, 18-19 degrees in central areas, and to 21-23 degrees in the south, the CWB forecasters said.
Officials from the weather bureau are expected to brief the press later Monday on a detailed weather forecast for the coming Lunar New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mobile, wireless Internet users continue rising in 2007

TEXT.P: The percentage of Taiwan's people who access the Internet through mobile or wireless devices stood at 24.2 percent in 2007, marking an increase of 8.6 percentage points over the year-earlier level, according to the results of a survey released recently by the Institute for Information Industry (III).

The figure includes 9.7 percent of the population that uses mobile Internet services and 19.7 percent who access the Internet wirelessly. The ratios of the two groups of users were up 1.6 percentage points and 7.7 percentage points, respectively, from 2006.
Based on teh results, the institute estimated that 5.55 million people in Taiwan were mobile or wireless Internet users in 2007, up 56.8 percent from 2006.
The survey found that mobile phones remained the most common devices for mobile online use in 2007, with 82.6 percent of mobile respondents using their mobile phones to go online.

In terms of the networks used, 41.3 percent of mobile Internet users accessed to the Internet through general packet radio services (GPRS) , while 33.5 percent of users did so through a 3G network, compared with just 21.6 percent of users in 2006.

On wireless networking, 81.9 percent of wireless Internet users went online using their notebook computers, and 22.1 percent of users did so using their desktop computers. Only a small number of users accessed to the Internet wirelessly through WiFi services available in smart phones, personal digital assistants or mobile phones.
Meanwhile, the survey revealed that the percentage of people in Taiwan subscribing to a 3G mobile network reached 16.5 percent in 2007, up 6.3 percentage points from the previous year.
The number of 3G mobile users was estimated at 3.77 million in 2007, a rise of 62.5 percent from 2006, according to the III.
In 2007, 23.6 percent of mobile phone users owned a 3G mobile phone, and 21.6 percent of mobile subscribers were registered with a 3G network, the survey results showed.
The percentage of mobile phone owners as a slice of the country's population stood at 69.6 percent in 2007, up 1.8 percentage points from 2006.

In terms of the market shares enjoyed by major mobile network operators in 2007, Chunghwa Telecom seized the largest share at 53.2 percent, followed by Taiwan Mobile at 32.8 percent and Far Eastone at 23.7 percent.

The figures corresponded to the findings of the survey in which 48.8 percent of mobile phone users named Chunghwa Telecom as the network they used most frequently, compared with 28.4 percent who named Taiwan Mobile and 20.5 percent who named Far Eastone.
The survey was conducted Aug. 4-23 by the III's Foreseeing Innovative New Digiservices as part of a study on the status of broadband, mobile and wireless use among Taiwanese households in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education minister cancels trip to Paraguay

TEXT.P: Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng has decided to cancel a planned trip to Paraguay due to the "disclosure" of his itinerary by the media, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Monday.
Liu Ching-jen, director of the MOE Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations, said that Tu was originally to depart Taipei Tuesday for Paraguay for a 15-day visit.
The minister, however, decided to call off his visit because "some important details of his scheduled itinerary" were disclosed by the media, Liu added.
Paraguay is one of Taiwan's 12 diplomatic allies in Central and South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers will have to pay for excess spending: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng urged newly sworn-in lawmakers of the 7th Legislature Monday to observe legislative regulations and control spending on the refurbishment of their research offices at the Legislative Yuan building and keeping expenses under NT$100,000 (US$3,106).
Wang said that if some legislators cannot keep their spending under NT$100,000, they will have to pay for the excess themselves.

Wang's reminder came in response to remarks made by Lin Yi-shih, director of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) Central Policy Committee, the day before calling for newly-sworn in KMT legislators to be frugal while having their research offices refurbished.

Lin call for KMT legislators to avoid extravagance and strive to build a "new image" for the Legislative Yuan, in which the KMT now holds an absolute majority after winning a landslide victory in the Jan. 12 legislative polls to take 81 seats of the downsized, restructured 113-member legislature.

Lin also said that the KMT legislative caucus will suggest, if necessary, that all legislators from all parties submit accounts of spending on the refurbishment of their research offices for publication to allow the general public to better understand the operations of the Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, the speaker said that although the space of the legislators' offices has been doubled as the number of the legislators has been almost halved, their offices are still not spacious and resemble "pigeon holes."

Wang also noted that the work days of the 7th legislature will be much tougher than those of its predecessor, pointing out that although each new legislator is now able to hire two more aides, their work loads, in terms of serving the constituents, will be much more difficult than before given the larger constituencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to boost machine parts production value to NT$276.1b in 2011

TEXT.P: Taiwan aims to become the world's leading machine part service supplier within the next four years, and has launched a project this year to boost the production value of the country's machine parts by 84 percent by 2011, according to a senior officials at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The value of the country's machine parts industry is expected to rise from NT$150 billion in 2007 to NT$276.1 billion.

Japan and Germany are currently the top ranking countries in the machinery industry, but Taiwan, with its high-end machinery tools being distributed all over the world, is the country most likely to join the race, said an official of Industrial Development Bureau (IDB), under the MOEA Monday.

Underscoring that ambition, the official told the CNA that the IDB's project is set to increase export values to NT$120 billion from last year's NT$41 billion in four years. "The project is also set to raise the number of employees in the industry from 25,000 to 47,500."
The project is run by the bureau's Precision Machinery Research and Development Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Super Bowl frenzy in Taipei

TEXT.P: Super Bowl frenzy hit the sports pubs of Taipei Monday morning with hordes of domestic and foreign fans thronging to watch live the match-up between the New England Patriots and New York Giants.

A local pub, the Tavern Premier, opened in 2000 by Swiss expatriate Michael Blanc, kept its doors open throughout the night and showed a full program of Super Bowl XLII, including pre-game shows, highlights of previous Super Bowls and of course the live broadcast of the big game itself from 7 a.m. Taipei time.
David Rucledge, an American teaching English in Taipei, pointed to himself as a "super fan."
"For Americans, this game is a big deal, like Christmas. It's like a national holiday," he said, adding, "this is the only game for which I will wake up at 6 o'clock in the morning."
Rucledge said he comes to Tavern Premier every Monday to watch NFL matches and never misses the Super Bowl. He has been working in Taiwan for 5 years.

Football fans swarmed to Tavern Premier to catch the action on the field, with over 70 satellite tvs, 7 inch personal screens and three huge 150 inch screens guaranteeing the most extensive coverage of the event.

"This is the eighth year that the Tavern Premier has shown the Super Bowl live, and our coverage is second to none, " manager Sandy Wang said, adding that they also showed the NFL quarter-finals and semi-finals.
"Every year the pub is fully booked when the Super Bowl kicks off and reservation are made as early as a month in advance," she said.

She went on to say that "football to the Americans is just as soccer to the British and baseball to Taiwanese, " and "some overseas businessmen even came here directly from the airport just to catch up with the match."

Fans can enjoy 10 kinds of draft beer on tap at the Tavern Premier, which also served the all you can eat "Fantastic Grand American Super Bowl Breakfast Buffet, " for NT$495 (US$ 15) per person, including a 10 percent Service Charge, from 6: 30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. to fill the fans' rumbling empty stomachs.
"The food is really good and it's all you can eat, " said Randy Bennett, an American custom painting artist who has been working in Taiwan for 10 years.
Two British tourists, Ben Chrystie and Chris Rumney, said that to watch Super Bowl in United Kingdom pubs would cost twice the price, around 20 pounds (US$39).

As the Super Bowl, America's most popular annual spectacle, falls on Monday morning Taiwan time, the manager said the Tavern Premier will rebroadcast the match at 7: 30 p.m. for those that had to work Monday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S., China more concerned with referendums than presidential race

TEXT.P: Results of the two referendum proposals regarding Taiwan's bid for membership in the United Nations -- not the results of Taiwan's presidential election -- are of greatest concern to China and the United States, academics said at a recent seminar.

"It seemed to me that China does not care who will win the presidential election in March. It is more concerned with the referendums, " Chiang Chi-chen, an assistant professor at Soochow University, said in a seminar held Friday on the prospects of cross-strait relations in 2008.

Two referendums on whether Taiwan should apply for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, or return to the world body under the country's official title Republic of China, or any other feasible name, will be held alongside the presidential election March 22.

The landslide victory of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the January Legislative election guarantees that the new president will have limited room to maneuver, regardless of who wins the presidency -- KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou or ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh, Chiang said.

"There is little doubt that China will focus on the referendum issue this year, " said Wang Kun-yi, a professor at Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies.
There are four possible scenarios concerning the results of the presidential election and the referendum, said Chang Wu-ueh, chairman of the Friends of Hong Kong and Macau Association.

Beijing's preferred outcome will be seeing Ma elected with the DPP's proposal, which asks for popular approval of applying for U.N. membership under the name Taiwan, failing to pass, Chang said. He added that a Hsieh victory and passage of the DPP proposal is the scenario Beijing most dislikes.

While it's inappropriate to portray the DPP's proposal as an "independence referendum", which President Chen Shui-bian vowed not to hold in his 2000 inauguration speech, the U.S. and China both took it as a "provocative first step towards de jure independence", said Lin Cheng-yi, a researcher at Academia Sinica.
"Which was why both China and the U.S. have seen the referendum issue as more important than the presidential election, " Lin noted.

China is expected to keep pressuring Taiwan on the referendum issue through third countries ahead of the March election. It is also expected to try to influence swing voters and supporters of the KMT-led pan-blue alliance to vote in the referendum, Chang said.
It will best serve Taiwan's interests if at least one referendum passes, either that of the DPP or the KMT, Lin said.
"What kind of message will we be sending the world if both referendums fail to pass?" he asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of OTC applicants up 76.9% in 2007

TEXT.P: A total of 46 Taiwan companies applied to have their stocks traded on the over- the-counter (OTC) market in 2007, according to tallies released Monday by the GreTai Securities Market (GTSM).
The number marks an increase of 76.9 percent compared with 2006, during which only 26 companies applied, GTSM officials said.

Of these 46 applicants, nine were recommended by SinoPac Securities, six each by Capital Investment Trust Corp. and Masterlink Securities Corp., and four each by Taiwan Securities Co. and Mega Securities, the officials said, noting that the number of applicants recommended by these five dealers together accounted for 63 percent of the total.
It was the second consecutive year that SinoPac Securities, Masterlink Securities and Taiwan Securities have been included on the top five list.
Meanwhile, 88 companies applied to register their shares as emerging stocks in 2007, a jump of 76 percent from 2006, they said.
By recommenders, 14 were recommended by SinoPac Securities, nine by Taiwan Securities Co. and seven each by Mega Securities, Capital Investment Trust Corp. and Yuanta Securities, they said.
SinoPac Securities, Taiwan Securities and Yuanta Securities were also among the top five emerging stock dealers in 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA unsure on air pacts with Macau and Hong Kong

TEXT.P: Although both the Taiwan-Macau and Taiwan-Hong Kong air pacts are set to expire this summer, the Civil Aviation Association (CAA) is not sure whether the agreements will be extended or new agreements will be signed.
The current Taiwan-Macau air pact is set to expire May 30, while the Taiwan-Hong Kong agreement will expire June 30.
The Taiwan-Macau aviation agreement was originally scheduled to expire in November 2005, but the two sides extended the agreement for half year periods several times.
The Taiwan-Hong Kong agreement was originally set to expire in June 2007, but similar extensions were negotiated between the two sides.

CAA Director Chang Kuo-cheng said that the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council handles matters related to aviation agreements, adding that it commissioned the Taipei Airlines Association to negotiate and sign the agreements. He added that the CAA has no means of taking charge of the matter.

It has been learned that Macau and Hong Kong postponed negotiations for new air pacts because of the fact that Taiwan is mulling to open up completely to Chinese tourists and to launch regular cross-strait weekend charter flight services.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90 percent of children exposed to second-hand smoke: survey

TEXT.P: As many as 90 percent of children surveyed recently by the Formosa Cancer Foundation identified themselves as victims of second-hand tobacco smoke, with the majority exposed to the hazard at home.
The results of the survey were released by the foundation Monday to coincide with World No Tobacco Day 2008, which focused on the theme of tobacco-free youth.

The survey revealed that while more than 90 percent of the respondents wish to live in a smoke-free environment, 70 percent have family members who smoke at home and another 60 percent have been forced to consume second-hand smoke exhaled by a visitor.
Half of the respondents do not know how to reject second-hand smoke, mainly because they are afraid they might get scolded by their parents or family members.
Some respondents also complained that their smoking family members ignore their protests, while others said they are too shy to stop their visitors from smoking.
The survey was conducted Jan. 15-28 online among 1,825 children.
To help children reduce their exposure to second-hand smoke, the foundation has designed a set of "no smoking" stickers to be placed in living rooms, cars, schools and bathrooms.

The stickers are being provided free of charge, and those wishing to receive them can write to the foundation at 5-2F, 16, Section Five, Nanjing East Road, Taipei, including a stamp with a value of NT$35. For further information, the public are urged to visit the foundation's Web site at www.canceraway.org.tw or call (02)8787-9907.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese yuan exchanges via 'mini links' top 4.56 million yuan

TEXT.P: New Taiwan dollar-Chinese yuan exchanges conducted on the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu have amounted to 4.56 million Chinese yuan (US$634,567) over the past two years, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reported Monday.

At a regular meeting, MAC officials said that since the new Taiwan dollar- Chinese yuan exchange services were legally opened in October 2005, four Taiwan financial institutions have been allowed to operate 12 currency exchange outlets on Kinmen and Matsu providing the exchange services.
A total of 4.56 million yuan had been exchanged in 61,900-odd transactions conducted at these 12 banking outlets as of the end of 2007, MAC officials said.
According to the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) , the buying and selling of Chinese yuan has been the major business of these Kinmen and Matsu bank outlets.
Among the customers, 99.7 percent were Taiwan citizens, with a mere 0.3 percent being Chinese citizens, according to the CBC.
Most of the transactions involved the sale of Chinese yuan for NT dollars, CBC officials said.
Unconfirmed reports have claimed that Taiwan residents might have amassed a total of more than 100 billion Chinese yuan over the past several years.

President Chen Shui-bian said in January 2007 that Taiwan cannot allow a full opening of exchange services for Chinese currency before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have signed a currency clearance and liquidation agreement.
In March 2004, the CBC began to allow each local citizen to bring in up to 6,000 yuan per homecoming visit, an amount that was raised to 20,000 yuan in October 2005.
According to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, local people have made a total of more than 12 million visits to China over the past three years.

Los Angeles TimesG Campaign '08--Primary focus is on California.
The first meaningful California presidential primary campaign in decades swirled to a close with a final round of candidate appeals, advertisement, mailers and door-knocking--and a boatload of uncertainty over exactly when the outcome will be decided. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterovirus tops infectious diseases in Taipei school campuses

TEXT.P: Enterovirus topped the list of infectious
diseases hitting Taipei school campuses last year, with 2,010 cases reported, Taipei City's health officials said Monday.
The officials, speaking at a press conference, said that the enterovirus was followed by chicken pox, mumps, scarlet fever, head louse, and pertussis.
Health officials said that the enterovirus is most prevalent in the spring, summer and early autumn, but that the disease could strike Taiwan almost all year round.
The number of enterovirus cases surged in the latter half of 2007 mainly because of the global warming effect, which saw temperatures not dropping even in the winter, the officials added.
Enteroviruses can be found in the respiratory secretions and stool of an infected person. Other persons may become infected by
direct contact with secretions from an infected person or by contact with contaminated surfaces or objects, such as a drinking glass or telephone.
Infected persons who become ill usually develop either mild upper respiratory symptoms a flu-like illness with fever and muscle aches, or an illness with rash.
Health authorities advised students to wash their hands, keep a healthy diet and exercise regularly to avoid being infected with various infectious diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: PM: Let's tackle cost fears together.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assured Singaporeans yesterday that their concerns about the rising cost of living, including food prices, have been heard - and are being addressed.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM: Food price controls and food subsidies are not the way to solve inflation problem.
Singapore is an open economy ans imports all its food, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 47 percent of playing cards contain excessive formaldehyde: survey

TEXT.P: Excessive levels of the carcinogenic chemical formaldehyde were found in 47 percent of playing cards surveyed recently by the Consumers' Foundation, foundation officials said Monday.

Of the total of 55 playing cards sampled, 26 were detected to contain formaldehyde residue ranging between 122.7 ppm to 1,691 ppm, much higher than the limit of 75 ppm set by the government for free formaldehyde, the officials said.
Sixteen, or 61.5 percent, of the substandard products were made in China, they added.

Also, 43, or 78 percent, of the cards surveyed were not labeled properly, including 17 China-made products, 13 Taiwan-made products and one U.S.-made product. The other 24 did not indicate their country of production.

Formaldehyde is a colorless, strong-smelling gas that is widely used as an industrial fungicide, germicide and disinfectant. It has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer as a known human carcinogen.

In addition to the long-term carcinogenic effect, formaldehyde exposure can also result in short-term health effects such as skin irritation and burning sensations of the eyes, nose and throat, foundation officials noted.

In light of the popularity of card games among Taiwanese during the Chinese New Year holiday, the officials urged consumers to avoid using cards that have a pungent smell when the wrapper is opened because they are very likely to contain formaldehyde.
Consumers should also wash their hands after playing and must not allow infants or young children to put playing cards in their mouths, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Real estate sector offers best salaries for new recruits: poll

TEXT.P: The highest starting salaries for new recruits who have worked for less than a year were paid by companies in the real estate sector in Taiwan in 2007, at an average of NT$32,452 (US$1,013) per month, according to the results of a survey issued Monday by the 1111 Job Bank, one of the country's major online job- brokering companies.

The lowest starting salary for new recruits was found in the retail and service business sector at an average of NT$26,457 per month among nine major lines of business in Taiwan, according to the report.

The nine sectors include: information and technology; manufacturing and traditional industries; financial and consultant services; trading and distribution; real estate and relevant operations; medicine, medical care, bio- chemistry, agriculture and animal husbandry; retail and service; media and publishing; and educational and non-governmental organizations.
The survey was conducted using a total of 137,815 copies of updated resumes offered by Job Bank members in 2007.
Apart from the real estate and the information and technology sectors, the starting salaries for young employees were all below the NT$30,000 per month barrier in all categories.
After working for seven or nine years, salaries in the real estate sector would surpass NT$40,000 per month, the report shows.
1111 Job Bank spokesman Wu Juei-yi indicated that factors such as work experience, position, educational background, company scale, and gender all have an impact on salary amounts.

Wu said his company conducted the survey not only to reflect the exact supply and demand situation in the manpower market but also to help young job seekers or those seeking to change jobs to know their "market value."
"Presenting a salary demand that is acceptable to the employer could help win a salary battle in the employment interview, " said Wu.

In terms of salary levels in 23 job categories, the survey results show that an employee serving in the general administration department and having seniority of less than 12 months was offered the lowest salary of NT$24,089 per month on average, while the salary for a junior construction engineer recorded the highest level at NT$37,983 per month.
After working seven or nine years, only those employed in the fields of opto- electronics and semiconductor were found to enjoy a monthly salary surpassing NT$50,000.

Wu noted that jobs requiring few professional skills, such as administration service workers, generally offered the lowest starting salaries, while in the case of the real estate sector, the relatively high salaries were a result of demand for professional skills.
He also suggested that job seekers cultivate attraction, beautification, creativity, distinctiveness and expressiveness in order to maintain their competitiveness in the employment market.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits soldiers in outlying islet of Siaociou

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited military personnel stationed on the outlying islet of Siaociou Monday to recognize their efforts two days before the Lunar New Year holiday.
Speaking to the soldiers, Chen said that he visited Wuchiu township three times after he assumed his post in 2000, but it was his first visit to Siaociou.

Siaociou is one of the two major islets that form Wuchiu township in Kinmen County, one of Taiwan's outlying islands in the Taiwan Strait. Kinmen lies closer to China's Fujian Province than to Taiwan proper and has been one of Taiwan's key defense outposts.

Chen noted that the newly inaugurated helicopter apron on Siaociou this year has greatly facilitated logistics, transportation, and the transport of medical resources for local residents and soldiers, expressing appreciation to those who helped complete the construction project.
Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu, Chief of the General Staff Huo Shou-yeh, and Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Chi-mai.

The visit to Siaociou Monday followed a trip by Chen to the Taiwan-held Taiping Island in the Spratly island chain in the South Chin Sea Saturday to inaugurate a 1,150-meter airstrip there, which Chen said was built for humanitarian purposes.

Taiping is the largest in the disputed Spratly island chain which is composed of a string of rocky outcrops possibly holding large oil and gas deposits. Besides Taiwan, five other countries -- China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei -- also claim sovereignty over the Spratlys.
Chen's Spratlys visit sparked protests from Vietnam and the Philippines.
But Chen urged all surrounding countries to jointly protect natural ecology and resources in the South China Sea rather than focusing on the exploration of natural resources in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan doctor promoting alternative method of treating liver cancer

TEXT.P: Radio frequency thermotherapy offers an alternative choice other than surgery to treat liver cancer, with each process taking only 30 minutes, a Taiwanese doctor said Sunday.
Lin Hsien-ping, a physician at Jen Ai Hospital in the central city of Taichung, said that he started using the method two years ago.
Lin said during an interview with the Central News Agency that the method can "effectively kill cancer cells without damaging normal ones."
The treatment was introduced into Taiwan a decade ago, but was not widely used as it was expensive and was not covered by the national health insurance program until in recent years, Lin said.
He noted that clinical experiences show that the treatment rarely resulted in major complications.
Citing as an example the 12 liver cancer patients who received such treatment from him, Lin said that only one could not bear with the pain caused by the treatment and thus gave it up.

Another patient had a relapse, while other patients did not experience any complications afterwards, Lin said, adding that the condition of these patients is still being monitored and they are still receiving treatment.
Lin noted that after undergoing such treatment, patients only need to stay in hospital for one day for further observation before being released.
Meanwhile, Lin also warned that radio frequency thermotherapy is not suitable for all liver cancer patients, except those who are in the early stage.
Lin explained that the treatment is better for those patients who have one tumor smaller than 5 cm, or those who have fewer than three tumors, with the largest one not bigger than 3 cm.
Taiwan has an estimated 3 million hepatitis B carriers and 600,000 hepatitis C suffers, making liver cancer one of the most common cancers in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: South-to-north march to be held to seek support for DPP candidate

TEXT.P: A local civic group promoting U.N. membership for Taiwan will organize a large- scale march from the country's south to north to solicit support for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, according to the group's spokesman.

Twu Shiing-jer, secretary-general of the U.N. for Taiwan Alliance, told the Central News Agency Sunday that many civic groups were very concerned about whether Hsieh will be able to win the March 22 election after his party's humiliating setback in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
The DPP won a mere 27 seats of the 113-seat legislature, compared with 81 seats clinched by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

For this reason, the alliance and the Hand-in-Hand to Safeguard Taiwan Alliance plan to hold a march -- which will start from Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, and end in the capital Taipei -- to consolidate and seek more general support for Hsieh, said Twu, who is also a DPP lawmaker.

The march, slated to take place between Feb. 7 and Feb. 28, is aimed at attracting more than one million people from various civic groups and the public, Twu said, adding that more details will be unveiled later this week.
Hsieh is trailing behind his rival Ma Ying-jeou from the main opposition Kuomintang, according to recent opinion polls.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 50% of laborers receive training in 2007

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of laborers in Taiwan received job-related training during 2007, according to tallies released Monday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The CLA's "living and employment situation" survey found that 54.4 percent of Taiwan laborers received some form of job training last year, representing an increasing of 4.3 percentage points over a similar survey in 2005 and a rise of 7.7 percentage points over the 2003 survey.

By category, 30.1 percent of Taiwan laborers received specialized skills training in 2007, up 11.3 percentage points over 2003, while 19.3 percent received work safety training, up 6.7 percentage points. A further 11.3 percent of laborers received interpersonal skills and communication training during the year.

All of the categories of job-related training saw increases in the number of laborers participating, including leadership and management training, which has shown a rise of 4.4 percentage points since 2003.

As to the effectiveness of the job-related training, over 90 percent of laborers participating said that the training was very useful, with 99 percent of those taking sales and customer service training saying that it was useful.
A total of 4,017 valid samples where collected in the CLA survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to promote tourism with new program

TEXT.P: The government expects to draw more foreign visitors to Taiwan in 2008 and 2009, thanks to a new promotion program integrating resources of the public and private sectors to be launched after the Chinese New Year holiday, a Tourism Bureau official said Monday.

The program, dubbed "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009," is expected to attract 4 million foreign visitors to Taiwan in 2008 and 4.25 million in 2009, with annual visitor expenditures by 2009 estimated at NT$200 billion (US$6.24 billion), the official said.
Taiwan was visited by over 3.71 million foreign tourists last year, the official continued.

The program has several major directions for implementation, including a domestic promotion project that will create a friendly travel environment and provide multilingual travel services for foreign visitors at airports and major sightseeing sites, and will encourage Taiwan residents to learn to be good hosts.

The program will also market Taiwan's traditional festivals and local cultural events such as the lantern festival, the dragon boat festival and the tung blossom season, along with in-depth travel information for different market segments, such as mountain climbing trips, wedding photo trips and nostalgia trips.

The bureau has also designed packages covering Taiwan's must-sees, must-eats and must-dos, like the Taipei 101 building in Taipei City, sampling local dishes in night markets and visiting the Taroko National Park in eastern Taiwan, with visitors assured of convenient transport.

Foreign visitors will get a variety of free gifts from the bureau, depending on the season and the bureau will also give out prize money for the first, second, third and fourth millionth foreign tourist as an incentive to encourage more people to travel to Taiwan, the official said.

A joint statement signed recently by a group of gynecologists at the hospital of Rome's University La Sapienza on saving premature fetus, even if it is against the mother's willingness, has brought about discussions in the society.

Though regulatory concerns make a bid by Google unlikely, it could play a role in bids by others.
