DOC.HEADLINE: Gas stations adjust hours for Lunar New Year holiday: CPC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-owned oil company, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will adjust the business hours of its gas stations island-wide to cope with the expected flood of traffic during the Chinese New Year holidays from Feb. 6 to Feb. 11, the company announced Monday.

According to the announcement, of the 647 CPC gas stations in the country, the 259 24-hour service stations will maintain the service hour. As for the others, stations around the tourist spots will extend their operation hours for at least one hour, while stations in the cities will reduce their hours by one to two hours.
City dwellers tend to travel to scenic areas during the holiday.
The tourist spots of the island tend to amass most of the traffic during the Lunar New Year, the largest festival in Taiwan, said a CPC official.
"On the other hand, revenue in the cities would shrink one third of the regular time due to the slow activities during the holidays, " he said.
The CPC's website offers details of each gas station's opening hours during the New Year holiday, he added.
As for the gas stations of privately-run gasoline provider Formosa Petrochemical Co. (FPCC), service hour will stay the same as usual, a FPCC official said Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Forex Monday, falling NT$0.108 to close at NT$32.070.
A total of US$1.209 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at a low of NT$32.017 and closed at the day's high of NT$32.178.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red Cross raising funds for China snowstorm relief

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China has appealed to local residents for support of its fundraising effort to help victims of China's worst snowstorm in 50 years, a Red Cross spokesman said Monday.
The storm, which has killed at least 60 people, has persisted for nearly three weeks and caused an estimated US$4.55 billion in economic losses.

The Red Cross spokesman said that the relief and rescue response to China's disaster has been overlooked because many of the reports on the storm have focused on the resulting transportation problems.

The group's effort is aimed at encouraging local residents to get into the spirit of helping those who are hungry or have nowhere to turn and allow people in China to get substantive assistance and feel the warmth of Taiwan's people, the spokesman said.
Those interested in making donations can download forms from the Red Cross' Web site, the spokesman added.

For many in China, the situation is dire, the Red Cross said. The storm has caused 140,900 houses to collapse and left 600,200 homes damaged. Over 1.61 million Chinese have been evacuated from their neighborhoods and more than 100 million acres of farmland have been impacted.

Many provinces in China's center, east, and south have been seriously affected by the bad weather, and several highways and airports were shut, leaving tens of thousand of passengers returning home for the Chinese New Year holiday stranded at various stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry seeking information on stranded Taiwanese businessmen

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang said Monday that the ministry is trying to find out about the situation of two Taiwanese businessmen in Chad who reportedly will be airlifted by China from the central African country.

Huang was responding to reports that China was in the process of airlifting 210 Chinese and two Taiwan nationals to safety in neighboring Cameroon amid heavy fighting between government and rebels forces in the nation's capital N'Djamena.
Huang noted that since Taiwan severed diplomatic ties with Chad in August 2006 following Chad's decision to forge ties with China, it has no representative offices there.
"The ministry is concerned with the situation of the two Taiwan businessmen there and will try to learn about their situation so that it can provide necessary assistance," Huang said.

The severing of ties came just hours before then-Premier Su Tseng-chang was to embark on a trip to Chad to attend the inauguration ceremony of Chad President Idriss Deby, who was re-elected to a third term in May that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma tops in bank deposits of presidential election candidates

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his wife have the highest amount in declared bank savings of any of the four couples involved in Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, according to assets disclosure reports unveiled Monday by the Central Election Commission (CEC).

Ma and his wife, Chou Mei-ching, have a total of NT$52.317 million (US$1.632 million) in bank deposits, far outstripping the just over NT$29 million declared by KMT vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew and his wife Chu Su-hsien.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his wife declared NT$12.35 million in bank savings, while running mate Su Tseng- chang and his wife, Chan Hsiou-ling, have just over NT$7 million in savings.

Su and his wife were also the only one of the four couples not to have any stock holdings or bonds, according to the joint asset disclosures, but they do have extensive property holdings, including six plots of land as well as two apartments in Taipei.
Hsieh and his wife own land and buildings or apartments in Taipei City's Zhongzheng and Zhongshan districts, Taipei County's Shihmen Township and Kaohsiung City's Sinsing and Sanmin districts.

As for the KMT candidates, Ma and Chou declared a total of six apartments, three in the Jingmei District of Taipei City and three others in Sindian City, Taipei County. Siew and his wife do not have any property holdings under their name, according to the disclosures.

The Mas and Sus did not declare any jewelry or works of art. Siew declared owning NT$2.1 million in art while his wife Chu reported having NT$6.5 million worth of jewelry. Hsieh reported owning a crystal sculpture worth NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan willing to talk with neighbors on proposed Spratly Initiative

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will negotiate with Southeast Asian nations on the disputed Spratly Islands based on a Spratly Initiative introduced Saturday by President Chen Shui-bian, Minister James Huang said Monday.

President Chen unveiled the initiative during his visit to the Taiwan-held Taiping Island, the largest in the Spratly Island archipelago in the South China Sea, that called for peaceful methods to develop the area's natural resources.

Huang said the spirit of the initiative is in line with the consistent positions of the countries that also claim sovereignty over the Spratlys, including the Philippines, Vietnam, China, Malaysia and Brunei.
"The MOFA will communicate with neighboring countries on the basis of the spirit of the initiative, " he said.

The Philippines and Vietnam protested Chen's visit to Taiping, but Huang reiterated Taiwan's sovereignty over the islet, where Taiwan has military and coast guard installations and Taiwanese-built permanent facilities.
"The so-called sovereignty disputes have been overly exaggerated," he said.

Speaking of Chen's visit to Taiping to preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a 1,150-meter runway, Huang said the visit was also aimed at extending the president's regards and concerns for personnel stationed in Taiwan's southernmost inhabited territory ahead of the Chinese New Year, which begins Thursday.
The Spratlys, located farther away from Taiwan than any other of its outlying islands, have the poorest living facilities of any Taiwan-held area, Huang said.

President Chen had expressed the hope that he would visit Taiping residents before completing his tenure in May, after visiting most of the other military bases of the country over the past seven years to show his concern for soldiers safeguarding the country, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor calls for turning airport into international one

TEXT.P: The mayor of Taiwan's third-largest city, Taichung, called Monday for an upgrading of the city's airport to turn it into an international airport to promote travel and trade.

"An upgrading for the airport, through private investment and adequate management by such world-level corporations which run Singapore's Changi Airport, Hong Kong International Airport or Thailand's Suvarnabhum Bangkok Airport, would definitely turn the airport into an international one with strong competitiveness, " said Jason Hu.
The mayor of the central Taiwan city, issued the call during a municipal meeting with city government officials.

Currently, Chingchuankang Airport serves only 28 "outbound" charter flights to Hong Kong and Macau per week -- an indication that there is still ample room for the facility to explore international service, according to Hu.

"I strongly believe that if the Evergreen Group or China Airlines were willing to invest in building a new terminal at Chingchuankang Airport, and top professional management corporations could take charge of operating the airport, it would undoubtedly become a leading international airport to better serve passengers," Hu said.
However, Hu said the central government has consistently turned a cold shoulder to his BOT (build-operate-transfer) proposal to allow private-sector investment and management in the airport.

According to Hu, he has contacted the Evergreen Group for an investment project involving building a terminal at the airport. But the Civil Aeronautics Administration under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has failed to respond to the issue positively, he said.
Air travel in central Taiwan has been hit hard since the Taichung airport was relocated in 2004 from near the city center to Chingchuangkang in neighboring Taichung County.
Carriers are keen to open new flights from the airport to overseas destinations to mitigate the adverse impact, including direct charter flights to China.
A significant number of Taiwan businessmen operating in China are from the Taichung area, where many traditional Taiwanese businesses currently are headquartered.
The many China-based Taiwan businessmen have to stop over in Hong Kong or Macau when traveling between Taiwan and China for business or family visits.
Direct shipping and airlinks between Taiwan and China are still banned following a Chinese civil war in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan expands roster ahead of Olympic baseball qualifiers

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national baseball team continued to toy with its roster Monday in its quest to find the lineup that will earn it a berth in the 2008 Olympic baseball tournament.
Manager Hung Yi-chung announced a 37-man training camp roster in prepartion for the final Olympic qualifying tournament, which will be held in Taichung and Yunlin in central Taiwan from March 3-14.
Taiwan will need to finish in the top three among eight teams in the tournament to earn the right to compete in Beijing.

"After a lengthy discussion with the coaching staff, we decided to expand the original 30-man roster to 37 as a number of young players have been playing well for the Select Team in Puerto Rico, " Hung said, referring to a team consisting of young and promising players currently training on the Caribbean island.

Expanding the roster will give Hung and his coaches a final chance to compare some of the younger players with battle-tested veterans before naming the squad's final 24-man roster for the qualifying tourney.

Taiwan finished an embarrassing eighth in the Baseball World Cup last November and finished a disappointing third in the Asian Baseball Championship last December, in which the top finisher, Japan, earned a spot in Beijing.

Although the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association failed to get permission from the New York Yankees to add Wang Chien-ming to the roster, the team will still have access to other hurlers who pitch professionally abroad.

They include Tsao Chin-hui, formerly of the Colorado Rockies and Los Angeles Dodgers who recently signed a minor league contract with the Kansas City Royals, Keng Po-hsuan, who is in the Toronto Blue Jays' farm system, and Hsu Ming-chieh and Chiang Chien-ming who pitch professionally in Japan.
The team's training camp will start Feb. 11 in Taichung, Hung said.

Taiwan's main competition in the tourney figures to comes from Australia, Mexico, South Korea and Canada, though it is unclear how much their rosters will be affected by being unable to call up U.S.-based players.
England, Spain and South Africa are not expected to pose much of a threat.
China, the United States, Cuba, the Netherlands and Japan have already booked their spots in the eight-team Olympic tournament.
The complete 37-man roster for Taiwan's national team is listed below:

Pitchers (18) : Tsao Chin-hui, Keng Po-hsuan, Lin En-yu, Hsu Ming-chieh, Chiang Chien-ming, Chang Chi-chia, Huang Jun-chung, Pan Wei-lun, Yang Chien-fu, Ni Fu- te, Lee Cheng-chang, Lee Wei-hua, Lin Po-yu, Lee Chu-kuan, Cheng Kai-wen, Lin Ke-chien, Tang Chia-jun, Huang Chih-lung.
Catchers (4): Yeh Chun-chang, Chen Feng-min, Kao Chih-kang, Lin Kun-sheng.
Infielders (9): Kao Kuo-ching, Yang Sen, Chang Tai-shan, Peng Cheng-min, Wang Sheng-wei, Lin Chih-sheng, Chiang Chih-hsien, Lin Yi-chuan, Chang Chien-ming.
Outfielders (6): Chen Chin-feng, Hsieh Chia-hsien, Lo Kuo-hui, Lin Che-hsuan, Chung Chen-yu, Chan Chi-yao.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese feel personal finances worsened in 2007: poll

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwan's salaried workers felt that their personal finances worsened in 2007, while over 30 percent said they had a second job, according to a poll conducted by a local manpower company.

In results of the survey released Monday by JCASE, an outsourcing and recruitment agency, nearly 66 percent of respondents complained of their "very poor" or "poor" economic situation, while 24 percent described their financial situation as "average."
Only 10 percent described themselves as "well off" or "rich."

Compared to their 2006 economic condition, 64.3 percent felt they had grown poorer, while 31.4 percent thought it was "about the same, " the survey found. Only 4.3 percent felt that they had become "richer."

Nearly 65 percent of those surveyed who felt they were worse off in 2007 attributed their financial plight to "soaring prices, " with other factors such as "insufficient incomes, " "excessive expenses" and "having credit card or bank loans, " also being cited by many respondents.

To tackle their monetary shortage, 34.2 percent of the respondents said they "have held an additional job or are in the process of getting one, "while 53.5 percent said they "were thinking of getting a second job to earn extra money," the survey found.
Only 12.3 percent said they "do not have a second job and are not thinking about getting one."
According to the poll results, Taiwan's moonlighters can earn an additional NT$22,000 per month on average.

Inputing data, writing for special projects, doing subcontracted odd jobs at home, and serving as convenience store clerks or part-timers at fast food chains, are the most popular part-time jobs among local moonlighters, the survey indicated.
The random online survey was conducted between Jan. 14-30, with 1,158 valid questionnaires received out of 5,000 sent. It had a margin of error of plus/minus 2.88 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan urged to correct misidentification of Taiwan sovereignty
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/04/08 23:00:49 (By Mike Chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Supporters of Taiwan in Japan called on Japanese businesses and people Sunday to boycott any product or action that belittles Taiwan.

They were referring to companies making globes portraying Taiwan as part of China and the Japanese government's inclusion of Taiwan as part of China in its geography textbooks and foreigners' registration certificates.

They issued the call at a meeting in Tokyo to protest against Tokyo-based Gakken Toys Co. for "belittling" Taiwan by portraying Taiwan as a part of China in its toy globes. The company has said it did so at the insistence of Beijing.

Participants at the meeting -- organized by three different groups and attended by Taiwanese expatriates and sympathetic Japanese -- raised objections to not only the toy globes but a Web site set up by Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs which displays Taiwan as a part of China.

Participants indicated that the Japanese government should be held responsible for disseminating incorrect information which describes Taiwan as a Chinese territory in geography textbooks, and for mistakenly entering the nationality of Taiwanese expatriates as "China" in their alien registration certificates.
Meeting attendees passed a resolution demanding that Japan correct all of the "misleading" and "false statements" disseminated over past decades.
The resolution said that "the sale and spread of the incorrect globes is related to Japan's decision to curry favor with China."

In the statement, participants also urged Japan's foreign ministry, Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology and Ministry of Justice to correct the errors, while calling on the public to stage protests against the agencies in question until those corrections are made.
The meeting was organized three Japan-based organizations -- the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association in Japan, the Taiwan Research Forum and an online magazine "The Voice of Taiwan."
The Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association is a group linked to former Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui, which aims to promote friendly relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Gakken Toys Co. has announced it will shut down by the end of March after taking a string of actions to apologize for its mistake and recalling its products in the face of widespread criticism in early January over the globes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese New Year mini-links service sets daily record for passengers

TEXT.P: A total of 3,103 passengers traveled between Taiwan-held Kinmen Island and two ports in China's Fujian province Monday, setting a new daily high for the expanded mini-links service set up last week to accommodate Chinese New Year travelers, according to the Kinmen harbor bureau.

With only two days left before the Chinese New Year, 2,058 passengers coming from the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Quanzhou entered Kinmen's Shuitou Port, including two Taiwanese patients suffering from brain hemorrhages, while 1,045 departed from Kinmen to the opposite side, port statistics showed.

The 3,000-plus passengers represented the highest daily level since Kinmen authorities launched a special program Jan. 29 to handle a surge in travelers during the peak period prior to the Feb. 7 Chinese New Year.

Over the past week, a total of 17,466 passengers have traveled between Kinmen and the two ports in Fujian province, with 10,442 coming from China and 7,042 heading for the Chinese side, Kinmen harbor bureau director Chang Kuo-tu said.
Most of the China-bound travelers are Chinese spouses or family members of Taiwanese citizens.
Special Lunar New Year charter flights have been put in place across the Taiwan Strait to fly China-based Taiwanese businessmen home ahead of the holiday, a period of peak demand.

Chang said, however, that the mini links service is still important to travelers sailing between the two sides, in particular to those from Taiwan's central region, due to its cheaper cost and shorter travel time.
"The number of passengers traveling via the mini links is expected to further pick up in the last two days before the start of the new year, " Chang predicted.
He said Shuitou port authorities have stepped up services to help travelers pass through immigration checkpoints more quickly.

The mini links -- direct trade and transport services between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and Fujian's Xiamen, Fuzhou and Quanzhou ports -- were initiated Jan. 2001 to offset the lack of such links between Taiwan proper and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign exchange reserves hit record high

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit a new record in January, but still dropped a notch in the world rankings to fifth, said Lin Sun-yuan, deputy director-general of the central bank's Department of Foreign Exchange Monday.
Lin said January's foreign currency reserves reached US$272.82 billion, increasing by US$2.51 billion over last December's figure.
China topped the world rankings with US$1.53 trillion in foreign reserves last December, the last month for which data there was available, Lin said.
It was followed by Japan, Russia, and India, which surpassed Taiwan for the first time with US$279.5 billion in reserves.

Taiwan's increasing foreign exchange reserves last month resulted from interest income, net incoming foreign investment, and the appreciation of major currencies such as the euro and Japanese yen against the dollar, Lin said.
The euro and the Japanese Yen rose against the dollar by 0.22 percent and 5.03 percent, respectively, from the end of last December to the end of January, Lin said.

South Korea, one of the other members of the traditional four Asian Tigers along with Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong, remained just behind Taiwan with US$261.8 billion in foreign reserves at the end of January.
Singapore and Hong Kong had foreign reserves of US$163.6 billion and US$146.9 billion respectively at the end of December, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 CPC staff reach Cameroon safely from Chad

TEXT.P: Two engineers working for Taiwan's state-run oil company CPC Corp., Taiwan in Chad have safely reached neighboring Cameroon amid clashes between government forces and rebels in the capital of the central African country, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Monday.
Earlier media reports said China was in the process of airlifting 200-plus Chinese people and two Taiwanese businessmen in Chad to Cameroon.

Yeh said, however, that the report was not correct. The two Taiwanese citizens in Chad were CPC employees, not ordinary businessmen and drove to neighboring Cameroon on their own without China's help.

Since Chad switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August 2006, Taiwan has not maintained an office there. Nevertheless, CPC staff have continued working there to fulfill a contract signed by the company and the Chadian government on oil exploration in the central African country.

Taiwan was forced to announce an end to diplomatic ties with Chad just hours before then-Premier Su Tseng-chang was to embark on a trip to Chad to attend the inauguration ceremony of Chad President Idriss Deby, who was re-elected to a third term in May that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate calls for rejection of China's intervention in poll

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh on Monday called on his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, to join him in opposing China's interference in Taiwan's presidential election.
Hsieh complained that Chinese state-run air carriers are offering 40 percent discounts on airfares ahead of the March 22 election to encourage China-based Taiwanese businessmen to return to vote.
Many believe most of the business community based across the Taiwan Strait is likely to support Ma.
"Such an election will not be fair, " said Hsieh at an autograph session for his new book "Viva Taiwan! Frank Hsieh's Commitment to Taiwan's Renewal" in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
He asked Ma to openly reject China's interference with Taiwan's businessmen and in Taiwan's election.
Ma, for his part, said Monday that Taiwan's democracy will not allow intervention from anyone, adding that if China factors in the March 22 presidential election, he'll strongly condemn it.
He would not acknowledge media reports, however, that Taiwanese businessmen operating in China overwhelmingly back him, saying, "that is not necessarily the case."
Ma said that as far as he knows, if the number of Taiwan businessmen returning to Taiwan is large enough, they should be able to get cheaper group fares.
Hsieh also tried to draw a distinction between the more open cross-strait policies of the two presidential contenders, saying he would insist on Taiwan's sovereignty and opposed a full opening.
He also said that he agreed to the opening of Chinese capital to invest in Taiwan's residential and commercial property market, but stressed he is opposed to speculation in real estate.

Taiwanese enterprises' investment in China should also not exceed 40 percent of their net worth, he added, although on previous occasions he has said the policy could be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

Hsieh claimed that Ma's support for a cross-strait common market will result in a loss of jobs for local workers, lower prices and dwindling markets for Taiwan's agricultural products, and a rise in smuggled goods into the country.

Hsieh's campaign team first voiced its concerns Sunday over China's influence on the election when it displayed a notification issued Jan. 28 by the China-based Taiwan Compatriot Investment Enterprises Association that Chinese state-run carriers are providing Taiwan businessmen with cheap plane tickets to return to Taiwan to vote.
Campaign staffers said Monday that the top officials of the association are currently the top brass of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office under its State Council.
Hsiao Bi-khim, former DPP legislator and a Hsieh spokeswoman, said the association's honorary chairman, Chen Yunlin, is the director of Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO).

The association's vice chairman and secretary-general He Shizhong is the director of TAO's Economic Bureau under the Taiwan Affairs Office. Its adviser Zheng Lizhong is TAO's deputy director. Another adviser Li Bingcai is the vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, he said.
Hsiao said that the association is "obviously a group orchestrated by Chinese authorities."
Hsiao pointed out that the association's offer of discount tickets will only be offered between March 1 and March 22 for returning to Taiwan, and back to China after March 22.
Hsiao said that China's subsidizing its air carriers to mobilize Taiwan businessmen to return to Taiwan shows its "brazen political intention."

A KMT official said Monday Taiwanese associations' deals with China's state- owned air carriers is "strictly business, " and asked Hsieh's team to apologize for attempting to smear Taiwan's businessmen operating in China for being in the 'same league" with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: This year is not especially cold: CWB

TEXT.P: The recent prolonged cold spell in Taiwan has prompted some to wonder if this is the is coldest winter ever, but a weather forecaster dismissed the idea Monday.
Wu Teh-jung, forecasting director of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , said that the average temperature in January was in fact the eighth warmest in history.

Wu said that although several cold spells hit Taiwan last month, only northern and northeastern Taiwan were affected. The average temperature in January was close to the normal temperature recorded for that month.
The average temperature in central and southern Taiwan was even higher than usual, he added.
Wu said the public has become so accustomed to warm winters in recent years that even if the cold weather falls within a normal level, people still feel cold.
According to CWB records, Chinese New Year's Eve in 2004, which fell on Jan. 21, was also very cold, with the mercury dropping to 8.1 degrees Celsius. The mercury dipped to 6.8 C Jan. 24 that year.

But from 2005 to 2007, the lows during Chinese New Year holidays all exceeded 10 C. The public may have to brace for a cold Chinese New Year holiday this year, with the bureau forecasting that the temperature will drop to 8 C.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 5, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1596: Japanese Shogun Hideyoshi Toyotomi puts 26 Catholic converts to death in Nagasaki after he banned Christianity earlier in the year.
1792: Tippo of Mysore, India is defeated and cedes half of Mysore to the British.
1788: Sir Robert Peel, British prime minister and founder of the Metropolitan Police, is born.
1900: Adlai Stevenson, American statesman and ambassador whose liberal views caused him trouble during the McCarthy witch hunts, is born.
1914: Andreas Papandreou, Greek prime minister, is born.
1917: Mexico becomes a federated republic of 28 states.
1922: The first issue of the U.S. magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and U.S. troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: U.S. President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops in withdrawing from the island of Tachen, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Executive Yuan adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1962: President Charles de Gaulle of France calls for independence for Algeria.
1971: U.S. Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1974: Thirteen-year-old Mats Wermelin of Sweden scores all 272 points in a basketball game.
1976: A major earthquake rocks Guatemala, killing nearly 23,000 people.
1977: Brazilian soccer star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1990: Rafael Calderon Fournier wins the presidential election in Costa Rica.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
1997: Switzerland's three banking giants announce the creation of a 100 million Swiss franc Holocaust memorial fund.
1999: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and his wife Hiromi Kabua arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1999: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou awards a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Transit Ambassador," which includes the right to travel on the Taipei MRT for free for the rest of his life.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something from the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of Taiwanese feel personal finances worsened in 2007: poll

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Taiwan's salaried workers felt that their personal finances worsened in 2007, while over 30 percent said they had a second job, according to a poll conducted by a local manpower company.

In results of the survey released Monday by JCASE, an outsourcing and recruitment agency, nearly 66 percent of respondents complained of their "very poor" or "poor" economic situation, while 24 percent described their financial situation as "average."
Only 10 percent described themselves as "well off" or "rich."

Compared to their 2006 economic condition, 64.3 percent felt they had grown poorer, while 31.4 percent thought it was "about the same, " the survey found. Only 4.3 percent felt that they had become "richer."

Nearly 65 percent of those surveyed who felt they were worse off in 2007 attributed their financial plight to "soaring prices, " with other factors such as "insufficient incomes, " "excessive expenses" and "having credit card or bank loans, " also being cited by many respondents.

To tackle their monetary shortage, 34.2 percent of the respondents said they "have held an additional job or are in the process of getting one, "while 53.5 percent said they "were thinking of getting a second job to earn extra money," the survey found.
Only 12.3 percent said they "do not have a second job and are not thinking about getting one."
According to the poll results, Taiwan's moonlighters can earn an additional NT$22,000 per month on average.

Inputing data, writing for special projects, doing subcontracted odd jobs at home, and serving as convenience store clerks or part-timers at fast food chains, are the most popular part-time jobs among local moonlighters, the survey indicated.
The random online survey was conducted between Jan. 14-30, with 1,158 valid questionnaires received out of 5,000 sent. It had a margin of error of plus/minus 2.88 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan urged to correct misidentification of Taiwan sovereignty
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/05/08 10:53:51 (By Mike Chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Supporters of Taiwan in Japan called on Japanese businesses and people Sunday to boycott any product or action that belittles Taiwan.

They were referring to companies making globes portraying Taiwan as part of China and the Japanese government's inclusion of Taiwan as part of China in its geography textbooks and foreigners' registration certificates.

They issued the call at a meeting in Tokyo to protest against Tokyo-based Gakken Toys Co. for "belittling" Taiwan by portraying Taiwan as a part of China in its toy globes. The company has said it did so at the insistence of Beijing.

Participants at the meeting -- organized by three different groups and attended by Taiwanese expatriates and sympathetic Japanese -- raised objections to not only the toy globes but a Web site set up by Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs which displays Taiwan as a part of China.

Participants indicated that the Japanese government should be held responsible for disseminating incorrect information which describes Taiwan as a Chinese territory in geography textbooks, and for mistakenly entering the nationality of Taiwanese expatriates as "China" in their alien registration certificates.
Meeting attendees passed a resolution demanding that Japan correct all of the "misleading" and "false statements" disseminated over past decades.
The resolution said that "the sale and spread of the incorrect globes is related to Japan's decision to curry favor with China."

In the statement, participants also urged Japan's foreign ministry, Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology and Ministry of Justice to correct the errors, while calling on the public to stage protests against the agencies in question until those corrections are made.
The meeting was organized three Japan-based organizations -- the Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association in Japan, the Taiwan Research Forum and an online magazine "The Voice of Taiwan."
The Friends of Lee Teng-hui Association is a group linked to former Taiwanese President Lee Teng-hui, which aims to promote friendly relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Gakken Toys Co. has announced it will shut down by the end of March after taking a string of actions to apologize for its mistake and recalling its products in the face of widespread criticism in early January over the globes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 CPC staff reach Cameroon safely from Chad

TEXT.P: Two engineers working for Taiwan's state-run oil company CPC Corp., Taiwan in Chad have safely reached neighboring Cameroon amid clashes between government forces and rebels in the capital of the central African country, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Monday.
Earlier media reports said China was in the process of airlifting 200-plus Chinese people and two Taiwanese businessmen in Chad to Cameroon.

Yeh said, however, that the report was not correct. The two Taiwanese citizens in Chad were CPC employees, not ordinary businessmen and drove to neighboring Cameroon on their own without China's help.

Since Chad switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in August 2006, Taiwan has not maintained an office there. Nevertheless, CPC staff have continued working there to fulfill a contract signed by the company and the Chadian government on oil exploration in the central African country.

Taiwan was forced to announce an end to diplomatic ties with Chad just hours before then-Premier Su Tseng-chang was to embark on a trip to Chad to attend the inauguration ceremony of Chadian President Idriss Deby, who was re-elected to a third term in May that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: This winter is not especially cold: CWB

TEXT.P: The recent prolonged cold spell in Taiwan has prompted some to wonder if this is the coldest winter ever, but a weather forecaster dismissed the idea Monday.
Wu Teh-jung, forecasting director of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) , said that the average temperature in January was in fact the eighth warmest in history.

Wu said that although several cold spells hit Taiwan last month, only northern and northeastern Taiwan were affected. The average temperature in January was close to the normal temperature recorded for that month.
The average temperature in central and southern Taiwan was even higher than usual, he added.
Wu said the public has become so accustomed to warm winters in recent years that even if the cold weather falls within a normal level, people still feel cold.
According to CWB records, Chinese New Year's Eve in 2004, which fell on Jan. 21, was also very cold, with the mercury dropping to 8.1 degrees Celsius. The mercury dipped to 6.8 C Jan. 24 that year.

But from 2005 to 2007, the lows during Chinese New Year holidays all exceeded 10 C. The public may have to brace for a cold Chinese New Year holiday this year, with the bureau forecasting that the temperature will drop to 8 C.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president confirms rejection of talks proposal by China
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 3 (CNA) 02/05/08 12:03:51 (By Mike Chang and Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait talks were made impossible by former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui in the mid-1990s due to his displeasure over China's attempts to interfere in Taiwan's democratization movement, according to a recent Japanese news agency report.

Lee was quoted by Kyodo News -- a Japan-based nonprofit cooperative news agency -- as having confirmed recently that there was indeed a chance for him to meet with his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, during the 1990s.
There was speculation at the time that Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Jung-fa tried to arrange for Lee and Jiang to hold talks aboard a vessel sailing in the Taiwan Strait.
But the Kyodo report marks the first time Lee has confirmed the authenticity of the rumors surrounding the proposed talks.
Lee rejected the proposal because he was afraid that if he had met with Jiang, he might have to compromise on the democratic reforms he was pushing at the time, the Japanese news agency said.
His decision was also triggered partly by his irritation over China's attempts to manipulate Taiwan's democratization movement, the report said.
Some analysts are of the opinion that Lee's rejection of the proposal contributed to the worsening ties between Taipei and Beijing in the latter part of the decade.

To show its displeasure with Lee, China launched three ballistic missiles on March 8, 1996 -- part of a week-long missile testing program -- that landed just off Taiwan's northern and southern coasts.

Beijing acknowledged the move was to intimidate Taiwan's voters ahead of the country's first direct presidential election on March 23, and persuade them not to vote for Lee. The former president won the election with an absolute majority, however, against three other high-profile rivals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Worshipping the gods in Taiwan moves to cyberspace

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporters
Taipei, Feb. 5 (CNA) Hordes of Taiwanese commonly swarm to temples around Taiwan before and during the Lunar New Year to pray for good luck.
But now with the help of technology, those seeking the attention of local deities can use the Internet, ATM machines and even cell phones to connect with the gods.

Several telecommunication companies, banks and convenience stores have launched "virtual lantern-lighting" and "virtual Taishuei- pacifying" services that enable people too busy to visit temples in person to still perform the rituals.

Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan Mobile, Far Eastone Telecom and Asia Pacific Telecom are working with the 300-year-old Mazu Temple in Lugang, Changhua County, to provide the service, while 3G telecommunication company VIBO is cooperating with the Hsinkang Feng-Tien Temple of Chiayi City in southern Taiwan.
The companies are seeking to capitalize on local adherence to Taoist tradition, in which "pacifying Taishuei" and "lighting the lantern" are indispensable rituals.

Taishuei is the title of the god whose constellation is designated as the monarch of a particular year of the Chinese zodiac, and who must be pacified by people born in certain years if they want to avoid bad luck.
In the coming Year of the Rat, people born under the sign of the rat or horse are considered to have offended the Taishuei and must therefore pacify Ying Ban, the Taishuei of 2008.
Lighting lanterns, such as the "Lantern of Light, " "Safety Lantern, " and "Education Lantern, " are thought to bring health, honor, and a brighter future.

Worshipers need only use their mobile phones to log on to the Internet and enter their name, birth date, and address to pacify Taishuei or light a lantern. Fending off the rage of Taishuei costs NT$600 while the cost of lighting lanterns depends on the temple. The Mazu temple in Lugang charges NT$600 to light a "Lantern of Light."

Customers of Far Eastern International Bank and Chinatrust Commercial Bank can use the companies' Web sites or ATM machines to perform the ritual, while others can fill out the appropriate forms available at convenience stores and submit them by fax or via the Internet.

Lu Ming Sen, chairman of the Feng-Tien, said that technology enables people from all over the world to worship the gods and pray for good luck, and it is just as effective as visiting the temple in person.
"No matter where you are, hold to your faith and the gods will bless you," he said.
For most traditionalists, going to temples to experience the entire process of pacifying Taishuei or lighting a lantern are very important events.
Ting Feng-chun, a worshiper at the famous Longshan Temple, located in Taipei's Wanhua district, said she came to pacify Taishuei on behalf of her son and herself.

"I have faith in the effectiveness of the Bodhisattva enshrined here, " Ting said, explaining that her son experienced the power of divine intervention by surviving a gunshot wound while serving in the army.

Longshan Temple, a well-established Buddhist temple founded in 1738, is the most popular place for pacifying Taishuei in Taipei as well as a local cultural landmark. The government designated the temple as a second grade historical site in 1985 to ensure that it would be permanently preserved.
The temple is not offering online services, however, not because it feels virtual worship is not legitimate, but because of the fear that the temple is not equipped to cope with the demand.

Chang Hsue-lin, the director of Longshan Temple affairs, said that the temple had to limit applications to pacify Taishuei to 1,000 per day due to the difficulties of processing the massive number of applications.
"Although the temple considered launching a Web site for people to apply online, concerns about the security and accuracy of personal information made us dismiss the idea," she said.

"Besides, if we allowed people to pacify Taishuei by applying through the Internet, all of the openings might be fully booked within one day, which is not fair for those who come to the temple personally, " she added.

Chang said Longshan Temple's 100,000 lanterns of light have all been sold to devotees, but for those who still want to light a lamp, the temple will set up two colossal Safety Lanterns on Chinese New Year Eve open to the general public.
The service is free and will last from Feb. 6 to March 26, Kuan Yin Bodhisattva's birthday, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local airlines seek expansion of cross-strait charter services

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's airlines industry proposed Tuesday that the government further expand cross-Taiwan Strait charter services, which they said have already proven successful in previous limited runs with passenger load factors of up to 80 percent.
The representatives suggested that the frequency of cross-strait passenger and cargo charters and the destinations they serve be expanded to serve more customers.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) officials responded to the proposal by noting that any plan to augment service would need to be arranged through negotiations with Chinese authorities.
The ministry said it would work out the technical details involved if the Cabinet arrives at a policy to expand the services.

Cross-strait passenger charter flights were first launched in 2003 to transport China-based Taiwanese businesspeople and their families home for the Chinese New Year holiday and back to China after that.
The services were expanded in 2006 to cover the Mid Autumn Festival and further in 2007 to cover two more holidays, the Tomb Sweeping Festival and the Dragon Boat Festival.
Expanding the number of non-stop flights between Taiwan and China has been a major point of emphasis of the local business community.

Local airlines, facing declining passenger numbers at home with the advent of the high-speed railway, are looking for new lucrative routes, while businesspeople would like to avoid the extra time and expense of traveling to China on business through a third point, usually Hong Kong or Macau.
There have been no regularly scheduled non-stop flights between Taiwan and China in nearly 60 years.
According to MOTC figures, a total of 192 flights carried 37,445 passengers during the 2007 Chinese New Year period from Feb. 5 to March 5, with a passenger load factor of 81.06 percent.
For the Tomb Sweeping Festival period that ran from March 29 to April 12, there were a total of 42 flights with a total of 7,000 passengers, with the passenger load factor reaching 75 percent.
For the Dragon Boat Festival period that ran from June 15 to June 22, a total of 42 flights carried 6,500 passengers, with a load factor of 74 percent.
The Mid Autumn Festival charter period, from Sept. 21 to Sept. 30, saw a total of 48 flights carry 8,500 passengers, with a passenger load factor of 78 percent.
In terms of cross-strait cargo charters, Taiwan's China Airlines operated a total of five flights last year on Dec. 12, Dec. 18, Dec. 24, Dec. 27 and Dec. 29.

As for emergency charter services, Taiwan's TransAsia Airways and China's Deer Jet provided 20 flights and four flights, respectively, to deliver Taiwanese patients from China back to Taiwan for medical treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Far East U. ranks 1st in patent application, approvals for 2007

TEXT.P: Far East University ranked first among all universities and colleges in the nation in terms of number of patent applications and patent approvals for 2007, according to the latest statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Intellectual Property Office (IPO).
It marked the fifth straight year that the Taipei County-based university finished at the top of the list in both categories.
Far East University applied for a total of 258 patents in 2007, ranking it first among all institutions of higher learning and 11th among all organizations, including companies, in Taiwan.
The university received a total of 78 patent approvals, ranking first among colleges and universities and 25th among all organizations in the country.
A total of 19 universities and colleges finished on the top 100 list in Taiwan in terms of patent applications, up from just 13 the previous year, according to the IPO figures.

Far East University officials said that the school's strong performance in terms of patent applications and approvals is in large part the result of efforts to promote innovation made by university President Wang Yuan-jen, Vice President Chung Ming-chi, as well as Chen Yu-gang, head of the school's Innovation and Creativity Center.

The officials added that thanks to their efforts, the university was even able to outpace several of the nation's top high-tech companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., United Microelectronics and Advanced Semiconductor Enginnering, in total number of patent applications and patent approvals for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: GPS devices susceptible to interference in thunderstorms: research

TEXT.P: Researchers have proved that global positioning systems (GPS) are susceptible to interference from thunderstorms and warned against their use in extreme weather conditions because they may provide inaccurate information, the local media reported Tuesday.

Lin Chien-Hung, an assistant professor at the Plasma and Space Sciences Center of National Cheng Kung University, said the strong atmospheric convections in a thunderstorm can create atmospheric oscillations, or tides, that rise to 90-120 kilometers above ground, just under the ionosphere.
Ions from the tides accumulate at that level and can potentially interfere with electromagnetic waves.

When the transmission of electromagnetic wave is impeded, Lin explained, signals from GPS satellites to GPS devices on the ground will be distorted, causing a phenomenon dubbed "GPS confusion, " in which the device shows inaccurate directions instead.

"Some of my friends told me weird stories of using the GPS guiding devices in thunderstorms, " Lin said. "They hoped the machine could lead them out of the mountain areas under heavy rain. But in the end, even though they followed exactly the directions given by GPS devices, they found themselves trapped in the middle of nowhere."
Lin said such stories inspired him to do further research into the reasons behind the strange phenomemon.

Using the data collected by FORMOSAT-3, a climate satellite launched and operated by the government-funded National Space Organization and its academic partners in the United States, Lin analyzed atmospheric variations during thunderstorms and observed how atmospheric tides created disruptions in electromagnetic waves.

Lin said that based on the data gathered by an IMAGE satellite in 2002, the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration has listed four areas on the Earth as equatorial regions with anomalies in ionospheric activities, including the Amazon valley in South America, the Congo River valley in Africa, tropical rain forests in Indonesia, and mid-Pacific regions where most tropical storms form.
"Taiwan is in the mid-Pacific region, where a thunderstorm near the ground will disturb the upper atmosphere and later the functions of GPS," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to launch workshops for human resource development

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (TaiwanICDF) will jointly organize 11 workshops to help the country's diplomatic allies in developing their human resources, a MOFA official announced Tuesday.

"This plan aims at sharing the experience of Taiwan, helping our allies and other friends cultivate the human resources necessary for developing a country's domestic infrastructure, economy, and society, " said Paul Lee, first secretary of MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.

Topics for the 11 workshops will include "World Trade Organization Trade Facilitation, " "Narrowing the Digital Divide, " "Taiwan's Experience in Environmental Protection, " and "Women's Development."

"The women's development workshop, a continuation of previous programs, is one of eight Millennium Development Goals of the United Nations, while the workshop on environmental protection, which has become a global issue, is a new initiative," Lee explained.

The International Cooperation and Development Fund, a nonprofit organization under the direction of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs founded in 1996, has launched many workshops to strengthen international cooperation and enhance Taiwan's foreign relations by promoting economic development, social progress and the welfare of the people in partner nations around the world.
Lee said estimates indicate that 300 government officials and professionals from all over the world will participate in this year's program.
At the press briefing, Lee also noted that Taiwan's booths in the "2008 African Agricultural, Irrigation, and Husbandry Exhibition" held in Burkina Faso Jan. 28 received great attention.

With trade relations growing between Taiwan and Burkina Faso, one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in West Africa, the MOFA dispatched a delegation of 17 people, including civilian enterprises, to take part in the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE to spend NT$200 million on lockers for elementary students

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Tuesday that it plans to appropriate NT$200 million (US$5.05 million) over the next three years to install lockers in elementary schools as part of its "lighter schoolbag" campaign.

Without access to lockers or other storage space, some local elementary students generally take all their books and other possessions home with them every day. The overloaded bookbags have been found to harm the spines of young students.

Compounding the problem, information collected from various cities and counties in 2005 showed that the lower the levels of elementary students, the less likely they were to use bookbags that met applicable standards, the officials said.
As a result, the ministry plans to appropriate NT$50 million each year between 2008 and 2011 to install lockers for the first- and second-graders in city and county schools.

In addition, the ministry will promote its "lighter schoolbag" campaign by asking city and county governments to urge parents to check the bags of their children regularly and encourage their children to make good use of the lockers in schools so that the bags are not weighed down by unnecessary items.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Lottery raises Super Lotto holiday jackpot to NT$290m

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Lottery Co. (TLC) has raised the jackpot for Thursday's Super Lotto draw to NT$290 million (US$9.07 million) in order to boost ticket sales during the Chinese New Year holiday.
TLC officials said that if nobody wins the top prize, the jackpot will continue to grow until someone finally wins.
The TLC launched the Super Lotto in January as part of its efforts to break even for this year after reporting nearly NT$350 million in losses for 2007.
The guaranteed minimum of the Super Lotto's jackpot prize is usually NT$250 million, though the amount has been raised for Thursday's draw in celebration of the holiday season.
TLC officials said that tickets will be on sale between 1 p.m. and 9 p.m. on weekdays at lottery outlets around the island during the holiday period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA urges people to be alert when traveling overseas

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Tuesday urged those who plan to travel overseas to remain alert while in foreign countries, and requested that its embassies and representative offices keep their emergency lines open during the Lunar New Year holiday, according to the MOFA's press release.

The MOFA also advised people to ensure that their passports are valid for at least six months, and that they have valid visas, travel insurance and overseas medical insurance. Travelers should also stay alert, watch over their personal belongings, and not carry contraband goods.
Travelers can log on to the Web site of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs at www.boca.gov.tw for further information.

In case of emergency, such as car accident, robbery or when one's personal safety is endangered, overseas citizens can seek assistance from the nearest Republic of China (Taiwan) embassy, consulate and representative office by calling the 24-hour toll free number 800-0885-0885.
For emergency assistance in Taipei, people can call emergency phone lines 886-3-3932628, 886-3-398-2629, and 886-3-3834849.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transportation during new year holiday to be smoother: Premier

TEXT.P: After a touring Taipei Main Station Tuesday morning, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung gave assurances that railway transportation during Chinese New Year holiday will be smoother than in previous years.

Accompanied by Cabinet Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun and Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei, the premier was briefed by directors of the Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) and the Bureau of High Speed Rail (HSR) about transportation during New Year Holiday.
"The HSR will provide additional services to benefit 100,000 passengers a day during the holiday season, " Chang affirmed, adding that operations will be smoother than in the past.
The Chinese New Year holiday, which begin Feb. 7 this year, are traditionally an occasion for family reunions and the busiest period for the nation's transportation networks.
Chang also presented cash bonuses to TRA and HSR staff to compensate them for their sacrifices during the holidays.
According to HSR, the number of daily runs have been increased from 114 to 126 on peak days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Mayor gives Lunar New Year money to kids in need

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu and the city's Gang Du Cable TV President Chang Han-wei presented Lunar New Year gift money to 60 disadvantaged elementary students at city hall Tuesday, signifying that the city's government and industries care for those in need.

The activity, organized by the media company, is among a series of social welfare activities the company has planned for the year to bring warmth to disadvantaged families and help poor children grow up healthily and happily.
"Kaohsiung is a city full of love and warmth and nobody in the city should feel lonely," Chen said, adding that the city government will continue to help people facing life's difficulties.

Kaohsiung City's Social Affairs Bureau also gave Lunar New Year gift money to a total of 995 kids from the city's disadvantaged families a day earlier, with funds of NT$600,000 (US$18,737) raised by 10 local social welfare organizations.
Hsu Chuan-sheng, director-general of the bureau, said each child received a red envelope containing NT$600.

A survey conducted by the Child Welfare League Foundation showed that the biggest dream of kids from disadvantaged families is to receive Lunar New Year gift money, Hsu said, adding that the city's activity is designed to make their dreams come true.

According to Hsu, the Kaohsiung City government gave Spring Festival consolation money to the city's 7,400-plus low income families. But he also said that many families awaiting help were not reached by the city government.

Hsu reminded those who face difficulties in life to dial "1957"--the exclusive line for social welfare affairs--for immediate help from the city government. He emphasized that the hotline will remain open during the Chinese New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free buses to Alishan forest park to run on Lunar New Year holiday

TEXT.P: Free shuttle buses to southern Taiwan's Alishan National Forest Recreation Area will be provided during the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday to relieve the expected heavy traffic flow, officials at the Forestry Bureau said Tuesday.

The shuttle buses will depart around 5 kilometers outside the national park's main entrance, where temporary parking lots will be set up for visitors, the officials from the Chiayi Forest District Office said.

The service will run between 8 a.m. and 4: 30 p.m. on Feb. 7, the first day of the new year, and between 3: 30 a.m. and 4: 30 p.m. on Feb. 8-11, with one bus departing every 20 minutes and one stop available every 500 meters along the route, they said.

To encourage visitors to use the shuttle service instead of driving directly into the recreation area, passengers who take the shuttle buses will enjoy a discount on their entrance tickets to the park.

The scenic mountain, located in the southern county of Chiayi, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Taiwan, offering the famous breathtaking sunrise, serene mountain landscape as well as ancient trees.
The park draws approximately 700,000 visitors every year, or an average of more than 1,900 visitors per day.

During peak periods such as the Chinese New Year holiday, the cherry blossom season between March and April and the summer vacation, the number of visitors can exceed 10,000 per day, according to tallies from the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration.
