La Repubblica: Marini quits, elections loom.
Italian Senate Speaker Franco Marini abandoned the mission assigned by President Giorgio Napolitano to seek support for an interim government tasked with approving a new electoral law. General elections appeared to be certain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan strives to win development contract in Saudi Arab

TEXT.P: Taiwan's executive branch of government has pledged to intensify it efforts to bid for a contract to develop an industrial zone in Saudi Arab as part of a new push to tap business opportunities in the Middle E, a top economics official said Tuesday.

"A work plan for the project is slated to be completed by the end of February, " said Fadah Hsieh, vice minister of the Executive Yuan's Ministry of Economic Affairs, while giving a briefing about his recent fact-finding trip to the country.
The government will collaborate with Taiwanese companies to jointly bid for the multimillion dollar project.

In late January, Hsieh led a delegation comprising of representatives from 11 local companies to Saudi Arabia to attend the 20th Session of the Saudi- Taiwan Joint Committee for Economic and Technical Cooperation.

During the meeting, the oil rich country which is trying to diversify its economy showed great interest in Taiwan's photovoltaic, nano and information technologies and medical and health care industries. Saudi Arabia also expressed hope in strengthening bilateral technology exchanges and intensifying existing vocational training programs between the two countries, Hsieh said.
While the delegation invited Saudi Arabia to invest in Taiwan, it also urged the wealthy Middle East country to increase imports of Taiwanese products to bridge Taiwan's trade deficit.
After the session, Hsieh made an inspection tour of the King Abdullah Economic City, the first completed city of the six economic cities which Saudi Arabia wants to build in coming years.

The King Abdullah Economic City is located about 170 km north of the commercial hub of Jeddah, which will be developed based on the division of industrial, residential, recreational and harbor zones, Hsieh noted.
"Most of the development projects in the economic city have already been assigned to contractors, " Hsieh said.
"What Taiwan is eying is a development deal of the economic city's industrial zone, but the investment scale of the project has yet been confirmed, " Hsieh added.
Saudi Arab plans to use the industrial zone to house firms engaging in middle and downstream petrochemical production , according to Hsieh.

To tap into the Middle East market, the Taiwan International Development Corp--. invested by the government-controlled National Development Fund and local businesses -- has originally planned to raise a NT$2 billion investment fund, but is now considering expanding it because of a warm response from Taiwan's private sector, Hsieh said.
He added that the investment fund raising will soon be completed.

The delegation was comprised of representatives from the state-owned China Steel Corp, CTCI Corp, Taiwan Fertilizer Co, Ltd, the state-run CPC Corp, UPC Group, China Man-Made Fiber Corp, Taiwan Chunghwa Telecom Co, CECI Engineering Consultant Inc, , Teco Electric and Machinery Co, National Development Fund and Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's green industries output to reach NT$192 billion in 2009

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) predicted Tuesday that the output of green industries, such as solar energy, biofuel and energy conservation, will reach NT$192 billion (US$5.91 billion) next year.
The nation's highest economic planning body predicted the output could reach NT$640 billion by 2015, with an average annual increase of 22.2 percent.

CEPD officials noted that green industries constitute one of the four emerging industries currently being promoted by the government, and that they are expected to become prime movers of Taiwan's economic development and create a large number of job opportunities.
The other three emerging industries being promoted by the government are wireless broadband, digital life and health care.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Forex Tuesday, falling NT$0.060 to close at NT$32.010.
A total of US$881 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at a high of NT$32.070 and closed at the day's low of NT$31.994.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA calls for public awareness of poultry product safety

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) urged the public Tuesday to purchase legally processed poultry ahead of the Lunar New Year which falls on Feb. 7.

The COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine issued the call asking consumers to pay extra attention when purchasing poultry products for the Chinese New Year holiday season that begins Wednesday and runs through Feb. 11.

According to bureau officials, consumers may be assured that their health will be fully protected if they purchase poultry processed in licensed slaughterhouses. There are 90 licensed abattoirs currently around Taiwan, where poultry must be scrutinized by vets before being slaughtered, they noted.

A total of some 180 million chickens, ducks and geese as well as 8.7 million pigs, cattle and lambs were killed in licensed slaughterhouses last year, with all of their substandard parts being disposed of by vets in accordance with the law, relevant statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rebar founder's family unable to post bail: lawyer

TEXT.P: Four members of the family of Wang You-theng, the fugitive founder of the Rebar Asia Pacific Group, may not be able to leave detention for the Chinese New Year holiday, which begins Wednesday, a lawyer for the family said Tuesday.

Lawyer Chen Feng-fu made the remarks one day after Taipei District Court granted bail of NT$150 million (US$4.55 million) for each member of the Wang family -- Frank Wang, Wang's younger brother, and his three sons, China Rebar Co. Vice Chairman Wang Lin-tai, Asia Pacific Broadband Telecom Co. President Wang Lin-i and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. Chairman Wang Lin-chiao.
The court set the high bail for the Wangs because they are believed to have embezzled large sum of money from the Rebar Group and to have played key roles in the scam.
But court granted release on bail in the amount of millions for six other Rebar executives, including NT$6 million for Wang Chin-chang, deputy chief of the accounting department of China Rebar.
Chen, after meeting with his clients in detention in Tucheng, Taipei County Tuesday morning, said that the bail set by the court is excessive.
In addition, the nation will soon enter the Chinese New Year holiday, which means that it will be more difficult to collect the large sum, he added.
"Wangs are not expected to be able to collect the money to post bail before the Chinese New Year," he added.
Chen said that he will appeal to the court later in the day to request that the required bail be lower and an extension to the deadline from Feb. 8 to Feb. 15.

Prosecutors indicted the Wangs and top officials of the Rebar group last March, saying that the family had benefited by setting up numerous dummy corporations through which they engaged in insider trading, accounting fraud and embezzlement.

The Rebar scandal came to light in January 2007 after the group's China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. applied for insolvency restructuring, triggering a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate.

Wang You-theng and his wife, Wang Chin She-ying, are currently on the run in the United States. Taiwan prosecutors are seeking a 30-year prison sentence for Wang plus a record high fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's retailers to lure consumers with big prizes during new year

TEXT.P: Six automobiles and over tens of thousands of prizes, including scooters, designer bags, laptop computers, airline tickets and watches, await lucky shoppers in Taipei's major department stores during the upcoming Lunar New Year as retailers seek recovery from a past year of declining consumer spending.

To lure Taiwanese consumers to open up their wallets, stores have teamed up this year to launch what they are billing as an exciting "Fortune Bags" promotion on the Lunar New Year Holiday, which begins on Thursday.

Shoppers visiting the department stores in Taipei on Thursday and Friday may spend as little as NT$ 1,000 (US$ 30) for a "Fortune Bag", a New Year tradition adopted from Japan. Inside the bag, all customers will be designated a gift with a guaranteed minimum value of NT$ 1,000. The luckiest could be rewarded the top prize -- an automobile.
It seems to be a sure-win deal, but shoppers must first purchase the bag, which may take over 24 hours of standing in line.
Taipei's department stores, including the Living Mall, the Breeze Center, the Shin Kong Mitsukoshi, and the Pacific SOGO will each launch its own "Fortune Bag" scheme with a limited number of bags.

"On New Year's Day, we provide customers with two Suzuki sedans as top prizes, one more than the previous year," said Josephine Chou, a public relations specialist at the Living Mall, which will offer 4,000 fortune bags.

She further emphasized that in addition to the top prizes, other commodities, such as iPods, digital cameras, laptop computers and TVs are also up for grabs, adding that "it is worth spending NT$1,000 for a chance to win one of these products."
Meanwhile, a Mazda 3 car worth NT$ 565,000 (US$ 17,650) is listed as the top prize by the Breeze Center, which will sell 5,000 fortune bags, so the odds of winning the top prize is one in 5,000.

"We wish to give our customers more valuable and better prizes, " stressed Wu Ching-hua, a public relations specialist at the Breeze Center, adding that "a fortune's favorite" can even win the opportunity to have dinner with Taiwan's supermodel "Liz" on Valentine's Day, which falls on Feb. 14 this year.

The "Fortune Bags" program is not only a chance for shoppers to win big prizes. For the department stores, it also helps boost consumer spending amid stagnating incomes, the constantly increasing consumer prices and the weak stock market in Taiwan in recent years.

According to a survey conducted by MasterCard, Taiwan's consumer confidence in 2007 measured 29.7 on its index, which was 1.1 less than the previous year and was the lowest among the Asia Pacific nations.
"We infuse an amount of NT$ 10 million to prepare the Fortune Bag prizes this year, " said Chou with a hope that "it may attract more customers to shop at the Living Mall during the holiday."
The Shin Kong Mitsukoshi department store, however, has no automobile to offer this year.

According to Liu Pin-chou, chief of the Mitsukoshi's advertising and promotion section, the top prize of this year in its four branches in Taipei's Xin-yi district will be a four-day free trip to Hong Kong and Macau.
"We don't give a super big prize this year, but we provide more and better gifts, " Liu said, noting that 1,500 fortune bags will be available.
Another leading department store in Taipei, the Pacific SOGO, does not have a mall-wide fortune bags program, but individual shops in the shopping center will have their own promotion plans.
"This enables our customers to choose the commodities they like," Carol Wang, a pubic relations specialist at SOGO, stressed.

"You will never know what is in a fortune bag, but here you can purchase the products you really like, " she said, adding that every SOGO customer who spends money on the special offers may also receive a chance to win a Suzuki Swift car.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei book fair to boost Taiwan publishing industry globally

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Book Fair (TIBF) will sign an agreement with the International Publishers Association (IPA) to upgrade Taiwan's status in the global publishing industry, the fair's organizer announced Monday.

The IPA's chairwoman Ana Maria Cabanallas is scheduled to sign the agreement with Minister of Government Information Office (GIO) Shieh Jhy-wey, whose office is the major sponsor of the book fair, at aceremony on Feb. 12, a day before this year's fair is launched, according to a statement issued by the Taipei Book Fair Foundation (TBFF).

The publisher's association is a global non-governmental organization representing all aspects of book and journal publishing, with a mission to promote and protect publishing and to raise awareness of publishing as a force for cultural and political advancement worldwide.

"The IPA has observed the contribution of the TBFF for years and decided to award the fair a promise of offering further assistances in the foundation's future projects, " Huang Pao-ping, the Taipei foundation's CEO told the CNA Tuesday. "It is a remarkable achievement for a non-governmental body, considering the fact that the country (Taiwan) has been blocked by international organizations for the lack of political recognitions," she added.
Huang also complimented Taiwan's publishing industry for doing a good job in protecting copyright and freedom of expression.

As a member of the association, the Taipei fair organizer's chairman Lin Tzai- chuei this year will be the first Taiwanese to attend the annual International Publishers Congress to be held in Seoul in May, which will discuss mainly Asian publishing trends.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan basketball league looks ahead to second half

TEXT.P: After a first half of the season full of good and not-so-good surprises, Taiwans domestic basketball league SBL (Super Basketball League) is looking forward to a prosperous second half on the eve of a two-week lunar new year break.

The semi-pro league, which is in the middle of its fifth season, consists of seven teams and adopts a 30-game regular season format. The regular season will be suspended briefly before resuming Feb. 15 after a two-week break for the new year.

Before the 2007-08 season opened last December, the league was expected to be top heavy as perennial power Yulon Dinos, defending champion Taiwan Beer and Dacin Tigers were all loaded with talented players while the remaining team were either inexperienced or under-budgeted to compete with the big boys.
The prediction is partially true as Yulon, which won three titles in the SBL's first four years, is currently leading the league at 16 wins and 4 losses. Taiwan Beer is not far behind at 15-6.

What surprised everyone was that Dacin is barely clinging on to its fourth place ranking with a sub-.500 record of nine wins and 11 losses. Dmedia Numen, which hires the only foreign player in the league, became a dark horse with a third- place 13-7 record.

Pure Youth Construction Corp., a bottom dweller during the previous four seasons, was another surprise at 9-12. The young team is making a strong push to the top four with the momentum of a five-game winning streak under the guidance of young head coach Hsu Chin-che.

Yulon forward Chen Hsin-an, the first Taiwanese player to play in the U.S. NBA team training camp in 2002, regained his top form and is leading the league in scoring with a 20.6 points per game to go with 8.8 rebounds. Dmedia import Jonathan Sanders has been dominating at both ends of the court, averaging 19.2 points, 16.6 rebounds and 5.7 assists per game.
Sanders was not alone. Ouyang Ching-hen, a 28-year-old Dmedia guard, is enjoying a breakout season as the league's third best scorer with an 18.7 scoring average.

However, the image of the league has been taking hits from numerous incidents on and off the court. Two on-court brawls have led to a number of player suspensions. Taiwan Beer head coach Yen Chia-hua and the team manager Lin Chieh- ho are in the middle of a 10-game suspension as well. Both were reprimanded as Yen kicked a referee and Lin punched another after a controversial game.
Three Demdia players were released from the team after being involved in a stabbing incident outside a Taipei nightclub last month.

The SBL, the brainchild of the Sports Affairs Council and the Chinese Taipei Basketball Association, in hope of reviving local basketball, was established in 2003, four years after the professional league Chinese Basketball Alliance (CBA) folded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Core consumer price growth hits 9-year high

TEXT.P: The core consumer price index recorded a year-on-year growth of 2.71 percent in January, representing the highest level since March 1999 and a monthly growth of over 2 percent for four months in a row, according to official statistics released Tuesday.

The index is produced after deducting fluctuations in consumer prices of fresh food products such as vegetables, fruit and seafood, as well as energy products. It reflects long-term trends of a country's consumer prices.

The tallies compiled by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) show that the consumer price index (CPI) recorded 102.93 in January, representing a slight drop of 0.57 percent compared with the previous month, but registering a rise of 2.96 percent compared with the same month of the previous year.

The DGBAS said in a news release that the decline was mainly caused by a drop in prices for winter vegetables thanks to a bumper harvest. A seasonal discount in ready-to-wear garments was also attributed to the CPI drop.

Referring to the year-on-year growth of 2.96 percent, DGBAS officials said that an overall growth in all major indices for the CPI was the reason for the surge, particularly a year-on-year increase of 5.29 percent in prices of food products and of 4.56 percent in transport costs.

The wholesale price index (WPI) registered at 111.38 in January, up by 0.81 percent from the previous month and up 10.21 percent from the same month of the previous year, according to the DGBAS statistics.
Wu Chao-ming, chief of the DGBAS third section, attributed the 10.21-percent rise -- the largest since November 2004 -- to fluctuations in raw materials and crude oil prices.

Meanwhile, the import price index increased by 16.94 percent in January from the year-earlier level when counted based on the new Taiwan dollar value, while the export price index posted a year-on-year growth of 3.1 percent, the tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employers urged to offer foreign workers legal four-day holiday

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) urged employers of foreign laborers Tuesday to follow the Labor Standards Law (LSL) and offer a four-day holiday to their workers during the upcoming Chinese New Year festival, which begins Wednesday and ends on next Monday.
Under the law, the foreign workers are entitled to the national holiday and have the right to decide whether or not to accept requests that they work extra shifts during that time.
Employers are obliged to offer double their workers' regular wage for such work, CLA said in a statement.

To foreign workers working as domestic help or caregivers, who are not covered by the LSL, the CLA indicated that their wages, work hours, holidays and extra work are all provided in their employment contracts.
No matter how the contract is written, CLA officials suggest that employers allow foreign workers to take the holiday off and refrain from asking them to work overtime.

DOC.HEADLINE: Debtor lawmaker donates election subsidies to disadvantaged

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Fu Kun-chi said at a news conference Tuesday that he has donated his election subsidies to social welfare groups, so his creditors would not be able to seize it as part of his debt repayment.
Fu said he bought rice and olive oil with all election subsidies and gave the goods to a total of 18 social welfare groups charged with helping the disadvantaged.

The election subsidy is given by the government to candidates who win a certain proportion of votes cast in elections. Each vote is worth NT$30. Fu received NT$1.87 million (US$58,396) for wining over 60,000 votes in the legislative elections last month.

Fu's creditors had asked the Central Election Commission (CEC) via adistrict court to detain Fu's election subsidies, but the CEC replied to the court that the request should be delivered to the Hualien County Election Commission, as it is the subsidy issuer for Fu.
Fu, meanwhile, said that the unpaid debts of NT$17.5 million in his name are due to his agreeing to act as a guarantor for other people.

Fu said he will not let the subsidy money be used to pay his debts. The donation to social welfare groups is aimed at returning the money to where it came from, he said, adding that he will give part of his salary to the disadvantaged every three months in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food products tested by Kaohsiung's health department up to par

TEXT.P: All the food products tested by Kaohsiung's Bureau of Health in a recent survey were found to meet applicable sanitary standards, bureau officials said Tuesday.

In the department's second such survey ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, a total of 89 products, including fruits and vegetables and meat items, sold in markets in the southern port city were tested, the officials said.

The department also conducted 23 sets of tests on chef's utensils, including plates, bowls and knives at various restaurants around the city, with all of the utensils testing negative for viral bacteria, the officials said.
While announcing the results, the officials urged restaurant owners to regulate themselves in order to maintain the safety of their products for the sake of consumers' health.

They also urged consumers to follow several simple guidelines when shopping for food products in order to protect their own health. The guidelines include avoiding purchasing food products that are not clearly labeled and food products sold on the street for which the origin is unknown, paying attention to the freshness of the products being sold, and remembering to thoroughly clean food products and preserve them well after purchasing them.
The officials also said that anyone with any concerns or doubts about the safety of any food products sold on the market in Kaohsiung can contact the department at (07)-717-6557.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ocean liner to bring Chinese tourists to Taiwan for Spring Festival

TEXT.P: The ocean liner Rhapsody of the Sea is scheduled to make port in Taiwan Feb. 11 -- the last day of the six-day Chinese New Year holiday, bringing over 2,000 foreign tourists, including some from China, to the island, Tourism Bureau officials said Tuesday.

The Rhapsody of the Sea is the first ocean liner to be given the green light by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council to bring Chinese travelers to Taiwan for sightseeing via a third country or area.

According to the bureau, the liner, the largest passenger ship in Asia, will berth at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan Feb. 11 and at Kaohsiung Harbor in the south the following day. It is scheduled to leave Kaohsiung late Feb. 12 for a return voyage to Hong Kong.

It is expected that 80 percent-90 percent of the travelers will go ashore for one-day tours of Keelung and Kaohsiung and the authorities have made preparations to offer them services ranging from rapid customs clearance and tour consultancy to show that they are welcome visitors, bureau officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Freeway traffic increasing ahead of Chinese New Year holiday

TEXT.P: Traffic on major freeways around Taiwan has been increasing since 3 p.m. Tuesday as large numbers of people head to their hometowns for the Chinese New Year holiday, officials said.

The peak period is expected to continue past 8 p.m., with the number of vehicles traveling on freeways likely to total 1.9 million for the day, according to officials at the Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau.
Meanwhile, railway traffic also entered its peak period Tuesday afternoon and is expected to remain busy until Wednesday noon, Ministry of Transportation and Communications officials said.

All south-bound trains provided by the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. are fully booked between Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday noon, as are almost all Tze Chiang express trains operated by the Taiwan Railway Administration, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: High amounts of agricultural produce traded in market

TEXT.P: With Chinese New Year just on the corner, the volume of agricultural goods sold in Taipei's wholesale markets is likely to hit an annual high of more than 3,000 metric tons Tuesday, according to officials of the Taipei Agricultural Products Marketing Corp. (TAPMC).

Cheng Yung-kun, director of the TAPMC's first wholesale market, said at least 2,500 metric tons of produce was sold at the market as of 10: 00 a.m. He predicted that the total volume for the day will break the 3,000 metric tons level as transactions continue through the afternoon.

The Taipei's fruits and vegetables wholesale market will open for only a half day Wednesday, the Lunar New Year's eve, when most shops and businesses will shut down in preparation for New Year's Day -- the most significant festival for Chinese people around the world.

According to TAMPC statistics, the price for vegetables averaged NT$22.4 per kilogram Tuesday, a rise from the price of NT$15.1 per kg a week ago. The average price of fruits slightly increased to NT$44.3 per kg from NT$43.2 per kg.

The average wholesale price for vegetables during the Lunar New Year's peak period this year is about the same as last year's level thanks to stable supplies, while the average price of fruits was up by some 40 percent as compared to the previous year's level due to shortages, TAMPC tallies showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abundant fruit, vegetable supplies before Lunar New Year holiday

TEXT.P: Supplies of daily necessities will continue to meet market demand in the two days ahead of the Feb. 6-11 Chinese New Year holiday, officials from the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission said Monday.
The daily necessities listed include vegetables, mushrooms, fish, meat and fruit, the officials said.
Currently, prices of vegetables and mushrooms are steady in markets around the country, while prices of fish, meat and fruit are up slightly, according to officials.
Officials went on to say that the current price of vegetables on the Taipei market averages NT$16 (US$0.5) per kilogram.

Mushroom prices on markets around the island currently range between NT$330 and NT$840 per kilogram. The average prices of other goods are: fish, NT$90 per kilogram; pork, NT$63 per kilogram; chicken, NT$61.5 per kilogram; and duck, NT$58 per kilogram. Average fruit prices stand at NT$47 per kilogram, according to the officials.

Meanwhile, the officials added, prices of some Chinese New Year treats -- including peanuts, pistachio nuts and dried squid products -- have seen a slight advance, with average prices ranging between NT$100 and NT$120 per kilogram.

On Chinese New Year's Day, people are expected to prepare traditional holiday feasts. As agricultural wholesale markets will be closed during the holiday, the demand for the agricultural produce is expected to peak with the approach of the holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung wiping out illegal trade in fishing boat diesel fuel

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung City Government urged local fishermen Tuesday not to sell their diesel oil rationed by the government and announced a plan to crack down on the illegal trade.

According to officials at the Kaohsiung City Government's ocean affairs bureau, the bureau will work jointly with the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the Coast Guard Administration in pursuit of that end.
The municipal bureau has worked out a comprehensive program to wipe out the illegal trade in fishing boat fuel, both on land and offshore, the officials said.

To prevent fishermen from forging documents on the distance sailed in order to make an illegal profit by selling government-rationed fishing boat oil, a task force composed of officials from the three units boarded a coast patrol boat to carry out inspections off the coast of Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, the officials said.
The officials called on fishermen to rigorously abide by the law and warned that anyone and any ship caught engaging in the unlawful business will be dealt with by the book harshly.
They also urged the public to report to the Fisheries Agency if they become aware of such cases.
The illegal trade in government-rationed fishing boat diesel oil among local fishermen has grown rapidly since petroleum and fuel prices surged by folds in the middle of last year.
Kaohsiung is the largest port city in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Release of reporter highlights Beijing's `carrot-stick' ploy: MAC

TEXT.P: China's release ahead of the Chinese New Year festival of a Hong Kong reporter convicted of spying for Taiwan signifies its "carrot-and-stick" strategy toward Taiwan, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a press statement Tuesday.

The country's top China policy planning agency issued the statement after Ching Cheong, a Hong Kong-based correspondent for Singapore's The Straits Times newspaper, was released on parole earlier in the day after having served more than half of a five-year prison term.

Ching, 58, was sentenced to five years in August 2006 on charges of spying for Taiwan. He was detained during a visit to the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou in April 2005 and sentenced in a one-day trial 16 months later. A Chinese court rejected his appeal in November 2006.
The MAC said it was delighted to see Ching regain his freedom and return to Hong Kong to be reunited with his family during the festive season.
Describing Ching's imprisonment as an example of Beijing's suppression of press freedom, the MAC expressed hope that similar cases will not happen again.
Like Ching, the MAC statement said, many other people have been put under surveillance and house arrest or detained by the Chinese authorities for covering news or seeking freedom of speech.

Noting that China hopes to nurture an image corresponding with that of a rising power, the MAC statement said it hopes the international community can push the Chinese authorities to remove their control of news and freedom of speech at an early date.
It also rebutted China's accusation that Ching spied in China for Taiwan, describing the allegation as totally unfounded.

Meanwhile, a senior MAC official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, analyzed that Ching's release, which followed the release of another alleged Taiwanese spy -- Lin Cheng-cheng, a former chairman of the Japanese language department at Tunghai University in central Taiwan -- is an effective application of its "carrot and stick" approach toward Taiwan.

As recently as last Saturday, the official said, China's two top agencies dealing with Taiwan affairs -- the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the Communist Party of China and the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council -- issued a joint statement condemning Taiwan's planned referendum on its U.N. membership bid.

"China, while on the one hand relentlessly and mercilessly suppressing Taiwan diplomatically, has on the other hand released the two alleged Taiwanese spies ahead of the most important Chinese festival in an attempt to gain good press and win the goodwill of the Taiwanese people," the official said.

In addition, the official went on, China has released Ching at a significant moment in an effort to shift international attention from its "inept crisis management" as shown in its response to its recent snowstorms.
"Ching's release will bring positive media coverage, thus mitigating media focus and scrutiny of China's new generation of leadership's administrative incompetence," the official added.

According to China's official Xinhua News Agency, Ching was convicted of selling unspecified "state secrets and intelligence" to a Taiwanese foundation that it claimed was a front for Taiwanese espionage activities in China.

The National Security Bureau has denied using the organization, known as the Foundation for International and Cross Strait Studies, for spying, saying it only commissioned the group to conduct academic research.

DOC.TEXT:

Bugging devices planted in a prison telephone were illegally used to record privileged conversations between an inmate and his solicitor, The Times has learnt.

With 24 states in play, leading candidates scour targeted areas for votes in busiest day of primaries and caucuses in presidential nominating history.

Searching Yahoo for Value Yahoo may have to resort to some big-deal brinksmanship to get a sweetened offer from Microsoft. The first battleground is over some of the most basic steps of valuing Yahoo. 12:03 a. m.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits Matsu

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited Matsu Tuesday to express his appreciation for the troops stationed on the outlying island ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Wednesday.

Chen, accompanied by Vice President Annette Lu, Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, Chief of the General Staff Huo Shou-yeh and Chen Chi-mai, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, also had lunch with the troops.

The president said he has never forgotten his pledges to the troops to cheer them up, adding that "no matter where they are, on the outlying islands, in the mountains or even in the remotest areas, I'll overcome difficulties to meet with you to express my appreciation."
He noted that it was his sixth visit to Matsu and that he has developed more admiration for the troops stationed there. Both he and Lu wished them a happy Chinese New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-dumping probe shows limited impact on local manufacturers

TEXT.P: Local stainless steel foundries were calm Tuesday in the face of a recent announcement by the European Union (EU) that it would launch a probe into Taiwan's alleged dumping of stainless cold-rolled steel plates.

The European Commission, the EU's executive branch, posted a bulletin last Friday announcing its intention to launch an investigation into the alleged dumping of cold-rolled steel plates by Taiwan, China and South Korea, the Bureau of Foreign Trade said in a news release.
The anti-dumping measure was adopted after European steel makers filed a complaint over exports by their competitors from China, South Korea and Taiwan.

Under the complaint, it is claimed that Taiwan's exports of steel products to the EU grew to 22.94 percent of total EU imports of this kind in September 2007, up from 18.89 percent in 2006 and 17.51 percent in 2005, according to the news release.
The bureau urged local businesses, which have been targeted by the probe, to cooperate with the investigation.

However, the Kaohsiung-based Tang Eng Iron Works Co. Ltd., one of Taiwan's major steel foundries, said the probe, won't threaten its operations even if the EU decides to levy punishing tariffs on Taiwan's steel products because the EU has never been a major market for the company's goods.

The Yulin County-based Froch Enterprise Co., one of the world's leading manufacturers of stainless steel tubes and pipes, and the Taipei County-based Hsin Kuang Steel Co., have both opined that the probe won't pose as a threat to their exports.

The companies stated that their exports to the European market have been limited because EU demand for steel products differs from that of other foreign markets in terms of kind and size, executives of the companies said.
The companies went on to say that they have a wealth of experience handling anti-dumping accusations and see little reason for concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fisheries agency demands further crackdown on elver smuggling

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Agency has urged the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) and local customs officials to reinforce a crackdown on elver smuggling many times but has not received any reports on the issue from the relevant organizations, an agency official complained Monday.

The remarks came after the Mainichi Shimbun, a major Japanese daily, reported earlier in the day that some Taiwanese companies are still smuggling elvers to Japan though Hong Kong, despite the Taiwanese government's ban on the export of elvers imposed last November.
The five-month ban is part of the government's efforts to preserve dwindling eel resources, said Tsao Hong-cheng, a deputy chief of the agency's fishery facilities and aquaculture section.
The falling stocks of elvers has resulted in prices soaring to NT$42 (US$1.3) each now from NT$5-NT$10 in 1990, when Taiwan netted up to 40 tonnes of the fish, Tsao went on.

The Mainichi Shimbun also cited agency tallies compiled as of late January and said the agency had reported a total of 3.5 tonnes of elvers caught so far this year, but that it had lost track of the whereabouts of 3 tonnes of the elvers.

In response, Tsao said that based on data collected from local fishery cooperatives, approximately 0.6 tonnes-1 tonne of bigger elvers have been put into aquaculture ponds, while smaller ones are still being kept in nursery ponds.

In addition, Tsao pointed out that the peak periods for netting elvers are December and January and that Taiwan has only caught a mere 3.5 tonnes this year. He also predicted that eel prices will continue to rise.
According to Tsao, Taiwan caught 6 tonnes of elvers in 2005, 16 tonnes in 2006 and 7 tonnes in 2007.
China and Japan also caught fewer elvers this year, with 9 tonnes and 3.5 tonnes, respectively, Tsao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Respiratory infections top emergency cases over Lunar New Year

TEXT.P: Acute upper respiratory tract infection has been the top cause of medical emergencies reported during previous Lunar New Year holiday, a health official said Tuesday.
The remarks came one day before this year's Lunar New Year holiday, which will end next Monday.
Chen Yu-min, an official of the Bureau of National Health Insurance, attributed the cause to people visiting their relatives and friends in different parts of Taiwan during the holiday.
Chen said that during the holiday period last year, more than 241,500 emergency cases were reported.

Of these, over 33,200 were acute upper respiratory tract infections, including symptoms of fever, headache and runny nose, followed by 27,800 enterogastritis cases and 16,000 acute abdominal pain cases, Chen added.
During the holidays, most hospitals in Taiwan will only receive emergency cases.

In terms of the different regions in Taiwan, Chen said most of the reported emergency cases in northern Taiwan were enterogastritis, while in other parts of Taiwan, most of the cases were acute upper respiratory tract infections.
Some 10 percent of the reported cases were related to traffic accidents or accidental injuries, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung city councilor indicted for destroying traffic tickets

TEXT.P: Prosecutors indicted Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Wu-chung Wednesday on charges of abusing his power by pressuring the southern port city's traffic police bureau to revoke speeding tickets, requesting a seven-year jail term for him.
The indictment came after the prosecutors launched a raid on Lin's office last September and found that 38 tickets had been destroyed at Lin's request.
Lin, however, claimed that he had "intended to help local residents fax their tickets to the traffic police bureau" and that it is up to the police to decide if the tickets should be revoked.
He also said he will stage a "hunger strike" in front of the Kaohsiung District Prosecutors Office Feb. 12 to protest the prosecutors' decision.
Lin's aides and three staff members of the traffic police bureau have also been indicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 schools win MOE university promotional subsidies

TEXT.P: Eleven schools will receive university promotional subsidies from the Ministry of Education (MOE) for creating world-class educational institutes, MOE Department of Higher Education Director-General Ho Chuo-fei said Tuesday.

The schools were selected from among 15 finalists competing for the second phase of the MOE's program titled "Five Years, 50 Billion, " which has a NT$50 billion (US$1.55 billion) budget and is aimed at upgrading local universities into top- ranking universities and research centers.
It has two phases of implementation, with phase one stretching over two years and the second phase taking a further three years. The MOE received 32 applications for the second phase.

The winning schools will receive subsidies ranging from NT$3 billion (US$93.68 million) down to NT$200 million, Ho said, adding that National Taiwan University, National Chengchi University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology and National Yang Ming University in Taipei City are included on the list of winners.

Chang Gung University and National Central University in Taoyuan County, National Tsing Hua University and National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu County, National Chung Hsing University in Taichung City, National Cheng Kung University in Tainan City and National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung City were also successful, Ho said.

According to Ho, the selection was made by an examination committee based on the schools' operations, educational systems, facilities, teaching and counselling performance, research centers, development strategies and financial plans, as well as their research performance, globalization and cooperation between academia and industry.

The schools will have to submit their improvement plans following suggestions and opinions from the committee before receiving the subsidies from the MOE, and the MOE will adjust the subsidy amount for each school every year according to their performance, Ho said.

As for the four schools not included in the program, Ho said the MOE will provide a total of NT$340 million to help them develop their special features in education. The four schools are National Taiwan Ocean University in Keelung City, Kaohsiung Medical University in Kaohsiung City, and Chung Yuan Christian University and Yuan Ze University in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP announces south-to-north march for its candidate

TEXT.P: A large-scale march from the country's south to the north will begin Wednesday to seek more support for Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, party headquarters officials announced Tuesday.
Hsieh is trailing his rival Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the runup to the March 22 election, according to recent opinion polls.
In addition, the DPP suffered a huge blow in last month's legislative polls, winning a mere 27 seats in the 113-seat legislature compared with 81 seats clinched by the KMT.
The march will start from Eluanbi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, and end in the capital Taipei, Lee Ying-yuan, Hsieh's campaign executive secretary-general, told a press conference.
It will be organized by the DPP and several civic groups, including the U.N. for Taiwan Alliance and the Hand-in-Hand to Safeguard Taiwan Alliance, according to Lee.
From Feb. 10, the marchers will organize a series of campaign rallies in Kaohsiung City, Tainan City, Chiayi City, Taichung City, Hsinchu City, Taoyuan City and Taipei County along the way.
The DPP will hold another rally in Taipei City Feb. 28 to conclude the march.
For her part, Cheng Li-chun, head of the DPP's youth department, said at the press conference that the DPP sincerely accepts the legislative outcome and has reflected on its mistakes.
However, the DPP is also worried that the KMT will abuse its power, as it now occupies three-quarters of the legislature, Cheng went on, calling on the public to take part in the march.
The DPP has repeatedly appealed to voters to elect Hsieh president to ensure a system of checks and balances in the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits Matsu

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian visited Matsu Tuesday to express his appreciation for the troops stationed on the outlying island ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday, which begins Wednesday.

Chen, accompanied by Vice President Annette Lu, Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, Chief of the General Staff Huo Shou-yeh and Chen Chi-mai, vice secretary-general of the Presidential Office, also had lunch with the troops.

The president said he has never forgotten his pledges to the troops to cheer them up, adding that "no matter where they are, on the outlying islands, in the mountains or even in the remotest areas, I'll overcome difficulties to meet with you to express my appreciation."
He noted that it was his sixth visit to Matsu and that he has developed more admiration for the troops stationed there. Both he and Lu wished them a happy Chinese New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 6, or the 30th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Pig according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1665: Queen Anne, last Stuart ruler of Britain, is born.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1804: Joseph Priestley, British chemist moted for work on the isolation of gases and his discovery of oxygen (1774), dies at the age of 71.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up its settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous batting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1917: British women over 30 get the vote.
1922: The Washington Conference ends with the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan agreeing on restricting the use of poison gas and submarine warfare.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up a Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers, as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, noted Taiwanese painter, dies at the age of 82.
1999: The Taipei District Court sentences Hong Kong business tycoon Lin Por-yen to three years and two months in prison for his role in a bribery scandal.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski says that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
2000: Tarja Halonen becomes first woman president of Finland.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 7, or the first day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1478: Sir Thomas More, English Lord Chancellor who was executed by Henry VIII for refusing to deny the Pope's authority, is born.
1685: King Charles II, king of England, Scotland, and Ireland known as the "merry monarch" who reigned during the Restoration, dies at the age of 55.
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well- loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1816: Italian missionary Giovanni Lantrua of Triora is executed by the Chinese.
1870: Alfred Adler, Austrian psychoanalyst who introduced the concept of the inferiority complex, is born.
1885: Sinclair Lewis, U.S. novelist and Nobel Prize winner who wrote "Main Street," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Communist Chinese troops.
1950: Vietnam splits in two, with the Soviet Union recognizing the provisional government of Ho Chi Minh and the United States and Britain endorsing the French-backed government of Emperor Bao Dai.
1955: Republic of China government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1960: Israeli archaeologists unearth a number of Dead Sea Scrolls.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees to the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan County.
1971: Switzerland grants women the right to vote.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term in office.
1974: Grenada gains independence, with Eric Gairy as its first prime minister.
1976: Emanuel O. Gardiner, Liberian deputy minister of planning and economic affairs, and Lafayette Kwie Johnson Jr., assistant minister of the Ministry of Industry, Commerce, and Transportation, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1982: Luis Alberto Monge becomes president of Costa Rica.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan into a National Park.
1986 Self-styled "President for Life" Jean Claude "Baby-Doc" Duvalier flees Haiti with his loot, bound for exile in France in the face of a national uprising.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent, Corazon Aquino, claim victory in the Philippine presidential election. The National Assembly would later rule that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly on power.
1991: In its most daring daylight raid to date, the Irish Republican Army fires three mortar bombs at British Prime Minister John Major's residence at No. 10 Downing Street.
1992: Ministers of Europe formally sign the Maastricht Treaty of the European Union.
1996: A Boeing 757 passenger jetliner on its way from the Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the king of Jordan following King Hussein's death from cancer.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 8, or the second day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba and later "discovers" Mexico.
1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He would be succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on the French island of Martinique in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and causing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, when Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member, is put to death.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula near the Caribbean coast.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the U.S. film actor and cult hero who died at the age of 24 in a road accident while driving his Spider convertible, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in Soviet-occupied North Korea, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Communist Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu, and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1955: Nikolai Bulganin becomes premier of the Soviet Union, replacing Georgi Malenkov.
1962: The U.S. military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1963: President Abdel-Karim Kassem of Iraq is overthrown and killed in a military coup.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne in order to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1966: The Republic of Vietnam and the United States issue the Declaration of Honolulu, outlining their aims for Vietnam.
1974: Dr. George L.B. Pratt, director of the Office of Education and Manpower, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Chinese investors in Taiwan and Gulf Oil Corporation officials agree on the establishment of a joint company to produce low-density polyethylene.
1976: Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan decorates Dr. Harry Bodan Shields, visiting vice minister of foreign affairs of the Republic of Nicaragua, with the Grand Cordon of the Order of Brilliant Star.
1976: Guatemalan Ambassador Agustin Donis Kesler calls on Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan to thank the government for helping earthquake victims.
1980: Louis Vorster, new ambassador of the Republic of South Africa, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games, taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: The U.S. liaison office in Vietnam begins business operations, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the two countries.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui says the ROC and the Vatican should join hands to strive for freedom and democracy for the enslaved people in mainland China and other parts of the world.
2001: Chen Li-fu, a member of the presidium of the opposition Kuomintang Central Advisory Committee, dies at the age of 103.
2001: Two reporters from mainland China's Xinhua News Agency who have been granted permission to be stationed in Taiwan arrive in Taipei, marking a new milestone for news exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE promotes elderly education amid aging society

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has doubled its budget for the promotion of elderly education to NT$46.54 million (US$1.45 million) for 2008 as Taiwan's senior population continues to increase, ministry officials said Wednesday.
The amount compares with NT$25.75 million earmarked for 2006 and NT$22.25 million for 2007, the officials said.

The program targeting seniors is in line with a white paper released by the ministry in 2006 to outline the government's education policy to deal with a greying society. Unveiled in the document are four major visions that the government aims to achieve: enhancing life-long learning, health and happiness, independence and self-esteem, and social participation among senior citizens.

In addition to working out a five-year plan to implement the policy, the ministry has also set up a task force consisting of government, academic and civic representatives to assist with the policy's implementation, the officials said.

To increase the country's citizens' understanding of the difficulties faced by seniors and the positive value of the group, the ministry is planning to add elements aimed at fostering knowledge about aging to the compulsory education curriculum, they said.

In a bid to promote the utility of senior human resources, the ministry is encouraging its affiliated agencies to recruit retired personnel and senior volunteers to help promote education programs for the elderly, they said, adding that such a method will help inspire their peers to take part in community service and interact more with society.

Meanwhile, the ministry will set up an "elderly education guidance centers" in the northern, central, southern and eastern regions, which will be tasked with developing teaching materials, training tutors, and supervising and guiding the implementation of elderly education.

Also, the ministry has proposed that a special unit be set up under the education bureau of each local government to take charge of promoting elderly education and that "grey-haired learning centers" and "life-long learning centers" be established in local communities, MOE officials said.
According to Interior Ministry tallies, the number of Taiwan people aged 65 and above amounted to 2,337,932 as of November 2007, accounting for 10.19 percent of the country's total population.

In 10 counties and cities, the ratios of senior citizens were higher than the average, accounting for 12-15 percent of the localities' population. They included Yilan County, Miaoli County, Nantou County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Tainan County, Taitung County, Hualien County, Penghu County and Kinmen County.

It has been forecast that 10 years from now, the number of people aged 65 and above in Taiwan will have reached 3.02 million, accounting for 13 percent of the country's total population and outnumbering people aged below 14 who are expected to account for only 12.72 percent of the population by then.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fashion guru Anna Sui invited to creativity education fair in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Fashion guru Anna Sui has been invited to attend the first "2008 International Creativity Education Fair" to be held March 5-9 in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, according to the organizer of the event.
Chen Yi-heng, director of National Sun Yat-sen University's Creativity and Innovation Research Center, said that the theme of this year's event is "Creativity Education, Dynamic Taiwan."
"Creativity should be developed among youngsters. Through education, students are encouraged to have the life attitude of being creative," Chen said.
The Ministry of Education launched the "White Paper on Creativity Education" in 2002 as the blueprint for constructing a country with creativity.

National Sun Yat-sen University is the organizer of the 2008 International Creativity Education Fair. Besides 200 booths of creativity display, 10 forums attended by international and domestic creative masters, including American fashion designer Anna Sui, Taiwan designer Goji Lin, Taiwan cartoonist Liu Hsing-ching and U Theater founder Lin Ching-min, will be held to share their experience, Chen said.

He further said the fair will serve as an information platform for those interested in creativity-related courses, as well as provide a great opportunity for extended discussion on creativity education.
"We hope to integrate creativity education with the daily life of the general public and make it into a national campaign," he said.
He added that a documentary of the whole fair will be filmed to be used in creativity education.
The fair is expected to attract some 100,000 visitors, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's three nuclear plants generate record high amount of power

TEXT.P: Taiwan's three operating nuclear power plants generated a total of 38.96 billion kilowatt-hours (kwh) of electricity in 2007, with the capacity factor reaching 90.28 percent, according to tallies released Wednesday by the Atomic Energy Council (AEC).
Both figures are the highest ever recorded by the power plants, AEC officials said.

In 2007, there were a total of 14 reportable events at the six reactor units belonging to the three power plants, including two trips, the officials said, adding that all these events were within "level 0, " meaning "no safety significance" on the international nuclear event scale introduced by the International Energy Agency.
They noted that after a measurement uncertainty recapture power uprate last year, power generation by the two reactor units at the second power plant increased by 20 megawatts.

Based on a capacity factor of 90 percent, the increment means power supply will increase by 158 million kwh per year, the officials said, adding that if the thermo-power generation were reduced by the same amount, carbon dioxide emissions in the country would decrease by 118,000 metric tons per year.
Meanwhile, they pointed out that automatic seismic scram devices installed at the three power plants officially began operating in November 2007.

According to the AEC, such a device immediately sends out a signal to the safety protection system of the nuclear power unit whenever the seismic sensor detects earthquake tremors exceeding the nuclear plant's Operating Basis Earthquake (OBE) . This signal causes a reactor trip and ensures that the reactor is safely shutdown in the event of a strong earthquake.

As to the fourth nuclear power plant that is still under construction, the AEC has assigned a committee consisting of civic and academic representatives to supervise the quality and safety of the project, AEC officials said, adding that as of the end of 2007, the project had been 75 percent completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mercury to drop as cold snap approaches

TEXT.P: A cold snap arriving on Chinese New Year's Eve is expected to bring the mercury down to as low as 10 degrees Celsius around Taiwan, forecasters at the Central Weather Bureau said Wednesday.

The cold snap will continue looming over Taiwan until Saturday -- the third day of Chinese New Year, the forecasters said, advising people with travel plans during the holiday to make sure to dress warmly.

Meanwhile, they said rainfall is expected to be moderate in most areas during the holiday, adding that mountainous areas in northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan are likely to experience rainfall Thursday.
Also, poor visibility is expected in mountainous areas, and people are urged to be extra cautious while driving in these areas, the forecasters said.

The Japan Times: Second toxin found in Chinese 'gyoza'
Another type of pesticide has been detected in "gyoza" dumplings made by Tianyang Food, the Chinese company under fire over its suspected link to recent food poisonings in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: PM confident of another good year for Singapore.
The new Chinese Year of the Rat begins tomorrow under more uncertain and challenging circumstances than the Year of the Pig, the Prime Minister said yesterday. But Mr Lee Hsien Loong assured Singaporeans, in his traditional message to mark the occasion, that the country is 'in a strong position to weather any storm'.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore will be more pro-family.
Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong dwelt on the importance of family ties in his Chinese New Year message that people still have to respect filial piety and understand the importance of the family for community even though the social values are changing.
Building on the 2004 pro-family measures, Mr. Lee said the Government is studying practical matters to see how it can create an even friendlier environment for having and raising children. They include childcare facilities, flexible work options and parental leave.

DOC.HEADLINE: President thanks citizens for contributions in New Year's message

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sent his Chinese New Year greetings in a pre-recorded video Wednesday, expressing his appreciation to all of Taiwan's citizens for their contribution to the country.

The video, intended for broadcast by domestic television networks on Chinese New Year's Eve, begins with footage of people from various walks of life working diligently, including police officers, bus drivers, freeway toll collectors, hair salon assistants, street cleaners, telecom maintenance workers, marketplace cleaners, grocery retailers, factory operators, farmers and fishermen.
The president said he would like to express his thanks to everyone in the country for their day-to-day contribution and devotion to Taiwan in the past and in the future.

Chen said he has always considered himself lucky to be able to stand by the side of such kind, passionate and hard-working people in going through difficult times and striving to uphold their dignity and change their destiny.

"It proves heaven is fair that Taiwan, lacking in natural resources, has such a precious group of people who have not only created an economic miracle but also attained the proudest achievements -- freedom and democracy," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Northeast coast railway one-day pass makes travel free and easy

TEXT.P: People can make use of the recently launched "Northeast Coast Railway One Day Pass, " which covers all scenic spots and tourist attractions along the northeast coast of Taiwan, to travel during the Lunar New Year holidays, an official of the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area said Wednesday.

"With the pass, which costs only NT$130 (US$ 4) , people can easily travel through the northeast coast area without being stuck in the holiday traffic jams, " said Chen Mei Kang, director of the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area.

The Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication cooperated with the Taiwan Railways Administration to launch the Northeast Coast Railway One Day Pass last November to promote tourism.
Chen said that tourists can look far into the distance to see the Pacific Ocean when taking the northeast coast railway line and that there is a mountain view as well.
"The openness and beautiful scenery can definitely cheer people up," he added.

Also, there are lots of tourist attractions near the stations of the Northeast Coast Line, including the Caoling Historic Trail, the Fulong beach area, the Dali Tian-gong Temple, and Kueishan Island, located 10 kilometer off the coast of Yilan.

Other tourist spots, such as the Chinguashi-Chiou-fen mining town and the Shuang-hsi flower garden, can easily reached by using the line, Chen said, adding that "recreation can be integrated with cultural and ecological tourism resources and together form a convenient, comfortable and safe way of travel."
He added that the one day pass also covers the Pingsi Branch Line, which people can make use of to visit all the scenic places along the line.

The "Northeast Coast Railway One Day Pass" are available at the Taipei Main Station or stations along the North-Link Line with a free brochure introducing information on tourist spots, food and accommodations, Chen said, adding that people can receive discount at certain shops by showing the pass.

Tourists can find itineraries recommended by the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area at http: //www.necoast-nsa.gov.tw. For more information regarding the one day pass, people can call the Northeast and Yilan Coast National Scenic Area at (02) 2499-1210.
