DOC.HEADLINE: Australia takes lead against Taiwan in Davis Cup

TEXT.P: World no. 22 Lleyton Hewitt gave Australia a 1-0 lead in its Asia/Oceania Zone Group I first round Davis Cup tie against Taiwan Friday at Kaohsiung's Yangming Tennis Center with a 6-4, 6-0, 6-3 win over Chen Ti, in a match that was more tightly contested than the score might indicate.
Taiwan's No. 1 Lu Yen-hsun was trying to even the score later Friday in a match against Australia No. 2 Chris Guccione.
The winner of the best-of-five match, that includes a doubles on Saturday and two reverse singles on Sunday, advances to the second round and a shot at a World Group playoff later in the year.

Australia was relegated at the end of last year to the Davis Cup regional zone for the first time since 1996. A traditional tennis powerhouse, Australia won the Davis Cup most recently in 1999 and 2003, while finishing runner-up in 2000 and 2001. (Luke Sabatier)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Davis Cup hope likely dashed by Australia

TEXT.P: Taiwan had hoped this would be the year it could finally achieve its long- anticipated Davis Cup breakthrough and at least reach a playoff round to enter the World Group of tennis' top international team competition, but Australia is now likely to derail its plans.

Led by world number 22 Lleyton Hewitt, Australia took a 2-0 lead against Taiwan on the first day of their best-of-five Asia/Oceania Zone Group I tie Friday, and needs only a win in Saturday's doubles or either of Sunday's reverse singles to advance to the second round.

On a court that Hewitt described as "strange", the former Wimbledon champion put away the much lower ranked Chen Ti, 6-4, 6-0, 6-3 in a 2 hour 19 minute match that was more tightly contested than the score would indicate.
Hard-serving Chris Guccione then used 21 aces to edge past Taiwan no. 1 Lu Yen- hsun 7-6 (5), 6-4, 7-6 (9) in a 2-hour 55 minute match that had only one break of serve.
The arrival of Hewitt, the highest ranked player to ever perform here in a competitive event, had its positive side, sparking unprecedented interest in a local tennis event.

Although tickets were being sold for a local Davis Cup tie for the first time in Taiwan --at NT$399 for the day and NT$1,000 for a three-day pass--5,500 tennis fans filled Yangming Tennis Center's center court to capacity.

But neither Lu nor Chen could find the inspiration needed to pick up a much needed point on the opening day of the tie, even if it was always going to be a major challenge to defeat an Australian team that was relegated from the World Group to Asia/Oceania Zone Group 1 at the end of last year for the first time since 1996.
Lu had defeated Guccione in their only previous encounter, but the powerful 6-foot-7 left-hander was not deterred in a high-quality match that turned on his serve.
"I spent the entire match thinking how I could get close to his serve," said Lu, who only had five break-point opportunities the entire match.
"I was hoping he would make a few mistakes but he didn't. I only had a few opportunities and couldn't take advantage of them."
While Guccione's serve made an impression, Lu credited the 22- year-old Australian's victory to his improved volleys and movement at the net.

"I really took note when I hit some really good crosscourt returns and he got them back in really tough spots. That made it even tougher because I couldn't just return his serve, but had to put it in a place that would give him trouble," Lu said.

That Guccione was on was never more obvious than at 9-9 in the third set tiebreaker when the Australian stuck a kick serve in the corner that nearly bounced into the courtside seats, giving Lu no chance.
That set up his fifth match point in the tiebreaker, converted when Lu sent a lunging forehand long.
"The reason I served well is because I needed to," Guccione said. " (Lu) is a great player and he returns serve very well."

In the first match of the day, Taiwan's Chen was not expected to win, but he actually moved up a break in the first set at 3-2 against his far more celebrated opponent, and was the more consistent of the two players in the sloppily played first eight games.
Hewitt's class eventually held, though.

"I felt good at the beginning and had a shot at the first set, but then I got a little too conservative," said Chen, chosen to play singles ahead of Taiwan's No. 2 Wang Yeu-tzuoo, who is still nursing a wrist injury. "He started moving me around and ran me a lot side to side in long rallies, and I had trouble keeping up."

Chen, ranked 248 positions lower than Hewitt, never let the highly regarded Australian off easily, pushing three of the six games in the second set to deuce and fighting off a total of 11 breaks points in the fourth and sixth games of the final set to hold serve before succumbing.
But the 24-year-old Chen, whose goal this year is to break into the top 200 for the first time in his career, acknowledged the gap between him and Hewitt.

"From a physical point of view, I'm not at Hewitt's level. If I had been, I could have given more in the third set," said Chen, who called for a trainer to treat a pulled left thigh midway through the third set. "I'm also missing a weapon that can get me easy points. I didn't serve as well as I would have liked today and that made a difference."
Chen only managed to get in 52 percent of first serves, while Hewitt often found a big serve when he needed it.

Hewitt, playing in his 43rd Davis Cup match since his debut in 1999 and known for his commitment to an event that many top players shun, admitted that playing in a Zonal Group tie was a new experience.

"It's easy to get up to play big Davis Cup matches at home in front of 15,000 people, playing finals and semifinals. It's very easy to play those ties. These are the tough ones to get motivated for," said Hewitt, who noted nonetheless that he never gets tired of Davis Cup, calling putting on the "golden jacket of Australia" the greatest honor there is.

Hewitt did get a special taste of playing in a zonal event, playing on a court that has not seen too many big events. When asked to describe its speed, the 26 -year-old Australian could only call it "skiddy" and "dirty" with a coating of dust that made bounces tricky.

A defeat in the tie would send Taiwan into a relegation round, but more importantly will keep it out of a World Group playoff that seemed likely in 2003 when the country made it into Asia/Oceania Group I behind Lu and Wang.
Since then, injuries and organizational flaps have held Taiwan back, but on Friday, the Australians were simply too good.
Taiwan is expected to send Lu and Wang in the doubles Saturday against Australia's Paul Hanley and Hewitt to keep the tie alive into Sunday. (Luke Sabatier)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 9, or the third day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1775: Hostilities between Britain and the American colony of Massachusetts become imminent as the British Parliament announces the state is in rebellion and approves new laws to control the situation.
1799: The U.S. Navy draws first blood in a war with France.
1801: France signs the Peace of Luneville with Austria, dissolving the Holy Roman Empire.
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and who advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1830: Explorer Charles Stuart discovers the source of Australia's longest river, the Murray.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege to the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: The U.S. Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty by a vote 64-6.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the U.S. took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the U.S. returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operations.
1964: Beatlemania hits the United States as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1973: H.E. Hisham Muhiuddin Nazer, state minister of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Six winners of the Second Cathay Children's Music Contest leave Taipei for Hong Kong to attend the Arts Festival.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Polish Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
1999: A 352-page collection of news photographs depicting historic moments in ROC diplomacy over the past six decades is published by the Central News Agency, which was founded in 1924.
1999: The Republic of the Marshall Islands opens an embassy in the Republic of China, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.
2000: The Taiwan Stock Exchange performs well on the first trading session after the Chinese New Year holiday, with the market's weighted price index breaking the 10,000 point level at the close.
2001: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Deputy Director-General Francis K.H. Liang, leaves Taipei for Beijing to attend a senior officials meeting of the Asia- Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Appeal issued for people to donate blood

TEXT.P: The Taipei Blood Donation Center appealed Friday for Taipei area residents to donate blood, saying supplies in the northern part of the island are dangerously low.

The center said only 3,868 bags of blood remained in stock in Taiwan's capital, less than a three-day supply and far short of the 10,000 to 16,000 bags considered to be a safe level of inventory. Each bag contains 250 c.c. blood.

The center will remain open to collect blood through the Chinese New Year holiday, while blood-collection buses parked at some of Taipei's more bustling locations will be open for blood donations beginning Saturday.
The center urged local residents to give blood to make sure those in need have access to it.
People willing to donate blood can call the center's hot line at 02-2897-1600 or visit the Web site http: //www.tp.blood.org.tw for more information.

DOC.HEADLINE: Young legislators concerned with economy and education

TEXT.P: Newly elected young members of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan will be focusing on the economy and education when the first session of the lawmaking body opens on Feb. 22, hoping to set a new tone in an arena known more recently for partisan rancor.
One of the new faces, 33-year-old Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chen Ting-fei representing a district in Tainan City, said she felt she could make a contribution to the economy.
"A nation's economic problems cannot be solved solely by a legislator, but I will use my educational background in business administration to monitor the government's economic policies, " she said.
She also promised to devote some of her time to education issues and help ease parents' fears and worries in this area of widespread concern.

Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Lin-chun, 33, who represents Kaohsiung County, criticized the government's education policy as being hamstrung by uncertainty, which has seriously impaired the rights of parents and students.
"They have no idea which policy to follow," Chiang said, pledging to supervise the government as it makes education-related decisions.
Chiang also promised to be more engaged in economic issues because of the high unemployment rate plaguing southern Taiwan.

The youngest lawmaker in the newly elected assembly, 27-year-old KMT Legislator Chang Chia-chun representing Yunlin County, said the economy would be her priority because of her county's special nature.

"Yunlin is an agriculture-based county and is more heavily influenced by the nation's economic situation than other cities or counties, " said Chang, the daughter of one of the county's more powerful political figures, former magistrate Chang Jung-wei.
As the only legislator who was born in the 1980s, Chang promised to voice the opinions of people her own age in the new legislative body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local civic groups call for more transparent legislature

TEXT.P: The newly elected legislature should be more transparent and open to help the public better understand its internal operations and its opaque inter-party negotiating system, local civic groups said Friday.

Contending that the new legislature should be more concerned about citizens' right to be informed, Ku called on the body, which begins its first session on Feb. 22, to make legislative negotiations open to the public.

"More open hearings or debates should be held to help people understand the advantages and disadvantages of legislation, " said Ku Chung-hwa, president of the Citizen Congress Watch. "Every interpellation should be televised live and inter-party negotiations must be recorded."

Many groups have complained about the previous legislature's tendency to resolve contentious legislation behind closed doors, leading to suspicions of deal- making based on the lawmakers' individual interests.
Other basic information, such as bills pending or attendance records, have not always been readily available.
"In the past, the public couldn't get access to the body's internal rules and real-time information on its activities, which is not typical of a true democracy, " said Ku.

Noting that the Legislative Yuan is well equipped with advanced communication facilities, Peng Jin-peng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum, said the legislature could make a greater effort to improve its transparency.
"People also need to know about the attendance of the lawmakers and the voting process within the Legislative Yuan," he stressed.
Chien Hsi-chieh, chief executive officer of the Peacetime Foundation of Taiwan, said the Legislative Yuan should set up or rent a television channel to publicly broadcast every session.
"This will help people supervise our legislature and prevent corruption," Chien stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charter flights could help business at local airports rebound

TEXT.P: Launching more international charter flights and cooperating with travel agencies to create attractive tour packages could be remedies for declining passenger traffic and revenues at local airports that serve only domestic routes, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said in a statement released Saturday.
The development of local overland transportation infrastructure has taken its toll on domestic routes -- and consequently airports serving those routes.

Taiwan's 18 airports generated NT$15.7 billion (US$490.62 million) in revenue in 2006, but the only two that made money that year were its two international gateways, the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport.
To improve the finances of the 16 money-losing airports, domestic airlines should break with routes that are already well served by ground transportation and look abroad, the CAA said.
"For airports in areas like Taichung, Kinmen and Hualien, which are locations fit for international airlines, launching international charter flights could revitalize business," the statement said.

Three local airlines, Uni Air, Far Eastern Air Transport and Mandarin Airlines, all benefited from such a strategy last year, the CAA said, citing Uni Air's profitable flights from Taichung to Japan, Hong Kong and Vietnam.
Special packages to popular tourist destinations in Taiwan's eastern counties and outlying islands could also spark business, the CAA said.
"Airlines could take advantage of the areas' natural beauty in combination with support from local governments and travel agencies to provide packages that spur demand," the statement said.
Another way to create business for the underused airports, the CAA suggested, was to organize aeronautics exhibitions or festivals.
"This could produce a twofold benefit -- raising profit while enticing more public attention to the development of the airline industry," the statement said.

Business at airports serving primarily domestic routes has been ravaged by the high-speed north-south railway connecting Taipei and Kaohsiung, two major north- south freeways, and other expressways making travel around the island faster and more convenient.

The number of domestic flights in Taiwan declined at an average rate of 7.7 percent from 2001 to 2007, and passenger load factors fell 25.3 percent between January and October 2007 after the high-speed railway was launched at the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung doctor warns of fatal bacteria in seafood

TEXT.P: A doctor at a Kaohsiung hospital warned people Saturday to be especially cautious when eating or cooking raw seafood to avoid being infected by a flesh eating bacteria in the food.

Chou Chih-kang, chief of the plastic surgery division at Yuan's General Hospital in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, issued the warning after a 60-year-old woman lost the function of part of her body and almost died after getting pricked by live shrimps as she was preparing a shrimp dish.

"The woman did not pay much attention when her fingers were pricked by a shrimp shell until they became red and swollen. She was rushed to the hospital a day later due to signs of fever and shock, " Chou said.

The bacteria that attacked the woman hits people with weakened immune systems particularly hard. Chou said the woman, who suffers from cirrhosis of the liver, was such a case. The flesh-eating bacteria affected half of her body, and she has had to undergo skin grafts during her 10-week hospital stay.
Chou said the woman was affected by marine vibrio, a potentially deadly marine bacterium that usually lives in warm sea water.

As Taiwan is surrounded by sea and seafood is one of the main food sources for people on the island, outbreaks of the seafood-related illness have been reported on occasion, and Chou cautioned that a number of people were killed or had to have limbs amputated because of vibrio wound infections.
"The illness, normally transmitted through raw or uncooked seafood, is usually characterized by abdominal pain, vomiting, nausea, diarrhea, fever and shivers, " Chou said.

Some of those infected by the bacteria recover quickly because of healthy immune systems, but others without the ability to fight the infection can go into shock and even die if they do not receive medical treatment in time.

Adding that the infections can also be spread by skin contact, Chou reminded oyster farmers, fishermen, food preparers or water sports enthusiaststs to confirm they do not have cuts, scratches, or abrasions on their skin when they come into contact with fish fins, shrimp shell, oyster shells or sea water.
Because the infection spreads unusually quickly and is difficult to treat, it has a mortality rate of between 55 percent and 57 percent.

Chou said diabetics, kidney disease patients and those who take prednisolone, an anti-inflammation drug, are at 80-times higher risk of being infected than ordinary people if they come into contact with the bacteria.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Candy Cultural Festival held in Tainan County

TEXT.P: The 2008 World Candy Cultural Festival, being held in the southern county of Tainan Saturday until Feb. 24, this year is featuring Thomas & Friends wooden railway cars as one of its main attractions.

The festival, sponsored by the Tainan County government and being staged in Hsiaolung Cultural Park in Jiali Township, has nine pavilions with a variety of special activities, with three for candy, one for chocolate, two for distinctive Taiwanese cultural displays, one for architectural designs, and one for Thomas & Friends wooden railway cars.
A playground was also set up for children.
Thomas & Friends is a famous U.S. brand of train toys based on the story written by Rev. W. Awdry for his son.

The Thomas & Friends wooden railway cars and the defunct "mini cargo trains" owned by Taiwan Sugar Corp. shuttle children who attend the event around the park to see models of famous tourist attractions in China, Southeast Asia, Japan and West Europe, the organizers said.
The county government has also designed three package tours, featuring the county's tourist attractions, for visitors to include as part of their sighteeeing plans for the Chinese New Year holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Free career consultation for job seekers available: CLA

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) can help job hunters make better decisions by offering an all-around career assessment to those who plan to look for a new job after the Chinese New Year, a CLA official said Saturday.

Lai Shu-li, an official of CLA's Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training, noted that Many Taiwanese hunt for new jobs after the New Year holiday, up to three times as many as during other times of the year, and employers also tend to create more positions in response to the job-seeking frenzy.

To help with their search, job seekers can take advantage of the bureau's consulting service at 351 career centers islandwide, said Lai. The bureau helps job hunters find their most suitable career paths by evaluating the professional attributes and interests of the respondent.

The service also includes an online platform providing Internet users with a personalized career checklist that steers job seekers toward careers in which they might have a better chance to prosper, Lai noted.
"The evaluation that is based on the checklist can also help the respondent to know himself better and develop greater fulfillment at work, thus helping lower the job transfer rate," he added.
Lai said job seekers can also use the CLA's career guidebooks to understand the future prospects of an industry, including its average salary and working conditions.
The bureau's online service operates 24 hours a day year round, even during the Chinese New Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NGO urges government to do more to control tobacco use

TEXT.P: An anti-tobacco organization said Friday that Taiwan's government should make more concrete efforts to control the use of tobacco, after a World Health Organization (WHO) report released Thursday said tobacco use kills 5.4 million people a year.

"Taiwan was once a model in the area of tobacco control. But in recent years, other countries have reached Taiwan's level by carrying out anti-tobacco policies efficiently while the Taiwanese government seems to hesitate, " said Lin Ching-li, the director of the tobacco control section of the John Tung Foundation (JTF) , in a phone interview with the Central News Agency.
The JTF, one of the most prominent nongovernmental organizations in Taiwan, was founded in 1984 to promote the public's interest in the areas of tobacco control and mental health.

The WHO's first report on global tobacco use and control efforts released Thursday in New York said tobacco use has become one of the biggest public health threats the world has ever faced, killing 5.4 million people a year at present and likely to kill 8 million by 2030.
About 20,000 people die annually from tobacco-related diseases in Taiwan, where about 5 million people, or 22 percent of the total population, smoke, according to foundation statistics.

Although Taiwan is not a WHO member state, it has made efforts to reduce tobacco use. In late January, the Department of Health (DOH) proposed raising the health tax on cigarettes to NT$45 a pack instead of the current NT$10.
An amendment to the Tobacco Hazard Control Act approved by the Legislative Yuan will also be implemented in early 2009.

"But Taiwan can do much better, " Lin said, arguing that the government should raise the tobacco commodity tax from 50 percent to at least 70 percent like most European countries, because "high prices are the most effective way to reduce tobacco use."

Lin added that surface area of warnings on cigarette packaging should be enlarged from 35 percent to 60 percent of the pack's total area, citing Canada's experience in which that country's young smoking population has dropped by 11 percent since big surface area graphic warnings were mandated in 2001.
"We hope that Taiwan come up with more resolute anti-tobacco policies, and establishes a smoke-free environment, " Lin stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate meets 'house stay' host families in Kaohsiung

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou pledged Saturday that if elected, he will strive to restore Taiwan's core values, such as moral virtue and working in a down-to-earth way.

Meeting with 24 families that hosted him during his "house stay" community outreach activities in Kaohsiung City, and Kaohiung and Pingtung counties over the past six months, Ma said he better understood through them the major problems in Taiwan's society.
"I eventually realized that the problems are from the government rather that from the society at large," Ma said.
He vowed that he would work to bring back Taiwan's core values and further build a harmonious society, enhance integrity in government and promote peaceful relations with China.
Saying that he regarded the families he stayed with as relatives, Ma hoped that his relationship with those family members would be more than an "overnight one" and be developed on a long-term basis.
"Since I embarked on my 'house stay' journey six months ago, I have stayed with 89 host families, " Ma said, and voiced his heartfelt gratitude for those who made breakfast for him during his stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC chief to present Taiwan-France Science & Technology Awards
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 9 (CNA) 02/09/08 20:23:01 (By P.C. Tand and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: National Science Council (NSC) Minister Chen Chien-jen will present the "2007 Taiwan-France Science & Technology Awards" to the two laureates at an awarding ceremony to be held in Paris on Feb. 11, officials at the Taipei Representative Office in France said Saturday.

The awards -- established in 1999 based on an agreement between the cabinet- level NSC and Academie des Sciences, Institut de France (French Academy Institute) -- are issued to one or two distinguished scientists in Taiwan or France to honor their achievements in specific scientific areas designated for the year by the review board.

Biology and chemistry were the areas designated for 2007, while mathematics, physics, chemistry, astronomy, geoscience, and engineering were the main categories for 2008, according to the NSC liaison office stationed in France.

The office said that the 2007 award winners are Hsing Yue-ie -- a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Plant and Microbial Biology -- and Michel Delseny -- a research fellow at University of Perpignan/CNRS in France.

According to Academia Sinica, Delseny and Hsing have been friends for 20 years and collaborated on seed research ever since. The duo's research led to major advances in rice genomics and functional genomics.

They analyzed a group of unique seeds laced with late embryogenesis abundant proteins -- which are essential to the desiccation tolerance in seed -- and their study of the protein's structure and potential functions has paved the way for many other valuable research results.

A NSC liaison officer noted that they were selected not only for their scientific accomplishments, also for their contribution to the promotion of bilateral academic and educational exchanges between Taiwan and France.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air quality in Taipei City during holiday better than usual

TEXT.P: Recent air pollution index readings from monitoring stations in Taipei City showed that air quality in the city during the first four days of the Chinese New Year holiday has been better than usual, an Environmental Protection Administration official said Saturday.

The official attributed the improvement to a significant decrease in vehicle exhaust fumes, as many commuters have either left the city to return to their hometowns in central and southern Taiwan for the New Year break, or simply stayed at home to enjoy the break.
Taipei's gain, however, came at the expense of central and southern Taiwan, where the vehicles heading south contributed to pollution in those areas.

Central and southern Taiwan benefited from the closure of polluting factories for the holidays, but the added exhaust fumes have kept pollution readings in the area at pre-holiday levels, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu to develop merchandise with distinct local flavor

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau of the Lienchiang County government wants to develop new local merchandise with a distinct local flavor that can spark business expansion and promote tourism in the area.
Lienchiang County is the administrative name for the outlying Matsu Islands, located 211 kilometers northeast of Taiwan.

The county attracts more than 100,000 visitors a year, a number that is still growing, who spend about NT$750 million (US$23.43 million) a year while visiting the county's islands. Because at least 40 percent of that is spent on local specialties, the bureau estimated that a market of at least NT$300 million exists for special products from the region.

The government has given financial support to the development of local products over the years, and believes that more investment from the private sector will boost the attractiveness of local merchandise.

With tourism the key engine of local economic growth, Matsu is known for its local liquors, fish noodles and bakeries. In the past goods from China were often seen on the shelves of local gift shops because of the direct transport links between the islands and China, but these products were later withdrawn because of their low-quality.
According to local tour guides, visitors in recent years have begun to complain about local products for their plainness and lack of choice.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australia downs Taiwan in Davis Cup

TEXT.P: For a while on Saturday, it appeared that Taiwan would pull off an unlikely upset in the doubles of its Asia/Oceania Zone Group I tie against Australia to keep its hopes alive, but the experience of the visitors and some unappreciated trash talking helped them prevail in five sets and clinch victory in the tie.

Trailing 2-0 after Friday's singles, Taiwan needed Lu Yen-hsun and Wang Yeu- tzuoo, who had not played together since the 2006 Asian Games in Doha, to beat doubles specialist Paul Hanley and Lleyton Hewitt, an accomplished doubles player in his own right, to make Sunday's reverse singles matches matter.

But after winning the first two sets, Taiwan became slightly deflated after Wang was broken early in the third set and eventually succumbed 4-6, 6-7 (4), 6-4, 6-2, 6-2, a defeat that gave Australia an insurmountable 3-0 lead in the tie.

With the victory, Australia advances to the second round of the group to face the winner of the tie between Thailand and Kazakhstan, which Thailand led 2-1 after Saturday's doubles. The winner of that battle will enter a World Group playoff that would give Australia a chance to get back into the elite 16-country World Group in which it has held a spot every year since 1981 except for 1996.

Taiwan, on the other hand, will enter a relegation playoff to keep its spot in Asia/Oceania Group I, where it has been since 2004. If it beats the loser of Thailand/Kazakhstan, its 2008 campaign will come to an end.

Although the arrival of Australia propped up local tennis, at least for a weekend, by drawing record crowds and media attention, it was also likely to extend Taiwan's Davis Cup frustration of never having a World Group playoff, despite having two of Asia's best players.

Hewitt beat Taiwan's Chen Ti in straight sets in the opening singles on Friday and Chris Guccione edged Taiwan no. 1 Lu in a match that Taiwan needed to have a chance on the weekend to give Australia a decisive advantage.

For the first two sets on Saturday, however, Lu and Wang were extremely sharp, and after Wang smashed a gorgeous crosscourt backhand to pass Hewitt to win the second set tiebreaker, an upset appeared possible.

But the Australians picked up the quality of their service returns and when they broke Wang's serve in the third game of the third set to go up 2-1, Taiwan was always on the defensive after that, being broken in the first games of the fourth and fifth sets.

After the match, Lu called the weekend "disappointing" but felt the matches had been played at a high level. More disconcerting to both Lu and Wang, however, was Hewitt's apparent expletive- and insult-laced trash talking during the doubles.
"They may have won the match, but they didn't win our respect, " Lu said, with both players chiding Hewitt for a lack of class.

Taiwan's team captain Lien Yu-hui, who ironically played doubles on Taiwan's last team that last a Davis Cup tie to Australia in 1996, protested to the chair umpire but said he didn't want to make a big deal of it on the court.

The Davis Cup is the world's most prestigious men's team tennis competition, with 16 countries in the World Group playing for the Cup every year. Below the elite level are regional zones, with Group I the highest level.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: The TimesG Archbishop faces calls to quit over Sharia row The Archbishop of Canterbury was facing a crisis of confidence in his leadership yesterday after calling for parts of Islamic law, or Sharia, to be introduced into Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 10, or the fourth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1846: British forces defeat Sikhs at Sobranhan, India.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1894: Harold Macmillan, British statesman and Conservative prime minister, is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the Republic of China-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In an historic exchange, captured U.S. spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking to freedom from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the ROC recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with the European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1974: An all-star women's basketball team leaves Taipei for a tour of the United States.
1976: Work begins on an elevated road across the North Gate area of Taipei, in a move designed to relieve traffic congestion.
1980: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with Colombia.
1981: King Juan Carlos names Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo as prime minister of Spain.
1981: The 32 new ROC Control Yuan members are sworn in.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a congratulatory message to President- elect Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
1998: Former French Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann dies. He is considered a founding father of the European Union.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua sign a joint communique reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.
2001: Fan Liqing and Zhen Binhua, the first two mainland Chinese reporters allowed to be stationed in Taiwan, cover their first story, with themselves being the center of attention among the local press.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man only wishes to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Passengers using Kinmen airport for flights to Taiwan proper

TEXT.P: The Shang Yi Airport on the Taiwan-controlled outlying island of Kinmen began in the early hours of Sunday to host crowds of travelers bound for Taiwan proper.
Despite the Lunar New Year holiday still having a full day to run people flocked to the airport, keen to fly back to their residences in Taiwan's cities.

Although a joint ticket counter opened by four domestic airlines operating Taiwan-Kinmen flights did not open until 7 a.m., people without reserved flights began to form a queue in front of the counter at 4 a.m.
As of 11: 30 a.m., there were more than 400 travelers on the waiting list, nearly 300 of whom were trying to get to Taipei, with only 60 people having obtained seats.

Airport Director Hung Nien-tsi said the number of passengers on the waiting list recorded a decline of nearly 50 percent in comparison with the level of the same period of last year, speculating that this might be a result of the shorter holiday this year.
The 2007 Lunar New Year festival ran from Feb. 17-22, but most people enjoyed a holiday spanning nine days after a workday adjustment. This year, the festival took place Feb. 6-11.
On Sunday, there were a total of 64 planned Kinmen-Taiwan flights and 30 extra flights, for a total of around 5,000 available seats, according to the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Maokong Gondola worth queuing in cold for': Taipei mayor

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Sunday that it is worth waiting in line in the cold to take the Maokong Gondola and see the sights along the cable car line in the city's Muzha district.
Like most places in Taiwan, Taipei was affected by a cold snap that arrived on Chinese New Year's Eve and continued on through the national holiday, bringing the mercury down to as low as 10 degrees.
Despite the cold, however, the gondola passenger numbers increased by 10 percent-20 percent, causing inevitable waits, Hau noted.
"Many passengers said the 40-minute ride was worth the one-hour wait," Hau added.
Hau was visiting the gondola system's Maokong Station and the Taipei Zoo, which is included on the line, to extend New Year's greetings to tourists and staff members.

The cable car system had about 22,000 passengers Feb. 7, 24,000 Feb. 8 and 25,000 Feb. 9, according to the Taipei Rapid Transport Corp., which operates the gondola. The system usually has about 20,000 passengers per day.
The gondola was closed Feb. 4-6 for maintenance, and was slated to remain open for 11 consecutive days from Feb. 7-17.

In contrast, the number of visitors to the Taipei Zoo during the holiday dropped by nearly half from last year's figure owing to the cold and rain, Taipei Zoo Director Chen Pao-chung said, adding however that an exhibition on rodents -- echoing the theme of the Year of the Rat -- was gaining popularity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever Chinese tourist group due to visit Taiwan Monday

TEXT.P: Nearly 700 Chinese tourists are expected to make port Monday in Taiwan aboard the Rhapsody of the Sea -- Asia's largest ocean liner -- making them the largest Chinese tourist group ever to be allowed to visit Taiwan, a local daily reported Sunday.

To welcome the tourists, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) has decided to relax the government's "no more than 1,000 visitors per day" restriction and to offer the tourists rapid customs clearance, the Chinese- language United Daily News reported.

According to the report, the MAC is "torn between loving and fearing" the visit by such a large number of Chinese travelers -- anticipating that the visits will provide a shot in the arm to the administration's "doubling the number of foreign tourists" plan, while fearing that some of them might abscond in Taiwan.
According to MAC regulations, the two Taiwan travel agencies authorized to sponsor the visits will be fined NT$200,000 (US$6,211) for each Chinese tourist who runs away.

The Rhapsody of the Sea is scheduled to berth at Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan Monday -- the last day of the six-day Chinese New Year holiday -- and at Kaohsiung Harbor in the south the following day.

The tourists are scheduled to be bused into Taipei City Monday for a half-day tour, with another half-day tour of Kaohsiung City the following day. The visitors are expected to generate business worth over NT$10 million in the two largest cities in Taiwan, according to the travel agencies.
The Rhapsody of the Sea is the first ocean liner to be given the green light by the MAC to bring Chinese tourists to Taiwan via a third country or area.

With over 2,000 holidaymakers aboard, including those from Southeast Asia, Australia, New Zealand and Hong Kong, the Rhapsody of the Sea is scheduled to leave Kaohsiung late Tuesday for a return voyage to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Baby Boss City' provides children with taste of adulthood

TEXT.P: "Baby Boss City, " a theme park for children aged between 3 and 15 years old to "get a taste of adult working life, " opened in the Taipei Living Mall over the Lunar New Year holiday, allowing children to "try out their dreams jobs, explor e career aptitudes and learn about the value of money, " according to its creative director.

"Baby Boss City is the first of its kind in the Greater China Area, " said Richard Tsai, who added that the project took a year of preparation and an investment of NT$400 million (US$12.4 million) by the SECOM Group, a local security company.
He said the concept came from a similar theme park called "Kidzania" in Mexico and other derivations such as "Wannado City" in the United States.

Kidzania, which opened in Mexico City in 1999, has turned out to be a huge success, receiving about 800,000 visitors annually. Japan and Indonesia also opened similar theme parks in 2006 and 2007, respectively.
"Kids like hands-on experiences where they can learn about an occupation by talking about it or better yet experiencing it through `job shadowing,'" Tsai said.
The 7613-square-meter Baby Boss City is a unique indoor family entertainment center, a micro-city replicating a real city with streets, buildings, retail outlets and vehicles.

Children can play adult roles in over 70 professions and occupations in this "real world replica, " according to Tsai, who added that it is a "safe, interactive and educational center where children actually perform the roles they are playing. "

Chu Han-kuang, marketing manager of the SECOM Group, said that led by a highly qualified team, "children will learn about the complexities of the adult world, its infrastructure, occupations and the value of money, just as in real life."

Designed to have children work independently without their parents around, the children will spend 35-45 minutes at every job, which the organizers claimed will allow them to "learn about the professional knowledge and experience the entire process" of working a job.

"Kids cannot focus on their work, think independently and choose what they really want to do with parents intervening, " Chu said, adding that parents can nevertheless take pictures from outside the huge glass windows.

Children begin the game with 20 "Baby Bucks, " the official currency of the "Baby Boss City," and will earn 10 "Baby Bucks" after finishing every job. They can use the money to buy goods and services or deposit it in a bank.
"Kids need to know that they are here to work. Therefore they are not supposed to take home the products but can buy them with special discounts, " Chu explained.

Liu Yang-hsin, mother of an 11-year-old, said the concept "is really good. Kids can learn and find out their interests from the games, which may help them decide what they want to do when they grow up. So I will definitely bring my kid again."

However she complained that since there were too many people, her child could only experience three jobs in three hours. Liang Hsiu-fen, mother of a six-year- old, added that the tickets are also too expensive.
"Parents need to pay NT$500 per person while a child's ticket costs NT$900," she pointed out.
Tsai said tickets bought online are 15 percent cheaper and reservations can be made up to three months in advance.

"Baby Boss City" has received sponsorship from multinational brands like Coca- Cola, Sony and Epson to leading domestic enterprises such as Kuang Chuan Dairy Co., TransAsia Airways, and I-mei Foods Co. Visitors learn how to operate different retail and service facilities according to these sponsors' standards.

"Commercial partners are key to 'Baby Boss City,' as they provide realism to the concept by sharing their brands and products in each pavilion. They enhance the activity by sharing their processes and technologies," Chu said.

The facility attracted more than 80,000 visitors during its Jan. 28-Feb. 6 trial period, Tsai said, adding that the turnover in the first year is estimated to reach NT$300 million with an estimated 700,000 visitors and that the SECOM Group is also planning to launch a similar project in China later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Laboratory in Taiwan to offer full WiMAX accreditation services

TEXT.P: The TTC-CCS laboratory, which is co-sponsored by the government and a private company, has been accredited by the WiMAX Forum to provide both fixed and mobile WiMAX certification services to manufacturers in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a statement released by the lab Sunday.

The WiMAX Forum is an industry-led, nonprofit organization initiated to certify and promote the compatibility and interoperability of products using the Worldwide Interoperability for Microwave Access, or WiMAX technology.

The forum presently has six certification testing labs worldwide -- four of them located in the United States, Europe, China and South Korea. The other two, both in Taiwan, are operated by ADT Corp. and the TTC-CCS Laboratory. The organization is now mulling whether to establish an additional lab in India later this year.
ADT was accredited to offer mobile WiMAX certification late last year, and TTC- CCS is the first in Taiwan that can also accredit fixed WiMAX products, said the statement.

TTC-CCS Lab, a joint venture of the government-funded Telecom Technology Center (TTC) in Kaohsiung and the Taipei-based Compliance Certification Services Inc., Taiwan (CCS), is said to integrate both parent institutions' long experience in testing the compatibility of various electronic products to provide a better service in the additional category of WiMAX.
In addition, Spain's AT4 wireless -- the first WiMAX Forum accredited lab in the world -- will also provide all necessary technical assistance to perfect the procedure, TTC staff said.

Commenting on the lab, WiMAX Forum President Ron Resnick said in the statement that it is a positive step toward ensuring capacity to answer the demand for WiMAX Forum Certified testing of Taiwanese industry and manufacturers in the Asian market.

Meanwhile, TTC Chairman Chien Jen-ter said the lab will provide excellent services to all forum members, while CCS Chairman Rock Hsu said the TTC-CCS is capable of satisfying the needs of both Taiwanese and global WiMAX manufacturers in terms of WiMAX certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Snow draws tourists to Hehuan mountain

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 tourist-packed automobiles drove up to the snow-capped Hehuan mountain in central Taiwan Sunday as sunlight warmed the bitterly cold air that has been chilling the island since Thursday.

Since Lunar New Year's Day Thursday, the whole country has been covered by an arctic air mass packing frigid winds. In the early hours of that day, Hehuan mountain, situated on the border of Nantou and Hualien counties, received the largest snowfall of this winter, according to a manager of the Hehuan Hostel, situated at over 3,100 meters.

Temperatures around the hostel were down to minus 3 degrees Celsius, the manager said, noting that the road over the mountain -- the highest highway in Taiwan at 3,275 meters -- was covered by around 6cm of snow.
The frigid weather, however, did not keep the tourists away, the hostel manager added.

The Central Weather Bureau reported that the cold front was weakening, with the temperatures expected to increase by 1-2 degrees Celsius Monday to 11-15 degrees in northern Taiwan, 11-19 degrees in the central region, and 13-24 degrees in the south, with showers expected in northern, northeastern and eastern areas the following day, according to the bureau's weather forecast report issued Sunday.

Chen Chang-nan, a police officer stationed at Jenai township, Nantou County, warned visitors to Hehuan mountain to beware of icy road conditions in the mountain area and he suggested that drivers use snow chains on their tires.

DOC.HEADLINE: President presents lucky money to orphans

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented lucky money to orphans in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan Sunday, the fourth day of the Lunar New Year, to show his concern for the wellbeing of orphans.
Chen visited the Hong Hua Orphanage in Taoyuan County's Tayuan township and the Ministry of the Interior's Northern Region Children's Home -- another orphanage -- in Taoyuan's Luchu township.
The children living in the orphanages greeted Chen with dance and he wished them well in their studies, as well as expressing gratitude to their teachers.
After visiting the orphanages, Chen went to a temple in Luchu township to pray for Taiwan's prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to produce cellulose alcohol to fuel bio-energy supply

TEXT.P: A government-run laboratory has initiated a project to produce cellulose alcohol from rice straw with the aim of expanding the sources of raw materials for biofuel, government sources reported Saturday.

Researchers of the project, sponsored by the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER) under the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council, have completed testing a prototype system of cellulose alcohol production and expect to establish a pilot plant with a daily alcohol output of 200 liters by late 2009.

Straw is mainly composed of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin, Project Director Wang Chia-pao explained, adding that xylose and glucose, both ingredients for alcohol, can be extracted from cellulose and hemicellulose.
"Our refining techniques can turn xylose and glucose into alcohol with 99.5 percent purity, which is suitable for gasohol production, " Wand noted.

Compared to using cane or corn, there are several inherent benefits in using straw, Wang pointed out, adding that one of them is that the straw is essentially agricultural by-product, which means the demands of the food market will not be threatened by the demands of biofuel, which could bring higher profits for farmers and wholesalers.

"However, " Wang continued, "the only downside at the present stage is that the production cost is still far higher than the acceptable range." Citing U.S. tallies, Wang said one liter of cellulose alcohol would cost NT$21.5 (about US$0.67).
Wang said once the cost is brought to below NT$10 per liter, the price will become competitive and the straw techniques will be worth putting into mass production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung mayor touts MRT system's coziness, convenience

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu took a ride on the Red Line of the city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system Sunday, the third day the system was open for free test rides before its formal inauguration later this year.

Accompanied by several municipal officials during her ride from station R8 in the bustling Sando commercial district to Kaihsuan station R5, Chen lauded the coziness and convenience of the mass rapid transit service.
"Although the train carriages swing mildly, the ride is generally comfortable and convenient, " Chen said, expressing her hope that the system will win praise and support from commuters.
She also touted the MRT system's avant-garde design, sleekness, bright ambience and spacious stations, saying it will provide a new mode of transport services for city dwellers.
The mayor also promised to push Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. (KRTC) to speed up preparatory work to get the system ready for formal commercial operations as early as possible.

The Red Line opened for free test rides Feb. 8 as part of the city's Lunar New Year celebrations. More than 220,000 residents in the southern port city had ridden on the system over the past three days, KRTC officials said.
The test rides will continue until Monday with an average of 350 trains operated per day, or one train every four minutes, the officials said.

"As city residents have long awaited the opening of the new transport system, the test ride has received enthusiastic response, with every train carriage jammed with passengers anxious to get a taste of the system, " said a KRTC official.

The system was originally scheduled for inauguration on the Lunar New Year's Day, which fell on Feb. 7 this year. According to city government sources, the exact opening day cannot be set until after the Ministry of Transportation and Communications completes field inspections.

Senator Barack Obama won decisive victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Washington, Louisiana and Nebraska on Saturday, giving him an impressive sweep going into a month when the Democratic nominating contests are expected to favor him.
The Wall Street Journal: Huckabee Wins Kansas, Louisiana; Obama Defeats Clinton in Contests

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's textile industry builds production base in Vietnam

TEXT.P: Vietnam has become an important production base for Taiwan's textile industry, with many Vietnam-bound investments seeing growth in output value and profits, an industry representative said Sunday.

Many of Taiwan's textile enterprises that have invested in China have transferred their investments or moved their investment focus from China to Vietnam to diversify operational risk and reduce production costs due to operational difficulties stemming from China's increasing labor costs, the rising renminbi exchange rate, and the more and more strict environmental laws and regulations in China.

Compared with China, Vietnam is attractive for investors because of its large population, abundant labor force, highly skilled workers, and relatively low labor costs. Its entry into the World Trade Organization last year has made the country a preferred investment destination for foreign investors.

An executive of the Eclat Textile Co., a Taiwan-based fabric and garment manufacturer, said the company started investing in Vietnam several years ago because of its good location, low labor costs and high market potential.
The company first set up a garment manufacturing plant in Vietnam and plans to also establish a fabric manufacturing plant there, producing 800,000 kg per month, the spokesman said.
The company has production bases in Taiwan, China, Cambodia, Africa and Vietnam, with the Vietnamese plant gradually gaining more and more important status.
Another Taiwan-based company, Tainan Spinning Co. headquartered in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, started investing in Vietnam more than a decade ago.

It has recently expanded its production capacity in Vietnam, hoping to increase capacity to 520,000 spindles this year and make it Vietnam's leading spinning manufacturer, the industry representative said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of China-based Taiwanese companies heading home rising

TEXT.P: The number of China-based Taiwanese companies heading home due to changing Chinese business and investment conditions has risen to a record high, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Sunday.

As of the end of 2007, the MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center had received 102 applications filed by overseas-based Taiwanese companies to return to Taiwan for fresh investment projects, center officials said.

Of these applications, 60 were filed by China-based Taiwanese companies, followed by 28 filed by Taiwanese companies based in Canada and the United States, nine from Southeast Asia and five from other areas of the world, the officials said.

The officials attributed the increasing number of China-based Taiwanese companies relocating their investments from China back to Taiwan mainly to the facts that China has begun to implement a new business tax law, a new labor contract law and lower export tax rebates from Jan. 1 -- factors that will inevitably push up business and investment costs there.

A Taiwanese businessman who spoke to CNA on condition of anonymity and who has ended his operations in China only recently, said he was forced to terminate his operations by "wavering Chinese laws, uncertainties involving investment and lower-than-expected profit margins."
"Going home is the best and warmest option," he said, adding that the Executive Yuan's moves to improve Taiwan's investment climate is another factor that caused him to decide to retreat from China.

Meanwhile, the officials said, China's implementation of its new labor contract law and other harsher business laws, plus the incessantly rising Chinese currency have pushed up business and investment costs, causing unprecedented pressure for Taiwanese firms with operations in China.

They added that the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade has become aware of the problems facing Taiwanese companies and has moved to address the issue, including collecting trade and business information from Japan and South Korea to learn how and whether the governments of those countries help tide Japanese and Korean companies operating in China over their difficulties coping with the new investment conditions.

Officials from the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said the bureau requires the Executive Yuan to increase allocation of IDB funds for industrial development this year to help accommodate recently returned Taiwanese manufacturers.
They said the allocation should be increased from the original NT$50 billion (US$1.55 billion) to NT$70 billion to help facilitate the relocation of newly returned Taiwanese companies.

Industrial zones targeted as ideal host locations include the Litse Industrial Zone in the eastern county of Yilan, an industrial zone in Kangshan in the southern county of Kaohsiung, Taipei County's Wuku, Liuying in the southern county of Tainan and an industrial zone in the eastern county of Hualien, they added.
Meanwhile, the Industrial Development and Investment Center officials said that not all China-based Taiwanese investment operations are suitable or even welcome to return to Taiwan.

Officials from the MOEA and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council will travel to South Asia and Southeast Asia more often this year to better understand the investment climates there so as to help relocate such unwelcome Taiwanese manufacturing companies to overseas locations other than China, they went on.
Those companies deemed unwelcome involve manufacturing industries that demand high levels of energy consumption, produce high levels of pollution and are highly labor-intensive, the officials said.

Vietnam and Cambodia -- emerging markets that still welcome all types of investment from abroad -- could be the top choice for such investment relocation, they said, adding that Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines could also be considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate supports 'religion diplomacy'

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh called Sunday for all members and followers of I-Kuan Tao -- a Taiwan-headquartered school of Taoists -- residing around the world to demonstrate the strength of "religion diplomacy" to contribute to the benefit of Taiwan.

Hsieh traveled to an I-Kuan Tao temple run by the Bao Guang Jian De (BGJD) Foundation located in Shihkang township in the central county of Taichung Sunday to wish I-Kuan Tao followers a happy Lunar New Year.
In his address to temple officials and temple goers, Hsieh stressed the importance of "sincerity and honesty, " saying that if a man is not trustworthy, he is unable to stand tall in society.

Meanwhile, Wu Den-yih, secretary-general of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , also visited the temple on Hsieh's heels. Wu came to relay greetings on behalf of KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou.
Officials of the BGJD Foundation, however, were intentionally "cool" toward the politicians, saying that they maintain "neutrality" toward all people regardless of their political affiliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dasyueshan enters birdwatching season

TEXT.P: The Dasyueshan National Forest Recreation Area in central Taiwan entered its birdwatching season, with the fruit of the idesia polycarpa tree, a large deciduous tree, drawing a variety of rare bird species, an official of the Executive Yuan's Forestry Bureau said Sunday.

Situated on the backside of the southwest-facing main ridge of the Syueshan range, the area is world-renowned for birdwatching during the December-February period when the idesia polycarpa is in fruit.

The glittering red fruit attract rarely seen birds such as the vivid niltava, the white-eared sibia, the green-backed tit, the black-browed barbet, the brown thrush, the island thrush, Swinhoe's pheasant and the mikado pheasant.

Birdwatchers might be able to see rare species like Swinhoe's pheasant or mikado pheasant right beside them on Trail 210 in the area in the afternoon in summer or in winter when a cold snap hits Taiwan, the official said, adding that birdwatchers come from as far afield as the U.K., the U.S. and Sweden.
The official invited bird lovers to visit the area but reminded them not to scare the birds and to remain quiet.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for regional cooperation on visit to Dongsha Island

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian landed Sunday on the Taiwan-held Dongsha Island in the South China Sea for a visit to military personnel stationed there, whom he wished a happy Lunar New Year.

It was Chen's third visit to the remote atoll since he assumed office in 2000. During his visit, he again brought up his "Spratly Initiative, " which he first made public the previous week in a call for regional cooperation aimed at developing the South China Sea into a huge marine conservation zone.

According to a news release from the Presidential Office, Chen stated in his address that the establishment of the Dongsha Atoll Marine National Park last year was the first step by Taiwan to carry out the eco-friendly development proposal.

All countries surrounding the South China Sea have been increasing their claims over sovereignty of the islands in the area over the past several years in an attempt to control the abundant energy sources believed to be under the seabed in the area, Chen said.

"As an oceanic people, we always assert that the ocean is not the end of our footsteps but an endless extension of our horizons. The ocean should not be a barrier and blockade among competitors, but a passageway for exchanges," Chen said.
In his proposed initiative, Chen went on, he made clear that "only peace, biology and cooperation are the future of the South China Sea."

With this in mind, he urged all the surrounding countries to give priority to his proposal to develop the South China Sea into a marine conservation zone in a joint effort to preserve valuable marine and natural resources.

The Dongsha Atoll Marine National Park, formally established Jan. 17, 2007 by the Taiwanese government on the Dongsha Island and its surrounding waters, is part of the country's efforts to practice conservation, Chen said.
The park is the seventh national park of Taiwan.

On the Dongsha Island, a coral atoll with a land area of 2.38 sq. km. that forms the Pratas Islands along with two coral reefs, Chen inspected a weather monitoring station and visited a local temple before meeting with military and coast guard personnel stationed there.

Chen was accompanied by Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, Chief of the General Staff Hou Shou-yeh, Minister of the Coast Guard Administration Wang Ginn-wang and Lin Chia-lung, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office.

Chen originally intended to visit the Dongsha Island Feb. 2 following a visit to Taiping Island in the Spratly archipelago, also in the South China Sea, but the plan was canceled due to bad weather, the news release said. The Dongsha Island is located 444 km southwest of the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 11, or the fifth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1889: A constitution is granted in Japan with a two-chamber Diet, with the Emperor retaining extensive powers.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1922: A treaty for securing China's independence and maintaining an "open door" is signed in Washington by nine powers.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty, which gives Vatican City the status of an independent sovereign state.
1944: American war planes strike heavy blows against Japanese positions in the Marshall Islands.
1945: The Yalta Conference ends with an agreement for the establishment of the United Nations as well as plans for the defeat of Germany.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with France.
1967: Military rule is imposed in Beijing.
1968: Communist troops execute 300 civilians in South Vietnam during fighting for the city of Hue.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as the first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning underwater nuclear testing.
1973: Lic. Raimundo Guerrero, president of the Mexican Chapter of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1974: Archbishop Domenico Enrici, roving ambassador of the Holy See, arrives in Taipei on an inspection tour. He had served in the Apostolic Internunciature in Taipei 20 years earlier.
1974: Nineteen top Chinese golfers, including Melbourne World Cup Champions Lu Liang-huan and M.N. Hsieh, leave for Manila for the Asian circuit.
1974: U.S. Army Assistant Secretary Eugene E. Berg and a party of 2 arrive in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman as its leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed Edward Heath.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives the visiting Dr. N. B. Sommer, the first vice president of U.S. Cyanamid Corporation, and W. A. Liffers, the Pacific area general manager.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after strikes, riots, and mass demonstrations against his rule.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela is freed after being imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure be disbanded by April 1.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa and U.S. President Bill Clinton fail to reach a critical trade deal.
2000: Liu Shao-tang, publisher of the Chinese-language monthly Biographical Literature, dies at the age of 80 after a long illness.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."
