DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate urges rival to save ad funds for charity

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh renewed his call Monday for his Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Ma Ying-jeou, not to splurge on campaign advertisements but rather donate those campaign funds to disadvantaged children.
Hsieh, accompanied by Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu and his top aides, repeated his appeal after visiting temples in the southern port city of Kaohsiung earlier the same day.

Claiming that a week-long advertising campaign could cost more than NT$20 million (US$625,000) , Hsieh said that Ma should cut back on campaign spending and donate the funds saved to local orphans or for providing free lunches to schoolchildren of low-income families.
Hsieh renewed his appeal to get Ma to agree to his recent proposal to have "more debates and fewer advertisements" and "more facts and fewer smears" in the run- up to the March 22 elections.
In response, Ma only said on the campaign trail in the southern city of Chiayi that he "respects Hsieh's opinion."

Meanwhile, both Hsieh and Ma have agreed to attend debates or platform presentations to be organized by local media organizations and the Central Election Commission, respectively, later this month and next month, though Hsieh called for more debates between the two candidates.
Hsieh also promised that if elected president, he will boost the economy and help China-based Taiwanese business people resolve problems relating to capital, technology, and labor.
Hsieh added that he will prevent a China-bound investment craze from hollowing out Taiwan's industries.
He also stressed the need to check and balance the powers of the future government and urged voters not to hand the presidency to the KMT as it now dominates the country's legislature.
The KMT secured 81 seats, nearly three-quarters of the total in the new 113-seat legislature, in last month's legislative elections, while the DPP only took 27 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group vows to scrutinize new legislature

TEXT.P: The Citizen Congress Watch (CCW), a private watchdog dedicated to scrutinizing Taiwan's parliament, will pay close attention to the newly-elected legislature in which the opposition Kuomintang-led "pan-blue" camp holds three-quarters of the seats, the group's head said Monday.

CCW Chairman Ku Chung-hua said that the watchdog group will evaluate the performance of legislators "based on their attendance records and speeches during the current legislative session that began Feb. 1."

The watchdog will also request the right to observe committee meetings relating to the rights of citizens, hold a forum in mid-February to draw up a white paper on parliamentary reform and organize a parade March 15 demanding greater legislative transparency and openness, Ku said.

Former Legislator Joanna Lei suggested that the watchdog organization use three tools to supervise the legislature: the Legislative Yuan's Gazette, the property declarations of public servants and the Lobbying Act.

Lei noted that four dimensions should be given particular attention in supervising legislative operations: whether legislators hold positions in private companies, whether they offend the rules regarding conflicts of interest, whether inter-party negotiations in the legislature are transparent and whether legislative meetings and data are open to citizens.

Hsu Yung-ming, an assistant professor of political science at Soochow University, said that as the Kuomintang now holds an absolutely dominant position in the Legislative Yuan, it will be hard for it to avoid responsibility if it fails to meet popular expectations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sniffer dogs help with crackdown on contraband during festival

TEXT.P: During the Lunar New Year travel season, the Council of Agriculture (COA) is urging Taiwanese nationals planning to travel abroad not to bring back prohibited goods, stressing that a dozen sniffer dogs are on duty at airports and harbors to safeguard Taiwan's environment.

According to the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ), there are about a dozen of dogs, mostly beagles, on duty at major gateways around the country, inspecting travelers' baggage around the clock, especially those returning from Southeast Asian countries, Hong Kong and Macau.

A BAPHIQ official explained that many migrant workers from Southeast Asia return to Taiwan after a visit to their native countries bearing hometown specialties, such as tropical fruits, spices, even seeds and plants, which may carry contagious viruses.
"All banned goods will be discovered by the dogs and be destroyed", the official said.

In order to prevent Taiwan's environment from being compromised by foreign species and contagious diseases such as avian influenza, the BAPHIQ official reiterated that travelers carrying contraband goods, including fruits, meat products, plants and endangered species, risk prosecution and may even be detained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate Dance Theater rehearsal studio burnt down

TEXT.P: A fire destroyed the rehearsal studio, costumes, props and production archives of Taiwan's celebrated Cloud Gate Dance Theater early Monday morning, causing "immeasurable" losses, according to the dance company's founder.
"Everything was destroyed, " said Lin Hwai-min, the dance company's founder and choreographer. "We lost our costumes, props and production archives tracking back to 1975."
Describing the fire as a "test from the God, " Lin added that the Cloud Gate suffered "immeasurable" losses from the fire.

Lin said he was grateful for firefighters' dedicated work that helped bring the fire under control quickly. Firefighters said the fire that broke out at around 2 a.m. could have been caused by an electrical short-circuit.

Lin said that the tour schedule of the Cloud Gate will not be affected even though the 1,324-square-meter rehearsal studio was consumed in the fire. "None of the 121 performances scheduled for this year will be dropped," he added.
The company will launch its latest repertoire in Taipei in March, and is slated to perform in New York's Guggenheim Museum in April before embarking on a seven- week European performance tour.

The world-famous dance organization, known for its blend of Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility, was founded in 1973. Among its best known works are "Nine Songs, " "Moon Water" and the "Cursive" trilogy inspired by Chinese brush calligraphy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA predicts stable growth for Taiwan's exports

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports will grow by at least 8 percent this year despite a slowing global economy, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Monday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) , said he believes that the bureau's efforts to expand exports and the inauguration of the Nankang exhibition hall in Taipei, slated for mid-March, will help propel the country's export growth this year, which he said might even hit 10 percent.
Huang said that Taiwan reported a 10.1-percent export growth last year despite the impact of the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis and soaring prices of oil and raw material.
He added that the figure represented an all-time high and refuted forecasts that Taiwan's export growth would slow over the year.

Therefore, although the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) is predicting that Taiwan will report an export growth rate of 6.3 percent this year, Huang said the BOFT is still looking to realize 8-percent growth.

Responding to a recent report released by the United Nations predicting that the world's economic growth rate will fall to 3.4 percent and attributing the drop to the U.S.'s credit crunch, Huang admitted that a slowing U.S. economy will have a negative impact on Taiwan's economy, but added that the impact will not be devastating.
The United States is Taiwan's second largest export market, according to Huang.
Huang is also confident that Taiwan's total trade this year will reach US$500 billion and that the trade surplus will increase to US$30.5 billion.
To reach those export goals, the bureau will continue to focus on Taiwan's top 10 export markets, Huang said.
He explained that the bureau's efforts last year helped to increase exports to the country's top 10 export markets by an average of 25.6 percent, which was twice the overall rate for the year.
In addition, the bureau will collaborate with local industry associations to increase exports to emerging markets in Asia and Africa and to oil producing countries in the Middle East, Huang went on.
The bureau will strive to help the country maintain a certain degree of trade surplus with China, Taiwan's largest export market, Huang noted.

According to the bureau's statistics, Taiwan last year posted double-digit growth in exports to China, Singapore, Vietnam, Thailand, Australia, Indonesia, India, the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, and Kuwait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major computer makers set to vie for world mini laptop market

TEXT.P: Mini notebook computers have become the hottest computer, communications and consumer electronics (3C) products, with major electronics producers planning to present consumers with at least 10 new mini notebook models in 2008.

ASUSTeck Computer Inc., Taiwan's largest PC manufacturer and the world's largest maker of computer motherboards, scored a huge early victory in that worldwide marketing battle with its new Eee PCs -- a mini notebook series with a seven- inch display priced between US$200 and US$400.
The company sold 350,000 units in less than three months between mid-October and the end of 2007 and expects to sell another 5 million units in 2008.

The success of ASUS's "two-pound wonder" -- so named as it weighs less than one kilogram -- has caught the attention of major PC makers, including Acer Inc., Hewlett-Packard Co. and Micro-Star International Co., all of which have sped up production of their own mini laptops to grab a slice of the notebook market pie, estimated at more than 1 billion users.

Acer, Taiwan's third-largest computer company by sales and the world's fourth- largest personal computer maker, has indicated that it plans to launch an 8.9-inch, low-priced notebook in the second quarter.
Dennis Chen, the Taiwan vice president of HP, said his company will release a mini laptop with a 8.5-inch display priced at about NT$15,000 (US$468). The unit will be loaded with Microsoft software.
Hsu Hsiang, chairman of Micro-Star, said that his company will bring out "a better model" than the Eee PC in March.
BenQ, Taiwan's top maker of computer gear and mobile phones, is also considering whether to launch its own version of the mini laptop.

The success of the ASUS Eee PC shows that Taiwan's electronics producers have the ability to launch their own products under new brand-names instead of merely supplying parts and components to foreign computer companies.
The shock-proof Eee PC units, pre-installed with Microsoft Windows, have over 40 built-in applications to enable users to learn, work and play.

According to market analysts, the Eee PC has captured the attention of consumers -- selling one unit every five seconds during its initial launch worldwide -- mainly because it is an excellent secondary computer for households with children. It is also a good primary computer for novice PC users who have never had the time or patience to master an operating system.
The interface is easy to use, with novice users able to check online transactions, order groceries, and keep in touch with friends and family members without difficulty.

The Eee PC has also gained a foothold in the U.S. education market because the lightweight laptop enables teachers to access, display and transfer video and music with ease, and to assign work to students, which can answered using the Eee PC.
ASUS shipped its first major batch of 1,300 Eee PCs to California's fourth largest school district -- the Fresno Unified School District -- for use as training aids by both students and teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate defends temple visits

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew claimed Monday that his frequent visits to temples around the country during the Lunar New Year holidays are not aimed at wooing voters but at demonstrating respect for religion.

Siew was responding to criticism that politicians from both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led "pan-green" camp and the KMT-led "pan- blue" alliance ) attend religious events during the Lunar New Year festival mainly for political purposes.

"The criticism is not fair," Siew said, adding he believes that temple visits by politicians from both camps are aimed at expressing respect for religion and praying for public and personal well-being.

"It is good for people to go to temples or attend religious activities as this signifies that Taiwan is a diverse society that respects religious freedom, " said Siew, suggesting that people visit temples to worship Buddha or attend activities organized by Christian and Catholic churches during the Chinese New Year holiday.

Siew made the remarks after attending the traditional ritual of "welcoming the God of Wealth" at the Wusheng Monastery of the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society located in Taipei County's Gungliau Township, some 60 kilometer from Taipei.
He also joined Dharma Master Hsin Tao, head of the Wusheng Monastery, to light lanterns and pray for blessings.

Siew said although they have known each other for a long time, Master Hsin Tao did not pray for his election but for a brighter future for the country. He said he expects himself to live up to Master Hsin Tao's virtues of respect, tolerance and philanthropy, and to bring hope to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan outshines South Korea in display panel market

TEXT.P: Taiwan outperformed South Korea in the display panel industry for the first time in 2007, shipping a greater number of display panels and realizing greater profits and turnover, according to annual financial reports released recently by major manufacturers in the two countries.

Four largest Taiwanese TFT-LCD display panel manufacturers -- Chimei Corp., AU Optronics Corp., Chunghwa Picture Tubes, LTD. and HannStar Display Corp. -- registered a total of NT$1.011 trillion (US$31.4 billion) in turnover last year, compared to NT$1.001 trillion recorded by two Korean leading display panel brands, Samsung Electronics Co. and LG. Philips LCD.
In 2006, the four Taiwanese manufacturers saw a collective turnover of NT$650 billion, while Samsung and LG. Philips LCD together earned NT$770 billion.
The TFT-LCDs (thin film transistor liquid crystal displays), are a variant of liquid crystal displays producing a fine quality image but consuming little electricity.
As to profits, the four Taiwanese manufacturers earned total profits of NT$132.4 billion, exceeding their Korean counterparts by NT$13.2 billion.
Moreover, the four Taiwanese companies realized an operating profit rate of 13 percent in 2007, outpacing the 11.9 percent of the two Korean manufacturers.
A company's operating profit is the profit remaining after direct and indirect costs are deducted.

According to statistics published by DisplaySearch, a market survey company, 175.5 million large display panels were shipped by the four Taiwanese manufacturers last year, while Samsung and LG. Philips LCD shipped 158.6 million units.
Taiwan was the leading player in the display panel market in 2007, capturing 44.2 percent of the TFT-LCD display global market, compared with the 40 percent held by the Korean manufacturers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two televised presidential debates to take place in February, March

TEXT.P: Two televised presidential debates between ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh and his Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Ma Ying-jeou, are slated to take place Feb. 24 and March 9, respectively, organizers said Monday.

The two debates are a result of long-term negotiations between the sides, which previously disagreed on the details of the debates, including format, dates and the number of debates to be held, according to the organizers.

During the first debate, both candidates will answer questions from local citizens submitted in the form of video clips, while during the second debate, the candidates will respond to questions posed by organizing media organizations.
The organizers of the debates include the Public Television Service (PTS) station, the Central News Agency (CNA) , the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News, and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese-Americans urge U.S. to back Taiwan's U.N. referendum
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 10 (CNA) 02/11/08 19:52:29 (By Michelle Tsai and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Sixty-seven Taiwanese-American groups have called on the U.S. government and ordinary American citizens to support Taiwan's upcoming referendum aimed at promoting the country's bid to enter the United Nations under the name Taiwan.
The referendum is slated to be held alongside the country's March 22 presidential election.

The groups made the joint appeal Sunday in a half-page advertisement published in the Washington Post's "Outlook" section, described by U.S.-based lobbying group Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) as "the must-read section for political pundits and for readers interested in foreign policy."

The ad came after several U.S. high-ranking officials voiced opposition to Taiwan's planned U.N. referendum, which has triggered widespread dissatisfaction among the Taiwanese American associations, the FAPA said in an earlier statement.
The associations decided to appeal to the U.S. public and seek popular support for the referendum, the FAPA statement noted.
The ad stated that due to China's long-term oppression and intimidation, "Taiwan has become an international orphan."

The ad called on U.S. President George W. Bush and his administration to support Taiwan's acceptance as a full and equal member of the international community and to back Taiwan's democratic referendum.
"As leaders of the Taiwanese-American organizations, we ask the United States administration and Congress to stand up for the principles of human rights and self-determination," the ad reads.

The ad quotes remarks from Bush's second inaugural address in 2004, that "it is the policy of the United States to seek and support the growth of democratic movements and institutions in every nation and culture."

The ad also quoted Bush in his last State of the Union Address, delivered Jan. 28, that "our foreign policy is based on a clear premise: We trust that people, when given the chance, will choose a future of freedom and peace."

Noting that "there can be no double standard when it comes to supporting democracy, " the ad wrote that Bush should "trust the people of Taiwan to choose a future of freedom and peace " by supporting Taiwan's planned U.N.-membership poll.

FAPA President Bob Yang said in the statement that "we believe that U.S.'s repeated high-volume opposition to the referendum casts doubt upon the U.S. willingness to stand up for democracy, and undermines the U.S. position as a champion of democracy in East Asia."

He said, "We ask that the U.S. support Taiwan's upcoming referendum. And if, for whatever reason, they are unable to support it, we ask that they at least keep quiet and let Taiwan's democratic process run its course."

DOC.HEADLINE: Another cold front approaching Taiwan: CWB

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced Monday afternoon that another cold front is approaching Taiwan, which will likely lower the mercury to about eight degrees Celsius in northern and central parts of the island.

According to the CWB, the cold front will affect Taiwan from Feb. 12-14, bringing overnight lows of eight degrees Celsius to the main island north of Tainan, regions along the northeastern coast and offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu.
Temperatures are expected to pick up Thursday.
The cold front is expected to bring more rain throughout the week to northern and northeastern parts of Taiwan, according to the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: New York Philharmonic in Taiwan to stage three concerts

TEXT.P: The New York Philharmonic, the oldest symphony orchestra in the United States and one of the oldest in the world, arrived in Taipei Monday to begin its 2008 tour of five Asian cities.

The orchestra will stage two concerts Feb. 11-12 at the National Concert Hall in Taipei and another concert Feb. 13 at the Kaohsiung Cultural Center in the southern Taiwan port city before leaving for Hong Kong Feb. 15. It will also perform in Shanghai and Beijing during the 11-concert tour, which will conclude Feb. 24.

Since its first visit to Asia in 1961, the New York Philharmonic has returned 12 times, last visiting Taiwan in 1998. The current tour is sponsored by the Credit Suisse Group, a leading global financial services company headquartered in Zurich.

"The Philharmonic has a significant record of touring Asia, but this will be our most substantial tour of the region in our history," said the orchestra's president and executive director, Zarin Mehta.
"I am delighted to be returning to Asia with the Philharmonic. It is always a great honor to present this orchestra to audiences around the world," said music director Lorin Maazel.
Maazel, 78, became the music director of the orchestra in 2002. He has led more than 150 orchestras in more than 5,000 opera and concert performances over the course of his career.

Maazel will conduct the orchestra in playing works by Barber, Beethoven, Brahms, Dvorak, Elgar, Mendelssohn, Mozart, Rossini, and Tchaikovsky. Soloists include Philharmonic Concertmaster Glenn Dicterow, Principal Horn Philip Myers, and guest cellist Alisa Weilerstein.

The orchestra, founded in 1842, has played a leading role in American musical life and over the last century has become renowned around the globe, having appeared in 420 cities in 58 countries on five continents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alliance launches 'Life Watch' project

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty is calling on the public to join its "Life Watch" project to help save the lives of prisoners mistakenly convicted and sentenced to death by courts.

Alliance members stressed that private individuals are welcome to take part in the "Life Watch" project and to serve as long-term observers to prevent the judicial system from taking the lives of innocent people.

Citing U.S. research, alliance members said that the courts might have arrived at an incorrect verdict in some 7 percent of cases involving the death penalty. A similar group, dubbed the "Innocence Project", is active in the U.S., they noted.

According to a 1994 publication of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC), 482 Taiwanese prisoners were executed during the 1955-1992 period. Alliance members noted that according to the statistics provided by the "Innocence Project", some 34 persons might have been wrongly put to death.
The RDEC publication shows that most of the 482 executed persons were drawn from the lower-ranks of society, being unemployed or low-income workers, poorly educated, or young, first-time offenders.

The Life Watch project is co-sponsored by the Taiwan Association for Human Rights, the Judicial Reform Foundation, the Chang Fo-chuan Center for the Study of Human Rights, Fujen University John Paul II Peace Institute and the Taipei Bar Association, alliance members added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Full opening to Chinese tourists expected after March 22 race

TEXT.P: Taiwan will hopefully open to Chinese tourists in the near future no matter who wins the March 22 presidential election, local tourism sources said Monday.

Many in the domestic industry believe that Taiwan and China will immediately step up the pace of bilateral tourism talks after a new president takes office May 20, no matter whether ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh or main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou is victorious in the coming race, the sources said.

Although cross-Taiwan Strait private exchanges have been authorized for the past 20 years, the sources said Taiwan and China have both failed to make a full opening to Chinese tourists to sightsee in Taiwan possible as a result of political concerns.
Despite the fact that Taiwan has made some efforts over the past three years to clear the way for a full opening, political barriers remain, they said.
Currently, only Chinese people holding foreign passports or those proceeding from a third country or area are allowed to enter Taiwan on pleasure trips.

However, in a stark contrast to the very small number of Chinese people that have visited Taiwan, local people are presently making more than 3 million visits per year to China after the Taiwan authorities lifted a ban on cross- strait grassroots exchanges in 1987.
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait did not begin two-way negotiations on a full opening to Chinese tourists until 2007.

Local tourism sources ascribed the slow pace of negotiations to unbending political wrangling between the two sides, saying that political elements have successfully blocked progress in the area. They went on to express hope that a new era of cross-strait relations will be inaugurated with a new president in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed views of 40 percent ceiling on China-bound investments

TEXT.P: While local trade and industry groups continue to urge the government to ease restrictions on the 40 percent cap on China-bound investment, academics are expressing a different view.

According to a survey by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), only 37 Taiwan companies, or 6.1 percent of the local companies listed in the Taiwan Stock Exchange that responded to the survey, admitted that their China investments have reached or even exceeded the 40 percent limit of the value of their net assets in their China-bound investments.

While another 24 companies said that their China-bound investments already hit more than 90 percent of their investment ceilings set by the government, 35 Taiwan businesses said that their investments in China are in the range between 80 percent and 90 percent in proportion to their full investment levels allowed by the the government.
That means that some 85 percent of Taiwan-based companies investing in China have not yet reached 80 percent of the maximum amount allowed by the government, according to the CEPD report.

Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih, who proposed the "no haste, be patient" China investment policy to the previous Kuomintang government to restrain Taiwan enterprises from making excessive investments in China, said it is clear that the vast majority of Taiwan businesses would not invest more than 40 percent of their net asset value in investment projects in China.
"It is obvious that the 40 percent cap on China-bound investments does not pose a barrier to Taiwan companies' investments in China, " Chen stated.

"If people continue rehashing the issue and demanding that the government lift the 40 percent restriction, it could be termed as a politically charged move, " Chen said while blaming government officials for failing to provide the public with a clear explanation of the situation.

Arguing that the government cannot use its one-sided judgment to craft its China investment policy, he said, it imposed the 40 precent cap in Taiwan businesses' investment in China to prevent them from "putting all their eggs in a single basket."
Chen, however, admitted that the cap might be adjusted on a case-by-case basis as China has becomes a manufacturing base for most Taiwan corporations.
According to Chen, the 40 percent investment ceiling can be eased for branded Taiwanese enterprises which enjoy a noticeable market share in China.
Taiwan Institute of Economic Research Vice President Kung Ming-shin echoed Chen's view, saying that statistics compiled by the Taiwan Stock Exchange reflected a similar finding as the CEPD report.
"The rhetoric pinning the future of all Taiwanese companies to their investments in China has been exaggerated," Kung contended.

"Even if the government were to soften or lift the existing 40 percent investment limit, it would not necessarily be helpful to Taiwanese enterprises hoping to invest in China in light of the prevailing globalization trends among ambitious corporations, " he said.

Ho Yu, a standing board member of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) , said he was surprised by the findings of the two reports, which he described as "a far cry from the genuine situation."

"It is the government's 40 percent investment ceiling which has driven many Taiwan companies to pursue their investment projects in China through third countries or areas, misleading the public to believe that the restriction raises no problems for most Taiwan enterprises," he said.
"Actually, the government has imposed many restraints on China-bound investments by local companies and Taiwan's economic policy must be further liberalized," he said.
The CNFI is one of the leading industrial associations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese tourists arriving by ship receive red-carpet welcome

TEXT.P: A total of 659 Chinese tourists arrived at the northern Taiwan port of Keelung via a luxury ocean liner Monday, receiving a warm welcome from local harbor and administrative officials.

The Chinese visitors, who came along with 1,541 other foreign tourists aboard the British-registered ocean liner "Rhapsody of the Seas, " formed the largest Chinese tour group ever to visit Taiwan. The cruise ship set out from Hong Kong for a pleasure voyage that will also make a port call at Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan Tuesday.
Keelung Mayor Chang Tung-jung, Keelung Harbor Bureau Director Hsiao Ting-hsun and other local officials greeted the Chinese and other foreign visitors upon their arrival at around 11 a.m.

The harbor bureau rolled out red carpet to welcome the Chinese and foreign tourists who walked from the port onto a fleet of buses for sightseeing in nearby Taipei City. Major destinations included Taipei 101, the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall which was formerly known as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and Lungshan Temple. Some Chinese tourists didn't join the Taipei journey and instead toured noted scenic spots in Keelung and Jioufen.

Chang said it's a new arrangement for Chinese people to come by ocean liner. According to Chang, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council changed the rule before the Lunar New Year holiday to allow for entry of Chinese holidaymakers via ship from ports outside China.

Granted double-entry visas for the first time, the tourists departed Keelung Monday evening and are scheduled to reach the southern port of Kaohsiung Tuesday for a half-day tour before heading back to Hong Kong the same day.
The large tourist group is expected to bring an extra bonanza for local travel industry.

A Keelung harbor official said the five-star Rhapsody of the Seas is scheduled to make four more port calls in Taiwan in the coming weeks, scheduled for Feb. 24, March 5, March 15, and March 25, respectively.

"The cruise liner will take some 10,000 Chinese and foreign tourists to Taiwan, " the official said, adding that the port calls will not only help increase major Taiwan harbors' passenger volume but will also give a boost to the country's flagging service sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese tourists to arrive by cruise liners: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed credit for the entry of a large Chinese tour group into Taiwan Monday, saying he personally endorsed taking an exception to the existing rules to make possible the arrival of the Chinese tourists.
Chen made the remarks after 659 Chinese tourists arrived at Keelung Harbor aboard a luxury cruise liner around Monday noon for a half-day sightseeing tour in northern Taiwan.
It marked the first time that Chinese tourists have come via a cruise ship. It was also the largest Chinese tour group ever to visit Taiwan.

Taiwan blocks most Chinese travelers for security reasons or fear of visitors overstaying their visa. It sets a daily limit on the number of Chinese tourists at 1,000. Given the group's large number, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), wthe thich charts Taiwan's China policy, faced a dilemma on whether to approve its entry application late last year. The MAC presented the case to the president.
Chen said while visiting Tienhsien Temple in Keelung Monday afternoon that he approved the case on a trial basis.

"On my way to the temple, I saw the large ocean liner that took the Chinese tourists to Keelung earlier in the day. I thought I had made a rightful decision to approve their entry for sightseeing purposes. We took an exception to our existing rules in an effort to promote goodwill exchanges across the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.
The presdient said he has also approved another case in which a cruise liner will take Chinese holidaymakers to Taiwan via Hong Kong in the near future.

If all these trial cases proceed smoothly, Chen said, more similar cases will follow. Noting that he has confidence in Taiwan's prosperity and stability, Chen said his administration will keep the door open for Chinese citizens intending to sightsee in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 12, or the sixth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the U.S. president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the American Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search of gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China when Japanese forces quickly breach Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy in the war between the Ching court and Japan which broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Palau from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1960: The Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan announces that the total membership of the Republic of China National Assembly, under the period of national emergency, shall be 1,576.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the ROC to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: Express trains collide north of Hsinchu, in northern Taiwan, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Chang Kwang-shih, ROC vice minister of economic affairs, returns from Saudi Arabia, where he signed a memorandum of economic coorperation.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1974: Raimundo Guerrero, chairman of the World Anti-Communist League, arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1975: The people of South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1976: Six hundred members of the ROC's National Federation of Industries Association, National Federation of Businesses Association, and the Industrial and Business Association meet and pledge to support government economic policy.
1976: The first Sino-Japanese exhibition of modern painting opens, with more than 52 works by contemporary Japanese artists on display.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The U.S. Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1992: Mongolia's new non-communist constitution takes effect.
1996: Yasser Arafat becomes the first president of Palestine.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the ROC Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policymaking task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
1999: The U.S. Senate votes against removing President Bill Clinton from office in the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
2000: Taiwan doctor Chen Chiu-huang wins the 2000 award of the Foundation de Enterprise Montblanc de la Culture of Britain.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: More Chinese tourists to arrive by cruise liners: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed credit for the entry of a large Chinese tour group into Taiwan Monday, saying he personally endorsed making an exception to existing rules to facilitate the group's visit.

The 659 Chinese tourists, the largest Chinese group ever to visit Taiwan, arrived at Keelung Harbor around Monday at noon along with 1,541 other foreign tourists aboard the British-registered ocean liner "Rhapsody of the Seas" for a half-day of sightseeing in northern Taiwan.

The group, which departed from Hong Kong Sunday and was scheduled to make a stop in Kaohsiung Tuesday before returning home, was also the first composed of Chinese nationals to come to Taiwan via a cruise ship.
Taiwan blocks most Chinese travelers for security reasons or fear of visitors overstaying their visa and sets a daily limit on the number of Chinese tourists at 1,000.

Given the group's large number, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which coordinates Taiwan's China policy, faced a dilemma over whether to approve its application for entry late last year and presented the case to the president.
Chen said while visiting Tienhsien Temple in Keelung Monday afternoon that he approved the case on a trial basis.

"On my way to the temple, I saw the large ocean liner that took the Chinese tourists to Keelung earlier in the day. I thought I made the right decision to approve their entry for sightseeing purposes. We made an exception to our existing rules in an effort to promote goodwill exchanges across the Taiwan Strait," Chen said.
The president said he has also approved another visit by a cruise liner that will take Chinese vacationers to Taiwan via Hong Kong in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitors to Alishan decrease during Chinese New Year holiday

TEXT.P: Visitor arrivals to the southern Taiwan mountain resort of Alishan saw a sharp decrease during this year's Chinese New Year holiday, probably because of the chilly weather, officials said Tuesday.

Only 30,156 people visited Alishan during the six-day holiday that ran from Feb. 6 to Feb. 11, a sharp decline from the 53,000 in 2007 and 51,000 in 2006 who spent some of their New Year's break at the mountain resort, according to officials at the Forestry Bureau's Chiayi Forest District Office.

The arrivals included 950 recorded on Chinese New Year's Eve, 4,485 on the first day of Chinese New Year, 6,808 on the second day, 8,267 on the third day, 7,037 on the fourth day, and 2,609 on the fifth day, the officials said.

The scenic mountain, located in the southern county of Chiayi, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in Taiwan, famous for its breathtaking sunrise, serene mountain landscape and ancient trees.
The park draws approximately 700,000 visitors per year, or an average of more than 1,900 visitors per day, according to figures compiled by the Alishan National Scenic Area Administration.
During peak periods such as the Chinese New Year holiday, the cherry blossom season between March and April and summer vacation, the number of visitors can exceed 10,000 per day, the figures show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Friend of Taiwan passes away
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 11 (CNA) 02/12/08 12:41:41 (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Tom Lantos (D-Calif.), a senior member of the U.S. House of Representatives who was one of the staunchest supporters of Taiwan, died Monday of esophageal cancer. He was 80.

Members of Taiwan's diplomatic corps in the United States, the Formosan Association of Public Affairs, and Taiwanese friends of Lantos around the U.S. all sent letters of condolence to Lantos' family over his death.

Lantos died early Monday at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center in suburban Maryland. He was surrounded by his wife, Annette, two daughters, and many of his 18 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.
Lantos, who had been a congressman since 1980, said last month after being diagnosed with esophageal cancer that he would serve out his 14th term but would not seek re-election.

A teenager twice escaped from a Nazi-run forced labor camp in Hungary and a friend to all those around the world who fought for democracy and human rights, Lantos spared no effort in supporting Taiwan and Tibet.
He was largely instrumental in facilitating the 1995 visit by then President Lee Teng-hui to the United States and made a speech at Lee's Alma Mater, Cornell University.
When Lee visited Washington, D.C. in 2005 after he retired, he met with Lantos personally for a private conversation.

Lantos pushed numerous bills in the House of Representatives that supported Taiwan's participation in the international community, including U.S. congressional support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.
In 2005, he spoke publicly in Congress to oppose the European Union's plans to lift its arms embargo against China.

In his capacity as chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Lantos saw to it that a non-binding resolution, HCR136, was adopted June 25, 2007 urging the Bush administration to lift restrictions on visits to the United States by high-level elected and appointed officials of Taiwan, including the president.
Before Christmas, Lantos and Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Letinen (R-Fla.) jointly submitted a resolution, HCR278, calling for stronger support for Taiwan's democratization and its security.
The resolution also urged the international community to send observers to Taiwan in March to witness the presidential election slated for March 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: More opportunities than job seekers in 2007: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Public employment service centers posted more job openings than there were job seekers in 2007, with each person looking for a job having an average of 1.3 opportunities, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

The centers posted 1.17 million job openings in 2007 for the 905,000 people who sought work during the year, but the average of 1.3 job opportunities per job seeker was down from the 1.4 averaged in 2006, the DGBAS said.

In a year when the average unemployment rate in 2007 stayed steady at 3.91 percent, the number of jobs posted increased by 11.6 percent from the previous year while the number of job-seekers rose by 18.9 percent.

The DGBAS said 202,000 individuals in the 25-29 age bracket sought jobs in 2007, the most of any age group. Some 172,000 of those looking for jobs were over the age of 45, indicating that a sizable number of people were also looking to change their careers.

In terms of education background, the number of university graduates or those with more advanced degrees seeking jobs totaled 200,000, a 34 percent year-on- year rise, reflecting a growing unemployment or underemployment problem among the best educated in Taiwan.

The DGBAS said, however, that those with better educations tend to demand higher compensation and change jobs more frequently. Their joblessness tends to be voluntary and short-term, unlike for other groups in which unemployment is more prevalent.
