DOC.HEADLINE: Over 50% of Tainan junior high students finding dates online: survey

TEXT.P: Junior high school students in the southern city of Tainan have shown a heavy reliance on the Internet to find dates and gain knowledge about sex, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by the Tainan City Family Education Center.

The survey revealed that 58 percent of respondents sought to meet someone of the opposite sex online and 71 percent were in favor of using the Internet to meet friends, either of the opposite sex or the same sex.
Among the most common methods adopted by the respondents to meet friends online, 73 percent did so through instant messengers, 55 percent through online games and 23 percent through blogs.
While 35 percent of respondents said they would have the first real meeting with the friends they met online within one month, 39 percent would do so between one and three months.

The survey found that 48 percent of respondents obtained knowledge about sex through the Internet and that 63 percent had visited a pornographic Web site or looked at pornographic magazines, films, comics or photos.
Some 48 percent obtained information about pornographic Web sites through search engines while 22 percent did so through e-mails forward to them by others.
Despite the high acceptance of modern cyber technology among the respondents, the survey showed that their attitude toward sex was rather traditional.
Approximately 80 percent of respondents said they cannot accept one-night stands, for example, and 56 percent said they were against pre-marital sex.

Meanwhile, nearly 90 percent of respondents objected to having sex without using a condom, 62 percent were against the idea of having kids while still in school, and 40 percent did not think having a shotgun marriage would be responsible behavior.

While 90 percent of respondents considered it important for them to receive education on ways to prevent sexual harrassment, approximately 90 percent did not agree with the notion that boys have no need to receive education on sexual assault prevention.

Thirty-nine percent of respondents had never discussed gender issues with their parents, and if they have any problems concerning relationships, 68 percent said they would seek help over the Internet.
The survey was carried out in January among 1,164 students from 12 junior high schools in Tainan City.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP presidential candidate wants more TV debates

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that there should be more than two televised presidential debates between him and his Kuomintang rival, Ma Ying-jeou.

"Such major issues as national identity, sovereignty and economic policies should be debated. But one's personality as well as integrity should also be open to challenges, " he said, saying that was why he felt the number of televised debates should be increased.
He noted that a prospective leader of the nation should be one with integrity, or else, his words cannot be trusted.
Hsieh's camp has recently challenged Ma's loyalty and integrity over his possession of permanent residency status, or a "green card," from the United States.

Ma said that the green card, which he obtained while studying in the United States in the late 1970s, had lost its validity in the mid-'80s after he returned to Taiwan to live and obtained a non-immigration tourist visa for travel to the U.S.
Hsieh said the ability of a future leader to carry through his policies is also essential.
"One's performance in the past could also be debated," the former premier and Kaohsiung mayor suggested.
Two debates between the two candidates are slated to take place Feb. 24 and March 9, according to organizers.

During the first debate, the candidates will answer questions from local citizens submitted in the form of video clips. In the second debate, Hsieh and Ma will field questions from media organizations holding the debates.
The organizers of the debates include the Public Television Service station, the Central News Agency, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News, and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices fall on Taipei stock market

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices fell Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 120.69 points, or 1.57 percent, to close at 7,553.3.

On the first day of trading following the Chinese New Year holiday, the bourse opened at 7,568.3 and fluctuated between 7,619.98 and 7,530.37 during the day's session. A total of 3.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$113.63 billion (US$3.55 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground. Cement stocks advanced by 5.6 percent, the most of any sector. Construction issues rose 4.7 percent, foodstuff issues increased 2.4 percent, plastics and chemicals shares grew 1.1 percent, and paper and pulp issues gained 0.3 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground. Machinery and electronics shares fell 3.2 percent, the most of any sector. Banking and financial shares dropped 1.6 percent and textile stocks were down 0.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,353 to 585, with 268 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expert offers advice on countering 'post-holiday' syndrome

TEXT.P: With millions of Taiwanese heading back to school or work Tuesday after the extended Chinese New Year break, a local psychiatrist offered tips on how to overcome "post-holiday syndrome."

Yang Tsung-tsai, director of Cardinal Tien Hospital's Department of Psychiatry, said that many workers and students may experience a lack of energy and motivation as well as difficulty concentrating when they head back to the classroom or office following the holidays.
"Many may be wishing that the holidays could be even longer, but everyone has to face up to reality and get back to their regular routine," Yang said.
"During the holidays, a lot of people overindulge in eating, drinking, and merrymaking, and adjusting to their regular work schedule after the holidays can be difficult," he said.
To overcome post-holiday syndrome, Yang suggested that people eat a healthy and balanced diet that includes less spicy and oily foods and more foods that are high in fiber, vitamins and minerals.
He also suggested that people exercise more and try to go to bed early in order to get a good night's sleep.
"By following these simple steps, you can overcome post-holiday syndrome within 3-5 days and get back into your regular routine, " Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to launch 'guide dog diplomacy' activities

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Taiwan Guide Dog Association will jointly launch a series of "guide dog diplomacy" activities at the end of this month that will include obtaining guide dogs and technical support from other countries, a MOFA official said Tuesday.

The ministry's NGO Affairs Committee Vice Chairman Chiang Kuo-chiang said that besides establishing links with the international community, the activities would also raise awareness in Taiwan about the needs of its visually- impaired citizens and the serious shortage of guide dogs in the country.
There are currently about 50,000 blind people in Taiwan but only 20 trained guide dogs, he said.

As part of the "animal diplomacy" activities, the committee will work with the Taiwan Guide Dog Association and the Animal Protection Association of the Republic of China in seeking assistance from several countries, including Japan, South Korea, the United States, England, Denmark and Norway, to provide guide dogs to Taiwan and introduce advanced guide dog training techniques.
"It is hoped that this will help in efforts to increase the number and quality of guide dogs in Taiwan for the benefit of the country's visually-impaired citizens," he said.
Chiang indicated that the activities were being patterned after the successful "animal diplomacy" activities held last year based on the theme of bird ecology.

He said the NGO Affairs Committee will hold a news conference to explain the "guide dog diplomacy" plan in more detail near the end of the month and will invite Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang as well as foreign diplomats stationed in Taiwan to participate in order to raise awareness of the guide dog shortage in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for leaner, restructured government

TEXT.P: Despite having only three months left in office, President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday called for bipartisan support to downsize the government into a leaner, more efficient administration.

Speaking during a ceremony held at the Presidential Office to mark the beginning of the lunar Year of the Rat, Chen expressed hope that legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) can reach agreement on restructuring the government before the March 22 presidential election.
Chen said he hopes the two parties will consult with each other and agree to pass an amendment to the Executive Yuan Organization Act to overhaul the executive branch of government.

Noting that running "lean and mean" governments is now a world trend, Chen said he hopes the amendment could be passed into law soon, paving the way for an administration downsizing and restructuring.
The Executive Yuan-initiated proposal calls for legislation to legally cut the number of Cabinet-level agencies from the current 39 to around 22.
Chen further said passage of such an amendment would be the first of his "three wishes" as the head of the state for the Year of the Rat.
His second wish, Chen said, is to see the upcoming presidential race be held smoothly and successfully, irrespective of whether the candidate from the DPP or the KMT wins.

Chen said his third wish is to see Taiwan be admitted into the United Nations as a full member -- either joining the world body under the name Taiwan or "re- entering" it under the name of the Republic of China on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT bigwig denies existence of '3rd U.N.-bid referendum'

TEXT.P: A legislative bigwig of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) categorically denied Tuesday that there was a "third referendum proposal" regarding Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations.
Lin Yi-shih, a KMT legislator who doubles as director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, said neither the KMT nor the legislature has plans on a "third UN-bid referendum."
The Central Election Commission decided late last year to hold two referendums, seeking public opinion on Taiwan's quest to enter the United Nations, alongside the March 22 presidential election.

One of the referendums, proposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, tests public approval for Taiwan to attempt to enter the U.N. under the name Taiwan. The other referendum, proposed by the opposition KMT, calls for Taiwan's entry into the U.N. under the name of the Republic of China, or whatever feasible name.
The ROC was expelled from the U.N. in 1971 after the international organization awarded the China seat to the People's Republic of China.
Lin also said that it was clear the two referendums will be held, despite disapproval from Washington and pressure from Beijing to scrap the plans.
The holding of two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid alongside the March 22 presidential election is now a "closed and non-negotiable matter," Lin said.

The Legislative Yuan -- in which the KMT now holds an absolute majority following its landslide victory in the Jan. 12 legislative elections -- is unable to say no to the referendums except for blessing them, Lin said.

Meanwhile, Lin would not comment on news reports Tuesday that the Executive Yuan plans to put an amendment to the Executive Yuan Organization Act as one of the priority bills to be debated and screened by the new legislature, which was sworn in on Feb. 1, but has yet to begin its first plenary session.

The Executive Yuan-proposed amendment calls for cutting the number of Cabinet- level agencies from the current 39 to around 26, including only 14 ministries, seven councils and five independent agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Lottery gives NT$1.8 billion to welfare projects

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Lottery Co. (TLC) has donated NT$1.8 billion (US$56 million) from its public lottery ticket sales in December to various public welfare projects, a TLC spokesman said Tuesday.
The contribution for the month of December has raised the company's total contribution in 2007 to NT$15.5 billion, the spokesman noted.
Of the December donation, NT$908 million, or 50 percent, goes to local governments to fund their social welfare and charity events, the spokesman said.
Taipei County in northern Taiwan received the largest share of NT$140 million, followed by the capital Taipei's NT$123 million.
Another NT$817 million, or 45 percent of the December total, is used to sponsor the national pension scheme, according to the spokesman.
The remaining NT$90.8 million, or 5 percent, is allocated as reserve funds for the national health insurance program, the spokesman said.

In related news, no winner of the TLC's Super Lotto jackpot prize -- NT$470 million -- was produced Monday for the sixth time in a row. If no one wins the top prize, the jackpot will continue to grow until someone wins it.
The TLC, a subsidiary of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., is authorized to run the computerized public welfare lottery from 2007 to 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supply situation to remain stable thru end of April

TEXT.P: Taiwan's water supply is expected to remain normal through the end of April, Taiwan Water Corp. (TWC) said Tuesday.
The country's main water supplier said that last year's typhoon season brought rainfall that filled Taiwan's major reservoirs to well over 70 percent of their capacity.

In addition, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) has forecast that rainfall during the first quarter of the year will be normal or slightly on the low side for most of the country's reservoirs, with only Penghu likely to experience a meaningful shortage of rain during the period.
As a result, Taiwan's water supply should remain stable through the end of April, the water company said.
The water supply situation in Penghu should return to normal by mid-June with the implementation of first-phase water conservation measures, the company added.

Taiwan Water Corp. has been actively pushing for the construction of two seawater desalination plants in Penghu, and the company believed the water supply situation in the county would be more stable when the facilities were completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to reshuffle diplomatic deployments soon

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang said Tuesday that the Ministry will soon make major changes to the deployment of mission chiefs stationed abroad to improve Taiwan's position given "harsh" diplomatic conditions.

Speaking at the MOFA's Lunar New Year reception, Huang said the adjustments, which will include chiefs of embassies, and representative offices in Europe and the United States, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Kansas City, will target those whose terms are expiring, the aged, and those who have health problems.

The deployment adjustments will be finalized at the end of February, with the appointment of the deputy representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the U.S. to be announced soon.

Huang said he wrote a letter on the Lunar New Year's Eve expressing his sincere appreciation to the front-line diplomats for their hard work. He noted that besides facing constant pressure due to the Chinese diplomatic offense, diplomats must also deal with harsh challenges such as difficult living environments, education problems facing those with children, and health concerns.
"People see diplomats as well-paid, with a high public profile. But beneath the rosy picture it is, in fact, a job full of difficulties and hardships unknown to the public," Huang said.

Without going into detail, the minister revealed that "a chief of mission in a South American country" and his wife faced armed robbers just before the Chinese New Year. Fortunately, they were not harmed, but psychologically both the head and his wife have suffered tremendous trauma, he added.

Also, as tuition fees in some foreign countries have almost doubled over the past decade and continue to rise, some diplomats have had to sell their homes in Taiwan in order to support their children's studies.

Huang has promised to increase the education allowance extended to diplomats with children this year so that they will not have to worry about the future of their children while fighting Taiwan's diplomatic battles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president urges citizens to take part in U.N. bid referendums

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu called on citizens Tuesday to actively participate in the two upcoming referendums on the country's U.N. bid to make sure that they are passed.

Claiming the move would be important to ensuring that Taiwan's voices are heard around the world, Lu expressed concern that Taiwan would have no chance to join the United Nations if the referendums were to fail.

"If less than half of voters take part in the referendums and less than half of participating voters vote in favor of the referendums, how will the international community interpret the outcome?" Lu asked.

Lu made the remarks during a ceremony held at the Presidential Office to mark the beginning of the Year of the Rat. She was referring to the referendums to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election: one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party on joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan and another sponsored by the opposition Kuomintang on regaining U.N. membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

According to Lu, these two referendums are more important and would have a more profound impact than the two referendums held alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections, which failed to pass because the turnout rates did not reach the required 50 percent.

Lu noted that most of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, including Nauru, the Marshall Islands and the Solomon Islands, achieved independence after World War II and have gained membership in the United Nations.
Lu said Taiwan lacks dignity and U.N. membership and that the country must not continue to be denied dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 159 points to close at 7,508, with 50,393 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 149 points to finish at 7,491, with 1,888 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 138 points to close at 7,498, with nine contract transactions.
September futures moved down 153 points to finish at 7,315, with 20 contract transactions, while December futures lost 174 points to close 7,300, with four contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 120.69 points Tuesday to finish at 7,553.3, with market turnover of NT$113.63 billion (US$3.55 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,667 for February; 7,640 for March; 7,636 for June; 7,468 for September and 7,474 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
February TE futures dropped 12.3 points to close at 282.7, with 3,795 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved down 11.75 points to finish at 281.8, with 84 contract exchanges.
September TE futures lost 10.55 points to close at 277.8, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June or December.
February TF futures moved down 18.4 points to close at 1,002, with 2,888 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures dropped 14 points to finish at 1,003, with 72 contracts traded.
June TF futures lost 30.2 points to finish at 1000.2, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September or December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.126 to close at NT$31.884.
A total of US$1.121 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.080 and hit a low of NT$31.870.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Finance Minister Padoa-Schioppa: There is no budget surplus.
Italian Finance Minister Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa said Monday that there is no budget surplus and that there is no room for cutting tax rates prior to the April 13-14 elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S. relations of paramount importance: foreign minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang reiterated Tuesday that U.S.-Taiwan relations are of "paramount importance" in Taiwan's diplomacy and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will continue to communicate with the U.S. on Taiwan's U.N. bid referendum.

Speaking to reporters after a MOFA Lunar New Year reception, Huang said: "As Taiwan has experienced rapid political and social change in the past seven years, which is likely beyond the understanding of our foreign friends, 'communication' remains the most important tool for Taiwan to strengthen the relations with the U.S."

Regarding a suggestion by Frank Hsieh, the Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate, that a compromise be reached between the DPP's U.N. referendum on joining the United Nations under the name of Taiwan and the opposition Kuomintang's proposal of returning the U.N. under the name of Republic of China, Huang said "the MOFA has no opinion."
"Being a member state of the U.N. is a common goal of the Taiwanese people. The MOFA will continue to try to ensure that the international community understands," he noted.
Huang added that should the DPP and KMT negotiate a new approach, the MOFA will follow the government's directions and communicate with the U.S. to improve bilateral relations.
Huang said "with the Beijing Olympics approaching, China's power is reaching its zenith, which is reflected by the fact that Taiwan is facing immense pressure from China's diplomatic offense."
"But time is on our side, " he said, encouraging MOFA staff to do their best in fighting the diplomatic battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: New measures to be unveiled soon to boost TSE listing: official

TEXT.P: New measures will be unveiled soon to encourage overseas Taiwanese companies, including those in China, to have their stocks traded on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) , the exchange's Chairman Wu Rong-i said Tuesday.

"There will be 'new progress' in the near future in the plan to have more Taiwanese companies overseas list their stocks on the TSE," Wu said, addressing aceremony marking the stock exchange's first trading day in the lunar Year of the Rat.
He said recently that the TSE has set a target of increasing the number of its listed companies by 40 in 2008, up from the current 698.

Wu told a year-end press conference that the Financial Supervisory Commission would be satisfied with 30 new firms listed. He added that 13 companies have already obtained permission to be listed on the TSE in 2008, including 10 that are currently listed on the over-the-counter market, known as the Gre Tai Securities Market.
Wu on Tuesday also said confidently that despite the flagging international economic situation, Taiwan's stock market is highly promising this year, with "ample room" for Taiwan shares to "catch up."
The TSE is said to be among the top 10 stock exchanges in the world in terms of trading value.

The TSE began operations in 1962. Its listed companies reached a record of 700 between February and June of 2005 and then slipped to 688 in 2006. At the end of 2006, the total market capitalization of the 688 companies amounted to US$594 billion, while the average daily trading value totaled US$2.96 billion, representing a market turnover rate of 137.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi prosecutors set up anti-bribe center

TEXT.P: The Chiayi District Prosecutors Office has set up a liaison center aimed at cracking down on election irregularities such as vote-buying and violence in the March 22 presidential elections, an office spokesman said Tuesday.

Sung Kuo-yeh, prosecutor-general of the Chiayi District Prosecutors Office, said the center will welcome reports of vote-buying or election-related violence and is offering rewards of up to NT$15 million (US$471,700) for informants.

"The center will be open round the clock and the prosecutors at the center will investigate any vote-buying or violence case impartially, regardless of the political affiliation of the subjects of the investigations," Sung said.

He urged the candidates or their campaign staff to strictly abide by the country's laws to ensure a fair election and called on the public to report cases of vote-buying or election-related violence in Chiayi county and city to develop the area as the cleanest electoral constituency in the country.
Informants can call the center at (05) 2752548 or on a toll-free telephone line at 0800024099.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boutique hotels, florists gear up for Valentine's Day

TEXT.P: Boutique hotels and florists in the Taipei area are gearing up for Feb. 14 Valentine's Day, indicating that the Taiwanese fever for this Western tradition is not affected by the slowing economy and cold weather.

"Business on Valentine's Day is expected to rise by 25 percent over other days," said Zhuang Bo-hong, deputy manager of the business administration department of Wego Taipei, the first boutique hotel in Taiwan, opened in 2000 with 86 luxuriously decorated rooms in various themes such as "Bali" or "European" style.
According to Zhuang, an estimated 450 couples will visit the Wego Taipei for a euphemistically named "two-hour rest" on Valentine's Day, at NT$1,500 (US$48) per session.

"Going to a hotel to celebrate special days like Valentine's Day has become very popular in recent years," Zhuang said, adding that he "expects to see a long line in front of our hotel waiting for rooms."

Noting that the Wego Taipei has not raised its tariffs, although the cost of living in Taiwan has continued to increase, Zhuang added that the hotel even gives away special gifts -- underwear for both males and females -- for the amorous couples.
Lee Shu-feng, executive assistant to the chairman of another boutique hotel, the Isis Taipei, also said he expects scores of couples coming for a two-hour stay.
Neither the Wego Taipei nor the Isis Taipei accept reservations, forcing customers to stand in line to be allocated a room on a first come, first served basis.
Noting that the Isis Taipei will not increase charges for Valentine's Day, Lee said the hotel gives away condoms, mugs and scented gifts to customers.
Florists, meanwhile, are also looking forward to brisk business.
Jing Yu-juan, owner of the Hua Hsin Florist, said while arranging bouquets that "sending flowers to loved ones will never become outmoded."
Unaffected by the weak economy, she noted that "on special occasions, such as Valentine's Day, males always want to present the best to their female friends."
"There is a trend in recent years that more and more gay people also order flowers for their partners, " Jing said, adding that "some office ladies even order flowers for themselves."
In order to deal with the rush of orders, Jing said she has also hired 20 taxis as couriers to deliver bouquets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate dancers resume practicing after devastating fire

TEXT.P: Dancers from Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theater resumed practicing Tuesday, one day after a fire destroyed the rehearsal studio of the celebrated dance troupe based in Bali, Taipei County.

The dancers stretched and jumped in a makeshift studio at Taipei National University of the Arts nearby. Smiles returned to their faces after tears over the fire early Monday, which firefighters believe is probably caused by an electrical short circuit.
The blaze destroyed rehearsal studios, props, costumes and production archives among other things of the 35-year-old troupe.

"There is no time for tears," Lin Hwai-min, the troupe's founder and choreographer, told the dancers, encouraging them to "practice as usual" so that they can perform well in all 121 performances scheduled for this year.

Lin on Tuesday also went to inspect three possible sites offered by Taipei County Government as a replacement facility for the dance troupe. He was accompanied by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, Panchiao City Mayor Chiang Huei-cheng as well as Taipei City Government Department of Culture Director Lee Yung-ping.
Lee said the city will offer land lots in Neihu and Mujha districts in suburban Taipei for the dance company's use.
Both Chou and Lee were vying for Cloud Gate to make its home in their respective city or county so as to "help upgrade the cultural level" of their area.

Lin said that the Cloud Gate will not need a site that will require a great deal of renovations for the time being, as the dance group is scheduled to perform overseas and in southern Taiwan next month.
But he said that he is still "looking for a place where the Cloud Gate could settle permanently."

The props and costumes of the "Nine Song, " and "White Serpent Legend," two of the best known works by the troupe, were damaged, Lin said, but as they will not be performed this year, the company will take time to repair and recover the damaged or ruined items.
But the destroyed costume of the "Water Moon," which is scheduled to be performed in this year's tour, will have to be reproduced soon.
The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called for the government Tuesday to take the initiative in assisting the Cloud Gate Dance Theater to overcome its crisis.

KMT Legislators Lin Yi-shih, Alex Fai, and Chu Feng-chih made the appeal when they met with the officials of the Ministry of Education and the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) to discuss possible measures to help the Cloud Gate.

"Cloud Gate is the jewel of Taiwan and the pride of its people," Chu said, requesting the government take the initiative to provide assistance for funds and a rehearsal site in the short term and a substantial reconstruction plan for the burned-down rehearsal studio in the mid- and long-term.
CCA Tzou Hung-tao said that the council has contacted Lin Hwai-min to inquire if he needs assistance in personnel support or damaged materials.

The CCA has also offered Huashan Culture Park and the Ching-mei Human Rights Memorial Park for use during the transitional period until a more long-term site for dance rehearsal can be found, Tzou added.

Meanwhile, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu donated NT$200,000 (US$6,250) to the Cloud Gate Tuesday, saying that he is willing to chip in to help the dance troupe and hope others will do the same. Former Taichung City Mayor Lin Po-jung also donated NT$50,000.
The company will launch its latest repertoire in Taipei in March, and is slated to perform in New York's Guggenheim Museum in April before embarking on a seven- week European performance tour.

The world-famous dance troupe, known for its blend of Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility, was founded in 1973. Among its latest works are the "Cursive" trilogy inspired by Chinese brush calligraphy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lunar New Year travel spree unaffected by cold weather

TEXT.P: Although a cold front covered Taiwan during the Lunar New Year holidays from Feb. 7-11, millions of visitors still flocked to tourist attractions around the country, officials of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Tuesday.
According to official estimates, Taiwan's people made a total of 5.9 million visits to tourist attractions or resorts during the five-day period.

There were also some 2.85 million visits to tourist destinations in central Taiwan, marking a rise of more than 60 percent, or over 1 million visits, compared to the figure posted in the same period of the previous year, Tourism Bureau estimates showed.

Tourism officials attributed the growth in the central region to its fine weather, many large-scale theme parks, scenic spots, such as Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County -- one of the most famous tourist spots across Taiwan, and the celebrations of several seasonal flower festivals.

During the same five-day period, tourist and resort facilities in northern Taiwan embraced 1.26 million arrivals, down slightly from the year-earlier level of 1.3 million, while in southern Taiwan, people made 1.95 million visits to local tourist or recreational parks, up by 500,000 visits from the 2007 level.
In eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien, people made a total of 690,000 pleasure trips to the region's recreational establishments Feb. 7 - 11, up by 10,000 over the 2007 figure.

In Taitung County, however, the number of tourist arrivals to the Chipen Hot Spring area and tourist destinations along its coasts fell by around 30 percent over the same period year on year. The East Rift Valley and the Southern Cross- island Highway saw their tourist arrivals drop by some 50 percent, according to local business people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate founder lashes out at poor investment in culture

TEXT.P: The founder of Taiwan's celebrated Cloud Gate Dance Theater lashed out at the government Tuesday for what he described as "the pittance" it invests in culture.

Lin Hwai-min, also the dance troupe's choreographer, made the remarks when he inspected several possible sites for the group in Taipei County after an electrical fire destroyed the rehearsal studio, costumes, props and production archives of the 35-year-old company based in Bali, Taipei County, a day earlier.

Lin said that the government's funding for culture is "simply too low, " citing the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) as an example, saying that its subsidies for performing groups is a meager NT$100 million (US$3.13 million) a year.

"With a large number of performing groups on this small island, we just don't see any vision, or ambition, or determination by the government when it appropriates such small amounts of money, " Lin said.
The fire in Bali was put out in hours, but the fire within Lin raged even more fiercely.
Lin said that society "extended a warm hand to us after the fire, "but he pointed out that if the government had a sound mechanism, the matter could have been "dealt with easily."
He lamented that the CCA has a dearth of emergency relief measures and that its cultural policy has not improved.

"The population and the size of Taiwan are small, but it has high density and quality of performance groups, " Lin said, noting that in addition to Cloud Gate, there are the Han Tang Yuefu, the Contemporary Legend Theater and the Performance Workshop Theater.
"The phenomenon is astonishing, but the government's investment in culture is only a fraction of what is needed," he said.

Lin said that in the wake of the fire "there is no time for tears" and he urged his dancers to start practicing Tuesday after the Chinese New Year holiday so that they can perform well in 121 local and overseas performances this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet looking to pass legal amendments on government reform

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will pass a draft package of amendments to the Organic Act of the Executive Yuan, with the aim of restructuring the executive branch of the government to better cope with contemporary social changes and meet new challenges, an official said Tuesday.

According to the draft package, the number of agencies under Executive Yuan will be cut from 39 to 26, including 14 ministries, seven councils, and another five independent organizations, the official said.

The Executive Yuan will also draft amendments to the Basic Organizational Code of the Central Government, which currently stipulates a ceiling of 13 government ministries and four councils to smooth the legislative process, the official said.

The draft amendments will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval after being passed by the Executive Yuan, the official said. However, he added that winning agreement from the legislature may not be easy as the amendments -- versions of which have been proposed many times -- touch on many entrenched interests.

The streamlining is intended to increase the Executive Yuan's operational efficiency, with many overlapping duties being cut or integrated, the official said, adding that many of the reforms were previously proposed in 2005.

The proposed amendments designate 14 ministries for the future Executive Yuan, with a new ministry on veterans' affairs being added to the 13 proposed in 2005. It will also increase the number of councils from four to seven.

The five independent organizations designated in the draft amendments are the Central Bank, the Central Election Commission, the Fair Trade Commission, the National Communications Commission, and the Financial Supervisory Commission, the official said.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou have both made reform of government administration a part of their political platforms, the official said.

After listening to a report on the planned reforms by Shih Neng-chieh, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission under the Executive Yuan, earlier this month, Premire Chang Chun-hsiung indicated that the Cabinet would push the legislature to pass the amendment package during its current session, the official said.

Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said the proposed Executive Yuan restructuring plan is consistent with the DPP administration's promotion of government reform, but is not particularly associated with the presidential election slated for March 22.
Shieh made the remarks to reporters as he joined the Lunar New Year's greeting activities at the Chinese Television System.
Shieh expressed the hope that the package would be passed by the new legislature, which is dominated by the KMT, as early as possible. The new legislature will open its first plenary session Feb. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker's corruption conviction upheld in High Court retrial

TEXT.P: Controversial opposition Legislator Yen Ching-piao was convicted on charges of corruption and possession of firearms during his tenure as speaker of the Taichung County Council by the Taiwan High Court Tuesday, upholding previous court rulings.

The High Court again found Yen guilty of possessing firearms and illegally using up to NT$20.6 million in public funds to entertain guests at night clubs during his stint as Taichung County Council speaker from Oct. 1998 to Dec. 2000.

The Taichung branch of the Taiwan High Court sentenced Yen to a combined 11 years in prison, with eight years for the corruption charges and three years and six months for the firearm possession conviction. The sentence is two years shorter than that handed down by the same court in a previous trial.
According to Tuesday's verdict, Yen will also be stripped of his civil rights for six years after serving his prison term.
Protesting his innocence, Yen, who was re-elected with a high proportion of the vote in the hotly contested Jan. 12 legislative elections, said he will definitely again appeal to the Supreme Court.

Taichung County Council Speaker Chang Ching-tang, who was deputy speaker when Yen led the body, was also convicted for his role in the corruption case and sentenced to eight years and four months in jail. Another accomplice in the case, Tsai Wen-hsiung, a former chief secretary of the council, was given a sentence of eight years and two months.

The three were found guilty of the charges by the Taichung District Court and then by the High Court in the case's first retrial. After the High Court verdict, the defendents appealed to the ruling to the Supreme Court, which sent the cases back to the High Court for a new trial that concluded with Tuesday's guilty verdicts.
Yen, Chang and Tsai can all file another appeal with the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition opens for six-day show

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition, which opens Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, is expected to attract more than 400,000 visitors from around the world during its six-day run until Feb. 18, organizers said Tuesday.
Over 1,000 exhibitors from nearly 50 countries are taking part in the annual show, displaying their works in Chinese, Japanese, English, French, German and other languages.
The first day of the exhibition is reserved for book industry professionals, with the remaining five days open to the general public.
Australia is the theme country of this year's exhibition and the Australian pavilion will display some 1,000 books and publications provided by 25 publishers.

Major events at the Australian pavilion will include an Australian artists' book exhibition featuring books by seven outstanding artists, an Australian Way of Life exhibition highlighting the multiculturalism of Australian society, a Show Me Australia photography competition, and an exhibition of original sketches and works by famous illustrator Shaun Tan.

Tan and seven Australian writers -- Tony Wheeler, Maureen Wheeler, Markus Zusak, Shaun Tan, Nerrilee Weir, Nick Earls and Jennifer Fefferies -- will speak at seminars to introduce Australian culture, art, literature and the publishing business. They will also attend autograph sessions.

Other events include a seminar titled Mechanics on Translation and Distribution Rights Feb. 13, a presentation Feb. 14 to launch the latest titles from Malaysia and the Philippines, and a seminar on the art of storytelling Feb. 17.

The Taipei book exhibition, one of the largest in Asia, has been the annual meeting point for Asian publishers for decades. It has earned a reputation as the most diversified international book fair in Asia, providing the most up-to- date information about the publishing industry.

On the eve of the opening of the 2008 show, Government Information Office head Shieh Jhy-wey, representing the Taipei International Book Exhibition, signed an agreement with Ana Maria Cabanellas, president of the International Publishers' Association (IPA), for the book fair to join the IPA as a cooperative partner.

The IPA is an international industry federation representing the publishing industry worldwide through 78 national, regional and specialized publishers associations in 66 countries. Established in Paris in 1896, the IPA mission is to promote and protect publishing and to raise awareness of publishing as a force for economic, cultural and political development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate resolved in presidential bid

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou urged the public Tuesday to support his presidential bid in the March 22 race, saying that giving the KMT's full power in the legislative and executive branches will bring progress for Taiwan.

Ma issued the call while addressing a Lunar New Year gathering of KMT members at the party's headquarters, in which KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker Tseng Yung-chuan and KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih also were present.

Brushing aside widespread speculation that Taiwan would return to an authoritarian rule if the KMT succeeds in seizing the presidency after its avalanche victory in the Jan. 12 legislative polls, Ma reiterated that the country would make remarkable progress should the KMT win the presidency while fully in control of the Legislative Yuan.
"If the Presidential Office and the Legislative Yuan could work in tandem, it would improve the welfare of the people and lead to the advancement of the country," Ma asserted.

"If the KMT controls the legislature and the central government, the party must be fully held accountable for its performance in ruling the country, " he said, adding that "Taiwan's people have had enough with political wrangling."

Ma also blamed the incumbent Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration for what he calls Taiwan's lackluster performance in recent years, arguing that the government is responsible for the people's current difficulties.

"Taiwan's problem lies in the government sector, and now is the time for the people to have a new government, particularly as the DPP administration has impeded Taiwan's advancement over the past eight years," he went on to claim.
The KMT presidential candidate also expressed confidence of winning the March 22 race, in which he will face DPP rival Frank Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA commends communities and volunteers

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) released Tuesday a list of 18 communities and 19 volunteers around Taiwan who have contributed to the island's environmental and ecological protection.

Of the 18 communities, three of them, located in Chiayi City and Tainan County in southern Taiwan and Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan, were graded as excellent. They were commended because of residents' efforts to apply ecological knowledge to their daily lives and to improving their living environments, said Yan Hsu-Ming, director of the EPA's planning department.

EPA official Liu Zong-yong said residents of Yanpu village in Changhua County, central Taiwan, transformed a pigpen and waste ground into a leisure center and organic vegetable garden, using the waste to build and decorate, turning old bricks into a path and using discarded wood to build a fence.

Among the commended volunteers, Chen Zhi-ming, a retired fisherman living near the coast of Tainan County, was mentioned for his contributions to soil improvement, conservation and restoration of various plants growing in the coastal area.
"What is meaningful is that the efforts of these ordinary people have made our living environment better, " said Liu, urging the rest of the public to help protect the environment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shihding township head indicted for helping tax dodgers

TEXT.P: A township head in Taipei County and two of his subordinates were indicted Wednesday on charges of helping wealthy individuals evade taxes in 2005.
The Public Prosecutors Office of the Taipei District Court is seeking a sentence of 10 years in prison for Shihding township head Yeh Jung-hua, plus a fine of NT$10 million (US$313,795).

The prosecutors are also asking a sentence of six-and-a-half years for Yeh's secretary, Huang Chao-chin, and a sentence of five-and-a-half years for Chiu Chien-liang, head of the township government's public construction department.

According to the prosecution, the trio helped about 180 wealthy people, including well-known doctors, to evade taxes of NT$260 million by accepting large tax-deductible donations from them in the name of aiding the township's green project while actually giving 80 percent of the donations back to the donors.

Although the national tax authorities tried to contact the township government to inquire about its green project after detecting the apparent abnormalities, Yeh and his two subordinates ignored them.

Prosecutors and agents from the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice questioned Yeh, Huang and Chiu, as well as some 190 suspected tax dodgers in April last year. Yeh was taken into custody but was later released on NT$1 million bail.
Most of the tax dodgers received suspended sentences after paying all the taxes they owed to the national coffers and making donations to charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's GDP growth can be maintained at more than 4%: think tanks

TEXT.P: Most domestic and foreign think tanks forecast that Taiwan's economic growth for 2008 can be maintained at a minimum of 4 percent despite a possible economic downturn in the United States.

Thomas M.f. Yeh, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development's (CEPD), said Tuesday that despite a gloomy economic outlook in the U.S., Taiwan's foreign trade will still grow stably due largely to local manufacturers' successful export deployment in emerging markets.

"Taiwan's exports to the Asian region have accounted for more than 60 percent of its total exports, while the global demand for the island's electronic and panel display products is still strong, " Yeh said.

Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) Chairman David S. Hong shared Yeh's view, predicting that the island's exports may grow by 9.38 percent this year, while its imports may increase by 10.33 percent.
The council and the institute forecast Taiwan's economic growth for this year at 4.8 percent and 4.29 percent, respectively.

However, the Taiwan-based Polaris Research Institute's President Liang Kuo-yuan showed a more pessimistic view on Taiwan's foreign trade, stressing that the growth in Taiwan's exports may be offset by the economic downfall in the United States.

"Taiwan's exports will just register a moderate growth in 2008, which will be lower than that of last year as most of the major economies around the world will suffer a slowdown in their economic growth this year," Liang added at a recent press conference.

U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke acknowledged recently that "U.S. economic outlooks are deteriorating" due to rising oil prices and the slumping housing market, with former Federal Reserve chief Alan Greenspan echoing Bernanke's view by saying recently that the U.S. economy has shown "signs of recession."

DOC.HEADLINE: President congratulates new Belize PM: MOFA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sent a letter during the Lunar New Year holiday to congratulate newly elected Belize Prime Minister Dean Barrow and express hope that bilateral relations will grow even closer under the new government, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regularly scheduled press briefing, Yeh noted that Belize's opposition United Democratic Party (UDP) won the most parliamentary seats in the Feb. 7 election and that its leader, Dean Barrow, was inaugurated Feb. 8 as the new prime minister.
Yeh rebutted media speculation that the new government of Belize might switch diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to the People's Republic of China.

She noted that before the election, Barrow, speaking to Belize domestic media and the British Broadcasting Company, said his country would maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan if the UDP won the election.
Taiwan appreciates the staunch support of Belize and wishes to continue with bilateral cooperation projects in the areas of culture, agriculture, education and medical aid, she added.

Belize, a former British colony located in Central America, established diplomatic ties with Taiwan in 1989. Belize is one of Taiwan's most loyal allies supporting the country's efforts to join the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public reminded of good hygiene to prevent enterovirus infection

TEXT.P: The Center of Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health called on the public Tuesday to maintain good personal hygiene to prevent cluster infections of enterovirus after the start of the new school semester.

CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting pointed out that the country already has had 30 reported serious cases of enterovirus infection since the beginning of this year. Among them, 13 were confirmed, with 10 in southern Taiwan, one in central Taiwan and two in northern Taiwan, Lin said.
The 13th confirmed case was that of an 18-month baby in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, Lin went on.
"It is not the peak season for the disease yet and the high number of serious cases is an abnormal situation," Lin said. The peak season for enterovirus disease is usually summer.

There were only two reported serious cases and non-confirmed cases during the same period of last year. A total of 49 cases were reported throughout last year, with 12 confirmed and two fatalities, Lin continued.

The enterovirus epidemic curve of the past three weeks showed a drop of 39.5 percent from when the previous semester was still in session, but the percentage might rise again after the new semester begins because the disease tends to become epidemic among people with intensive contacts, such as schoolchildren, Lin said.
Lin reminded parents to be alert to symptoms of high fever, lapses in consciousness and muscle spasms in their children and to seek early treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei International Book Fair spearheads world's book fairs

TEXT.P: The International Publishers Association (IPA) awarded the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) the privilege of being the world's first to join its book fair partnership program, thanks to Taiwan's well-developed freedom of speech and publication, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Shieh Jhy- wey said Tuesday at a press conference.

On behalf of the GIO -- the book fair's major sponsor -- Shieh signed a partnership program agreement with IPA President Ana Maria Cabanellas, finalizing what Shieh hailed as a historic step for Taiwan's publishing industry.
"Taiwan is a small island, so it is important for the country to boost its image overseas as much as possible," he said.

Shieh also noted the IPA's preference of Taiwan over China. "Taiwan's publication industry has two major prevalences -- free publication and free speech, " Shieh pointed out, referring to the partnership program that places high value on these two basic rights, still under strict control by the government in China.

The partnership program, which allows non- publisher organizations like TIBE to take part in the IPA, aims to improve the operation of the book fair and make sure the process is in line with the IPA's chief principals such as respecting copyright laws, Cabanellas said, adding that there are also training sessions provided to help further develop local publishers.

Although the rights enjoyed by an IPA member and a book fair program participant are largely the same, book fair partners do not have the right to vote in the IPA General Assembly, according to Cabanellas.

The IPA initiated the book fair partnership program in 2006, with the aim of helping promote book fairs around the world. At the Frankfurt Book Fair last October, the association offered the program's first invitation to TIBE, which also participated in the German book fair to promote Taiwanese books and writers.

Cabanellas also expressed anticipation for the IPA Publishers Congress in May in Seoul, saying the organization is very interested in this year's congress "because the Asian delegates will help us learn more about the publishing industry in the region."

Linden Lin, chairman of Taipei Book Fair Foundation, will deliver a speech at the congress to discuss the status and prospects of Taiwan's publishing industry. The foundation is the organizer of the TIBE.

China, despite its infamous record on freedom of speech, is also invited to the congress. Although China is not an IPA member, Cabanallas noted, a Chinese delegate will give a speech discussing publishing freedom in China.
The congress is held every four years for global publishers to review the international publishing industry, covering a range of topics including marketing and censorship issues.
At present, seven of the 50-plus IPA member states are in Asia -- India, Indonesia, Japan, Korea, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
The Taipei book fair will be held for six days from Feb. 13-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Halls 1, 2 and 3, with the Australian Pavilion as its centerpiece.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sports lottery to intensify Taiwan's lottery market competition

TEXT.P: The Taipei Fubon Bank is expected to launch a sports lottery in May at the latest, which will pose a major threat to the Taiwan Lottery Co. (TLC) , which is currently the official operator of various public welfare lotteries in Taiwan.
A spokesman for the bank said Tuesday that 20 percent of the respondents to a recent survey carried out by the bank said they will buy sports lottery tickets.

Sports lottery ticket buyers will have greater odds of winning the lottery if they have a better understanding of the rules of the games and the participating teams, according to Fubon Vice President Richard Yang.
In the initial stage, the sports lottery will focus on games of the U.S. NBA basketball, Major League Baseball and the Union of European Football Associations, Yang noted.
He further predicted that 400 games will be played on a monthly basis, with a maximum of 6,000 games held annually.
Overall, the compound annual growth rate of the world's sports lottery market has hit 13 percent, while that of the world's lottery market only registers 9 percent.
According to Yang, public welfare lottery ticket buyers in Taiwan are aged between 18 and 65, with equal numbers of males and females.
In contrast, in other countries, sports lottery ticket buyers are aged between 25 and 45, mostly white-collar males and male computer users who have strong interest in sport.

To counter the possible strong competition from the sports lottery, the Taiwan Lottery Co. (TLC) -- which suffered losses in lottery sales last year -- will launch new products every season, said company Chairman Oliver Shang.
The TLC, a subsidiary of the Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., beat the Taipei Fubon Bank in 2006 to become the authorized runner of public welfare lotteries from 2007 to 2013.
The following year, the Taipei Fubon Bank defeated other bidders, including the Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., to win the right to operate the sports lottery from 2008 to 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE offers tuition subsidies to underprivileged children

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) has been offering tuition subsidies to underprivileged children and is hoping that local governments will help distribute the subsidies to elementary and junior high students from poor families, a ministry official said Tuesday.

Pan Wen-chung, director of the MOE's Department of Elementary Education, noted that the ministry has established a three-level protection net since 2005 aimed at offering financial help of NT$2,000 annually to children from underprivileged families, provided by schools, local governments and the central government.
According to Pan, some 40,000 elementary and junior high school children cannot afford annual school tuition fees.

He called on teachers to check on the financial situation of their students and for local governments to assign budget for the tuition subsidies, adding that the MOE will help collect funds to ensure that students do not drop out of school due to financial factors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Core consumer prices to surge this year: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to face rising inflationary pressure this year due to soaring core consumer prices and rising grain prices and commodity costs, according to official statistics released Tuesday.

Core consumer prices, which exclude vegetables, fruits and fish, as well as food and energy costs, registered a year-on-year growth of 1.35 percent last year, the highest level since 1997, due to skyrocketing grain prices on the international market, according to the tallies compiled by the Directorate- General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS).
A DGBAS official said core consumer prices will drive overall commodity prices up.

Between 2006-2007, the price surge of agricultural products was the most noticeable, with the price of Chinese herbs hiking the most at 43.75 percent, followed by that of tomatoes at 38.7 percent, corn at 22.84 percent, cabbages at 18.13 percent and Chinese cabbages at 16 percent, according to the tallies.
Prices on the vegetable index in 2007 rose by 9.52 percent year-on-year which contributed to an increase of 1. 8 percent in the year's CPI, the report revealed.

The official attributed the soaring consumer-price inflation mainly to the unrelenting rise of grain prices which he said pushed commodity suppliers to adjust prices upward to shift costs to consumers.

Citing the tallies, the official said that as a result, prices of a wide range of products posted a year-on-year growth, such as the price of salad oils, which went up 14.44 percent, that of raw milk up 7.31 percent, bread 6.12 percent, adult milk powder 5.61 percent, cereals 4.87 percent, Western fast food 2.77 percent, and instant noodles 2.64 percent.
The official expected that core consumer prices will drive overall commodity prices up.
In the face of the rising costs of raw materials and high oil prices this year, Taiwan is expected to face greater inflationary pressures than last year, according to the officials.

DGBAS forecast Taiwan's economic growth rate for 2008 will be 1.84 percent, the official said. The figures correspond to the results of several local and international forecasts, such as Global Insight Inc's 2.3 percent, compared with 2.01 percent by Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, 1.95 percent by Polaris Research Institute, 1.93 percent by Academia Sinica and 1.86 percent by Taiwan Research Institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 350,000 test rides taken on Kaohsiung MRT

TEXT.P: More than 350,000 people took test rides on a section of the Red Line of the Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transport system from Feb. 8-11, a Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. official said Monday.
The corporation opened the 8.2 km section Feb. 8, the second day of the Chinese New Year holidays, for free test rides.
The section spans six stations located in the southern area of the 28.3 km Red Line, which includes 23 stations, the official said.
According to an exit poll conducted by the corporation during the test run period, up to 98 percent of the respondents agreed that the rides were both convenient and pleasant.

Ninety percent of the respondents expressed the opinion that the Red Line offers a higher level of comfort and service than that provided by the MRT system in Taipei, northern Taiwan, according to the exit poll.
The Red Line is expected to be formally inaugurated in early March, corporation sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's January exports, imports remain brisk

TEXT.P: Taiwan's January exports totaled US$22.1 billion and imports registered US$20.6 billion, the fourth- and third-highest single-month values in the country's history, respectively, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Tuesday.
January exports and imports saw year-on-year rises of 11.9 percent and 14.8 percent, respectively, said Hsu Ray-lin, deputy director of the ministry's statistics department.

Hsu attributed the export growth to an increase of over 14-percent in exports to Hong Kong, China, South Korea and the six member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) -- Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.
On the import growth, Hsu explained that Taiwan's imports from Hong Kong, China, the United States, Japan and Europe grew more than 13 percent in the month.
He further said that Taiwan reported a trade surplus of US$1.53 billion in January, marking the 23rd trade surplus month in a row since March 2006.
The figures indicate that Taiwan's foreign trade is continuing to expand steadily, Hsu noted.
According to Hsu, exports of chemical, machinery and precision instrument products rose greatly in January, while those of traditional products dropped.
Imports of mineral and machinery products saw the largest growths of the total January imports, Hsu said, adding that it was still too early to determine if domestic investment is improving.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien Blood Center urges public to donate blood

TEXT.P: The Hualien Blood Center appealed to the public Tuesday to donate blood to help relieve a blood shortage that has troubled the center since before the Lunar New Year holiday.
Center staff said the current stockpile of various types of blood is dangerously low, with a shortfall of about 1,000 bags.
They pointed out that the center has only 23 bags of Type A blood left, although 235 bags are needed to maintain a safe storage level to meet demand for seven days.

The stock of Type B blood is down to 51 bags, far lower than the safe level of 200 bags. The center should also have 380 bags of Type O blood, but the stockpile has dropped to 111 bags, while Type AB blood, usually maintained at 60 bags, is down to only 11 bags.

Workers at the center urged members of the public aged between 17 and 65 to donate blood generously to help resolve the shortage if they are in good physical condition and meet the requirements of a minimum 50 kg in weight for males and 45 kg for females.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND to check if alleged spy got information on defense system

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has formed a task force to determine if an alleged Chinese spy arrested in the United States offered Beijing information about a new air defense system that it intends to purchase from Washington, the ministry said Tuesday in a news release.

The press statement was issued after the U.S. Department of Justice announced Monday that four individuals suspected of spying for China had been arrested. Among them is a Taiwanese-American identified as Kuo Tai-sheng.

According to a United Evening News report, the leaked classified information was mostly related to a C4ISR system that Taiwan intends to procure to integrate its military command, control, communications, computers, intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance systems.

The MND statement said the ministry has consistently communicated with the U.S. Department of Defense through arms purchase channels concerning weaponry systems. Noting that the U.S. has imposed internal controls on all related information, the statement said the MND will voice concern as to whether any information about the C4ISR system has been leaked, and will adopt response measures.

Meanwhile, an Associated Press report said Kuo Tai-sheng, 58, was arrested for allegedly providing Beijing with information obtained from Pentagon weapons systems policy analyst Gregg W. Bergersen, 51.

The U.S. Justice Department said Monday that Bergersen sold classified defense information to Kuo, whom it identified as a New Orleans furniture salesman. In return, Kuo, a Taiwanese native and naturalized U.S. citizen, forwarded the information to the Chinese government, it said.

In an affidavit, the department said that Bergersen worked for the Arlington, Virginia-based Defense Security Cooperation Agency, and that he had discussed with Kuo the sophisticated command, control and communications system that Taiwan is purchasing from U.S. defense contractor Lockheed Martin.

An unidentified MND official was quoted as having told Associated Press that the ministry was trying to ascertain if the information Kuo allegedly supplied was related to the C4ISR system, formally known as Automated Air Defense System.

"We understand Kuo was not awarded any contracts connected with the command system, " the official said. "The U.S. Defense Department is handling our weapons purchases, and we are trying to understand it."
According to a Lockheed Martin company statement, its Automated Air Defense System "will significantly increase operational command and control, as well as ensure system survivability."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Travelers to Europe May Face Fingerprinting
The European Commission will propose tomorrow that all foreign travelers entering and leaving Europe, including U.S. citizens, should be fingerprinted. If approved by the European Parliament, the measure would mean that precisely identifying information on tens of millions of citizens will be added in coming years to databases that could be shared by friendly governments around the world.
The Washington Times:Youth enthusiastic for voice in primary
Young voters in the region are eager to cast ballots in the primary today, saying they are excited about the Democratic presidential candidates and participating in a meaningful election.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Mortgage Crisis Spreads Past Subprime Loans
The credit crisis is no longer just a subprime mortgage problem.
The Wall Street Journal:Scrutiny Tightens for Title Insurers
The collapse of the housing boom is bringing harsh new scrutiny to the $17 billion title- insurance business, including allegations that insurers colluded illegally and paid kickbacks to agents or brokers to get business.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGInternet users could be banned over illegal downloads
People who illegally download films and music will be cut off from the internet under new legislative proposals to be unveiled next week.
Internet service providers (ISPs) will be legally required to take action against users who access pirated material, The Times has learnt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened Wednesday.
The weighted price index was up 91.50 points at 7,644.80 on a turnover of NT$2.93 billion (US$91.9 million) at the open. The index lost 120.69 points, or 1.57 percent, to close at 7,553.3 Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.739 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.145 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 13, or the seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1542: Catherine Howard, wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded for treason.
1668: Spain recognizes the independence of Portugal under the Treaty of Lisbon.
1692: Under English orders, Robert Campbell of Glen Lyon and his 128 men carry out the Glencoe massacre in Scotland against the MacDonald clan.
1793: Austria, Britain, Holland, Prussia, Spain, and Sardinia form an alliance against France.
1858: Captain John Speke and Sir Richard Burton become the first Europeans to discover Lake Tanganyika in East Africa.
1912: Dr. Sun Yat-sen tenders his resignation to the provisional Senate which was established in Nanking on Jan. 28, 1912. He also agrees to relinquish the provisional presidency of the Republic of China to Yuan Shih-kai, who promises to establish a republican government.
1920: Switzerland is admitted to the League of Nations.
1935: A judge sentences Bruno Hauptmann to die in the electric chair after a New Jersey jury found him guilty of kidnapping and murdering flying ace Charles Lindbergh's infant son three years earlier.
1941: The wonder drug penicillin is used for the first time on a human, a policeman from Oxford, England.
1945: U.S. warplanes bomb Dresden, Germany, killing over 35,000 civilians, while allied forces capture Budapest, Hungary.
1954: Chou Lu, a veteran revolutionary leader of the Kuomintang, dies in Taipei at the age of 70.
1957: The British Defense Ministry announces the production of its first H-bomb.
1958: Taipei area records its lowest temperature (2.6 degrees Celsius) in half a century.
1960: The French test their first atomic bomb in the Sahara Desert in Africa.
1966: The list of winners of the first 10 outstanding ROC female youth awards is announced.
1971: Spiro Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1971: Aided by U.S. aircraft and artillery, South Vietnamese troops enter Laos.
1973: Minister of Economic Affairs Y. S. Sun of the ROC leaves for Bangkok to attend a meeting of the board of trustees of the Asian Institute of Technology and meet with Thai government officials.
1975: The ROC Cabinet decides to ban activities of the Christian Unification Church on the grounds that it has been violating the customs of the Chinese people.
1975: The Sino-Guatemalan and the Sino-Dominican technical cooperation agreements are approved by the ROC Cabinet.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghanistan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits performing artists from Taiwan to stage commercial performances in mainland China and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A U.S. missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
1994: A ferry taking illegal Burmese workers home capsizes off Thailand. More than 150 of them are feared dead.
1998: A special convention votes to make Australia a republic and promises a referendum on replacing the queen as head of state in 1999.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is composed and happy; a fool is always worried and full of distress."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Election unlikely to affect ties with China: official
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/08 13:05:37 (By P.C. Tang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: There is unlikely to be any progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations whatever the outcome of the March 22 presidential election, a Taiwan official said at a seminar in Brussels Tuesday.

Liu Shih-chung, deputy chief of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Research and Planning Committee, contended that even if Ma Ying-jeou from the pro-unification Kuomintang (KMT) were to be elected president, it is unlikely Beijing would allow Taiwan more space in the international arena.

Speaking at a seminar held by the European Institute for Asian Studies in the Belgian capital, Liu said that whoever is elected to lead Taiwan will still have to deal with China's continued intimidation and suppression of the country.
The next president's most important duty, he asserted, will be to protect Taiwan's security and sovereignty and uphold the people's right to determine Taiwan's future.

Meanwhile, the official argued that the KMT's landslide win in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, in which it won 81 of the 113 seats contested, does not mean the party will definitely emerge victorious on March 22.

But the victory did allow Beijing to breathe a sigh of relief, Liu said, because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) repeated calls to re-engineer the Constitution was nightmarish for China.

The KMT's dominance of the legislature, which must approve constitutional amendments by a three-quarters majority before they are voted on by the people, means that initiatives to change the Constitution to formalize Taiwan's independence are likely to be blocked in the next four years.

On the two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid to be held alongside the presidential elections, Liu said Beijing opposes both questions, whether the DPP's version on joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan" or the KMT's initiative to regain U.N. membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

With China increasing its deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan and stepping up its policy of isolating Taiwan diplomatically, the referendums were simply a measure to counter Beijing's attempt to change the cross-strait status quo, Liu argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH reminds lovers to use condoms ahead of Valentine's Day

TEXT.P: With couples around Taiwan set to enjoy a romantic Valentine's Day, the Department of Health (DOH) reminded lovers Wednesday to use condoms to prevent turning their romance into regret.
Yang Ching-hui, a section chief at the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, stressed that condoms are effective in preventing the spread of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases.
He cautioned couples not to see AIDS as a threat only to homosexuals, citing statistics which show that over 20 percent of new AIDS cases in Taiwan are the result of heterosexual intercourse.
Couples should also use condoms when engaging in oral sex, Yang said, noting that research has revealed that HIV can also be transmitted orally.
Yang further said that couples should avoid using oil-based lubricants on condoms as such lubricants increase the likelihood of condoms breaking during intercourse.
If couples decide to use lubricants, they should use safer water-based ones instead, he advised.

Noting that sexual intercourse is the main way that AIDS is transmitted in Taiwan, Yang urged couples to not let their passion get the better of them and to be sure to use a condom to avoid a tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT dollar's rate of appreciation against greenback 2nd highest in Asia

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar's rate of appreciation against the U.S. dollar has been the second highest among all Asian currencies so far this year, according to figures released Wednesday by a Singapore-based asset management company.

The NT dollar has risen 2.58 percent against the greenback since the start of the year, trailing only the Malaysian ringgit, which has appreciated 2.65 percent, according to the UOB Investment Advisor (Taiwan) Ltd.

Most Asian currencies have appreciated against the U.S. dollar so far this year, with the Indonesian rupiah gaining 2.48 percent, the Singapore dollar rising 1.89 percent, the Philippine peso up 1.38 percent, and the Chinese yuan gaining 1.07 percent, the figures showed.

The Indian rupee and Hong Kong dollar have also made slight gains, at 0.35 percent and 0.33 percent, respectively, while the Thai baht and South Korean won have slid by 6.74 percent and 0.43 percent, respectively.

Although the NT dollar has performed well among Asian currencies so far this year, the local currency placed near the bottom of the list in 2007, rising just 2.58 percent against the greenback, well behind the Thai baht's 25.49 percent, the Philippine peso's 25.12 percent, the Indian rupee's 22.65 percent and the Malaysian ringgit's 10.59 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet postpones approving amendments aimed at streamlining gov't

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Wednesday postponed approving measures that would streamline the executive branch of Taiwan's government, but Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said he would try to push the revisions through next week.
The Cabinet was considering a draft package of amendments to the Organization Act of the Executive Yuan that would cut the number of agencies under the Executive Yuan from 39 to 26.

Chang said the amendments have taken longer to iron out than any other bills considered during his second term as premier, which began in May 2007. He noted that he had asked Vice Premier Chiou I-jen to hold discussions with related ministries and councils to try and make progress on the issue before the Executive Yuan's meeting next week.

Chang is treating the measures with some urgency because of what he said is the "profound influence" the government reform package would have in increasing the Executive Yuan's operational efficiency, with many overlapping duties being cut or integrated.
