Based on a 2005 proposal that called for the Executive Yuan to be composed of 13 ministries and four councils, the draft amendments currently under consideration propose a structure of 14 ministries, seven councils and five independent organizations.

The new measures would add a ministry for veterans' affairs and three other councils -- the National Science Council, the Gender Equality Commission, and the Oceans Commission -- to the 2005 proposal.

The draft amendments will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval after being passed by the Executive Yuan, but achieving a consensus in the legislature could be even more difficult because the amendments touch on many entrenched interests with support in the lawmaking body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Frozen soybeans top Taiwan's agricultural exports

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports about 23,000 tons of frozen soybeans each year, making it the top foreign reserve earner among all agricultural produce exported, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Wednesday.

Taiwan last year produced some 43,000 tons of frozen soybeans -- a major source of vegetarian protein -- with more than half, or about 23,000 tons, being exported, officials from the COA Food and Agriculture Agency said.

Based on an average export price of US$1.75 per kilogram, the export of frozen soybeans generated about US$50 million last year in forex revenues. That far exceeded Taiwan's second most valuable export crop -- ginger -- which had an export value of US$5.08 million in 2007, the officials said.
The biggest market for Taiwan's frozen soybeans is Japan, where Taiwan's soybeans have a 35 percent share of the frozen soybean market, they noted.

The officials said that to secure stable supplies of soybeans and lower production costs, the COA began last year to assist the Taiwan Regional Association of Frozen Vegetable and Fruit to develop an exclusive soybean plantation zone in the Kaohsiung-Pingtung area in southern Taiwan.

About 6 tons of soybeans can be harvested two to three times a year from each hectare of the exclusive zone -- an area of 2,497 hectares -- ensuring production of about 30,000 tons a year, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Belgian university student group pushes Taiwan's U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 12 (CNA) 02/13/08 16:02:05 (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese students studying at a Belgian university launched a drive Tuesday to rally support for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations as a full member.

The drive is aimed not only at letting Taiwan know that Taiwanese students in Belgium are supportive of U.N. membership for the country, but also at soliciting support for the bid from other foreign students studying in Belgium and members of the international community, said campaign spokeswoman Shen Yi- ling.

In a written statement from the Taiwanese student association at the French- language Universite Catholique de Louvain in Belgium, the group said Taiwan has an independent constitutional system under which its people enjoy free and dynamic political lives.

Arguing that the international community has not fully understood the "collective mindset" of the Taiwanese people, the group said Taiwan's U.N. bid is a first, critical step in getting the world to better learn about Taiwan.

Taiwan's people, whether they live in Taiwan or abroad and irrespective of their political persuasions, should say out loud with one single voice that "Taiwan and its 23 million people deserve U.N. membership," the statement urged.

As the Republic of China, Taiwan lost its seat in the world body to the People's Republic of China in 1971, and has reapplied unsuccessfully for membership in the body every year since 1993. Last year was the first time Taiwan tried to apply for a U.N. seat under the name "Taiwan."

Two referendums will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election on the U.N. bid -- one proposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on joining the U.N. under the name "Taiwan, " the other proposed by the Kuomintang on rejoining the U.N. under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.
The group urged Taiwanese voters to participate in the polls to help the world realize the importance U.N. membership for Taiwan.

Should the referendums fail -- and they would be defeated if 50 percent of eligible voters do not cast ballots on the questions -- it would send a message to the world that Taiwan's people do not want to enter the U.N. and even worse, that they "want to be ruled by the People's Republic of China government," the group said.

While some foreign governments do not support Taiwan's holding of the referendums, "many foreign friends here in Brussels support the idea of Taiwan's being admitted into the U.N.," the statement said.

The Louvain student group printed handouts of "U.N. membership for Taiwan" in Chinese, English, French, German, Dutch, Spanish, Italian, Japanese, Vietnamese and Malaysian to solicit global support for Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government initiates tree planting drive

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) has initiated a renewed drive to promote the planting of trees with the aim of encouraging every citizen to plant at least one tree in his or her lifetime, COA senior officials said Wednesday.

The officials said that in the wake of drastic climate changes caused by global warming, Taiwan should contribute to alleviate the burden on the environment as a responsible member of the global village.
"Tree planting is an important first step to achieve that goal, " they added.

The drive -- officially titled "One Life, One Tree, for a Motherland of Green" -- is using 12 species of tree corresponding to the 12 signs of the zodiac to induce people to sow the tree seed corresponding to their sign on their birthday, in the hope that at least half of the population will have been persuaded to plant their own trees within five years.

COA Minister Su Jia-chyuan estimated that if all 23 million Taiwanese follow the call, it will raise the nation's forest coverage by 59.09 percent, reducing carbon emissions, producing oxygen and retaining water that could be worth billions of dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: Toxic dumplings may give Taiwan opening in Japan: TAITRA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will step up efforts to help Taiwan's food manufacturers penetrate the Japanese market after dumplings made in China found to contain a toxic pesticide called into question the reliability of China-made products.

Japan relies on imports for 60 percent of its food supply, and China is the country's largest source of food imports, but with China's reputation tainted, Japanese buyers have been forced to adjust their purchasing habits, TAITRA officials said.

The officials said they will invite Japanese buyers and media to visit Taiwan's local frozen food manufacturers and see for themselves the strict food safety criteria Taiwanese suppliers have put in place.
"This will boost Japanese buyers' confidence in Taiwan products," they said.

The semi-official trade promotion organization is also planning to organize groups of local businesses to take part in two major Japanese food expositions, the Super Market Trade Show, Japan's biggest supermarket trade show that takes place in Tokyo later this month, and FOODDEX Japan, to be held in Tokyo in March.

At least 2,000 people in 46 prefectures reportedly got sick after eating the pesticide-contaminated dumplings from China. Japanese food companies recalled the toxic dumplings, and some high-end department stores have even removed all Chinese frozen foods from their shelves.

As a result, Japanese consumers' faith in China-made food has plunged. A poll conducted by the Kyodo News Agency Feb. 9-10 found that 75.9 percent of Japanese say they will no longer use food products made in China.

TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shui recently invited officials from the Taiwan Frozen Food Processors Association and three big frozen food producers -- Chi Mei, I Mei and Taiwan Sugar -- to discuss possible trade opportunities.
They told Yeh that recent inquires from Japan have increased markedly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has low coverage rate of residential quake insurance

TEXT.P: Only 24.6 percent of Taiwan's residences are insured against earthquakes, a low coverage rate compared to that found in other countries, a Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) official said Wednesday.

Earthquake insurance coverage rates for residential buildings abroad range between 40 percent and 50 percent, with the rate in New Zealand surpassing 80 percent, said FSC Administrative Vice Chairwoman Susan Chang.

Although many local residents still do not buy earthquake insurance for their homes, earthquake policies have grown more popular in the wake of destructive temblors that have hit Taiwan over the past 10 years.

Taiwan's earthquake insurance coverage rate stood at a mere 0.2 percent when a major quake of magnitude 7.3 devastated central Taiwan in September 1999, leaving over 2,400 people dead and more than 8,000 injured, Chang noted.

The government implemented a residential earthquake insurance system in 2002, and since then, more than 1.87 million residential quake insurance polices, worth NT$2.53 trillion (US$79.4 billion) , have been purchased, according to the commission's Insurance Bureau.

Despite the constant threat from earthquakes, most local homeowners do not ensure their homes or apartments against damage from earthquakes until they need to apply for housing loans, said Chang, who added that her commission will step up its efforts to raise local citizens' awareness of controlling risk to their properties.
Taiwan is frequently hit by earthquakes, with 51 active faults around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung Arts Festival to include Guinness world record attempt

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu invited art lovers from around Taiwan Wednesday to visit the Taichung Traditional Arts festival to experience the blending of traditional arts with modern creativity.

The festival, slated to be held Feb. 15-24, will feature traditional plays, operas and folk art activities, as well as an arts market, according to Taichung City's Cultural Affairs Bureau, which is organizing the event.
Bureau officials said one of the highlights of the festival will be a massed erhu performance on the evening of Feb. 16.

Noting that over 200 people have already registered to perform at the event, the bureau officials said they are considering applying to challenge a Guinness world record for the most people performing on the erhu, a traditional two- stringed Chinese musical instrument, at the same venue.
The festival will also feature performances by over a dozen famous drama troupes from around the country, including the Guoguang Opera Troupe and a drama troupe from Nanhua University.

Describing Taichung City as a center of traditional culture, Hu said the festival will provide a great opportunity for people from around the country to get a first-hand taste of traditional Taiwanese artforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 20 points to close at 7,485, with 43,050 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost two points to finish at 7,486, with 1,849 contracts traded, while June futures gained seven points to close at 7,505, with 15 contract transactions.
September futures dropped nine points to finish at 7,306, with 27 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 2.75 points Wednesday to finish at 7,550.55, with market turnover of NT$99.134 billion (US$3.12 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,505 for February; 7,488 for March; 7,498 for June; 7,315 for September and 7,300 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
February TE futures dropped 2.7 points to close at 280, with 3,374 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved down 2.8 points to finish at 279, with 227 contracts changing hands.
September TE futures lost 3.6 points to close at 274.2, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures rose 14 points to close at 1,015.6, with 3,909 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures gained 14.2 points to finish at 1,017.2, with 177 contracts traded.
June TF futures moved up 8.4 points to finish at 1013.6, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down slightly on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were marginally lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 2.75 points, or 0.03 percent, to close at 7,550.55.

Finishing lower for the second consecutive day, the bourse opened at 7,644.8 and fluctuated between 7,655.89 and 7,533.6 during the day's session. A total of 3.56 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$99.13 billion (US$3.13 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground. Plastics and chemicals shares advanced by 2.2 percent, the most of any sector. Banking and financial shares rose 0.7 percent and textile stocks increased 0.1 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground. Construction issues fell 2.4 percent, more than any other sector. Cement stocks dropped 1.8 percent, foodstuff issues were down 1 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 0.5 percent, and paper and pulp issues dropped 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,016 to 736, with 471 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF to sponsor gathering with China-based Taiwanese businessmen

TEXT.P: The semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will sponsor a Lunar New Year meeting Thursday with China-based Taiwanese businessmen to swap opinions on issues of key concern to them, including direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, a government official said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said the main purpose of the gathering is to explore different views regarding the establishment of direct shipping and air links and the opening of charter flight services across the strait, among other major China investment policies.

In addition, the annual meeting is also aimed at gaining a better understanding of how the government can provide assistance to Taiwanese businessmen who have sustained losses following the recent snowstorms in China -- the worst in 50 years.
The MAC oversees the operations of the SEF, which is in charge of dealing with Taiwan-China private exchanges in the absence of government-to-government contacts.
President Chen Shui-bian will also take part in the gathering and give his best wishes to the nearly 200 businessmen expected to attend, the MAC chairman said.

In a bid to avoid political implications, he said that ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Ma Ying-jeou, have not been invited to the meeting.
Both Hsieh and Ma have proclaimed that if elected in the March 22 race, they will relax restrictions on China-bound investment by Taiwanese businesses.

According to Chen, SEF Chairman Hung Chi-chang and SEF Secretary-General You Ying-lung were scheduled Wednesday to first explain the government's recent cross-strait investment polices of key interest to a dozen chiefs of China-based Taiwanese businessmen's associations in a closed- door preparatory meeting to pave the way for the meeting the following day.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.196 to close at NT$31.688.
A total of US$1.359 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.884 and fluctuated between NT$31.634 and NT$31.930.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT shrugs off DPP candidate's suggestions on U.N. referendums

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) shrugged off Wednesday a suggestion by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh that he ask President Chen Shui-bian to call a bipartisan meeting on the referendums to be held on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen said it is "absolutely unnecessary" for Hsieh to ask the president to call a meeting over whether one of the two U.N.-bid referendums scheduled to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election should be forgone or whether a new, more viable U.N.-bid referendum should be worked out.

Huang said no DPP-KMT negotiations over the U.N.-bid referendums are necessary, as both sides know each other's stance over the issue very well, adding that politicians of all persuasions should now focus their energy and attention on the presidential election and try to put forward clear campaign platforms.

The Republic of China lost its seat in the world body to the People's Republic of China in 1971 and has re-applied unsuccessfully for membership in the body every year since 1993. Last year was the first time Taiwan had tried to apply for a U.N. seat under the name Taiwan.

Two referendums will be held alongside the presidential election on the U.N. bid -- one proposed by the DPP on joining the U.N. under the name Taiwan, the other proposed by the KMT on rejoining the U.N. under the name Republic of China or any other "suitable" name.

Hsieh reiterated earlier Wednesday that he supports both referendums and said he will meet the president shortly, during which he will "suggest to Chen that he call a meeting between the DPP and KMT decision-makers to work out the best solution to the DPP-KMT bickering on the issue."

Huang said that as Hsieh expressed support for the KMT-initiated referendum, he and his campaign staff must know that the first referendum, proposed by the DPP, is a dead end in the country's U.N. efforts.
Huang urged Hsieh and the DPP to forgo the DPP referendum once and for all.

He added that the KMT has never opposed the holding of any referendum on major issues, but said the party -- which now holds an absolute majority in the legislature after winning a landslide victory in the Jan. 12 legislative polls -- is firmly opposed to the plan of holding the referendums alongside the presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT should cooperate to have referendums passed: Hsieh

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh suggested Wednesday that his party seeks to cooperate with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to push for the passage of two U.N. bid referendums promoted respectively by the parties.

Hsieh, who is also chairman of the DPP, said he will officially present the proposal to President Chen Shui-bian during his planned meeting with Chen in the next couple of days, in the hope that the president will call a meeting that brings together leaders or representatives of the two parties to find a resolution that is best for Taiwan.

The two referendums are set to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election. While the DPP's version advocates joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " the KMT's initiative calls for regaining U.N. membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

However, following the failure of the two referendums held alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections because the turnout rates did not reach the required 50 percent, there have been concerns that the upcoming referendums would fail to pass as well for the same reason, especially when voters who opt to take part in the DPP-backed referendum are likely to skip the KMT-initiated referendum, and vice versa.

Reiterating his support for both referendums, Hsieh said he does not wish to see the KMT launch any drive to boycott the referendums like it did in January and cause them to fail, because such an outcome would mislead the world into doubting Taiwan's determination to join the United Nations and Taiwan's status as a country independent of China.

According to Hsieh, the two parties should support instead of compete with each other because the two referendums are not necessarily mutually exclusive, given that the KMT initiative is ambiguous compared with the DPP's and does not rule out the name "Taiwan" as a possible option.
"Joining the United Nations has been a humble desire of the Taiwan people for many years. Don't destroy Taiwan's common interests for election rivalry," Hsieh said.

Also Wednesday, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jyh-wey said the government's publicity on the U.N. bid referendums will focus on the two parties' common ground, rather than their differences, pointing out that the most important purpose of the two referendums is to declare to the world the 23 million Taiwanese people's desire to participate in the United Nations and to see the end of the "international apartheid" against Taiwan.

As the number of people signing the DPP and KMT referendum petitions totaled approximately 4 million, Hsieh said he believes if the referendums are passed, they will produce a "world-shattering" effect in the international community.
However, the KMT appeared disinterested in the DPP's gesture.

KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said the DPP should give up its referendum bid now that it is willing to support the KMT's initiative, which he claimed is the correct approach for Taiwan to participate in the United Nations.

Although the DPP initiative is intended to help Taiwan break through the isolation imposed by China, it has instead brought about much disaster to Taiwan over the past six months, with major countries including the United States and Japan as well as the European Union having openly expressed their opposition to the bid, Ma contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Campaign '08GPotomac primaries favor Obama.
A new battleground looms in a state where picnickers still flock to venerated fields of Confederate glory. The campaigns of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama are gearing up for today's presidential primary in Virginia, a key Southern state rife with knotty demographics and shifting party loyalties. Both camps view the Democratic vote in Virginia as their toughest matchup in the so- called Potomac primaries, a stretch of contests that also includes Maryland and the District of Columbia, where large and passionate constituencies among black voters and college students make Obama a heavy favorite. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan through the eyes of a French cartoonist

TEXT.P: A French cartoonist who published a comic book on Taiwan seven years ago says Taiwan remains a place full of wonder and surprises, with its "joy of living" its best asset.

"Taiwan is a country living constantly in the present, " said the cartoonist known as Golo in an interview with the Central News Agency. "Working, investing, succeeding, claiming independence and enjoying life seem to represent the attitudes of most Taiwanese people."

In his book "Made in Taiwan" published in 2001, Golo paints a humorous and incisive picture of Taiwan through its lively night markets, ubiquitous convenience stores, and people's obsession with karaoke.
His memories of Taiwan from his visit back then are all positive, he says, but he did find some surprises.

"I was shocked by the quantity of motorcycles in Taipei, but Taiwanese people's hospitality and kindness impressed me most, " he said. "So I was surprised that there were not many foreign tourists in Taiwan."

Born in Bayonne in southern France and a resident of Egypt for the past 15 years, Golo has traveled all over the world. He said that these multicultural experiences "are really an advantage in my drawing. Contacts with people from different cultures warrant an open-minded vision."

Golo, who once worked for a news agency in Egypt as a caricaturist, incorporates his social observations in his illustrations. In his eyes, "Taipei is a modern city, but what is good is that it is not just a copy of other occidental cities."

Golo is in Taiwan for a month at the invitation of Le Pigeonnier, a French publisher, to coincide with the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE). He is promoting "Made in Taiwan, " and collecting information and observations for a second "Made in Taiwan" book of cartoons.
The TIBE, considered to be the largest book fair in Asia, is being held from Feb. 13-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center. Golo will meet his readers at a special event Feb. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Okinawa rape case sparks resentment
A U.S. Marine who allegedly raped a 14-year-old Okinawa girl was turned over to prosecutors Tuesday in a case that has prompted government officials to voice outrage and warn the incident could affect the Japan-U.S. alliance and the reorganization of U.S. bases in the prefecture.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Abortion, police in hospital.
Seven law enforcement agents entered a hospital in Naples Tuesday to quarantine a fetus from an alleged illegal abortion operation. The current law allows abortions until the 90th day of pregnancy and terminations after this point when the mother's health is at risk or when the fetus is deformed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC nomination list to be presented before opening of legislature

TEXT.P: Government spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey said Wednesday that the Executive Yuan will present its list of candidates for the National Communications Commission (NCC) to the seventh Legislative Yuan for confirmation before the legislative session formally begins Feb. 22.

However, Shieh did not divulge if some of the current NCC members will be retained, stressing that the selection of the candidates will be based on consideration of their qualifications. He added that the Cabinet might recruit talent from the academic and industrial sectors to the media watchdog.

The current NCC commissioners were originally scheduled to step down Jan. 31 together with the sixth Legislative Yuan after the Council of Grand Justices ruled last July that the way the NCC was formed violated the Constitution as it infringed upon the power of the administrative branch.

According to an amendment to the NCC Organic Law approved last December, the Cabinet should have presented the nomination list by Jan. 31. However, the plan was upset as the Cabinet led by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung advanced its resignation to Jan. 24, although the Cabinet members were later retained by President Chen Shui-bian.
NCC Chairman Su Yeong-chin said Jan. 31 that the media regulatory body should maintain its normal functions until the new commissioners assume their posts.

Under the amended law, the number of NCC members should be cut to seven from the existing 13 and the candidates should be nominated by the premier rather than being recommended by major political parties in proportion to the number of seats they hold in the legislature, as is the case at present. The term of office is also extended to four years from the original three under the amended law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan ratifies two U.N. human rights treaties

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan ratified two U.N. human rights treaties Wednesday, 31 years after signing them while the Republic of China in Taiwan was still a member of the United Nations.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said after his Cabinet ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR) that once the domestic ratification process is completed, including the legislature's approval and the president's signature, the ratification document will be sent to the U.N. secretary-general for depositing.

However, Chang said it will be a tough challenge to persuade the top U.N. executive official to take over the ratification instrument to allow Taiwan to complete the entire process of adopting the treaties given that the ROC is no longer a U.N. member.
The U.N. gave the China seat to the People's Republic of China at the expense of Taiwan in 1971.
Despite the challenge, the premier instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to still seek completion of the ratification process "based on the general international political climate."
Under normal circumstances, the covenants come into force for the state ratifying them three months after the date of deposit with the U.N.

The ROC government did not complete the domestic ratification process after signing the two covenants in 1967 because of the sea change in the international situation that led to the 1971 transfer of the ROC's seat in the United Nations to China.
Ratifying these treaties now would be acting in accordance with President Chen Shui-bian's call for Taiwan to become a part of the international human rights community, Chang said.

Chang indicated that President Chen has continually called on the Cabinet to urge the legislature to ratify the International Bill of Human Rights, which contains the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the two treaties, to allow it to serve as the formal legal basis of human rights in Taiwan.

"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs' taking active efforts to push for the treaties' ratification is of great meaning in demonstrating Taiwan's concrete efforts to protect human rights and to fulfill the duty as a member of the international community, " Chang said.

As the ratification has to happen at the same time when a draft bill regulating the treaties' implementation is passed at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said, they will be delivered together to the legislature for review. All relevant government agencies will be expected to actively communicate with political parties to seek the bill and the treaties' passage.

The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, created in 1966 and entered into force on March 23, 1976, recognizes the basic right of all individuals in the world to freedom, justice and peace. It condemns slavery, genocide, torture, cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment, and capital punishment for pregnant women or persons below 18 years of age.

The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights is a multilateral treaty which was adopted by the U.N. General Assembly on Dec. 16, 1966, and went into effect from Jan. 3, 1976. It recognizes that all people have the right to freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development. It also recognizes the right to establish trade unions and go on strike.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 crewmen rescued from gravel barge in rough seas

TEXT.P: Coast Guard Administration (CGA) officials in northeastern Taiwan rescued seven Taiwanese and five Myanmarese crewmen from their stricken sand and gravel barge caught in rough seas off Hualien harbor early Wednesday.

The barge, the Hsiang Jung No. 102, left Hualien a day earlier carrying 8,600 metric tons of gravel on its way to meet with its mother ship, the Hai Peng No. 8. About two nautical miles from the harbor, the barge lost power and began to drift, according to CGA officials.
After the crew lowered the anchor, the barge began to take on water in rough seas at dusk and was in danger of sinking.
Upon receiving its distress signal, the CGA's Hualien office dispatched three boats to the scene, but they were unable to get close to the barge because the sea was too rough.
CGA workers had to throw lifesavers to the barge, coax the 12 crewmen to jump into the freezing water, and pull them up one by one to safety. The rescue mission took about two hours.
Three of the crewmen suffered minor injuries, while some of the others had signs of hypothermia. They were quartered at a lodge in Hualien port.

DOC.HEADLINE: Professors at Taiwan's top university awarded for dedication

TEXT.P: A professor who quietly paid poor students' tuition for 10 years was among eight instructors from the prestigious National Taiwan University (NTU) awarded Wednesday for going above and beyond their call of duty to help young people.
The eight professors were praised as the "best NTU tutors" for the special care they showed their students, at a ceremony where a book about their efforts was also released.

Among the eight -- selected from among 56 lecturers recommended by all NTU graduate institutes and departments -- was Chang Wen-liang, a professor with the university's Department of Bioenvironmental Systems Engineering, who was praised for his long devotion to taking care of students, including paying tuitions for financially-strained ones.
For more than 10 years, Chang quietly paid the tuitions for students whose family could not afford to pay, enabling them to complete their studies.

One of his techniques in ensuring no student fell through the cracks, was what he calls "one-on-one challenge" in which he would challenge his students who are about to flunk his classes to table tennis matches. If the students beat him, they pass.
On Wednesday, he advised teachers, particularly tutors, to be more tolerant and understanding of today's students. He said they are under greater social pressure than their predecessors.
Another professor recognized was Chen Tsung-fu, who teaches at NTU's law school.

Last year, after learning that the student had not attended school for more than one month as a result of a burn, which led to an amputation of his leg, Chen volunteered to tutor the student at his home for several months. Afterwards, the student passed the tests to enter NTU's graduate school of law and passed the national lawyer examination as a top scorer.
Speaking at the ceremony, NTU President Lee Si-chen expressed hope that the professors can serve as examples to other lecturers.
Lee encouraged all NTU lecturers to pay closer attention to and show greater care for their students, in addition to simplifying their teaching methods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Metal center to help electronic and auto parts industries transform

TEXT.P: The Metal Industries Research and Development Center (MIRDC), a non-profit organization, plans to help Taiwan's electronic and auto parts industries transform into value-added businesses, manufacturing novel materials instead of depending on imports, the organization announced Wednesday.

Co-operating with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the MIRDC said that it has already fostered two novel industries -- "hyperfine pipeline material" and "roll bonding material" -- which are expected to "reduce the import figure of materials for the electronic and auto parts industries by NT$1.6 billion (US$5 million) , as well as mobilize the upgrading and transformation of several other traditional industries."

Taiwan's electronic and auto parts industries have to import most of the materials they need as the metal materials they use are mostly complex alloys of which the technology to design and manufacture are in the hands of major American and Japanese companies, the organization said, adding that other materials such as metal fine wire and high purity fine wire and rods also have to be imported.

In order to cut operating costs and help these industries upgrade and transform, the MIRDC has also developed several advanced manufacturing technologies such as continued casting of fine material and roll bonding technology, according to the organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT hopes to convene more legislative meetings to review bills

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is considering convening more legislative floor meetings in addition to the regularly scheduled ones, prior to the March 22 presidential election, a KMT official said Wednesday.

Lin Yi-shih, a KMT legislator and executive director of the party's Policy Committee, said the move is aimed at addressing public dissatisfaction over stalled bills in recent years, adding that he supports "wasting no time" after the legislature opens its first session on Feb. 22.
In addition to Tuesday and Friday when the legislature regularly holds its floor meetings, other weekdays and "even Saturday could be used to convene extra floor meetings," Lin said.
But the idea still awaits approval by the KMT caucus in the legislature, said Lin.
After the conveners of eight legislative committees are elected on March 3, the legislature can start to review bills, Lin said.

Another purpose of the KMT's proposed plan to work overtime now that it holds a large majority in the legislature is to not give the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) any chance to complain about the KMT ahead of the crucial presidential race.
Lin accused the DPP of continuing to try to heap blame on the KMT for the stalled bill review in order to cast the party in a negative light.
For this reason, the KMT will shoulder its responsibility to "convene floor meetings even seven days a week until the end of the March 22 presidential election," Lin said.

Noting that the previous legislature had left a large number of major bills unattended to, he said that the newly elected legislature will need to "give the legislature a new image so that the public will sense the efficiency of the new legislature."

He also said that the party will not rule out the possibility of publishing the attendance rates of KMT caucus members and the number of them speaking in the legislature, and even publish the progress of bills under review.
Lin said this will show that the KMT, with 81 seats in the 113-member legislature, is willing to serve as a "responsible" party.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to attend opening of Tokyo Marathon 2008

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin will head to Japan Thursday to attend the opening of the Tokyo Marathon 2008 slated for Feb. 17, a city government official said Wednesday.

At the invitation of Tokyo Mayor Shintaro Ishihara, Hau will attended the opening of Asia's biggest city marathon, in which some 30,000 athletes from around the world will compete, including two recommended by the Taipei city government.
In addition to attending the event, Hau will also study Tokyo's Super Dike Project, a major levee system that can withstand earthquakes as well as floods.
"Tokyo's super levee construction plan could serve as a reference in helping the Taipei city government to resolve flooding problems in Beitou and on Shezidao," Hau said.
He is scheduled to return home Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA honors award-winning Web site designers

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) held a news conference Tuesday to honor designers of a new Web site for winning prizes at an international competition in San Francisco in January, and to celebrate the success of an incubation program set up by the MOEA.

The competition, called DEMO '08, is an annual conference that serves as a launch platform for new products, technology and Web sites. It is held twice a year, with one around February and the other in September. This year's first competition was held from Jan. 28-30.

The competition is organized by the International Data Group, the world's leading technology media, research, and event company, now in its 18th year. Famous online service companies such as Google and the Skype Group, as well as Trend Micro Taiwan, an anti-virus software company, have all made presentations for their products at the competition in the past.

According to an MOEA official, the award-winning Web site, Atlaspost, won DEMOgod Award--the jury's favorite--along with other 10 projects from foreign teams. The Web site is an innovative map-based social network that lets users network on a global map.

Atlaspost also won the People's Choice Award, which was voted on by over 500 venture companies and more than 100 international media organizations. The award was given to a non-American team for the first time.
The Web site was established last April by brothers Jerry and Andy Kuo and has over 150,000 visitors per day. Their awards have paved the way for raising capital in the future, the official said.
The designers said the capital will be used to promote the Web site's overseas market, with numbers of members at the end of this year projected at 200,000 in Taiwan and 500,000 in the United States.
The team was among 12 Taiwanese Web site design groups that took part in DEMO '08. It was the first time Taiwan had sent a delegation to DEMO.

These groups are under an incubation program on Web 2.0, or next generation network, a trend in which reciprocity between Web site providers and users is emphasized. The MOEA commissioned the Institute for Information Industry to assist in the incubation program.

A total of 77 teams were selected from among nearly 700 applications this year to give presentations at the competition, including two Taiwanese teams representing Atlaspost and Citiport, and DEMOgods awards were given to the outstanding presentations. Taiwan was the only Asian country with teams selected to give presentations, indicating the success of the incubation program, the official said.
The official said other Taiwanese teams such as Webi, VooEasy and Globeme also won high evaluation from the jury and might win the chance to give presentations at the DEMOfall '08 in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preferential measure aims to lure traditional businesses back home

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday the prolongation of a preferential measure to help promote a three-year renovation plan for Taiwan's industrial zones to help persuade Taiwan traditional businesses that have invested overseas to return home, according to Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Chen Chao-yih.

In line with the prolonged preferential measure, the Executive Yuan will increase the level of available funds to about NT$20 billion (US$635 million) to help carry out the plan until Dec. 31 this year, Chen told a news conference after an Executive Yuan weekly meeting.

Along with about NT$10 billion in funding left over from the first stage, the Executive Yuan will earmark a total of NT$11.7 billion over the coming two decades, or NT$600 million every year, to reach the NT$20 billion level, Chen explained.

The second-phase preferential measure is expected to attract NT$100 billion worth of investment capital and generate tax revenue of some NT$1.8 billion per year for the national coffers, according to Chen.

The preferential measure allows companies to rent land free of charge in Taiwan's industrial zones for the first two years and offers different levels of discount on rentals starting from the third year.
"The measure will be very helpful in wooing overseas Taiwanese enterprises -- most of which are traditional businesses -- to come back and invest in the domestic market," Chen said.

Concerning the industrial zones renewal plan, Chen said that such investment by returning Taiwanese businessmen through cooperation with the central and local governments will also help achieve the aim.
"The IDB will select two industrial zones in the initial stage to gradually implement the renovation plan through 2010," Chen said.

According to the IDB chief, of the 61 industrial zones administered by his bureau, 51 have been established for more than 20 years and most of them lack sufficient infrastructure and day-to-day conveniences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fire will not hold back Cloud Gate: founder

TEXT.P: Lin Hwai-min, founder and artistic director of Taiwan's celebrated Cloud Gate Dance Theater, said Wednesday that although Monday's fire destroyed its rehearsal studio, the group will not allow the tragedy to hold it back.
Lin stressed that the 35-year-old Cloud Gate Dance will rise from the ashes to "stage a comeback" and that the company will not delay the year's tour schedule.
A fire destroyed the 1,324 square-meter rehearsal studio, costumes, props and production archives of the world-famous dance theater early Monday morning, causing "immeasurable losses."
Lin shared his favorite tea -- and the story behind its creation -- with reporters Wednesday afternoon while introducing the organization's domestic and foreign tour schedule in 2008.

Taitea No. 18, also known as the "Red Jade, " is a kind of tea grown by Nantou County's Yuchih Township, located in middle of Taiwan and a disaster area suffered from the September 21 Earthquake in 1999.

"People in Yuchih Township came through grief and applied their wisdom and efforts to develop their own tea industry with local features. That is something worth emulating by the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre," Lin said.
Lin also mentioned that he happened to find and recover masks used in the organization's 20 anniversary repertoire "Nine Songs, " from the fire scene.
"Everybody was astonished seeing these masks intact as the box holding them was destroyed, " he said, adding that "these masks will continue to fly on the stage."

Since the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre is slated for a series of performances in the United States and Europe starting in April, Lin said the most urgent matter is to find a place to rehearse their new work.

"We are lucky to be allowed to rehearse in places provided by the Taipei National University of the Arts and in the Shih-ming Hall of the Taiwan Cement Building, " Lin said, adding that "we still need to find a permanent studio for the long term."
Lin said that he hopes to locate a suitable place before March.

Sympathy has been expressed from all circles of Taiwanese society since the fire, including presidential candidates, Frank Hsieh and Ma Ying-jeou, Taipei Mayor Hau lung-bin, Taipei Country Magistrate Chou His-wei, as well as Hao Ming- yi, chairman of the Locus publishing Company, and Jimmy Lia, Taiwan's famous illustrator.

Wang Touh, chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs, was dispatched by President Chen Shui-bian to provide assistance to this "national treasure" of Taiwan. Wang promised to help the Cloud Gate find new rehearsal studio and suggested establishing a disaster relief fund for art groups.

The world-famous dance organization, know for blending Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility, was founded in 1973. Among its best known works are "Nine Songs, "Moon Water" and the "Cursive" trilogy inspired by Chinese brush calligraphy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two authors awarded with TIBE Prize

TEXT.P: Two local authors were awarded at the opening ceremony of the Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) Wednesday for their contributions to Taiwanese literature.

Prime Minister Chang Chun-hsiung presided over the TIBE opening ceremony held at the Taipei World Trade Center and awarded the TIBE Prize to Zhang Yin-tai and Chiang Hsun, who will receive NT$200,000 (US$6,273) and NT$100,000, respectively for their publishers.

Chan said in his opening remarks at the ceremony that the TIBE "will not only create business opportunities and broaden the vision of Taiwanese but will also encourage Taiwanese publishers to play a more important role in the world."
Zhang Yin-tai was awarded in the category of fiction for her mystery story which inspires a passion for the nature in its readers and which features a bear able to write.
Chiang Hsun, a well-known writer in the field of esthetics, was awarded in the non-fiction category. His book, titled "On Solitude," explores six different types of solitude in modern society.

The TIBE Prize, the first of its kind in the TIBE, is designed to "encourage Taiwanese publishers and authors and to promote Taiwanese literature on the international market," said TIBE Board Chairman Lin Tsai-chueh, who expressed hope that the prize will become a focus of the annual exhibition, like the prizes awarded at other major book fairs in Frankfurt, Leipzig and Bologna.
The 16th annual TIBE is being held from Feb. 13-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to set up calligraphy hall

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government in central Taiwan plans to establish a calligraphy hall by the middle of the year to promote the ancient Chinese art, a county official said Wednesday.

The hall will serve as a venue for calligraphy exhibitions and for workshops designed to help local residents gain a better understanding of the art, said Patrick T.F. Lin, director of the county's Cultural Affairs Bureau.
The hall will be set up inside the Wenkai Academy, which was inaugurated in the county's Lukang township in 1824, according to Lin.
The hall plan came after the county government held a recent exhibition of calligraphy collected by a local calligrapher, Lin explained.
Following the conclusion of the exhibition, the calligrapher decided to donate the works to the bureau in the hope that the bureau could find a permanent place to display them, Lin noted.
Lin added that many of the county's renowned calligraphers came from Lukang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Iranian publisher commends Taiwan's readers at book fair

TEXT.P: An Iranian publisher of the only Middle Eastern publishing company taking part in the 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition commended Taiwan's readers Wednesday as "educated and civilized people", saying they are very interested in Iranian books.

Speaking on the first day of the book fair, Farideh Khalatbaree, chairman and managing director of Shabaviz Publishing Company, said when Taiwanese see the books from Iran, "they are shouting and screaming and I can see their excitement."

Although the books, all of which are illustrations for children, are written in Farsi, the ancient Persian language widely spoken in Iran, Afghanistan, Tajikistan, and the Pamir Mountain region, 4,000 titles displayed by the Shabaviz received great attention from industry professionals on the first day of the fair.

Farideh believes that Iranian publications can introduce Taiwanese readers to a different culture. So far three Taiwan's publishers, including the Joy Enterprises Organization, have published Chinese version books of the Shabaviz Publishing Company.
Despite facing great competition with 360 foreign publishers as well as 332 local publishing houses, Farideh said confidently that "I have good things to offer."
"We publish children's books, and we think from children's (perspective)," she stressed.

The is the third year for the Shabaviz Publishing Company to participate in the Taipei International Book Exhibition. Farideh said she hopes that through frequent interactions with Taiwan's readers and publishers from the region, more and more Taiwanese readers will appreciate the beauty and value of Iranian publications.

The 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition opened Wednesday at the Taipei World Trade Center and is expected to attract over 400, 000 visitors from around the world during its six-day run until Feb. 18.
According to the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, the organizer, the first day of the exhibition is reserved for book industry professionals, with the remaining five days open to the public.
Australia is the theme country of this year's fair and the Australia pavilion displays some 1,000 titles by 25 publishers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu incurs NT$100 million aquaculture losses from cold spells

TEXT.P: The recent series of cold fronts that have swept Taiwan have caused a massive fish die-off in Penghu County, resulting in losses of nearly NT$100 million for the aquaculture industry in the outlying island county, a county official said Wednesday.

Numerous fish and fry -- apart from some freeze-resistant species -- cultivated in net-cage fish farms around the county perished as a result of the cold. "The damage is more serious than we expected, " said Cheng Ming-yuan, chief of the county's Agriculture and Fisheries Bureau.
Cobia, one of the most important species reared in the county because of its high economic value, suffered the most severe damage, Cheng said.

While the dead fish can still be eaten, the bureau has been in contact with the frozen seafood industry to have the dead fish quickly frozen and sent to Taiwan proper for further processing, Cheng noted.
He added that the bureau is also making all-out efforts to rescue other at-risk fish and deal with the aftermath in order to reduce losses.

Cheng made the report while accompanying Legislator Lin Bing-kun, officials of the Council of Agriculture's Fisheries Agency and the chief of a local fishermen's association on an inspection tour of Hsiyu township, the worst- affected area of the county.

He also suggested that the Fisheries Agency raise the maximum amount of compensation for damage caused by natural disaster from NT$150,000 to NT$500,000 and earmark an additional NT$18 million to subsidize fishermen to buy fry so they can continue their business.

Also expressing his discontent with existing compensation regulations, Lin said that as fishery information such as stock levels and prices are listed and made public, the Fisheries Agency should provide compensation for fishermen based on the listing information rather than using households or acreages as a basis for compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fish breeders in Penghu sustain losses due to cold weather

TEXT.P: Cobia fish farmers in outlying Penghu County located off southwestern Taiwan, have sustained huge losses since the country came under the influence of cold weather brought by a succession of cold fronts.

According to a report issued Wednesday by the Council of Agriculture (COA) on agricultural losses caused by the low temperatures, 28.8 hectares of offshore aquaculture pens for cobia breeding reported losses valued at NT$77.31 million (US$2.4 million).

Since the Central Weather Bureau issued a warning against low temperatures last Tuesday, the country has been under the influence of a cold air mass that has brought coastal temperatures in the region to as low as 10 degrees Celsius, according to a meteorologist at the bureau.
Cobia is one of the major fish bred in offshore cages along Penghu's coastlines due to the high prices it commands.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC announces campaign subsidies for DPP and KMT

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Wednesday that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will be eligible to receive a campaign subsidy of more than NT$180 million (US$5.62 million) , while the main opposition Kuomintang will be eligible to receive a subsidy of more than NT$250 million.

The CEC noted that the Public Officials Election and Recall Law stipulates that the nation will provide campaign subsidies to political parties every year based on the results of the latest legislative elections. The latest elections took place Jan. 12 this year.

Political parties managing to garner more than five percent of the votes cast in the legislative elections are eligible to receive subsides every year during the current legislature, which runs from Feb. 1, 2008 through Jan. 31, 2012.
Out of the 12 political parties that took part in the legislative elections this year, only the DPP and the KMT received more than five percent of the votes cast, the CEC said.
The KMT garnered 5,010,801 votes, which translate to NT$250,540,050, while the DPP garnered 3,610,106 votes and will receive NT$180,505,300.
The KMT won 81 seats in the 113-member legislature, compared with 27 seats for the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Container art exhibition from southern Taiwan to tour the world

TEXT.P: An exhibition of container art from the southern port city of Kaohsiung will begin its world tour in April, with the Port of Genoa in northern Italy being the tour's first stop, a spokesman for the Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts said Wednesday.

It is the first time that the biennial Kaohsiung International Container Arts Festival will tour the world, the spokesman said. The event made its debut in 2001 and the current edition was inaugurated last December, taking "Sustainable Cosmopolis Eco-container Art Project" as its theme.

The current exhibition showcases the creations of more than 20 artists from eight countries, taking previously used shipping containers as creative materials for works touching on ecology, global warming and environmental protection.
The museum hopes to encourage international dialogue and invites the participation of other countries concerned with issues related to ecology, the spokesman said.

The museum plans to invite young artists to design containers to promote the 2009 World Games, to be held in the city next year. These container arts will travel with others currently being exhibited in the city to seaports around the world.

According to the spokesman, the Yang Ming Marine Corp. headquartered in Keelung City in southern Taiwan will sponsor the exhibition's world tour. But he added that exhibition period in Italy and the second leg of the tour is yet to be decided.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan draws attention in Tokyo's nanotechnology exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/08 21:04:42 (By Mike Chang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has drawn widespread attention from other countries as it showcases the results of years of nanotechnology research and applications in an international nanotechnology exhibition and conference that opened Wednesday in Tokyo, Japan.
The exhibition, now in its seventh year and is the largest event of its kind, will run through Feb. 15.

Each year, Taiwan mainly sends its research institutes that are involved in a national nanotechnology program to participate in the event, said Soong Ching- tan, chief executive officer of Taiwan's national nanotechnology program.
This year, Taiwanese participants also include government agencies, universities, and companies.
And the 25-booth theme hall Taiwan set up for this year's event is a relatively large number compared with those set up by the other 22 countries, which took part in the 520-booth exhibition.
Nanotechnology attempts to change structures at the atomic level and could assist industries to make new and better products as well as avoid animal testing.
Scientists around the world are trying to do research into how to apply the technology for commercial use in various fields, including the cosmetics, pharmaceutical and environmental industries.

This year, Taiwan's hall stands near that of the United Kingdom, Germany, Sweden, and South Korea, offering Taiwan exhibitors a good opportunity to introduce to them Taiwan's latest research results in the field and to learn about these countries' developments, Soong noted.
In addition, Taiwan will look for opportunities to establish exchanges and collaboration with many countries at the exhibition, Soong added.

According to Soong, Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) has greatly assisted Taiwan's traditional industry and opto-electronics industry to develop value-added services through the application of nanotechnology.
Meanwhile, Soong pointed out that the Taiwan government has begun to implement a six-year nanotechnology program in 2003, which he said has achieved fruitful results.

For her part, Su Tsung-tsan, head of the ITRI's Nanotechnology Research Center, said that at the exhibition, Taiwan is displaying the results of its efforts to apply nanotechnology to daily life in the hope that it can get a share of the Japanese market.

Su noted that Taiwan's efforts to industrialize nanotechnology has won global recognition and that the exhibition will further help other countries understand Taiwan's basic research efforts in the field.

Su added that the national program has effectively boosted the research and development of nanotechnology in Taiwan, citing as examples a rising number of research papers published by Taiwanese scholars on the new technology over the years and an increasing amount of investment made by Taiwanese companies in the technology.

Wu Tzong-ming, a professor of National Chung Hsing University who introduces Taiwan's nanotechnology training program at the exhibition, said that Taiwan has a good model of educating young students about nanotechnology, which only developed within the past few years.

Exhibitors from Japan, South Korea, and Thailand have all expressed strong interest in Taiwan's educational program that have successfully raised primary and junior high school students' awareness of nanotechnology, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of outbound Taiwanese during Chinese New Year holiday down

TEXT.P: The number of outbound Taiwanese passengers during this year's Chinese New Year holiday was down by an average of between 10 percent and 15 percent compared with last year, the National Immigration Agency (NIA) said Wednesday.

According to NIA statistics, the number of people entering and leaving Taiwan totaled 385,829 during the Feb. 6-11 Chinese New Year holiday this year, with the number of people leaving Taiwan during the period totaling 193,223.

During the last Chinese New Year, which ran from Feb. 17-25, the number of people leaving and entering Taiwan totaled 403,187, with the number leaving Taiwan totaling 240,248. That translates to nearly 10,000 fewer outbound passengers per day during this year's holiday.

Tourism and aviation operators attributed the decrease mainly to the weather, noting that major tourism destinations for Taiwanese in the past -- such as China, Japan and South Korea -- were suffering cold spells, with China struck by its worst snowstorms in years.

Nearly 10,000 people who had planned to travel overseas for sightseeing canceled their trips. This, coupled with family members of China-based Taiwanese businessmen who dropped plans to travel to China, also contributed to the decrease.
The fact that the new school semester opened right after the holiday, along with the shorter length of this year's holiday, also dampened many people's interest in making a family trip.
Moreover, the performance of the stock market in January was dismal, causing still more people to cancel their travel plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli vocalist to perform in Taiwan for charity

TEXT.P: Israeli vocalist David D'or is slated to perform in Taiwan Feb. 28 in support of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation's efforts to address global warming, announced Raphael Gamzou, head of Israeli mission in Taiwan.

Noting that the concert symbolizes good relations between Israel and Taiwan, Gamzou said that he believes "Tzu Chi's work, volunteers and international networking deserve greater international exposure for their efforts on behalf of the Earth and humanity alike."
Helping people suffering from the effects of global warming and urging them to reduce CO2 emissions are the main focuses of the organization's environmental appeals.
David D'or previously visited Taiwan in November 2006 and September 2007 for charity benefit performances in support of the Tzu Chi foundation.

This year, Gazmou said, the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei decided to hold the concert at the Performing Art Center in the northern Hsinchu city saying, "Sisters and brothers of Tzu Chi, and other people from other cities should enjoy David's music and vocal achievement."
The event is co-organized by the Hsinchu based Accton Technology Corporation, the Hsinchu Science Park, Industrial Technology Research Institute and two local universities.
Applauding the organization for its efforts, Tzu-pao Yang, Deputy Minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, promised to invite foreign diplomats in Taiwan to join in the event.

"I am very happy to see a foreign diplomat in Taiwan (Raphael Gamzou) working to bring the most accomplished singer of his nation to perform in Taiwan, " Yang stressed, adding that the event reveals new "opportunities for international cooperation."
In addition to the concert in Hsinchu, D'Or and the musicians are scheduled to meet with Master Chen Yen in Hualien and to give three concerts especially for Tzu Chi commissioners and volunteers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier calls for creating central anti-corruption bureau soon

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung called Wednesday for a central government-level anti- corruption unit to be set up soon in order to effectively wipe out graft and build clean and efficient governance in Taiwan.

Chang made the call during the weekly Cabinet meeting, in which the Executive Yuan approved a package of draft amendments, including one to set up an anti- corruption bureau under the Ministry of Justice.

"The public and all political parties are keen to see an anti-corruption bureau established in the central government, as several high-profile corruption scandals which occurred in recent years have seriously tainted the government's image and its credibility," Chang said.

The premier expressed hope that the newly elected Legislative Yuan could pass the draft amendment concerning setting up the central anti-corruption bureau as soon as possible after it opens its first session later this month.
According to Chang, similar bills failed to clear the legislative floors in 2000, 2002 and 2005, due to the adjournment of the legislative sessions.

Combating corruption is one the major concerns for Taiwan's voters in this election year, with presidential candidates of both the ruling and opposition camps proclaiming that they will try to root out graft if elected in the March 22 race.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Cheng Kung University to hold seminar on innovation

TEXT.P: The Institute of Innovation and Advanced Studies (IIAS) of National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in southern city of Tainan will hold two workshops on innovative technologies Feb. 18, with the participation of several world-famous scientists.

According to a press release of the IIAS, Aaron Ciechanover, the 2004 Nobel laureate in chemistry; Britton Chance, a member of U.S. National Academy of Sciences and Ma Tso-Pin, a member of U.S. National Academy of Engineering and a pioneer of CMOS integrated circuits, have been invited to attend the workshops.

Tzeng Yonhua, who heads the IIAS, noted that the workshop on innovative technologies will focus on biomedical, alternative energy and nanotechnology, while the other workshop will focus on simulation-based engineering and science.

On the sidelines of the three-day workshops, the NCKU will also invite some 200 students from major senior high schools in Taiwan to participate in a talk with Ciechanover Feb. 20 at NCKU Hospital in hopes of contributing to advanced education on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic air travel registers 15 year record low

TEXT.P: The number of domestic air traffic passengers dropped to a 15-year low last year, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Wednesday.
The MOTC statistics came on the heels of several domestic airlines suffering financial crises due to fierce competition from the island's first high-speed rail system.
According to the MOTC, passengers made a total of 12.71 million trips via domestic flights last year, a 26.8 decrease in passenger travel from the 2006 level, the equivalent of 4.65 million trips.
A MOTC official suggested that the Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) is the main reason for the loss of air passengers traffic.

The 345 km-long rail system links Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south, the two largest cities in Taiwan, shortening travel time by rail from the original four-and-a-half hours to 90 minutes.
Despite offering discounts, several domestic airlines have announced since last May that they will retreat from some routes to seek other opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors want election win of KMT legislator-elect annulled
DOC.DATELINE: Miaoli, northern Taiwan, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/08 21:49:37 (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors Office in Miaoli filed a legal action Wednesday, seeking to annul the election win of Lee Yi-ting, a legislator-elect of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) from Miaoli County, on charges of vote-buying.

The civil lawsuit was instituted three weeks after prosecutors indicted Lee and two of his campaign assistants -- Lai Yi-ching and Lin Yu-hua -- and sought a sentence of two years in prison, plus a fine of NT$2 million (US$63,220), for each of the trio.
Lee became the first legislator-elect from the Jan. 12 elections to be prosecuted for vote-buying and faces the possible annulment of his election.

According to the prosecutors, Lee, who was general secretary of the Miaoli County Farmers' Association before he ran in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, donated cash and goods to temples and civil organizations in Miaoli County between June and October 2007 through Lai and Lin, and sought their votes in the elections.
The prosecutors claimed that Lee's vote-buying behavior violated the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, although he did not hand the donations to the recipients directly.
Lee professed innocence, saying that the donations were made by his campaign aides without his knowledge or consent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax revenue for January up 16.3% over last year

TEXT.P: National net tax revenues for January reached NT$124.5 billion (US$3.93 billion) , an increase of NT$17.5 billion or 16.3 percent over last January, an official of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Wednesday.

Hsu Juei-lin, deputy director-general of the MOF's Department of Statistics, pointed out that although overall tax revenues increased, the revenues of securities transactions tax and land increment tax decreased.
Hsu said land increment tax revenues last month were down by 16.6 percent over last January, owing to number of land transactions cases decreasing by seven percent.

The revenue from securities transactions tax for January accounted for NT$10.2 billion, a decrease of NT$300 million or 2.5 percent compared with the same period last year, Hsu said, adding that the decreases were due to the impact of falling international stock markets.
Hsu noted that income tax revenues for the last month reached NT$28.8 billion, an increase of NT$9.1 billion or 45.9 percent, which is the highest rate of increase since last January.
Of the income tax, revenues from business income taxes were NT$3.1 billion, up NT$3.4 billion, while individual income taxes reached NT$25.8 billion, increasing NT$5.7 billion or 28.3 percent.
In addition, business tax revenues accounted for NT$46.9 billion, enjoying an increase of NT$10.3 billion or 28 percent over last January's figure, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exam to be held in June to recruit employees for MOEA organizations

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has decided to sponsor a joint examination in mid-June to recruit employees for five state-run companies that are subordinate to the ministry, an MOEA official in charge of personnel affairs said Wednesday.
The five companies are Taiwan Power Co.; CPC Corp., Taiwan; Taiwan Shipbuilding Corp.; Aerospace Industrial Development Corp.; and Taiwan Water Corp., the official said.
The MOEA plans to recruit at least 800 employees at a starting salary of NT$36,000 (US$1,136.58) per month for most of the positions, the official added.

The MOEA will formally announce the examination in the country's major newspapers in mid-March and has decided to also accept online registration for the test beginning in late March, the official said.

The written exam will be held simultaneously in Taipei, northern Taiwan; Taichung, central Taiwan; and Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, in mid-June. Those who gain admission to the organizations must file report-for-duty registrations in mid-October.
People interested in taking the exam can visit the MOEA's Web site at http: //www.moea.gov.tw/ for more information, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former lawmaker seeks to invalidate rival's election

TEXT.P: A former legislator who lost by a slim margin in the Jan. 12 legislative elections filed a suit against his winning rival Wednesday to invalidate his electoral victory.

Wu Cherng-dean, a two-time legislator of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) who lost in his re-election bid to Chen Fu-hai by a mere 74 votes, said he decided to take the legal action after the Kinmen Prosecutors Office indicted Chen on charges of alleged vote-buying during the campaign period.
Chen protested that he had engaged in a clean campaign and said that his indictment was only a result of different views on the part of the prosecutors.
"I'm sure that justice will vindicate me," Chen affirmed.
In a crowded field of six, Chen defeated his closest rival, Wu, 9,912 against 9,838 votes.
Chen became the only independent in the 113-member legislature. The KMT won 81 seats, compared with 27 seats taken by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Chen attributed his victory to his experience as a representative of villages and townships, as a county councilor and as a Kinhu township head, which he said has informed him of the needs of the grassroot community.

According to the revised Public Officials Election and Recall law, Wu can request a vote recount within seven days of the election if the gap between him and his rival falls within 0.3 percent of the total number of valid votes.
But Wu decided against requesting a recount and instead sought to invalidate the results based on Chen's corruption indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Travelers advised to be on guard against measles epidemic in Japan

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH), alerted by a measles epidemic in Japan, advised travelers Wednesday not to take infants under 12 months old to that country, or, if they must, to have their infants inoculated against the disease.

According to Japan's National Institute of Infectious Diseases, reports from hospitals and medical clinics around Japan show that as of Feb. 3 this year, 1,164 people have been infected with measles, mostly in and around Tokyo.
The second largest group was found in Fukuoka Prefecture, followed by a group in Hokkaido.

Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the DOH Center for Disease Control, said they are monitoring the developing epidemic in the neighboring country, but believe that most Taiwanese people above one year of age should enjoy immunity against the disease.

Citing Taiwan's inoculation system, Lin explained that Taiwan began to carry out mandatory inoculation against measles in 1978. Since 1992, all children have been inoculated with two doses of MMR, a combined vaccine for rubella, measles and mumps, he noted.
Lin went on that more than 95 percent of local people under the age of 31 have been inoculated.
In comparison, Lin said Japan has adopted a more "conservative" policy in the inoculation, with people "recommended, " instead "obliged," to be inoculated against measles.
Japan also provided only one shot of MMR until April 2006, Lin said, adding that the practice was widely considered a major factor contributing to the epidemic in eastern Japan last year.
Symptoms of measles include fever, coughing, runny nose and conjunctivitis. Patients are prone to otitis media, pneumonia and encephalitis, according to Lin.

According to the original CDC-recommended immunization schedule for infants in Taiwan, children at or above the age of 12 months should receive a chicken pox vaccine, and those at or above 15 months should receive a MMR vaccine.

On that basis, Lin suggested that parents of infants under one year old not travel with their children to Japan. If they must travel, he advised those with infants above nine months old take one shot of MMR vaccine two weeks before traveling to Japan, to allow the body time to develop immunity.
