DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival to open Feb. 16

TEXT.P: The 2008 Hsinchu International Glass Art Festival will open Feb. 16 and run until April 20, displaying hundreds of glass works by domestic artists and their foreign counterparts from 10 countries.
The biennial event, sponsored by the Hsinchu city government, will take place at the Hsinchu Glass Art Museum. Organizers said the exhibition is expected to attract at least 300,000 visitors.
Hsinchu Mayor Lin Junq-tser told reporters Wednesday that the theme of the festival is "Mermaids Touring the Glass Fairyland," with more than 100 works featuring the motif on display.

In addition to works by renowned glass artists in Taiwan, the festival will show 50 glass masterpieces created by artists from 10 countries, including the United States, Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Australia, Israel, India and Japan.
A "glass art street" in a former air force dependents' village near the Hsinchu Glass Art Museum in Hsinchu Park will remain open throughout the exhibition, according to Lin.
Visitors will have the opportunity to observe the artists work on weekends. They will also have hands-on opportunities to create their own glassworks and take them home.
Hsinchu, which has dubbed itself the "city of culture and science," has organized the biennial event since 1995. The 2006 festival attracted more than 410,000 visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Door may be opened wider for Chinese patients: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government may ease restrictions on the entry of Chinese citizens for medical purposes, an official of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

According to the official, the government launched an experimental program last July for foreign nationals to apply for medical visas in an effort to speed up the globalization of Taiwan's medical services industry. Chinese citizens are also eligible to apply for such visas on a case-by-case basis.
As of the end of last year, the official said, 50 foreign and seven Chinese passport holders had applied for visas for medical purposes.

The seven Chinese applicants intended to visit Taiwan to receive various kinds of medical treatment, including live liver transplants, joint replacement, cochlear implants and treatment for post-cervical surgery complications and osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, the official said.
So far, only four of the Chinese applicants have actually come to Taiwan, the official said, adding that two have completed medical treatment.
Under current regulations, only Chinese citizens who fall victim to diseases that China cannot treat will be allowed to come to Taiwan for treatment.

Noting that this restriction might have discouraged prospective medical visitors from China, the official said the CEPD will invite representatives from other relevant government agencies, including the Mainland affairs Council and the Department of Health, to discuss the feasibility of canceling or revising this regulation so that more Chinese people will be able to enter Taiwan for medical treatment.

"As China could be a major source of medical visitors to Taiwan, we belive that easing restrictions on Chinese applicants will help facilitate the expansion of Taiwan's medical services industry, " the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EP deputy head calls for opening of WHA to Taiwan reporters
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/13/08 23:53:49 (By P.C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Union should push the World Health Organization (WHO) to allow Taiwanese journalists to cover the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) activities, a European Parliament heavyweight urged Wednesday.

According to a report posted on the online edition of the European Parliament magazine, Edward McMillan-Scott, vice president of the parliament -- the EU's legislative arm, is pushing the EU authority to lobby the WHO to lift its ban on Taiwanese reporters intending to cover the annual WHA meeting and relevant activities slated to open May 19 in Geneva.
Over the past four years, Taiwan reporters have repeatedly been barred from covering the WHA activities. WHA is the WHO's decision-making body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 14, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Essay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of "discovery," charting and "naming" many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1797: British naval forces under Admiral John Jervis and Captain Horatio Nelson defeat the Spanish fleet off Portugal's Cape St. Vincent.
1859: Oregon becomes the 33rd state of the United States.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by a treaty.
1912: Arizona becomes the 48th state of the United States.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the U.S. industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that later becomes International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1939: The German battleship Bismarck is launched.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1956: Soviet President Nikita Khrushchev denounces the policies of Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic adviser to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: The Soviet Union launches its Luna 20 spacecraft to the moon.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on the same basis as Moscow.
1973: Walter Benche Medina, newly-appointed ambassador of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1974: A six-member Jordanian trade mission led by S.A. Matouk, president of the Amman Chamber of Commerce, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1974: Commissioner W. Stanley Cottrill, international secretary of the Salvation Army International Headquarters, leaves Taipei after a three-day visit.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific becomes a territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted Republic of China musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa," or death sentence, against British writer Salman Rushdie for what he deemed to be blasphemy in the author's book "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
1999: Former Nixon White House aide John Ehrlichman dies at the age of 73. He served 18 months in prison for his role in the Watergate cover-up.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of the Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Cor Boonstra, president of Royal Philips Electronics, in recognition of his company's contribution to Taiwan's economic development.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian says that he will visit Beijing and invite mainland Chinese leaders to visit Taipei if he wins the March 18 election.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."
