DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Workplace 'love contracts' frowned upon by most Taiwan workers: survey

TEXT.P: Companies in the United States and Britain are trying to blunt Cupid's arrows by imposing "love contracts" on office love affairs, though the idea appears undesirable among workers in Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released Thursday to mark Valentine's Day.

The survey, conducted by the online employment service provider 1111 Job Bank among 1,403 office workers, revealed that 70.42 percent of respondents oppose the signing of "love contracts," mainly because they think such a move is meaningless and that it is improper to make relationships "contractual".

The "consensual relationship agreements" were first introduced in the United States to protect companies from sexual harassment suits should an office romance end badly. Such agreements have become more and more common in British workplaces in recent years, with approximately one-quarter of U.K. corporations requiring that their staff sign the documents, according to foreign media reports.

In addition to setting the ground rules for office behavior, such agreements also require workers to disclose any romantic relations with colleagues to confirm that the relationship is voluntary, the reports said.
The Taiwan survey found that only 3 percent of respondents work for a company where office affairs are strictly prohibited.
Among respondents who have dated a co-worker, 66.8 percent did not make the affair public because they did not want to become a subject for gossip.
In the event of a breakdown of an office relationship, 56 percent of respondents said they would quit or move to another department to avoid embarrassment.

A total of 51.39 percent of respondents agreed that the neglect of work is the most negative effect of office romances on corporations, and 67 percent admitted that office relationships undermined their job performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan tourism exchange increases in 2007: MOFA

TEXT.P: The greater number of tourists traveling between Taiwan and Japan in 2007 indicates that bilateral exchanges are growing ever closer, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Speaking at the MOFA's regularly scheduled press briefing, Peter Tsai, deputy executive director of the ministry's Committee on Japanese Affairs, said that in 2007 the number of travelers between Taiwan and Japan reached 2.545 million -- 1,165,000 going from Taiwan to Japan, and 1,380,000 passing in the other direction.

Both numbers were up slightly over the 2006 totals, with an additional 5,000 Taiwanese tourists and 170,000 Japanese travelers, respectively, he said, adding that these statistics, which were released by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and Japan National Tourist Organization, are relatively accurate.

"Bilateral exchanges between the two countries are believed to be occurring even more frequently this year, " Tsai said, as by mid-February there have been 13 civil and government groups visiting their counterparts.
Tsai said that among the 8,340,000 travelers and the NT$1 trillion (US$31.6 billion) in tourism income Japan received in 2007, Taiwanese tourists alone contributed NT$300 billion.
"Taiwanese tourists are very generous and usually spend a lot because they enjoy the kindness of the Japanese people and appreciate made in Japan products," Tsai said.
He went on to say that the MOFA has extended the visa-free period for Japanese tourists to stay from 30 to 90 days in hopes of attracting more Japanese to visit Taiwan.

Taiwan and Japan are among each other's favorite travel destinations. Citizens of the two countries can travel without visas between the two, and an accord was signed last August for mutual recognition of the driver's license issued by the other's government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 314.73 points, or 4.16 percent, to close at 7,865.28.

Rebounding after two consecutive losing sessions, the bourse opened at 7,711.45 and fluctuated between 7,865.28 and 7,707 during the day's session. A total of 4.32 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$114.64 billion (US$3.62 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground. Machinery and electronics shares advanced by 4.8 percent, the most of any sector. Plastics and chemicals shares rose 4.3 percent, banking and financial shares increased 3.8 percent, paper and pulp issues rose 3.5 percent, foodstuff issues gained 2.5 percent, textile stocks grew 1.7 percent, construction issues were up 1.2 percent and cement stocks advanced 0.6 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,667 to 287, with 301 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan's food safety notification mechanism works well: MOFA

TEXT.P: A recent incident involving contaminated dumplings in Japan has proven that the two countries' food safety notification mechanisms work well, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Peter Tsai, deputy executive director of the ministry's Committee on Japanese Affairs, said that after the food scare involving contaminated dumplings imported from China by Japan's Mitsuke Co. was exposed, Japan's Interchange Association Taipei Office immediately notified the MOFA to inform them that Taiwan may have, in turn, imported the toxic dumplings from Japan.
"Taiwan and Japan have established a very good notification mechanism to ensure the safety of food for both countries' citizens," Tsai said.

Some 48 packages of dumplings from the company in question were imported last October and sold at a food fair in Taipei's SOGO Department. However, these were manufactured at a different time from the problematic dumplings in Japan and no one was reported ill. .
The contaminated food has caused at least 2,000 people in 46 prefectures to fall ill after eating the pesticide-contaminated dumplings from Tianyan Food in China's Hebei Province.
Japan relies on imports for 60 percent of its food supply, with China being the country's largest source of food imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic leaders request chance to speak against U.N. referendums

TEXT.P: Two civic leaders asked for the opportunity to speak out against two referendums on Taiwan's bid for U.N. membership in public debates Thursday, the deadline set by the Central Election Commission (CEC) for such requests.

Wu Jung-yuan, chairman of the little-known Labor Party, and Huang Kuang-kuo, convener of the Democratic Action Alliance, filed an application with the commission for a chance to air their views in opposition to the referendums in five televised debates organized by the CEC between Feb. 27 and March 8.

The two referendums, which will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election, include one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan, and another initiated by the Kuomintang (KMT) on returning to the world body under the nation's official name, the Republic of China, or any other practical names.
Wu and Huang called themselves representatives of an Anti-Referendum- to-U.N. Alliance formed last year by 10 civic groups.

After filing their applications, the two and their followers unfurled banners reading "Oppose referendum on U.N. bid and say no to referendum ballots, " and "Oppose using referendums to disrupt election."

They urged the public not to claim referendum ballots next month, saying that the two referendums are "fake issues" manipulated by the DPP and the KMT in the hope of boosting support for their respective parties in the upcoming election.
Wu said that the referendums have not been accepted by the international community, noting that the United States said the referendum on the U.N. bid is causing unnecessary provocation and tension.
Huang said "political figures have manipulated the referendums for political gains."

"Both Wu and I are ready for the debates, and the DPP and the KMT have to make clear their stance on referendums, " he continued. Huang will represent the opposite views only to the DPP-initiated referendum, while Wu will represent those opposing to both referendums.
The CEC will sponsor five presentations or debates for the referendums, which will be held Feb. 27, March 1, 2, 5 and 8, respectively.

CEC officials have said that the leading initiators of the two referendums will argue in favor of their proposals, while the Legislative Yuan, the Executive Yuan and civic groups may represent the opposite view.

Those who are interested in becoming representatives of the side opposed to the referendum should apply to the CEC before Feb. 14, they said. So far, the Legislative Yuan and the Executive Yuan have not applied to the CEC to represent the opposite view, and the alliance is the only civic group to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to promote globalization of medical services

TEXT.P: The government has set 2008 as a year in which it will promote the globalization of Taiwan's medical services, as the level of its medical care is competitive with that available worldwide, a Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official said Thursday.

"Taiwan's medical industry has tremendous potential given its competitive prices and service quality, " the official said, adding that the island's medical service sector is playing a leading role in Asia.

According to statistics released by Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, during the period 1997-2005, the five-year survival rate following liver transplantation in Taiwan was 90 percent, far outstripping the 60 percent registered in the United States.

In addition, a surgical team from National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) has helped a Vietnamese hospital in completing that country's first successful adult liver transplant from living donor last month, reflecting Taiwan's standard of medical care.

However, "there have been only 50 visa applications with Taiwan's representative offices abroad for medical care in the country since the Cabinet first presented its flagship plan for the globalization of medical services in the second half of last year, " the official said.

To further elevate Taiwan's image of providing a high level of medical care, the CEPD will offer subsidies for the Department of Health (DOH) to publish a book to help local hospitals organize service packages to attract foreign patients.
The DOH is also soliciting support from the Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission to use the cultural centers of Taiwan's representative offices abroad as medical consultation centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-referendum alliance petitions KMT for support

TEXT.P: Members of the "Anti-Referendum-to-U.N. Alliance" headed to the Kuomintang's (KMT's) headquarters in Taipei City Thursday to petition the main opposition party to support their cause.

Carrying banners and placards bearing such slogans as "Boycott the Referendum" and "Vote for Democracy, Replace the Government," the alliance members urged the KMT to show courage by openly opposing the U.N. bid referendums to be held alongside the Mar. 22 presidential election.

On Feb. 1, the Central Election Commission announced that two referendums -- one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the country applying to join the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," and the other launched by the KMT on "The Republic of China" applying to return to the world body -- would be held in tandem with the presidential poll.

In a press statement released Thursday, the alliance pointed out that the KMT has an overwhelming majority in the new legislature, and calling on the party to "not be kidnapped by the DPP's deceptive U.N.-bid referendum trick" and to "uphold the hope of Taiwan's people of living and working in peace."

The alliance urged the KMT to "not succumb to the DPP's spell" and to show wisdom and courage by boycotting the referendums and "casting a ballot for democracy and rescuing the economy for the Taiwan people."

Tu Chien-teh, vice chairman of the KMT's Organization and Development Committee, who greeted the alliance members and accepted their petition, said that the KMT has "heard their voice, " adding that he would ask the party's high-ranking members to issue a clear and definite decision on the referendum after assessing the situation.
Many observers view the DPP's move to hold the U.N.-bid referendum alongside the presidential election as a bid to garner more votes for its candidate, Frank Hsieh.

Tu told the alliance members that KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung met with President Chen Shui-bian shortly after the Jan. 22 legislative elections and expressed to the president his concerns over the referendum issue as well as the importance of the CEC remaining impartial.
Tu echoed the KMT chairman's words, uttered earlier this month, that the KMT is not opposed to the holding of referendums, but rather to "hijacking elections with referendums."

Also earlier this month, KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun said the party was in the process of mapping out countermeasures to the CEC's move to hold the referendums and presidential poll together and that it would make a final decision on the matter before the first session of the new legislature opens Feb. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon, Cardinal Tien Hospital to fund health services for seniors

TEXT.P: The Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho Branch and Taipei Fubon Bank Charitable Foundation are teaming up to provide remote health monitoring services for 60 middle or low-income seniors living alone in the Greater Taipei Region.
According to Interior Ministry figures, there are over 320,000 seniors living alone in Taiwan, with over half of them suffering from ailments that limit their ability to care for themselves.
Many of these seniors pass away alone in their homes without anyone discovering their bodies for several days after they have died, indicating that the country's care system is inadequate.

To help address the problem, the Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho Branch and Taipei Fubon Bank Charitable Foundation have decided to cooperate to fund a remote health monitoring system for poor elderly citizens living alone.
Two communities will be selected under the program, with the homes of 30 low- income seniors in each community to be fitted with medical equipment to monitor their health via the Internet.
Health monitoring equipment will also be set up at two community centers in the selected areas for seniors to receive health checkups.
Under the program, doctors, nurses, nutritionists, physical therapists, social workers and pharmacists will be on hand to provide 24-hour health services to the seniors.
The Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho Branch and the Taipei Fubon Bank Charitable Foundation will provide subsidies to allow the 60 seniors to take part in the program free of charge.
The hospital and foundation said they are making the move in hopes that other businesses will follow suit by offering funds to help provide health monitoring services to elderly people living alone.
Hospital officials said that anyone over 65 years of age living on a low income or suffering from a chronic disease can apply to join the program.
They further said the hospital will assist those who are not selected for the program by finding alternative funding from social welfare organizations.

Teng Shi-hsiung, head of the Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho Branch, said that the program will not only help disadvantaged seniors living alone, it will also be of benefit to seniors living with relatives who work during the day and are unable to care for them.
The health care management program's monitoring system will help these families keep on top of the health condition of their elderly loved ones without having to worry, Teng said.

Those interested in applying to join the program can contact the Cardinal Tien Hospital Yung Ho Branch at (02)-2982-6060, ext. 20755, or visit the hospital's Web site at org.tw/news.act/act970124.htm for an application form.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February rose 406 points to close at 7,897, with 53,700 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 401 points to finish at 7,883, with 3,526 contracts traded, while June futures increased 383 points to close at 7,888, with 46 contract transactions.
September futures moved up 396 points to finish at 7,702, with 43 contract transactions, while December futures rose 375 points to close at 7,661, with three contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 314.73 points Thursday to finish at 7,865.28, with market turnover of NT$114.64 billion (US$3.61 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,491 for February; 7,482 for March; 7,505 for June; 7,306 for September and 7,286 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
February TE futures rose 18.15 points to close at 298, with 5,527 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 18.35 points to finish at 297.45, with 640 contract transactions.

June TE futures increased 19.15 points to close at 294.95, with three contracts traded, while September TE futures gained 11.8 points to finish at 286, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.
February TF futures moved up 40.8 points to close at 1,056.2, with 5,437 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures rose 38.8 points to finish at 1,056, with 731 contracts traded.
June TF futures gained 22.4 points to finish at 1036, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for any other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas travel most wanted Valentine's Day gift: survey

TEXT.P: Traveling overseas with one's lover is the Valentine's gift most desired by large numbers of Taiwan's consumers, but few are actually planning to spend much money celebrating the occasion, according to the results of a survey released Thursday to mark Valentine's Day.

The survey revealed that overseas travel was cited by 31.2 percent of respondents as the Valentine's Day gift they most wished to receive, followed by a date with a dream lover, mentioned by 19.5 percent of respondents, and a romantic dinner, favored by 17 percent of respondents.
However, when asked how they planned to celebrate the day, a majority -- 39 percent -- of respondents said they will simply have an intimate dinner.

While 24.2 percent of respondents will buy something as a gift for their lovers, 18.5 percent will stay home to enjoy time alone with each other. Another 17 percent of respondents said that they will not celebrate in any way.
The survey found that the respondents planned to spend an average of NT$2,050 celebrating Valentine's Day.
By gender, men seem to be more generous than women in terms of Valentine's Day spending, with men planning to spending NT$2,478 on average, compared with the average of NT$1,639 among women.

Compared with 25.2 percent of respondents planning to spend no more than NT$1,000 on Valentine's Day celebration, 18.9 percent plan to spend over NT$3,000 and 9.4 percent plan to celebrate the occasion in creative ways that do not require money.

The survey was conducted Jan. 16-22 among 3,074 consumers by MiniJob.com.tw, an employment brokerage Web site launched by 104 Job Bank to serve small- and medium-sized businesses. It has a margin of error of 1.77 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG It's a sweep for McCain and Obama.
Barack Obama piled up three more commanding wins Tuesday--in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia--establishing the onetime underdog as the front- runner in the Democratic presidential race against Hillary Rodham Clinton . On the Republicn side, Sen. John McCain of Arizona moved closer to clinching the nomination , winning all three contests over former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee and Rep. Ron Paul of Texas. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.012 to close at NT$31.700.
A total of US$1.076 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.705 and fluctuated between NT$31.570 and NT$31.745.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cold-related emergency cases surge at hospitals

TEXT.P: Hospitals in Taiwan have reported a surge in the number of emergency medical cases related to the recent cold, wet weather, which has seen the temperature drop to below 10 degrees Celsius in many parts of the country over the past week.
Officials of the Central Weather Bureau forecast that the mercury will likely remain low until later this week.
Prior to the Lunar New Year holiday, at least five people died due to the cold weather, hospital sources said.
Following the holiday, a number of patients suffering from hypothermia were sent to Mackay Memorial Hospital in the capital, Taipei, one of whom died, a hospital emergency room staffer said.

Kao Wei-feng, a doctor in charge of Taipei Veterans General Hospital's emergency room, said that the hospital received several patients aged between 50 and 60 who had fainted while soaking in hot springs during the cold snap.

To cope with the sudden increase in the number of emergency cases, National Taiwan University Hospital has stepped up its management of the wards at its stroke center and cardiology department, a spokesman for the hospital said.

Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, noted that during the past week, the hospital's emergency room was inundated with patients suffering from heart attack, stroke, asthma, diarrhea or respiratory diseases.
Chang Gung estimated that the number of patients at the hospital's emergency room grew by 10 to 20 percent during this period.

In related news, shelters in Taipei City and Taipei County have reported some 300 visits from homeless people, while a local social welfare foundation said that it has opened nine shelters around Taiwan for homeless people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan office in New York opens job center to help students
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 13 (CNA) 02/14/08 17:48:22 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: A special center aimed at helping Taiwanese students in the United States find jobs was officially opened Wednesday by the Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office(TECO) in New York.

The U.S. Job Orientation Foundation, co-sponsored by Taiwanese entrepreneur Chen Chu-kuei, is the first of its kind set up by one of the seven U.S.-based Taiwan cultural divisions, which are under the Ministry of Education.
The center will initially serve an estimated 5,000 Taiwanese students in the states of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Connecticut.

Chu Yueh-mei, executive commissioner of the foundation, said 22 Taiwanese businesses, including the Crystal Window & Door System, LTD, the Tenren Tea, and the World Journal, have joined the center's program, providing work opportunities to Taiwanese students seeking jobs in the U.S.
"Professionals with a background in accounting, finance, civil engineering, mechanics, information, marketing administration or medicine are in need," she added.

Ethan Kuo, director of the Cultural Division of the Taiwan office in New York, stressed that "the foundation indeed gives those attempting to work in the U.S after graduation a very good platform of finding a job."
Businesses could also benefit by knowing where to go to find talent who know Mandarin Chinese, English and Taiwanese, said Ku Ya-ming, chairman of the Flushing Chinese Business Association.
"This is a win-win situation," Ku stressed.

The Cultural Division suggests those who are interested can obtain more information from its website www.edutwny.org or send inquiries to newyork@edutwny.org, esther.c.cyang@hotmail.com or jeanhf40@yahoo.com. Telephone inquiry is also available at 1-212- 317-7388.
ENDTIEM/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: CSC to forge R&D alliance to boost local steel industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based China Steel Corp. (CSC), in which the government has a stake of more than 20 percent, will push for the establishment of a research and development alliance with local companies to enhance the competitiveness of the country's steel industry, a company spokesman said Thursday.
The announcement comes as Taiwan's steel industry faces strong, low-cost rivals from China, India, and the Southeast Asia, the spokesman said.
To stand out among the competition, Taiwan's steel industry must upgrade its technologies and the quality of their products, the spokesman noted.
In addition, the industry needs to create more added value to differentiate itself from an increasing number of low-cost competitors in the market, the spokesman went on.

According to the spokesman, Taiwan's steel-related industries are supported by many small and medium enterprises, which lack the resources to develop basic research abilities and expand their production scale.
These enterprises do not have the ability to enter the supply chains of international companies or increase their marketing channels, the spokesman said.

As the leading company in the local steel industry, China Steel Corp. -- headquartered in the southern port city of Kaohsiung -- has decided to collaborate with the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Metal Industries Research and Development Center to promote the alliance project, the spokesman pointed out.
The project will focus on developing new products and technologies to boost the production of high-grade steel, he remarked.
Currently, Taiwan produces some 3.5 million metric tons of high-grade steel every year.

China Steel Corp. aims to raise production to over 4.6 million metric tons by 2012, which the company predicts will help increase the production value of Taiwan's steel-related industries by more than NT$300 billion (US$ 9.5 billion) annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Counterfeit sea cucumber reported in hypermarket

TEXT.P: The Consumers Foundation (CF) said Thursday that counterfeit sea cucumber, a popular Chinese delicacy, was reported in traditional marketplaces and even a noted hypermarket.
Foundation officials questioned whether the RT-Mart, the nation's second-largest hypermarket operator, has been involved in cheating consumers, although the latter said it was a victim itself.
CF officials noted that consumers had recently complained to the Taipei County government that they bought counterfeit sea cucumber for NT$460 per kilo in a traditional marketplace.
They then received complaints from consumers that they bought counterfeit sea cucumber from the RT-Mart.
The consumers told the CF officials that they bought the sea cucumber at NT$700 (US$21.87) per kilo from RT-Mart's Chunglun outlet in downtown Taipei.

The officials said genuine sea cucumber normally sells for around NT$1,000 per kilo. The RT-Mart, selling the substandard sea cucumber at a price higher than that sold in the traditional marketplaces, could mislead the consumers into thinking that they were purchasing the genuine product.
The officials said that the RT-Mart "has failed to do its share" to safeguard the quality of its products, and that such dishonesty could make officials subject to imprisonment or fines.
An RT-Mart executive said the company will get to the bottom of the substandard products and compensate the consumers.
The executive condemned the provider of the "kongyaku jelly" sea cucumber, saying that it will no longer do business with the supplier in question.

DOC.HEADLINE: Billiards proposed as must for Taiwan's major athletic games

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Billiards and Snooker Association -- Taiwan's umbrella organization for billiards -- will work to make the game a must-have event at Taiwan's three major athletic games, the top executive of the association said Thursday.

Tu Yung-hui, president of the association, told reporters that a meeting of the association's Board of Directors and the Board of Supervisors earlier this week had reached a consensus that the three billiard sports -- carom, pool and snooker -- should be included in the National Athletic Games, the National College Games and the National High School Athletic Games.
Tu said the association will make a formal request to the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports to realize this goal.
He said that billiards has long been neglected in Taiwan, as all of the athletic events have placed it in the optional category.

Tu also said that his association will hire a carom coach and a snooker coach from abroad to help train Taiwan's billiard players for the 2009 World Games to be held in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

Billiards made its debut at the 2001 World Games in Akita, Japan. The 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung will feature billiards for the third consecutive time. It is expected to draw record crowds to watch the world's best players in action.
Pool enjoys enormous popularity in Taiwan, and quite a few Taiwanese professional pool players, both men and women, have achieved celebrity status by participating in world tournaments.
Carom, pool and snooker are all derived from the same game, but have developed distinct identities, with each having its own rules and world governing body.
Billiards are played in about 150 countries, with the number of registered players estimated at more than 100 million. The games' world tournaments enjoy a broad based, global television audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier confirms defense company establishment

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung confirmed Thursday that a defense company has been established with investment from various government agencies and state-owned corporations, but stressed that it was a private company.

Chang confirmed a local newspaper report about the company named "Taiwan Goal" on the sidelines of a Lunar New Year meeting with China-based Taiwanese business people, but did not elaborate on the company's objectives.

The Chinese-language China Times reported Thursday that Taiwan Goal, charged with integrating local and international military equipment manufacturers and various military services, has been established and that Wu Nai-jen has been named as president.

Also on Thursday, National Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu said that an investment of 45 percent of the initial Taiwan Goal's capital came from the Ministry of National Defense (MND), adding that the MND will hold a press conference Friday to elaborate on the functions of the company.

Wu Nai-jen said in a statement issued Thursday that Taiwan Goal was established as a platform to integrate international military equipment suppliers and competent local companies to work on military system maintenance and components manufacture.

Wu said he took the role as a voluntary president without compensation, adding that he will resign after the next president is inaugurated May 20. He went on to say that Taiwan Goal will not be able to sign any contracts before May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cruise tourist arrivals in 2007 hit nearly five-year high

TEXT.P: The number of tourist arrivals aboard cruise liners calling at Taiwan's international ports hit a nearly five-year high of more than 426,000 last year, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Thursday.
According to the most recent statistics compiled by the MOTC, the 2007 figure marked an increase of about 111,000 over the 2006 level, or a 35.3 percent growth year on year.

MOTC officials predicted that the number for 2008 will further climb as Taiwan's international ports will step up efforts to attract more arrivals. For instance, Hualien Port in eastern Taiwan is making efforts in this regard, they noted.
Last year, Keelung Port in northern Taiwan saw the largest number of 272,000 cruise liner tourist arrivals, or 63.8 percent of the total.
MOTC officials attributed the large growth at Keelung Port to the embarkation of the Super Star Libra -- the leading cruise liner in the Asia-Pacific -- from late June through November last year.
According to Star Cruises officials, the company's cruises are slated to call at Taiwanese ports this summer.

The British-registered Rhapsody of the Seas was the most recent ocean liner to visit Keelung, mooring for half a day Feb. 11 and for another half-day at Kaohsiung Port in southern Taiwan the following day.
There were more than 2,000 passengers aboard the cruise ship, nearly 700 of whom were Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin police nab 10 drug traffickers

TEXT.P: Police in Yunlin County said Thursday that they caught 10 drug traffickers the previous night in various southern counties in Taiwan, with four of the suspects from the same family.
The four men, led by a 49-year-old suspect named Lin Chien-hung, were uncle and cousins, Yunlin County Police Station chief Tai Tien-yueh said.

According to Tai, more than 60 policemen, tracking the suspects for more than three months on a tip, rushed to 17 recreational spots and playgrounds in Yunlin, Chiayi and Pingtung counties where they arrested the 10 men who were caught trying to sell a variety of illegal narcotics to customers. One accomplice is still at large, Tai added.

Police officers also seized 459.2 grams of heroine, 56.8 grams of amphetamine, 0.68 grams of FM2, 0.4 grams of ecstasy powder and two electronic scales, as well as small distribution bags and pipes for smoking marijuana or other drugs.

Police authorities will continue cracking down on drug traffickers in their current spring raid against drug-related crimes, as police records show that as many as 85 percent of burglaries in Yunlin County were committed by repeat drug addicts, Tai said. Many local farmers in the largely rural county therefore fell victim to this type of crime, he noted.
The 10 men have been turned over to the Yunlin Prosecutors Office for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Researchers make breakthrough on key flat display component

TEXT.P: Researchers at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) have developed a new production technology involving flexible optical film, reducing manufacturing costs by 50 percent and dependency on a key material monopolized by Japanese enterprises, officials at the Hsinchu-based institute said Thursday.

They explained that the flexible optical film is a key component in the polarizer, protecting the panel-like unit by adhering to its surface, while a polarizer is essential to controlling the light emitted by the flat panel display.

"However, the primary material for the protection film -- Triacetyl cellulose, or TAC -- is monopolized by Japanese enterprises who hold the production and related patents, " they continued, adding that the global production value of TAC is expected to reach NT$47 billion (about US$1.48 billion).
"If Taiwan is to upgrade and expand its FPD industry, we have to find the way bypassing the TAC barrier and obtain self-sufficiency in upstream material and component production, " they noted.

To facilitate that goal, the Ministry of Economic Affairs commissioned the ITRI to pursue refinements of the protective film's production processes; the new flexible optical film was developed as a result of those refinements.

ITRI experts in optoelectronics said the new techniques have lowered local industry's dependence on TAC by combining a mixture of organic and inorganic materials and new procedures to produce the flexible optical film.
"The new film is better than TAC film in terms of hardness, moisture-resistance, and stability in dimensions," they said.

The new techniques can also provide a simpler, eco-friendly production process, thus reducing production and capital costs, they pointed out, adding that the cost of the new film is only half that of TAC film.

According to ITRI, at least five patents are held by the institute in related fields and the technologies have been transferred to a local manufacturer for pilot production. ITRI estimated the annual production value of the new film could reach NT$5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses from cold weather rise to NT$113.65 million

TEXT.P: Agricultural losses caused by the recent spate of cold weather have increased to NT$113.65 million (US$3.55 million) across Taiwan, with crops and fish farms suffering the greatest damage, according to the latest tallies released Thursday by the Council of Agriculture (COA).
That total covers NT$77.31 million in damage to cobia farmed in Paisha and Hsiyu townships, Penghu County, affecting a total of 28.8 hectares of fish farms.
Crop damage amounts to NT$36.34 million, mainly reported to have affected pear, grape, peach and bell fruit crops planted in Yilan, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hsinchu Counties.
A total of 197 hectares, or 32 percent of these counties' farmland, have been damaged, with another 62 hectares of crops being entirely destroyed, according to the COA.
Also Thursday, an estimated 70,000 to 100,000 milkfish farmed in the coastal townships of Taihsi and Mailiao in Yunlin County were killed by the cold weather, fish farmers said.

Most of the affected fish were raised in shallow ponds no deeper than one meter that were designed for the cohabitation of milkfish and hard clams. These shallow ponds tend to offer less protection against cold snaps, the farmers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD begins project to monitor climatic changes

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has kicked off a monitoring project to tackle the increased impact of climatic change on Taiwan, CEPD officials said Thursday.

According to CEPD officials, the council has begun working on the six-year assessment project worth NT$170 million (US$5.31 million), the findings of which will be used to forge effective strategies to deal with all possible scenarios arising as a result of climatic change.

The strategies will focus on exploring sustainable growth of national territory, flood control programs and stimulating economic development in the hope of lowering investment risks in Taiwan and taking better advantage of national resources, CEPD officials explained.

According to the officials, Taiwan's scientific and academic circles, such as the Cabinet-level National Science Council, Academia Sinica and a study center under National Taiwan University, have devoted much energy to studying climatic change.

"The application of academic research to the sustainable use of the nation's resources and building public infrastructure to secure economic progress over the long term are the government's top priorities at the current stage," the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreigners 'leave roots in Taiwan' by planting trees

TEXT.P: Three hundred foreign dignitaries and students, at the invitation of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , planted trees on Valentine's Day Thursday to "show their love for nature and for Taiwan."

In cold and rainy weather, the foreign residents participated in the activity titled "Plant a Tree, Leave your Roots in Taiwan" organized by the EPA on the Linkou campus of National Taiwan Normal University in Taipei County, as a symbol of fighting against the effects of global warming.
"I'm glad to plant a tree to enhance Taiwan's sustainable development and help reduce air pollution, " said Ao Jallow, a 42-year-old student from Gambia.
According to EPA calculations, the 300 saplings planted will have absorbed up to 360 tons of CO2 after two decades.

But Taiwan is expected to do more. Guy Ledoux, head of the European Economic and Trade Office, encouraged Taiwan to set a higher target of carbon reduction, adding that the European Union has vowed to reduce carbon emissions in Europe by 20 percent by 2020.

Excited to be participating in the activity, Low Sang Thoi from Singapore, said she hopes to see more and more greenery in Taiwan, adding that "in Singapore, the number of trees is double that of the population."

The activity was not held on Valentine's Day by chance. The EPA launched the slogan "leave roots in Taiwan" by inviting foreign residents to "turn their personal love into love for the land." Each tree is tagged with the planter's name, the planting date and the species name.

"I'll remember that I have a baby tree in Taiwan, " said Santos Daniel from Belize, who studies environmental sustainable development at National Central University. Photos of the trees will be uploaded on the EPA Web site, as well as other information, such as the quantity of CO2 absorbed and the carbon offset by each tree.
According to Santos, "planting a tree is a symbolic way of showing that humans care for nature. But what is really important is to apply environmental protection ideas to daily life."

DOC.HEADLINE: Flags of Taichung and its sister cities raised for Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: Flags of 18 sister cities were raised along with the host city Taichung in central Taiwan Thursday to kick off the celebration of the Lantern Festival, which falls on Feb. 21 this year.

"This symbolizes close relations between Taichung and its 18 sister cities and Taichung's march towards the international stage," Hsiao Chia-chi, Deputy Mayor of Taichung City, said at the flag raising ceremony.

The 18 sister cities of Taichung include the U.S. New Haven City in Connecticut State, the Kwajalein Atoll of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, San Pedro Sula of Honduras, the Philippine's City of Makati, and the U.S. City of Columbus in Georgia State.

Noting that Taichung City always invites it sister cities to take part in its big events or festivals, Hsiao said "this kind of cultural exchanges will help strengthen ties between Taichung and its allies, making Taichung more internationalized."
As Taichung's sister cities are mostly located in America and Africa, Hsiao also disclosed a future plan for the city to form sister city relationships with cities in Japan and European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor to attend opening of Tokyo Marathon 2008

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin departed for Japan Thursday to attend the opening of the Tokyo Marathon 2008, slated for Feb. 17.

At the invitation of Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, Hau will attend the opening of Asia's biggest city marathon, in which some 30,000 athletes from around the world will compete, including two recommended by the Taipei city government, a city official said.

In addition to attending the event, Hau will also participate in a conference of Asian Network of Major Cities21 (ANMC21) , which was advocated by Shintaro Ishihara and formed in Kuala Lumpur in August 2000, with the aim of boosting friendship among and prosperity of Asian's major cities.
Besides, the official said, Hau is planning to study Tokyo's Super Dike Project, amajor levee system that can withstand earthquakes as well as floods.
"Tokyo's super levee construction plan could serve as a reference in helping the Taipei city government to resolve flooding problems in Beitou and on Shezidao," Hau said.
He is scheduled to return home Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Goal established in January: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan Goal -- a company established under the guidance of the government to integrate national defense resources -- completed registration with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Jan. 28, MOEA officials said Thursday.
According to the MOEA data, Taiwan Goal was registered as an ordinary company with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million.

Wu Nai-jen, a DPP heavyweight and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp. (CSC) -- was registered as chairman and a member of the board directors of Taiwan Goal, according to the MOEA data.

Other registered Taiwan Goal board directors include Lin Wen-yuan, CSC chairman, and Tung Ching-hsiung, president of Chunghwa System Integration, which is a subsidiary of Chunghwa Telecom. Kuo Shui-yi, deputy director of Chunghwa Telecom's Investment Department, has been registered as a supervisor of Taiwan Goal, according to the MOEA.

According to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang, Taiwan Goal has a seven-member board of directors, with three seats going to the Ministry of National Defense, which will contribute 45 percent of Taiwan Goal's capital.

Taiwan Goal's office is located in Taipei 101, according to the MOEA data, contradicting a report in the local daily China Times, which said that Taiwan Goal is headquartered at the Armament Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense.

Taiwan Goal is registered to deal in a wide variety of businesses, including: the import and export of arms and weaponry systems; sales of garments and accessories, industrial explosives, precision instruments, and batteries of all types; and product design, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local-flavored designs can revive Taiwan's furniture sector: TAITRA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top design center and government agency in charge of developing trade will team up at the upcoming Taipei International Furniture Show to promote local furniture designs infused with oriental and traditional art, in a bid to revitalize Taiwan's ailing furniture industry.

To help transform local furniture designs into better sales around the world, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will cooperate with the Taiwan Design Center (TDC) to hold a theme exhibition "Taiwan Design: Oriental Attitude" during the four-day fair from Feb. 28 to March 2.
The exhibition will display 29 Taiwanese artists' furniture works.
Pai Teh-hsiung, a council official, told CNA Thursday that combining Taiwan's local art and creative designs could be the key to popularizing Taiwan's furniture goods worldwide.

"Taiwan's furniture exports have been damaged by low-cost manufacturers in China and Southeast Asian countries; therefore launching our own brands powered by local creative designs could be a remedy to the slumping industry," Pai said.

The design center, a non-official agency supported by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, has been working with trade shows to promote Taiwan's local creative power.

A design center official who works on the furniture fair said it was important to blend the unique mix of Taiwanese art into furniture products. He said that at last year's Masion & Objects, a Paris-based furniture trade show, the locally-featured designs of Taiwan's glass products attracted many buyers.
"The creative works in this year's main exhibition are inspired by Taiwan's traditional (wooden) stools, of which you can only spot in the countryside nowadays," he went on.

In addition to the exhibition, the design center also organizes four seminars during the four-day trade show to hold discussions about the industry's emerging challenges, including developing eco-friendly products and making brands that cope with future lifestyles.

The seminars will be convened by world-renowned designers and brand makers, including a General Electric manager. The US- based company recently proposed a plan, the Ecomagination, to further improve "green", or environmentally friendly, designs with a more creative approach.
Taiwan's furniture exports amounted to US$1.25 billion (NT$40 billion) in 2006, posing only 0.44 percent in year-on-year growth, according to the Taiwan Furniture Manufacturer Association.

More than 270 domestic and foreign furniture manufacturers are expected to participate in this year's trade show. The attendees will occupy about 1,100 booths, an increase from last year's 226 companies which filled 1,083 booths, according to Pai.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel sets new high in monthly business revenues

TEXT.P: China Steel Corp. (CSC) reported Thursday a fresh single-month high in business revenues, reaching nearly NT$20.04 billion in January.

The company's business revenue last month broke the NT$20 billion level for the first time to register a record high of NT$20.039 billion (US$6.36 million) , marking a 21.75 percent year-on-year growth and a 5.59 percent increase from last December's level, according to CSC officials.

The CSC officials attributed the growth to its higher production output in January, which totaled 930,000 metric tons -- exceeding December's level of 900,000 metric tons -- due to strong market demand.
In the face of growing demand, the steel maker has adjusted upward by 5 percent its sales price quote for the first quarter of this year, CSC officials said.

CSC officials predicted that prices of the company's products will further rise by at least 5 percent in the second quarter thanks to robust demand in the world market and rising transportation costs.
The CSC, Taiwan's only integrated steel maker and slab producer, is based in Kaohsiung City, the largest city in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 45% admit to having one-night stand: Taipei City Hospital

TEXT.P: Taipei City Hospital called on the public to practice safe sex Thursday, Valentine's Day, as it released figures to show that 45 percent of those who were screened for HIV/AIDS at the hospital last year admitted that they had at least one one-night stand.
Hospitals officials said that of 1,693 people who received AIDS screening tests in 2007 under the conditions of anonymity, 760 admitted that they had a one- night stand.

Among those who had taken the tests, 579 suspected that their sexual partners might have been infected with AIDS, and 108 reported that they had solicited the services of a prostitute. Another 29 said they had bought sex via the Internet.
Only 14.3 percent said that they used condoms during every sex act, according to the statistics.

City officials said that many of those infected with the AIDS reported that they had no health problems before taking the screening tests. Even after they were diagnosed to have been infected, a great number said that they did not feel unwell.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT to help entrepreneurs promote sales through e-marketing

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold three workshops on e-marketing starting Feb. 18 in central and southern Taiwan to help local firms promote their sales via Internet.
"Global e-commerce is now prospering, but the e-commerce market will be gigantic in the future, " an official of BOFT's Kaohsiung office said.
According to statistics released by the office, some 1.1 billion people around the world surfed the Internet in 2006, and the number of Web sites in the world reached 125 million in 2007.

"It is estimated that the market scale of Taiwan's e-commerce will top NT$200 billion (US$6.3 billion) in 2008, " the official said, adding that integrating the real and virtual marketing platforms will now be an important topic for local enterprises looking to boost their competitiveness.
BOFT's Kaohsiung office will hold three workshops Feb. 18-20 in Tainan, Kaohsiung and Taichung, respectively. Interested people can visit BOFT's Web site at: www.trade.gov.tw.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges early passage of indigenous autonomy act

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the Legislative Yuan Thursday to pass into law a draft bill governing indigenous autonomy to help preserve aboriginal culture and traditions and boost social movement and sustainable tribal development.

Chen urged members of the 7th legislature to "put aside political prejudice" and pass the draft bill as soon as possible, given that the Executive Yuan referred the bill twice to the Legislative Yuan, in 2003 and 2007, but it had been returned without review on both occasions.
He made the call during a meeting at the Presidential Office with a group of representatives of the newly formed tribal assembly of the Saisiat tribe.

The president offered his congratulations to the Saisiat people -- the smallest of Taiwan's 13 officially recognized indigenous groups with a population of around 4,600 -- for having recently had 35 members of the tribe's lower house elected to form Taiwan's first aboriginal bicameral assembly body.

The Saisiat people -- based in the mountainous areas in the northern counties of Hsinchu and Miaoli -- elected the 35 lower house members Feb. 3 before merging members of an upper house into a Saisiat aboriginal assembly that same day. The upper house was formed in January by tribal elders and chieftains recommended by different Saisiat families.

Chen called for the other 12 indigenous groups around Taiwan to emulate the Saisiat people by forming their respective tribal assemblies based on the spirit of a yet-to-be-enacted indigenous autonomy act.

He added that the legislation of an indigenous autonomy act would not only echo the spirit of the United Nations' Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples adopted last September, it also reflects the nation's determination to allow aboriginal people to be their own masters.
In recent related news, the Pinuyumayan aborigines based in the eastern county of Taitung announced the establishment of a tribal assembly Jan. 27 after two years of preparation.
The assembly will push for a new partnership between the central government and indigenous tribal groups, according to an initiator of the Pinuyumayan bicameral tribal assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense minister confirms new arms procurement company created: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/14/08 21:35:52 (By Elizabeth Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu was quoted as having confirmed Thursday the administration of outgoing President Chen Shui-bian recently created a company to handle arms purchases, beyond the control of the defense ministry.

Lee was quoted as having told opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers that the ministry will contribute 45 percent of the capital to form the company, which is commissioned to integrate resources to boost the country's national defense industry and facilitate arms procurement.
According to KMT lawmakers, Lee made the remarks during a closed-door meeting hosted by the party's legislative caucus earlier in the day.
Lee declined to make any comments after the meeting, but he promised to hold a news conference Friday to brief the media on the matter.

A report in the Thursday edition of the Taipei-based newspaper China Times said that the government secretly set up the company to serve as a platform to deal with foreign arms suppliers. The company was formed with a founding capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million).

The new company, known as Taiwan Goal, was established to strike deals on arms, weaponry systems and military industrial exchanges with companies abroad, the report said, citing "reliable military sources."

The China Times reported that the company was born under the promotion of Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, and that Wu Nai-jen, a veteran member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , has been appointed chairman of the company's board of directors.

Wu stated in a press statement issued the same day that Taiwan Goal was founded in late January to handle relations between foreign weapon procurement and supply traders and skilled local manufacturers in the hopes of promoting development and technology upgrade of the domestic national defense industry.

Wu indicated that he has been working as a volunteer chairman, receiving no wages and that he will resign after the new president assumes office May 20 to allow the new government to fully control the company's personnel arrangement.
He has rejected the offers of wages and any other treatments from the company including a personal driver and automobile, the heavyweight of the former New Tide Faction in the DPP noted.

Wu also revealed that the company has contacted many foreign weapon suppliers since its founding last month in an effort to bring them in alliance with Taiwanese enterprises in logistic services. No business contract is likely to be signed before May 20.
"Although Taiwan Goal is a private company, there's no individual stockholders in the company," he noted in the statement.
KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang on Thursday lashed out at the government's move, claiming Taiwan Goal is a "political deal designed to rig money bills and election votes."

Lin claimed that the company was established with taxpayers' money and that its bills are footed by public agencies and state-run firms, including Chunghua Telecom and the defense ministry, the ministry holds only three of the seven seats on the board, with the remaining four controlled by Chiou, Wu and two people from the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local university forges sisterhood ties with Polish school

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Medical University (KMU) in the southern port city of Kaohsiung forged sisterhood relations Thursday with Poland's Medical University of Lodz, paving the way for future academic cooperation, according to a KMU spokesman.

The agreement was signed in Kaohsiung by KMU President Yu Hsing-su and Studies in English Language Dean Kan Wilczynski of Lodz. The signing was the result of frequent contact and visits between the two schools since last year and a mutual interest in academic cooperation.
Lodz was inaugurated in 2002 as a merger of the Medical Academy of Lodz, founded in 1950, and the Military Medical Academy of Lodz, established in 1958.
Enjoying resources from the two academies, the school is one of the leading research institutes in Central Europe. It has six research institutes and seven teaching hospitals.

Like many medical schools in Poland, Lodz provides all-English teaching courses for international students. Taiwanese students who want to study in Poland do not need to learn Polish before entering schools there, the spokesman noted.

Poland's educational system requires six years of study for medical science, five years for dentistry and four years for postgraduate medical sciences, and Polish medical diplomas are accepted in Taiwan.

KMU students will be able to take courses at Lodz and to do their internships in Europe as a result of the signing of the sisterhood agreement, and students at Lodz will have opportunities to learn medical sciences in Taiwan, the spokesman said.

"If faculty at Lodz agree to give short-term tutorials at KMU, it will be of great benefit for the school's improvement in terms of gaining international standards of teaching and research, " the spokesman said.
KMU also expects that through the sisterhood ties, the European Union will recognize KMU diplomas. The EU already recognizes Lodz diplomas but not those issued by KMU, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislative caucus positive on establishment of 'Taiwan Goal'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus Thursday recognized the government's efforts in establishing a company to boost the development of Taiwan's defense industry and facilitate its arms procurement.

Caucus whip Lai Ching-te made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan in response to media inquiries on a newspaper report, saying that the DPP administration, pushed by Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, organized a company, named Taiwan Goal, in secret to integrate the production resources of the country's defense industry.

The government has also appointed DPP veteran member Wu Nai-jen -- who no longer holds any governmental position -- to serve as chairman of the company, the report said, citing "reliable military sources."
Lai said that in the past the government managed to purchase armaments for national defense but did not work to establish a defense industry in Taiwan.

To correct the lack and safeguard the country, the government planned and established the company to take charge of the integration of the country's national defense resources and the development of the defense industry.
Lai went on to urge people around the country to support the project.

The lawmaker also indicated that under the National Defense Law, the government has the right to establish a company to take charge of the integration of the country's productive resources to improve the country's national defense.
"No matter which party wins power in the future, it has to continue operations of the company," Lai claimed.

However, Legislator Chang Hsien-Yao of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Taiwan Goal was founded, under instructions from the Executive Yuan, as a private company "in an attempt to avoid the Legislative Yuan's supervision."
In this regard, Chang pledged "all KMT members in the legislative committee of national defense will boycott the company until a new government is formed May 20."

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate Dance Theater finds temporary studio after fire

TEXT.P: Taiwan's celebrated Cloud Gate Dance Theater has decided to use a temporary rehearsal studio offered by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) after the theater's old one was recently destroyed by a blaze, CCA Chairman Wang Tuoh said Thursday.
A fire burned down early Monday the world famous dance theater's 1,324 square- meter rehearsal studio, as well as costumes, props and production archives.
The dance theater -- known for blending Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility -- is slated for a series of performances in the United States and Europe starting in April.
Wang made the announcement at a press conference after meeting with Lin Hwai- min, founder and choreographer of the 35-year-old dance troupe, earlier in the day.

During the meeting, Lin told Wang that he has decided to choose the Ching-mei Human Rights Memorial Park in the northern county of Taipei as a mid-term rehearsal venue and will start to use it from March.
The Taipei city and county government have also offered sites for Lin to use as rehearsal studios.

Wang said that in the past, the council only provided emergency assistance to individual artists instead of groups. He added that the council will formulate a package of measures to offer emergency relief for art groups.
To further expand its help for local cultural groups, the council will provide 23 idle places for performing arts groups to use to reduce their financial burdens, Wang said.
In addition, Wang said that he agreed with Lin that the council and the government should increase its funds to promote culture and art.
This year, the government allocated only 1.34 percent of its total funds -- NT$1.6 trillion (US$50.6 billion) -- for cultural development and 0.36 percent for the council, according to Wang.

He said he hopes that in the future, the cultural funds could be raised to account for 3 percent or 4 percent of the total government funds, while the council's funds could rise to 1.5 percent or 2 percent.
Meanwhile, Wang said that he will also push for upgrading the council into a ministry.
Among Cloud Gate's best known works are "Nine Songs," "Moon Water" and the "Cursive" trilogy inspired by Chinese brush calligraphy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to award prizes to encourage tree planting

TEXT.P: Participants in a recently launched national tree planting campaign will have a chance to win prizes, a government agency organizing the event said Thursday, in the latest effort to encourage tree planting in Taiwan.

The activity called "Green the World, " was launched Wednesday by the Council of Agriculture (COA) , with the aim of encouraging every citizen to plant at least one tree in his or her lifetime. Organizers estimate 10 million trees will be planted within five years.

As part of the program, the public is invited to plant trees on available land and send photos and information of their tree plantings to the council via the program's Web site at http: //greentheworld.gov.tw/.
Each participant will receive a certificate from the council with the planting time, place, planter's name, and serial numbers listed on it.
Yen Jen-to, director-general of the council's Forestry Bureau, said the activity is among a series of events for this year's tree planting month which began Feb. 4 and will run through March 12.
Those who have serial numbers being 5,000, 10,000, or their multiples will win free admission tickets for national forest recreation areas, Yen said.
The council will present certificates of recognition to groups that plant over 5,000 trees or individuals who grow more than 1,000 trees, Yen said.
The public may also join the tree planting activity in another way by designing greeting cards on tree planting and submitting their designs to the council for a competition.

The council began accepting entries on Wednesday and will do so through Feb. 25. Details can be accessed at the same Web site, Yen said, adding that the highest prize money for the competition is NT$30, 000 (US$946).

For those who have no idea about what trees to plant, Yen said the council has selected 12 species of trees corresponding to the 12 months in a year, such as the Taiwan cherry for January, camphor for April, and reetha tree for December.

The list is to induce people to sow the tree seed corresponding to their birth months, in the hope that at least half of the population will have been persuaded to plant their own trees within five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Six sister city representatives to attend Kaohsiung Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: Performing groups from six sister cities in five countries will join Kaohsiung residents in their celebration of the 2008 Lantern Festival scheduled to begin Feb. 16, Kaohsiung city government officials said Thursday.
The groups, comprising a total of 115 dancers and musicians, will perform at No. 13 Wharf of Kaohsiung harbor at the opening of the festival and in the two following days of celebrations.

The main attraction of this year's Lantern Festival celebrating the arrival of the Year of the Rat is a lantern exhibition with the rat as the theme. The exhibition will run until March 2, with showgrounds along the Love River and in Kaohsiung harbor displaying hundreds of colorful lanterns of various design.
Local dance groups will also give performances throughout the festival and will present special effects using fire, water and fireworks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of job applicants, openings rise high after New Year holiday

TEXT.P: The number of job applicants and job openings on Feb. 12, the first day following the Chinese New Year holiday, were staggering high, according to a local online employment service company.

The number of job applicants on Feb. 12 exceeded 265,000, marking an increase of 15 percent over Feb. 23, 2007, the first day following last year's festival, while the number of job openings on that day were around 230,000, 2.5 times more than those on February weekdays ahead of the holiday, an executive of the 104 Job Bank said Thursday, quoting statistics from the bank's database.
Local employees, who often receive year-end bonuses just before the Chinese New Year holiday, often change jobs as soon as the holiday is over, said Chiu Wen- jen, the job bank's marketing chief.

Of the job applicants, 2,583 people sought administrative posts, 1,733 people sought sales positions, 1,591 were pursuing technical careers, 984 people were looking for client services posts and 880 people preferred jobs related to product purchases and logistical storehouse management, Chiu went on.

By business classification, computer and consumer electronics manufacturers accounted for 9 percent of the total job openings, followed by semiconductor producers' 7.5 percent and computer software and Internet-related product makers' 7.1 percent, Chiu said.
By job classification, business sales accounted for 14.3 percent of the total job openings, followed by industrial development's 10.3 percent and software engineering's 6 percent.
The Chinese New Year holiday this year ran from Feb. 6 through Feb. 11.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tries to win investment, votes from `taishang'

TEXT.P: With over 70 percent of its outbound investment going to China and a stagnant economy, the government is doing more to encourage Taiwanese businessmen to "re- invest" in their homeland and vote in the March 22 presidential election.

President Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Economic Affairs Steve Chen and Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) President Hung Chi-chang made the remarks at an annual Lunar New Year gathering Thursday for more than 500 Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, known locally as "taishang. "

Facing the challenges of China's new labor laws and stricter taxation, Taiwanese businessmen should start considering the deployment of "China plus one, " which means increasing investment to a new country. That country could be Vietnam or Taiwan, Hung said after describing the businessmen as Taiwan's "invisible national power and national pride."

He also urged China-based Taiwanese to vote in the presidential election and make Taiwan's democracy an example for China and the Chinese community. An estimated 1 million taishang and their dependents reside in China.
There will be more than 17 million eligible voters in the presidential election, so that the 1 million votes of taishang represent almost 6 percent of the electorate.
Taiwanese businessmen need to cope with the changing investment environment in China that is the result of a new labor law and new tax regulations, said Chen.

A China with cheap land, cheap labor, tax incentives and low standards of environmental protection -- the main reasons that has attracted Taiwanese businessmen to China since the late 1980's -- is in the past, he said.

This is why the government has created a project to attract investment back to Taiwan with incentives on land lease and taxation, he noted, adding that the government also encourages Taiwanese businesses to start the process of enterprise transformation and focus on high value-added products.

"Not all businesses are suitable for returning to Taiwan. We realize that. The MOEA will also do its best to help Taiwanese businesses invest in various other regions, including Central and South America, Central and Eastern Europe, India and Vietnam, " Steve Chen said.

To bring back the investment, the government has to first convince the presidents of the 102 Taiwanese businessmen associations in China, who are seen as highly influential among the taishang. A total of 82 incumbent or former presidents of the associations attended the annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Currency appreciation expected to boost investment

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank appears ready to allow the New Taiwan dollar to continue appreciating in an attempt to create a friendly environment for foreign investment, a banking analyst said Thursday.
The analyst made the remarks a day after the New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.196 to NT$31.688 against the U.S. dollar--the highest level in 21 months.

As of Wednesday, the local currency had risen for eight trading days in a row with a cumulative gain of NT$0.657, since Jan. 28 according to the analyst, who said that the currency's rate of appreciation against the greenback has been the second most rapid among all Asian currencies so far this year, only lagging behind the Malaysian ringgit. The NT dollar lost a marginal NT$0.012 against the greenback to close at NT$31.7 Thursday.

The analyst said that the Central Bank of the Republic of China's move reflected its worry that its monetary policy might be too tight in view of the fact that the country's M2, the broadest measure of the nation's money supply, dropped to a record low of 1.36 percent last December due to weakness in the stock market and a massive outflow of capital as well as the slow growth of bank loans and investment.

Therefore, the central bank decided to allow sufficient appreciation of Taiwan's currency to attract inward remittance of foreign capital into Taiwan's stock market to further stimulate domestic demand and facilitate local economic development.
The decision may also be interpreted as reflecting the central bank's intention to ease restrictions on the capital market and create an environment more favorable to investment, the analyst added.

Noting that the central bank is expected to allow further appreciation of the currency to offset inflationary pressures, the analyst said that when the currency appreciates to a certain level, the bank will step in to maintain a stable monetary policy.

"Taiwan is one of a small number of countries with the necessary conditions to raise interest rates, " the analyst said, forecasting that the central bank will later shift to a tighter monetary policy by means of raising interest rates in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen prosecutors ask for legislator-elect's win to be annulled

TEXT.P: A public prosecutor in Kinmen County filed a civil lawsuit Thursday seeking to annul the election win of legislator-elect Chen Fu-hai on charges of vote- buying.
Chen, an independent, defeated his rival of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in a constituency on the outlying island by a slim margin in the Jan. 12 legislative elections.
Prosecutor Hsi Chih-ying claimed that Chen had asked three voters to support him in the elections in return for promises to help them get salary increases from their boss after his election victory.
The civil suit came after the Kinmen Public Prosecutors Office indicted Chen Jan. 31 on charges of vote-buying in violation of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law.
Chen, the only independent elected to the new legislature, unseated Wu Cheng- dien, a two-term incumbent of the KMT, with 9,912 votes, winning by just 74 votes.
A day earlier, Wu also filed a civil action with the court seeking to nullify Chen's qualification as an elected lawmaker of Kinmen County on charges that he had bribed voters.
Chen professed his innocence and said that the legal proceedings will eventually clear his name.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official explains defense management company's functions

TEXT.P: Founding private companies to handle deals involving national defense management, production and marketing is an international trend for the integration of national defense department and civil industrial sectors, a defense official said Thursday.

Wu Wei-rong, director-general of the Armaments Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, made the remarks at a press conference held by the ministry in response to a local newspaper report that the government has secretly organized a company, named Taiwan Goal, to handle arms deals with foreign traders.

At the press conference, Wu delivered a report on the progress of a plan to establish an institute to carry out the development of the nation's defense industry, but did not mention any company by name.

Wu said that Taiwan has been faced with many barriers in its arms procurement from abroad. Even after it succeeds in a purchase, it has still to spend a lot of money to maintain the armaments because the nation cannot join the foreign production and maintenance line for the armaments due to its sensitive political status in the international community.

In addition, "the country's failure to expand its international sales of locally made weapons has also contributed to a waste of the country's scientific research energy, "Wu added, claiming that establishing a national defense management, production and trading company will solve all the problems.

With such a company, Wu went on, the government will be able to integrate reciprocal technology transfers between foreign contractors and local industries and export locally developed technologies or weaponry components to overseas arms producers.

Citing a Singaporean private national defense company, Wu said it helped Singapore purchase Lafayette frigates from France and at the same time win a big portion of the contracts to assemble Lafayette hulls and combat systems on Singapore soil.
"If Taiwan had a similar company, it would not only be able to facilitate arms procurement but could also work with foreign companies in technology sharing and development, " Wu said.
In addition, Taiwan could also join the global supply chain for armaments. "There are limitless trade opportunities," Wu continued.

Capital of NT$200 million has been underwritten for the planned company, NT$90 million of which will be from the MND, Wu said, adding that the project is still in the planning stages and that no funds have been injected by the MND. If the plan comes to fruition, the company will not begin operating before June, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italian soldier killed in Afganistan.
An Italian soldier was killed and another one was injured in an attack Wednesday at Rudbar, some 60 kilometers to Kabul, where they were carrying out a mission. Italy has now a 2,350-man peacekeeping force in Afganistan, serving as part of the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGCost of a ticket on the worst-run trains races ahead as punctuality and overcrowding go off the rails
Britains worst-performing train company has imposed the highest fare increases of any operator since privatisation, more than doubling the price of open tickets, a study has found.
Since 1995 the average standard single fare of First Great Western has risen by 145 per cent, well above inflation over the period of 41 per cent.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Candidates' Earmarks Worth Millions
Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton helped secure more than $340 million worth of home- state projects in last year's spending bills, placing her among the top 10 Senate recipients of what are commonly known as earmarks, according to a new study by a nonpartisan budget watchdog group.
The Washington Times:Europe savors '08 race drama
Europeans across the old continent have been transfixed by the U.S. presidential race, gobbling up press reports and wrestling with the intricacies of the primary system in search of clues to the likely next president.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Obama's Lead in Delegates Shifts Focus of Campaign
Senator Barack Obama emerged from Tuesdayzs primaries leading Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton by more than 100 delegates, a small but significant advantage that Democrats said would be difficult for Mrs. Clinton to make up in the remaining contests in the presidential nomination battle.
The Wall Street Journal:China Plant Played Role In Drug Tied to 4 Deaths
A Chinese facility that hasn't been inspected by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration made the active ingredient in much of the widely used Baxter International Inc. blood-thinner that is under investigation after reports of hundreds of allergic reactions and four deaths among the drug's users, the agency said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday.

The weighted price index was down 98.79 points at 7,766.49 on a turnover of NT$3.3 billion (US$104.1 million) at the open. The index gained 314.73 points, or 4.16 percent, to close at 7865.28 Thursday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.708 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.008 from Thursday.
