As of Wednesday, the local currency had risen for eight trading days in a row with a cumulative gain of NT$0.657, since Jan. 28 according to the analyst, who said that the currency's rate of appreciation against the greenback has been the second most rapid among all Asian currencies so far this year, only lagging behind the Malaysian ringgit. The analyst said that the Central Bank of the Republic of China's move reflected its worry that its monetary policy might be too tight in view of the fact that the country's M2, the broadest measure of the nation's money supply, dropped to a record low of 1.36 percent last December due to weakness in the stock market and a massive outflow of capital as well as the slow growth of bank loans and investment.

Therefore, the central bank decided to allow sufficient appreciation of Taiwan's currency to attract inward remittance of foreign capital into Taiwan's stock market to further stimulate domestic demand and facilitate local economic development.
The decision may also be interpreted as reflecting the central bank's intention to ease restrictions on the capital market and create an environment more favorable to investment, the analyst added.

Noting that the central bank is expected to allow further appreciation of the currency to offset inflationary pressures, the analyst said that when the currency appreciates to a certain level, the bank will step in to maintain a stable monetary policy.

"Taiwan is one of a small number of countries with the necessary conditions to raise interest rates, " the analyst said, forecasting that the central bank will later shift to a tighter monetary policy by means of raising interest rates in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official explains defense management company's functions

TEXT.P: Founding private companies to handle deals involving national defense management, production and marketing is an international trend for the integration of national defense department and civil industrial sectors, a defense official said Thursday.

Wu Wei-rong, director-general of the Armaments Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, made the remarks at a press conference held by the ministry in response to a local newspaper report that the government has secretly organized a company, named Taiwan Goal, to handle arms deals with foreign traders.

At the press conference, Wu delivered a report on the progress of a plan to establish an institute to carry out the development of the nation's defense industry, but did not mention any company by name.

Wu said that Taiwan has been faced with many barriers in its arms procurement from abroad. Even after it succeeds in a purchase, it has still to spend a lot of money to maintain the armaments because the nation cannot join the foreign production and maintenance line for the armaments due to its sensitive political status in the international community.

In addition, "the country's failure to expand its international sales of locally made weapons has also contributed to a waste of the country's scientific research energy, "Wu added, claiming that establishing a national defense management, production and trading company will solve all the problems.

With such a company, Wu went on, the government will be able to integrate reciprocal technology transfers between foreign contractors and local industries and export locally developed technologies or weaponry components to overseas arms producers.

Citing a Singaporean private national defense company, Wu said it helped Singapore purchase Lafayette frigates from France and at the same time win a big portion of the contracts to assemble Lafayette hulls and combat systems on Singapore soil.
"If Taiwan had a similar company, it would not only be able to facilitate arms procurement but could also work with foreign companies in technology sharing and development, " Wu said.
In addition, Taiwan could also join the global supply chain for armaments. "There are limitless trade opportunities," Wu continued.

Capital of NT$200 million has been underwritten for the planned company, NT$90 million of which will be from the MND, Wu said, adding that the project is still in the planning stages and that no funds have been injected by the MND. If the plan comes to fruition, the company will not begin operating before June, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 15, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1564: Galileo Galilei, the Italian astronomer and physicist who was the first to use a telescope to study the stars, is born.
1748: Jeremy Bentham, English philosopher, is born. He was a pioneer of utilitarianism, an ethical doctrine which holds that the best action is one that will result in the greatest happiness and least pain for the greatest number of people.
1898: The U.S. battleship Maine, which was sent to Cuba to protect American citizens during the Cuban rebellion against Spanish rule, explodes and sinks in Havana Harbor as 260 lose their lives.
1912: Yuan Shih-kai is elected provisional president by the provisional Senate.
1922: The Permanent Court of International Justice, established by the League of Nations, holds its first session in The Hague, capital of the Netherlands.
1928: After some 70 years of efforts, the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
1933: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt escapes an assassination attempt in Miami by Italian-born anarchist Giuseppe Zangara.
1936: China's first international long-distance telephone service between Shanghai and Tokyo begins operation.
1942: Thousands of British troops in Singapore surrender to Japanese forces in World War II.
1944: The Allies begin to bomb the German-held strategic position of Monte Cassino in Italy as some 1,000 British bombers pound Berlin, Germany. Meanwhile U.S. troops recapture the Solomon Islands in the Pacific in World War II.
1945: British forces reach the River Rhine in their advance toward Berlin during World War II.
1946: The world's first computer is born at a university in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania.
1952: Greece and Turkey formally join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1965: Canada adopts a new national flag with red and white colors as its base and a maple leaf at the center.
1965: Mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Chen Yi says in Beijing that peaceful coexistence with the United States is out of the question.
1966: South Korean President Park Chung Hee arrives in Taipei for a four-day state visit.
1970: A Dominican Airlines DC-9 crashes into the sea, killing all 102 aboard.
1973: Henry A. Kissinger, the United States' national security adviser under President Richard M. Nixon, visits the Chinese mainland.
1973: The Republic of China and Paraguay sign an agreement on technical cooperation at Asuncion.
1974: The Chinese Petroleum Corporation signs an oil exploration agreement with two Philippine corporations.
1974: Arthur Pothuije, director of the new U.S. Trade Center in Taipei, arrives with his wife.
1974: Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of state for finance and national economy, arrives in Taipei for talks on economic cooperation.
1975: Kuo Chie-hsiung of the Republic of China fires a record 6-under-par 66 for an eight-stroke victory in the Philippines Open Golf Championship.
1976: Clement C. Conger, curator of the U.S. White House and the diplomatic reception room of the U.S. State Department, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1989: The Soviet Union withdraws its remaining soldiers from Afghanistan, ending nine years of military intervention.
1994: Pyongyang agrees to open part of its nuclear program to international inspection.
1995: A fire at a restaurant in Taichung City claims 64 lives in one of Taiwan's worst fire disasters in recent years.
1999: Henry Kendall, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, dies at the age of 72. He is considered a pioneer of the environmental movement among scientists.
2000: The two new naval patrol boats, the Chinchiang and the Hsianchiang, are formally commissioned by the ROC Navy.
2001: The sixth Japanese-Taiwan academic symposium, sponsored by the Asia- Pacific Forum of Japan, is held in Tokyo, attended by about 50 scholars and experts from the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, sentiment is called out by the study of poetry; judgment is formed by the study of the arts; and education of the character is completed by the study of music."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidates number 1 on ballot, Kuomintang candidates number 2

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate, Su Tseng-chang, will be choice number one on the presidential election ballot, while their Kuomintang rivals Ma Ying-jeou and Vincent Siew will be number two, according to a draw held Friday at the Central Election Commission.
Both pairs of candidates had their campaign managers draw their respective numbers for the order in which they will appear on the ballot for the March 22 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: Assets of Taiwanese OBUs hit record high in 2007

TEXT.P: The combined assets of offshore banking units (OBUs) in Taiwan amounted to a record US$91.28 billion at the end of last December, up US$14.6 billion or 19.03 percent from the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Friday by the Taiwan-based Central Bank of China.
At the end of 2007, there were a total of 65 OBUs in Taiwan, including 38 operated by domestic banks and 27 by foreign banks, the tallies show.
While the assets of domestic bank OBUs amounted to US$66.08 billion, those of foreign bank OBUs amounted to US$25.2 billion.

The turnover of foreign exchange trading by these OBUs amounted to US$10.17 billion for last December, including US$6.23 billion in spot transactions, US$1.65 billion in outright forwards and US$2.29 billion in foreign exchange swaps.
Dues to related offices and deposits by financial institutions were the OBUs' main sources of funds, accounting for 61 percent of their total liabilities, the tallies indicate.
By area of origin, funds from Asia accounted for 68 percent, those from America for 21 percent, those from Europe for 9 percent and those from other areas for 2 percent.
At the end of 2007, outstanding loans granted by OBUs were valued at US$24.88 billion, with 97 percent extended to overseas clients and 3 percent to local clients, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trade deficit with Taiwan declining
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 14 (CNA) 02/15/08 12:27:03 (By Michelle Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States' trade deficit with Taiwan declined by a sharp 21.2 percent last year as a result of expanded exports to and declining imports from Taiwan, according to the latest foreign trade report released by the Department of Commerce Thursday.

The U.S. trade deficit with Taiwan decreased to US$11.9 billion in 2007, making Taiwan the United States' 17th-largest source of trade deficit in the world that year. Taiwan was the U.S.'s 12th-largest trade deficit source in 2006, with a surplus of US$15.2 billion, according to the report.

In 2007, the United States exported US$26.4 billion-worth of products and services to Taiwan, up roughly 14 percent over the year-earlier level of US$23 billion, while posting import trade of US$38.3 billion with Taiwan, marking a mere 0.2 percent growth from the 2006 level of US$38.2 billion.

Liang Kuo-hsin, director of the Economic Affairs Department under the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, attributed the growth in U.S. exports to Taiwan mainly to the surge in overall U.S. export trade that year.

Growing Taiwan high tech investment in the United States and Taiwan's expanded purchases of equipment for semiconductor and LCD flat display panel manufacturing also played a role in shoring up U.S. exports to Taiwan in 2007, Liang said.

He reiterated that Taiwan welcomes growing U.S. exports to Taiwan, but added that it is concerned over declining U.S. imports from Taiwan, citing the fact that many Taiwanese companies received orders from the United States but had their products delivered from China or Southeast Asia.
He stressed the importance of U.S.-Taiwan talks on the signing of a free trade agreement between the two countries.
Meanwhile, the U.S. trade deficit with China hit a new record high in 2007, up 10.2 percent to the tune of US$256.3 billion.
China, meanwhile, was also the largest source of the U.S. trade deficit last year, followed by Japan, Mexico, Canada and Germany, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Trusts managed by Taiwanese trust firms up 30% in 2007

TEXT.P: Trusts placed under the management of Taiwanese trust companies amounted to NT$5.17 trillion (US$163.09 billion) at the end of last December, up 30 percent from the year-earlier level, according to tallies released Friday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
Money placed in trust remained the most popular in 2007, with the amount of money trusts increasing 32 percent to stand at NT$4.3 trillion, accounting for 84 percent of the total, FSC officials said.

Trusts of loans and related security interests accounted for 7 percent of the total amount, while securities trusts accounted for 4.2 percent and real estate trusts accounted for 3.5 percent, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP whip shrugs off approval ratings poll results

TEXT.P: The whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus shrugged off Friday the results of a daily newspaper's poll of public approval for the two presidential candidates.

William Lai dismissed the results of a United Daily News poll conducted the day before showing that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying- jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew had an approval rating of 56 percent, while Ma's opponent ticket -- the DPP's Frank Hsieh and his running mate Su Tseng-chang -- had an approval rating of just 18 percent.

Lai claimed that the information he had was quite different from the UDN poll, saying that "if the poll was true, the Ma-Siew ticket should probably set off firecrackers now for celebrations." He did not elaborate on his information or its source.
He added that the purpose of the pro-unification daily conducting the poll during the election period was simply aimed at rooting for the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up slightly on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were marginally up Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 11.09 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 7,876.37.

Rising for the second consecutive day, the bourse opened at 7,766.49 and fluctuated between 7,888.15 and 7,761.93 during the day's session. A total of 3.88 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$108.05 billion (US$3.3 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares advancing 0.9 percent and construction issues rising 0.4 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground. Cement stocks fell 2.2 percent, more than any other sector. Textile stocks dropped 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 0.8 percent, and banking and financial shares dropped 0.7 percent, while foodstuff issues fell 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,012 to 793, with 422 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates' opinions should be heeded in government overhaul

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that the opinions of the two presidential candidates should be heeded while the administration makes plans to overhaul the executive branch of the government.

Noting that the presidential candidates of both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Kuomintang (KMT) have put forth opinions pertaining to Cabinet measures that would streamline the organization of the Executive Yuan, Wang said that as soon as the Executive Yuan refers the administration streamlining plan to the Legislative Yuan, he will make sure the proposal is reviewed immediately.

Wang expressed hope that the Cabinet will refer the draft package of amendments to the Organic Act of the Executive Yuan to the Legislative Yuan soon so that the package can be reviewed and passed into law prior to the March 22 presidential election.
The Cabinet earlier in the week postponed approving measures that would streamline the organization of the Executive Yuan and would cut the number of agencies under the Executive Yuan from 39 to 26.
Both Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Vice Premier Chiou I-jen have said they will try to push the revisions through next week.

Based on a 2005 proposal that called for the Executive Yuan to be composed of 13 ministries and four councils, the draft amendments currently under consideration propose a structure of 14 ministries, seven councils and five independent organizations.
The new measures would add a ministry for veterans affairs and two other councils -- a gender equality commission and an oceans commission -- to the 2005 proposal.
The establishment of a ministry of veterans affairs was at the center of heated debate among Executive Yuan ministries and agencies Wednesday.

Attempting to push through the new ministry, Chiou said it would not merely be a "transplant" of the existing Veterans Affairs Commission but would actually be crucial for the implementation of a volunteer military service system in the future.

The draft amendments will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval after being passed by the Executive Yuan, but achieving a consensus in the legislature could be very difficult because the amendments touch on many areas in which various vested interests have support in the lawmaking body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier defends controversial private defense company

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reaffirmed Friday that the controversial establishment of a private company to handle Taiwan's foreign arms transactions was appropriate and necessary to "develop an independent defense industry."

The premier contended that the company will serve as a platform to integrate Taiwan's arms purchases and procurement projects, and will help upgrade both Taiwan's domestic arms industry and the economy as a whole.
Taiwan Goal's main targets, he said, would be "to give rise to Taiwan's arm sales, upgrade Taiwan's defense industry and develop independent technologies."

News of the formation of the company, called Taiwan Goal, emerged Wednesday and was confirmed by the Ministry of National Defense, which will hold a 45 percent stake in the venture with an NT$90 million investment.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) criticized the company as constituting a political arrangement favoring the former New Tide faction of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and questioned the timing of the new venture, launched less than two months before Taiwan's March 22 presidential election.

Chang insisted, however, that the arms broker, which would include the involvement of various government sectors, would be closely monitored by the legislature, stressing "this is the essence of democracy."
He dismissed reports that his Cabinet would receive a hefty commission for setting up the firm, saying "the Executive Yuan is not as naive as that."
"We should use a broader perspective to look at the case, " Chang stressed.

Describing the establishment of Taiwan Goal as a beginning, Chang said the government had an obligation to carry out its policies, regardless of when the presidential election is held, and he believed the company would be seen through by the new government and executives appointed by the new president.
"The government must continue carrying out policies that benefit both the nation and its people," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Economy grew 3.7% but outlook is murky
Japan's economy grew an annualized 3.7 percent in the October-December period, more than twice the rate forecast, thanks to strong capital investment and exports, the Cabinet Office said Thursday in a preliminary report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural, fishery losses amount to NT$142 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agriculture and fishery losses due to the recent cold spell had amounted to NT$142 million (US$4.48 million), as of Friday, according to tallies released by the Council of Agricultural Affairs (COA).
Fishery losses totalled NT$85.43 million, with Penghu County bearing the brunt with losses estimated at NT$84.82 million, followed by Tainan County at NT$616,000, the COA figures show.

Meanwhile, agricultural losses had amounted to NT$57.14 million, with Hsinchu County the hardest-hit region, followed by Yilan County, Taichung County, Kaohsiung County, Miaoli County and Yunlin County, in that order, according to the tallies.

COA officials said they had instructed local agricultural councils to deal with the situation, including offering guidance to farmers on how to protect their crops from cold weather. They added that they will continue to monitor developments related to agricultural losses caused by the recent cold spell, as well as the response measures implemented.
Ever since the beginning of February, the island has been in the grip of the cold spell that has driven temperatures down to below 10 degrees Celsius and was expected to last until this weekend.

With minutes left in a class in ocean sciences at Northern Illinois University on Thursday afternoon, a tall skinny man dressed all in black stepped out from behind a curtain on the stage of the lecture hall, said nothing, and opened fire with a shotgun, the authorities and witnesses said.

Citigroup Inc. has barred investors in one of its hedge funds from withdrawing their money, another black eye for the financial behemoth's troubled foray into new types of investments.

: The Straits Times: F1 ticketing fiasco.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County, Taipower to promote tree-planting plan

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung county government and Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) will collaborate on a plan to plant over 40,000 trees in a 30-hectare area of the southern county, Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Friday.
The announcement came after Yang met with Taipower Vice President Lee Jiin-tyan to discuss the plan at Kaohsiung City Hall the previous day.
Lee promised that Taipower will fully support the plan proposed by the county government.
The plan is part of the county government's efforts to work with local companies to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, which some believe is the major cause of global warming, Yang said.

Calling for more support for the tree-planting plan from local religious and community groups, Yang noted that steel and energy companies -- which he claimed have had major negative impacts on the environment -- should also join the efforts to stop global warming.
Beginning in 2004, the county government has begun to push for a project to plant 1 million trees within five years, Yang went on.
However, the county government has already reached the goal earlier than expected, having planted more than 1.4 million trees as of the end of 2007, Yang went on.
According to Yang, the project has received support from the private sector, including the China Steel Corp. and the state-owned oil company CPC Corp., Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records year's first measles case contracted overseas

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese man contracted the measles after a recent visit to China, the first overseas measles infection recorded this year, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported Friday.

The patient, a 27-year-old electronics engineer living in Taipei County, was sent to China by his employer between mid-November 2007 and Jan. 26, 2008, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting.
Shortly after his return to Taiwan, the man developed a cough and a runny nose on Jan. 30, but did not seek medical treatment until a red rash appeared Feb. 4, Lin said.

The case was reported to health authorities as a possible case of the measles, and test results released Friday confirmed the diagnosis, Lin said, adding that it is unclear if the man had previously been vaccinated against the disease.

According to Lin, more than 95 percent of Taiwan's citizens aged 31 and below have received measles inoculations, but some people might not develop an immunity to the disease even after the inoculation.
Taiwan has not recorded any indigenous measles infections for many years, although there have been some overseas infections, the largest number of which originate in China, Lin said.
Of the 10 overseas measles cases recorded last year, five were contracted in China, four in Japan and one in the Philippines, he said.

The 10 victims included two infants who had not reached the statutory age for measles vaccines, four adults who had never received an inoculation, one who had only received one vaccination dose, and three whose inoculation history was unknown, Lin said.
Many of the victims were foreign or Chinese spouses of Taiwan citizens, Lin said.
In Taiwan, children are given a first dose of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine when they are between 12-15 months old and the second dose during their first year of elementary school.
Lin advised people planning to travel overseas with infants below one year old to make sure to have the children immunized at least two weeks prior to departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT: Women staged demonstrations Thursday in several cities in Italy in protest against an alleged attack on their right to abortion. The protests were partly a response to a controversial incident in a Naples hospital in which a woman was questioned by police Tuesday immediately after receiving an alleged illegal abortion operation. The current law allows abortions until the 90th day of pregnancy and terminations after this point when the mother's health is at risk or when the fetus is deformed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

A total of US$940 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.720 and fluctuated between NT$31.685 and NT$31.750.
