TAIEX Index futures for March lost 16 points to finish at 7,866, with 4,401 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 25 points to close at 7,863, with 10 contract transactions.
September futures moved down 41 points to finish at 7,661, with 19 contract transactions, while December futures lost 16 points to close at 7,645, with three contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index gained 11.09 points Friday to finish at 7,876.37, with market turnover of NT$108.04 billion (US$3.4 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,897 for February; 7,882 for March; 7,888 for June; 7,702 for September and 7,661 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
February TE futures rose 1.55 points to close at 299.5, with 5,249 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 0.65 point to finish at 298.1, with 641 contract exchanges.

June TE futures gained 5.1 points to finish at 293.65, with one contract traded, while September TE futures lost 1.75 points to close at 287.35, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

February TF futures moved down 7.6 points to close at 1,048, with 5,193 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures dropped 10.6 points to finish at 1,045.4, with 1,380 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic airline files for bankruptcy protection, concerning creditors

TEXT.P: Far Eastern Air Transport (FAT) , one of Taiwan's airlines that have been hit hard by a downturn in domestic air travel, filed for reorganization Friday in an attempt to work its way out of a financial crisis.

The filing means the carrier, which reported debts of NT$9.99 billion (US$315 million) at the end of September 2007, will be able to protect its assets from claims by creditors while its request is being considered by the Taipei District Court and also if the request is granted.

The news prompted FAT's main creditor banks -- Far Eastern International Bank, Bank of Taiwan, Ta Chong Bank and Mega International Commercial Bank -- to hold an emergency meeting to discuss possible measures to collect payment on their outstanding loans.

The Commercial Times reported Friday that FAT has more than NT$5 billion in bank debts, with Far Eastern International Bank being the airline's biggest creditor and a major shareholder, with NT$862 million (US$26.94 million) in outstanding loans to the company.

Some of FAT's loans were secured with collateral, leaving those creditors in better position to claim repayment, but according to the airline's financial statement for the third quarter, it still had NT$600 million in unsecured loans.

Industry insiders said that those financial institutions that made secured loans could afford to give Far Eastern some time to get its business in order, but suggested that those banks with unsecured loans might be less forgiving and be unwilling to restructure the airline's servicing of its debts.
That could worsen FAT's credit standing and trigger a vicious cycle by dealing a further blow to the airline's credit rating and cash flow situation.
Questions were first raised over FAT's financial status on Wednesday when it bounced a check for NT$151 million for fuel and was also unable to meet its landing fee obligations.

On the same day, the International Air Transport Association's Clearing House formally notified its members that it had suspended the airline temporarily for running up US$848,000 (NT$27.14 million) in unpaid bills.

The suspension threatened FAT's code sharing arrangements with other airlines, but the airline stressed that service with its partners would continue despite the crisis. FAT operates a number of flights to China via third countries, such as South Korea, in cooperation with Chinese carriers.
Trading of FAT's shares on the Gre Tai Securities Market was also restricted, with margin transactions suspended on Thursday.
The airline, Taiwan's oldest privately owned carrier, suffered a loss of NT$3.3 billion last year through Sept. 30, according to its financial statement.

Taiwan's carriers specializing in domestic routes suffered a severe downturn after a high-speed railway became operational in the country's western corridor in Jan. 2007. Passenger rides fell from 19 million in 2006 to 12 million in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's indigenous population totals 484,000: govt

TEXT.P: Taiwan's indigenous people totaled 484,000 at the end of 2007, accounting for 2.1 percent of the country's population, according to a report released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
The number marked an increase of 1.95 percent from 2006, much higher than the growth rate of 0.36 percent for the total population, the report said.
A total of 256,000, or 52.9 percent, of the indigenous people lived in mountainous areas, according to the report.
By ethnic origins, the Amis tribe accounted for the largest number at 173,000, followed by the Atayal and the Paiwan, each accounting for approximately 80,000 people.
The eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung were home to the largest number of indigenous people, with 33.8 percent of Taitung's population and 26 percent of Hualien's population being aborigines.
The average age of indigenous people stood at 31.7, five years younger than the average of 36.7 for the total population.
Those aged 65 and over as a percentage of the population registered 6.1 percent among indigenous people, compared with 10.2 percent among all citizens.

The aging index -- the number of people aged 65 and over per 100 youths under age 15 -- stood at 25.2 percent among the indigenous population, which was also much lower than the 58.1 percent for the total population.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei County promotes environmentally-friendly online lanterns

TEXT.P: Taipei County's Environmental Protection Bureau is promoting "online sky lanterns" as an eco-friendly and safe alternative to traditional lanterns ahead of the Lantern Festival, when rice paper lanterns are lit and sent into flight.
According to the bureau, the kerosene and paper burned when releasing a single sky lantern results in the release of about one kilogram of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

Chiang Pen-Chi, section chief of the bureau's "Low-Carbon Society Development Center, " said at a press conference Friday that the online sky lanterns provided by the county government have attracted over 10,000 Taiwan residents over the past several years, resulting in a 10-ton reduction in carbon dioxide emissions.
Besides being better for the environment, the online sky lanterns offer a safer alternative to the traditional lanterns, which cause several fires in Taiwan each year.

Yang Chi-hong, director of the center, also touted the online sky lantern program, noting that all advanced countries have been making efforts to fight global warming and reduce greenhouse gas emissions while at the same time working to preserve traditional culture.

Bureau officials invited all citizens to help in these efforts ahead of the Lantern Festival by choosing the environmentally-friendly online sky lantern alternative by visiting the bureau's Web site at http://www.epb.tpc.gov.tw/.

They said members of the public can choose from among nine sky lanterns offered by the bureau -- namely lanterns that provide "peace, growth, business, happiness, dreams, sweetness, love, wealth, and brightness" -- and pray to make their wishes come true.

For those not accustomed to the idea of replacing their traditional sky lantern custom with an online version, the county government's Tourism Bureau is offering still another eco-friendly alternative free of charge.
Those interested can send a letter with their name and wish to the county government's tourism center in Pingsi, where the most popular lantern-lighting activity is held annually.

Staff members at the center will then write the names and wishes on selected lanterns during the Pingsi Sky Lantern Festival and release them in order that everyone can enjoy a new year full of hopes and aspirations.
The high point of this year's Lantern Festival in Pingsi will be held on Feb. 21, the 15th day of the first month of the new lunar year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung County to expand industrial zones for Taiwan businessmen

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County government plans to expand the southern county's industrial zones within two years as an increasing number of China-based Taiwanese business people are returning to invest in Taiwan, Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing said Friday.
Yang made the remarks at a commissioners' meeting on the development and investment of the county's industrial and commerce industries at the county government office earlier in the day.

Yang explained that some China-based Taiwan business people have started making plans to return to Taiwan as China has introduced a law to better protect the rights of its labors early this year, which has raised local labor costs.

Beijing has also ended preferential tax treatment for foreign investors, including Taiwanese companies and is putting more pressure on foreign-invested factories to reduce pollution, further driving up the cost of doing business in China.
In recent weeks, dozens of China-based Taiwan business people have inquired about how to set up factories in the county's industrial zones, Yang said.
To meet the needs of more of these business people, the county government has decided to expand the county's current industrial zones and establish new ones, he said.

On the results of county's industrial development efforts, Yang said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has listed the Southern Taiwan Science Park's branch in the county as a demonstration area for the solar energy industry.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) plans to develop solar energy technology in the county, which has attracted attention from major European companies, he said.

In addition, the Kaohsiung Science Park has a special area for the manufacturing of high value added biomedical equipment, which has already attracted five companies to set up factories there, Yang noted.
The county government also plans to work with National Cheng Kung University and Kaohsiung Medical University to set up a research center, Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military procurement should be overseen by legislature: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that it would be "more normal and reasonable" if military procurement and related industries, which are important to national security, can be overseen by the legislature.
Wang was responding to news of the creation of a new private company called Taiwan Goal that will handle overseas arms transactions and exchanges.
Although the Ministry of National Defense will have a 45 percent stake in the company, it is unclear if it will be controlled by the ministry or subject to legislative oversight.

Wang said that if the government holds only a minority stake in the company, then it is the concern of all members of the country. But should the government, or the Ministry of National Defense, hold more than 50 percent of Taiwan Goal's shares the Legislative Yuan would be legitimately able to monitor it, he suggested.
Wang said he only became aware of the company's existence Thursday after reading about it in a local daily newspaper, and had no knowledge of Taiwan Goal's operations and related matters.
He said how Taiwan Goal will fare or whether it will continue to exist will depend on the new administration elected in the March 22 presidential election.

The Ministry of National Defense confirmed on Thursday the creation of the company, formed to boost the country's national defense industry and engage in arms dealings with foreign suppliers that the government would have trouble handling.

Wu Nai-jen, a veteran member of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , has been appointed as the unpaid chairman of the company's board of directors, which sparked criticism of conflict of interest from opposition Kuomintang lawmakers.
Wu defended his role Thursday, stressing that he would step down from the post after the new president assumes office May 20 to allow a new government to control the company's leadership.

The company has contacted many foreign weapons suppliers since its founding last month in an effort to develop alliances with Taiwanese enterprises for logistics services, but no contract is likely to be signed before May 20, Wu said.

Kuomintang Legislator Lin Yu-fang criticized the move Thursday, saying that while the company was funded by public agencies and state-run firms, including Chunghua Telecom and the defense ministry, the government held only three of the seven seats on the board.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 100 students benefited from Internet afterschool program

TEXT.P: An Internet afterschool program launched by the Ministry of Education (MOE) has benefited more than 100 students across Taiwan, the ministry said Friday.

The program, designed to enhance the education of underprivileged children living in remote areas after school via the Internet, has benefited more than 100 primary and junior high school students from Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties in northern Taiwan, Nantou County in central Taiwan and Kaohsiung County in the south since it was launched in November 2006, the ministry said.

Fu Jen Catholic University in Taipei County, National Chi Nan University in Nantou County and Wen Tzao Ursuling College in Kaohsiung City administer the project in northern, central and southern Taiwan, respectively, in cooperation with the ministry.

The NT$8.5 million (US$27,000) program aims at offering extra educational assistance to students of low economic and social status as part of the government's efforts to narrow the gap between the urban and rural areas and between the rich and the poor, the ministry stressed.
To date, not one of the volunteers, teachers and students who participate in the program in northern Taiwan has quit, the ministry said.
Students in central and southern regions are provided with computers, the Internet and scanners to help them learn at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's safety industry to enjoy annual 15% growth

TEXT.P: Taiwan's safety industry is prospering and is expected to enjoy a 15 percent or 16 percent annual growth rate in the next few years, Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) Director-General Chen Chao-yih said Friday.
Chen made the remarks during a press conference to illustrate advanced products related to the safety industry developed by domestic companies.

In exhibition at the press conference were safety equipment including video phones, WebCams, 3G cell phones (with global positioning system), radio- frequency identification (RFID) apparatus, monitors for factories, carbon monoxide monitors for households, as well as monitors for nursing homes.

Despite the fact that the safety industry involves many aspects of daily life, Chen said, there are still many people dying from preventable deaths due to lack of safety alarms. He cited the example of numerous cases of people dying each year from too much exposure to carbon monoxide because their windows were closed and they did not have a detector for the poisonous gas.
"This kind of thing can be prevented easily with a gas monitor, which is generally cheap," Chen added.

Safety monitoring equipment is also urgently needed in nursing homes and for elderly people living alone, as well as in factories, sewage treatment plants and other public enterprises involving water, electricity, gas and telecommunications, Chen said.

With an increasingly aging population, the demand for safety monitoring apparatus will grow in Taiwan, Chen predicted, adding that he saw the safety industry as a star industry in the future, following Taiwan's two flagship industries -- semiconductor and panel display industries.
The production value of Taiwan's safety industry is expected to reach NT$124.5 billion (US$3.9 billion) in 2007, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Lonely Planet' publisher urges Taiwanese to be bold travelers

TEXT.P: Australian author Tony Wheeler, founder of the world's best known travel guide "Lonely Planet, on Thursday encouraged Taiwanese people to be brave travelers as he unveiled his latest book "Badlands, " which is about his experience traveling in so-called rogue states in the world.
"The hardest part is deciding to go. Don't worry if your trip would work out. Just go," Wheeler told an audience at a Taipei bookstore.
Wheeler is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the organizers of the 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition. Australia is the theme country of this year's book fair.

Wheeler urged Taiwanese people, considered one of the most traveled people in the world, to take risks and venture out to different countries. Many Taiwanese tend to join tours when they travel, but more young people are beginning to plan their own itineraries and explore a country on their own, using travel guides such as Wheeler's.

Showing slides at the book fair, Wheeler talked about all the nine "rogue states" he visited which often made headlines in newspapers and have been branded as the world's most autocratic and hazardous countries, including Afghanistan, Albania, Burma, Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea and Saudi Arabia.

Wheeler said that in his latest book, he tried to provoke readers into thinking about "what makes a country evil? " and "how bad is really bad? " by sharing his observations of each country's attitude toward human rights, terrorism and foreign policy.
The book also attempted to present colorful local landscapes and cultures and provide a frank look at life in these countries, while revealing unknown history and popular myths about the countries.

Wheeler and his wife Maureen established "Lonely Planet, " one of the world's most successful independent travel information companies, after they wrapped up their journey across Asia and Australia in the early 1970s.
The couple wrote "Across Asia on the Cheap" about the Asia overland trip soon after they got married, Wheeler said.
"The first book was totally unplanned. It was completed at the request of our friends who were interested in the trip," he said.
The book became the first tour guide published by "Lonely Planet," and proved very popular.
"We followed that with 'South-East Asia on a Shoestring' and it turned to be one of the best selling books in history," said Wheeler.
At present, the travel guide company has offices in London and Oakland, California along with headquarters in Melbourne. It employs 500 staff and 300 on-the-road authors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's five free trade zones attract 132 companies: CEPD

TEXT.P: There were 132 enterprises operating in five free trade zones (FTZs) around the country as of the end of 2007, signifying that the zones are gradually drawing interest from the private sector, the Council for Economic Planning and Development said Friday.

Logistics services providers DHL International and Federal Express Corporation set up facilities in August and December 2007 respectively in the Taoyuan Free Trade Zone, the latest companies to establish up presences there, the CEPD said.
FedEx believes that having a facility in the zone will help it expedite delivery and help enterprises in the zone handle cargo and logistic-related problems, the CEPD said.

The five FTZs, located in Keelung Harbor, Taipei Harbor, Taichung Harbor and Kaohsiung Harbor and Taoyuan Airport, allow companies to import and export materials with only cursory customs procedures as long as they are processed inside the zone.
The Taoyuan zone, operated by the Far Glory Group, began operating on Jan. 1, 2001 and has so far attracted 80 enterprises, which is ahead of schedule according to the CEPD.

In an effort to boost the competitiveness of Taiwan's FTZs compared to those in neighboring countries, the governement is considering further easing restrictions governing companies' operations in the zones, the CEPD noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsinchu City tops in population increase, birth and marriage rates

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City recorded the highest population increase, as well as birth and marriage rates in the country for January, while having the lowest death rate during the month, according to statistics released Friday by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).
The tallies revealed that Hsinchu City's population rate increase for January was 0.141 percent, ranking ahead of Hsinchu County, Taoyuan County, Taichung City and Taipei County, in that order.
Taiwan's overall population rate increase for the period was 0.03 percent, according to the MOI figures.
Keelung City had the lowest population rate increase in Taiwan, followed by Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Pingtung County and Taitung County, in that order.

Hsinchu City's natural population increase rate for the month was also the country's highest, at 0.082 percent, while Hsinchu County ranked second, followed by Taoyuan County, Taichung County and Taichung City, in that order. The country's overall natural population increase rate was 0.02 percent, according to the MOI tallies.
Hsinchu City was also tops in the country in birth rate, at 1.23 births per 1,000 population, while Keelung City ranked at the bottom of the list.

As for marriage rate, Hsinchu City and Miaoli County tied for first for the month, at 0.094 percent, followed by Hsinchu County, Taoyuan County and Taipei County. Placing at the bottom of the list was Taitung County, Penghu County and Keelung City.
Meanwhile, Hsinchu County had the lowest death rate in the country, at 0.41 deaths per 1,000 population, followed by Taipei County and Taoyuan County.

The highest death rates were recorded in Hualien County, Yunlin County, Chiayi County, Taitung County and Pingtung County, in that order, while the country's overall death rate was 0.57 per 1,000 population, according to the tallies.
Figures for the counties of Kinmen and Lienchiang were not included in the compiled statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Shoppers to pay for superstore shake-up
Supermarkets are to face public shaming and huge fines if they use their size to force down prices paid to their suppliers, the Competition Commission will announce today.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government helps goat farmers in Penghu to increase income

TEXT.P: The government has helped boost the income of goat farmers on the outlying island of Penghu by teaching them to process and package the meat for sale to consumers rather than sending live animals to Taiwan for processing, a Council of Agriculture (COA) official said Friday.

Lu Ming-tsung, director of the Penghu Working Station of the COA's Livestock Research Institute, said the institute and the Penghu County government have helped the farmers slaughter, cut, season, freeze, and put the meat into packages that can be sold to consumers around the country.

Lu said 30 to 35 packages can be made from one goat, and 2,000 packages in 15 different flavors are produced every month. Seventy percent of the production is sold in Penghu, with the rest going to Taiwan.

Goat meat is especially popular in Taiwan in the winter months for its health properties, but the institute said it is preparing to teach farmers more processing techniques to create a demand for the meat in the summer.
Penghu has two main farmer groups, raising between 5,000 and 5,500 goats annually. The animals are ready for slaughter when their weight reaches between 50 and 60 kilograms.

In the past, these live goats from Penghu were sent to Taiwan proper to process, with high transportation fees and the loss of weight or even deaths of the goats during the voyage costing Penghu farmers dearly.
Adding to their plights in 2007, Lu said, was that the wholesale price for goat meat fell to about NT$120 per kilo, down from NT$200 per kg. the previous year.
"For this reason, it is cheaper to have goats slaughtered, cut, processed and packaged in Penghu," Lu said.

To reduce the cost of raising goats, the institute also introduced to Penghu napier grass, an improved fodder grass that is a high in protein and allows farmers to cut down on the use of corn as a feed.

Farmers responded positively to the fodder grass, Lu said. Even though the grass, also known as "elephant grass", "Sudan grass" or "king grass, " can't grow in the winter, it can be stored in large volume ahead of the winter months.
"The farmers estimated that they save about NT$60,000 per month using the alternative grass," he said.

According to the Goat Farmer Association of the ROC, goats are mostly raised in areas south of Changhua. Sihu Township in the central Taiwan county is the largest goat meat auction and consumption market.
During the Chinese New Year holiday, Sihu Township reportedly slaughtered about 450 goats per day, association officials said.
The COA estimates that about 134,000 goats will be slaughtered in Taiwan in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumer's rights should be top priority in FAT crisis: minister

TEXT.P: As the financial crisis of Far Eastern Air Transport (FAT) unfolds, Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei stressed Friday that "consumers' rights must remain the priority, " adding that "the ministry and the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) will continue to assist FAT in solving its problems."

Tsai made the remarks when reporters asked him about the Taiwanese airline's financial woes, which were revealed this week, but the minister came short of providing details of any government plan to deal with the crisis.

FAT, one of Taiwan's major domestic airlines which celebrated its 50th anniversary in November 2007, filed for bankruptcy protection Friday after reporting debts of NT$9.99 billion (US$315 million) at the end of September 2007.

The airline reported a loss of NT$ 3.3 billion as of Sept. 30 last year, exceeding half of its capital. Like Taiwan's other carriers, FAT has been hit hard by a downturn in domestic air travel, partly due to competition from a new high speed rail service launched in January 2007.

So far, the company's membership in the International Air Transport Association's Clearing House (ICH) has been temporary suspended Wednesday due to its US$ 848,000 (NT$27.14 million) in unpaid bills.

Tsai Friday said the company had been a model for domestic airlines in the past 50 years, and that "FAT should now protect the rights of its customers and maintain its safety record, as well as its service."

"The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has also instructed the CAA to supervise FAT to meet the requirements in this regard, " Tsai added. The minister further urged the airline's board of directors as well as its management to make more efforts to tackle its problems, adding that "in the short run, FAT should seek a satisfactory way to solve the problems caused by its debts to the ICH."
In the long run, Tsai said, he hoped that the airline will improve its financial structure by learning a lesson from the crisis and rebuilding itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu's 'Golden-Face Matsu' statue arrives in Taipei for festival

TEXT.P: The 417-year-old "Golden-Face Matsu" icon, enshrined at the Tien Hou Temple on Taiwan's outlying island of Penghu, was brought to Taipei Friday, where the Chinese Goddess of the Sea will take part in the traditional Lantern Festival Feb. 21.
Matsu is the most worshipped local goddess in Taiwan and the Lantern Festival marks the 15th day of the Lunar New Year, which began on Feb. 7 this year.

Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa and many Matsu believers, escorting the icon, flew to Taipei earlier Friday before driving to the city hall where the historic statue was settled on the main stage of the 2008 Taipei Lantern Festival.
The festival runs from Feb. 15 to 24.

A series of traditional rituals were held at the city hall plaza Friday to mark the arrival of the important statue of the goddess in Taiwan's main island. Vice President Annette Lu and former Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh attended the ceremonies.
One of the religious rituals saw the Penghu County chief drawing eyes on a huge turtle-shaped statue made of rice to "open vision" for the symbolic "divine turtle."

The annual creation of the "divine rice turtle, " at the weight of over 2,000 kg, is part of a long tradition known in Penghu as "begging turtle for safety and wellness," which is held before to the Lantern Festival each year, Wang said.

In ancient times, people from the Chinese mainland sailed across rough waters to Penghu, struggling against high seas in search of a better life. Citing legends, Wang said people were saved by sea turtles from drowning, and therefore created icons modeled into turtles with rice and other food materials to pray to turtles for a safe year, each year. The activity is known as "begging turtle."
The activity has been held for more than 150 years on Penghu, an island off southern Taiwan proper.
Wang said the Penghu county government is making efforts to promote the event as one of the major Lantern Festival activities in the country, in a drive to boost tourism in Penghu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan college to confer honorary degrees to two foreign scientists

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Taiwan's southern city of Tainan will confer honorary degrees on two outstanding foreign scientists this month for their contribution to the school and to Taiwan's scientific development, a university official said Friday.

One of the professors is Aaron Ciechanover, who serves as a chair professor in the university. He was awarded a Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2004 for his co- discovery of one of the most important cyclical processes in biochemistry. Ciechanover is also a faculty member of the Vascular and Cancer Biology Research Center, the Rappaport Faculty of Medicine and Research Institute, and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa, Israel.

The other scientist to receive an honorary degree is Britton Chance, who is also a chair professor of the Taiwan university. He received a Ph.D. in physical chemistry in 1940 at the University of Pennsylvania, and the second Ph.D. in physiology at Cambridge University in 1942.
Chance's research interest focuses on the use of infrared light to characterize the properties of various tissues and breast tumors.
The two distinguished scientists will also be invited to attend two workshops sponsored by NCKU's Institute of Innovation and Advanced Studies (IIAS) on innovative technologies on Feb. 18.

On the sidelines of the three-day workshops, the NCKU will also invite some 200 students from major senior high schools in Taiwan to participate in a talk with Ciechanover on Feb. 20 at NCKU Hospital, with the hope of contributing to advanced education in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua Magistrate extends New Year's greetings to county citizens

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Chuo Po-yuan extended New Year's greetings to county citizens at the county government office in central Taiwan Friday, expressing gratitude to them for helping to improve the county's development.

Chuo said with citizens' help, the central government passed the county's proposal of expanding land for the county's Changhua City before the Chinese New Year holiday. The plan allows the county to gain additional land of over 1,000 hectares.

Chuo wished each citizen a happy new year and spoke of the hope that there will be more good news on the county's development, but did not elaborate. He invited county staff and the public to continue making efforts to improve the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records breakthrough in staphylococcus aureus research

TEXT.P: A team from Taiwan's top research institution, Academia Sinica, has found a way to fight staphylococcus aureus, a bacterium that is a common cause of staph infections which has grown resistant to many antibiotics.
The finding was published Friday in Science Express, an internationally renowned science publication.

The team discovered that cholesterol-lowering medicines will effectively block staphylococcus aureus from using a cartenoid pigment to turn itself into the golden color that enables it to avoid being destroyed by white blood cells.
Researchers expected that the research finding would soon result in the development of a medication that could tackle the bacterium more effectively, Academia Sinica said in a statement.

Staphylococcus aureus, also known as golden staph, produces hospital and community-acquired infections. When the bacterium is resistant to penicillins, known formally as methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus, it poses a serious threat to public health, the statement said.
The bacterium can cause a range of illnesses, including minor skin infections, boils, cellulitis, and more major problems such as pneumonia, meningitis, and toxic shock syndrome.

Staphylococcus aureus inside a human body uses a golden pigment, called staphyloxanthin, to avoid being destroyed by white blood cells, or leukocytes, which are the cells of the immune system defending the body against both infectious disease and foreign materials, the statement said.
The team that made the discovery, composed of several experts from Taiwan and the United States, was led by Academia Sinica Vice President Andrew Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Convenience store to open tearoom appealing to women

TEXT.P: A local convenience store is joining with a Japanese partner to open a tearoom in Taipei that will cater primarily to women to capitalize on the growing purchasing power of female consumers, a company executive said Friday.

Taiwan-based President Chain Store Corp. which runs over 3,000 7-Elevens on the island, has entered into a joint venture with Japan's Sazaby League, to introduce Sazaby's "Afternoon Tea TEAROOM" franchise to Taiwan, said James Hsieh, the company's chief of strategy.

President will hold 51 percent of the venture's shares. Sazaby, involved in fashion, lifestyle stores, and food franchises, will hold the remaining 49 percent. Their goal is to open 10 outlets in Taiwan by 2010.

The two companies have already teamed up to introduce the tearoom brand in China last year. Their first restaurant in Taiwan, to be located in Taipei, began trial operations Thursday and is scheduled to be formally opened Feb. 21.
"Afternoon Tea TEAROOM will be designed to appeal to female customers, serving delicate and exquisite food and providing good service and a comfortable dining environment for women, " Hsieh said.
Sazaby League sent three high-ranking executives from Japan to train personnel in Taiwan, he added.

The companies are betting that the spending power of women will grow increasingly dominant in the future, with Hsieh estimating that women will eventually guide 80 percent of the Taiwan's consumer market.

The consumption power of women has already risen substantially in the past decade, Hsieh said, with the income of females growing 1.6 times during that period while that of males has only risen 1.4 times.
To ensure the business has a feminine touch, The executive in charge of the brand in Taiwan will also be a woman, Hsieh said.
The venture plans to open one more outlet in 2008 with locations along MRT lines to be the first considered when opening new stores, Hsieh said.
The chain store also cooperates with Duskin, Japan's biggest doughnut retail chain, and America's Cold Stone Creamery and Starbucks Coffee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local cartoonist clinches top award in graphic novel competition

TEXT.P: A local cartoonist has clinched the Supreme Champion Award of the 2007 Graphic Novel Awards presented by the Government Information Office (GIO), according to a GIO official.

GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey presented the Supreme Champion Award to 26-year-old Hung Pei-en during a ceremony held Thursday at the Animated Cartoon Hall in the Taipei World Trade Center, where the six-day 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition is being held. Also present was veteran cartoonist Liu Hsing-ching.
Hung earned a medal, a certificate and NT$700,000 (US$22,082), according to the official.
The GIO gave out NT$3.6 million in prizes to this year's 10 award winners, the official added.

The GIO has decided to make bilingual brochures in Chinese and English carrying excerpts from the award recipients' cartoon novels and display them at several well-known overseas book fairs in an effort to make local cartoon works known to the rest of the world, according to the official.

The GIO has been promoting the local cartoon industry over the past few years, organizing competitions related to the Graphic Novel Awards on a regular basis, Shieh said, noting that the GIO has also subsidized local cartoon publishers, helping them launch inventive cartoon publications regularly.
The GIO hopes the country's cartoon industry can have a transfusion of new talented cartoonists as a result of the awards, Shieh added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola prepares to greet its 3 millionth rider

TEXT.P: Five painted Maokong gondolas greeted riders Friday as the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC), the operator of the new cable car system, is preparing to celebrate the arrival of its 3 millionth passenger.

Transit Corp. officials said the system, which was inaugurated on July 4, 2007, is expected to see passenger volume hit 3 million this Sunday, and the painted gondolas are part of the celebrations by the company to mark that occasion.

Other activities to celebrate the high ridership include installation of the LED lamp under the seats in the gondola cars to create a romantic atmosphere at night in the mountainous area where the cable car system is located.

The Transit Corp. is also preparing to present each rider with a bottle of cute gondola-shaped mineral water on the day when the passenger volume hits 3 million. A total of 10,000 bottles will be given out.

The Maokung cable car system, which connects two popular tourist attractions -- the Taipei Zoo and the Mucha tea growing district -- is the longest gondola in Taiwan, at a length of 4.03 km. It takes only 20 minutes to travel between the two terminals.

Transit Corp. officials said that according to a market survey of 1,108 riders over 16 years old, up to 80 percent said they were satisfied with the ride, and 94 percent said they would recommend it to friends and relatives.
Also, 84 percent of passengers said they are willing to ride the cable car again.

The survey also found that 73 percent of the patrons said they took the ride because they wanted to experience it and 55 percent said they would also visit the scenic spots along the route, with the biggest percentage -- 35 percent -- saying they wanted to visit the Taipei Zoo, one of the four stops, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Collecting kitchen leftovers beneficial: EPA

TEXT.P: The government will continue to promote a leftovers collection policy that has proven itself to be eco-friendly and financially rewarding, the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) announced Friday.

The policy, fully implemented throughout Taiwan's 25 cities and counties, can earn NT$2.9 billion (US$92 million) annually for national coffers, EPA officials said. The amount of leftovers collected from around the country exceeds 1,800 metric tons per day, they noted.

Kitchen scraps can be used as compost or hog feed, which helps farmers save on fertilizer costs and saves the government from burning the leftovers in two incinerators capable of handling 900 tons of garbage every day, the officials explained.
The success of this program to recycle leftovers has drawn the affirmation of countries around the world, the EPA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Visitors warned against littering during Lantern Festival

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government urged the public Friday not to litter in the upcoming Lantern Festival, warning that violators will face fines of up to NT$6,000 (US$195).

Kuo Yung, deputy director of the municipal Environmental Protection Bureau, said that 24 classified recycling spots staffed by 50 environmental protection activists will be set up at the square of the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall -- the main venue of this year's Lantern Festival celebrations -- and its neighborhood.
The festive activities were kicked off Friday and will run through Feb. 24.

Kuo urged visitors to the festival not to throw rubbish or garbage in the hall's compound and its neighboring areas. He warned that fines ranging from NT$1,200 to NT$6,000 can be imposed on those caught.
Throughout the hall's neighborhood, 120 inspectors and 160 scavengers, coupled with 280 volunteers will be dispatched to help maintain street cleanness during the 10-day festival, according to Kuo.

It is the first time that the Taipei city government will host the annual event at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall instead of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, which used to be named the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall until late last year.
During the 2007 Lantern Festival, municipal officials issued 320 littering tickets.

Meanwhile, municipal authorities announced Friday that 80,000 small lanterns featuring the animal of this Lunar New Year, an auspicious rat, will be given away to the public from Saturday. According to lunar calendar, the Year of the Rat began on Feb. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four Taiwan academics elected members of U.S. Academy of Engineering

TEXT.P: Four American academics of Taiwanese origin have been elected as new members of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) of the United States, according to a news release posted on the academy's Web site earlier this week.
The four are among 61 other U.S. members and nine foreign associates elected to the academy this year.

NAE President Charles M. Vest said in the news release that with the 65 new members and nine new foreign associates, the academy's U.S. membership has increased to 2,227 and its number of foreign associates has risen to 194.
Vest will present certificates to the new members and foreign associates at the academy's principal office in Washington, D.C. at a time yet to be announced.
The four members from Taiwan are:

-- Mau-Chung Frank Chang: Professor in the electrical engineering department of the University of California, Los Angeles; elected for the development and commercialization of gallium arsenide (GaAs) power amplifiers and integrated circuits.

-- Lee-Lueng Fu: Senior project scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, California; elected for his contributions to the development of satellite altimetry and applications in oceanography, geodesy, and climatology.

-- Burn-Jeng Lin: senior director of nanopatterning technology at Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Taiwan; elected for his technical innovations and leadership in the development of lithography for semiconductor manufacturing.

-- William W-G. Yeh: distinguished professor and chair of the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles; elected for the development of methodologies for optimizing the management of water resources, and for inverse methods of estimating subsurface parameters.
Two academics of Chinese origin were also elected:

-- Stephen Z.D. Cheng: Dean of the College of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering, University of Akron, Ohio; elected for the development of materials for liquid crystal displays and the elucidation of structure- property relationships in polymeric materials.

-- Zhigang Suo: Professor of mechanics and materials at the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences of Harvard University in Massachusetts; elected for his fundamental and applied contributions to the thermo-mechanical performance of electronic material systems, actuator materials, and composites.
The NAE, established in 1964, is a private, independent, nonprofit institution. It provides advisory services to the U.S. federal government through the National Research Council.

Election to the NAE is one of the highest professional honors accorded to an engineer. Its members are elected by current NAE members for having distinguished themselves in business and academic management, in technical positions, as university faculty, or as leaders in government and private engineering organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest NT$1 billion to boost tourism: premier

TEXT.P: Taiwan will invest NT$1 billion (US$31.25 million) to boost the country's tourism industry over the next two years, and has set a target of attracting 4 million foreign visitors to Taiwan in 2008, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung announced Friday.
Introducing the "Tour Taiwan 2008-2009 Plan, " Chang was upbeat over tourism growth in 2007, when 3.71 million foreigners visited Taiwan, an increase of 5.82 percent over the previous year.
He said investing in the sector would help reach the target of 4 million visitors in 2008 and pay substantial dividends.

"We will strengthen Taiwan's international promotion activities and create a high-quality environment to achieve the goal, which is expected to generate revenues of NT$192.1 billion (US$ 6 billion) for Taiwan, " said Chang, who stressed that developing Taiwan's tourism sector has always been a main concern of the government.

Noting that the new plan would create new job opportunities and develop the nation's economy, the premier said "it will also boost Taiwan's international image and increase foreigners' familiarity with the country."

Expressing special thanks to the Japanese tour operators and travel agencies present at the ceremony, Transportation and Communications Minister Tsai Duei hoped even more tourists from Japan will come to visit "the beautiful island of Taiwan."
Of the 3.71 million visitor arrivals here in 2007, 1.16 million were from the Japan, according to statistics released by the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai promised to develop more promotional tools to lure international visitors, including launching Web sites in Chinese, English and Japanese for major events being held in Taiwan, such as the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and the 21st Summer Deaflympics in Taipei in 2009.
"We'll do this to serve foreigners so they can develop a better understanding of the events," Lai said.

Other measures aimed at attracting more international tourists include offering big prizes to the 1 millionth, 2 millionth, 3 millionth and 4 millionth visitor for the year, and providing discounts to independent travelers as well as organized tour groups.
Lai appealed to all Taiwanese people to promote Taiwan together and said that "on behalf on Taiwan, every Taiwanese should invite more foreign friends to visit the island."

DOC.HEADLINE: Questions for presidential debate announced

TEXT.P: The organizers of two presidential debates between ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh and his Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Ma Ying-jeou, announced Friday the 20 questions that local citizens will ask the candidates in their first debate.

The questions, asked via citizen-generated videos, were chosen from 465 submissions, and will touch on national identity, environmental protection, foreign relations, the economy, finance, human rights, the integrity of the government, and the possibility of building a casino on the outlying island of Penghu.

The candidates will also be asked how they would lead Taiwan into the ranks of countries with per capita income of US$30,000, whether they would legalize gay marriage during their term in office, and how they would boost the country's declining birth rate.
Other topics to be addressed include education reform and the treatment of former corrupt government officials.
Each candidate will be required to answer each question, and the 20 questioners will be on hand to follow up with the candidates if they feel the need to do so.
The first debate will take place on Feb. 24.

During the second debate to be held March 9, the candidates will answer questions raised by organizing media organizations, including Public Television Service (PTS) station, the Central News Agency (CNA), the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News, and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: China to face more international pressure before Olympics: MAC

TEXT.P: China is expected to face intensified pressure from the international community before the Beijing Olympics over its support for Sudan's government, but Taiwan so far has no plans to boycott the Games, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.

"The Olympic Games have been given multiple meanings. As the host country, China has been under tremendous pressure, but it should not shun its obligations as a member of the international community either, " MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said in response to a question on American film director Steven Spielberg's withdrawal as an artistic adviser to the Beijing Olympics.

Spielberg made the announcement Tuesday after failing to prod China to do more to end the conflict in Darfur in western Sudan that has left hundreds of thousands dead and displaced more than 2 million people.

Before Spielberg withdrew, a number of celebrities, international media watchdogs and human rights organizations had been calling for a boycott of the 2008 Olympics because of China's support for the Sudanese government, which has been blamed for most of the atrocities in the conflict and used Chinese-made weapons against its enemies.
Asked if Taiwan would consider boycotting the event, Liu said that "there have been no substantial discussions on that matter from our side."

China has been engaging in an intense competition for energy and mineral products as part of its "peaceful rise, " which was why it had to develop close diplomatic relations with a number of authoritarian regimes, Liu said.

The United Nations and other international organizations are trying to pressure China and ask it to play a more positive and responsible role in handling the Darfur situation and domestic human rights protection, Liu said.

"If China wants to assure the international community about its peaceful rise, it should not merely sit by and watch -- or shield -- the injustice in front of its face. For the international community, that would be ironic and reveal China's anti-democratic attitude and lack of respect for human rights, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pavilion attracts visitors at Philippine travel expo
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb.15 (CNA) 02/15/08 21:51:56 (By Emerson Lim & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Visitors at the Philippine 15th Travel Tour Expo 2008 swarmed into the Taiwan pavilion Friday, attracted by many promotional "tour Taiwan" packages and free tickets to tourist sites.
The annual Travel Tour Expo, the biggest annual event in the Philippines' travel and tourism industry, kicked off Friday in Pasay City, a southern suburb of the capital Manila.

A total of 345 booths were set up at the venue by governmental tourism departments, airlines, cruise lines and travel agencies from 23 countries, according to the organizers, the Philippine Department of Tourism and the Philippine Travel Agencies Association.

Three companies had booths in the Taiwan pavilion: the Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) , Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) and Jeron Travel and Tours Co., run by Taiwanese businessmen operating in the Philippines.

Attending the annual expo for the first time, the TVA's booth featured a signboard reading "Tour Taiwan Years" and introduced visitors to Taiwan's scenic tourist spots, cultural activities, food and fashion.
TVA marketing manager Chou Huei-chin said 2008 and 2009 are the "Tour Taiwan Years, " a government-initiated program aimed at attracting foreign tourists to the country.

Under the program, travelers visiting Taiwan on a holiday will enjoy many special deals, including free tickets for rides on Taipei's MRT or Kaohsiung cruise boats and entrance to amusement parks, Chou said.
CAL also made special offers to spur new business, offering round trip tickets between Taipei or Kaohsiung and Manila for US$280, about US$100 less than normally charged.
Taiwan's Executive Yuan ratified the "Tour Taiwan Years" program in late 2007, which aims to increase the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan to over 4 million this year.
An average of 5,000 Filipinos a month applied for visas to Taiwan in 2007, most of whom were migrant workers, according to figures from Taiwan's representative office in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD to continue providing computer courses for women in rural areas

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development has decided to continue a subsidized program to provide free computer courses for women in rural areas aimed at bridging the digital disparity between cities and rural areas.

The council will earmark NT$30 million (US$94,518) from the Executive Yuan's Sino-American Fund for Economic and Social Development for the program, more than doubling the its NT$14.5 million budget in 2007 when it trained over 10,000 women.
This year's program is expected to benefit over 20,000 women, with NT$1,500 the maximum amount participants in the program can receive, the CEPD said.

Under the project, the council will subsidize non-profit organizations to provide 24 hours of basic computer training to the course attendees. This year's courses will be begin later this month at the earliest.
The CEPD said most Taiwanese women, especially those in rural areas, dedicate more time than men to taking care of children and family chores and thus have little time to learn computer skills.

The program offers them basic computer skills so that they can have access to better job opportunities, improve their interpersonal relations and create more communication channels with their children.
With their computer skills, they can also acquire further education in many fields, the council said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to give up 'quit and win' contest due to funding shortage

TEXT.P: Taiwan cannot participate in this year's "quit and win" contest, an activity promoted by the World Health Organization to encourage people to quit smoking, because of a shortage of funds, a foundation in charge of running the activity in Taiwan said Friday.

Lin Ching-li, the director of the tobacco section of the John Tung Foundation, noted that more than 70 countries have responded to the drive to sponsor the activities every second year, and Taiwan has held the contest three times since 2002.
But with this year's activity requiring NT$10 million (US$312,500) in funding, and the group having only raised NT$400,000 of NT$900,000 pledged so far, it has had to abandon its plans, Lin said.

"The foundation was forced to give up the contest. The limited amount of money collected will be used on an anti-smoking campaign, ' she said, dismissing any suggestions that the contest could be salvaged.
"Even if we continued to solicit donations, there would not be enough time left, " she added, noting that the foundation needed two months to prepare for the contest scheduled for May.

Lin said the sluggish economy has dampened the interest of businesses in contributing to the activity and some state-owned enterprises said that they could not make any contributions prior to the inauguration of the new president May 20.
The foundation has been the event's major sponsor the last three times it has been held, but it stopped receiving official donations in 2006.
The international smoking cessation competition is organized every second year by the National Public Health Institute of Finland and supported by the World Health Organization.

Adult smokers who have smoked for at least one year can register for the contest. The goal is to abstain from smoking for a specified period of four weeks in May. At the end of this period, every country selects one winner who receives a national prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung City marks 20th anniversary of sisterhood with Portland

TEXT.P: The southern port city of Kaohsiung celebrated the 20th anniversary of its sister city relations with Portland, Oregon, at a local school Friday, with performances staged by both sides.

The celebration was attended by Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Chiu Tai-san, and a delegation from Portland led by Portland-Kaohsiung Sister City Association President Tom Crowder and Portland's Rose Festival Queen Elizabeth Larson.
Kaohsiung City formed its sisterhood with Portland, a city known for its green spaces and commitment to environmental protection, in 1988.
The delegation will also join this year's Kaohsiung Lantern Festival slated for Feb. 16-March 2, and will also visit several prominent sightseeing spots to gain a better understanding of the city.
The celebration was held at Kaohsiung City's Shu-Te Home Economics and Commercial High School, which has participated for many years in Portland's Rose Festival, an annual civic festival in Portland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009 begins with concert at Sun Moon Lake

TEXT.P: The "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" program mapped out by the Tourism Bureau was launched Friday with a concert at scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan and the opening of a cherry festival around the lake.
From Feb. 15 through March 8, a two-hour concert will take place at 7 p.m. every Friday and Saturday near the Shueishe Pier and the Shueishe Tourist Service Center.

According to officials of the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area Administration, the cherry festival will run until March 16. To help visitors get around, 10 free shuttle buses ferrying tourists between the Formosa Aborigine Cultural Village and the Shuili and Checheng train stations in Shueili Township will be provided.
Hotels around the lake will offer discounts, while tourist bus companies will allow one passenger in every group of five a free ride when they purchase one- day or two-day travel packages.

Tourism officials pointed out that the Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009 program includes a wide range of events and activities to enable international visitors to familiarize themselves with local culture and customs and enjoy Taiwan's nature and scenery.

Major events include the Taiwan Lantern Festival, the Dajia Mazu International Festival, the Yangmingshan Flower Season, the Hakka Tung Flower Festival, the Dragon Boat Festival, the Taiwan Food Festival, the Blue Fin Tuna Cultural Festival, and the Keelung Ghost Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City commits itself to improve worker safety

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Bureau of Labor Affairs has designated 2008 as "Worker Safety Year" and will impose strict guidelines to help companies prevent their workers from suffering occupational injuries, a city official said Friday.

Chang Chi-yu, head of the bureau's Labor Standards Inspection Office, made the pledge after the office staged a skit to show the city government's resolve to fully protect workers' safety in partnership with private enterprises.

Beginning this year, employers are required to report in detail to the inspection office potential dangers their laborers might encounter when working on large-scale renovation or construction projects or when operating dangerous machinery or equipment, Chang said.

Construction workers are the highest-risk group among all sectors in terms of occupational casualties, said Chang, citing 2007 statistics which showed that 28 workers were killed at their work places in Taipei City, 22 of whom were construction workers.
No major occupational casualty or death has occurred since the beginning of the year, and the campaign, Chang said, hoped to keep the record clean.
With the designation of 2008 as the "Worker Safety Year, " Taipei hopes to raise companies' awareness of their employees' safety in the workplace, he said.

In a related development, Council of Labor Affairs Deputy Minister Kuo Fang-yu inked a "safe partnership pledge" with Taiwan Power Corp. President Cheng-yi Tu Friday, promising to fully protect laborers' safety and health at the construction site of the fourth nuclear power plant in Gongliao Township in Taipei County.
Seven workers have been killed at the site since construction of the facility began in 1998, including two this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourist arrivals expected to break 4 million for 2008

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that the number of tourist arrivals is expected to break the 4 million mark this year thanks to concerted efforts by the government and the travel service sector.

On the day when Taiwan launched its "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" campaign, Chen said his administration had given priority to promoting the domestic tourist industry, with the number of foreign visitors rising from 2.62 million in 2000 to 3.71 million last year.

Chen singled out the growth of Japanese tourists to Taiwan as a major achievement. Although Japan suffered from a slumping economy and soaring airfares that resulted in a decline in the number of overall Japanese outbound travelers last year, the number of Japanese vacationers to Taiwan still registered a rise from the 2006 level.

"Japan was the largest source of visitors to Taiwan, accounting for 31.39 percent of total tourist arrivals for 2007, " said Chen, who was speaking to foreign travel service executives invited to Taipei by the Tourism Bureau for the contributions to the local tourist sector.
He voiced his appreciation for the dedicated efforts of Taiwanese and Japanese tour operators in organizing attractive holiday packages to lure more visitors to Taiwan.

Over the past year, Chen said, the number of toruists from South Korea, Singapore and Malaysia also posted large increases thanks to joint efforts of tourist officials and travel agents at home and abroad.

With the launch of the "Tour Taiwan Years" promotional campaign, Chen said the government will assist local travel agents in offering a myriad of diverse travel packages by fusing tradition with innovative sensibility.
"Through the investment of up to NT$1 billion over the next two years, the annual number of tourist arrivals will hopefully exceed 4 million to hit 4.25 million this year," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics Minister pondering whether to ban rebar exports

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve Ruey-long Chen said Friday that he will make a decision next week on whether to ban exports of reinforcing steel bars, or rebars, in response to calls by property developers to stabilize domestic rebar prices.
Chen said Taiwan exported 378,000 metric tons of rebars between January and November 2007, but felt the amount would not have a big impact on local prices.
"The quantity was not large, and even if a ban is imposed on rebar exports, it would not help too much," he said.

The request to ban exports of the bars was made by Lai Cheng-i, deputy chairman of the federation of real estate development associations around Taiwan because rising prices of steel products in international markets have had a negative impact on Taiwan's construction industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA approves two China-bound investment projects

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) gave preliminary approval Friday to two major China-bound investment projects at a review meeting Friday.

Minister Steve Reuy-long Chen said the two projects "will have a positive effect on Taiwan's economic development, " referring to Formosa Plastics Group's plan to invest US$100 million in a specialty steel company in Zhangzhou, Fujian province, and semiconductor packager and tester ASE's plan to increase its investment in its Shanghai packaging plant by US$30 million.

Chen made the remarks after presiding over an interministerial conference on whether the projects were in line with the government's "active management and effective opening" policy regarding investment in China.
"Now that the projects have passed policy-related screening, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs is expected to formally approve them next week," Chen said.

FPG Chairman Li Chih-chun, Formosa Heavy Industry Corp. President Wu Kuo-hsiung, and ASE Chairman Jason Chang all attended the meeting to explain in detail their investment plans and future business development blueprints.
They reported on their financing plans, technology transfer and equipment delivery as well as matching investment in Taiwan and their globalization plan.

Chen said FPG pledged that its investment in Taiwan will reach NT$813.3 billion (US$25.67 billion) in five years, and that related equipment will be produced in Taiwan and delivered to China. The technical and management staff will be recruited in Taiwan to create job opportunities.
Chen said ASE has invested over NT$145 billion in Taiwan, and indicated it would continue to increase investment in Taiwan depending on market cicumstances.

This is the third time that the ministry has convened a policy-related screening meeting. The ministry had previously approved investment projects by semiconductor manufacturers to relocate their old 8-inch-wafer plants using a 0.25-micron manufacturing process to China.
The government also approved an application by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. to use 0.18-micro chip manufacturing technology at its wafer foundry in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 16, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, Polish astronomer, is born. He advanced the theory that the earth and other planets revolve around the sun, discrediting the Ptolemaic model of the universe.
1659: A new way of paying money without using either coinage or a letter of credit is first used in England when Mr. Nicholas Vanacker signs a "cheque" to a creditor.
1884: Robert J. Flaherty, U.S. explorer and filmmaker, is born. His works, including "Nanook of the North," were the world's first major documentaries.
1906: British labor representatives meet in London to establish the Labour Party.
1918: Lithuania, which is located in Northern Europe, proclaims its independence from Russia.
1931: The Control Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1937: The synthetic material nylon, which was developed by the U.S. chemist Wallace Carothers, is patented.
1942: Kim Jong Il, North Korean leader, is born.
1944: Allied aircraft bomb a Japanese naval base at Truk in the Caroline Islands, destroying some 200 planes.
1945: The United States starts massive air raids on Tokyo as U.S. forces capture Bataan in the Philippines during World War II.
1959: Fidel Castro becomes the leader of Cuba at the age of 32.
1960: The USS Triton begins an underwater voyage around the world, becoming the first nuclear submarine to undertake such a journey.
1968: A China Air Transportation plane flying from Hong Kong to Taipei crashes in Linkuo, killing 21 and injuring 43.
1970: The Directorate General of Posts starts nighttime business operations.
1973: Robert E. Page, vice president of United Press International, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The Republic of China revalues the New Taiwan dollar upward by 5 percent against the U.S. dollar. The new exchange rate is NT$38 to US$1.
1976: A new radar control system is inaugurated at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan.
1976: Yu Hao-chang, former ROC Army commander in chief, returns to Taipei after more than a year of medical treatment in the United States.
1983: The Dutch airline Martinair inaugurates flight services to Taiwan, marking the first air link between the Netherlands and the Republic of China.
1986: A China Airlines Boeing 737 plane crashes near Makung, in Taiwan's Penghu Islands, killing all 13 aboard.
1992: OPEC member countries agree to cut oil output by 1 million barrels a day.
1994: An earthquake claims 134 lives and injures at least 550 in southern Sumatra in Indonesia.
1994: The Helenic Republic (Greece) declares an embargo on the Macedonian Republic in a conflict over the use of the name Macedonia. The two countries later reached an agreement on the use of the formal name "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" for the latter's entry into the United Nations.
1998: A China Airlines Airbus A-300 plane returning from Bali crashes near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, killing all 116 aboard and six people on the ground.
2000: Two destroyers of the Republic of China, the Loyang and Suiyang, are decommissioned after more than two decades of active service.
2000: The ruling Kuomintang formally files a lawsuit against independent presidential candidate and former KMT Secretary-General James Soong, accusing him of embezzling party funds.
2004: Taiwan's Government Information Office and National Geographic Channel International announce a cooperative project on documentary production aimed at introducing Taiwan's natural beauty and cultural legacy to the world.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The common people should be educated in what they ought to do; not to ask why they should do it."

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Hongbao Budget.
Singaporeans received a $1.8 billion surplus-sharing hong bao from Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam yesterday.This year's Budget comes stuffed with personal income tax rebates of up to $2,000, cash gifts all round in the form of Growth Dividends, and top-ups to Medisave.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The Budget for uniting people and creating advantages.
Singapore Government announced new fiscal year budget yesterday which share S$1.8 billion surplus to Singaporeans, to build a first- class economy and a the society have the resilience, and to help every Singaporean can seize new opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Most decorative items sold at stationery stores substandard: BSMI

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of low-cost fashion accessories available at stationery or bookstores are substandard, and some even contain excessive amounts of toxic substances, Taiwan's standards bureau said Friday.

The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs recently tested 24 accessories randomly selected from local bookstores and stationery shops that are popular with elementary and junior high school students.

The selected items included bracelets, wristbands, ankle bracelets, necklaces, earrings, rings, hair pins and medallions, with prices ranging between NT$10 (US$0.31) and NT$99 apiece, the bureau said.

Test results showed that 19 of the 24 items failed to meet specified standards, a failure rate of 79.2 percent. A common defect found among the substandard items was the tendancy for small components on the accessories to come loose easily or break.
More worrying, however, was that four of the articles were found to contain excessive amounts of lead, with one even reaching 2,305 ppm, far higher than the limit of 90 ppm, the bureau said.
If the lead-contaminated items were swallowed accidentally by small children, their nervous system could be harmed or they might fall victim to acute lead poisoning, the bureau said.
Based on the results, the bureau has ordered the immediate recall or destruction of the items that were found to be substandard.
The survey also discovered that product labeling was subpar. The Chinese- language labels on 16 of the inspected items, or two-thirds of the total, failed to meet government-established standards.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen-Xiamen passenger ferry catches fire

TEXT.P: A passenger ferry sailing from Xiamen in southeastern China to the Taiwan- controlled outlying island of Kinmen caught fire Saturday morning, with the blaze trapping more than 10 crew members.

The fire occurred on the Xiamen-registered "Tong An" vessel after it had docked in Kinmen. All 37 passengers aboard the ship were able to disembark, but as of noon Saturday, firefighters were still trying to put out the blaze and rescue the crew.
Preliminary reports speculated that the fire was sparked by a faulty electric wire. There were no reports of casualties.
It was the first time a passenger ship sailing the "mini-links" route betweeen China and Kinmen had caught fire since the links were opened in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMS the most popular way to send Chinese New Year's greetings: survey

TEXT.P: Fewer people in Taiwan planned to follow the tradition of visiting relatives or friends during the Chinese New Year holiday this year, with text messages replacing the time-honored practice, a survey has found.

According to the results of a survey conducted Jan. 16-29 among 1,361 office workers by online employment broker 1111 Job Bank, while only 66.86 percent of respondents said they would take the initiative to send their best wishes for the Chinese New Year, using text messages to do so was favored by 93.08 percent of the respondents in a multiple choice question.

Another 57.14 percent of the respondents said they would call their friends while 37.47 percent said they would send their greetings by e-mail or card. Only 35.27 percent said they would visit their relatives or friends in person to offer their greetings.
Among the respondents who said they would send text messages, 56 percent planned to write them themselves instead of using readily available standard messages.

Asked to whom they would send text messages, 96.69 percent of respondents planned to send them to friends, 57.62 percent were sending them to colleagues, 26.92 percent were sending them to relatives and 16.17 percent were sending them to their supervisors.
Among the respondents who were not considering the use of text messages, 50.79 percent thought it would be more sincere to use other methods, while 49.21 percent were simply too lazy to type.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temperatures to rise across Taiwan over next week: CWB

TEXT.P: Temperatures across Taiwan are expected to rise Saturday and into next week as the cold front affecting the island for nearly the past two weeks gradually dissipates, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

The CWB forecast highs of 16 degrees Celsius in northern Taiwan, 19 C in central regions, 16 C in the northeastern part of the island, 22 C in the south, 16 C in the outlying county of Penghu and 16 C on Kinmen Island.

Chiayi County was forecast to experience a low of 10 C in the early morning hours due to the influence of a radiational cooling effect, which is particularly pronounced when heat radiates from the earth's surface under clear skies, CWB meteorologists said.

Meanwhile, the northeastern and eastern parts of Taiwan are expected to see sporadic rain and cloudy skies Saturday, with the chance of rainfall increasing in most areas around the island the following day, according to the CWB.
CWB meteorologists said temperatures are expected to continue rising over the next week, with Taiwan's central and southern regions forecast to experience highs of above 20 C Sunday.
Northern Taiwan is expected to see highs of over 20 C before the Lantern Festival on Feb. 21, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former legislator shot in Taipei County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/16/08 15:09:38 (By Howard Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Former lawmaker Lee Sen-zong, who lost his seat in January's legislative elections, was shot in the chest early Saturday morning in Taipei County after trying to get away from two men who had abducted him.
Lee was walking to his car after attending a party at a friend's house at around 4:30 a.m. when two individuals jumped him and dragged him into their car.

A little over 10 minutes into their journey, the driver of the car pulled to the side of the road after spotting a police patrol car to avoid suspicion. Lee jumped out of the vehicle to try and catch the attention of the policemen, but was shot in the right side of the chest.
He was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital and is in stable condition, according to NTUH Department of Traumatology doctor Han Yin-yi, who treated him.
As of Saturday noon, Lee's assailants had yet to be apprehended and the motive for the attack remained unclear.

President Chen Shui-bian expressed deep concern over the shooting as soon as he was informed of it and ordered police to immediately open an investigation into the incident, the Presidential Office said.

National Police Agency Director-General Hou Yu-ih, one of those who rushed to the hospital after the shooting, said the police collected bullet shells and other evidence left at the crime scene that they hoped would lead them to the suspects.
Hou expressed confidence that the case would be solved very soon.

Lee was elected to two terms as a Taipei County councilor, and then served five consecutive terms in Taiwan's legislature between 1993 and 2008 as a member of the Kuomintang (KMT) representing Taipei County.

When he failed to win a nomination as a KMT candidate in the Jan. 12 legislative polls, he defected to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, becoming that party's nominee in Taipei County's first district. The move proved unsuccessful as he failed to win re-election, garnering just under 40 percent of the vote in the district.
Also expressing concern over the incident, Executive Yuan spokesman Shieh Jyh- wey said the Cabinet hopes the police will get to the bottom of the matter soon and wishes Lee an early recovery.
Others who visited Lee at the hospital were Criminal Investigation Bureau Commissioner Huang Mao-sui and incumbent KMT Legislator Lin Yu-fang.
