DOC.HEADLINE: Crew rescued from fire-stricken Kinmen-Xiamen ferry

TEXT.P: All 19 crew members aboard a passenger ferry that caught fire Saturday at a port in Kinmen were rescued after being trapped by the blaze, which was still smoldering as of Saturday afternoon.
Only one crew member was reported suffering from minor smoke inhalation.

The fire occurred on the Xiamen-registered "Tong An" vessel after it had arrived at Shuitou Wharf in Taiwan-controlled Kinmen from Xiamen on China's southeastern coast, and all its 37 passengers had disembarked. As of noon Saturday, firefighters were still trying to put out the blaze and rescue the crew.
Preliminary reports speculated that the fire was sparked by a faulty electric wire.
It was the first time a passenger ship plying the route between China and Kinmen had caught fire since the links were opened in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: High speed railway offers business class discount

TEXT.P: Business class tickets for travel on Taiwan's high speed railway will be discounted by 20 percent starting March 1, an official of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corporation (THSRC) announced Friday.
Senior citizens, passengers under 12 and groups, who already were eligible for a 5 percent discount on business class tickets, will now enjoy a 25 percent discount for the higher class of service.

Ted Chia, assistant manager of THSRC's Public Affairs Division, said business class -- which usually occupies one of the 12 passenger cars on an average high speed train -- has had low load factors because of the short travel times, and he hoped the discount would fill up some of the many empty seats.

"There is no deadline for this offer, " Chia said. "Senior citizens can take advantage of this along with the original five percent discount to enjoy more spacious seating, making the journey more pleasant."

With the discount, the price of a one-way business class ticket for the 96 minute to two-hour trip between Taipei in the north and Zuoying in the south would fall from the original NT$2,440 (US$76) to NT$1,950 (US$59), or just NT$460 (US$14) more than the economy class fare, THSRC said in a statement.

Touting the advantages of traveling business class, Chia said Taipei, Taichung, and Zuoying all had ticket counters dedicated to business class passengers to provide faster and more convenient service, and noted that riders in business class received free coffee, tea, or bottled water and had access to personal entertainment systems.

The high-speed railway, which operates between Taipei and Zuoying and has stations along the way in Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi, and Tainan, was officially launched on Jan. 5, 2007 and had served 1.5 million passengers as of December 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor promotes organic farmers' market in Taichung

TEXT.P: A festive celebration was held Saturday to mark the reopening of an organic farmers' market on the campus of National Chung Hsing University (NCHU) in Taichung City, central Taiwan, after a week-long break for the Lunar New Year holiday.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, joined the festivities and visited stands displaying various fresh, organic and locally-grown vegetables and fruits.

"Promoting organic agriculture can help people eat in a healthy and safe manner, " Hu said in recognizing NCHU's contributions to integrating agricultural production and marketing and opening its campus to local communities.
The NCHU Organic Farmers' Market was formed under the sponsorship of the NCHU College of Agriculture and Natural Resources and formally opened last Sept. 8.
Every Saturday since then, from 8 a.m. to noon, farmers from neighboring areas and even eastern Taiwan have sold their produce at the market while happily answering questions about their crops.

All farmers selling their produce in the market have passed strict scientific screening reviews by the university before obtaining NCHU certification as growers of organic produce, a requirement to set up a booth in the market.

NCHU Department of Bio-Industry Extension and Management Director Tung Shin-jui, who guided the creation of the market, said most of the produce sold there comes from organic farmers based in central Taiwan.

He believed this new marketing channel would facilitate sales of perishable and nontoxic agricultural products from small local farms that might otherwise have trouble finding commercial opportunities.
In the market, farmers can directly explain to consumers how they grow and care for their crops, establishing bonds of mutual trust between the two sides, Tung said.

Mayor Hu said that in hosting the farmers' market, the university was no longer an "ivory tower" because students were able to learn something practical related to real life. He also promise to push the city government to do more to boost development of the country's organic agricultural sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public advised not to travel to South Africa outside a group

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Consular Affairs advised the public Saturday to avoid traveling to South Africa on their own and not as part of tour groups because of the worsening public order there.
The bureau issued the warning on its official Web site following a recent incident in which two Taiwanese backpackers were robbed in downtown Johannesburg.
The bureau also advised people who do join a package tour to South Africa to follow their groups closely and avoid going anywhere alone while in Johannesburg, the bureau said.
Also Saturday, the bureau continued to urge the public to postpone any plans to travel to East Timor.

If they cannot avoid such a trip, they should keep track of the latest developments in the country and refrain from taking part in any public assemblies or going to any dangerous areas while in the country, the bureau said.

On Feb. 11, East Timorese President Jose Ramos-Horta was shot and critically wounded by rebel soldiers outside his home. East Timor declared a two-day state of emergency immediately after the assassination attempt.

DOC.HEADLINE: Marshall Islands foreign minister to arrive Sunday

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands Foreign Minister Tony deBrum will arrive in Taiwan Sunday to make arrangements for President Litokwa Tomeing's visit to Taiwan next month, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.
DeBrum will be the first ministerial-level official to visit Taiwan since Tomeing was elected president of the South Pacific Island Jan. 7.

Tomeing's election raised concerns in Taiwan because of public remarks he made late last year advocating cutting ties with Taiwan to recognize China, but fears of a switch in allegiance have since abated.
The Marshall Islands are one of Taiwan's 23 formal allies.

During deBrum's five-day visit, he is expected to meet with President Chen Shui- bian, Vice President Annette Lu and Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang to exchange views with them on bilateral cooperation.
He will also take the high speed train to Taichung, central Taiwan, and visit Kuandu in Taipei County to observe how ecotourism is promoted locally, the foreign ministry said.

DeBrum will be visiting Taiwan for the fourth time. He was finance minister when he accompanied former Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua to Taiwan to sign the communique establishing diplomatic relations between Taiwan and the Marshall Islands in November 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Farmers' Party endorses KMT presidential hopeful

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Farmers' Party (TFP) Saturday declared its support for Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate Vincent Siew in the Mar. 22 presidential election and urged them to support a TFP proposal that would restore a health insurance system for farmers.
The endorsement came following a meeting Friday of the party's National Party Affairs Development Committee at which the decision was made to support the KMT ticket.

The party is strongly opposed to the National Pension Act proposed by the Democratic Progressive Party government because it would replace the farmers health insurance system and potentially restrict the benefits that come with it.

Party spokesman Hsieh Yung-huei said the Farmers Party protested the cancellation of the farmers insurance plan with the government prior to the Jan. 12 legislative elections and has since submitted a proposal to both the DPP and KMT to amend the National Pension Act.

"Only the KMT responded positively to the appeals and showed its support, " Hsieh said. "The TFP endorses candidates willing to take care of farmers' rights as well as the development of agriculture."

Under the National Pension Act that is slated to take effect on Oct. 1, 2008, those aged between 25 and 65 who do not participate in the labor insurance program and are not covered by civil servant, military or teachers insurance programs are eligible to join the national pension fund program.

The amendment proposed by the Farmers Party would include the existing farmer's health insurance within the framework of the National Pension Act and remove restrictions that the party says limits farmers' rights.

The Taiwan Farmers Party was only recently formed and has a limited following. It garnered only 57,144 votes, or 0.58 percent of the total cast, in the vote for political parties in the Jan. 12 legislative election.
By Howard Lin

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' group pushes for installation of carbon monoxide detectors

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation called on the government Saturday to mandate the installation of carbon monoxide detectors at restaurants using propane gas or charcoal to protect consumers from inhaling dangerous carbon monoxide gases.
The call came a day after 27 people were poisoned by carbon monoxide at a hot pot restaurant in Lungtan Township, Taoyuan County, that used charcoal heaters.

Alarmed by the incident, the foundation's chairman, Cheng Jen-hung, and secretary-general, Yu Kai-hsiung, visited a barbecue restaurant in Taipei City Saturday together with officials from the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) to measure carbon monoxide emissions from the charcoal burning stove.
After a stove was lit and the charcoal was allowed to burn for one minute, the carbon monoxide concentration in the air reached 1,291 ppm near the stove.

According to bureau technician Wang Huan-lung, people can experience reduced ability to work if they are exposed to an environment where the carbon monoxide concentration reaches 50 ppm for 1.5-4 hours.
They can get a severe headache if the concentration reaches 200 ppm and feel weak and dizzy if the concentration increases to 400 ppm, Wang said.

A concentration of 1,200 ppm can cause the heartbeat rate to increase and become irregular, and a concentration of 2,000 ppm or higher can result in a loss of consciousness and death, Wang said, adding that humans die within minutes if the concentration reaches 5,000 ppm or above.
Cheng advised consumers to leave immediately if they feel uncomfortable while eating at a restaurant and not wait until they became too weak to move.

DOC.HEADLINE: French writer shares reading experiences with Taiwanese readers

TEXT.P: French writer Gilles Lapouge, the producer of the most popular TV program on literature in French broadcasting history, has had a life-long love of books and literature and insisted Saturday that reading remained important and relevent.

In Taiwan to promote his latest work, "L'Encre du voyage," at the Taipei International Book Exhibition, the 85-year-old Lapouge looked back at his career and had some advice for local students when it comes to reading in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Lapouge was one of the creators of the famous French program "Apostrophes" that ran from 1975 to 1990 and drew consistently high audience shares of 12 percent in the '80s.

The show's success stemmed from the popularity of its host, highly regarded literary critic Bernard Pivot, who in his book "Le Metier de Lire, " or "The Profession of Reading, " said he read eight hours a day.

"Pivot's personal charisma and especially his professionalism" were essential to the program's high ratings, Lapouge said. "After Pivot, it is difficult to see another literary TV program of quality."

Not that others haven't tried, including in Taiwan, where there have been many programs that discuss books and literature and interviewed writers. Those that did not serve as shameless promoters for local publishers, however, quickly disappeared from TV screens because of low ratings, and today only one literary show remains, on CTiTV.
That doesn't mean, though, that reading is becoming a lost pleasure. On the contrary, Lapouge is still optimistic about the book market in France.
"Some people say that French people read less, but it is not true," he says, noting that in 2007, about 800 novels were published there.

Lapouge suggests that reading in France has almost become a feminine activity, as women read a lot of romance novels translated from English. But while bestsellers lists there are often dominated by foreign books, mostly from the UK and U.S., he is confident that pure French literature will persist.
"French people have a strongly rooted tradition in pure literature, " he insisted.

For Taiwanese youth who bear the constant pressure of exams, Lapouge encouraged them to spend their time reading "useless" books for pleasure to avoid being overwhelmed by "useful" books assigned in school.

Lapouge also had praise for the exhibition, saying that compared to other book exhibitions, the TIBE "is more lively and the promotion of sales is more delicate, " as people buy without feeling pressured by vendors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imported Jersey cattle contributing to Taiwan's dairy industry

TEXT.P: The more than 500 Jersey cows introduced into Taiwan since June 2006 have adapted to Taiwan and begun contributing milk to the local market, the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday.

Taiwan has worked to develop its dairy industry for over 50 years, relying entirely on breeding Holstein cows until two years ago, when the COA agreed to allow the import of Jersey cows as dairy cows to sharpen the domestic dairy industry's competitive edge, according to the COA's Animal Industry Department.
The honey-brown Jersey cattle grow smaller than the black-and-white Holstein, with the weight of an adult cow ranging from 400 kilograms to 450 kilograms, far lighter than the Holstein's 700 kg.

Their smaller appetites and need for less land area because of their smaller size, along with their adaptability to Taiwan's heat and food sources, are among the reasons they are more economical to raise per unit of milk produced than Holsteins, contributing to the breed's increasing popularity on the island, the Animal Industry Department said.
Another attribute of Jersey cows is that their milk has a higher percentage of butterfat, about 6 percent, than the 3.7-3.8 percent of butterfat contained in the Holstein cows' milk.

The high butterfat and protein rates make the Jersey cows' milk more suitable for making cheese and butter, and as a result local dairy farms are gearing up to sell Jersey-milk-based products like fresh cream to the local market in the near future, the Animal Industry Department indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP counts on defeated lawmakers to help boost presidential bid

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will try to pool the strength of defeated DPP legislators to help the party win the March 22 presidential election, said one of the campaign managers for the DPP presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang.

Speaking on the campaign's strategy, Gao Jhy-peng said he hoped to capitalize on the resources and support base of the defeated DPP legislators, and use them to develop momentum ahead of the upcoming election.
The DPP suffered a crushing defeat in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, winning only 27 seats compared with the 81 seats captured by the main opposition Kuomintang in the 113-member legislature.
Gao said that the party is scheduled to "launch 100 campaign offices and 10,000 support groups for the Hsieh-Su ticket around the island."
DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher from Tainan County, who won his bid for re- election, said Saturday that he will turn his campaign office into a support group for the DPP ticket.

Huang also expressed the hope that voters in Tainan County will support the DPP as strongly as they did in the 2004 presidential election, when nearly 65 percent of those voting in the county backed native son President Chen Shui- bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hsieh-Su campaign office to launch walk for U.N. bid referendum

TEXT.P: The campaign of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang is launching a walk next month across much of Taiwan to promote the party's U.N.-bid referendum.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih, the director of the campaign's Tainan office, said the walk covering Taiwan's western corridor aimed to drum up support for the DPP-initiated referendum to be held simultaneously with the March 22 presidential election.
Su said he hopes the planned walk will spark passion among local voters for the referendum on joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," and boost support for the Hsieh-Su ticket.
Under the current plan, the walk will start March 3 in Pingtung, the southernmost county of western Taiwan, and head north before reaching Taipei March 21, the eve of the presidential election.
Su said he discussed the plan with President Chen Shui-bian, who visited the county Saturday.
According to Su, President Chen expressed "the willingness to join the walk, " but will only decide after learning more about the activity and communicating with Hsieh's camp.
Kuo Kuo-wen, the director of the DPP's Tainan County chapter, said the walk will follow urban roads, and the public will be invited to join.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan insurers eye booming Chinese market

TEXT.P: Facing a mature market at home, Taiwan's insurance companies are eyeing China's underdeveloped insurance sector and its 20 percent annual growth rates for expansion, a research report by local brokerage firm IBT Securities has concluded.

Insurers in Taiwan have become increasingly restless over the slow growth rates in the domestic insurance market in recent years. The country's insurance penetration rate -- the ratio of premium revenues to gross domestic product -- ranked third in the world at 14.5 percent in 2006, an indication of limited growth potential in the future.
In contrast, China's estimated insurance rate of 2.8 percent in 2006 and its per capita insurance premium revenue of 493 Chinese yuan leave ample room for growth, the report noted.

China's insurance market expanded rapidly in the first half of the decade, with life insurance premiums of 413.2 billion yuan at the end of 2006, 2.9 times higher than in 2000, and property and casualty insurance premiums of 150.9 billion yuan, 2.2 times higher than in 2000.
Chinese government estimates suggest that this growth should continue and even accelerate in the second half of the decade.

China's 11th five-year economic plan covering the insurance sector released in October 2006 estimated that premium revenues in 2010 would be double those in 2005, exceeding 1 trillion yuan, and assets managed by the industry would reach 5 trillion yuan, well above the 1.97 trillion yuan in assets managed at the end of 2006.
The plan also expected the insurance penetration rate in China to reach 4 percent by 2010.

Gaining a foothold in China's closed market, however, could be a major challenge for local insurers, the report said. China's life insurance market is still dominated by domestic players, with foreign operators having only a 6 percent market share.

And Taiwan's share of that is minimal, the report said. Taipei-based Cathay Life Insurance, Taiwan's biggest life insurer, had only 1.37 percent of the foreign share of China's life insurance market at the end of 2006, the report said.

To make inroads into China, local insurers have sought out partners there. Cathay Life has joined with China Eastern Airlines to set up a life insurance company in Shanghai, and Taiwan's Shin Kong Life Insurance partnered with Hainan Airlines to establish a life insurance firm based in Beijing.
Taiwan Life Insurance, meanwhile, is negotiating with Xiamen D&D Inc. to set up a life insurance venture in southern China.
Taiwan's insurers are being tempted by China's potential, even if they suffer losses there in their first few years of operations, because of the prospect of a stagnant market at home.

Taiwan's insurance penetration rate grew only marginally in 2006 to 14.5 percent, from 14.1 percent in 2005 according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), and premium income grew only 5 percent to reach US$51.6 billion in 2006.
The world's average penetration rate in 2006 was 7.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP Lu optimistic KMT will engage in talks on defensive referendum

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu expressed optimism Sunday that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will engage in negotiations with the ruling party on a proposal that President Chen Shui-bian initiate a "defensive referendum" to resolve doubts plaguing two referendums on the country's U.N. bid.

According to media reports, some opposition "pan-blue" alliance politicians, noting U.S. opposition to the referendums, have suggested that Chen introduce a"defensive referendum" or the Legislative Yuan come up with an alternative referendum in place of the two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.
Under the Referendum Law, the president has the authority to launch referendums on matters of national security, referred to as "defensive referendums, " when the country faces an external threat.

Speaking in Kinmen where she was reviewing several BOT (build-operate- transfer) projects proposed by the county government, Lu said that the KMT's engaging in negotiations on the referendum issue would represent "a real start to reconciliation and co-existence" between the ruling and opposition parties.
It would be "a critical turning point in the nation's development and help push the country into a new era," she said.

Noting that the KMT now controls a large majority in the new legislature, Lu said that "if the party wants to express its respect and tolerance for democracy, it should cordially invite President Chen to exercise his powers to initiate a defensive referendum."
She said that this would be a sign of goodwill, adding that she believes President Chen would reciprocate by showing respect for the legislature.
The vice president also noted that it is the hope of Taiwan's people that the country gain membership in the United Nations as soon as possible.

On Saturday, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou expressed his strong opposition to the proposal that the president initiate a "defensive referendum" over the U.N. bid issue, saying that it would represent an abuse of power.
Ma also said his party supports the U.N.-bid referendums but is opposed to holding them in tandem with the presidential election.

The Central Election Commission (CEC) announced at the start of this month that the two referendums -- one initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the country joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," and the other launched by the KMT on regaining membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name -- would be held alongside the presidential poll.

Shortly after the announcement, KMT legislative caucus whip Kuo Su-chun said the party was in the process of mapping out countermeasures to the CEC's move and that it would make a final decision on the matter before the first session of the new legislature opens Feb. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly all motor vehicles have third-party liability insurance

TEXT.P: Nearly all motor vehicles in Taiwan are insured against third-party liability, the Financial Supervisory Commission said Sunday.

The commission, Taiwan's chief financial regulatory body, reported that as of the end of 2007, all automobiles in Taiwan and 96 percent of motorcycle owners were covered by third-party liability insurance.

Taiwan's Compulsory Automobile Liability Insurance Law went into effect in early 1998, requiring all car owners to be insured against legal claims that they injured or caused damage to others, including passengers in the car or individuals outside the car.
A year later, motorcyclists were also required to do the same.

Official statistics show that as of the end of 2007, a total of 16.62 million motor vehicles in Taiwan were covered by third-party liability insurance, comprising 7.19 million automobiles and 9.42 million motorcycles.
The law was amended in 2005 to increase the amount payable to a killed or maimed victim in a motor vehicle accident to NT$1.5 million (US$47,275).

According to the amended law, if a motor vehicle is not covered by a third-party liability insurance policy that is valid for at least 30 days, the owner is not allowed to renew his vehicle's license plate, have the vehicle undergo inspection, or change ownership of the vehicle. An insurance company is required to notify its clients to renew their third-party liability insurance at least 30 days before their policies expire.

Under the law, a policyholder's insurance company must provide compensation for death or injuries to third-party victims, regardless of who may be at fault in a road accident involving a policy holder.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT vice presidential candidate blasts DPP's economic policies

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew accused the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday of dragging down Taiwan's economy during its time in office.

"While the global economy has experienced a high tide of growth over the past eight years, Taiwan's economy has been at a low ebb during the same period," Siew said at a Lunar New Year's gathering of a local Lions Club chapter in Chungho City.
"The government, and not the people, is to blame for Taiwan's poor economic performance during the last eight years," he said.

He claimed that the administration's ideological polices have led to a flight of capital and talent that has "bled the country, " and led China-based Taiwanese businesspeople to think twice about sending capital back to Taiwan.

Siew said that he and KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou will adopt policies of economic liberalization, especially in terms of cross-strait trade, that will provide a mechanism to allow for China-based Taiwanese companies to re-invest in Taiwan and attract foreign capital to the country.

"For those who are concerned that more liberal economic policies will lead to even higher unemployment, there's no need to worry, because the companies that were going to China have already gone," he said.
Siew further argued that adopting more liberal policies, as championed by the KMT ticket, is the only way to give Taiwan's economy the chance to develop after years of failed DPP policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vegetable prices soar after Lunar New Year holidays

TEXT.P: Prices of vegetables have soared by an average of 30 percent to 50 percent after the Lunar New Year holiday, and they are expected to remain high during the coming week, according to a spokesman for Siluo Fruit and Vegetables Market in central Taiwan.

Tight supplies caused by reduced harvests during the recent weeks of cold and rainy weather and increasing demand from schools are likely to keep vegetable prices high for at least another week, predicted Chiang Li-yuan, an assistant manager at the country's largest wholesale produce marketing company.
Taiwan has been hit by a cold front since the first day of the Lunar New Year Feb. 7, causing losses to vegetable, fruit, and fish farmers.

According to the Council of Agriculture's Agricultural and Food Agency (AFA) , the cold spell has led to losses of NT$85.4 million (US$2.67 million) in aquaculture and NT$57.1 million (US$ 1.79 million) in fruit crops nationwide so far, especially in the counties of Penghu, Hsinchu, Yilan, Taichung, Kaohsiung, Miaoli and Yunlin.
That does not include losses in some parts of the country that have yet to report the damage, said Tsai Ching-chiang, deputy director of the agency.
He stressed that where losses met the criteria for natural disaster relief, the council would help farmers financially and help them replant their farms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese puppetry brings joy to ailing young girl in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 16 (CNA) 02/17/08 18:37:14 (photo available at CNA photo section 2008-02-16-0021) (By Josie Chou & Steve Bercic)

TEXT.P: In an inspiring example of traditional Taiwanese culture spreading its influence around the world, Taiwanese puppet theater has brought joy into the life of a young American girl suffering from muscular dystrophy.

A 9-year-old girl named Trisha Stanford fell in love with the artform when she saw the Taiyuan Puppet Theater Company stage a performance last October at the Salt Lake City children's hospital where she was being cared for.

The troupe, led by Huang Wu-shan, a well-known student of Taiwanese puppeteer master Li Tien-lu, performed at the hospital as part of the Taiwan Cultural Festival held in Utah's largest city Oct. 15-20.

The festival, sponsored by the Press Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco and various Taiwan government agencies, featured Taiwanese film showings, performances, music and culinary arts.
Little Trisha, who had been in the hospital for three months awaiting spinal surgery, was immediately drawn to the colorful puppets in the puppet theater show.
"The visit by the puppet troupe was one of the highlights in Trisha's young life," her mother said.
After the show, Huang taught Trisha some puppet manipulation techniques. Although it was Trisha's first time handling a puppet, everyone in the troupe felt she had a natural talent for the artform.

Just recently, months after the troupe had left Salt Lake City, the U.S. organizers of the Taiwan Cultural Festival received a package sent from Taiwan by the troupe containing a DVD of a famous Taiwanese puppet theater film and a full-sized puppet of the main character in the film that were meant as gifts for Trisha.
When the organizers sent the loving gift to the young girl, they learned some wonderful and moving news. Trisha's surgery had been a success, and she had been released from hospital in November.
The nine-year-old was recovering well and was even able to walk short distances on her own.

Playing with the gift sent by the troupe, Trisha expressed her love for Taiwanese puppetry and her wish to be able to visit Taiwan one day to see the many puppet museums there and learn even more about the traditional Taiwanese artform.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese entrepreneur in Philippines donates wheelchairs
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb.16 (CNA) 02/17/08 18:42:09 (By Emerson T. Lim and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese entrepreneur in the Philippines donated 60 wheelchairs Saturday to a charity organization in Bulacan province, a sign of the concern shown by Taiwan for the disabled in the Philippines.

Alex Ting, the donor and chairman of the Taiwan Association (Phils) Inc., said he hoped "the donation can be a gesture that will lead to greater concern for people in need in the Philippines and improve their level of social welfare."
Ting personally pledged to donate another 240 wheelchairs during his term as chairman and said 200 more would be donated by the association.

Ting also promised to continue his support for a program proposed by his predecessor, Huang Shih-kai, and co-sponsored by Taiwan's Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation to provide free treatment for children with cleft lips as well as other free medical services to Filipinos.

Wu Hsin-hsing, the head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines who attended the ceremony marking the donation of the wheelchairs, commended Ting's generosity as a bridge that "indeed helps strengthen harmonious relations between Taiwan and the Philippines."

The ceremony was held at the Barcie International Center of the University of Regina Carmeli. Veronica Gonzales, chairwoman of the Buklod Lingap Bulacan Foundation, immediately sent the wheelchairs to 60 disabled people chosen by the Social Welfare and Development Office of Bulacan.
Bulacan is a province in the Philippines central Luzon region.
After his daughter received a wheelchair, the father of a young disabled girl expressed his deep appreciation to Ting, who said his daughter had hoped for a wheelchair for a long time."
"The difficulties in her daily life will be greatly reduced because of the help of Taiwan's people, " said the father as he shed tears of joy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Maokong Gondola surpasses 3-million passenger mark

TEXT.P: The Maokong Gondola, plagued by breakdowns and controversy in its first few weeks of operation and open for less than a year, served its 3 millionth passenger Sunday afternoon just after 2 p.m., the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) said.
As part of the celebrations marking the 3-million ride milestone, TRTC handed out 10,000 commemorative gondola-shaped bottles of mineral water to passengers Sunday.
The transit company also had five cable cars painted in a colorful pattern and fit with LED lamps to mark the event, creating a festive atmosphere for the occasion.

At 4.03 kilometers, the Maokong Gondola is the longest cable car system in Taiwan, and ferries passengers between two popular tourist attractions -- the Taipei Zoo and the Mucha tea growing area -- in just 20 minutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: With Taiwan's help, Genghis Khan returns to Mongolia

TEXT.P: CNA staff reporter

Taipei, Feb. 17 (CNA) A huge portrait of Mongolia's great emperor Genghis Khan (1162-1227) composed of more than 430,000 crystal mosaic tiles will soon be inaugurated at Ulan Bator's international airport, thanks to the help of several Rotary Club members from Taipei.

The installation of the nearly-three-story high Genghis Khan portrait -- made with 437,000 crystal mosaic tiles by German workers based on a portrait of Genghis Khan in the National Palace Museum's collection -- is expected to be completed in April, said Chan Ming-chu, governor of Rotary International District 3480.

Already a landmark in Ulan Bator, the Genghis Khan portrait will be a place where all Mongolian people can conveniently worship and remember their great national founding father, said Migeddorj Batchimeg, Mongolia's representative in Taiwan.

Batchimeg, who speaks fluent Mandarin Chinese and has been instrumental in arranging the placement of the portrait at the Ulan Bator international airport, expressed her gratitude to members of the Rotary International District 3480 and National Palace Museum for the precious gift they gave to the Mongolian people.

Describing Genghis Khan as "the major source of pride" for Mongolia's people, Batchimeg said he created the foundation for the largest empire in world history, which encompassed China, the Middle East, Russia and Central Asia at its peak under Genghis Khan's grandson Kublai Khan, who ruled from 1260 to 1294 and founded the Yuan Dynasty in China.

During the time Mongolia was closely aligned with the Soviet Union, the Russians through their proxies in Ulan Bator tried to smear the image of Genghis Khan by saying he and his army caused the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people, Batchimeg asserted.

After the fall of communism in Mongolia in 1990 and the adoption of new constitution in 1992, however, Genghis Khan was recognized again as the country's hero and founding father and has since been worshiped and commemorated on a regular basis.
Even the name of the capital city's airport was changed to Genghis Khan International Airport three years ago, she said.

To many historians, Genghis Khan remains a puzzle because few artifacts related to him specifically have been left behind. As a consequence, Mongolians consider the portrait of Genghis Khan in Taipei's National Palace Museum to be one of the most precious treasures connecting them to their founding father.

The 59.4 cm X 47 cm color portrait on a silk sheet is thought to be a likeness of Genghis Khan in his sixties painted during the era of Kubilai Khan. It is generally accepted as the most accurate depiction of Genghis Khan and considered a "must see" by Mongolian officials or citizens whenever they visit Taiwan, Batchimeg said.

The mosaic reproduction of the portrait came to life because the Taipei-based Rotary International District 3480, which had quietly sought to enhance bilateral relations between Taiwan and Mongolia, knotted sisterhood ties with the Niislel Rotary Club in Ulan Bator in 2004.

After paying visits to Taipei and viewing Genghis Khan's portrait at the National Palace Museum several times, the Niislel Rotary members expressed their "dream" that the portrait would one day be returned to Mongolia.

While that dream has yet to be fulfilled, the Rotary Club's Chan decided to do the next best thing and offer Mongolia a large reproduction based on the original. Chan's husband and fellow Rotary Club member Wang Chen-jung, who owns a building materials company that imports Italian and Spanish mosaic tiles, took the initiative in producing the giant portrait.

He first approached National Palace Museum officials for their permission to reproduce the painting, and after long negotiations, the museum finally agreed to offer the Rotary Club a digitalized image of the portrait early last year.

A thrilled Wang then ordered expensive 1 cm x 1 cm x 1 cm crystal mosaic tiles from abroad and recruited mosaic experts from Germany to prepare to travel to Ulan Bator to put together the portrait, which would stand 9 meters tall and 6 meters wide.

The tiles were shipped to Ulan Bator in May last year, and the German workers assembled the portrait in September. It will be the centerpiece of an 11 meter by 7 meter monument to Genghis Khan when work is completed.

To many historians and peoples around the world, Genghis Khan is viewed as a destructive warlord capable of breathtaking cruelty, but Batchimeg said the man revered by Mongolians was responsible for many positive developments.

Genghis Khan's mounted Mongol army consolidated the Silk Road, laying a solid foundation for trade, cultural and religious exchanges between East and West, and he also laid down laws that were similar to Mongolia's existing constitution, Batchimeg said.

Diplomacy was developed in the Mongolian empire, where foreign envoys were respected and well-treated, while "golden plates" -- similar to today's passports -- were used to facilitate diplomatic exchanges among nations, Batchimeg noted.

And now Mongolians will be brought closer to their founding father through a project made possible with the assistance of Batchimeg's Taipei Office, the Ulan Bator mayor, an ad hoc committee organized by the Mongolian Civil Aeronautic Administration and officials from the Genghis Khan International Airport, Chan said.
Chan said she and her husband as well as other Rotary Club members will travel to Ulan Bator in April to witness the inauguration of the Genghis Khan monument.
The two have also decided to visit rural areas of Mongolia later this year to inspect water-supply systems and help with the construction of deep-water wells around the drought-striken country.
Batchimeg, who took graduate-level courses at Taipei's National Chengchi University in 1997-1999, is a graduate of Beijing Language and Culture University.

One of the key figures in arranging the establishment of Taiwan and Mongolia representative offices in each other's country, Batchimeg said she is glad that a result of increased bilateral ties Taiwanese friends no longer ask her questions like "Did you ride a horse to work in Mongolia?"

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's textile industry revived by government efforts

TEXT.P: Taiwan's textile industry is recovering from the impact of the 2005 removal of textile quotas worldwide, thanks to government efforts to breathe new life into the industry, according to the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Taiwan's garment, towel and socks factories were hard-hit after January 2005 because international buyers shifted their orders to other countries where production costs were lower.

Most of these factories were initially forced to depend on the domestic market for survival, but according to the IDB, many have since recovered, benefiting from an NT$735 million IDB program that helped many small enterprises in the textile industry upgrade themselves and secure 1,000 jobs.

One example of the plan's success was sweater factories that made use of an IDB plan to allow imports of wool yarn from China. They used the yarn to weave patches that were then exported to other countries and sewn into sweaters.

A total of 2.42 million sweaters have been exported in this manner since July 2005, according to bureau statistics, boosting average factory capacity utilization rates in Taiwan's sweater industry from 20 percent in 2005 to 80 percent at present.

Another program launched in April 2006 to help Taiwan's towel industry, coupled with measures to impose anti-dumping duties on towel imports from China, has helped Taiwan's towel factories increase their capacity utilization rate to 60 percent.
As a result, output value increased by over 50 percent to NT$480 million in 2007, bureau figures show.
The socks industry also has shown increased competitiveness, with its exports between January and September 2007 reaching US$85.23 million, up US$2.5 million from the same period of 2006.

Taiwan's textile industry had been a major foreign exchange earner for five decades. However, growing competition from other countries in recent years has forced several textile plants to relocate to Southeast Asia, China, and Central America, where production costs are lower.

The industry has since shifted its export focus to midstream and upstream fiber and yarn products. The primary destinations for Taiwan's textile exports are Hong Kong, China, the United States, and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Book Fair business decline under scrutiny

TEXT.P: A lukewarm response to the annual Taipei International Book Exhibition has many publishers concerned that attendance and sales at this year's show will fall short of levels attained in recent years.

With the six-day book fair set to end on Feb. 18, many publishers are attributing the lack of enthusiasm this year to the cold weather, declining readership in Taiwan, fewer student visitors because of the early opening of schools, and the lack of international interest.

Declining readership and less foreign participation are particularly troubling trends, observers say. The number of foreign publishers fell to 360 from last year's 370, while the total number of publishers also decreased to 687 from 711 year-on-year.
Vincent Wei, project manager of the publisher Chiu Ko Publishing Co. said Sunday that the sluggish sales are the result of slumping readership in Taiwan.
"Our sales may be more or less the same as last year, but we are witnessing a declining number of local readers who actually buy books at the fair," Wei said.
Wei indicated that Chiu Ko, like other local publishers, are trying to save the industry by creating more titles that cater to the public's tastes.

The fair's licensing business has also fallen off as an increasing number of Taiwanese publishers no longer see the show as an important venue for book licensing, said a senior worker of another major local publisher, who declined to be identified.

He said Taiwan's publishers can no longer rely on the fair for their licensing business, adding that many companies would rather explore overseas opportunities at other foreign international book fairs like the Frankfurt Book Fair.

The thriving Beijing book fair also has hurt licensing opportunities at the Taipei book fair, said Amelie Sun, a marketing director of the French-language publisher Librairie Le Pigeonnier, which represents French publishers at the fair.
"The international publishers are reducing their presence because they believe the Beijing book fair is more lucrative as it helps them march into China's huge book market," Sun explained.

There are some exceptions to the trend, as the themed country of the fair, Australia, which displayed more than 1,000 titles from 24 Australian publishers in its pavilion, reached a broader readership through the show.

"Unlike the local publishers, our books appeal to a different group of readers who take a high interest in foreign cultures, " said Steve Chiu, the senior manager of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office.
Chiu said the sales and licensing business at the Australian Pavilion have exceeded expectations, with children's books and non-fiction leading the way.

"Compared with the status in previous years, we discovered that Taiwan readers' capacity is improving, as they are now focusing on a more diverse array of titles rather than just the English-learning publications," he added.

About 400,000 people attended last year's book fair. The organizer of the book fair, the Taipei Book Fair Foundation predicted that attendance for this year could remain about the same, with a record 100,000 visits recorded on Saturday, when the weather turned warmer.
The foundation will announce this year's overall attendance at the end of the fair Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan International Science Fair to announce winners Feb. 22

TEXT.P: A screening committee will announce the domestic and foreign winners in the 2008 Taiwan International Science Fair Feb. 22, and all the winning works and other masterpieces will be put on display at the Taiwan Science Education Center in Taipei's Shihlin district until March 3, organizers said Sunday.

Officials at the center told reporters that in addition to 107 works that have passed the preliminary screening, 60 young students from 17 countries will also submit their works in various fields of science to the fair in the next two days.
These countries include the United States, Canada, Mexico, Russia, France, Germany, New Zealand, South Africa, Singapore and Thailand.

The screening committee will spend two days to evaluate the entries before announcing the top three winners among both the domestic and the foreign entries. The top three domestic winners will represent Taiwan in international science exhibitions held in the United States, Canada, Hong Kong, Singapore, Hungary and New Zealand.

The fair's two co-organizers -- the Bureau of Education of the Taipei City Government and the Taipei Municipal First Girls' Senior High School -- will select appropriate local families to host the overseas students during the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'God Man Dog' wins Tagesspiegel Readers' Prize at Berlin film fest

TEXT.P: A Taiwan movie that humorously fashions an allegorical tragicomedy about the crisis of faith in contemporary Taiwan -- "God Man Dog" -- has won the Tagesspiegel Readers' Prize in Berlin, the film's local producer said Sunday.

The film, directed by Taiwanese director Singing Chen, was chosen from among the 36 movies from 33 countries competing in the 2008 Berlin International Film Festival's Forum for New Cinema, which is aimed at honoring young filmmakers.

By winning the award, Chen received 3,000 euros in prize money. The award marked yet another recognition for Taiwanese films from the annual Berlin film fest following a Teddy Bear Award won by "Spider Lilies" in 2007.
According to a statement issued by the "God Man Dog" producer, the film has attracted much attention since its premiere at the annual Berlin film festival that began Feb. 7 and ran until Sunday.

"The film consistently drew packed audience each time it was screened during the festival, " the statement said, adding that major German newspapers, including Der Tagesspiegel, a Berlin-based national daily that organizes the Tagesspiegel Readers' Prize, have given prominent coverage and ran many reviews about the film.

Although the Tagesspiegel Readers' Prize is not a formal award presented by Berlin film festival organizers, the German paper attached great importance to the competition, the statement said. It invited nine professionals from various fields to judge all entries competing in the Forum for New Cinema.

The statement quoted reports from Berlin as saying that the nine members of the jury unanimously agreed that "God Man Dog" was the most appealing. "They decided to give the laurel to the film without even any discussion," the statement said.
Chen was quoted as having said at the presentation that she feels honored and excited to receive recognition from the most important German newspaper.

Recalling that she overcame a lot of difficulties producing the film, Chen said she takes great delight and comfort in winning the award. "The award vindicates all the pains I endured during the production process," she added.

The film tries to unite three disparate stories of unhappy people, touching on emotional problems of urbanites, social problems of aborigines and commodification of body. A fateful car accident brought together these three group of people from different social classes, religions and ethnicity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical doctors face hurdles in making inroads into China

TEXT.P: Taiwanese medical doctors intending to practice medicine in China face many hurdles, including high thresholds for getting medical licenses and differences in healthcare operations on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, medical sources said Sunday.
China allowed Taiwanese medical practitioners to take part in its accreditation test for the first time last July, attracting 270 hopefuls from Taiwan.

According to a Taiwanese medical educator who spoke on condition of anonymity, more than half of the Taiwanese hopefuls have practiced medicine for more than 10 years, but about a quarter of them even failed to pass the first phase of the test.
"Three of the Taiwanese doctors who flunked the first phase of the test have been practicing medicine for more than 30 years and 18 have a 20-year seniority," he said.
Quoting those who took part in that test, the medical educator said differences in Chinese writing systems and languages used in medical records form the first hurdles for Taiwanese hopefuls.

"Many Taiwanese doctors were not familiar with simplified Chinese characters and Chinese clinical terms," the educator said. In Taiwan, medical doctors use traditional Chinese characters and usually write medical records in English.

There are also many differences in practical healthcare operations, he said. For instance, protective garb worn by medical professionals in operating rooms is disposable in Taiwan, but the article should be given back after one service cycle in China. Chinese medical practitioners are also required to follow established steps in wearing and recycling protective garb.

As examination hopefuls had to face three examiners in the first phase of the test, which focused on medical skills, the test results could also be affected by the examiners' state of mind or personal preferences. Some examiners were quoted as having told young Taiwanese hopefuls that as they were still young, they should tried later.
"Given all these factors, it's hard for Taiwanese hopefuls to get high marks in skill tests," the educator said.
Nevertheless, both Taiwanese and Chinese manpower brokers said they were surprised by the large number of Taiwanese participants in last year's medical accreditation test in China.
Even though getting China's medical license is not easy, market sources said, China's opening of medical accreditation test for Taiwanese practitioners is still a boon.

"The measure opens a window of opportunity for Taiwanese medical professionals as Taiwan's medical service system is mature and saturated, " said a Taiwanese hospital operator familiar with medical market situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin You-chun, a China-trained Taiwanese doctor at a general hospital invested by a Taiwanese business group in the central Chinese province of Hunan, said China's medical service industry is promising and has a strong growth potential.

"Even though many problems exist in doctors-patients relations and hospital management, there is still ample room for medical service and healthcare market to grow in China, " Lin said, adding that it is why he and his brother had traveled to China to study medicine many years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Casini: UDC to campaign alone.
Italian Christian Democratic Union Party (UDC) leader Pierferdinando Casini announced Saturday that his party would campaign alone in the April 13-14 general elections, refusing a party-merger call from former premier Silvio Berlusconi. The center-right coalition "House of Liberty" leader proposed that all allied parties would run elections under the banner of a new unified "Liberty Party".

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 18, or the 12th day of first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for St. Peter's Cathedral, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of a Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1685: La Salle, a French explorer, sets up the first European settlement in Texas.
1745: Alessandro Volta, Italian physicist who invented the electric battery, is born. The volt is named in his honor.
1855: Nicholas I, the czar of Russia who suppressed the December Movement and led his country into the Crimean War, dies at the age of 59.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, a US astronomer, is the first to see Pluto, realizing it is the Sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" (Manchuria) proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1943: Madame Chiang Kai-shek addresses a joint session of the US House and Senate.
1945: The battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's telecom equipment production forecast to grow 24% this year

TEXT.P: Taiwan's telecommunications equipment industry is expected to rebound from a low ebb in 2007 and achieve production of NT$907.5 billion (US$28.595 billion) this year, a research unit under the Ministry of Economic Affairs forecast Monday.
The Industrial Technology Information Services (ITIS) forecast the industry's production would increase by 24 percent over the figure of NT$732 billion for 2007.
Growth in production value was a relatively low 4.6 percent for last year, according to ITIS tallies.

ITIS industry analyst Lin Yu-ru said that broadband Internet equipment demand has been relatively stable, but due to the maturation of products, growth in this area will be relatively small this year.
She added that wireless telecommunications products will be the main driving force behind growth in the industry's production value.
In the area, domestic manufacturers are expected to continue to diversify their source of customers and expand their orders, Lin said.

Another driving force behind growth in production value of Taiwan's telecommunications equipment industry will be GPS products, with the market for portable navigation device products expected to continue to grow steadily as demand in emerging economies increases, she said.

Lin further said that these two driving forces are expected to see growth in production of over 10 percent for 2008, which will allow Taiwan's telecommunications equipment industry to rebound from a low point in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan better equipped to declare independence: candidate

TEXT.P: Taiwan has better conditions and reasons for declaring independence than Kosovo, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vice presidential candidate Su Tseng-chang claimed Monday.
Su, running mate of presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, said that "Taiwan, the hard-built ship of democracy with a polished deck, should never be sailed into another country's harbor."

Speaking at a rally marking the establishment of the Hsieh-Su campaign headquarters in the southern county of Chiayi, Su said the Taiwan people were allowed to directly elect their president only after a struggle lasting several generations.

By comparison, he said, Kosovo, with a population of 2 million, declared independence from Serbia earlier Monday after losing some 200,000 people in conflict. Despite an economy on the verge of collapse, the people of Kosovo decided to be their own masters, courageously standing up to build a new country of their own.

Unlike Kosovo, which is "just beginning in terms of building a democratic nation, " Taiwan is well-developed and now a full-fledged democracy, thanks to decades of efforts by the Taiwanese people, according to Su.
Calling for voters in the Chiayi area not to allow Taiwan's hard-earned democracy to go down the drain, Su urged the Chiayi people to vote for the DPP ticket in the March 22 presidential election.

According to Su, although the DPP suffered a humiliating loss in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, the voters should not allow the main opposition Kuomintang -- which now holds an absolute majority in the legislature -- to "turn Taiwan into a winner-take-all society."
Describing the presidential election as a "last-ditch battle to defend Taiwan's sovereignty, " Su claimed that the DPP ticket has the "only candidates" who can protect Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry denies report on student loan defaults

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education denied Monday that the student loan default ratio has surpassed 12 percent and that the amount of overdue student loans has risen to a record high NT$4.41 billion (US$130.4 million) as reported by the local Chinese-language China Times Monday.

"I don't know where the daily got its figures from," said Hou Chou-fei, head of the ministry's Department of Higher Education, noting that the actual student loan default ratio currently stands at under 3 percent.

Speaking at a press conference held to respond to the report, Hou said that no banks or lending institutions have applied for repayment of any overdue student loans by the Small and Medium Business Credit Guarantee Fund which serves as guarantor for student loans at the request of the government.
"There is no need to be concerned as the ministry has the student loan situation completely under control," he said.
According to the China Times report, over 900,000 students have received student loans amounting to over NT$150 billion in total, with the loan default ratio reaching 12.11 percent.
Ho said that the actual number of students who have received loans is closer to 800,000 and that the loan default ratio stands at only 2.44 percent.
He further said that the ministry has a mechanism in place for recovering overdue student loans and that the success rate for recovering loans overdue for less than one year is quite high.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up slightly on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were marginally up Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 14.53 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 7,890.9.

Gainers outnumbered losers 1,105 to 757, with 379 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lantern Festival foods tested safe: Taipei's health department

TEXT.P: All but one of the traditional Lantern Festival food products recently tested by Taipei City's Department of Health were found to be up to par in terms of safety standards, bureau officials said Monday.

In the survey conducted ahead of the festival which traditionally comes at the end of the Lunar New Year holiday, on Feb. 21 this year, a total of 62 food products, ranging from glutinous rice dumplings to red bean sweets, were tested at retail food outlets and traditional markets around the city.
The survey included tests on the levels of preservatives and artificial coloring in the products.

Only one sample, a glutinous rice ball snack, was found to have excess amounts of the food preservative benzoic acid, which inhibits growth of mold and some bacteria. The product contained 2.82 g/kg of the substance, well above the maximum prescribed safety limit of 1.0 g/kg.

Bureau officials said that according to law, food manufacturers can be fined between NT$30,000 (US$937) and NT$50,000 for producing products with excess amounts of preservatives, artificial coloring and other additives.
Products found to contain excess amounts of such substances will also be pulled from store shelves, they said, adding that the laws are in place to protect consumers' health.
