DOC.HEADLINE: Government pushing beneficial cross-strait policies: official

TEXT.P: The administration has continued to relax restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and believes that procrastination should not be tolerated, a high- ranking official said Monday, speaking on condition of anonymity.

The government is not dragging its feet on pushing beneficial cross-strait policies, including relaxing requirements for certain sectors to benefit from the "mini links" and enlarging the sphere of the "mini links" application, as well as considering an amnesty on Taiwanese businessmen who have invested in China without informing the government, the official from the Presidential Office said.

Noting that the "mini links" -- initiated by Taiwan in January 2001 to allow Fujian-based Taiwanese businessmen, or taishang, to travel directly between China and Taiwan via the Taiwan-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu -- are so far limited to Fujian-based taishang and certain other groups of people, the administration is mulling whether to allow taishang based in other Chinese provinces and areas to use the "mini links, " he noted.

The official made the remarks in response to an Economic Daily News report that same day speculating that President Chen Shui-bian is likely to adjust or relax his China policies prior to the end of his term May 20.

He confirmed that Chen met with a group of chairmen of Taiwan businessmen's associations in China for a discussion Feb. 15 arranged by Hung Chi-chang, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.

During the discussion, according to the official, many taishang expressed their intention to relocate their investments back to Taiwan owing to China's deteriorating investment climate, including higher levels of taxation and stricter government regulations on foreign-financed investment projects.

But taishang, who have skirted government regulations on investing in China, were quoted as having expressed worries that they could immediately face penalties such as fines or the imposition of retroactive taxes should they return to Taiwan with their investment capital.
They expressed hope during the meeting with Chen that the government will build a mechanism to facilitate the inflow of large amounts of funds from China, the official said.

The official claimed that the administration is doing what it should to take better care of taishang but has not decided whether those policies should be implemented before or after the March 22 presidential election.
Meanwhile, main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou expressed welcome to the notion that Chen will announce a relaxation on cross- strait policies prior to May 20.

Accusing Chen of failing to relax his China policies over the past nearly eight years in office, Ma said the reported plan of a relaxation, "made on the eve of his stepping down, " is still a welcome development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't studying ways to cope with rising raw material prices: BOFT

TEXT.P: Finding ways for Taiwanese exporters to cope with rising raw material prices while making their export deployments worldwide this year is an important topic that needs to be addressed, a Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) official said Monday.

According to statistics released by customs authorities, Taiwan's foreign trade totaled US$42.75 billion in January, with exports registering an annual growth of 11.9 percent and imports reaching a year-on-year increase of 14.8 percent.
The increased imports resulted in a shrinkage in the nation's trade surplus in January, which registered US$1.53 billion, a decrease of 16.5 percent over the same month of last year.
Due to surging global prices of oil and raw materials, Taiwan's imports of crude oil reached US$2.52 billion in January, which represented a 27.1 percent growth over the year-earlier level.

Meanwhile, imports of steel products stood at US$1.18 billion in January, an increase of 8.9 percent over the same month of last year, with imports of cereals reaching US$444 million, representing year-on-year growth of 29.4 percent.

The BOFT official noted that with the rapid economic rise of China, India, Brazil, Russia and Eastern Europe over the last few years, prices of construction raw materials in world markets are also increasing.
In addition, the official went on, the demand for construction projects spawned by the approaching 2008 Beijing Olympics has caused surges in the prices of cement, steel and other metals.

"As Taiwan's exports focus on machinery, electrical products and basic metals, with the exports of these products accounting for more than 50 percent of its total, it is easy for its exports to be affected by global price hikes of raw materials, " the official said.
"Local exporters this year need to reduce the negative impact on them caused by these price hikes," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese student shines in French acrobatic festival

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese student captured the top prize at a recent international circus festival in Paris for his outstanding skills with the diabolo, a traditional Chinese folk toy.

Lin Wei-liang, a freshman at National Taipei University of Education, won the President of the Republic of France Award, the top prize, for his diabolo routine at the 29th Festival Modial du Cirque de Demain, Lin' s coach Tseng Wen- hsiu said Monday in an interview with the CNA.
Lin also won first prize in the "public choice" category at the festival, held Jan.31 -Feb. 3 with the aim of providing a platform for new and up-and-coming artists to showcase their innovations.

The annual event, conducted every winter in Paris, is one of the four major circus arts competitions along with China's Wuqiao International Circus Festival and the Wuhan Acrobatic Festival, as well as the prestigious International Circus Festival of Monte Carlo in Monaco, Tseng added.

Noting that almost all the contestants were from professional acrobatic troupes from China, the United States, Europe and Africa, Tseng said it was particularly difficult for Lin, an amateur acrobat, to steal the show.
"Lin is the first Taiwanese delegate eligible to compete in the event and the first in Taiwan to win top prize in the festival's diabolo category," Tseng went on.

The Chinese embassy in Paris tried to interfere in Lin's participation by insisting that event organizers ban him from wearing and carrying the Republic of China flag and demanding that he use the name "Taiwan, China" to attend the competition. Lin especially stressed that he was from Taiwan during the award presentation ceremony.

After the competition, Lin and Tseng traveled to Belgium to take part in a local acrobatic festival there and conduct diabolo demonstrations and exchanges with foreign performers at a local training workshop.

DOC.HEADLINE: Multilingual handbook earns appreciation from foreign spouses

TEXT.P: A handbook in six languages that provides the increasing number of foreign spouses in southern Kaohsiung City with information on living in Taiwan has been warmly received, officials of the city's Civil Affairs Bureau (CAB) said Monday.

The Kaohsiung City Government Foreign Spouse Manual, printed in Chinese, English, Vietnamese, Indonesian, Cambodian and Thai, is aimed at giving foreign spouses, mainly from Southeast Asia and China, a better understanding of local customs and easier access to the information they need, such as how to apply for Republic of China citizenship, the officials said.
According to the CAB, 19,123 foreign spouses living in Kaohsiung City as of end of January are expected to benefit from the manual.

Among the 11 municipal districts of Kaohsiung City, Siaogang, in the southeast of the city with a population of 151,932 as of January, has 804 registered foreign spouses from Southeast Asia, 60 percent of whom are from Vietnam.

In order to make them feel more at home, the Siaogang District Household Registration Office (SDHRO) recently also launched a popular Vietnamese-language Web site to provide the women with more accessible information on government services as well as citizenship applications.

"The location of the SDHRO, addresses of government offices and information about classes especially designed for foreign spouses by the city authorities can be found on the Web site, " an SDHRO official said, adding that browsers can also watch programs from Ho Chi Min City TV and Hanoi TV on the site.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pushes efforts to help rebuild Cloud Gate rehearsal studio

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he has instructed the government to do whatever it could to help the Cloud Gate Dance Theater recover after a fire destroyed the world-famous company's rehearsal studio a week ago.

Speaking during a get-together with members of Taiwan's literati circles to mark the beginning of the Year of the Rat, Chen said he phoned Lin Hwai-min -- founder and choreographer of the 35-year-old dance company -- "in real time" to express his concern soon after Cloud Gate's 1,324 square-meter rehearsal studio, costumes, props and production archives were burned down on Feb. 11.
The fire is believed to have been caused by an electrical short circuit.
Chen said he also immediately instructed the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs to provide assistance to Lin and his dance company.
The president said the blaze saddened him and he could hardly handle the feelings of grief toward Cloud Gate's losses.

"I was wondering why there were various investment or business deals worth over NT$10 billion (US$312 million) under discussion in Taiwan everyday, but few people were willing to invest in outstanding cultural groups like Cloud Gate," he said.
"Is there anything wrong with the country's policies or regulatory systems?" he asked, adding that the Cloud Gate fire could provide a chance for the entire country to reflect.

The Cloud Gate, known for blending Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility, was founded by Lin in 1973. Among its best known works are "Nine Songs, "Moon Water" and the "Cursive" trilogy inspired by Chinese brush calligraphy.
Since the Cloud Gate Dance Theatre is slated for a series of performances in the United States and Europe starting in April, Lin said the most urgent matter is finding a place to rehearse.

"We are lucky to be allowed to rehearse in places provided by the Taipei National University of the Arts and in the Shih-ming Hall of the Taiwan Cement Building, " Lin said, adding that "we still need to find a permanent studio for the long term."

DOC.HEADLINE: Fire has raised renowned Taiwan dance troupe's profile: founder

TEXT.P: A blaze that burned down the warehouse-like rehearsal studio of Taiwan's world- famous dance troupe has placed it on local newspapers' front page for the first time in its 35 year history, the founder said Sunday, lamenting the fact that it took a disaster to raise the troupe's profile.

The Cloud Gate Dance Theater -- known for blending Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility -- has staged over 1,500 shows locally and globally over the years, with each attracting an average of 60,000 people.
The theater is generally regarded as having made a major contribution to raising Taiwan's global image.

However, the theater's founder, Lin Hwai-min, complained that Cloud Gate's performances had never been covered by local newspapers as a front-page story until the fire early last Monday, which he said reflected a general lack of understanding of the performing arts in Taiwan.
He made the remarks while addressing a group of audience at an international book fair, held in the capital in Taipei on Feb. 13-18.
Lin, also the troupe's choreographer, received flowers and cheers of encouragement from dozens people in the audience.

The fire, believed to be caused by an electrical short circuit, destroyed the theater's 1,324 square-meter rehearsal studio in suburban Taipei County in northern Taiwan, as well as costumes, props and production archives.
Meanwhile, Lin admitted that the rehearsal studio was an illegal building.
"Over the past 16 years, despite the blazing heat in the summer and freezing cold in the winter at the illegal iron warehouse, we felt as if we were in heaven, "he said.
Lin explained that the troupe chose the place as a rehearsal studio due to a lack of funds, a problem he stressed is faced by all performing groups in Taiwan.

According to Lin, the Cloud Gate began performing overseas from 1975. The theater put on more than 50 shows in eight countries across the world's seven continents last year, and is scheduled to stage 121 performances at home and abroad this year.
The troupe will depart for the United States and Europe for a series of performances starting in April.
When the theater returns to Taiwan in June, it will begin to use a site in Taipei offered by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) as a temporary rehearsal studio, Lin said.
At the event, Lin also criticized President Chen Shui-bian for failing to carry out his campaign pledge to establish a culture ministry during his eight-year term, which will end in May.
"Of course. President Chen is not the first president in Taiwan who does not attach importance to culture," Lin said.
In the latest Feb. 14 issue of his e-paper, Chen expressed regret over the fire and lauded the theater's contribution to Taiwan's art and cultural sector over the years.
Chen further urged local companies to give financial support to the Cloud Gate and other local performing groups.
He added that the government also needs to review its policy on the country's cultural development.
According to recent remarks made by Council for Cultural Affairs Chairman Wang Tuoh, Lin has declined a proposal made by Chen that state-run enterprises offer emergency relief funds to the theater.
On Monday, Lin visited Taipei County's Fire Bureau and offered his appreciation to 175 firefighters who were dispatched to put out the flame.
As a Buddhist, Lin described the firefighters as "Bodhisattva," a Buddhist deity who had vowed to come to the rescue of all beings who cry out for help.

DOC.HEADLINE: National research repository system taking shape:MOE

TEXT.P: The government is pushing for the establishment of a national research repository system to increase global visibility of and ease access to local academic institutes' research findings, an education ministry official said Monday.

The system -- an online platform for collecting, preserving, and disseminating an education or research institute's intellectual output in digital form -- is modeled after one created by Taiwan's top university, National Taiwan University, in Taipei City.
Commissioned by the Ministry of Education in 2006, National Taiwan University (NTU) recently completed establishing its institutional repository, or IR.

The repository allows an institute to preserve materials such as research journal articles, conference papers, research reports, slides, and teaching plans, as well as administrative documents, in digital files and to establish a Web site for a full-text search.

The education ministry official pointed out that the amount of research papers generated by Taiwan's academia is no less than other developed countries'; however, the citation frequency of Taiwan's research papers was relatively low compared with other countries owing to difficult access to and incomplete preservation of Taiwan's material. Having an institutional repository is believed to be the solution to the problem, the official added.

As part of a policy to promote the repository system among educational institutions nationwide, the ministry this year will help at least 15 universities and 15 vocational training schools to establish their institutional repositories based on each school's research features.

The policy will utilize softwares developed and procedures established by National Taiwan University in establishing its own repository system, which currently includes over 30,000 files of research output of its staff and students, with over 10,000 files being stored in full-text digital form.

The school also helped the ministry set up the Taiwan Academic Institutional Repository Web site--a portal site linked to the repositories of local schools --to provide integrated research reference services, the official said.
He added that at present the Web site only covers NTU's resources, but will eventually include systems established by other schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opposition lawmakers demand disbanding of private defense company

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) demanded Monday that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government immediately disband the private defense company -- Taiwan Goal -- it set up last month to handle Taiwan's arms deals with other countries.

Legislator Kuo Su-chun, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, warned at a press conference that if Premier Chang Chung-hsiung does not disband the company, the KMT-dominated new legislature will adopt a resolution after opening its first session Feb. 22 to forbid the Ministry of National Defense from becoming a founding shareholder of Taiwan Goal or from signing any contracts with the company.

Kuo said that if the defense ministry has already entered into contracts with Taiwan Goal, the KMT caucus will boycott all related government budgets to prevent public funds from being invested in the company.
She added that if the KMT gets back into power in the March 22 presidential election, the new KMT government will not ratify any contracts with Taiwan Goal and will immediately disband the company.

Last week, the premier confirmed the controversial establishment of the private defense company with public funds from various government agencies and state- owned corporations to handle Taiwan's foreign arms transactions. He defended the move as necessary to help upgrade Taiwan's arms industry.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) also confirmed that Taiwan Goal completed registration with the MOEA Jan. 28 as a private company, with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million, and that Wu Nai-jen, a DPP heavyweight and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp. (CSC) -- serves as chairman of the company.

MOEA data shows that Taiwan Goal has a seven-member board of directors, with three seats going to the defense ministry, which will contribute 45 percent of Taiwan Goal's capital. The company's office is located in Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest buildings.

Taiwan Goal is registered to deal in a variety of businesses, including the import and export of arms and weaponry systems; sales of garments and accessories, industrial explosives, precision instruments, and batteries of all types; and product design, according to the MOEA.
Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu has acknowledged that although the defense ministry is the largest shareholder, the company will be beyond the control of his ministry.

DPP legislative caucus whip Lai Ching-te told the news media that the DPP administration, pushed by Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, set up the company. Lai contended that under the National Defense Law, the government has the right to establish such a company, and that no matter which party wins power in the next election, it should allow the company to continue operating.
KMT lawmakers said they believe Taiwan Goal was founded as a private company in an attempt to avoid legislative supervision over arms deals with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's global participation will suit Japan interests: president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan's inclusion in international organizations is in the mutual interest of Taiwan and Japan, and appealed to pro-Taiwan Japanese lawmakers for their continuing support.

Speaking at a ceremony in which he presented medals to Shinji Sato and Takeo Hiranuma, the former and current heads of the Japan-ROC Diet Members' Consultative Council, Chen thanked the two and the council for their efforts in helping Taiwan join global organizations and hoped those efforts would continue in the future.

Taiwan has unsuccessfully sought membership in the United Nations for 15 consecutive years, thwarted by opposition from permanent Security Council member China, and is seeking backing for its bid this year from non-allied friends such as Japan.
The president also commended the council for its efforts in promoting relations between Taiwan and Japan, describing current ties between the two countries as "the best in history."
He cited bilateral trade exceeding US$60 billion in 2007 and Taiwanese and Japanese making a combined 2.5 million visits to each other's countries as signs of the strong ties.

The council, better known as the Nikakon, consists of some 240 Japanese lawmakers from across the political spectrum. It was established soon after Japan switched diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China in 1972 to maintain unofficial ties with Taiwan and has actively promoted closer bilateral exchanges.
Chen specifically lauded Hiranuma for helping Taiwan gain full membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) in his capacity as Japan's minister of economy, trade, and industry in 2001.
In 2005, Chen said, Hiranuma was head of the lawmakers' council and successfully appealed to the Japanese government to grant visa-free treatment to Taiwanese tourists visiting Japan.
Furthermore, due to Hiranuma's efforts in 2007, Japan and Taiwan decided to recognize drivers' licenses issued by each other's government, the president said.
Taiwan and Japan have close trade ties and commerce cooperation despite an absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Promoting Taiwanese literature abroad difficult: Writer

TEXT.P: Li Ang, one of Taiwan's best known writers abroad, is pessimistic over Taiwanese literature's future on the international market, saying "it is an inevitable trend that writing is a sunset industry."

"In past decades, Taiwanese writers have made efforts to introduce their creations to the world and have gained fruitful results, but as to the future, I can only say that Taiwan will have a very rough road, " the outspoken Li said Monday at a workshop organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA).

The 56-year-old Li has reportedly had more of her works translated into foreign languages than any other Taiwanese writer. Her best known novel, "The Butcher's Wife" (1983) , has been translated into a dozen languages, including English, French and German.
She attributed the retreat of Taiwanese literature to the government's lack of ambition, international trends, and pressure on Taiwan from its giant neighbor, China.

Taiwan faced a particularly difficult challenge in the area of Chinese literature, Li asserted, because writers from China are drawing the attention of western publishers while Taiwan remains a distant island unnoticed by readers in the West, especially those in Europe.
"The Taiwanese government has no ambition and foresight in promoting culture," said Li in explaining Taiwan's inability to crack overseas literary markets.
She believed that South Korea, which has organized conferences on cross- continental literature in recent years, could be a model for the country in the future.
Not all observers at the workshop held on the sidelines of the Taipei International Book Exhibition were as pessimistic as Li.

Huang Ying-che, professor of Chinese literature at Aichi University in Japan, and Liao Ping-hui, the director general of the National Science Council's Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, said Taiwanese literature had strengths that could appeal to foreign readers if technical obstacles could be overcome.

Liao acknowledged that Taiwanese literature faced a big challenge to gain international attention, but not because of cultural gaps or competition with China. The problem, Liao said, is a lack of translators who can faithfully and elegantly translate Taiwanese novels into foreign languages, in part because they are not paid enough.
Huang said Taiwanese writers could develop followings because they are more sophisticated on topics like national and gender identification than other Asian writers.
"Taiwanese literature can attract foreign readers' attention with its multiple cultures. That's our advantage, " Huang said.
"What we need are good writers, professional translators, publishers with broad perspectives and aid from government, " said Huang in describing how to promote local works abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic airlines must create new demand to survive: experts

TEXT.P: Several air travel industry experts said Taiwan's domestic airlines must reduce their supply or create new demand in order to weather challenges they face due to increasing rail travel and rising fuel costs.

Fang Chih-chiang, president of the Taipei Airlines Association, told a CNA reporter in a telephone interview Sunday that all of Taiwan's four airlines operating domestic flights have encountered financial difficulties in the last few years due largely to the conveniences offered by land travel operators and the rising oil prices.

Among the four airlines -- Far Eastern Air Transport Co. (FAT) , TransAsia Airways, Mandarin Airlines and UNI Air -- the FAT has applied recently for bankruptcy protection after it reported debts of NT$9.99 billion (US$315 million) at the end of September 2007 and could no longer pay its bills. Like Taiwan's other carriers, FAT has been hit hard by a downturn in domestic air travel, partly due to competition from a new high speed rail service launched in January 2007.
The other three Taiwanese domestic airlines meanwhile were also struggling to survive after they started to cut back on some domestic routes in the western part of Taiwan last May.
Fang admitted that the airlines were facing difficulties because of there has been an excessive supply over demand during the last few years.
He suggested that these airlines allow the market to decide their fate or create new demand for the air traffic, including operating direct flights across the Taiwan Strait to mainland China.
"Although the direct air transport across Taiwan Strait is not a cure-all drug, it will really create some business opportunities under the current situation, " Fang said.
But a political stalemate between Taipei and Beijing has made opening direct flights impossible any time soon, he added.

Meanwhile, National Cheng Kung University professor Tai Tzuo-min noted that domestic air flights have its necessity and if all the airlines stop their routes in the west part of Taiwan, it will create a monopoly by the Taiwan High- Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) , which has already taken passengers from the airlines.

The 345 km-long rail system links Taipei in the north and Kaohsiung in the south, the two largest cities in Taiwan, shortening travel time by rail from the original four-and-a-half hours to 90 minutes.
When the high-speed rail system was under construction, the four airlines already predicted trouble for the future and began expanding into Asian routes.

Although the four airlines were allowed to open some charter flight routes to other Asian regions, including South Korea, Hong Kong and Japan, their income from those flights were unstable. Many of the airlines hoped that the government could open direct transport between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, said an aviation source who requested anonymity.

Citing the example of Japan, whose Tokyo-Nagoya air routes had to be halted after its high-speed rail Shinkansen was launched, a Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) official admitted that now the only way for the Taiwanese domestic airlines to survive is to expand into international and cross-Strait routes.
According to statistics released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) last week, the number of domestic air traffic passengers dropped to a 15-year low last year.

During the 2001-2006 period, the number of domestic passengers declined each year, with ridership on routes over western Taiwan registering a year-on-year decrease of 49.6 percent during the first ten months of last year.

The transportation ministry's statistics also showed that passengers made a total of 12.71 million trips via domestic flights last year, a 26.8 decrease in passenger travel from the 2006 level, despite of the discounts ranging from 20 percent to 50 percent offered by the airlines since the fourth quarter of last year.

Domestic travel reached its peak from 1997 to 1998, with more than 100 flights flying the Taipei-Kaohsiung route daily during that period, compared to 22 flights operating currently, which will dwindle from March when more domestic flight routes will be suspended.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80 percent of women hope to start own businesses: survey

TEXT.P: Some 80 percent of Taiwan's women hope to create their own businesses, although only 4 percent have achieved this goal, according to the results of a survey published Monday by a head hunting company.

According to the poll conducted online by www.1111.com.tw, an absolute majority of the remaining 76.2 percent of the women surveyed have not been able to start their own businesses due to a lack of funds. Concerns over high investment risks and market conditions were also citied by 57.9 percent and 48.1 percent of the respondents, respectively.

On average, the women questioned said they would need about NT$400,000 in funds to begin their own businesses, with 55.8 percent saying that they would use their investment returns or bank savings to start up their ventures and 33.6 percent saying they would apply for a government loan.

Nearly 29.5 percent said they would form a joint venture with friends or relatives, while 28.9 percent said they would seek a bank loan. More than 10.1 percent said they would borrow the start-up money from friends or family members.

As to the question of to what kinds of businesses most women would be most willing to get involved in, 31.6 percent pointed the restaurant sector, followed by 20.7 percent who cited the boutique business and 10.5 percent who mentioned the tourism sector, according to the survey.
Some 6.4 percent said they would like to have their own beauty care centers, while 5.7 percent said they would like to own a day-care center or a cram school, the survey indicated.

As to the question of what kind of skills the respondents think they lack, 66.1 percent replied computing, while 62.8 percent contended that they would have to improve their accounting skills, ahead of 58.9 percent who said they do not possess marketing and sales distribution knowledge.
The poll was carried out from Jan. 28-Feb. 11, recovering 1,079 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPA to create more marine national parks on outlying islands

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government has begun surveying and analyzing the marine ecology of several offshore islands, looking to turn them into marine national parks to better conserve marine resources, an official at the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior said Monday.

The islands being studied by the government include Green Island, a small volcanic island off the coast of southeastern Taiwan, the Penghu Archipelago, which consists of nearly a hundred islets lying in the middle of the Taiwan Strait, and the Three Northern Islands -- Pengjia Islet, Mianhua Islet, and Huaping Islet -- off Taiwan's northern coast.
The agency also hopes to strengthen local residents' understanding of marine resources conservation and encourage them to participate in protecting their environment.

The goal is not only to gain their support for establishing marine national parks on their homelands but also to develop a foundation for the creation of conservation-related jobs in the future, said the official, who is involved in planning marine natinal parks.
The policy reflects the government's efforts to improve its protections of nearby oceans and marine life to levels on a par with world standards.
As part of the campaign, Taiwan inaugurated its first marine national park, the Dongsha Marine National Park, last year. It covers Dongsha Island and two coral reefs located in the South China Sea.
Dongsha's coastal waters are known for their biodiversity, with 489 fish species and about 200 coral strains documented, as well as numerous other marine species.
The park has not yet opened to the public because of conservation concerns, and the focus in the near future will be on coral reef rehabilitation, the official said.
A Marine National Park Headquarters was established last year in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to oversee operations related to the marine park.

Over the next three years, it will remove foreign species of plants from Dongsha Island and cultivate fauna and floral species endemic to the island in the hope of restoring the land to its original look, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT committee to decide on referendum issue: KMT candidate

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has yet to make a final decision on whether it should call on its backers not to participate in the two U.N. membership bid referendums to be held along with the March 22 presidential race, the party's presidential hopeful Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.
Ma said he favors holding the two referendums at another date to push for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations, but added that he is opposed to binding them to the presidential election.
"The KMT has been consistent in its stance that it will act on the decision to be made by the party's Central Standing Committee," Ma told reporters following a visit to a local temple.
"But to date, we have not made any final decision in this regard," he went on.
Meanwhile, speculation surfaced that some Taiwan businessmen based in China have endorsed a pledge calling for a boycott of the two referendums.

One of the two referendums was proposed by the KMT on re-entering the United Nations in the name of the Republic of China or other feasible designations, and the other was initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on seeking public endorsement to join the world body as Taiwan.

Both the United States and China have expressed objections to the DPP's U.N. bid referendum, and there have been reports that some politicians have suggested that President Chen Shui-bian propose a "defensive referendum" on the issue as a way to discard the two planned referendums. The current Referendum Law allows the president to initiate a "defensive referendum" should the country face an external threat.

According to KMT Secretary-General Wu Duen-yih, the KMT hopes that the Central Election Commission (CEC) will be unswayed by the DPP and will de-link the presidential election from the two referendums.

"The KMT expects that the CEC will make such an announcement as soon as possible with only a little more than a month to go before the March 22 presidential election, " Wu said later the same day after attending a meeting at Ma's campaign headquarters.

Commenting on whether there will be a third initiative to push the KMT and the DPP to stop their bickering over the U.N. membership bid, Wu urged the DPP to support the KMT's U.N. membership referendum, as conditions do not exist for the holding of a defensive referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYC sponsors seminar on youth occupational development

TEXT.P: A seminar on occupational development opened Monday in the central county of Changhua under the auspices of the National Youth Commission (NYC).

The two-day seminar at the Chungchou Institute of Technology in Changhua County is being attended by 156 participants, including school workers, Council of Labor Affairs officials, Education Ministry officials and representatives of labor affairs departments from local governments, an NYC official said.

On the first day of the seminar, Barry Chung, former president of the National Career Development Association (NCDA) , delivered a keynote speech titled "New Thinking on Occupational Guidance" and the seminar participants later visited several local industrial companies and the Central Taiwan Science Park, the official added.

On Tuesday, several university scholars are scheduled to share their respective schools' experiences in offering occupational guidance to their students and they will also discuss measures for beefing up students' abilities to obtain jobs, according to the official.
The NCDA is a U.S.-based organization with the mission of promoting career development of people in every age group.

DOC.HEADLINE: Star Cruises liner takes tourists to Lantern Festival in Taiwan

TEXT.P: An ocean liner with Star Cruises, the third largest cruise line operator in the world, ferried 700 foreign tourists to the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung Monday to attend Lantern Festival celebrations for the first time.

The arrival of the ship run by the Hong Kong-based cruise line company marked a milestone for local tourism. Star Cruises pulled out of Taiwan in 2005 and 2006 reportedly because of the lack of direct transportation links between Taiwan and China, but resumed service here in 2007.
The tourists -- from Europe, the United States, Hong Kong, and Macau -- received a warm welcome from Kaohsiung city government officials and the marching band of a local school in the port city.

They also received small lanterns and the city maps as gifts from Tsai Wu-de, head of the city's Economic Affairs Bureau, and had their photos taken with girls in Chinese-style clothes, who greeted them at the port.

Many cities and counties in Taiwan have recently kicked off week-long activities featuring colorful lanterns of various designs to celebrate the traditional Lantern Festival, which will falls on Feb. 21 this year.
The Kaohsiung Lantern Festival celebrations started Feb. 16 and will run through March 2.

Meanwhile, later in the day, the cruise company allowed children from disadvantaged families in the city to board the cruise to watch shows and have food as part of a charity event jointly organized by the cruise operator and the city's Social Affairs Bureau.
The ocean liner is scheduled to leave Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to revitalize Hakka culture with 5-year program

TEXT.P: The government will launch a NT$2.36 billion (US$74.5 million) five-year program to revitalize Hakka culture and further enrich the country's multicultural environment, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said in a statement.
The project, approved Monday by the CEPD, was submitted by the Council for Hakka Affairs and will start this year and run through 2013.

The main objectives of the program include preserving the traditional colors of Hakka communities, bringing cultural development to where Hakka people settled, and renewing idle communities, the statement said.

The Council for Hakka Affairs has selected 15 Hakka communities that will benefit from the project, located in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan, Taichung County in central Taiwan, and Pingtung County in southern Taiwan.

The project will also renovate historic buildings representing traditional Hakka architecture, integrate the operation of Hakka museums, and improve the facilities and equipment at Hakka culture performance venues.

The CEPD expects that the project will intensify Hakka people's identification with their culture, and encourage the public to pay more attention to Hakka culture and visit Hakka museums more frequently, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses due to cold weather near NT$90 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural losses due to the recent cold spell have risen to NT$87.17 million (US$2.75 million), with high-grafted pears being the crop suffering the heaviest damage, according to statistics released by agriculture authorities Monday.
The statistics also show that Taiwan's fishery losses as a result of the latest cold weather amounted to NT$85.43 million, and that Penghu County alone suffered losses totaling NT$84.81 million.

The Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said that a series of cold snaps in the past several weeks, with temperatures dipping to as low as 7 degrees Celsius, have caused damage to at least seven crop categories: high-grafted pears, rice seedlings, flowers, grapes, wax apples, peaches and leafy vegetables.
Statistics compiled by the agency show that damage to high-grafted pear buds alone amounted to NT$79 million.
High-grafted pears are grown mainly in the counties of Hsinchu, Yilan and Taichung.

The high stem-grafting technique was developed to produce juicy and crispy pears of high quality. The method took pear stems from high-altitude temperate zones and had them grafted into cuts in stems of low-altitude Hengshan pears -- a cultivated variety of Asian pear -- to produce a new generation of pear in three to four years.
Currently four high-grafted pear varieties have been developed: the Feng-shui pear, Hsin-hsing pear, the New Century pear, and the Hsing-shui pear.

About 6,000 hectares of Taiwan's farmland has been devoted to growing high- grafted pears, with some 300 million buds grafted each year, according to the Agricultural Research Institute under the COA.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate wants Kinmen talks with Chinese president

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh promised Monday that if elected, he will invite Chinese President Hu Jintao to visit Taiwan and discuss bilateral ties on the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen.
Hsieh made the pledge during a campaign stop in Kinmen, which lies closer to China's southeastern coastal province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

Addressing more than 500 supporters at a ceremony marking the inauguration of his campaign office in Kinmen, Hsieh issued a "Kinmen Declaration" in which he pledged to invite Hu to visit Taiwan and Kinmen if he wins the March 22 presidential election.

Kinmen was once a main battleground during hostilities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the late 1950s, and Hsieh said it would be historically significant if the top leaders from both sides could hold peace talks on the frontline outpost.

"Cross-strait talks were once held in a third country (Singapore). It would be meaningful if such talks could take place in Kinmen, which would put our defense outpost into the global spotlight," Hsieh said.
Acknowledging the existence of cross-strait political differences, Hsieh said the two sides should shelve such divergences for the time being.
"We should not let unsolvable problems hinder possible progress in resolving solvable issues," he noted.

Taiwan and China have not had official talks during the DPP's eight years in power. China has insisted that Taiwan acknowledge it is part of "one China" before talks can be held, a proposition the DPP administration has rejected.

In his "Kinmen Declaration," Hsieh also promised to make Taiwan a war-free zone and Kinmen a special peace zone. Moreover, he pledged to push for China's democratization in addition to promoting Taiwan's sustainable development.
On cross-strait talks, Hsieh said courage, resolve and wisdom are needed and that Taiwan's sovereignty cannot be compromised.
On Kinmen's development, Hsieh said if elected, he will see to it that Kinmen be developed into a special economic zone that features peace, globalization and tourism.

"In addition to expanding the existing direct ferry services between Kinmen and China's Fujian Province, cross-strait charter flights should also be opened to facilitate travel by Taiwanese businessmen operating in China," Hsieh said, adding that if elected, he will allow entry of international capital to speed up Kinmen's development.
Unused military-controlled land plots will also be opened for county government management for commercial and tourism development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan congratulates Kosovo on gaining independence

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) congratulated Kosovo on gaining independence Monday, saying Taiwan "is delighted that the people of Kosovo have the fruits of independence, democracy and freedom to look forward to."
In a statement released Monday, the ministry expressed its admiration for the determination of the people of Kosovo in pursuing the lofty ideal of independence despite a multitude of barriers.

"The people of Kosovo have insisted on an ideal that they believe in, which is to peacefully pursue independence, without being threatened or scared away. Their determination in achieving this lofty ideal is truly admirable," the statement said.

Kosovo, formerly a province of Serbia under United Nations administration, officially announced its independence Sunday and has been supported by the United States, as well as the majority of countries in the European Union.
The ministry noted that self-determination is a right recognized by the United Nations and that it is the people who are masters of their nation's future.
"In no way should the independence of one nation be denied by another," the statement said.

As a member of the international community that cherishes democracy and freedom, Taiwan is delighted that the people of Kosovo have the fruits of independence, democracy and freedom to look forward to, the statement said, adding "May Kosovo enjoy a bright and prosperous future."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA approves suspension of four domestic flight routes

TEXT.P: Requests by three local airlines to suspend four domestic routes have been approved by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The CAA approved Monday Far East Air Transport Corp.'s (FAT) request to stop flying the Taipei-Tainan and Kaohsiung-Hualien routes and Mandarin Airlines' request to terminate its Taichung-Taitung route, both effective March 1.

UNI Airways Corp. request to stop flying the Taipei-Kaohsiung route, also to take effect March 1, was approved by the CAA prior to the Chinese New Year holiday, the aviation agency said in a statement.

The CAA decided to approve the carriers' applications to cease operations of the routes based on the dwindling demand for the flights and the availability of other carriers or alternate means of ground transportation to provide convenient service between the destinations.

The passenger load factor on the Taipei-Tainan route in January this year fell by 64 percent compared to the previous year's level, while the passenger load factors on the Kaohsiung-Hualien and Taichung-Taitung routes for all of last year averaged only 38 percent and 36 percent, respectively, the CAA statement said.

FAT's pullout from the two routes are not expected to have a big impact on the local aviation market, as TransAsia Airways and Mandarin Airlines will still offer service on the Taipei-Tainan and Kaohsiung-Hualien routes respectively.
Mandarin Airlines, however, was the only airline flying between Taichung and Taitung, but the CAA expects rail services to pick up the slack, it said in the statement.
The termination of the routes are yet another sign of the distress facing local carriers that primarily ply domestic routes.
According to the CAA, the start of the north-south high speed railway launched in the beginning of 2007 has dealt a heavy blow to the domestic air travel market.
Flights to eastern Taiwan have also been affected by the introduction of faster trains and more convenient schedules by Taiwan's conventional rail system.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGNorthern Rock takeover brings back nationalisation
Alistair Darling will today introduce emergency legislation to nationalise Northern Rock after abandoning a five-month search for a private buyer for the stricken bank.
Gordon Brown signed off the decision to mount the first national-isation in modern times of a major high-street bank yesterday afternoon, adding aG90 billion liability to the Government's sheet.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan International Book Exhibition draws 410,000 visitors

TEXT.P: The six-day 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition ended Monday after having attracted over 410,000 visitors, according to statistics compiled by the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, organizer of the annual event.
Lin Tsai-chueh, chairman of the foundation, told reporters that the figure is slightly higher than the 400,000 visitors recorded for the 2007 exhibition.
Lin also noted that the number of publishers participating in this year's exhibition was also lower than last year. He said the decrease was related to the worldwide economic recession.
Altogether, 687 publishers, including 360 from 37 foreign countries, took part in the 2008 exhibition, compared with last year's 711 publishers, including 370 from 39 foreign countries.
The domestic and foreign publishers, together with Taiwan's government agencies, operated a total of 2,145 stalls in the Taipei World Trade Center's three exhibition halls.
Australia was the theme country of this year's exhibition and the Australian pavilion displayed over 1,000 books and publications provided by 25 publishers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local institute pioneers system turning rice straws into biofuel

TEXT.P: A research institute in Taiwan has successfully developed the country's first system that can turn rice straws into cellulosic ethanol, a type of biofuel, an official at the institute said Monday.

The Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) plans to complete the construction of a system that can produce 200 liters of cellulosic ethanol on a daily basis by 2010, said Kuo Ming-chao, one of the institute's three deputy directors.

The process developed by the institute at present can transform a batch of 10 kilograms of rice straws into 2 liters of 99.5 percent-pure cellulosic ethanol, and the institute plans to develop a system by 2010 that can process 1 ton of rice straws per day.

According to Kuo, Taiwan consumes 10 million kiloliters of fuel and produces 1.5 million tons of rice straws every year. He believes that the process will one day provide 3 percent of Taiwan's fuel needs, but did not specify when such mass production would begin.

After the 2010 goal is achieved, Kuo said the institute will move on to build a system that can manage 10 tons of rice straws on a daily basis, which would still only serve as a "demonstration" model for local companies.
In the end, Kuo said, the institute will transfer the processing technology to local companies.
The United States has also developed a process to produce ethanol with biomass residues and plans to build a system that can handle 2,000 tons of residues by 2012.

The U.S.' Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, which was signed by U.S. President George W. Bush late last year, requires an increased production of biofuel, focusing mainly on cellulosic ethanol.

Wang Chia-pao, the researcher responsible for the institute's cellulosic ethanol research and application project, described the development of the fuel as a necessary path to seeking an alternative source of energy for Taiwan.

The institute aims to cut down the future mass production cost to NT$25 (about US$0.79) per liter, which he acknowledged is a "very challenging goal" based on the institute's current transferring ability.
At present, the institute will focus on developing the technology and will not strive to lower production costs until the technology is mature, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday.
The weighted price index was up 94.57 points at 7,985.47 on a turnover of NT$3.7 billion (US$116.55 million) at the open. The index gained 14.53 points, or 0.18 percent, to close at 7,890.9 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.747 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.001 from Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/19/08 10:19:14 (EMBARGOED FOR RELEASE AT 16:00 GMT SUNDAY, FEB. 18)
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 19, or the 13rd day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the Sun, is born.
1800: Napoleon Bonaparte proclaims himself First Consul of the newly established French dictatorship.
1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2003: Adm. Ni Yue-si, a strategy adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found." ENDITEM 2007.02.19.TODAY IN HISTORY

1861: Tsar Alexander II signs a proclamation setting free 20 million serfs, almost a third of Russia's population.
1878: Thomas Edison, the U.S. inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th U.S. president, who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War and was an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1915: A French-British fleet begins shelling Turkish fortifications along the strategic Dardenelles waterway in a bid to defeat Turkey and reopen the critical Black Sea supply route to Russia.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi Province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: U.S. forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American lives.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist" and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The ROC and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1958: The ROC Navy sinks three Chinese communist warships and damages three others in a battle off the Min River estuary.
1959: Britain, Greece and Turkey guarantee the independence of the island of Cyprus.
1963: U.S. President John F. Kennedy announces that the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport terminal in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1973: Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister Ing Afredo Obiols Gomez leaves for home after a weeklong tour of Taiwan.
1974: The presiding bishop of the American Episcopal Church, the Most Rev. John Hines, arrives for the Thanksgiving and Holy Communion Service on the 20th founding anniversary of the Taiwan Episcopal Church.
1976: Four Beijing opera stars leave Taipei for Hong Kong to participate in the Hong Kong Festival of Arts.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins the general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Mainland China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
2003: Adm. Ni Yue-si, a strategy adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found."

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News

The Japan Times Britain plans to nationalize Northern Rock
Britain decided to nationalize Northern Rock on Sunday, abandoning a five -month attempt to snare a private sector buyer for the ailing bank and piling more pressure on Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local institute pioneers system turning rice straws into biofuel

TEXT.P: A research institute in Taiwan has successfully developed the country's first system that can turn rice straws into cellulosic ethanol, a type of biofuel, an official at the institute said Monday.

The Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) plans to complete the construction of a system that can produce 200 liters of cellulosic ethanol on a daily basis by 2010, said Kuo Ming-chao, one of the institute's three deputy directors.

The process developed by the institute at present can transform a batch of 10 kilograms of rice straws into 2 liters of 99.5 percent-pure cellulosic ethanol, and the institute plans to develop a system by 2010 that can process 1 ton of rice straws per day.

According to Kuo, Taiwan consumes 10 million kiloliters of fuel and produces 1.5 million tons of rice straws every year. He believes that the process will one day provide 3 percent of Taiwan's fuel needs, but did not specify when such mass production would begin.

After the 2010 goal is achieved, Kuo said the institute will move on to build a system that can manage 10 tons of rice straws on a daily basis, which would still only serve as a "demonstration" model for local companies.
In the end, Kuo said, the institute will transfer the processing technology to local companies.
The United States has also developed a process to produce ethanol with biomass residues and plans to build a system that can handle 2,000 tons of residues by 2012.

The U.S.' Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007, which was signed by U.S. President George W. Bush late last year, requires an increased production of biofuel, focusing mainly on cellulosic ethanol.

Wang Chia-pao, the researcher responsible for the institute's cellulosic ethanol research and application project, described the development of the fuel as a necessary path to seeking an alternative source of energy for Taiwan.

The institute aims to cut down the future mass production cost to NT$25 (about US$0.79) per liter, which he acknowledged is a "very challenging goal" based on the institute's current transferring ability.
At present, the institute will focus on developing the technology and will not strive to lower production costs until the technology is mature, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan International Book Exhibition draws 410,000 visitors

TEXT.P: The six-day 2008 Taipei International Book Exhibition ended Monday after having attracted over 410,000 visitors, according to statistics compiled by the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, organizer of the annual event.
Lin Tsai-chueh, chairman of the foundation, told reporters that the figure is slightly higher than the 400,000 visitors recorded for the 2007 exhibition.
Lin also noted that the number of publishers participating in this year's exhibition was also lower than last year. He said the decrease was related to the worldwide economic recession.
Altogether, 687 publishers, including 360 from 37 foreign countries, took part in the 2008 exhibition, compared with last year's 711 publishers, including 370 from 39 foreign countries.
The domestic and foreign publishers, together with Taiwan's government agencies, operated a total of 2,145 stalls in the Taipei World Trade Center's three exhibition halls.
Australia was the theme country of this year's exhibition and the Australian pavilion displayed over 1,000 books and publications provided by 25 publishers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate wants Kinmen talks with Chinese president

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh promised Monday that if elected, he will invite Chinese President Hu Jintao to visit Taiwan and discuss bilateral ties on the Taiwan-held island of Kinmen.
Hsieh made the pledge during a campaign stop in Kinmen, which lies closer to China's southeastern coastal province of Fujian than to Taiwan proper.

Addressing more than 500 supporters at a ceremony marking the inauguration of his campaign office in Kinmen, Hsieh issued a "Kinmen Declaration" in which he pledged to invite Hu to visit Taiwan and Kinmen if he wins the March 22 presidential election.

Kinmen was once a main battleground during hostilities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in the late 1950s, and Hsieh said it would be historically significant if the top leaders from both sides could hold peace talks on the frontline outpost.

"Cross-strait talks were once held in a third country (Singapore). It would be meaningful if such talks could take place in Kinmen, which would put our defense outpost into the global spotlight," Hsieh said.
Acknowledging the existence of cross-strait political differences, Hsieh said the two sides should shelve such divergences for the time being.
"We should not let unsolvable problems hinder possible progress in resolving solvable issues," he noted.

Taiwan and China have not had official talks during the DPP's eight years in power. China has insisted that Taiwan acknowledge it is part of "one China" before talks can be held, a proposition the DPP administration has rejected.

In his "Kinmen Declaration," Hsieh also promised to make Taiwan a war-free zone and Kinmen a special peace zone. Moreover, he pledged to push for China's democratization in addition to promoting Taiwan's sustainable development.
On cross-strait talks, Hsieh said courage, resolve and wisdom are needed and that Taiwan's sovereignty cannot be compromised.
On Kinmen's development, Hsieh said if elected, he will see to it that Kinmen be developed into a special economic zone that features peace, globalization and tourism.

"In addition to expanding the existing direct ferry services between Kinmen and China's Fujian Province, cross-strait charter flights should also be opened to facilitate travel by Taiwanese businessmen operating in China," Hsieh said, adding that if elected, he will allow entry of international capital to speed up Kinmen's development.
Unused military-controlled land plots will also be opened for county government management for commercial and tourism development, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan congratulates Kosovo on gaining independence

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) congratulated Kosovo on gaining independence Monday, saying Taiwan "is delighted that the people of Kosovo have the fruits of independence, democracy and freedom to look forward to."
In a statement released Monday, the ministry expressed its admiration for the determination of the people of Kosovo in pursuing the lofty ideal of independence despite a multitude of barriers.

"The people of Kosovo have insisted on an ideal that they believe in, which is to peacefully pursue independence, without being threatened or scared away. Their determination in achieving this lofty ideal is truly admirable," the statement said.

Kosovo, formerly a province of Serbia under United Nations administration, officially announced its independence Sunday and has been supported by the United States, as well as the majority of countries in the European Union.
The ministry noted that self-determination is a right recognized by the United Nations and that it is the people who are masters of their nation's future.
"In no way should the independence of one nation be denied by another," the statement said.

As a member of the international community that cherishes democracy and freedom, Taiwan is delighted that the people of Kosovo have the fruits of independence, democracy and freedom to look forward to, the statement said, adding "May Kosovo enjoy a bright and prosperous future."

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses due to cold weather near NT$90 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural losses due to the recent cold spell have risen to NT$87.17 million (US$2.75 million), with high-grafted pears being the crop suffering the heaviest damage, according to statistics released by agriculture authorities Monday.
The statistics also show that Taiwan's fishery losses as a result of the latest cold weather amounted to NT$85.43 million, and that Penghu County alone suffered losses totaling NT$84.81 million.

The Agriculture and Food Agency under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said that a series of cold snaps in the past several weeks, with temperatures dipping to as low as 7 degrees Celsius, have caused damage to at least seven crop categories: high-grafted pears, rice seedlings, flowers, grapes, wax apples, peaches and leafy vegetables.
Statistics compiled by the agency show that damage to high-grafted pear buds alone amounted to NT$79 million.
High-grafted pears are grown mainly in the counties of Hsinchu, Yilan and Taichung.

The high stem-grafting technique was developed to produce juicy and crispy pears of high quality. The method took pear stems from high-altitude temperate zones and had them grafted into cuts in stems of low-altitude Hengshan pears -- a cultivated variety of Asian pear -- to produce a new generation of pear in three to four years.
Currently four high-grafted pear varieties have been developed: the Feng-shui pear, Hsin-hsing pear, the New Century pear, and the Hsing-shui pear.

About 6,000 hectares of Taiwan's farmland has been devoted to growing high- grafted pears, with some 300 million buds grafted each year, according to the Agricultural Research Institute under the COA.
