DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to ease restrictions on Chinese investment in property market

TEXT.P: The government is finalizing its plan to ease restrictions on Chinese citizens intending to invest in Taiwan's property market, offering investment incentives such as exempting them from proving the origin of their capital and allowing them to borrow more from Taiwan banks, a high-ranking Mainland Affairs Council official said Monday.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said under proposed revisions to current regulations, prospective Chinese investors would no long be required to provide any certificate of origin of funds -- a requirement that has blocked Chinese capital inflows because the Chinese government has not permitted its citizens to invest in Taiwan's property market.
The maximum loan amounts that Chinese citizens would obtain from domestic banks could reach 50 percent of the worth of the property, the official said.

Also, the business properties that Chinese citizens would be allowed to invest in would cover most leisure and tourism facilities such as resorts and leisure farms, but exclude hotels near major attractions, in light of the fact the Chinese government has not allowed foreign investment in China's hotels, he said.

Meanwhile, to allow Chinese citizens more time to deal with property transactions in Taiwan, they would be allowed to stay up to 90 days for each visit to Taiwan, compared with a maximum of 10 days per visit and no more than 30 days per year at present, the official said.
Taiwan has opened its property market to Chinese investors since 2002, but only a few cases have been successful so far due to the large number of restrictions imposed by Taiwan.

Asked to comment on the policy, Sherry Wu, director of commercial property of the Taiwan branch of Jones Lang LaSalle, a U.S.-based real estate services and money management firm, predicted that the measure would invigorate Taiwan's property market.
After the measure is implemented, the scale of the commercial property market -- which amounted to NT$120 billion (US$3.78 billion) in 2007 -- is expected to double, Wu said.

Wu noted that while many Chinese investors attracted to the high return on property investment in Taiwan have visited the country over the past several years to explore business opportunities here, they have not been able to make any move because Taiwan imposes many restrictions on Chinese investment in its property market.

Expressing a different view, Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's (NCCU's) Department of Land Economics, said the measure might have short-term stimulation on Taiwan's property market but is not going to resolve the basic problem faced by the country's real estate industry.

According to Chang, the oversupply of residential properties -- which are unaffordable to many people in the country -- is the core issue faced by the industry and is one that cannot be solved by foreign capital.

Lin Chu-chia, a professor at NCCU's Economics Department, suggested that the government sets as few restrictions as possible on the areas Chinese citizens would be allowed to invest in so as to maximize the measure's positive effect on Taiwan's real estate industry.
Also, Lin said the duration of stay for Chinese citizens should not be limited to 90 days per visit, which he claimed is too short for an investor.

DOC.HEADLINE: No unusual movement by Chinese military forces detected: MND

TEXT.P: No unusual movement by Chinese military forces has been detected amid the heat of presidential campaign in Taiwan, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Tuesday at a news conference Tuesday.
Wang Cheng-hsiao, an MND intelligence official, made the remarks when he reported on China's possible military movement ahead of Taiwan's March 22 presidential election.
He said that Chinese military personnel were involved in snowstorm relief and defense readiness operations during the Chinese New Year holiday and engaged in routine basic training afterward.
Wang said that China has deployed around 1,300 missiles in its southeastern coastal provinces opposite Taiwan, with their range covering the island.

"No unusual movement of its 700-odd fighters, 60,000 ground forces and approximately 90 vessels has been detected so far," he said, adding that "the military will continue to monitor the situation closely."
Wang noted that the number of Chinese sea and aerial operations were drastically decreased due to inclement weather conditions over the Chinese New Year holiday.
There were over 180 charter flights between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait during the Chinese New Year holiday, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose sharply Tuesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 133.51 points, or 1.69 percent, to close at the day's high of 8,024.41.

The bourse opened at 7,985.47 and fluctuated between 7,932.79 and 8,024.41 during the day's session. A total of 4.5 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$121.04 billion (US$3.8 billion).

Boosted by the advance on the stock markets in European and Asian countries, all of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stock moving up the most at 4.4 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 4.2 percent, and textile stocks at 2.4 percent. Plastics and chemical shares, machinery and electronics stocks as well as banking and financial issues both gained 1.7 percent, construction stocks were up 0.8 percent, and foodstuff issues increased by 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,321 to 531, with 394 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved up 103 points to close at 8,020, with 45,103 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March gained 114 points to finish at 7,999, with 19,648 contracts traded, while June futures increased 104 points to close at 7,969, with 85 contract transactions.
September futures rose 63 points to finish at 7,780, with 136 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 80 points to close at 7,780, with 82 contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 133.51 points Tuesday to finish at 8,024.41, with market turnover of NT$121.04 billion (US$3.8 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,917 for February; 7,885 for March; 7,865 for June; 7,717 for September and 7,700 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
February TE futures rose 4.7 points to close at 307, with 5,028 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved up 5.35 points to finish at 304.55, with 3,307 contract exchanges.
September TE futures remained unchanged to close at 290, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
February TF futures rose 13.2 points to close at 1,049.2, with 3,384 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures increased 15.2 points to finish at 1,048, with 3,074 contracts traded.

June TF futures moved up 19 points to finish at 1049, with one contract traded, while September TF futures gained 17.2 points to close at 1,050.4, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: South Pacific allies with new leaders still loyal to Taiwan: MOFA

TEXT.P: The diplomatic ties between Taiwan and its three allies in the South PacificXthe Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Republic of Nauru, and the Solomon IslandsXremain solid and close although these nations recently went through power transitions, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regularly scheduled press briefing, Donald Lee, director-general of the ministry's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, noting concerns that there might be a switch in allegiance of the South Pacific nations are "not true", stressed that the diplomatic links between Taiwan and its South Pacific allies remain unchanged and will continue to grow closer and firmer under their new governments.
"The heads of state of these three countries plan to visit Taiwan in March, a clear indication that our friendships remain solid and firm," he added.

According to Lee, Solomon Islands Prime Minister Derek Sikua, Marshall Islands President Litokwa Tomeing and Nauru President Marcus Stephen are scheduled to visit Taiwan March 2, March 9 and at the end of March, respectively.
Marshall Islands Foreign Minister Tony deBrum arrived Sunday to make arrangements for President Tomeing's visit and his counterpart of Nauru is due to arrive Tuesday evening, he said.

Tomeing became president of the Republic of Marshall Islands after winning the election Jan. 7, while Stephen and Sikua were elected Dec. 19 and Dec. 20 last year, respectively, after their predecessors were ousted by votes of no confidence.

The governments of China and Taiwan have been engaging in a long-running diplomatic tug-of-war to attract allies in the Pacific region -- where six out of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies are located -- offering generous aid packages and assistance in economic, agricultural and educational development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese baseball eyes Olympic ticket

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national baseball team has one last chance to earn a berth in the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games baseball tournament, and despite the likely absence of its foreign-based players, the team says it's ready.
It better be.

The squad drew the wrath of home fans late last year when it finished an embarrassing eighth in the Baseball World Cup in November and a disappointing third in the Asian Baseball Championship in December, and many worried that baseball in Taiwan was in a state of permanent decline.
But the team can redeem itself by finishing in the top three of the final eight- team Olympic qualifying tournament that will be held in Taichung and Douliou in central Taiwan from March 3-14.
"In fact, this is a five-for-three competition, " manager Hung Yi-chung said in Taichung, where the team is training for the tournament.
Hung was referring to the quality of the field, with five countries -- Taiwan, South Korea, Canada, Australia and Mexico -- expected to compete for the final three Olympic slots.
The remaining three teams, international baseball minnows Germany, Spain and South Africa, are seen as having little chance of staging a breakthrough.
South Korea is expected to be the strongest team, Hung said, so Taiwan's game plan will be to win two of its three round robin games against Australia, Mexico and Canada to secure a top three finish.

Hung's task will be complicated by the absence of Taiwan's foreign-based stars. Pitchers Tsao Chin-hui and Keng Po-hsuan, who play in the United States, and Lin En-yu and Hsu Ming-chieh, who pitch in Japan, have all dropped out and opted to concentrate on advancing their professional careers.

That means Hung will be left with a roster composed mostly of players who compete in Taiwan's Chinese Professional Baseball League or local amateurs, but the manager said he's prepared to play with an all-local 24-man roster if need be.
Regardless of how the roster shapes up, Hung said, Taiwan will still try to win every game, and could be helped by having more information on its opponents.

Local baseball commentators blasted the national team for poor scouting after its disappointing finishes in the Baseball World Cup and Asian Championship, but it has made more of an effort before this tourney to learn its adversaries' tendancies.

Players have been watching a lot of film from games played by Canada, Mexico and Australia, Hung said, and he believed the three teams will not be as strong as their World Cup squads because they'll be missing some of their U.S. Major League players.
Major League Baseball has prohibited players on teams' 40-man rosters from participating in the Olympic qualifiers.

Hung hopes to have his team sharp by the time the tournament opens next month. To get the players back into game condition, the national squad will play a six- game warm-up series against the six CPBL teams, beginning Feb. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH reports 14th confirmed enterovirus-71 case of year

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) confirmed Tuesday an enterovirus-71 case involving a 21-month-old child in Pingtung County, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Taiwan to 14 for the year.

Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control under the DOH, said that the girl's parents took her to a Kaohsiung medical center on Feb. 4 after discovering blisters all over her body.

The child was released from hospital the next day after her condition improved. However, on Feb. 6, the child developed a fever, symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), as well as arm and leg spasms, Lin said.

The parents brought the child back to the same medical center, and the child was immediately admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. On Feb. 19, after conducting tests, the hospital reported the suspected enterovirus-71 case to the CDC. The child was released from the medical center several days later after her condition had improved.

Lin said that although the latest data shows that enterovirus may be on the wane, the data was compiled ahead of the start of school following the extended holiday break which he noted may be the reason for the decline in new enterovirus cases.

Pointing out that enterovirus may make a resurgence when school starts again, Lin reminded parents and teachers to not let their guard down and to pay attention to students' sanitary habits as well as to make sure that they wash their hands often to avoid being infected.
He also urged parents to take their kids to a hospital immediately if they develop a fever, HFMD symptoms, or arm and leg spasms.

In 2007, there were a total of 49 cases of confirmed enterovirus infections in Taiwan, with two fatalities. So far this year, there have been 14 cases, with no fatalities, which Lin said shows that citizens have become more aware of the threat of enterovirus.

Some major European nations, including Germany, Great Britain, France and Italy, are backing Kosovo's independence. Italian Foreign Minister Massimo D'Alema said Monday that his country would recognize Kosovo as a "sovereign state under international supervision." (By Huang Kwang-chun)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to partner with EU on greenhouse gas monitoring
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 18 (CNA) 02/19/08 17:27:07 (By P.C. Tang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to become an official partner of a European Union greenhouse gas monitoring program after a Taiwanese university signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with laboratories of EU countries in Brussels Monday.

The Taiwan-based National Central University inked the MOU with German and French national laboratories in the Belgian capital, finalizing a joint project aimed at measuring greenhouse gases over the Pacific region.

The agreement paves the way for Taiwan to become a formal partner of the In- Service Aircraft for Global Observing System (IAGOS) program supported by the EU Commission, said Wang Kuo-ying, a professor in the university's Department of Atmospheric Sciences and Institute of Atmospheric Physics.
The formal partnership will also enable Taiwan to learn about greenhouse gas changes being monitored by the IAGOS program in other regions of the world, Wang said.
Taiwan's participation fills a crucial gap in the EU program, which has failed thus far to include the Pacific Ocean in its monitoring program, Wang said.

Starting later next year, the IAGOS program will install monitoring equipment on a total of 10-20 long-haul Airbus aircraft, including some operated by Taiwan's largest carrier, China Airlines Ltd. (CAL), to survey the Pacific Ocean region.
CAL also signed the MOU Monday.

Winston Dang, minister of Taiwan's Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) who attended the signing ceremony in the Belgian capital, lauded the partnership, as it comes at a time when Taiwan is limited diplomatically because of China's obstruction.
Dang said he believes Taiwan's active efforts to join the world in protecting the environment will eventually earn it the recognition of the international community.

At the ceremony, representatives from national laboratories in Germany and French as well as EU officials also said that the cooperation with Taiwan is significant for the EU's related research plans and will enhance their competitiveness.
Prior to the signing of the MOU, Dang gave a speech on Taiwan's achievements and efforts in waste recycling and greenhouse gas reduction.
Dang later told the Central News Agency that the EU attaches great importance to environmental protection, and said it might become a major factor in its interaction with other countries.

Citing China as an example, Dang said that before agreeing to lift its embargo on arms exports to China, the EU might ask Beijing to resolve its heavy pollution problems in addition to improving its bad human rights record.
Later in the day, Dang met with EU officials to review the results of bilateral projects launched last year and exchange ideas on energy and greenhouse gas reduction issues.
In addition, Dang was invited by Luxembourg lawmakers Sunday to visit communities there to learn more about their efforts to conserve energy and use renewable energies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese prisoners in Thailand receive good care: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) rebutted reports that the government ignores Taiwanese prisoners in Thailand, saying efforts have been made to protect their rights, with some even released ahead of schedule due to the ministry's help, a MOFA official said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regularly scheduled press briefing, Donald Lee, director-general of the ministry's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said that Taiwan's 119 inmates in Thailand are not neglected by the government.

"Officials of Taiwan's Representative Office in Thailand paid visits before and during the Chinese New Year to 10 different prisons to console Taiwanese prisoners, " Lee said, adding that the ministry has been actively involved in helping them.
"Assistance such as free health care and medicine, as well as document translations, are provided," he said.
The ministry also worked with the Taiwan Dental Association to dispatch the first ever dental delegation to Thailand in mid-January to give free dental care to the Taiwanese inmates.
"It is something that many other foreign prisoners very much envied," Lee said.

The foreign ministry also provided legal assistance to Taiwanese prisoners who applied for early release, the MOFA official said. Nine Taiwanese prisoners have been granted early release over the years, including three who received general pardons in honor of Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej's 80th birthday last December.
Another 34 have applications for early release pending.
There are 119 Taiwanese imprisoned in Thailand, with 85 percent of them imprisoned for drug trafficking, a felony in the Southeast Asian country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's flat panel display output to top NT$2 trillion: ITRI

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's flat panel display industry is expected to increase 22.6 percent to NT$2.15 trillion in 2008, marking the first time the industry's output has topped NT$2 trillion, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast Tuesday.

In 2007, the industry's production value totaled NT$1.75 trillion, up 37.6 percent from 2006, with panel production exceeding NT$1 trillion for the first time in 2007 to amount to NT$1.28 trillion, an increase of 41 percent from 2006.
Large-area thin-film transistor liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD) panels remained the industry's locomotive in 2007, with the products' production value soaring 42 percent to NT$1.09 trillion.

According to ITRI's Industrial Technology Information Services (ITIS), Taiwan's panel production is likely to further expand by 23.8 percent this year to amount to NT$1.59 trillion, driven mainly by large-area and small- and medium-sized TFT-LCD panels.

The ITIS predicted that the production of large-area TFT-LCD panels measuring 10 inches and over will jump 26 percent to amount to NT$1.37 trillion this year, while that of small- and medium-sized TFT-LCD panels will climb 22.7 percent to NT$156 billion.

However, the production of super twisted nematic liquid crystal display (STN- LCD) panels is expected to decline 9.8 percent to NT$57.5 billion this year, while that of organic light-emitting diode (OLED) panels is likely to drop 5.4 percent to NT$6 billion, the ITIS said.

Meanwhile, the ITIS predicted the production of key parts and components will increase 22 percent to amount to NT$554.18 billion this year, including NT$158 billion for color filters, NT$81 billion for polarizers, NT$138 billion for glass substrates and NT$177.18 billion for back light modules.

DOC.HEADLINE: Syringe vending machines to hit Changhua to fight HIV/AIDS

TEXT.P: Changhua's Public Health Bureau announced Tuesday that it will put syringe- dispensing machines in 49 locations around the county to provide drug users with round-the-clock access to sterile syringes.

Yeh Yen-po, director of the bureau, said that the vending machines are being installed as part of the county government's program to fight the spread of HIV/AIDS and other diseases by making it unnecessary for drug addicts to share needles.
"For just NT$10, drug users can get two sterile syringes, diluent and alcohol- soaked sanitary tissues, " Yeh said.
He noted that the number of new HIV/AIDS cases resulting from the sharing of needles among intravenous drug users in the southern Taiwan county increased to 166 in 2005.

However, after the county government in central Taiwan began the clean needle program in late 2006, the number of new cases declined to 92 in 2007, marking a 52 percent drop over the figure for the previous year.
Under the program, the Public Health Bureau set up HIV/AIDS information service centers at pharmacies, clinics, hospitals and 27 bureau offices around the county, Yeh said.
Intravenous drug users can receive sterile syringes at any of these centers, he said, adding that a total of 160,000 syringes were handed out at the centers last year.
The health bureau decided to install syringe dispensing machines after drug users complained that they could only obtain the syringes during the centers' hours of operations.
The bureau then decided to ask the Department of Health (DOH) for funds to set up syringe vending machines outside the centers to allow drug users round-the- clock access to clean syringes.
Yeh said the bureau will determine whether to add more machines in other locations around the county after assessing the effect of those to be installed.

The first county in Taiwan to set up syringe vending machines is southern Taiwan's Tainan County, which set up 10 such dispensers in May 2007, with 16 machines currently in operation, a Tainan County Health Bureau official told a CNA reporter.
Local media reported that other cities and counties have similar plans, including Keelung City, Taipei County and Taipei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.048 to close at NT$31.698.
A total of US$994 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.775 and hit a low of NT$31.658.

DOC.HEADLINE: EasyCards to be used in northern railway system

TEXT.P: Railway passengers will be allowed to pay their fares with EasyCards in four stations in the greater Taipei area later this year on a trial basis, the president of the Taipei Smart Card Corp. (TSCC) said Tuesday.

The trial, which will cover the Taipei, Wanhua, Banchiao and Shulin stations, will allow the Taiwan Railway Administration to evaluate the feasibility of expanding the use of EasyCards to all 19 stations between Keelung and Jhongli, which see 400,000 commuters per day, according to TSCC President Lin Chih-ying.
The contactless prepaid cards were first launched by the company in September 2002 as a travel pass for passengers using the metro and public bus systems in Taipei City.
Over the past several years, the use of EasyCards has been expanded to Taipei city government-run parking lots and admission to the Taipei Zoo and municipal libraries.
According to the TSCC, the 12 million EasyCards issued so far can now also be used outside Taipei, in Keelung, Yilan, Jhongli and Taichung.

From late March, EasyCards will also be valid on public transport system on the outlying island of Matsu, with the applications covering public buses and ferries between Matsu and Taiwan proper, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to allot NT$23 billion for nano-science, technology R&D

TEXT.P: The government is planning to appropriate NT$23 billion (US$726 million) to fund the second stage of the "Taiwan National Science and Technology Program for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology" slated for 2009-2014, officials at the cabinet- level National Science Council (NSC) said Tuesday.
The first stage, which began in 2003 with NT$17.8 billion in funding, will conclude by the end of this year, officials told reporters.

In the first phase, more than 4,000 science research papers have been generated to date, dozens of top-notch research teams were initiated, and ties between industry, university, and research institutions have been strengthened, they said.

Program Director Wu Maw-kuen, who is also the director of the Institute of Physics under Taiwan's top research institute Academia Sinica, said the program office is now working on the outlines of the next phase by determining which items of research are worth further financial support.

Wu said the focus of the next stage will be nano- electronic and optoelectronic technology, nano-scale instruments, nanotechnology for energy and environmental applications, nano-scale biomedical research, and the various technologies' utilization in potential and traditional industries.

According to the science council, so far completed research projects under the auspices of the program include the visualization of circuits and gene expression patterns in the whole Drosophila (fruit fly) brain, the target drug for diabetes, and nano porosity materials for cell marking and gene therapy.

And those that have already been used in pilot production or mass production include various materials, equipment, machinery, components and instruments using related nanotechnologies developed by Taiwanese researchers, according to the council.
Some of the items have great commercial potential, science council officials said.

They said TAK Technology Co., a local company which received the technology of LiNiCoO2 anode production from the Hsinchu-based Industrial Technology Research Institute, had generated a production value of NT$1.5 billion last year, and the estimated production value for 2009 is expected to reach NT$3 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Religious leaders and foreign diplomats pray for world peace

TEXT.P: Representatives of various religions and foreign diplomats in Taiwan on Tuesday prayed together for peace for Taiwan and the world, in an expression of co- existence and tolerance across different religious and ethnic groups.

The Cross Religions Prayer held at the Museum of World Religions in the Taipei suburb of Yonghe attracted representatives of Christian, Catholic, Orthodox, I Kuan Tao, Hindu, Judaic and Muslim faiths as wells as the ambassadors of the Holy See, the Republic of Honduras and the Republic of Guatemala.

For the love of all conscious beings, may we work hand in hand and listen with our hearts in this new year,said Dharma Master Hsin Tao, founder of the Ling Jiou Mountain Buddhist Society and the Museum of World Religions, which organized the event.
"We shall respect each faith, tolerate each ethnic group, and love each life so as to relieve all beings from their suffering, " he said.

Noting that everyone should devote themselves to human harmony, world peace, and the protection of the earth, Master Hsin Tao further urged the world "to move forward to love, peace and a family on earth."
Marlene Villela-Talbott, Honduras ambassador to Taiwan, praised the gathering, saying, "this is a good opportunity for people all over the world to work together for peace and love.
Citing a line from a Jewish prayer, Raphael Gamzou, Israel's representative in Taiwan, said that"the one who makes peace in Heaven will make peace in Israel, in Taiwan, and around the world."

Expressing his appreciation for the efforts for peace made by the organizer, Gamzou told the Central News Agency that, "I will join all the prayers for peace, the peace for Israel, for Taiwan, and for humanity."
The Museum of World Religions, founded in 2001 by Master Hsin Tao, offers different faiths a bridge for cross-religion exchanges, co-existence of different faiths and world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Award-winning movie director returns from Berlin with trophy

TEXT.P: The director of Taiwanese film "God Man Dog" returned to Taipei Tuesday after winning an award in Berlin for her movie, an allegorical tragicomedy about the crisis of faith in contemporary Taiwan.
Singing Chen said upon her return that she was jubilant and excited to win the Tagesspiegel Readers' Prize affiliated with the annual Berlin International Film Festival.
The prize was sponsored by the Berlin-based national daily Der Tagesspiegel to honor young filmmakers whose movies have been selected for screening in the Berlin Film Festival's Forum for New Cinema.
Noting that the film depicts some of the phenomena and problems in Taiwan, Chen said she wanted to introduce Taiwan to the international community through the film.

"It is a great honor and encouragement to win this prize, " Chen said, adding that she was almost moved to tears when the German audience gave her a standing ovation at the end of the film. German moviegoers are known to be highly discerning and critical, she added.
"God Man Dog" is Chen's second feature film. She received 3,000 euros in prize money by clinching the Tagesspiegel award.
The film will be screened in Taiwan from the second half of March, Chen said, adding that she is hopeful the film will win critical acclaim and become a local box-office success.
The film was chosen from among 36 movies from 33 countries competing in the Forum for New Cinema.

The film tries to unite three disparate stories of unhappy people, touching on the emotional problems of urbanites, the social problems of aborigines and the making of the body into a commodity. A fateful car accident brings together these groups of people from different social classes, religions and ethnicity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local school signs cooperation agreement with UC Berkeley

TEXT.P: A college under prestigious National Taiwan University (NTU) signed an agreement Tuesday with the Hass School of Business at University of California, Berkeley, on academic cooperation.

The agreement was inked at NTU Taipei campus by Hung Mao-wei, dean of NTU's College of Management, and Tom Campbell, dean of the Hass School of Business, one of the best business schools in the United States.

Hung told CNA reporters that the agreement paves the way for the two schools to hold exchange student programs and joint seminars and research projects in the hope of boosting academic improvement for both sides. He also expressed hope that the agreement will help the college to be ranked among the world's top management schools.

Exchanges in teaching personnel will begin in the summer at the earliest, Hung said, adding that the college will also help Hass to strengthen its exchanges with high-level Taiwanese business leaders.

The college has made great efforts to create an international teaching and learning environment. It worked with three foreign schools with excellent academic records in 2005 and the number has grown to nearly 50 this year, Hung said.
"Improving students' international perspectives during their college period gives them higher competence and more options for their further studies or careers," Hung said.
In Asia, Hass also cooperates with universities in Hong Kong and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu residents pitch in to clear beaches of dead fish

TEXT.P: Penghu county government officials and residents joined in a campaign Tuesday to remove dead fish washed ashore by the ton on the outlying island chain as a result of the recent cold spell.

Penghu Magistrate Wang Chien-fa led the campaign, supported by members of the public and officials from the county government's Environmental Protection Bureau, Agriculture and Fishery Bureau, Public Works Bureau and Economic Affairs Bureau.

Wang launched the drive after massive numbers of dead fish kept washing up on Penghu's scenic beaches, although environmental protection officials had been using heavy equipment to remove 17 metric tons of fish carcasses over the past two days.
The Penghu island group lies about 50 km west of Taiwan proper. The four most seriously affected beaches are located in Huhsi township and Baisha township.
"This ecological disaster will have a serious impact on Penghu's fishery industry," Wang said.
"The dead fish on the beaches are from shallow waters," Wang continued, adding that more dead fish from deeper waters might wash ashore in the next few days.
Wang expressed concern that the abnormal cold weather might have broken the food chain, making it difficult for Penghu's fishermen to make a living.
He said it is important that the county government step up marine conservation programs to allow the release large amounts of young fish into the ocean.

When the fish first started washing ashore, some local residents picked them up and made "a small fortune." But as more carcasses kept piling up on the beaches, county government officials began to worry about sanitation problems as the fish began to rot.

Penghu's fish culture industry also suffered its heaviest losses in 30 years -- estimated at NT$181.86 million -- as a result of the cold spell over the past two weeks, according to statistics released by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

County government statistics show that fish farms in Penghu lost over 1,500 metric tons, or 80 percent of their fish, including cobia and grouper, which experts say cannot survive temperatures below 15 degrees Celsius.
The COA is working on a relief program to provide low-interest loans to help Penghu's fish farmers get back on their feet.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH signs MOU with university to produce serum to combat snake venom

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) and National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Tuesday on the production of horse serum to combat snake venom.
Steve Hsu-sung Kuo, director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, and university President Ku Yuan-kuang signed the MOU, with DOH Minister Hou Sheng- mou looking on.
Hou noted that the university has a spacious campus and livestock departments, which he said would make it "most suitable for the production of horse serum to fight against snake venom."
The concept was first suggested by Ku, Hou said, and after the DOH chief inspected the school's environment, the deal was sealed.

The NT$250 million (US$7.92 million) project calls for the construction of a horse stable and the production of the horse serum, and is expected to result in annual output of 5,000 vials of horse serum for domestic use as well as exports.
The project is significant, CDC officials said, because the serum is not readily available from other countries.
They said various diluted snake venoms will first be injected into the horses, which will then produce the antibodies used in the serum to fight poisonous snake bites.

The officials said that Taiwan has produced serum to fight snake venom for more than six decades, with both its quality and quantity winning worldwide recognition. Only three people have died of snake bites in Taiwan over the past five years because of a delay in receiving the serum.
The CDC currently maintains around 50 horses in a rented stable in Houli, Taichung County, but they will be moved to the new stable as part of the project, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Taiwan No. 1' exhibition to open in central Taiwan

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring people, events, places and things that have set milestones in Taiwan's history is slated to open Feb. 23 in central Taiwan to enhance understanding of the country's history, an organizer said Tuesday.

The Taiwan No. 1 exhibition will run through Aug. 22 at Academia Historica's Taiwan Historica in Chunshin New Village in the central county of Nantou, Hsieh Chia-liang, head of Taiwan Historica, told a press conference in Taipei.
Hsieh said he hopes visitors will learn about many of the milestones in Taiwan's past and that the exhibition will help them "look on the bright side" of Taiwan.
The exhibition will display Taiwan's first popular hit song record and a replica of the first fossil to be discovered in Taiwan, Hsieh noted.

Ann Chen -- Taiwan's taekwondo fighter who won a gold medal in the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul -- said at the press conference that she felt proud to be featured in the exhibition and encouraged the public to see it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Digital divide exists among employees: survey

TEXT.P: Statistics released Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) indicate that the Internet is more accessible to young workers with high-level education in Taiwan, while a digital divide still exists among workers, varying with age, educational level, vocation and region.
According to the survey results, about 71.4 percent of the labor force are connected to the Internet, a 17.8 percent increase from 2003.
The survey also found that more than 96 percent of workers aged between 15 and 24 have used the Internet, while less than 32 percent of workers above 55 years of age have done so.

In the category of employment, about 95 percent of employees in finance and assurance services have to use a computer at work, and 92.2 percent of those in the information and communication sector use them, while only 28.3 percent of workers in the service industry do so.

The statistics also show that 94.3 percent of workers in Taipei have a personal computer at home, while 89.1 percent in the southern city of Kaohsiung and in northern Taiwan have one and 82.7 percent in central regions of the island have computer access. In eastern and southern Taiwan, less than 80 percent of workers own personal computers.
The survey was conducted by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission in September 2007, with a total of 8,590 valid responses collected from workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate receives honorary degree from Taiwanese university

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in the southern city of Tainan conferred honorary degrees Tuesday on two outstanding foreign scientists, including a Nobel laureate, for their contributions to Taiwan's scientific development.

Aaron Ciechanover, an Israeli biologist who serves as a chair professor in the university, was awarded a Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2004 for his co-discovery of one of the most important cyclical processes in biochemistry. Ciechanover is also a faculty member of the Vascular and Cancer Biology Research Center, the Rappaport Faculty of Medicine and Research Institute, and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology in Haifa, Israel.

Britton Chance, who is also a chair professor of the university, received a Ph.D. in physical chemistry in 1940 at the University of Pennsylvania, and a second Ph.D. in physiology at Cambridge University in 1942.

Chance, now 94, is currently a professor at the University of Pennsylvania and has been a member of U.S. National Academy of Science and a foreign member of the British Royal Society. His research interest focuses on the use of infrared light to characterize the properties of various tissues and breast tumors. With more than 4,000 publications, Chance was also on the U.S. Olympic yachting team in 1952.
NCKU President Lai Ming-chao presided over the conferral ceremony, which was attended by more than 100 domestic and foreign academics and experts.

Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, sent an e-mail to NCKU expressing gratitude for the respect given to Ciechanover and expressing hope that Taiwanese and Israeli scientific investigation can be further boosted through Ciechanover's contributions.
During the ceremony, Ciechanover said the academic sector is a sphere in which people can contribute and win recognition regardless of nationality or political affiliation.

Chance for his part noted that sciences are a wonderful puzzle for him. "Sciences keep us going forward and never let us rest, " Chance said, adding that he is lucky to have had the privilege to explore the sciences.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate confirms possibility of relaxing China policies

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , confirmed a media report Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian plans to relax cross-Taiwan Strait trade and investment policies, describing it as the result of "internal negotiations" within the party.

Admitting that "the DPP administration would assess relaxing its China-related economic and investment policies," Hsieh attributed the latest development to "continued negotiations and communications within the party."

His comments, made at his campaign office in response to reporters' questions, coincided with recent speculation that the president was assessing the possibility of relaxing cross-strait economic policies before his term ends on May 20.

It had been previously reported that Hsieh and the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan were at odds over his proposals to reduce or waive punishment for Taiwanese businessmen who have invested illegally in China.

In response to another media report that the government would ease restrictions on Chinese nationals investing in Taiwan's real estate market, Hsieh said that as far as he knew, Chinese investors would only be permitted to invest in commercial properties.
Hsieh also said he hopes to help lure Taiwanese businessmen operating in China to return home and invest in the domestic market by helping them resolve labor, capital and technology obstacles.
The DPP presidential candidate has tried to appeal to swing voters by offering a vision of closer relations with China, in contrast to a less accommodating policy favored during Chen's presidency.
Hsieh said Monday that he would invite Chinese President Hu Jintao for talks on the Taiwan-controlled island of Kinmen if elected president on March 22.
According to the DPP presidential hopeful, Taiwan and China still can conduct negotiations even if the two sides have many longstanding disputes dividing them, including Taiwan's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to invest NT$15 billion in eastern rail line

TEXT.P: The government has decided to invest NT$15 billion (US$468.8 million) over the next seven years in the first phase of a project to modernize the rail system in the less-developed eastern part of the country.

The overall plan, developed by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), consists of two major projects to improve the 155-kilometer part of the line connecting Hualien and Taitung -- replacing diesel-powered trains with electric-powered trains and converting single track sections to double track.
When the project is fully completed, the line's 2 hour 55 minute travel time will be reduced to under two hours and out of the 30 stations on the line at present, only 11 will remain.

At a briefing on the plan Monday, Sharon Hsieh, one of the council's planners in the Urban and Housing Development Department, said the first phase of the plan, to begin as early as sometime next year, will focus on the electrification of the line and laying double track in sections with severe bottlenecks.
During the second phase, she said, the electrification process and the line's conversion to a double track railway will be fully completed.

Hsieh said switching to electric-powered locomotives, which are commonly used in most of Taiwan's railway system, will increase train frequencies and improve safety. Average speeds will be improved to 130km/hr from 110km/hr by using electric power.

The eastern railway network is formed by three main sections -- the Yilan Line, the North-link Line and the Hua-Tung Line. While the two northern lines are fully electrified, only diesel powered trains can operate on the Hua-Tung Line.

That means travelers from Taipei to Taitung must either change trains in Hualien or wait there while an electric-powered locomotive is replaced a diesel-powered one. The inconvenience and longer travel time to Taitung is seen as an impediment to tourism in the region.

Hsieh said the first phase of the project will take seven years to complete at a cost of NT$15 billion. The budget will be reviewed annually by the legislature, and the council will review the project's construction progress carried out by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

The plan is part of a 2005 government campaign aimed at bringing greater economic prosperity to Taiwan's eastern countiesVYilan, Hualien and Taitung -- that includes development plans ranging from rebuilding rural communities to upgrading transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group calls for referendum on fourth nuclear power plant

TEXT.P: A civic group called Tuesday for a referendum to decide the fate of the fourth nuclear power plant under construction in Kungliao township, Taipei County.

Iap Phok-bun, chief executive of the Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association (Nuke-4 RIA) , said the controversial issue is of major public concern and should be decided by the people in a referendum.

Iap made the remarks in response to remarks made earlier in the day by former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh calling for construction of the plant to continue on the grounds that Taiwan is facing a worsening energy shortage.
He also called for an amendment to the Referendum Law to lower the threshold of interest for the holding of a referendum.

According to Lee, he recently met former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin I-hsiung and they agreed that the DPP's goal to make Taiwan nuclear-free should be put aside for 50 years.
Both Lee and Lin were previously staunch supporters of the DPP's nuclear-free goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT might respond to inquiry on presidential candidates' status

TEXT.P: In response to a question emailed by a CNA reporter, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) spokesman Thomas Hedges wrote Tuesday that AIT "will consider" responding to issues of U.S. citizenship and permanent residency concerning both of Taiwan's presidential candidates should it receive such inquiries from the Taiwanese authorities.

"AIT would certainly consider responding to an inquiry from the Central Election Commission regarding U.S. citizenship or permanent legal resident status of candidates in the presidential election. To date, AIT has received no such inquiry, " Hodges wrote in an email.

The Central Election Committee (CEC) has requested authorization from both ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Frank Hsieh and Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Ma Ying-jeou in order to verify whether both hold dual citizenship, which would violate Taiwanese election laws, or permanent residency of a foreign country.

Hsieh's camp has recently challenged Ma over his possession of a U.S. green card. Ma claims that the green card, which he obtained while studying in the U.S. in the late 1970s, lost its validity in the mid-1980s after he returned to Taiwan.
The CEC, which listed eight questions in a questionnaire for both campaigns, had not received replies from either Hsieh or Ma, CEC spokesman Deng Tien-yu said that day.
Both were asked to provide their passport numbers, dates of birth, Chinese and English names and say whether they hold U.S. social security numbers, foreign residency or passports.
In addition to the AIT, the CEC will also submit the same inquiries to the representative offices of Japan and the United Kingdom on the matter.
Hsieh studied in Japan and Ma was born in Hong Kong, a former British colony.

In his email response, Hodges wrote that as AIT Taipei Office Director Stephen Young and senior U.S. State Department officials have said on several occasions, the U.S. government has no favorite in the election.
"We will respond to inquiries of this nature in whatever manner best maintains our neutrality in this election, " he wrote.
The AIT declined to comment on the dispute when Hsieh's camp first made the allegation against Ma in late January.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate swipes DPP rival over Kinmen talks offer

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou took aim Tuesday at his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Frank Hsieh, accusing him of making "sensationalist and unworkable empty remarks" that are not beneficial to the people's livelihoods.

"Hsieh should prioritize issues concerning the people's livelihoods in his remarks about cross-Taiwan Strait ties if he is to comment in this regard, " Ma said, arguing that "it is neither imminent nor possible for the leaders of Taiwan and China to meet at present."

Ma made the comments to reporters in a gathering after a tour of Shenao fishing port in Taipei County, northern Taiwan. The KMT hopeful also unveiled the marine policy he will adopt if elected president on March 22 during a meeting with Shenao residents.
Hsieh offered an olive branch a day earlier to Chinese President Hu Jintao, inviting him for talks on Taiwan-held Kinmen Island if Hsieh wins the presidency.
According to the KMT presidential candidate, cross-strait labor, fisheries and trade disputes are urgent issues that the two sides should seek to settle quickly.

Turning to speculation that the DPP government is assessing the feasibility of relaxing its China economic and investment policies and reducing penalties for Taiwanese businessmen who have invested in China against Taiwanese regulations, Ma urged the administration not to waste its time as there are only three months left of Chen's presidency.
"The DPP should have done so much sooner, since it came to power in 2000," Ma said.

Hsieh confirmed earlier that day that the government is studying the possibility of relaxing its China policy in a bid to mark a departure from President Chen Shui-bian and attract more voters, including the many China-based Taiwan businessmen.
According to unofficial estimates, the number of Taiwan businessmen operating in China and their families could amount to some 2 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: 25% of health insurance used for patients with serious disease

TEXT.P: One quarter of the NT$440 billion (US$13.75 billion) health insurance expenses in 2007 were spent on patients with serious illnesses, the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) said Tuesday.
Among them, 320,000 cancer patients used up most of the expenses at NT$36 billion, according to 2007 statistics.

They said that in addition to the cancer patients, patients requiring dialysis and respirators, psychiatric patients and premature babies all benefited from the health insurance payments, which they said "have helped patients avoid financial crisis because of their diseases and have helped build up a social safety net."

The officials said that as of the end of 2007, 760,000 people had met the criteria to be listed as major or serious patients. The number in this category patients accounted for between 10 percent and 14 percent of patients a decade ago, but dropped to between 4 percent and 9 percent over the past three years.
This shows that the growth in the number of patients with major or serious illness has slacked off, they said.

The number of cancer patients was the largest group, with each patient using up more than NT$100,000 of national health expenses on average. In comparison, the 63,000 kidney patients used up NT$32.7 billion, averaging NT$520,000 annually per patient.
Nearly 30,000 patients that used respirators used up more than NT$25 billion, among whom, over half used the respirators for more than 21 days, at an average cost of NT$7,610 per day.
The officials said that the increase in new dialysis patients and the total number of dialysis patients has also lessened and that the growth of expenses allocated to them has also slowed.
The number of patients requiring respirators had climbed to 30,000 in 2007 from 25,000 five years ago, and the costs also increased to NT$27.3 billion in 2006 from around NT$22 billion in 2003-2005.
The growth level surpassed the growth of around 4 percent of national health insurance expenses annually and had only slackened off since 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan officially recognizes Kosovo independence

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang announced Tuesday that Taiwan officially recognizes Kosovo's independence but denied speculation that the decision came after angry remarks from China about Taiwan's expression of congratulation to the newly independent country.

The decision came after the United States and other European countries recognized Kosovos sovereignty, Huang said, adding that the remarks by China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs did not influence Taiwans decision.

China reacted angrily to Taiwans expression of support for Kosovos independence. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Liu Jianchao said in a statement Monday thatit is known to all that as a part of China, Taiwan has no right or eligibility to give so-called recognitionto Kosovo.

As a sovereign, independent country and part of the international community with 23 allies, there is no doubt that Taiwan has the right to recognize Kosovo,Huang said, adding that Taiwans expression of congratulations was a kind ofacquiescencebefore Tuesdays official announcement of recognition.
It would be negligent of the ministry if Taiwan did not express its stance on this significant international matter,he added.

Huang said Chinas remarks came asno surpriseas it has long been squeezing Taiwans diplomatic space in the international community. Although the recognition of Kosovo is by no means a response to Chinas comment, had Taiwan done nothing on the issue, it would be admitting that what China said is correct.

Self-determination is a right recognized by the United Nations, and Taiwan, a member of the international community that cherishes democracy and freedom, is delighted that the people of Kosovo have the fruits of independence, democracy and freedom to look forward to, the minister said.

Under international law, a sovereign state can recognize an entity as a country to join any international body that requires statehood, Huang noted, saying that Chinas remarks failed to accord with the basic concept of international law.

Huang said there have been some contacts between Taiwan and Kosovo over the last two years and that Taiwan has made a good impression on Kosovan government officials and media that have visited Taiwan.

Given that Taiwan wishes to develop all kinds of relations with any country that cherishes peace and freedom, Taiwan willcontinue the bilateral contacts and develop further relations based on respect and mutual willingness,he said.

Kosovo, formerly a province of Serbia and under UN administration since mid-1999, has over 90 percent ethnic Albanians and 7 percent Serbs making up its 2 million population. It has officially declared independence and has been recognized by the United States as well as the majority of countries in the European Union.
However, there are a number of dissenters to Kosovos independence, including Serbia and Russia, which even called an emergency United Nations Security Council meeting to protest the declaration.

China expressed grave concern over Kosovo's declaration of independence Monday, saying that it can produce a series of results that will lead to a seriously negative influence on peace and stability in the Balkan region, and that U.N. Security Council Resolution 1244 is still the political basis and legal foundation under which Kosovo's status should be resolved.

China fears that the immediate recognition granted to Kosovo by major European countries and the U.S. might set a precedent for Taiwan and Tibet, which have a similar relationship to Beijing as Kosovo has to the Serbian capital, Belgrade.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung poised to begin light rail construction

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government will begin to award contracts for a light rail project as soon as the Cabinet approves the project's budget of NT$12.2 billion (US$385.12 million), the city government's Mass Rapid Transit Bureau said Tuesday.

Officials in charge of the project's planning and integration told reporters they will invite the private sector in June at the latest to invest NT$5.29 billion in the project, while 75 percent of the rest of the budget will come from the central government, with the remaining 25 percent put up by the city government.
The officials said the city government cannot afford to wait any longer, because the central government cannot be expected to indefinitely stand by its promise to provide the needed funds.

The 19.6-km light railway is proposed to supplement Kaohsiung's mass rapid transit system, which is still under construction. The circular line will have 34 stations, with a 16.3 km stretch of the line completed for use in 2013 and the full line going into operation in 2017.
In January, the Kaohsiung city council decided to freeze an initial NT$60 million budget intended for acquiring land for the project.
Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has expressed concern that further procrastination might force the southern port city to abandon the project altogether.

Most council members, including Speaker Chuang Chi-wang, favor a bus rapid transit (BRT) system instead of a light rail circular route, because they contend that light rail systems are no longer preferred by cities in other countries as the centerpiece of their regional transportation systems.

They have suggested a high-quality bus service, which they said could be established at a cost of NT$60 million per kilometer, much lower than the NT$NT$600 million per kilometer for a light rail system.

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets visiting Marshall Islands foreign minister

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian met at the Presidential Office Tuesday with Marshall Islands Foreign Minister Tony deBrum, who arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a five- day visit.
DeBrum is visiting Taiwan to make arrangements for a visit next month by Marshall Islands President Litokwa Tomeing at Chen's invitation.
Chen extended his congratulations to the Pacific island's United People's Party (UPP) for its victory in the presidential election held Jan. 7 and to the new government formed by the UPP.

He also expressed gratitude to deBrum for his contributions to bilateral diplomatic relations. DeBrum was finance minister of the Marshall Islands when the two countries forged diplomatic ties Oct. 21, 1998 and also attended the signing ceremony, Chen noted , adding that both deBrum and the UPP have made great efforts in forging and maintaining the ties.

Chen said he invited Tomeing to make a state visit when he phoned to congratulate him Jan. 9. He also thanked Vice President Annette Lu for setting up the timing of the visit on her diplomatic trip to the Marshall Islands last month.
Chen expressed hope that relations between Taiwan and the Marshall Islands will grow closer on the basis of their present solid friendship.

DeBrum told Chen that his country is grateful for the help provided by Taiwan's government and people. It has always supported Taiwan's determination to seek independence because what Taiwan has undergone has also been experienced by the Marshall Islands, he added.

Chen pointed out that he will have already left the Presidential Office when the third Taiwan-Pacific Allies Summit is held later this year in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, but he said he will still receive Tomeing and a Marshall Islands delegation in private.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Academia Sinica head says nuclear plants are `lesser evil'

TEXT.P: Former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Tuesday that his support for the construction of a fourth nuclear power plant in Taiwan does not represent a change in his stance, explaining that he considers nuclear energy "the lesser evil."

Lee was responding to questions about an Academia Sinica environment and energy group's report released a day earlier on cutting carbon dioxide emissions. Lee served as the convener of the country's top research institute's group.
The report also calls for liberalization of trade between Taiwan and China and the opening up of the energy market between the two sides.

"With the current situation of insufficient energy and no feasibility of turning away from nuclear energy, the group is forced to choose the lesser evil," Lee said on the sidelines of a meeting to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the late Chien Szu-liang, who served as Academia Sinica president from 1970-1983.
Lee said he agrees with ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) former Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung's ideals of having a "nuclear-free homeland, " but said present CO2 emissions are too high.
Coal-fired power plants contribute heavily to CO2 emissions.
"To achieve the goal of cutting CO2 levels in 2025 to the level of 2000, the new government should put off the decommissioning of the previous older nuclear power plants," Lee said.

The DPP government, in response to Lin's call for a "nuclear-free homeland," suspended the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant in October 2000, shortly after President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for his first term in office.

An agreement was reached for the resumption of construction only after bitter wrangling between the executive and legislative branches in February 2001, but billions of dollars were lost due to the suspension.
The power plant in Kungliao, Taipei county has yet to be completed.

In response to the Academia Sinica report, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh gave a more reserved response, saying that the party has already included the goal of having a "nuclear-free homeland" in its party platform.
The DPP is opposed to the construction of the new nuclear power plant, Hsieh said, adding that Taiwan should instead "have efficient, low-risk generators replace the aged generators."
His rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang, was positive about the report.
Ma said that reducing the use of energy that causes CO2 emissions has become a world trend and urged the speedy completion of the fourth nuclear power plant.
Lee, well-respected in Taiwan and a Nobel laureate, was considered a major factor in catapulting Chen into the presidency in 2000 when he openly endorsed him.
Chen's victory ended KMT's rule of more than five decades in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC to reduce penalty on businessmen who invested illegally in China

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) confirmed Monday that the government will lower fines on Taiwanese business people who violated local regulations when investing in China.

President Chen Shui-bian reportedly is considering offering amnesty before he leaves office in May to those businesses that invested in China without the permission of the government, hoping to lure them back to Taiwan.

Companies that violated investment laws when they relocated to China are subject to fines ranging between NT$50,000 (US$1,577) and NT$25 million, and are reluctant to return to Taiwan because of fears they would have to pay a stiff penalty.
The MAC official said under the new government policy, his agency was inclined to limit any fines to the minimum amount permissible, which he felt would provide an incentive for their return.
"In my opinion, most of the Taiwanese businessmen are more willing and can afford to pay the lowest penalty," the official said, but he indicated there would be some exceptions.

"Taiwanese enterprises with operations in China making products that are not among the categories permitted by the government to be produced there will not be eligible for the amnesty, as it would require amending the law," the official said.
"The MAC will continue study ways to address the issue, " he added.

The biggest fine ever levied under the existing regulations was NT$5 million, imposed on United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) , the world's No. 2 chip foundry, for helping a Chinese chipmaker establish a plant in Suzhou, China by providing capital, personnel and technology.

In addition to the amnesty policy, the MAC official said, the government also plans to offer more tax and land acquisition incentives to lure Taiwanese business people with investments abroad back to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA allots funds to win back China-based Taiwan investors

TEXT.P: In a bid to lure Taiwanese investors back from China to help boost the local economy, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has earmarked NT$10 million to help their enterprises upgrade capabilities if they want to invest in Taiwan, Minister Steve R.L. Chen announced Monday.
The plan is part of an existing project aimed at offering assistance to local small and medium businesses to obtain business expertise and upgrade manufacturing techniques.

Chen said the ministry is also planning to adopt simplified application procedures to allow China-based Taiwanese investors, who have yet to complete company registration in Taiwan, to apply for a subsidy before setting up a company here.
Also Tuesday, Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey dismissed speculation that the government's plan to adjust its policy on cross-Taiwan Strait trade is related to the March 22 presidential race.
"The government, when coping with cross-strait economic issues, has been going beyond party lines and never takes into account factors associated with election results," Shieh said.
More than 1 million Taiwanese business people and their family members are reportedly living in China. They represent a significant voting bloc in the upcoming election.

Shieh did not respond to questions regarding whether the government will grant amnesty to Taiwanese investors who have violated relevant regulations in investing in China. Violators are subject to legal penalties.
Shieh argued that China is no longer favorable to Taiwanese investors due to the higher cost of doing business in the mainland as a result of China's new labor laws and stricter tax regulations.
Therefore, Shieh said, the government is duty bound to create an attractive investment environment in Taiwan for the Taiwanese business people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate decides on permanent site for rehearsal studio

TEXT.P: Taiwan's world-famous Cloud Gate Dance Theater has decided to choose a disused art and education site in the northern county of Taipei to be the theater's permanent rehearsal studio, a Taipei County official said Tuesday.

The decision came as a surprise because Lin Hwai-min, founder and choreographer of the 35-year-old dance company, said a day earlier that the company still needed time to finalize a decision on its new studio.
The theater's 1,324 square-meter rehearsal studio, costumes, props and production archives were lost in a fire Feb. 11.
Lin was expected to call a news conference the following day to explain the company's decision, along with Taipei magistrate Chou Hsi-wei.
Lin contacted Chou Monday to express his willingness to rent the site in the county's Tamshui township as a new rehearsal studio, the county official said.
Chou welcomed Lin's decision and promised his full assistance for the troupe, known for blending Asian mythology, folklore and aesthetics with a modern sensibility, according to the official.
Among Cloud Gate's best known works are Nine Songs, Moon Water and the Cursive trilogy inspired by Chinese calligraphy.
Following the fire, the Taipei county government, the Taipei city government and the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) offered to provide Lin with rehearsal spaces and funds.

During a Feb. 14 meeting with CCA Chairman Wang Tuoh, Lin told Wang that he had decided to choose the Taiwan Human Rights Memorial park in Taipei City's Jingmei as a mid-term rehearsal venue and will start to use it from March.
Cloud Gate is generally considered to have greatly raised Taiwan's international profile.
The theater has staged over 1,500 shows locally and globally over the years, with each attracting an average of 60,000 people.

Lin had previously blasted the central government for failing to boost the country's cultural development and called for greater attention to local performing art groups, which he said are in dire financial need.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hospital, convenience stores to raise money for aborigines

TEXT.P: A Christian hospital in eastern Taiwan announced Tuesday that it was joining hands with FamilyMart, a convenience store chain, to solicit donations to help aboriginal youths.

Huang Sheng-hsiung, executive officer of the Mennonite Christian Hospital in Hualien, said the goal is to raise NT$11.75 million (US$357,200) for aboriginal youths who cannot pursue regular studies to learn vocational skills, and help them come out of their dire economic straits.

Huang noted that the average lifespan of aboriginal people is 10 years shorter than non-aboriginals, which he said is not due only to environmental or nutritional factors but also to lack of education.
He said education can serve as a "fishing pole" for the economically underprivileged people, so that they can "fish for themselves" rather than just being given fish handouts.

According to statistics of the Council of Indigenous Peoples, the jobless rate among aboriginal people is two or three times the national average. The jobless rate among the aboriginal community surges during periods of economic sluggishness, yet when the economy turns around, the drop in the jobless rate among them is usually slower than in other sectors.

Huang said aboriginal youths usually enter the job market early to support their families and that if they can find work in their hometowns, they will tend to stay there, which will not only reduce the exodus of young people from aboriginal communities but will also help the elderly get better care.
Family Mart Chairman Pan Chin-ting said he will install donation boxes in the chain's 2,000 stores around the country.
He will also mobilize staff to go to Hualien and Taitung to do volunteer work to publicize and promote the donation drive.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prosecutors undecided on whether to probe defense company

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Task Force (SITF) under the Supreme Prosecutors Office remains undecided on whether to probe a newly established defense company known as Taiwan Goal, a spokesman for the panel said Tuesday.

Chen Yun-nan, director of the SITF office, was commenting on media reports that the Supreme Prosecutors Office will investigate possible irregularities in Taiwan Goal's establishment under the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's guidance.
According to Chen, the SITF is just collecting news clips and other relevant information and data. At the moment, he said, the SITF is still undecided on whether to launch a probe into the case.

Meanwhile, Vice Premier Chiuo I-jen was quoted as having told incumbent and former DPP lawmakers Tuesday that the establishment of Taiwan Goal, a joint venture between the government and private investors, is mainly aimed at diversifying sources of Taiwan's arms procurement.

Taiwan Goal, founded late last month, is led by Wu Nai-jen, a stalwart of the DPP's now disbanded New Tide faction. Capital of NT$200 million (US$6.3 million) has been underwritten for Taiwan Goal, with NT$90 million expected to come from the Ministry of National Defense. As the project is still in the planning stages, the defense ministry has not yet injected any funds into the company, ministry officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Wednesday.

The weighted price index was down 24.29 points at 8,000.12 on a turnover of NT$2.91 billion (US$91.8 million) at the open. The index gained 133.51 points, or 1.69 percent, to close at 8,024.41 Tuesday.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.660 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.038 from Tuesday.
