DOC.HEADLINE: Swimmers to take on Taiwan Strait again

TEXT.P: Veteran long-distance Taiwanese swimmer Wang Han is planning to lead a team of nine swimmers across the Taiwan Strait in June, after failing in a similar attempt in August 2007 due to poor weather conditions.

Wang, who successfully swam across 12 major channels or straits around the world between 1986 and 1998, including a solo crossing of the Strait of Gibraltar and a tag team effort across the English Channel, issued an open invitation to long- distance swimmers of any nationality living in Taiwan or gender, aged between 20 and 45, to join his team.
The nine swimmers he eventually selects, two other back-ups and Wang himself are expected to begin training March 29, Wang said at a news conference.

Wang's plan is for the 10 swimmers to start their swim from either of the northern counties of Hsinchu or Miaoli in June when sea temperatures are higher and swim in a relay toward a beach in China's Fujian province, if weather and sea conditions permit.
The journey could take three to five days to finish, depending on the conditions, Wang said.

The shortest straight-line distance across the Taiwan Strait is 145 kilometers, but the actual swimming distance, when taking into account detours to avoid sharks and adverse ocean currents, could be 200 kilometers, he indicated.
The ideal dates for the challenge will be June 10 and June 23, Wang said, citing the Central Weather Bureau's marine meteorology information services.

Wang, 56, once said that despite his successful experiences in swimming across straits or channels around the globe, he considered the Taiwan Strait as the "longest" and "most difficult" one to tackle, giving various political, environmental and even psychological difficulties involved.
After several years of preparation, Wang and his team announced the first attempt to swim across the Taiwan Strait in January 2007.
The swim began from Fishermen's Wharf in Danshuei, Taipei County, Aug. 22, with 28 swimmers, including 16 from Taiwan, eight from China and four from South Africa, participating.
Their ill-fated challenge ended the next day, however, when the swimmers were transported back to Taiwan as a result of overcast skies and turbulent ocean currents caused by an oncoming typhoon.
Wang and his team are also planning a third attempt to swim across the Taiwan Strait in 2009, where the swimmers would first fly to Fujian and swim back to Taiwan across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Joint venture company planned for investment in India: MOEA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will join forces with the private sector in setting up an investment and development company which will focus on encouraging and facilitating Taiwanese investment in India, a high-ranking MOEA official said Tuesday.

In addition to building an industrial park in India, the official said, the proposed company will also search for business opportunities, evaluate business feasibility and establish an information data bank for Taiwanese enterprises interested in investing in India.

According to the official, Taiwan hopes to forge stronger economic ties with India as the South Asian coutnry is one of the so-called "BRIC" coutnries considered as the most promising of the world's emerging markets.
The company's establishment is part of a government policy to expand the investment network for Taiwanese business people, the official said.

Economic Affairs Minister Steve R. L. Chen will invite industry representatives later this week to discuss the details of establishing the company geared towards India investments, in the hope of making concrete progress on setting up the company by the end of this year, the official said.

A majority of the funding for the company will come from the private sector, which will lead the company, the official said, but the MOEA does not rule out the possibility that the company's capital will be partly funded by the Executive Yuan's National Development Fund.

The southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh has already agreed to provide 1,200 hectares of land as an industrial area for Taiwanese investors to set up factories and offices there, based on a memorandum of understanding signed by Taiwan and India last month.

Chiu Po-ching, director-general of MOEA's Department of Investment Services led a delegation to India earlier this year to evaluate development of some of India's industries, including those in software, information technology, food processing, shoe making, and vehicle components and parts.
Taiwanese manufactureres had launched a total of 69 investment projercts worth around US$400 million in India as of last July, according to governemnt statistics.

Taiwan's government had previously started fund-raising to establish a company to facilitate investments in the Middle East, as the area is also included in the government's plan to widen Taiwan's investment network.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's notebook computer shipments hit record high in Q4 2007

TEXT.P: Taiwan shipped 28.19 million notebook computers in the fourth quarter of 2007, hitting a record high for a single quarter, according to a report released Wednesday by the International Data Corp. (IDC) Taiwan.

The number marked an increase of 11.6 percent from the previous quarter and a growth of 44 percent over the year-earlier level, driven mainly by rising market demand and Christmas purchases, the report said.

Of the shipments, 24.95 million units, or 88.5 percent, were delivered by Taiwan's top five original design manufacturers (ODMs) -- Quanta Computer Inc., Compal Electronics Inc., Wistron Corp., Inventec Corp. and ASUSTek Computer Inc., the report said.
Notebook production during the period amounted to US$15.14 billion, for a year- on-year increase of 31.6 percent, it said.

Helen Chiang, a research manager with IDC Taiwan, said domestic notebook manufacturers performed better than expected in the quarter because of brisk sales in consumer PC models by major brands such as Hewlett Packard, Acer and Dell.
Although battery supply shortages had been predicted to impact notebook shipments, only a small number of manufacturers were actually affected, Chiang pointed out.
For the first quarter of 2008, the shortage is expected to also have only a limited impact on the industry, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: MSDF destroyer cuts fish trawler in half
A Maritime Self-Defense Force destroyer cut a small trawler in two before dawn Tuesday in the Pacific about 40 km off China Prefecture, and the boat's father- and-son crew were missing.

DOC.HEADLINE: German EMBA students studying at National Chengchi University

TEXT.P: Another foreign university has sent students to National Chengchi University's Business School for a short-term course of intensive study, school officials said Wednesday.

The officials said that 13 EMBA students from the Stuttgart Institute of Management and Technology visited the Hsinchu Science-based Park Wednesday as part of a company visit activity. The students began their weeklong course Monday.

The school has arranged for them a 20-hour course on Asian emerging markets. The course includes an economic analysis of Taiwan and China, Taiwan's emerging market, and comparison and analysis of global and Asian business cultures.

School officials said that since the school passed the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) international accreditation in 2006, more foreign universities have been persuaded to offer their students the opportunity to study there.
The officials said Purdue University, which sent students to the school last year, will send more next month.
Italy's Boconni School of Management and Austria's University of Innsbruck have also planned to send students for the intensive course for around two weeks this year.
The National Chengchi University Business School is one of the best in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Youth Commission chief's resignation approved

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has approved the resignation of National Youth Commission (NYC) Minister Cheng Li-chiun, the Executive Yuan said in a press release Wednesday.
Cheng, 39, a Ph.D. candidate of philosophy at University of Paris X-Nanterre, has held the post since 2004.

Main opposition Kuomintang Legislator Hsiao Chin-tien recently charged that Cheng has occupied herself with campaigning for Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, instead of devoting herself to the problems of jobless youth.

Cheng led more than 20 students in launching a campaign activity, dubbed the "Against the Wind, Love Taiwan Most" walk, under the Eluanbi Lighthouse at the southernmost tip of Taiwan Feb. 6. The group plans to walk along the western coast of Taiwan until it reaches Taipei Feb. 28.
Cheng said before the walk that she had already tendered her resignation, although the premier had yet to approve it and she had to go on leave.
She also said that she decided to take part in the walk to "safeguard Taiwan's democracy and future with young people."

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for February moved down 145 points to close at 7,877, with 28,243 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for March lost 168 points to finish at 7,828, with 4,3919 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 175 points to close at 7,794, with 20 contract transactions.
September futures fell 190 points to finish at 7,590, with 68 contract transactions, while December futures lost 194 points to close at 7,586, with 83 contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index lost 129.94 points Wednesday to finish at 7,894.47, with market turnover of NT$113.68 billion (US$3.59 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 8,022 for February; 7,996 for March; 7,969 for June; 7,780 for September and 7,780 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

February TE futures rose 5.65 points to close at 301.6, with 2,491 contracts traded, while March TE futures moved down 6.65 points to finish at 297.7, with 4,140 contract exchanges. December TE futures lost 10.65 points to finish at 290, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

February TF futures moved down 27.6 points to close at 1,021.6, with 2,213 contracts changing hands, while March TF futures dropped 29.4 points to finish at 1,018.2, with 3,709 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Wisconsin Hands Obama aVictory, the Ninth in a Row
Senator Barack Obama decisively beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday night, accelerating his momentum ahead of crucial primaries in Ohio and Texas and cutting into Mrs. Clintonzs support among women and union members.
The Wall Street Journal:Obama Holds Off Clinton in Wisconsin
Barack Obama held off Hillary Clinton's belated attempt to brake his momentum in Wisconsin's Democratic primary, winning his ninth-straight presidential- nominating contest as the two get closer to the showdown Sen. Clinton has promised in Ohio and Texas two weeks away.
In Wisconsin's Republican primary and Washington state caucuses, Arizona Sen. John McCain prevailed as expected over his main remaining challenger, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee. The senator drew closer to the 1,191 delegates that would make official his current status as the party's presumptive nominee, though a sizable number of social conservatives continued to register their unhappiness by voting for his rival.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.050 to close at NT$31.648.
A total of US$1.146 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.705 and hit a low of NT$31.575.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dispute between bank and fugitive tycoon's wife nears verdict
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 19 (CNA) 02/20/08 17:06:14 (By Chu Lu-sheng and Howard Lin)

TEXT.P: Final arguments were heard at a Los Angeles court Tuesday in a dispute between a Taiwan-based bank and the wife of a Taiwanese fugitive tycoon, but it is uncertain when the judge will render his verdict.

Attorneys for Mega International Commercial Bank stated the bank's case in a federal court in Los Angeles against defendant Wang Chin She-ying, president of China Rebar Co., an affiliate of the Rebar Group. Mega Bank is the Rebar Group's biggest creditor.

Wang You-theng, Wang Chin's husband as well as founder of the Rebar Group, is suspected of having embezzled billions of dollars in corporate funds from the group before fleeing with his wife to China in late 2006 and then to the United States in January 2007.

Mega Bank filed suit in a Los Angeles court on Feb. 5, 2007 to recover the Rebar Group's outstanding loans. According to bank officials, the bank initially hoped to recover US$ 210 million but later adjusted the figure after reassessing their strategy.
After hearing oral arguments, Judge Elihn M. Berle said it might take some time to announce the verdict due to his involvement with other pending jury trials.

According to convention in U.S. civil procedures, judges can issue verdicts within two or three days. Some judges, however, will issue a temporary verdict that enables both sides to appeal or add details within 15 days. After taking the added information into consideration, the judge then renders his final verdict.
If Mega Bank wins the case, a list of assets that the bank can claim from Wang Chin to reimburse her debts will be listed with the verdict.

A high-end property worth US$3 million under Wang Chin's name in Pasadena, California and about 7,000 shares of OMNIBANK worth US$200,000 to US$300,000 will be the premier targets for the bank in reclaiming the debts, said officials of Mega's Los Angeles branch.
Wang Chin, however, could also appeal a verdict against her.

The Rebar scandal came to light in January 2007 after the group's China Rebar Co. and Chia Hsin Food and Synthetic Fiber Co. applied for insolvency restructuring, triggering a run on the Chinese Bank, another Rebar affiliate.
Taiwan authorities placed the couple on the country's most-wanted list in Jan. 2007 and have been seeking U.S. assistance to have them repatriated back to Taiwan to face charges.

In March, Taiwanese prosecutors indicted Wang and 106 others involved in the Rebar Group scandal on a long list of charges, including fraud, money laundering and insider trading. They are seeking a prison sentence of 30 years and an unprecedented fine of NT$1.71 billion (US$52.13 million) for Wang.

According to initial estimates, the total losses caused by the Wang family's systematic siphoning of assets from Rebar Group-owned subsidiaries totals NT$300 billion (US$ 9.38 billion) -- about one-fourth of Taiwan's annual tax revenues.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Cuban leader Fidel Castro steps down.
Cuban leader Fidel Castro announced his retirement Tuesday. The United States government urged Cuba to hold democratic elections and said that the embargo on Cuba remains in place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Gene screening technique used in IVF to produce healthy baby

TEXT.P: Taiwanese researchers have successfully applied gene screening techniques to the in-vitro fertilization process and helped a couple carrying pathogenic genes of thalassemia to have a healthy baby girl last month, medical sources reported Wednesday.

Researchers from National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) said the girl's birth could also bring some hope to her seriously ill older brother, who was born two years ago and diagnosed at birth as having serious thalassemia or Mediterranean anemia.

Her umbilical cord blood, collected and preserved at delivery, contains the genes that can be used to treat her brother, with the aim of at least alleviating his symptoms even if a cure cannot be effected, they claimed.

Chen Su-yuen, a physician at NTUH's Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, said both of the couple carry the thalassemia gene but neither have shown symptoms. However, the genes were passed onto the older boy and became dominant.

Chen said the couple went to his hospital for assistance with gene-screened IVF, in the hope that they could have a healthy baby and that the newborn's umbilical stem cells could save the older child.

Hospital researchers later retrieved eggs and sperm from the couple and developed 16 embryos for further screening. After careful inspections and comparisons, only one of the 16 embryos was determined to be carrying recessive pathogenic genes that will not develop into thalassemia and whose human lymphocyte antigen (HLA) is identical to that of the older boy, indicating that gene therapy can be carried out without rejection.
The stem cell transplant operation for the boy will take place in April or May, according to a NTUH statement.

Su Yi-ning, a physician at the NTUH's Department of Medical Genetics, explained that when both parents carry thalassemia genes, their children have a 25 percent possibility of carrying the dominant gene, a 50 percent chance of carrying recessive genes, and only a 25 percent chance of carrying normal genes.
For HLA rejection among siblings, the percentage of non- rejection is 25 percent, Su went on.

"For a sibling to carry normal genes and have identical HLA to the brother, the chance is as low as 0.06 percent; and to carry recessive genes and the identical HLA, the chance is 0.18 percent, " Su explained, adding that the IVF success rate is about 25 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Police arrest one suspect in shooting of former legislator

TEXT.P: One of the two suspects in the kidnapping and shooting of a former legislator over the weekend has been arrested, Taipei County police said Wednesday.
The 21-year-old suspect, Zeng Zheng-tang, was arrested Tuesday night in a satellite city near Taipei, police said. The other suspect, also a young man, remained on the run.

The two suspects, both jobless, wanted to commit a robbery last Saturday and took former legislator Lee Sen-zong hostage at gunpoint, police said. The 61 -year-old Lee was coming out of a dinner party with his friends when the two suspects coerced him to drive to a nearby mountain area.
When Lee saw a patrol car, he tried to jump out of the car, but was shot in his right shoulder.
Lee is recovering after surgery.
The arrested suspect Zeng said that the kidnapping was unplanned and that he and his accomplice were not aware of the former legislator's identity, police said.
Asked why he fired the shot, Zeng said the gun accidentally discharged while being loaded, according to police.
Police are looking for the other suspect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Taiwan users of Internet up marginally in January: survey

TEXT.P: Over 15 million Taiwan residents have surfed the Internet in their lives as of the end of January, a modest rise from the same period a year earlier, with the highest rate of use in Taipei City, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.

The "Internet Broadband Usage in Taiwan" survey conducted by the Taiwan Network Information Center (TWNIC) revealed that 15,548,000 individual users in Taiwan accessed the Internet last month, 318,000 more than the same period last year.

Just over two-thirds, or 68.51 percent, of Taiwan's population aged 12 and above use the Internet, a 0.74 percent increase from the previous year while 63.37 percent used broadband, the survey showed.

A slightly higher percentage of males (70.2 percent) than females (66.8 percent) logged onto the Internet, while the highest concentration of use was in the 16-20 age bracket at 96.95 percent. People over the age of 56 were the least likely to surf the Web, with only 17.89 percent logging on.

Taipei City has the highest individual Internet use rate at 80.23 percent, followed by 74.63 in the southern city of Kaohsiung. Taiwan's eastern region had the lowest Internet use rate at 52.36 percent, compared to 66.91 percent in the north (excluding Taipei), 55.14 percent in central Taiwan, and 56.30 percent in the south (excluding Kaohsiung).
Regarding household access to the Web, 72.33 percent, or 5,406,000 households in Taiwan, are connected to the Internet, while 66.41 percent, or 4,960,000 households, are using broadband.
The survey also showed that among broadband users, 93.57 percent go online at home, with the peak hours for surfing falling between 7 p.m. and midnight.

Some 20.74 percent of those using broadband spent more than one hour but less than two hours online on weekdays, followed by 14.74 percent using the Internet more than two hours but less than three hours.

As for the most common uses of the Internet, 57.48 percent cited searching for information, followed by browsing Web pages (46.76 percent) , e-mails (26.96 percent) , playing games online (20.80 percent) , chatting (17.41 percent) , getting the weather forecast (11.76 percent), and shopping (9.49 percent).

Among the problems Internet users find the most irritating, 40.50 percent named slow downloading speed, followed by unstable or poor connections (38.01 percent) and slow uploading speed (22.81 percent).

The survey was conducted through computer assisted telephone interviews in the daytime during Dec. 1, 2007 and Jan. 31, 2008 with people aged 12 and above who reside in 23 cities and counties in Taiwan, the TWNIC said, adding that there were 3,213 valid samples with a 95 percent confidence level and 1.5 percent sampling error.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Coercion may silence people only temporarily': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has lauded Kosovo's decision to declare independence from Serbia, saying that "coercion, intimidation and violence may silence people only temporarily."

Speaking to foreign ambassadors and delegates to Taiwan at a Spring Festival banquet hosted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday, Chen said that "the developments in Kosovo over the past few days have once more demonstrated the global trend toward democracy and self-determination."
"Coercion, intimidation and violence may silence people temporarily," he went on, "but in the long run, it is futile."
In addition, Chen said Taiwan will take another step to consolidate and deepen its own democracy next month as the country will hold its fourth direct presidential election March 22.

Alongside the elections, two national referendums proposed by different political parties will be held, aimed at supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. Taiwan's U.N. membership applications have been rejected by the world body for the past 15 years annually due to China's objections.
Chen also drew attention to activists' efforts to call on China to improve its notorious human rights record.
He said that "many people concerned with the human rights situation in China hope to highlight that country's human rights abuses through the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games."
"They are exerting pressure on the Communist Party of China and are making known their hope that China will not just content itself with hosting this magnificent sporting event, " Chen noted.
"Rather, they hope China will make genuine progress on its human rights practices and realize the true Olympic spirit of peace, justice and harmony," he added.

Chen's remarks came after Hollywood film director Steven Spielberg recently quit as an artistic adviser to the 2008 Olympics to protest China's failure to do enough to pressure Sudan to end the continuing human suffering in Darfur.

During the address, Chen further expressed hope that "China will renounce its intention and preparations to use force against Taiwan, so that the dream of peaceful co-existence for Taiwan and China, and a win-win situation for both, can one day come true."

China has deployed in its southeastern coastal areas over 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan and Beijing has repeatedly refused to rule out the use of force against Taiwan if it declares formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down nearly 2 percent on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices plummeted Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 129.94 points, or 1.61 percent, to close at 7,894.47.

Suffering a decline after two consecutive days of gains, the bourse opened at 8,000.12 and fluctuated between 8,040.83 and 7,855.48 during the day's session. A total of 4.14 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$113.68 billion (US$3.59 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground. Cement stocks fell 3 percent, the most of any sector. Textile stocks dropped 2.3 percent, food and stuff issues lost 2.2 percent, banking and financial shares were down 2.1 percent, machinery and electronics shares shed 1.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares fell 1.3 percent, construction issues dropped 0.9 percent and paper and pulp issues lost 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,532 to 360, with 322 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pakistani celebrates rebirth after liver transplant in Taiwan

TEXT.P: A Pakistani businessman celebrated his rebirth Tuesday after receiving a successful liver transplant at a southern Taiwan hospital, made possible by a special favor from Taiwanese authorities who granted him an unusual visa.
Ahmed Khawaja Shakeel, 46, is Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital's first liver transplant recipient from a country considered unfriendly toward Taiwan.

Another Pakistani man had approached the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Hospital for a similar surgery last September, but the patient's visa application was rejected by Taiwan's representative office in Saudi Arabia, hospital sources said.

According to Taiwan's visa regulations, citizens from countries listed as politically unfriendly and risky for migration are barred from visiting Taiwan for medical purposes. Pakistan is high on the list of such countries.
When relevant government authorities finally agreed to issue the man a visa at the hospital's request on humanitarian considerations, the patient had already died.
In Khawaja's case, the Chang Gung sources said, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) assigned a staff member to assist in the visa application upon receiving the hospital's request last November.

Khawaja was diagnosed with hepatitis C and cirrhosis in 2004. After vomiting blood five times, he was advised to get a liver transplant. He first traveled to Singapore for treatment. Physicians there suggested that he seek a liver transplant at the Chang Gung hospital in Kaohsiung County.

With foreign ministry's special assistance, Khawaja obtained a visa about 20 days after Chang Gung received his inquiry letter on Nov. 12 last year. Accompanied by his wife and their only son, Khawaja arrived in Kaohsiung from Singapore on Jan. 14.
On Jan. 29, a Chang Gung surgical team conducted a liver transplant on Khawaja, with his son donating a part of his liver for the operation.
The 10-hour surgery was successful and Khawaja is recovering well, doctors said.
The hospital held a celebration for Khawaja Tuesday.
Khawaja said he heartily appreciates the medical team that saved his life. "I'll tell my compatriots about Taiwan's high quality health care and medical service," a grateful Khawaja said.
Khawaja is scheduled for discharge from the hospital in late March and will then be transferred to a hostel operated by the hospital where he will live for one month while he undergoes observation.
If all goes well, he will be allowed to return to Pakistan in late April, hospital sources said.
According to the sources, Khawaja's case is expected to help boost the government's plan to promote globalization of Taiwan's medical service industry.
The government has relaxed visa regulations to attract foreign and Chinese citizens to travel to Taiwan for medical treatment as part of its efforts to spur growth of medical tourism. enditem/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival to run for 11 days in Tainan County

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival, which opens in Tainan County's Southern Taiwan Science Park Thursday, will run for 11 days until March 2, celebrating the arrival of the Year of the Rat.

According to the Tainan county government, which is organizing the festival, President Chen Shui-bian will preside over a ceremony at 7 p.m. Feb. 21 to light the centerpiece of the lantern festival, a lantern in the shape of a giant spinous country rat -- a species of rodent endemic to Taiwan -- praying for peace and prosperity for the nation.

The venue of the lantern festival is located in Solar City, a special zone of the science park, with 88 hectares of showgrounds. Over 55,000 red and yellow lanterns are used to form giant Chinese and English characters that read "Taiwan Peace," the theme of the festival. A special area is reserved for religious lanterns.
Local and foreign performing groups, including a troupe from Japan, will provide entertainment to visitors, who will also be treated to 34 fireworks shows throughout the festival.
The Tainan county government has also prepared 120,000 hand-held lanterns featuring the rat motif to give away to visitors.
To make it easier for visitors to reach the festival, the Taiwan Railway Administration has scheduled 58 trains each day to stop at a temporary station located about 100 meters from the venue.
The Taiwan High Speed Railway will also provide daily free shuttle services from its Tainan Station in Gueiren township to the venue.

For those who drive their own cars to the festival, there is a three-hectare parking at the venue, with additional parking spaces in the Tree Valley Park, located on the western edge of the Southern Taiwan Science Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND should not fund private arms company: official

TEXT.P: A Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said Wednesday that he has suggested to Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu that it is not appropriate for the ministry to fund a private arms firm, Taiwan Goal, which was set up last month to deal with Taiwan's arms deals with other countries.
Wu Wei-jung, director of the MND's Armaments Bureau, made the remarks when he attended a news conference called by Legislator Kuo Su-chun, a caucus whip of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).
Wu said that after a cautious overview, he suggested that the plan for the MND to hold a 45 percent stake in the company is unfeasible.
"Although the idea of establishing the company is good, the timing is inappropriate because of the March 22 presidential election, which may give rise to misgivings," Wu said.
Asked by Kuo whether he suggested to Minister Lee that the company be disbanded, Wu said only that he "had made full suggestions and communications."
"As far as I know, Lee agreed to the view," Wu continued.

Kuo demanded that Premier Chang Chu-hsiung announce the disbanding of Taiwan Goal prior to the general interpellation session when the legislature officially opens its first plenary session Feb. 22, describing the stance as the KMT's "bottom line."

Kuo said earlier in the week that if the premier does not disband the company, the KMT-dominated new legislature will adopt a resolution after the opening of the first session to forbid the MND from becoming a founding shareholder or from signing any contracts with the company.

She also said that if the MND has already entered into contracts with Taiwan Goal, the KMT caucus will boycott all related government budgets, to prevent public funds from being invested in the company.

She further said that if the KMT gets back into power in the March 22 presidential election, the new administration will not ratify any contracts with Taiwan Goal and will immediately disband the company.

KMT Legislator Chang Hsien-yao questioned if the MND or the Armaments Bureau had any say in the forming of the company, even though the MND is the largest shareholder, and asked if the name was being given by the Presidential Office. Wu said the Presidential Office did "suggest a name."

Premier Chang confirmed last week that the controversial establishment of Taiwan Goal was made possible with public funds from various government agencies and state-owned corporations, but he defended the move as "necessary to help upgrade Taiwan's defense industry."

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) also confirmed that Taiwan Goal completed registration with the MOEA Jan. 28 as a private company, with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million, and that Wu Nai-jen, a DPP heavyweight and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp. -- serves as chairman of the company.

MOEA data shows that Taiwan Goal has a seven-member board of directors, with three seats going to the MND, which will contribute 45 percent of Taiwan Goal's capital. The company's office is located in Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest buildings.

Taiwan Goal is registered to deal in a variety of businesses, including the import and export of arms and weaponry systems; sales of garments and accessories, industrial explosives, precision instruments, and batteries of all types; and product design, according to the MOEA.
The defense minister was quoted by opposition KMT lawmakers as having acknowledged that although the MND is the largest shareholder, the company will be beyond the control of his ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enhancing mini-links aimed at boosting local tourism: MAC

TEXT.P: Before the government makes the mini-links fully available to the public, it will first enhance the benefits of the links for residents of the islands of Kinmen and Matsu, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Wednesday.

"Although the government has not opened the mini-links to everyone, it has been studying feasible means to help bolster tourism on the two outlying islands by taking advantage of the links, such as organizing group tours for tourists from Taiwan proper to visit China's Fujian Province via the links," Chen said.
Chen made the comments in response to reporters' questions following a regular weekly Executive Yuan meeting.

According to the MAC chief, it would be good if Kinmen and Matsu travel agencies could design special tour packages to attract Taiwan residents to stay for two nights on the two outlying islands and then travel to Fujian for sightseeing.
"And should China be willing to allow more tourists to sightsee in Kinmen or Matsu, tourism on both islands would benefit greatly, " he added.

Frank Hsieh, the presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 22 presidential election, confirmed a day earlier that President Chen Shui-bian is assessing the possibility of relaxing the government's China economic and investment policies before he ends his tenure May 20.
The MAC chief, said, however that "many opening proposals toward China, although being assessed by the government, are still some way off."

"The government's failure to make the mini-links available to all Taiwan's nationals lies in the large number of local people visiting China every year," he argued, noting that in 2007, Taiwan people made more than 4 million visits to China.

"The facilities at Kinmen and Matsu airports cannot accommodate such a large number as 10,000 travelers per day if the mini-links were opened to all Taiwan citizens, " he explained, insisting that "the key point concerning the mini- links at the present stage is to take better advantage of them and create wellbeing for residents of the two outlying islands."

"The government has done its best to permit as many people as possible to use the direct shipping services linking Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands to China's Fujian Province after their implementation from January 2001," according to Chen.

"The scope of the current mini-links was expanded in 2004 to all China-based Taiwanese businessmen registered with the government, retired veterans and religious and academic groups, marking a departure from earlier years, when only Fujian-based Taiwanese businessmen and Kinmen and Matsu residents were permitted to travel via the links, "he went on.

The mini-links -- direct shipping and trade services between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou -- were set up to offset the lack of such links between Taiwan proper and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet passes streamlining amendments

TEXT.P: The Cabinet passed draft amendments and a provisional statute Wednesday that, if passed by the legislature, will streamline the Executive Yuan's structure and provide incentives for civil servants and political appointees to retire early.

Under the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan amendment, the number of Cabinet agencies will be reduced from 36 to 26, with 14 ministries, seven councils and five independent institutions. The amendment, if passed, will be implemented Jan. 1, 2010.

The Cabinet also passed a draft provisional statute on the adjustment of the functions, business and organization of the Executive Yuan that will allow civil servants with 20 years of service, civil servants aged over 50 with 10 years of service, and those who have served in the highest posts for at least three years to apply to retire with an additional seven months' salary.

The statute applies to over 190,000 civil servants, political appointees and faculty members of public schools and universities. Only civil servants hired before the date of the statute's passage by the Cabinet, or Feb. 20, 2008, will be included.

Those eligible for the retirement incentive will be able to apply from July 1, 2009, with the amount of the incentive progressively reduced by 58 percent of a month's salary each month during the one-year period that the statute is in effect.

The Executive Yuan also passed an amendment to the Organic Standard Law of the Central Government Agencies to raise the limit on the number of ministries and councils from 13 and four, respectively, to 14 and seven. The amendment also increases the limit on the number of departments from 104 to 112, and on the number of bureaus and agencies from 50 to 54.

DOC.HEADLINE: County in Taiwan pats itself on the back for pothole repairs

TEXT.P: The Changhua county government in central Taiwan has repaired nearly 99 percent of the pot-holed roads reported by local residents in the past two years, a county official said Tuesday.

The achievement is the result of a collaborative project between the county government, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' Directorate General of Highways as well as local township offices.
The project was aimed at improving traffic safety for local residents, Cheng Hsi-chuan, an official of the county's Department of Public Works, told reporters.
Since launching the project in 2006, the county government has received a total of 1,784 reports about potholes, 1,766 of which have been resolved, according to Cheng.
Encouraging local residents to help improve the county's roads, Cheng said they can call a toll-free hotline: 0800-665050 to report any further problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Ministry announces ban on rebar exports

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Wednesday a ban on the export of rebars and small billets -- the main material for the production of round steel bars or rebars for construction -- in light of an outcry from the domestic real estate development industry over surging steel prices.
The ban is expected to last for three months after it takes effect in two weeks, according to Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen.
Meanwhile, Chen said, the MOEA will also put exports of H-shaped steel and steel scrap under "supervision" which will also last for three months.
The ministry, however, will respect the market mechanism rather than intervening in price fluctuations of steel building materials, he added.

Lai Cheng-yi, chairman of the Shining Group, which is known for building high- priced houses and resorts, complained earlier in the day that the costs of construction development have surged by NT$6,000 (US$189.27) per ping (3.3 sq. ft. ) over the past few weeks, mainly as a result of surging prices of rebars and gravel.
"The problem is now that you cannot buy rebars (reinforcing steel bars) even if you have money, " said Lai, claiming that there are people who have been hoarding the products.

Lai expressed hope that the administration will investigate the surging prices and warned that public construction projects and private developers will be forced to suspend operations should the government not intervene in time.
Wei Chia-ming, president of the Shining Group, said that owing to the surging prices, the room for price negotiations between developers and house buyers has shrunk by at least 5 percent.

Wei lamented that because each major steel bar supplier is now willing to provide Shining with no more than 2,000 kg of the product each month, the company has been forced to source steel bars from as many more suppliers as possible.
Even pushing like this, Wei said, Shining is anticipating that it will face difficulty achieving its target for this year of building NT$35 billion (US$1.1 billion)-worth of houses and resorts.

As a result of surging prices of imported iron ore, which has skyrocketed by 65 percent over the past two weeks, the price of round steel bars in Taiwan is expected to exceed NT$30,000 per ton in two months, anticipated Chung Jung- chang, chairman of Huaku Construction, another listed real estate development company.

The domestic housing market will suffer an obvious impact beginning from the second half of the year, with the market in northern Taiwan sustaining relatively lighter impact than that in southern Taiwan because the northern Taiwan-based developers can translate higher building costs into higher selling prices, while their counterparts in southern Taiwan -- where housing prices are much lower -- will not be able to raise their selling prices much in order not to frighten off clients, Chung noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan provides 111 scholarships to Latin American allies in 2008
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/08 20:51:41 (By Ramon Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is providing a total of 111 scholarships to students from the country's Latin American allies in 2008, Taiwan diplomats stationed in Panama said Tuesday, citing MOFA data.
Central America, South Africa and the Caribbean region are where 12 of Taiwan's 23 diplomatic allies are located.

The scholarships include 20 reserved for Paraguayan students, 18 for Panamanian students, 19 for Nicaraguan students, 18 for Honduran students, eight for El Salvadoran students, six for Guatemalan students, six for Belizean students, five for Saint Lucia students, four for Haitian students, four for St. Vincent and the Grenadines students, and three for Saint Christopher and Nevis students, the data shows.
No scholarships have been reserved for the Dominican Republic this year.

Worldwide, MOFA is offering 163 scholarships this year to students from countries with diplomatic ties with Taiwan or those from countries specified as diplomatically favorable to Taiwan, after deducting four that were originally intended for students from Malawi -- which switched recognition to Beijing last month.
The Taiwan Scholarship Program was launched in 2004 by the Taiwan government to encourage international students to study in Taiwan.

In addition to the MOFA, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the National Science Council are providing 250, 62 and 25 scholarships, respectively, to students from countries with no diplomatic ties with Taiwan under the program this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical charity offers free treatment in Swaziland
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/20/08 21:20:01 (By Liu Cheng-ching and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese charity on Wednesday provided free medical service to patients in the southern African country of Swaziland who are too poor to see a doctor.

Crowds of patients suffering diabetes, pulmonary tuberculosis, malaria, and dysentery arrived from nearby regions at a police station square in Swaziland's Kaphunga to seek treatment from members of the Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps (TRMPC).

The charity, founded in 1995, is a private, non-sectarian, and non-profit organization dedicated to improving the quality of life by providing medical services and health education at home and abroad.
Describing Kaphunga as a poverty-stricken area, Swaziland's Health and Social Welfare Minister Njabulo Mabuza said that local residents might never be able to go to hospitals.
Mabuza expressed appreciation to Taiwan's ambassador to Swaziland Leonard Chao for helping to organize the charitable service.
For his part, Chao said that such a medical service is another way for Taiwan to expand its assistance to the African nation, while lauding the efforts of the charity's medical workers.
Swaziland is one of 23 countries which recognizes the sovereignty of Taiwan and has diplomatic relations with the island instead of its rival China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Company for investing in Mideast to be set up: official

TEXT.P: An investment and development company will be set up in mid-April to encourage and facilitate Taiwanese businesses to invest in the Middle East, officials in charge of the Executive Yuan's National Development Fund said Wednesday.

The Fund will join forces with the private sector to form the company by investing a maximum of NT$800 million (US$25.28 million) at the highest or under the ceiling of 40 percent of total paid-in capital of the new company.

"The company will help expand business opportunities in the Middle East, seek major construction tender cases, evaluate business feasibility, and establish a business information data bank for Taiwanese investors," one of the officials told reporters.

The government expects to solicit a total of NT$2.8 billion of capital to set up the company, but does not rule out the possibility of increasing the target fund, due to strong interest from the private sector, the official said.
The company will be controlled by the private sector, the official said.

So far fundraising has gone well, the official said, adding that more private enterprises are showing interest in investing in the company after the Ministry of Economic Affairs sent a delegation to the Middle East to scope out business opportunities earlier this year.

The Middle East market is attractive to international investors due to its abundant oil resources and the fact that several countries in the region are seeking to diversify their economies, which could present good investment opportunities for Taiwanese firms.
The area is considered by Taiwan's government as a good investment destination for Taiwanese businesses in its attempt to seek more countries for Taiwanese business people to invest in.

Government officials hope to target the petrochemical and construction industries and tap into the market through the company, especially in the six Gulf countries -- Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the United Arab Emirates.

Leaders of Taiwan's state-run oil company CPC Corp., as well as Taiwan Fertilizer Co., TECO Electric and Machinery Corp., Farglory Land Development Co., CECI Engineering Consultant, and the CTCI Corp. have held discussions on investing in the new company, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kosovo not likely to join U.N. in short term: scholar

TEXT.P: It is not possible for Kosovo to play an active role in the United Nations nor in other non-governmental organizations any time soon, a U.S. scholar said in Taipei Wednesday.

Herbert London, president of the Washington-based think tank, the Hudson Institute, said in an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency that neither Russia nor China will permit Kosovo to play an active role in the U.N.

"But there is an NGO status that is possible for Kosovo, such as in the World Health Organization or other entities within the U.N. That is a possible compromise. But in the short term, I don't even think that compromise will occur," he added.

He went on to say that "all the comments that have been issued in the last couple of days clearly suggest that China is going to take a pretty tough line when it comes to Kosovo's involvement in U.N. activities."

According to London, an expert on U.N. affairs, Kosovo's declaration of independence created a "very interesting precedent," and the Chinese government at the moment is very concerned about the precedent.

China expressed grave concern about Kosovo's declaration of independence, saying that it can produce a series of results that will lead to a seriously negative influence on peace and stability in the Balkans.

China fears that the immediate recognition granted to Kosovo by major European countries and the United States might set a precedent for Taiwan and Tibet, which have similar relationships to Beijing as Kosovo had to Serbia before the province went independent.

London said that there is a kind of "ambiguity" in the American position on the Kosovo issue and Taiwan, since on the one hand, the U.S. recognizes Kosovo, while on the other hand, it does not recognize Taiwan.

"The double standard emerged from the fact that China is not Serbia. China's role in world affairs is totally different from Serbia's," he said, adding that "we can turn our back on Serbia, which is unimportant in the state of world affairs. But turning our back on China is not so easy considering all the U.S. investments in China."

However, London said "time is on the side of Taiwan" because it is only a question of time before China undergoes dramatic changes as the political system will have to be liberalized in facing the problems of the market economy.
"In the future, the China that looks very different from the China today, might very well open up opportunities for Taiwan that are inconceivable at the moment," London said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Expanding 'mini-link' would be 'belated blessing': Kinmen head

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng said Wednesday that reported plans by the government to expand direct "mini strait links" across the Taiwan Strait would be a "belated blessing."

Lee was responding to news reports that Chen Chin-jun, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, recently revealed that the Cabinet is considering expanding the "mini cross-strait links, " between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and China's Fujian province.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong confirmed Wednesday that the government was considering taking such a step, but he noted that realizing such proposals to further open up to China was still "some way off."
According to the news reports, under the plan, those who reside in Taiwan proper would also be allowed to travel to Fujian province directly if they stay two nights in Kinmen and Matsu.
The reports said allowing more people to travel to China through the outlying islands is aimed at boosting tourism and economic development on the outlying islands.

Lee said Wednesday that although the plan might be an attempt by the Executive Yuan, which is currently controlled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to win voter support for its candidate in the March 22 presidential election, he would still be happy to see the proposal "carried out."
Lee noted that Vice President Annette Lu had called for the expansion of the cross-Strait links during her two visits to Kinmen.

The scope of the current mini-links was expanded in 2004 to all China-based Taiwanese businessmen registered with the government, retired veterans and religious and academic groups to travel between Taiwan and China, marking a departure from earlier years, when only Fujian-based Taiwanese businessmen and Kinmen and Matsu residents were permitted to travel via the links.

The mini-links -- direct shipping and trade services between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and the Fujian ports of Xiamen, Mawei and Quanzhou -- were set up to offset the lack of such links between Taiwan proper and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bikes to be allowed on trains to promote cycling: TRA

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Rail Administration (TRA) will launch a pilot program in March to allow bicyclists to bring their bikes on trains, in an attempt to satisfy the increasing demand of cyclists to travel long distance with their bikes, a TRA spokesman said Wednesday.
This will be the first long-haul public transportation in Taiwan to allow passengers with their bicycles on board.

"Riding a bicycle has become a trend in Taiwan, but for cyclists, traveling to counties far away from home is troublesome, " said TRA Deputy Managing Director Chang Ying-huei. "The TRA hopes to give better service to the cyclists to show its concern about our customers as well as the environment."

Describing the difficulties bike riders face in Taiwan, Chen Chi-yuan, founder of the Big Apple (bicycle) Team, which has an estimated 30,000 cyclists around the island who are members, expressed his appreciation for the TRA's decision.
"This service indeed benefits cyclists intending to travel far with their bikes," Chen said.
"We are prohibited on board (many types of public transportation) , whether it's buses or trains.... Hopefully, this kind of service will continue and more routes can be introduced by the TRA."

According to the TRA, a special train, the "Environmental Friendly Train", will be operated on a trial basis between Sijhih, a satellite city of Taipei City, and Miaoli, 112.3 km south of the capital on March 8, April 19 and May 17 respectively.
"We will evaluate the outcome of the trials as well as the popularity of the service to see whether we can continue the program, " said Yang Chen-teh, director of the TRA's transportaiton department.
The fare for a bicycle will be the same as a passenger's.
Groups of six or more cyclists are requested to make reservations in advance so rail service staff can prepare space for them on the train, said Yang.

Yang said the TRA is also planning to launch another route for this service to the eastern coastal city of Hualien in the summer. The scenic and less populated Hualien is a popular area for bicyclists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Search teams from Matsu fail to find missing Chinese fishermen

TEXT.P: Search teams consisting of fire brigade members and Coast Guard Administration officials on the outlying island of Matsu searched nearby waters in the East China Sea for the past three days but failed to find the eight missing crew members from a sunken Chinese fishing boat.

Lienchiang County Magistrate Chen Hsueh-sheng said he activated the county's emergency response mechanism after a Matsu fishery radio station received distress signals Feb. 18 from the Chinese side saying that its fishing boat, the Minlianyu 1917, capsized off Dongyin Island, one of the islands in the Matsu island chain, a day earlier.
Chen said he immediately dispatched a search team from the local fire brigade to search the area by boat, and notified the COA to send its patrol cutters to join the search.

After receiving a request for help Tuesday from the Taiwan Affairs office in Lianjiang County of China's Fujian province, Chen asked the Sunrise Airlines Co. to send a helicopter to circle at low altitude around the shipwreck Wednesday, but the search again found no survivors.

The magistrate said the location of the ship-sinking -- at about 120 degrees east longitude and 26 degrees north latitude -- is actually quite distant from Dongyin Island, and that the vast stretch of water made the search very difficult.

Lianjiang is a county on the coast of Fujian province. Most of the county is controlled by China, while a number of outlying islands, known as the Matsu Islands, are governed by Taiwan as a separate Lienchiang County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's trade office in Libya formally inaugurated: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade office in Tripoli, Libya was formally inaugurated on Feb. 13 after nearly two years of preparations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Wednesday.
MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said "the office will open a window of opportunity for Taiwan to develop relations with Libya on all levels."
"It will also serve as the new foothold for Taiwan to promote exchanges with North African countries and help tap investment opportunities for Taiwan businessmen," she added.
Taiwan and Libya maintained diplomatic relations from 1959 through 1978. In 1980, Taiwan set up a trade office in Libya, which was shut down in September 1997.
But Taiwan has continued to make efforts to seek substantial exchanges with the oil-rich North African nation.

Through such efforts, Saif Qadhafi, the elder son of Libya leader Moammar Gadhafi, visited Taiwan in January 2006, and reached an agreement with Taiwan on exchanging representative offices. Saif became the first influential Libyan figure to visit Taiwan since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1978.
President Chen Shui-bian also visited Libya in May of that year.

MOFA officials said that Libya has greatly improved its international image and its ties with the West by cooperating with Washington in fighting terrorism after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice President promises to help Penghu overcome fishery losses

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu promised Wednesday that the central government will offer help to Penghu's fishing and aquaculture industries to overcome their current difficulties after record amounts of fish died due to cold weather conditions over the past two weeks.

Lu made the pledge during an inspection tour of the offshore island county where she was briefed by the county's fishery bureau chief Cheng Ming-yuan on the plight faced by local fishermen and aquaculture farmers.

While giving her assurances to local fishermen and the aquaculture industry that the central government will provide assistance to help them tackle their losses, she suggested the county government assess the possibility of developing the deep-sea fishing industry in collaboration with Taiwan's diplomatic allies instead of relying on the local aquaculture industry -- a main business on Penghu.

According to Lu, Penghu's eco-marine system has been severely damaged by the recent cold snap, and the local government also should consider shifting its focus to make Penghu a high-tech island group in view of unavoidable natural catastrophes arising from worsening dramatic climatic changes around the world.

As much as 1,537 metric tons of fish raised by the local aquaculture industry died as a result of the recent cold weather, causing losses of more than NT$180 million (US$5.7 million), Cheng reported, explaining that a significant portion of the dead aquatic products are of high value, including garoupa, gurnard, eel and scallop.
Cheng further pointed out that overall monetary losses would be uncalculatable to Penghu County if the damage made to at least 3,000 metric tons in fishery resources were added.

Commenting on an ocean resources recovery plan and a package of measures to prop up the local aquaculture industry, Cheng said that an estimated NT$236 million in funds will be needed to carry out the tasks.

Meanwhile, local residents helping the county government workers remove the large piles of dead fish washed ashore Penghu's beaches over the past 10 days say they will need more time to complete the clean up.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial mergers in Taiwan bear fruit: official

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to promote acquisitions and mergers among local banks in the last two years have boosted the financial sector's production values and wages, a top financial regulatory official said Wednesday.
The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will continue to encourage large local banks to expand their overseas markets and attract foreign investment in Taiwan, said FSC Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng.

Despite the negative impacts of the credit card crisis in 2006, Taiwan's insurance industry saw a growth rate of 7.8 percent in the first three quarters of 2007, Hu said in a keynote speech to students at National Taiwan University.
The percentage was much higher than the country's economic growth rate of 5.45 percent, Hu said.
In addition, the total loans for local small and medium enterprises grew 9.3 percent year-on-year to surpass NT$3 trillion (US$94.7 billion) in 2007, Hu added.
In the past, Taiwan had too many banks that provided similar services, which resulted in price competition, he explained.
The acquisitions and mergers involving foreign investment in recent years have forced problematic banks out of the market, Hu said.
The number of Taiwan's banks has decreased from 53 in 2001 to 39 at present, according to Hu.
The consolidation of the financial sector has also increased local banks' profits, which has helped the sector outperform other industries in terms of pay raises and year-end bonuses, Hu said.
To further boost the financial sector's competitiveness, the commission will push for the establishment of a financial monitoring mechanism between Taiwan and China, Hu pointed out.
Meanwhile, local banks' offshore banking units (OBUs) have been allowed to accept foreign currency checking deposits, in currencies other than the Chinese yuan, from January this year, he continued.
Hu said that the opening was aimed at enabling the OBUs to meet the capital needs of overseas Taiwanese businesspeople.
Hu explained that China-based Taiwanese businesspeople have become a major source of profits for the OBUs.
As of the end of last year, the OBUs' assets totaled NT$3 trillion, Hu said, adding that the pre-tax profits of the OBUs accounted for 57 percent of the total banks' pre-tax earnings last year.

Furthermore, Hu said that the commission plans to ease the restrictions on the amount of loans that the OBUs can offer to China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, which is currently capped at the 30 percent of an OBU's net worth of assets, or 10 percent for unsecured loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Miss Tibet has no regrets over defiance of China's name change

TEXT.P: Miss Tibet Tsering Chungtak said in Taipei Wednesday that she did not regret making the decision to quit a beauty pageant in Malaysia last year over China's pressure to have her "Miss Tibet" sash replaced with one reading "Miss Tibet- China."
Chungtak, who won the crown last October, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a visit at the invitation of the Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest organizer.

The 22-year-old pageant winner is a student at the University of Delhi in India. The Miss Tibet pageant has been held for the fifth year at Dharamsala in northern India where the Government of Tibet in Exile is located.
Chungtak's host organization held a reception party for her in Taipei City Wednesday.

Chungtak told CNA reporters that she was forced to quit a beauty pageant in Malaysia last December. She said that China pressured the competition organizer to replace Chungtak's "Miss Tibet" sash to one reading "Miss Tibet-China, "and that she was told if she refused to wear the replaced sash she would have to leave the competition.

Chungtak made the decision to withdraw from the Miss Tourism Queen 2007 pageant and returned to her home in India. She said she did not regret making the decision and still believes she did the right thing in pulling out.
Similar title replacements due to pressure from the Chinese government have been experienced by many of Taiwan's pageant entrants participating in international competitions.

In response to questions about her opinions on Taiwan's future, Chungtak said "Taiwan has the right to make decisions for its own future and the right should be respected by other countries." She further added that "Taiwan's future is in the hands of Taiwan's people."

As to the future of Tibet, Chungtak said she will follow the Dalai Lama's moderate approaches in dealing with China. Tibet is currently officially claimed and administered by China, while many Tibetans place their allegiance with the exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.
Chungtak's itinerary in Taiwan includes meeting with Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey and visits to central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: European bank applies to set up branch in Taiwan: FSC

TEXT.P: A European bank has applied to establish a branch in Taiwan, following the trend of foreign banks acquiring domestic ones over the past two years and the subsiding credit card crisis, Financial Supervisory Commission Vice Chairwoman Susan Chang said Wednesday.

Chang said the European bank's name can only be announced after the application is approved. But she revealed that the bank's strong points are in asset management, derivative product investment and new financial products.
"Taiwan will have a total of 33 foreign banks if the application is approved," Chang said.
The acquisition of domestic banks by foreign banks has atracted more multinational banking groups to pay attention to the Taiwan market, Chang said.
The London-based Standard Chartered PLC acquired Taiwan's Hsinchu International Bank in September 2006.

The New York-based Citigroup Inc., the most profitable overseas bank in Taiwan, bought the Bank of Overseas Chinese last April, while ABN Amro Holding NV assumed control of Taitung Business Bank last June. The HSBC Holdings PLC, Europe's biggest bank by market value, took control of the debt-laden Chinese Bank last December.
Chang said many international financial institutes have recently inquired about setting up branches in Taiwan, but did not submit applications because they did not meet the basic requirements.

Only international financial institutions ranked among the world's top 500 without any major irregularities within the past five years are qualified to apply to establish branches in Taiwan, Chang said.

Chang added that investment from foreign financial institutions will help increase management efficiency and service quality, and also proves that Taiwan's financial market is recognized by the international community.
The commission will keep working on easing restrictions related to foreign financial institutions' investment in Taiwan to boost the internationalization of Taiwan's financial market, Chang said.
She added that the ease of restrictions on the cross-Taiwan Strait financial policies will also contribute to attracting more investment from foreign financial institutions to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Disc listing foreign criminals lost for a year
Serious offenders on the run from the Netherlands have been able to commit further crimes in Britain after the Crown Prosecution Service mislaid a computer disc containing their details.
Home Office ministers were told within the past two or three weeks that a disc containing details of 4,000 offenders whom the Dutch authorities wished to trace had been missing for almost a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior Taipei city government official acquitted of slander

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung branch of the Taiwan High Court acquitted a senior Taipei City government official of slander charges, saying that he harbored no intention of insulting the plaintiff, the Public Prosecutors Office in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Su Ying-kuei, director of the Taipei City Department's Department of Labor Affairs and a former independent legislator, was earlier sentenced by the Kaohsiung District Court to one and a half months in prison, which could be converted to a fine, for calling prosecutors in Kaohsiung "walking dogs."
Su made the remarks on May 23, 2006 while appearing in court over another slander case involving himself.

Unhappy with the district court sentence, Su appealed the case to the High Court. A presiding judge granted his petition and overturned the sentence, saying that Su was merely expressing his displeasure with the attitudes of the prosecutors in handling the libel suit involving him, and that his remarks should not be construed as verbal abuse.
As the higher court's ruling is final, the Public Prosecutors Office in Kaohsiung may not appeal the case further.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 21, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Ministry of Foreign Affairs news conference. Date and Time: 10:30 a.m., Thursday, Feb. 21, 2008. Place: MOFA news center, 2, Ketagalan Blvd., Taipei City.
