DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday.

The weighted price index was up 87.88 points at 7,982.35 on a turnover of NT$2.99 billion (US$94.48 million) at the open. The index lost 129.94 points, or 1.61 percent, to close at 7,894.47 Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Thursday.
The greenback was trading at NT$31.536 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.112 from Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 21, or the 15th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1673: Jean Baptiste Poquelin Moliere, the French playwright whose sophisticated comedies include "Tartuffe" and "The Misanthrope," is buried in secret in a Paris cemetery.
1795: Holland surrenders Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) to Britain.
1858: Edwin Holmes of Boston installs the first electric burglar alarm.
1866: August von Wasserman, the German bacteriologist who invented a test to detect syphilis, is born.
1911: The United States and Japan sign a treaty limiting the flow of Japanese workers into the United States.
1916: Massed German artillery begin a furious bombardment of a crucial 13-kilometer sector of the French line at Verdun in the middle of the Western Front.
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1944: General Hideki Tojo, prime minister of Japan, replaces Field Marshall Hajime Sugiyama as chief of the Imperial Army general staff.
1957: Israel defies a U.N. resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1963: Moscow warns Washington that an American attack on Cuba would mean world war.
1969: King Hassan of Morocco is granted a patent by the U.S. Patents Office for his device to monitor the function of the human heart.
1970: A cargo plane belonging to Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes on top of Fushoushan in suburban Taipei, killing its two pilots.
1972: U.S. President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1973: Forty-six manufacturers attend the second European Industrial Machinery Exhibition in Taipei.
1973: Lt. Gen. Robert R. Williams, acting commander of the U.S. Army, Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Swaziland Vice Prime Minister Z.A. Khumalo arrives in Taipei for a week- long tour.
1974: The Buenos Aires University Club rugby team, champions of South America, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: The Taiwan Shipbuilding Corporation begins construction of a fifth 100,000-ton tanker for the Chinese Petroleum Corporation.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating a demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Hun Sen, premier of Cambodia, holds peace talks with his rival, Prince Ranaridh Sihanouk, in Bangkok.
1990: Salvadorean President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1992: Mainland China welcomes foreigners back to its stock market in Shanghai for the first time since 1949.
1998: The U.S. government advises its citizens to leave Iraq, in anticipation of new airstrikes.
2000: ROC Defense Minister Tang Fei arrives in Singapore to attend a five-day Asian Aerospace Show.
2000: Liberian President Charles Ghankay Taylor arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirits without integrity, of dullness without humility, of simplicity without honesty -- of such men I really do not know what to say."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan's trade office in Libya formally inaugurated: MOFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade office in Tripoli, Libya was formally inaugurated on Feb. 13 after nearly two years of preparations, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Wednesday.
MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said "the office will open a window of opportunity for Taiwan to develop relations with Libya on all levels."
"It will also serve as the new foothold for Taiwan to promote exchanges with North African countries and help tap investment opportunities for Taiwan businessmen," she added.
Taiwan and Libya maintained diplomatic relations from 1959 through 1978. In 1980, Taiwan set up a trade office in Libya, which was shut down in September 1997.
But Taiwan has continued to make efforts to seek substantial exchanges with the oil-rich North African nation.

Through such efforts, Saif Qadhafi, the elder son of Libya leader Moammar Gadhafi, visited Taiwan in January 2006, and reached an agreement with Taiwan on exchanging representative offices. Saif became the first influential Libyan figure to visit Taiwan since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1978.
President Chen Shui-bian also visited Libya in May of that year.

MOFA officials said that Libya has greatly improved its international image and its ties with the West by cooperating with Washington in fighting terrorism after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States in 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial mergers in Taiwan bear fruit: official

TEXT.P: The government's efforts to promote acquisitions and mergers among local banks in the last two years have boosted the financial sector's production values and wages, a top financial regulatory official said Wednesday.
The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) will continue to encourage large local banks to expand their overseas markets and attract foreign investment in Taiwan, said FSC Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng.

Despite the negative impacts of the credit card crisis in 2006, Taiwan's insurance industry saw a growth rate of 7.8 percent in the first three quarters of 2007, Hu said in a keynote speech to students at National Taiwan University.
The percentage was much higher than the country's economic growth rate of 5.45 percent, Hu said.
In addition, the total loans for local small and medium enterprises grew 9.3 percent year-on-year to surpass NT$3 trillion (US$94.7 billion) in 2007, Hu added.
In the past, Taiwan had too many banks that provided similar services, which resulted in price competition, he explained.
The acquisitions and mergers involving foreign investment in recent years have forced problematic banks out of the market, Hu said.
The number of Taiwan's banks has decreased from 53 in 2001 to 39 at present, according to Hu.
The consolidation of the financial sector has also increased local banks' profits, which has helped the sector outperform other industries in terms of pay raises and year-end bonuses, Hu said.
To further boost the financial sector's competitiveness, the commission will push for the establishment of a financial monitoring mechanism between Taiwan and China, Hu pointed out.
Meanwhile, local banks' offshore banking units (OBUs) have been allowed to accept foreign currency checking deposits, in currencies other than the Chinese yuan, from January this year, he continued.
Hu said that the opening was aimed at enabling the OBUs to meet the capital needs of overseas Taiwanese businesspeople.
Hu explained that China-based Taiwanese businesspeople have become a major source of profits for the OBUs.
As of the end of last year, the OBUs' assets totaled NT$3 trillion, Hu said, adding that the pre-tax profits of the OBUs accounted for 57 percent of the total banks' pre-tax earnings last year.

Furthermore, Hu said that the commission plans to ease the restrictions on the amount of loans that the OBUs can offer to China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, which is currently capped at the 30 percent of an OBU's net worth of assets, or 10 percent for unsecured loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Miss Tibet has no regrets over defying China's name change

TEXT.P: Miss Tibet Tsering Chungtak said in Taipei Wednesday that she did not regret making the decision to quit a beauty pageant in Malaysia last year over China's pressure to have her "Miss Tibet" sash replaced with one reading "Miss Tibet- China."
Chungtak, who won the crown last October, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a visit at the invitation of the Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest organizer.

The 22-year-old pageant winner is a student at the University of Delhi in India. The Miss Tibet pageant has been held for the fifth year at Dharamsala in northern India where the Government of Tibet in Exile is located.
Chungtak's host organization held a reception party for her in Taipei City Wednesday.

Chungtak told CNA reporters that she was forced to quit a beauty pageant in Malaysia last December. She said that China pressured the competition organizer to replace Chungtak's "Miss Tibet" sash to one reading "Miss Tibet-China, "and that she was told if she refused to wear the replaced sash she would have to leave the competition.

Chungtak made the decision to withdraw from the Miss Tourism Queen 2007 pageant and returned to her home in India. She said she did not regret making the decision and still believes she did the right thing in pulling out.
Similar title replacements due to pressure from the Chinese government have been experienced by many of Taiwan's pageant entrants participating in international competitions.

In response to questions about her opinions on Taiwan's future, Chungtak said "Taiwan has the right to make decisions for its own future and the right should be respected by other countries." She further added that "Taiwan's future is in the hands of Taiwan's people."

As to the future of Tibet, Chungtak said she will follow the Dalai Lama's moderate approaches in dealing with China. Tibet is currently officially claimed and administered by China, while many Tibetans place their allegiance with the exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.
Chungtak's itinerary in Taiwan includes meeting with Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey and visits to central and southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: European bank applies to set up branch in Taiwan: FSC

TEXT.P: A European bank has applied to establish a branch in Taiwan, following the trend of foreign banks acquiring domestic ones over the past two years and the subsiding credit card crisis, Financial Supervisory Commission Vice Chairwoman Susan Chang said Wednesday.

Chang said the European bank's name can only be announced after the application is approved. But she revealed that the bank's strong points are in asset management, derivative product investment and new financial products.
"Taiwan will have a total of 33 foreign banks if the application is approved," Chang said.
The acquisition of domestic banks by foreign banks has atracted more multinational banking groups to pay attention to the Taiwan market, Chang said.
The London-based Standard Chartered PLC acquired Taiwan's Hsinchu International Bank in September 2006.

The New York-based Citigroup Inc., the most profitable overseas bank in Taiwan, bought the Bank of Overseas Chinese last April, while ABN Amro Holding NV assumed control of Taitung Business Bank last June. The HSBC Holdings PLC, Europe's biggest bank by market value, took control of the debt-laden Chinese Bank last December.
Chang said many international financial institutes have recently inquired about setting up branches in Taiwan, but did not submit applications because they did not meet the basic requirements.

Only international financial institutions ranked among the world's top 500 without any major irregularities within the past five years are qualified to apply to establish branches in Taiwan, Chang said.

Chang added that investment from foreign financial institutions will help increase management efficiency and service quality, and also proves that Taiwan's financial market is recognized by the international community.
The commission will keep working on easing restrictions related to foreign financial institutions' investment in Taiwan to boost the internationalization of Taiwan's financial market, Chang said.
She added that the ease of restrictions on the cross-Taiwan Strait financial policies will also contribute to attracting more investment from foreign financial institutions to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet unveils plan to cut business, individual income tax rates

TEXT.P: The Cabinet unveiled Wednesday its plan to reduce business and individual income tax rates to ease the burdens on taxpayers, a measure which could be implemented as early as 2010.

The plan was put forth in preparation for the expected expiration of the Statute for Upgrading Industries at the end of 2009. The government is expected to see its revenue increase by NT$150 billion (US$4.74 billion) per year after the tax deductions or exemptions currently enjoyed by targeted businesses are abolished following the termination of the statute, said Minister of Finance Ho Chih-chin.
The new tax rates could be put into force Jan. 1, 2010 if related laws are amended by the Legislative Yuan by then, Ho said.

Under the plan, the business income tax rate would be decreased from the current 25 percent to 17.5 percent, and the current 10 percent tax rate on undistributed corporate earnings would be abolished altogether.
According to Deputy Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ford, the changes would help improve taxation transparency because they would conform the nominal tax rate with the effective tax rate.

Chang said the reform would also bridge the gap between Taiwan and neighboring economies such as Hong Kong and Singapore, which see their business income tax rates standing at 17.5 percent and 18 percent, respectively, and thus help enhance Taiwan's international competitiveness.

In terms of individual income tax, the Cabinet is planning to adjust the progressive tax brackets from the current 6 percent, 13 percent, 21 percent, 30 percent and 40 percent to 5.5 percent, 12 percent, 19.5 percent, 28 percent and 37.5 percent.

The special deduction for salary or wages per person would be increased from the current NT$78,000 to NT$100,000, that for the disabled would be raised from NT$77,000 to NT$100,000, and that for tuition would be adjusted from NT$25,000 per household to NT$25,000 per child.
Concerning the standard deduction category for income tax, the amount would be raised from NT$46,000 to NT$60,000 for singles and from NT$92,000 to NT$120,000 for married couples.

Chang said the government believes the reform would benefit all taxpayers, especially relieving the burdens of low and middle income earners in light of the fact that 67 percent of Taiwan households use the standard deduction category when filing their tax returns, 65 percent of which are low or middle income families.
Minister Ho said the decrease of business and individual income tax rates is expected to reduce the government's revenue by NT$2 billion per year.

However, the changes are expected to boost the country's nominal gross domestic product (GDP) by 1.63 percentage points, the real GDP by 0.35 percentage points, the real private consumption expenditure by 1.15 percent and the real fixed capital formation by 5.71 percent, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices surged Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 191.46 points, or 2.42 percent, to close at 8,085.93.

Rebounding after the previous day's losing sessions, the bourse opened at 7,982.35 and fluctuated between 8,085.93 and 7,972.13 during the day's session. A total of 4.58 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$120.31 billion (US$3.82 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground. Textile stocks advanced by 4.2 percent, the most of any sector. Cement stocks rose 3.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares were up 2.8 percent, banking and financial shares and construction issues both increased 2.3 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and paper and pulp issues both gained 2 percent and foodstuff issues advanced 1.8 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,599 to 321, with 340 stocks remaining unchanged.

: The Straits Times: Govt seeks greater protection for the mentally ill.

Singapore's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) passenger traffics reached a new high record last month after taxi fares rising, it shows that government's public transport system promoting is working.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA demands China Steel to first meet domestic needs

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has required China Steel Corp., the nation's largest steelmaker, to prioritize its steel supplies for domestic needs by maintaining its lower than international market price in the face of surging global steel prices, Minister Steve R.L. Chen said Thursday.

As an increase in steel prices is a world trend and the price of every steel product item offered by China Steel is already lower than the international market price by US$130-US$150 per metric ton, it is unreasonable and might cause market chaos to demand that prices be further cut, Chen added.
Chen was responding to the domestic construction industry's call on the ministry to urge the state-run steel manufacturer to cut domestic prices due to soaring international prices.

The ministry, in the capacity of the steelmaker's largest shareholder, also asked the company to ban downstream manufacturers maintaining cooperative relations with it from exporting unprocessed steel products to foreign countries, Chen added.

As to the downstream steel producers' comments that "China Steel's steel materials are extremely hard to get, even if we bring great amounts of cash to the company, " Chen said that given the company's limited output, it is natural for that company to first offer products to its existing clients rather than meeting the needs of new ones.
Meanwhile, Chen noted the rising prices of steel products highlighted the importance of Taiwan's self production capacity.

Chen's remarks came after the ministry announced Wednesday a ban on exports of small steel billets and reinforcing steel bars, or rebars--the main material for construction--in view of a supply shortage. The measure will begin March 5 for three months.
The ministry will put exports of H-shaped steel and steel scrap under "supervision" which would also last for three months.

However, steel corporations that receive orders, letters of credit or advance receipts, and other verified documents before March 5, can apply for export approval by the ministry's Bureau of Foreign Trade on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legal awareness low among Taiwan young Internet users: survey

TEXT.P: While downloading resources online is popular among young Internet users in Taiwan, many are unaware of the legality or safety of the downloaded items, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by the Business Software Alliance's Taiwan branch.
The survey conducted among 440 youths aged 13-24 revealed that 42 percent of respondents go online every day and 85.4 percent usually stay online for more than one hour each time.

Slightly over 31 percent of Taiwan youth usually go online to chat with friends through instant messenging and play online games, 13.4 percent visit or run blogs, 12.3 percent do searches, 4.5 percent view news reports, 2 percent receive or send e-mail, and 2 percent visit chat rooms.
It was found that 79.8 percent of respondents have had experience downloading Internet resources.

Of these respondents, 74.9 percent have obtained music, 64.1 percent have gotten games, 58.4 percent have downloaded photos, 40.2 percent have gained computer software, 30.5 percent have downloaded movies, and 16.8 percent have obtained online comic or fiction literature -- all for free.

The results showed that 40.2 percent of respondents have no idea if the resources they have downloaded are legal or illegal, and 54.7 percent have seen their computers suffer a viral attack after a download.

Meanwhile, 64.7 percent of respondents will share the downloaded information with classmates or friends, and 68.8 percent have received less than four lessons on cyber safety or cyber ethics in one semester.
The survey was carried out Feb. 1-5 by National Chengchi University's Marketing Survey Research Center for BSA-Taiwan. It has a margin of error of 3.9 percent.

According to BSA-Taiwan officials, the Chinese language equivalent of the BSA's B4Usurf Web site that aims to teach youths about cyber safety and cyber ethics is now available at http://tw.b4usurf.org.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressmen call for abolition of 'one China' policy
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 20 (CNA) 02/21/08 17:41:14 (By Jorge Liu and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A group of nine members of the U.S. Congress sent a joint letter to President George W. Bush Tuesday calling on him to abolish what they called an "obsolete" "one China" policy, which they said would make China incorrectly estimate the situation.

In the letter, the congressmen stressed that the "one China" policy was drawn up during the Cold War. As the policy implies that Taiwan is a part of China, it offers Beijing an excuse to oppose any defensive arms supply by the United States to Taiwan and an opportunity to control Taiwan and its nearby important marine routes, the letter said.

As long as the United States continues to acknowledge Beijing's claim that Taiwan is part of China, the Beijing government will keep on raising objections to United States' arms supply to Taiwan, and its protection of Taiwan's democracy," the congressmen said.

They cited an example as saying that China refused recently two American ships entry to Hong Kong to evade a storm as a way to show its displeasure about America's promise to guarantee Taiwan's security and President Bush's awarding the Congressional Gold Medal to the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet that the Chinese government sees as a separatist.

Today, the stability in the West Pacific has been maintained not because of America's "one China" policy, but rather because of the Taiwan Relations Act abided by the U.S. government, the congressmen continued.

It's unthinkable that the American government still adopts a policy enacted in the 1970s during the 21st century, they said, warning that the United States will face increasing tension in the region unless it updates its "one China" policy.

In addition, they said, it would cause disastrous results due to the complicated messages transmitted by the U.S. to China and Taiwan when the United States adopts a "one China" policy while abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act.
Being a vanguard for freedom, the U.S. should set an example by insisting on its beliefs, values and principles since it has urged China to play a responsible role, the congressmen stressed.

The nine congressmen are Gus Bilirakis (R-Fla.), Thomas Tancredo (R-Colo.), Thaddeus Mccotter (R-Mich.), Steve Chabot (R-Ohio), Scott Garrett (R-N.J.) , Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.) , John Culberson (R- Texas), Mark Souder (R-Ind.) and Collin Peterson (D-Minn.).

DOC.HEADLINE: Private oil supplier mulling price hikes

TEXT.P: Formosa Petrochemical Corp. -- Taiwan's sole private fuel supplier -- urged the government Thursday to lift a freeze on its floating pricing system and said that it might adjust upward its product prices in March.

"The government and the public should face up to the reality of a high oil price era and that their efforts to freeze product prices will not resolve this problem," company spokesman Lin Keh Yen said.
"We hope the government will resume allowing the industry to use a floating oil pricing system," Lin said.
He added that "Formosa Petrochemical Corp. does not rule out the possibility of increasing prices for its products in March."
The government has suppressed oil price hikes by Formosa's rival state-run CPC Corp., making it difficult for Formosa to raise its prices.

As the international crude oil price again re-surged to US$100 per barrel Tuesday, domestic gasoline and diesel prices should be hiked by NT$2.20 and by NT$2.50 per liter, respectively, in March, Lin said.
According to Lin, the freeze on the domestic oil and fuel prices has cut down the company's profit by some NT$1 billion (US$31.75 million).
Lin voiced the hope that the government would reinstate its oil floating pricing mechanism in view of recent jumps in international crude oil prices.

He meanwhile pledged that his company will definitely supply the home market first before supplying overseas markets. Currently, 45 percent of the company's products are sold to the domestic market, Lin noted.

State-owned fuel supplier CPC Corp. Taiwan imposed a floating pricing mechanism in January 2007 that adjusted its product prices every week in response to crude oil price changes in the world market. But the system was substituted by a monthly adjustment formular last September.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs ordered a freeze on the mechanism in November 2007 out of fear that continuous hikes would fan inflationary pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 203 points to close at 8,032, with 59,055 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 177 points to finish at 8,006, with 135 contracts traded, while June futures increased 185 points to close at 7,979, with 38 contract transactions.
September futures gained 190 points to finish at 7,780, with 61 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 191 points to close at 7,777, with nine contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 191.46 points Thursday to finish at 8,085.93, with market turnover of NT$120.31 billion (US$3.82 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,829 for March; 7,829 for April; 7,794 for June; 7,590 for September and 7,586 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

March TE futures gained 10.05 points to close at 307.95, with 6,070 contracts traded, while April TE futures increased 8.8 points to finish at 306.7, with 23 contract exchanges. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures moved up 23.4 points to close at 1,042.8, with 4,803 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures rose 24.6 points to finish at 1,044, with seven contracts traded.
September TF futures increased 9.2 points to finish at 1034.2, with eight contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June and December.

A total of US$1.25 billion changed hands during the day's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan appoints representative to Libya

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) appointed Ibrahim Chao, Taiwan's deputy representative to Saudi Arabia, as the island's deputy representative to Libya, MOFA Spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Thursday.
There is currently no representative from Taiwan appointed to Libya, Yeh said, so Chao will serve as acting representative in the mean time.

Yeh said Chao studied in Libya in North Africa for many years and received his doctoral degree in that country. He also taught there and is proficient in Arabic, Libya's official language, according to Yeh.
"Chao will help strengthen bilateral relations at his new position," Yeh said.
Chao's appointment comes shortly after the Taiwan Commercial Office in Tripoli, Libya's capital, was inaugurated on Feb. 13 after nearly two years of preparations.
"The office will open a window of opportunity for Taiwan to develop relations with Libya on all levels," Yeh said.

"It will also serve as the new foothold for Taiwan to promote exchanges with North African countries and help tap investment opportunities for Taiwan businessmen," she added. Libya draws foreign investors with its development in petrochemical, tourism, and basic infrastructure construction industries.
In Africa, Taiwan also has representative offices in Nigeria and South Africa, in addition to Libya. It has embassies in Swaziland, Gambia, Burkina Faso, Sao Tome and Principe.

Taiwan and Libya maintained diplomatic relations from 1959 through 1978, but relations ended in 1978 when Libya switched diplomatic recognition to China. In 1980, Taiwan set up a trade office in Libya, which was shut down in September 1997 because of pressure from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for support for U.N. bid referendums

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the country's citizens Thursday to put aside their political differences to vote for the two upcoming referendums on the country's bid to be accepted into the United Nations.
According to Chen, the move would allow them to display their support for Taiwan and let the world hear Taiwan's desire to participate in the world body.

The president made the remarks in the latest issue of his online newsletter, in response to a letter from a citizen who praised Chen for amassing four intangible assets for the country, including introducing the referendum system in Taiwan and raising a stronger sense of Taiwan identity.

Agreeing that the public's consciousness about Taiwan's identity has taken roots in the country over the past seven years, Chen noted that while only 36 percent of the country's citizens identified themselves as Taiwanese, rather than Chinese, in 2000, the percentage of people considering themselves Taiwanese has increased to 68 percent today.

On the referendum system, Chen said the enactment of the Referendum Act in 2003 made possible the country's first referendum in March 2004, which he said helped deepen and consolidate Taiwan's democracy.
Following that were two referendums held last month alongside the Jan. 12 legislative elections, but voter turnout was too low for the referendums to be considered.

Two more referendums -- both on Taiwan's long bid to join the U.N. -- will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election to help Taiwan realize the idea that "sovereignty lies in the hands of the people, "Chen said.

The two referendums are initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . While the DPP's version advocates joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " the KMT's initiative calls for regaining U.N. membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

However, as both the 2004 referendum and the Jan. 12 referendums failed because the turnout rates did not reach the required 50 percent -- partly due to a boycott by the KMT, there have been concerns that the upcoming referendums would fail to pass as well, especially when voters who opt to take part in the KMT- initiated referendum are likely to skip the DPP-backed referendum, and vice versa.
Based on such concerns, the DPP has recently been calling on the public to take an active part in both referendums to ensure their passage.

DOC.HEADLINE: 47.79 million desktops to be exported by Taiwan this year: analyst

TEXT.P: Taiwan will export 47.79 million desktop computers this year, with a growth rate of 3.7 percent over last year, according to an industry analyst Wednesday.

Wang Ching-shu of the Institute of Information Industry (III) predicted that the export of desktops in the first quarter of this year will be 11.35 million, with production value totaling US$3.29 billion.

Citing recent statistics from the Institute of Information Industry (III) database, Wang said Wednesday that it is estimated that the number of desktop computers exported to overseas markets in the first quarter of this year will register 11.35 million, with production value totaling US$3.29 billion.

The first quarter of each year is generally a dull season for the global sales of desktop computers, said Wang, but the demand for desktop computers during this year's first quarter seems even more languid, apparently due to the impact of the US subprime mortgage crisis.
Low laptop computer prices and a wait-and-see attitude taken by most potential buyers of Microsoft's Windows Vista-based computers were also factors causing a slower rate of growth in desktop sales.
The subprime mortgage crisis saw a sharp rise in home foreclosures which started in the United States in September 2007 and developed into a global financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan represents a model for China: scholar

TEXT.P: Taiwan's isolation in the international community has a negative effect on the country only in the short term, while its democratic and economic achievements can serve as a great example for the region, especially China, a U.S. scholar said in Taipei Wednesday.

"The isolation that Taiwan feels is entirely artificial. It is based entirely on the great shadow of the penumbra of China, " Herbert London, president of the Washington-based think tank, the Hudson Institute, said in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Speaking about Taiwan's role in the international community, he said "time is very much on the side of Taiwan."

London noted that the difficulty Taiwan has in trying to join the United Nations is due to China possessing the veto power. As long as China is a member of the U.N. Security Council and unanimous vote in the Security Council is required for Taiwan to join the U.N., Taiwan will be barred from joining the world body, he said.
"That isolation is a great problem in the short term for Taiwan," London said, but he stressing that "if you take a long term view, I'm very sanguine about Taiwan's role in the world."
Playing an even more active role in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) , a forum of which Taiwan is a part, is one way Taiwan can build bridges with other countries, London said.
He noted that the commercial arrangements that could be made between Taiwan and ASEAN countries can play an important role in "cementing relationships that ultimately lead to political contact."
London said: "Taiwan can reach out on its own and has an awful lot to offer" such as its democracy, political system, and economic achievements.
Describing Taiwan's economic and democratic achievements as "exceedingly important", London said "in some respects, Taiwan represents a model for China."
According to London, it is logical to expect that China's political system will have to undergo a significant change, a form of liberalization.

However, China does not have a multi-party system nor does it understand the nature of democratic institutions, he said. When China does eventually liberalize its political system, which is only a matter of time, the model can come from its neighbor -Taiwan, London said.

"The rise of the Democratic Progressive Party has been an amazing development and however critical Taiwanese people are of President Chen Shui-bian, the fact that Taiwan has an active two party system is very important," London said.

DOC.HEADLINE: People indifferent to human rights violations: activist

TEXT.P: Most people around the world are indifferent toward human rights violations, David Matas, a Canadian human right attorney, claimed Thursday at an international forum, adding that even though the public agrees that human rights violations in China are wrong, "they are not prepared to do anything about it."

Describing indifference as the "biggest obstacle" to combating human rights violations, Matas said that "people are indifferent because they do not pay close enough attention to sort out truth from falsehood, the real from the unreal."

He further suggested that the best strategies are to arouse awareness of human rights and to enable everyone to distinguish the lies told by any regime -- like China -- in the form of propaganda and hiding the truth.

Discounting China's promise to improve its human rights record, Paolo Barabesi, a representative of Human Rights Without Frontiers, examined cases of how China has suppressed religion and the development of human rights within the nation, saying that "there has not been any progress."

The International Forum titled Human Rights in China and the 2008 Olympics, organized by the Coalition to Investigate the Persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG) and the Taiwan Culture Foundation, was aimed at pressing China to improve its human rights record before the 2008 Beijing Olympics scheduled to open Aug. 8.

Human rights defenders, including David Kilgour, the former Canadian secretary of state for Asia-Pacific affairs, Australian Senator Andrew Bartlett, Falun Gong spokesman Erping Zhang and Dhondup Dorjee, vice president of the Tibetan Youth Congress, as well as Falun Gong practitioners and scholars, were attending the one-and-a-half day seminar to exchange views and experiences.

Legislator Lai Ching-te of Taiwan, the president of CIPFG Asia, urged the governments of all nations to face the bloody suppression of human rights by the Chinese government and take measures to prevent the Beijing Olympics from being a repeat of the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

Pointing out that the Berlin Olympics were a propaganda tool for Adolf Hitler and Nazi Germany to stir up nationalism, Lai said that "what the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games is going to become is in our hands."

Cabinet spokesman Shieh Jhy-wey also said that "it is very important for people around the world to be able to speak out and to act as individuals, " which is, according to him, what the Chinese government fears the most.

On Taiwan's role in helping facilitate human rights in China, Shieh said that "Taiwan is not only a part of the word... it will fight against this communist regime that has killed many people, " adding that "working against evil, working against the devil is a part of human rights."

In response to Lai and Shieh, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Tung Chen- yuan said at the opening address of the forum that "we believe Chinese people deserve just as good human rights as other people in the world."
Describing Taiwan as a model of democracy among Chinese societies, Tung expressed hope that Taiwan's experience in democratization will promote human rights and the legal system in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority of voters unswayed by 'green card' issue: poll

TEXT.P: A large majority of Taiwan's voters are not concerned about a controversy over whether presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou holding a U.S. green card, according to poll results released Thursday, which indicated the issue will not swing votes in the upcoming election.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's candidate Frank Hsieh's camp has recently challenged opposition Kuomintang candidate Ma's loyalty and integrity over his possession of U.S. permanent residency status, or a "green card" from the United States.
Ma said that the green card, which he obtained while studying in the U. S. in the late 1970s, had lost its validity in the mid-'80s after he returned to Taiwan.

According to the pro-independence Taiwan Thinktank, which conducted the poll, 65.3 percent of the respondents said they will not change their decision on voting Hsieh or Ma because of the controversy.

However, 19.4 percent of the survey respondents said the green card controversy is leading them to change their mind on who to vote for in the presidential election slated for March 22, the poll found.

Taiwan Thinktank conducted the telephone poll on Feb. 13-16 among eligible voters randomly selected nationwide. A total of 1,088 valid samples were collected with a margin of error of 3.0 percentage points.

The poll, meanwhile, found that 66.5 percent of the respondents considered the green card incident as "political rhetoric" played up by the DPP camp. Only 19.5 percent considered the green card issue "an important discussion topic."
Meanwhile, 38.5 percent of the respondents said they believed Ma had been "dishonest" when he talked about his U.S. green card, compared with 16.5 percent who disagreed with the suggestion.

The poll also found that 38.4 percent of the respondents considered it "inappropriate" for a candidate who is a U.S. green card holder to be the nation's future head of state, compared with 34.2 percent who disagreed, Taiwan Thinktank said.

Meanwhile, up to 51 percent of the respondents said Ma and his wife should make public their passport records to address public concerns, compared with 25.3 percent who said it is unnecessary for the couple to do so.

While 41.9 percent of the respondents criticized Ma's crisis handling ability in the wake of the green card incident, 26 percent said Ma has no problem in terms of crisis management, according to the Taiwan Thinktank.

Meanwhile, according to the poll, 40 percent of the respondents said Hsieh made impressive achievements during his tenure as mayor of the southern metropolis Kaohsiung between 1998-2005, such as streamlining the Love River that flows across Kaohsiung. But 46.3 percent said they have no idea what and whether Ma had done during his tenure as Taipei mayor between 1998-2006.

On the question of who voters think will perform better during upcoming televised presidential debates between Hsieh and Ma, 43.3 percent said Hsieh will perform better, compared with a mere 16.7 percent for Ma.
The two debates are slated for Feb. 24 and March 9.
Two referendums will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election on Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations.

According to the poll, 44.1 percent of the respondents said they support the DPP-proposed referendum on joining the U.N. under the name "Taiwan, " compared with 40.5 percent who expressed opposition to the suggestion.

A total of 37.4 percent said they support the KMT-proposed referendum on joining the U.N. under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name, compared with 45.2 percent who expressed opposition to the suggestion, according to the poll.
Neither the DPP-proposed U.N.-bid referendum nor the KMT-proposed U.N.-bid referendum obtained support by half of the country's general voters, the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessmen reserved about `voter plane tickets'
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/21/08 19:53:27 (By H.H. Chiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: China-based Taiwanese businessmen seem to be adopting a wait-and-see attitude toward booking preferential air tickets for flights home for the March 22 presidential vote, a local travel agent said Thursday.

Lin Yu-chen, a manager in charge of the Chinese market of the Taipei-based SET travel agency, said some Taiwan businessmen might have reservations about flying back to Taiwan and taking part in the presidential election. "This might be another factor why some tickets have not been booked, apart from the traditionally low season in March," she explained.

Lin, however, was reluctant to reveal the actual number of Taiwanese businessmen to have booked the tickets -- which are some 40 percent cheaper than normal flight prices. SET travel agency, in collaboration with the Beijing-based Taiwan Compatriot Investment Enterprises Association, which provides preferential air tickets to Taiwanese businessmen, is responsible for booking the tickets for the businessmen.

In response to the cool response from the Taiwanese businessmen, the secretary- general of the association pledged that the association will do its best to help all Taiwanese businessmen hoping to get home to vote in the presidential election buy cheap tickets.
It is also understood that some of the businessmen have complained that they did not know about the booking service for the preferential tickets.
According to the association's estimates, at least 250,000 Taiwanese people residing in China, including businessmen and students, are planning to return to vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: Output of IC manufacturing sector to rise in 2008: ITRI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) manufacturing sector is expected to retain its momentum in 2008, with its production value increasing to NT$1.59 trillion (US$50.35 billion) , the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast Thursday.

The projected figure will represent a rise of 8.8 percent from 2007, when the production value of the sector expanded to NT$1.46 trillion, a year-on-year growth of 4.6 percent over 2006, according to the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center.

The production value of IC design amounted to NT$399.7 billion in 2007, up a whopping 23.6 percent over 2006, while that of IC manufacturing reached NT$727.4 billion, representing a decline of 5.1 percent year-on-year. The production value of IC packaging reached NT$228 billion, up 8.2 percent, while that of IC testing topped NT$102.3 billion, up 10.7 percent year-on-year, according to the center.

In the IC sector as a whole, the production value of IC design is forecast to reach NT$450 billion this year, up 12.6 percent over 2007, while that of IC manufacturing is expected to reach NT$766 billion, representing a year-on-year increase of 5.3 percent, that of IC packaging is forecast to reach NT$255 billion, up 11.8 percent, and that of IC testing is forecast to top NT$115 billion, up 12.4 percent, according to the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: 200 'fat' police officers to join marathon under 'get lean' program

TEXT.P: Two hundred overweight policemen were among 1,000 policemen in northern Taiwan who registered to take part in an international marathon scheduled for next month, the National Police Agency (NPA) said Thursday.

Chen Kuo-en, who is in charge of public relations in the NPA, said the "fat cops" -- whose combined weight is nearly 20 tons -- were encouraged by the agency's Director-General Hou Yu-ih to take part in the marathon to be held in Taipei County on March 2.

The NPA is currently promoting a "get lean by weight loss" program and encouraging all overweight policemen to get more exercise to get rid of flab. Hou has encouraged those officers with body mass index (BMI) larger than 27 to take part in the event.
BMI is found by dividing one's weight by the square of one's height in meters. If the result is more than 24, the person is considered overweight, obese if over 27, and too thin if lower than 18.5.
Chen said that the competition will be divided into three categories: 42 km, 21 km and 6 km, and he himself will run the 42-km category.
Hou will lead some policemen to run the 6-km race, while his deputy, Hsieh Hsiu- neng, at the age of 60, will run the 21-km, according to Chen.
Chen also said that to encourage policemen to stay fit, police stations around the island have invited nutritionists to speak on balanced diets regularly.
In addition to promoting more exercise, the NPA is also offering "belly dance" classes to policemen, hoping that it will be a "fun" and "easy" way to get weight down.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agriculture experts test new eco-friendly crop enhancer in Taoyuan

TEXT.P: Agriculture researchers at a government- run laboratory have proven the effects of a new eco-friendly crop enhancer in boosting the output of cultivated vegetables and improving land productivity, government sources said Thursday.

Explaining the composition of the bio-enhancer, staffers at the Taoyuan District Agricultural Research and Extension Station under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said they first carbonize bamboo stems left over by local farmers and then grind the bamboo charcoal into particles to mix with other ingredients.

In field experiments, the bio-enhancer provides maximal effect at the ratio of 1,000 kg per hectare. However, when the amount exceeds 1,500 kg per hectare, the marginal effect decreases drastically, they said.
"At the optimal ratio, the output volume of lettuce is raised by 4 percent," said Fu Yang-jen, deputy director of the station.
"Meanwhile, the enhancer can also purify farmland by absorbing toxic chemicals," Fu explained.

The station researchers said bamboo charcoal has a high pH value, hence can be used to neutralize acid soil laced with fertilizer or pesticide residue to provide a more suitable environment for plant growth. Meanwhile the numerous microscopic holes in charcoal particles also traps these chemicals.

According to COA tallies, most vegetable farmers in northern Taiwan use indoor cultivation facilities, covering a total of 250 hectares in the Keelung, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu areas. These facilities generate an annual vegetable output of 3,750 tons.

"If they overuse the fertilizer or pesticide, the secluded environment contains too high concentrations of these chemicals, hence the need for an eco-friendly crop enhancer that can raise output while purging the excessive chemicals to support sustainable agriculture," Fu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT will not exclude presenting resolution on U.N. bid

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Thursday that his party will not exclude presenting a resolution in the legislature on Taiwan's desire to join the United Nations.

Wu made the remarks after attending a seminar on legislative affairs held by a KMT thinktank in Taipei. His remarks came at a time when both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the KMT are promoting their own versions of a U.N. bid referendum to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.

The DPP's version focuses on joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan, which has encountered strong opposition from the United States and several European countries, while KMT's referendum proposal advocates regaining U.N. membership under the name Republic of China or another "suitable" name.

Describing the holding of referendums as an inevitable step for Taiwan on its march toward full democracy, President Chen Shui-bian has expressed hope that both parties can reach a consensus on the U.N. bid referendum and has suggested that the Legislative Yuan present a third referendum as another option.

However, Wu said his party will not support the third referendum, but might present a resolution in the legislature at an appropriate time to illustrate the desire of Taiwan's people to participate in world organizations.

Considering the slim chances of the two parties reaching a consensus on the U.N. bid referendum, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih claimed recently that a resolution passed by the legislature can more clearly demonstrate public opinions.
"We welcome the participation of the DPP in the wording of the resolution," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival opens in Tainan County

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival, organized by the Tainan county government, opened in the Southern Taiwan Science Park for an 11-day show until March 2 to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Rat.

President Chen Shui-bian lit the centerpiece of the festival, a giant lantern in the shape of a spinous country rat -- a species of rodent endemic to Taiwan -- standing on its hind legs and holding a gold ingot to its chest.
The 15-meter papier mache rat is mounted on a three-meter pedestal and the whole piece weighs 25 metric tons.

The venue of the lantern festival is located in Solar City, a special zone of the science park, with a 88-hectare showground. Over 55,000 red and yellow lanterns have been used to form giant Chinese and English characters that read "Taiwan Peace" -- the theme of the festival.
In addition to the centerpiece, there are eight areas in the showground for lanterns in different motifs and designs, plus a flower show and a gourmet food street.

Prior to the opening ceremony at 7 p.m., visitors were treated to a two-hour performance by seven dance groups, including five from Japan -- a 22-member Yosakoi dance group, a 52-member Kamidon dance troupe from Kamikawa in Hokkaido, a 62-member dance team from Hokkaido University, a 28-member Nebuta traditional folk dance troupe from Aomori Prefecture, and a Basara dance group from Mizunami in Gifu Prefecture.
The two domestic groups were a lion dance team from Taichung and
a dance team consisting of students from the Taipei Physical Education College's Dance Department and the Department of Sport Training Science and Martial Arts.
There will be 34 fireworks shows throughout the festival and the county government will give away 120,000 hand-held lanterns featuring the rat motif as gifts to visitors.

To encourage the public to use mass transit vehicles, the organizers will distribute gift lanterns to visitors in the next three days at a new temporary railway station located 100 meters from the venue of the festival. The Taiwan Railway Administration has scheduled 58 trains each day to stop at the station.
The Taiwan High Speed Railway will also provide daily free shuttle services from its Tainan Station in Gueiren township to the showground.

DOC.HEADLINE: Domestic airlines see 2007 decline

TEXT.P: Domestic airlines' operations for 2007 slid in both passenger and cargo traffics, hit by mounting oil prices and the impact of the high speed railway, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Thursday.
Ministry statistics show that the total number of passengers of the six domestic airlines for 2007 was 24.79 million, down by 7.1 percent or 1.9 million from the year-earlier level.

Of this figure, the number of domestic flight passengers was 6.32 million, a decrease of 26.6 percent from the figure of 2006, the official said. The number of international flight passengers rose slightly by 2.1 percent from the 2006 figure to 18.47 million, according to the statistics.

Meanwhile, the total freight volume of the six domestic airlines for 2007 was 1.73 million tons, a decrease of 50,000 tons or 3 percent, from the year-earlier level. Domestic route freight volume was 5.2 tons, down 2.3 percent, while international route freight volume for the same year was 1.68 million tons, down by 3 percent.

The world's airlines, including Taiwan's, all faced challenges due to the rising oil prices. However, the local airlines were also affected by the Taiwan High Speed Railway, which began operating last January, offering an alternative quick method of traveling the length of Taiwan. Its express train takes 90 minutes to travel from Taipei City in northern Taiwan to Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, at a cost of about NT$1,500 (US$48) . The airfare for the same journey is about NT$2,000.
THSR's relatively cheap fare and acceptable speed have forced several domestic airlines to stop operations on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route.

DOC.HEADLINE: Small German community keeps tradition alive in Taiwan

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relatively small German expatriate community is keeping a centuries old tradition from their home country alive here by hosting an event celebrating the spring harvest next week.

The Green Cabbage Dinner, a North-Germany tradition that celebrates the harvest with cabbage and liquors, will be held for the eighth consecutive year in Taiwan to cater to nostalgic German expatriates.

Menu items for the dinner are made from ingredients imported from Germany, with each year's event serving the same German cuisine, including specially-cooked German cabbage, sausages, potatoes, beer and schnaps, which is an unsweetened distilled beverage popular in Germany.
In addition, as in previous years, German entertainers are invited to spice up the party, with German folk singer Peter Petrel scheduled to perform this year.
The event will be held on Feb. 29 at the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel, the location for the party in three of the past eight years.
The party is organized by Jens Finke, a German expatriate from Bremen of northern Germany, who first initiated the event eight years ago.
Over 80 percent of the guests are local Germans, who take the opportunity to absorb their cooking from their home country and get together with their countrymen, according to Finke.

"Each time we keep the dishes the same as much as possible to maintain our unique German tradition alive in a foreign country, " Finke said, hailing this as a key consideration in organizing the event.
Rooted in German tradition, the cabbage dinner has been staged around northern Germany every February since 1545.

The Taipei-based series was first launched in 2001 and has become the main social function for the German community in Taipei ever since, drawing approximately 130 participants each year, said Finke, who owns an ice cream shop in Taipei's Tianmu district.
The same event is held around major Asian cities including Shanghai, Hong Kong, Seoul and Tokyo. The Hong Kong event is among the oldest, with more than 20 years of history.
Event sponsors are mostly German enterprises, including electronics giant Siemens, beer maker Beck's, spring water company Apollinaris and shipping company Kuehne + Nagel.
This year Apollinaris will sponsor the event by giving out free bottles of spring water, while the Kuehne + Nagel will offer free shipping service for ingredients exported from Germany.
"They (German companies) sponsor the event mainly to show their support to the German community here, rather than seeking advertisement opportunities," Finke said.

Having participated in all previous Green Cabbage Dinners, Brenda Rowek, a Taiwanese who is married to a German expatriate, said although the food served at the dinner might not fit the taste of Taiwanese, the warm-hearted ambience welcomes everyone who joins the meal.

She said one of the major challenges of continuing the event is to maintain the level of participation, due to factors like the high entrance fee and the small population of Germans in Taiwan, which has shown very little growth in recent years.

"Nowadays a large portion of Germans in Taiwan are students rather than employees of German companies," she said, indicating that the NT$1,800 entrance fee for the party might be too expensive for the students.
But the turnout at the dinner does not indicate a decline in German investment in the island.
Duncan Levine, Communications Director of European Chamber of Commerce Taipei, said there are no indications that German business activities are declining in Taiwan.

Over US$1.7 billion (NT$54.4 billion) of German investment in Taiwan and a bilateral trade volume of US$10 billion between the two countries were recorded in 2006, making Germany the biggest trading partner of Taiwan among EU member states, according to a report issued by the European Economic and Trade Office in 2007.

The current population of Germans living in Taiwan is around 1,400 to 1,500 people and has been stable, according to an estimate by Sven Meier, the Press and Public Relations Officer of the German Institute Taipei.

Levine noted it is becoming more common for German companies in Taiwan to hire more local employees rather than German expatriates, a trend that might explain the lack of growth in expatriate numbers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Watchdog group pushes for webcasting of legislative proceedings

TEXT.P: Local parliamentary reform activists urged the new legislature Thursday to have all major legislative proceedings broadcast live over the Internet to enhance transparency and accountability.

Key members of the Citizen Congress Watch, a private watchdog group dedicated to supervising the lawmaking body, made the appeal at a news conference held on the eve of the opening of the new legislative session.

Ku Chung-hua, the watchdog body's chairman, first criticized Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng for lending only "half-hearted support" to their call for full transparency in all legislative proceedings.
Ku was referring to Wang's recent declaration that he will push for legislative reforms, including crafting a parliamentary broadcasting system.

While recognizing Wang's consent to have legislative floor meetings broadcast live, Ku said it is regrettable that Wang did not promise similar transparency for other legislative proceedings, such as committee meetings and cross-party caucus negotiations.

Wang's hesitation to have committee meetings broadcast live and to scrap closed- door caucus negotiations will only increase public misgivings about shady deals inside the legislature, Ku pointed out.

Noting that the new, streamlined legislature, with only 113 seats instead of the previous 225, will determine the fate of many critical bills, Ku said the public has the right to know details of legislative proceedings.

"The public should have access to the operations of the legislative standing committees, " Ku said, adding that it is unreasonable and unjustifiable to keep the operations of legislative committees from public supervision.
Denial of public access to legislative committee proceedings violates the existing regulations, which require transparency of government information, Ku added.

He further took to task the legislature's spending of tens of millions of dollars installing a closed-circuit audio-visual broadcasting system that restricts broadcasting of floor meetings and committee sessions to only inside the legislature.
Ku also questioned the plausibility of the legislature's plan to send a delegation abroad to study parliamentary broadcasting systems adopted in major foreign countries.

"The legislature need simply modify its current in-house broadcasting system to allow public access, " Ku noted, adding that he sees no need for the legislature to waste money and time studying foreign practices.

Speaking on the same occasion, Huang Hsiu-tuan, a professor at Soochow University, said the results of a recent survey by the Citizen Congress Watch show that procedure committee and caucus negotiations are the least transparent among all the legislative proceedings.

"Although Hong Kong lags behind Taiwan in democratic development and its Legislative Council is less powerful than its Taiwan counterpart, it outstrips Taiwan in terms of legislative transparency as all of its legislative proceedings are broadcast live and its citizens can easily observe legislative meetings in person," she noted.
Huang also urged the legislature to revise many exisiting regulations governing its operations to facilitate public supervision of the lawmaking body.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official calls for attention to culture

TEXT.P: The government should realize that culture is one of a country's major foundations and should allocate more funds to boost cultural development, a top cultural official said Wednesday.

Speaking to a group of nearly 100 art workers and activists, Wang Tuoh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), said the CCA will strive to raise the percentage of its funds in the central government's total funds to 1.5 percent from the current 1.34 percent.
Wang said that the government has long failed to pay enough attention to cultural development.
He added that a recent fire that destroyed the rehearsal studio of Taiwan's highly acclaimed Cloud Gate Dance Theatre has exposed many long-term problems faced by the country's cultural sector.
The Feb. 11 fire burned down the 35-year-old theater's 1,324 square-meter rehearsal studio, as well as destroying costumes, props and production archives.
In the past, Wang went on, the council only offered emergency relief measures to individual artists.
Now, the council is formulating regulations to provide similar measures to art groups, he added.
In addition, Wang noted, the council has assisted Cloud Gate in using the Taiwan Human Rights Memorial park in Jingmei, Taipei City, as a temporary rehearsal studio for one year.
After the theater leaves the park, the space will be provided to other performing groups, which he said will add artistic touches to the park, a former military detention center.
Wang said culture should transcend politics and urged people in the cultural sector and other members of the public to be more open-minded and to respect different opinions.

On a different occasion that same day, Wang, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member, was invited to give a report at a regular DPP Central Standing Committee on how the council helped Cloud Gate.

After listening to the report, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh, who is also the party's candidate for the March 22 presidential election, vowed that if he is elected, he will increase the government's cultural funding to 5 percent of its budget, which would amount to some NT$80 billion (US$2.5 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: Government adjusts economic growth rate downward for 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan will be able to achieve an economic growth rate of 4.32 percent this year, down slightly from the previously targeted 4.53 percent, the country's top statistics official forecast Thursday.

Hsu Jan-yau, director-general of the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said the agency adjusted downward the economic growth forecast for this year mainly in light of the impact of the subprime mortgage crisis in the United States and its aftermath, which has wreaked havoc on the global economy since last year.

The DGBAS made public that day Taiwan's economic tallies for 2007, including an overall economic growth of 5.7 percent year-on-year, with per capita gross domestic product (GDP) hitting US$16,790 and the consumer price index (CPI) rising by a mild 1.8 percent year-on-year.
Hsu forecast that with an economic growth rate of 4.32 percent, the country's per capita GDP is expected to hit US$18,042 this year.

Worldwide, he predicted, the global economy -- which will inevitably sustain the impact of the U.S. subprime crisis and aftermath -- will post a growth of 3.2 percent for this year, 0.1 percentage points lower than was forecast last November.

He predicted that the U.S. economy will expand by a mere 1.4 percent this year, down from 2.2 percent that was posted last year, despite the facts that the U.S. Fed cut interest rates several times and President George W. Bush signed a new US$168 billion economic measure to rev up the sagging economy.

The world's major economic players, including Japan, the European Union and China, will also witness slower economic growth this year, at 1.2 percent, 1.9 percent and 9.9 percent, respectively, from the previously estimated 2.1 percent, 2.9 percent and 11.4 percent, he said.

Fortunately, Hsu said, Taiwan will fare better than the U.S., Japan and the EU economically this year, as the country has increased its exports to newly emerged markets such as the ASEAN countries, India and the Middle East -- a development that will help alleviate the impact of declining imports from major industrialized countries.

Taiwan's exports to those newly emerged economies constituted 17.7 percent of the country's entire export trade last year, compared to the U.S.' 13 percent and the EU's 10.8 percent, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government encouraging academia-industry collaboration

TEXT.P: The government will boost the efficiency of the collaboration between universities and industry in a bid to keep up with the changing global economy with high-end product innovation, Small and Medium Enterprise Administration Director-General Robert Lai said Thursday.

A 2006 project initiated by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) was put into action in January with the goals of doubling the trade volume from intellectual property rights developed in universities, enticing industry to allocate more research funding and boosting the number of companies incubated by universities, Lai said.

"To maximize the use of academic research and enhance technology transfer and the commercialization of university- born inventions, the project will team up with National Science Council (NSC) and the Ministry of Education (MOE) to establish a link between Taiwan universities and industry, " said Lai.

Addressing a seminar, Lai noted that past efforts on university-industry collaboration have not been efficient, as the business incubators in universities, funded with investment by industry for intellectual property development, have not been properly managed.
"Facing a highly competitive global intellectual economy, a well- integrated platform coordinating school research and product development is key to the survival of the companies," he added.

Tsai Lien-Sheng, top official of the Taiwan-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, also stressed the urgency of setting up such a platform, saying that universities must be aware of what industry needs in order to develop better products that find their places in the global market.
"Taiwan ranks third globally in the amount of patents acquired during 2001 and 2005, but those patents did not always help create lucrative products," Tsai said.
The project, set to reach its goals within the next four years, will oversee the subsidy plans given to prop up the country's university-industry cooperation in the initial stage.
In the second stage, a coordinating platform will be launched to integrate the cooperation, with the MOEA taking an advisory role to upgrade the profitability of Taiwanese inventions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers to abolish defensive referendum

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) plans to cancel the president's power to initiate a defensive referendum by revising the law in the new session of the legislature slated to open Friday, in which it holds a majority, KMT lawmakers said Thursday.

The announcement came after claims that President Chen Shui-bian might resort to a defensive referendum if the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) fail to reach a consensus before Friday on two upcoming referendums supporting the country's bid to join the United Nations.
Friday is the legal deadline for proposing a new referendum.
The DPP recently called on the KMT to support each other's U.N. bid referendums due to concern that the referendums, to be held alongside the March 22 presidential polls, might fail.
The U.N. bid referendums will mark the third time the government has held a referendum, even though neither of the earlier ones passed the threshold of voter interest.
According to the Referendum Act, the passage of a referendum requires votes from a majority of the electorate and for over 50 percent of those ballots to be "yes" votes.
In their referendums, both parties support U.N. membership for the country, but they disagree on what name the country should use in its membership applications.
The DPP-proposed referendum backs using the name Taiwan, while the KMT one advocates use of Republic of China, or another "suitable" name.
Opposing the president's use of a defensive referendum, the KMT lawmakers said the party has listed its own amendment to the Referendum Act as a priority bill.
The amendment, which will abolish an article of the Referendum Act governing the use of defensive referendums, is aimed at barring such a referendum from being "abused," the lawmakers claimed.
The amendment is part of the 59 priority bills that the KMT vowed to pass in the first session of the new 113-seat legislature, according to the lawmakers.

The priority bills will focus on boosting the economy, providing care for the disadvantaged, improving electoral rights, clean politics, legislative reforms, energy saving, government restructuring, educational development and financial reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing Olympics echoes Berlin Olympics: human rights advocates

TEXT.P: Major powers have ignored China's human rights violations in the run up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics, which is reminiscent of what happened before the 1936 Berlin Olympics, human rights advocates said Thursday in an international forum.

"Nazi authorities held high hopes for the 1936 Berlin Olympics, which they saw as an occasion to showcase the so-called German economic miracle and assert Germany's world power status, " said Seweryn Ozdowski, former commissioner of the Commonwealth of Human Rights in Australia.

"The Olympics in China seem to be set in exactly the same mould, " Peter Westmore, chairman of the Australia-based National Civil Council, said on the first day of an international forum on human rights in China and the 2008 Olympics.
The two-day forum was organized by the Coalition to Investigate the persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG) and the Taiwan Culture Foundation.
Another similarity between the two Olympics 64 years apart could be found in major powers' neglect of the host countries repeated human rights violations, the forum participants claimed.

"In 1936, Nazi dictatorship was already well-established, with political executions without trial, censorship of the media, abolition of the freedom of association and the racist Nurnberg Laws," said Ozdowski.
"The Communist Party of China (CPC) has not improved its human rights situation over the past 10 years, " said Michel Wu, former director of the Mandarin service of Radio France International.
"Despite this, the Western democracies have decided to overlook these developments in the name of unity of Olympic spirit, " he said.

While a number of celebrities, including American film director Steven Spielberg, and various non-government organizations have called for a boycott of the Beijing Olympics, most Western countries have decided to participate.

"Many Western governments, including my own, are afraid to offend Beijing, fearing that to raise the issue of human rights in a serious way would jeopardize trade and other links. Businesses, particularly those with subsidiaries in China and including media organizations, also fear offending China, " Westmore said.

"We should take comfort from the fact that just as courageous and far-sighted people opposed the German Olympics in 1936, today we are called on to object to the conducting of the Olympic Games in Beijing in 2008, " he added.

"China should not hold the Olympics. The CPC had no intention from the first to keep the promise that it would improve the human rights situation in China, " said Kan Ando, Japan vice president of CIPFG Asia.

The advocates called for a boycott of the Beijing Olympics as China has failed to fulfill its promise made in 2001 when it won the Olympics hosting bid to improve the human rights situation in China, so that the communist regime will learn a lesson and human rights in China can be protected.
"Let us remember that a boycott of the 1936 Berlin Olympics could have prevented World War II and holocaust, " Ozdowski said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President honors award-winning Web designers

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian honored two Taiwanese Web designers Thursday who won an international competition in the United States last month, and encouraged young people to learn from the winners' creativity, courage and efforts in running their own business.
Chen praised the designers in an article he posted on his e-newsletter Web site.

The award-winning Web site, Atlaspost, was established last April by brothers Jerry and Andy Kuo. It was selected as the jury's favorite along with other 10 projects from foreign teams at the DEMO '08 -- an annual conference that serves as a launch platform for new products, technology and Web sites.

Atlaspost also won the competition's People's Choice Award, which was voted on by over 500 venture companies and more than 100 international media organizations. The award was given to a non-American team for the first time.

It is an innovative map-based social network site that lets users network on a global map. It allows members to upload articles, albums, or other files for sharing, both regionally and globally. Locations of members will be shown on the Web site's map and they can find other members in their neighborhood or far away.
"The Web site is a channel for Taiwanese people to strengthen identification with others and introduce their homeland to the rest of the world," Chen said in the article.
The site already has nearly 200,000 members and many international venture companies have show interest in investing.

Chen said the Kuo brothers confronted financial difficulties in founding the site but eventually succeeded thanks to their efforts and persistence. He encouraged young people to learn from their spirit of achievement and to share their thoughts about Taiwan with other members of the site.
