DOC.HEADLINE: KMT will not rule out reinvestigating `319' shooting

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will not rule out the possibility of re-opening the investigation into the "319" shooting on the eve of the 2004 presidential election that injured President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Thursday.

Wu made the remarks after U.S. forensic expert Henry Lee, who participated in the investigation of the March 19 incident, said a day earlier that the real target of the shooting was the vice president. He had previously suggested in June 2006 that the case should be closed because investigators had exhausted all leads.

Asked to comment on the new development, KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said that all questions regarding further investigation into the shooting should wait until after the March 22 presidential election.
The vice president said Lee's new statement about the incident was unclear and urged him to elaborate. Otherwise, she added, it might affect the result of the election.

The 319 incident occurred when Chen and Lu were shot while campaigning in a jeep in Tainan, southern Taiwan. The opposition believes the shooting was staged to generate sympathy votes for Chen and Lu, enabling them to win a second term by a mere 29,500 votes.
A commission established by the legislature to investigate the incident met strong opposition from the Presidential Office, the Cabinet and other government agencies.

In August 2005, the Tainan Public Prosecutor's Office closed the case after concluding that Chen Yi-hsiung, the lone suspect in the shooting, had apparently committed suicide. Chen, 63, was found drowned in Anping Harbor in Tainan City 10 days after the shooting.
The opposition parties, however, were not convinced and tried to set up a commission through legislation to investigate the incident.

In December 2006, the Council of Grand Justices ruled that some of the articles in the organic statute of the commission were unconstitutional, because they gave the commission the same powers as those of prosecutors.

The opposition legislators amended the statute in early 2007 and a second commission was formed, with its 17 members selected in proportion to the number of seats held by different parties in the legislature.

However, in September 2007, the Grand Justices again ruled that certain clauses in the amended organic statute for the 319 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission were unconstitutional, because the commission should not have been given power to mete out penalties to those under investigation and because the commission should have obtained approval from relevant government agencies when using the services of their employees.

Despite these setbacks during its investigation, the second 319 Shooting Truth Investigation Commission completed two reports in 2006 -- one in August and the second in November -- and called for a review of the shooting.

The first report claimed that based on forensic analysis led by James Chun-i Lee, a professor at National Taiwan University's Graduate Institute of Forensic Medicine, Chen Yi-hsiung did not kill himself but was most likely murdered, because his body -- wrapped in fishing net and found in the harbor -- had been dumped into the water after he died.

The second report overturned one of the conclusions reached by a Criminal Investigation Bureau task force that the two shots fired at the president and vice president came from the same pistol, because one of the two bullet casings found at the scene had an outer caliber measuring 9.1 mm and could not be loaded into the chamber of the 9 mm pistol that police claim was used by the suspect.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's only dog sperm bank soothes dog lover's sorrow

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first and only dog sperm bank has helped soothe a dog lover's sorrow over the death of his beloved dog, a veterinarian at the bank said Thursday.

Years ago, a 50-year-old man brought his paralyzed boxer to the bank and had the dog's sperm stored there, recalled Cheng Feng-bang, who is also a professor at National Chung Hsing University's Veterinary Medicine Teaching Hospital in Taichung City, which runs the sperm bank.
The boxer died a year later.
Two years later, his owner decided to be "reunited" with his dog and sought assistance from the bank, Cheng said.
The bank made his dream come true by breeding two puppies from the sperm through the use of artificial insemination, Cheng said.
The bank, which was established nine years ago, now stores the sperm of 150 dogs.
The bank has also helped breed some rare and valuable species, Cheng said, adding that the bank can also assist dogs with vibriosis problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top security officer to attend Korean president-elect's inauguration

TEXT.P: National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen will attend the inauguration ceremony for South Korean President-elect Lee Myung-bak on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, a Presidential Office source said Friday.
The president decided the day before to assign Tan Sun Chen as his proxy to head a Taiwan delegation that will attend Lee's inauguration slated for Feb. 25 in Seoul, according to the official.

Lee, a former mayor of Seoul and former CEO of the massive Hyundai conglomeration, will be sworn in as South Korea's 17th president and the first "CEO president." As such, he is expected to govern with a management style similar to that of a company head.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmakers to abolish defensive referendum

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) plans to cancel the president's power to initiate a defensive referendum by revising the law in the new session of the legislature slated to open Friday, in which it holds a majority, KMT lawmakers said Thursday.

The announcement came after claims that President Chen Shui-bian might resort to a defensive referendum if the KMT and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) fail to reach a consensus before Friday on two upcoming referendums supporting the country's bid to join the United Nations.
Friday is the legal deadline for proposing a new referendum.
The DPP recently called on the KMT to support each other's U.N. bid referendums due to concern that the referendums, to be held alongside the March 22 presidential polls, might fail.
The U.N. bid referendums will mark the third time the government has held a referendum, even though neither of the earlier ones passed the threshold of voter interest.
According to the Referendum Act, the passage of a referendum requires votes from a majority of the electorate and for over 50 percent of those ballots to be "yes" votes.
In their referendums, both parties support U.N. membership for the country, but they disagree on what name the country should use in its membership applications.
The DPP-proposed referendum backs using the name Taiwan, while the KMT one advocates use of Republic of China, or another "suitable" name.
Opposing the president's use of a defensive referendum, the KMT lawmakers said the party has listed its own amendment to the Referendum Act as a priority bill.
The amendment, which will abolish an article of the Referendum Act governing the use of defensive referendums, is aimed at barring such a referendum from being "abused," the lawmakers claimed.
The amendment is part of the 59 priority bills that the KMT vowed to pass in the first session of the new 113-seat legislature, according to the lawmakers.

The priority bills will focus on boosting the economy, providing care for the disadvantaged, improving electoral rights, clean politics, legislative reforms, energy saving, government restructuring, educational development and financial reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing Olympics echoes Berlin Olympics: human rights advocates

TEXT.P: Major powers have ignored China's human rights violations in the run up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics, which is reminiscent of what happened before the 1936 Berlin Olympics, human rights advocates said Thursday in an international forum.

"Nazi authorities held high hopes for the 1936 Berlin Olympics, which they saw as an occasion to showcase the so-called German economic miracle and assert Germany's world power status, " said Seweryn Ozdowski, former commissioner of the Commonwealth of Human Rights in Australia.

"The Olympics in China seem to be set in exactly the same mould, " Peter Westmore, chairman of the Australia-based National Civil Council, said on the first day of an international forum on human rights in China and the 2008 Olympics.
The two-day forum was organized by the Coalition to Investigate the persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG) and the Taiwan Culture Foundation.
Another similarity between the two Olympics 64 years apart could be found in major powers' neglect of the host countries repeated human rights violations, the forum participants claimed.

"In 1936, Nazi dictatorship was already well-established, with political executions without trial, censorship of the media, abolition of the freedom of association and the racist Nurnberg Laws," said Ozdowski.
"The Communist Party of China (CPC) has not improved its human rights situation over the past 10 years, " said Michel Wu, former director of the Mandarin service of Radio France International.
"Despite this, the Western democracies have decided to overlook these developments in the name of unity of Olympic spirit, " he said.

While a number of celebrities, including American film director Steven Spielberg, and various non-government organizations have called for a boycott of the Beijing Olympics, most Western countries have decided to participate.

"Many Western governments, including my own, are afraid to offend Beijing, fearing that to raise the issue of human rights in a serious way would jeopardize trade and other links. Businesses, particularly those with subsidiaries in China and including media organizations, also fear offending China, " Westmore said.

"We should take comfort from the fact that just as courageous and far-sighted people opposed the German Olympics in 1936, today we are called on to object to the conducting of the Olympic Games in Beijing in 2008, " he added.

"China should not hold the Olympics. The CPC had no intention from the first to keep the promise that it would improve the human rights situation in China, " said Kan Ando, Japan vice president of CIPFG Asia.

The advocates called for a boycott of the Beijing Olympics as China has failed to fulfill its promise made in 2001 when it won the Olympics hosting bid to improve the human rights situation in China, so that the communist regime will learn a lesson and human rights in China can be protected.
"Let us remember that a boycott of the 1936 Berlin Olympics could have prevented World War II and holocaust, " Ozdowski said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 22, or the 16th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: Amerigo Vespucci, Italian navigator and "discoverer" of the South American coast, dies at the age of 58. America was named in his honor.
1732: George Washington, the first U.S. president, is born.
1784: The Empress of China, the first trading ship sent to China from the United States, sets sail from New York.
1788: Arthur Schopenhauer, German philosopher who saw the ideal state of man as one of contemplative freedom achieved through art, is born.
1810: Frederick Chopin, Polish-born French composer and pianist of the romantic era, is born. His music was noted chiefly for its expressiveness.
1857: Robert Baden-Powell, British hero of the siege of Mafeking in the Boer War and founder of the Boy Scouts, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1879: U.S. storekeeper Frank W. Woolworth, thinking centralized purchasing will help keep prices down and profits up, opens the new F.W. Woolworth Co. Five- and-Ten Cent Store in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.
1924: Calvin Coolidge becomes the first U.S. president to broadcast from the White House.
1932: Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1934: Nicaraguan guerrilla leader General Augusto Sandino is executed by his rival, General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1946: Dr. Selman Abrahams announces he has discovered streptomycin, an antibiotic which can be used to treat tuberculosis and bacterial infections.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secret Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1967: U.S. forces and South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1973: Gordon T. Wallis, chairman of the Irving Trust Company of New York, arrives to open a Taipei branch.
1974: Minister of Finance K.T. Li, Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun and Sheik Mohammed Aba Al-Khail, Saudi Arabian minister of finance and national economy, issue a joint communique on financial and economic cooperation.
1979: The Caribbean island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1990: The last statue of Joseph Stalin topples in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia.
1991: U.S. President George Bush gives Saddam Hussein 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war against allied forces.
1993: The Taiwanese film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: Russia and the International Monetary Fund reach a deal on a loan of more than US$10 billion.
1996: The French government announces the abolition of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
2000: Chien Wen-hui successfully receives a piece of his wife's liver in an operation performed at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung, marking the first wife-to-husband live-donor liver transplant ever conducted in Taiwan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian is accused of taking bribes from a Malaysian business tycoon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidate list for presidential election proclaimed

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) formally proclaimed Friday the list of candidates that will take part in the March 22 presidential election.

Two pairs of candidates are vying for the presidency, in the following balloting order: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Frank Hsieh and his running mate, Su Tseng-chang; and the Kuomintang's Ma Ying-jeou and his running mate, Vincent Siew, according to the proclamation.
The official campaign period for the election begins Feb. 23 and runs through March 21, with campaign hours from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. every day, it said.

According to the Presidential and Vice Presidential Election and Recall Act, candidates who allow their campaign activities to continue beyond the designated deadline and cause disturbance to social peace or the life of local residents can be fined up to NT$5 million for each violation.

The number of eligible voters for the election is estimated at more than 17 million, and the CEC is expected to complete compiling the roll of eligible voters by March 2 and proclaim the actual number March 18.

Also Friday, CEC officials reminded the public that release of opinion poll results related to the election will be banned during the last 10 days before the election, adding that reporting, circulation, comment or reference to such results will also be forbidden during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Opposition lawmakers blast arms company

TEXT.P: Legislators from the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) derided Friday the government's justification of a newly established defense company named Taiwan Goal.

Speaking at the first session of the KMT-dominated new legislature, KMT Legislator Wu Ching-chih lashed out at the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration for "secretly" establishing Taiwan Goal late last month with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.75 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million, to handle arms deals worth over NT$150 billion a year.
Wu criticized Premier Chang Chun-hsiung for "not mentioning a word" about Taiwan Goal in his written administrative report expected to be delivered at the Legislative Yuan later that day.

Vice Premier Chiuo I-jen was quoted as having told incumbent and former DPP lawmakers earlier this week that the establishment of Taiwan Goal -- a joint venture between the government and private investors and led by Wu Nai-jen, a stalwart of the DPP's now disbanded New Tide faction -- is mainly aimed at "diversifying the sources of Taiwan's arms procurement."

The KMT legislator claimed that Taiwan Goal -- which is beyond the control of either the Ministry of National Defense (MND) or the legislature -- is an operation using "government funds to benefit a few individuals."

Noting that even MND Armaments Bureau Director Wu Wei-jung had suggested that "it is not appropriate for the ministry to fund a private arms firm, " KMT Legislator Yang Chiung-ying said Taiwan Goal's establishment is "obviously questionable."
Wu Wei-jung made the remarks when he attended a news conference called by Kuo Su-chun, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, two days earlier.

He said that after a cautious overview, he suggested that the plan for the MND to hold a 45 percent stake in the company is unfeasible. "Although the idea of establishing the company is good, the timing is inappropriate because of the March 22 presidential election, which may give rise to misgivings," he said.

KMT Legislator Pan Wei-kang questioned the timing of Taiwan Goal's establishment and claimed that the company is a vehicle through which the Chen Shui-bian administration plans to steal the country's military resources before it bows out in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's inflation rate expected to reach 1.98% for 2008

TEXT.P: Taiwan's inflation rate is projected at a moderate 1.98 percent for 2008, when hikes in international commodity prices are expected to temper slightly, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) forecast Friday.

The wholesale price index (WPI) is expected to increase 2.4 percent this year, following a rise of 6.5 percent in 2007 owing to soaring international oil and commodity prices, said DGBAS Minister Hsu Jan-yau.

The consumer price index (CPI) jumped 1.8 percent last year, impacted by the rise in wholesale prices and storms that hit the island in the second half of the year that sharply boosted food prices, Hsu noted.

He predicted that international commodity prices will continue rising in the first half of this year but calm down slightly in the second half, with oil prices likely to average US$81.5 per barrel this year, compared with the average of US$70 per barrel in 2007.

Against this backdrop, Taiwan's CPI is likely to rise 3 percent in the first half of this year, and the increase is expected to diminish to 1 percent in the second half as prices become more stable, he said.

The Navy hit a failed intelligence satellite speeding 133 miles above the Earth with a three- stage missile on the first try Wednesday, a shot the Pentagon hopes destroyed the spacecraft's fuel tank filled with 1,000 pounds of potentially toxic gas. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: It's Singapore 2010.
The news that Singapore waited over seven months for came at precisely 7.11pm yesterday, broadcast live via satellite link from Lausanne in Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: International forum urges China to improve human rights

TEXT.P: An international forum titled Human Rights in China and the 2008 Olympics issued a statement Friday urging all governments and human rights organizations to "take action to prevent Chinese human rights violations and to work for a liberated, democratic and free China."
The delegates at the forum also condemned the Communist Party of China "for exporting abroad its violations of human rights, undermining moral values and endangering world security."
The two-day forum, which ended Friday in Taipei, was aimed at pressing China to improve its human rights record before the 2008 Beijing Olympics scheduled to open Aug. 8.

In the statement, the delegates called for support for a "global human rights torch relay " and announced the launch of a human rights torch relay into China in order to denounce the Beijing Olympics in return for better human rights in China.

The forum also concluded that the government of China has violated the commitment it made to improve its human rights record before the Olympics and that the human rights situation in China has deteriorated since Beijing was awarded the Olympics.
The statement said that unless the government of China stops immediately its grave human rights violations, leaders and delegates from all nations should boycott the Olympics.

The forum was organized by the Coalition to Investigate the Persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG) and the Taiwan Culture Foundation, with delegates from a wide variety of professions from around the globe, including politicians, lawyers, academics and human rights activists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 government fiscal deficit falls to NT$30 billion

TEXT.P: The central government's fiscal deficit dropped to NT$30 billion (US$960 million) in 2007, thanks to a 5.7 percent economic growth rate and an increase in tax revenue, Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Director-General Hsu Jan-yau said Friday.
In 2007, Taiwanese companies enjoyed earnings growth and the government registered an increase in overall tax revenue as a result of the country's stable economic growth, according to Hsu.

The total tax revenue totalled NT$1.7 trillion in 2007, surpassing the budgeted level by NT$120 billion, with the central government seeing an increase of NT$90 billion in tax revenue, Hsu said, adding that the increase has been reflected in the narrowing of the fiscal deficit.

According to preliminary calculations, the overall budget surplus for 2007 amounted to nearly NT$70 billion. While taking the special budget deficit into account, the central government's fiscal deficit stood at NT$30 billion, a whopping decrease compared with the deficit of NT314.7 billion recorded in 2003, Hsu added.
The figures signify a big step toward the government's goal of balancing the budget by 2011 tanks to its success in controlling budget and expenditure, Hsu claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate pledges NT$5 billion fund to boost cultural profile

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that he will launch an NT$5 billion (US$159.74 million) cultural diplomacy fund if elected president to elevate the country's profile and make culture the center of its soft power.

Ma said that along with the NT$5 billion (US$156.3 million) fund, he would establish a Taiwan award, an equivalent of the Nobel literary award for Chinese around the world, and provide pensions to creative artists.

At a meeting with 13 influential figures from local performing arts circles, including stage director Stan Lai and performer Chao Chih-chiang, to hear their views on cultural policy, Ma also proposed forming a Taiwan academy to counter a similar Chinese institute.

China's Confucius Academy, which addresses the needs of foreigners who want to learn Chinese language and culture, has branched out around the world in recent years as a cultural ambassador for the country.

The KMT candidate insisted that his pledges were not just "election language" and that he would deliver on them to make culture the foundation of Taiwan's soft power and substantially upgrade its profile.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices slightly higher on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were slightly higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.78 points, or 0.28 percent, to close at 8,108.71.

Rising for the second consecutive day, the bourse opened at 8,013.35 and fluctuated between 8,108.71 and 7,986.97 during the day's session. A total of 4.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$131.21 billion (US$4.19 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground. Construction issues advanced the most, by 2.2 percent. Banking and financial shares rose 1.1 percent, textile stocks increased 0.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares and foodstuff issues both gained 0.3 percent and machinery and electronics shares were up 0.1 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks dropping 0.7 percent and paper and pulp issues decreasing 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 989 to 856, with 399 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up nine points to close at 8,036, with 52,384 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 12 points to finish at 8,021, with 212 contracts traded, while June futures increased 31 points to close at 8,010, with 16 contract transactions.
September futures gained 10 points to finish at 7,790, with 23 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 18 points to close at 7,759, with 52 contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 22.78 points Friday to finish at 8,108.71 on turnover of NT$131.21 billion (US$4.16 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,027 for March; 8,009 for April; 7,979 for June; 7,780 for September and 7,777 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

March TE futures lost 0.7 point to close at 306.8, with 5,762 contracts traded, while April TE futures dropped 1.1 points to finish at 305.6, with 26 contract exchanges. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

March TF futures moved up 16.6 points to close at 1,059, with 4,304 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures rose 11 points to finish at 1,055, with 11 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: Excessive carbon monoxide detected at half of restaurants: survey

TEXT.P: Half of the restaurants tested in a recent Consumers' Foundation survey were found to have excessive levels of carbon monoxide, pointing to the need for making the installation of carbon monoxide detectors in restaurants compulsory, foundation officials said Friday.

The foundation tested 20 restaurants in Taipei City for three minutes each, and discovered that carbon monoxide concentrations at 10 of them averaged more than the 9 ppm limit set in Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) guidelines, the officials said.
Two restaurants, which were 90 percent occupied at the time of the test, registered average carbon monoxide concentrations of 103 ppm and 70.9 ppm, respectively, they said.

Foundation Chairman Cheng Jen-hung, referring to guidelines released in December 2005 by the EPA on indoor air quality, said the concentration of carbon monoxide at public and commercial establishments should not average more than 9 ppm during an uninterrupted eight-hour monitoring period.
Although the tests conducted by the foundation ran less than eight hours, the results indicate there is much room for improvement in the air quality of restaurants, Cheng said.
Carbon monoxide is a colorless, odorless gas produced by burning material containing carbon, such as propane gas, oil, kerosene, wood and charcoal.
Carbon monoxide poisoning in restaurants has received national attention after 27 customers were poisoned last week in Taoyuan County hot pot restaurant that used charcoal heaters.
The incident prompted calls for the government to mandate the installation of carbon detection monitors in all restaurants.

According to the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, people can be impaired at work if they are exposed to an environment where the carbon monoxide concentration reaches 50 ppm for 1.5-4 hours.
They can get a severe headache if the concentration reaches 200 ppm and feel weak and dizzy if the concentration increases to 400 ppm.
A concentration of 1,200 ppm can cause the heartbeat rate to increase and become irregular, and a concentration of 2,000 ppm or higher can result in a loss of consciousness and death.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.026 to close at NT$31.495.
A total of US$1.25 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$31.530 and hit a low of NT$31.300.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Fraud probe clears South Korea's Lee
A special prosecutor Thursday cleared South Korea's incoming President Lee Myung Bak of fraud allegations, bolstering his authority before he takes office next week.
