DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Rescues for Homeowners in Debt Weighed
Prodded in part by some of the nation's biggest banks, the Bush administration and Congress are considering costly new proposals for the government to rescue hundreds of thousands of homeowners whose mortgages are higher than the value of their houses.
The Wall Street Journal:Clinton Jabs at Obama On Speeches, Health Care
With the fate of her presidential campaign on the line, Hillary Clinton used one of the most anticipated debates of the primary season to take some shots at Democratic front-runner Barack Obama for both his speeches and his health-care policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Unrest in Belgrade, U.S. embassy blazed, one killed.
Angered by western support for Kosovo's independence, Serbian protesters attacked embassies of several nations in Belgrade and set fire to the United States embassy following a peaceful rally in protest against Kosovo's secession. A unidentified burnt body was found in the blazed U.S. embassy after the attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government denies intervening in foreign media interviews

TEXT.P: Two government agencies categorically denied Friday intervening in the operations of foreign media outlets by feeding them questions to put opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou on the spot during interviews.

Both the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and the Government Information Office (GIO) denied they have offered to "help" several European media outlets in preparing questions so that the European interviewers give KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou a hard time when interviewing him.

The MOFA and the GIO issued the denials in response to a report by the Taipei- based Chinese-language China Times Friday. According to the report, Ma's camp has questioned whether the agencies have assisted European media outlets, including French quarterly Politique Internationale and television station Euro News, in preparing "hard" questions for Ma for interviews to be conducted prior to the March 22 presidential election.

MOFA spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh dismissed the China Times report, saying that the foreign ministry could not possibly intervene in the content of interviews conducted by foreign media. Yeh said the foreign ministry regretted what it called the daily's unfounded and irresponsible allegation.

According to Yeh, Prof. Stephane Corcuff with the University of Lyon in France and his research team will interview both Ma and ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh later this month.
The interviews will be incorporated in their analysis of Taiwan's upcoming presidential election to be carried in Politique Internationale in March.
Corcuff will conduct the interviews with Ma and Hsieh through written questions that will first be sent to the MOFA and then forwarded to the two candidates' offices, Yeh said.

The spokeswoman added that as far as she knows, the questions expected to be asked by Corcuff and his researchers will all be "sharp" and "hard to deal with, " regardless of whether they are directed toward Ma or Hsieh.
Meanwhile, GIO Minister Shieh Jhy-wey defended his office's invitation of major international media outlets to cover news regarding the upcoming presidential election and candidates.
Shieh said Euro News has prepared many questions for Ma and Hsieh, questions that are sharp, down-to-earth and that could "pierce through to the truth with a single pertinent remark."

Saying that it is impossible for the GIO to "direct" European media in the preparation of questions for any Taiwan presidential candidate, Shieh contended that any politician would be arrogant if he considered his interviewers to be "opposed" to him if they asked him critical questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Obama-Clinton Debate Starts Warm, Heats Up
Sens. Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama disagreed sharply on how to achieve universal health care, debated about which of them is most ready to serve as commander in chief and argued over who can best change the country as they appealed for support Thursday ahead of showdown primaries in Texas and Ohio.
The Washington Times:Energy costs top money worries
Mortgages are making headlines and record numbers of homes are in foreclosure, but it's high energy prices that really bother consumers. It's the top problem people cite when asked what is wrong with the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: New fishing ground for sakura shrimp found off eastern Taiwan

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Research Institute under the Council of Agriculture (COA) has discovered a new fishing ground off Gueishan Island rich in two kinds of shrimp popular in local cuisine, an institute official said Friday.

Wu Chi-lun, head of the institute's Marine Fisheries Division, said the agency discovered the fishing ground for sakura and Japanese glass shrimp after approximately five years of fishing trials in the area, just off the coast of Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan.
Wu declined, however, to disclose the size of the fishing ground's stocks of the planktonic shrimp to prevent overfishing and damage to the biological environment in the area.
During their trials, he said, institute trawlers caught more Japanese glass shrimp than sakura shrimp in spring and summer while sakura shrimp dominated the catches in autumn and winter.
The thin-shelled sakura shrimp are rich in calcium that can be absorbed directly by the body.

Wu said the institute has completed research on the shrimps' biological characteristics, including their breeding patterns. Based on the research results, along with other research on planktonic shrimp found in Taiwan's waters, the COA will outline a long-term research program aimed at developing sustainable fishing in the waters, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL unveils list of top 10 bizarre cargoes

TEXT.P: A shipment of Planning documents weighing 7.56 tons has been selected one of the 10 most bizarre items shipped from Taiwan by the international courier firm DHL in 2007, officials at the company's Taiwan branch said Friday.
The shipment of documents was the company's heaviest item handled from Taiwan, while a chip resistor weighing only 0.0001 grams was the lightest, according to the company.

In terms of volume, the largest item handled was a steel rail measuring 365 centimeters long, 25 cm wide and 26 cm high, while the smallest shipment was also a chip resistor measuring only 1 cubic millimeter.

Also on the 2007 list of the top-10 bizarre shipments from Taiwan were a doll that resembled a real person in size, a copper propeller intended for use by a container vessel, a big drum designed for the "Taiko: Drum Master" drumming game, and a delicate U-shaped garden rocking chair.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi Hospital to try out umbilical cord stem cell therapy

TEXT.P: The Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital announced Friday that the hospital is to solicit volunteers willing to participate in a stem cell therapy trial project using umbilical cord blood for patients with spinal cord injuries.

Chen Tze-yung, vice president of Tzu Chi hospital's Taichung branch who heads the project, said the trial therapy project is intending to solicit 80 volunteers from March 1 to June 30 for the first observation stage of the project.

As the research efforts in spinal cord therapy made by Tzu Chi hospitals for the past years have gained recognition from both domestic and foreign medical institutions, the hospital has obtained money from sponsors from the United States, Hong Kong and China for this project, Chen said.
According to Chen, the project will be implemented at the hospital's headquarters in Hualien, and its branches in Taichung, Chiayi and Taipei.
"The project is to find a new possibility for the therapy for many patients with injuries to their spinal cords in Taiwan, " Chen stressed.

As the project is in its "observation stage", it will not involve any invasive examinations or treatments and will not require the patients to stop their regular treatments, Chen said, adding that it will only collect and register the information of the patients free of charge.

According to Chen, the volunteers should satisfy the following conditions: They should be aged between 16 and 65, diagnosed by medical doctors as patients having spinal cord injury, without serious brain damage, mentally stable, and not participating in other experimental treatments.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGUS aircraft did use British base to transport terrorist suspects
British facilities were used by the US to transport terrorist suspects at least twice, despite repeated government denials V including by Tony Blair - that the UK had any involvement in extraordinary rendition flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Speaker to respect decision by lawmakers on broadcasting content

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that he will respect the decision by lawmakers regarding the content of live broadcasting of legislative proceedings over the Internet, and that he will not "interfere with it."

Wang was responding to criticism a day earlier by Citizen Congress Watch, a private watchdog group dedicated to supervising the lawmaking body, that although Wang gave consent to have legislative floor meetings broadcast live, he did not promise similar transparency for other legislative proceedings, such as committee meetings and cross-party caucus negotiations.

The group noted that the public is entitled to know the details of legislative proceedings, given the fact that the new legislature is streamlined by half from the previous legislature and that the present 113 members will determine the fate of many important bills.
Wang said that he had never stated that he had "only agreed to broadcast legislative floor meetings," and he had no idea why the watchdog group leveled the criticism against him.
"I have no set views on the content of the broadcast," Wang said, adding that he "will fully respect the decision of the lawmakers."
He also said that the legislature will soon send a delegation abroad to observe the parliamentary broadcasting systems of other countries.
The lawmakers will mainly view the systems in the United States and Japan since their committees are similar to Taiwan's, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nutritionists offer tips on trimming down after New Year's feasts

TEXT.P: A hospital nutritionist offered four simple tips Thursday to people looking to shed some kilos after eating plenty of rich food during the Chinese New Year holiday.
Thursday's Lantern Festival marked the conclusion of New Year's celebrations, and many are looking to reduce waistlines that expanded with the holiday's festivities.

Most Taiwanese tend to indulge in foods that are unhealthy during Chinese New Year feasts -- including watermelon seeds, cashew nuts, sweet cakes, preserved fruit, coke, soda, fried fish, meat dumplings and processed dumplings thrown into hot pots.

Because many of these treats are high in calories, people should stop eating them if they want to lose weight, according to Chen Cheng-yu, a nutritionist at the Buddhist Tzu Chi General Hospital in Taipei.
Chen also suggested that people should eat less at dinner, avoid eating and drinking too much at one meal, and never eat immediately after exercising.
Other nutritionists suggested that people looking to lose weight should exercise more.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan and U.S. new leaders should talk: scholar

TEXT.P: The new presidents of Taiwan and the United States should sit down for face-to- face talks while the head of state of Taiwan should tone down the rhetoric regarding independence, a U.S. scholar suggested Wednesday in Taipei.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Herbert London, an American conservative activist boldly predicted that Ma Ying-jeou, presidential candidate of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , and John McCain, front-runner for the Republican nomination in the 2008 U.S. presidential election, would become the new heads of state of Taiwan and the U.S., respectively, and said if he were to provide advice to McCain, he would recommend that he should "do something George Bush is not willing to do-- that is to sit down with Mr. Ma."

London, the president of the Washington-based Hudson Institute, added that whether Frank Hsieh, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), or Ma Ying-jeou, candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), becomes the new president, "many refined statements about independence will be much more low-key than it's been under Mr. Chen."

The new U.S. president should "lay out the American position clear, to encourage Mr. Ma to do everything he can to lower the level of rhetoric, to understand the American position vis-a-vis China, and also understand that time may very much be on Taiwan's side, " he said.

Speaking of the criticism toward President Chen Shui-bian's hard-line stance on the issue of national identity and sovereignty, London said maybe Chen pushed a little harder than desired, at least from the America's perspective.

"But what he recognizes is a sentiment that goes very deep into the culture of Taiwan at the moment, and that is the desire to express independence even though it is 'de facto independence' not 'independence de jure'," he added.

The DPP's initiation of the referendum to join the United Nations under the name of Taiwan to be held with the March 22 presidential election not only angered China but also ruffled relations between Taiwan and the U.S.

As to whether the Beijing Olympics will stir up nationalism in China to an even higher level, London said the ethnic tide in China cannot be overlooked but the Olympics is "really a gloss over the real China."

"I don't think the Olympics will have the effect that the Chinese government is looking for, which is to display the strides that have been made in China. Instead, people will see that this is all facade, like the 'Potemkin village' in the former Soviet Union," he said.
London arrived in Taipei Feb. 19 for the first time to observe the run-up to Taiwan's presidential election as well as the island's political and economic situations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to continue 'one policy per week' governance

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that his "one policy per week" drive to improve Taiwan's economy and cross-Taiwan Strait relations would continue as long as he is in office.

In his administrative report delivered on the opening day of the new Legislative Yuan's first session, Chang said the Cabinet under his leadership will continue to push forward in a number of areas using the "one policy per week" campaign.

They included building "complete social networks" around the country, developing the economy in a way that would not compromise the environment, narrowing gaps between urban and rural areas, and improving cross-strait relations and Taiwan's ties with the international community.

Chang said his administrative team will do its best in the coming months to realize development projects, put ideals of justice and fairness into practice, and adhere to a Taiwan-centric political line to help secure sustainable development for the country.
He said that under the principle of a "Taiwan centric line, " the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration would continue to build on past efforts to push for closer cross-strait exchanges.

The DPP administration initiated in early 2007 the "mini three links" to allow Taiwanese businessmen to travel to China or return to Taiwan via the Taiwan-held islands of Kinmen and Matsu, Chang said.

It had also implemented a series of measures to facilitate two-way trade, fund remittance and direct charter flight services between Taiwan and China on major festivals over the past seven years, he said.

Chang noted that despite Taiwan's good will, Beijing has obstinately stuck to the "one China" policy when dealing with cross-strait issues and continued to step up its military intimidation and political attacks directed at Taiwan.

The premier expressed his hope that Beijing perceive the truth that Taiwan is an independent country that has never been ruled by China for a single day and that Beijing handle the cross-strait issue in a positive and constructive manner.

He hoped that trust and closer contacts could be developed across the Taiwan Strait in place of misunderstanding and suppression, saying that "win win" situations could be created when the two sides pragmatically engage in dialogue based on good will and sincerity.
Chang said that over the past several years, the DPP administration has completed many important tasks in the face of adversity and challenges from within the country and abroad.

Those tasks, he said, included the legislation of an act governing referendums and the holding of two referendums, in March 2004 and in January 2008, respectively; the establishment of the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation and the National 228 Memorial Hall; and adding the word "Taiwan" to all new Republic of China passports issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three NCC commissioners tender resignations

TEXT.P: Three members of the National Communications Commission (NCC), the country's media regulator, have tendered their resignations to the Executive Yuan, the commission's vice chairman, Howard Shyr, said Thursday.

The three commissioners -- Liu Yu-li, Lin Tung-tai, and Hsieh Chin-nan -- submitted their resignations before the Chinese New Year and are expected to leave before the beginning of March. Shyr said the three hoped to return to academia.
Only Liu's resignation has been approved so far, but she still must complete the necessary administrative procedures before she can leave, Shyr said.
Once the three leave, the commission will only have six members remaining, including Chairman Su Yeong-chin and Vice Chairman Shyr.

All of the members had pledged to step down Jan. 31 together with the sixth Legislative Yuan after the Justices of the Constitutional Court ruled last July that the way the NCC was formed violated the Constitution.

The constitutional arbiter found that having the members recommended by major political parties in proportion to the number of seats they held in the legislature infringed upon the power of the administrative branch.
As a result of the court's ruling, the government amended the commission's Organic Law last December to have the premier nominate the commissioners and then have the legislature confirm them.

According to the revised statute, the Cabinet should have presented a list of commissioner nominees to the legislature for confirmation by Jan. 31, but the plan was upset when the Cabinet, led by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, resigned en masse Jan. 24, four days ahead of schedule.

With the process to name new commissioners delayed, NCC Chairman Su backed down on the pledge to resign and expressed the hope on Jan. 31 that the body could maintain its normal operations until new members could assume their posts.

Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy-wey said Feb. 12 that the Executive Yuan would deliver the list of candidates for the commission to the seventh Legislative Yuan before it began Feb. 22.
But Legislative Yuan Secretariat Director-General Chuang Li-chen said that as of Friday afternoon, the list had not yet been received.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate vows to defend national sovereignty

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he will issue a statement strongly defending Taiwan's national sovereignty on the third anniversary of China's anti-secession law.

Speaking to KMT lawmakers at a seminar organized by the party's think tank, Ma said that he would like to invite 18 KMT mayors and magistrates as well as KMT lawmakers to issue a joint statement March 14 to help local people better understand the KMT's policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
In the statement, Ma is expected to stress that there is "only Taiwan's interest as the bottom line, and no red lines from foreign governments," Ma's aides said.
Ma had voiced his opposition immediately after Beijing introduced its anti- secession law targeting Taiwan, KMT Secretary-General Wu Den-yih said.

For this reason, Ma will not be affected by any attempts by the KMT's rival, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , to manipulate cross-strait issues in favor of the DPP to win the March 22 polls, he added.
The KMT is widely seen as supporting closer ties with Beijing than the DPP, which claims that the KMT seeks ultimate unification with China.
Ma is expected to say in the statement that China has no right to unilaterally decide Taiwan's future, Ma's aides said.

Ma will also stress that the people of Taiwan will not accept any country, including those that are friendly toward Taiwan, to make any move that will harm Taiwan's sovereignty, interests, and dignity.

In addition, Ma will stick to his stance and say that China made a mistake in enacting the anti-secession law, and that only when Beijing stops denying Taiwan's sovereignty will there be the possibility for cross-strait peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower could lose NT$100 billion this year: economics minister

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) could lose nearly NT$100 billion (US$3.17 billion) this year in a worst-case scenario, Economic Affairs Minister Steve R. L. Chen said Friday at a legislative hearing.

Fielding questions from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Ting Shou-chung, Chen said that based on the fluctuating cost of fuel, the ministry initially estimated Taipower's losses in 2008 at between NT$40 billion and NT$50 billion, after the company lost NT$31.24 billion in 2007.

But with the price of crude oil topping US$100 per barrel, and China's demand for coal rising in the wake of its worst snowstorms in half a century, the losses could be nearly NT$100 billion under the worst-case scenario, Chen said.

During his questioning of Chen, Ting attributed Taipower's losses in 2007 to the limited amount of power provided by nuclear energy. According to information provided by Taipower, the legislator said, nuclear energy is the cheapest method of power generation, but it accounted for only 38.3 billion kilowatt hours, or 20 percent, of the company's total power generation in 2007.

According to the MOEA, Taipower was the only one out of six state-owned enterprises under its supervision to lose money in 2007, mainly because it could not raise electricity rates as part of the government's policy to stabilize commodity prices despite surging crude oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan group in Japan to promote safe agricultural products

TEXT.P: A delegation from Taiwan promoted the country's high-quality agricultural products in Tokyo Friday, hoping to expand their share of the Japanese market.

The group was in Japan to capitalize on mounting fears among Japanese consumers and supermarkets that food imported from China is unsafe, prompted by a recent case of dumplings from China found to be tainted with toxic pesticides.
China is Japan's largest source of food imports, but with its reputation tainted, Japanese buyers have been forced to look in other directions, and Taiwan is hoping to benefit.

At a press conference in Tokyo, TAITRA Deputy Secretary-General Yeh Ming-shui underlined Taiwan's efforts in making safe and healthy food, citing Taiwan's mango exports to Japan that set a record high of 787 metric tons in 2007 after passing stricter pesticide-free tests in Japan.
"The figure also represented 83 percent-growth over the previous year," Yeh said.
The TAITRA official noted that Japan is already one of Taiwan's most important export markets, with the value of agricultural and livestock exports to Japan reaching US$850 million in 2007.
"Among Taiwan's 30 major agricultural export products, 11 are usually targeted at the Japanese market," Yeh said.
Meanwhile, Japan's agricultural exports to Taiwan totaled US$704 million last year, trailing only those of the United States and China.
"There is still plenty of room for both countries to boost their mutual trade in agricultural products, " Yeh stressed.

According to Yeh, Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA) has established a Taiwan Product Center in both Tokyo and Yokohama to promote goods imported from Taiwan, and plans to hold six Taiwan Fairs this year to boost the sales of Taiwan-made fruits, meat and processed products.

In addition, the TAITRA plans to invite several major Japanese food importers to visit Taiwan this year to gain a better understanding of the operations of Taiwanese factories, Yeh said. He called on Japanese entrepreneurs to adopt a more open attitude toward Taiwan's agricultural produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECCT encourages Taiwan to embrace international tourism approach

TEXT.P: A tourism policy developed from an international perspective could help improve the quaility of touring Taiwan, said Philippe Pellegrin, chairman of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) at a recent roundtable discussion with high-ranking Taiwan officials.

He suggested that Taiwan embrace the experience of professional travel agencies overseas to combine popular landmarks with cultural resources and offer international tourists a unique visit infused with local cultural flavor.

"For instance, the National Palace Museum, with the stored historical treasures, should be included in a package tour along with local gourmet cuisines and trade shows, " Pellegrin said at the forum organized by the Council of Economic Planning and Development.
Noting that tourism is an industry that caters to international customers, he said tour packages for high-spending foreign businessmen should present a comprehensive view of the island.
"Performances at the National Concert Hall should be showcased during the tour," he said.
Pellegrin called for trade show organizers to improve hotel booking services to persuade more foreign trade show participants to see some of the beautiful island on business trips.
To develop tourism on a long-term basis, he recommended that the government should place greater emphasis on attracting high-end overseas visitors.

CEPD Vice Chairman Thomas Yeh acknowledged that Taiwan's economy relied heavily on visitors from overseas and said the government plans to invest NT$1 billion (US$31 million) in a program to boost tourism and attract 4 million visitors to the country.
Some 3.7 million visitors arrived in Taiwan in 2007.
"But the declining world economy might force us to explore our domestic market, which is associated with our tourism environment, " Yeh said.

The NT$1 billion program, the brainchild of the Tourism Bureau, was launched Feb.15. and includes a wide range of events and activities to enable international visitors to familiarize themselves with local culture and customs and enjoy Taiwan's natural beauty.

Referring to the tourist industry as a "cultural export, " Yeh said the key to a prosperous tourism industry was integrating the old with the new, a strategy that has brought successes to tourism in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO launches Web site on information related to presidential election

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) said Friday that it had launched a Web site (http: //www.gio.gov.tw/elect2008/) to provide information related to the March 22 presidential election.

GIO officials said that in a departure from the past practice by relying on Taiwan's overseas offices to publicize the presidential election, it has established a communication platform for international media by allowing them to register directly via the Internet.

The GIO is hoping to learn the actual needs of the international media and provide them with the best service, the officials added, saying that it welcomes international media to cover the election and witness the development of its democratic politics.

The Web site provides reference material and information prior to their arrivals in Taiwan to cover the election, and introduces them to services that will be available at the international press center set up by the GIO, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Human rights group plans alternative Olympic torch relay into China

TEXT.P: An international human rights torch relay that seeks to end all human rights abuses in China will make its way into the Olympic host country through text messages, flying balloons and e-mails, a human rights group announced Friday.

Launched by the Coalition to Investigate the Persecution of Falun Gong in China (CIPFG) , the international relay has traveled to 26 countries and 80 cities around the world since the torch was lit in Athens, Greece on Aug.9, 2007.
The group has now decided to take it one step further by entering China.

"At this crucial time when the eyes of the world are on Beijing and in response to the strong demand by the Chinese people to further expose the tyranny of the CCP and to improve the increasingly poor human rights situation in China, the 'Human Rights Torch' will enter mainland China at the end of March 2008, " it said in a statement.

It called for all Chinese who are against dictatorship and for the pursuit of freedom to participate in an alternative and creative form of torch relay from the end of March to the end of the Olympic Games in August.

Considering the safety of the participants, the China leg of the torch relay will not be a traditional run. Instead, participants can distribute a relay logo through e-mails, text messages, e-cards, and blog entries.
They can also hand out T-shirts or baseball caps printed with the slogan "The same world, the same human rights" on them, or play the relay's theme song using multimedia devices in public spaces.
Participants can also write messages on bills, important buildings and facilities, and even a flying balloon.

CIPFG, the main organizer of a two-day international forum on the human rights situation in China and the 2008 Olympics, also released a joint statement Friday, urging the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to request the host Chinese Olympic National Committee to adhere to the Fundamental Principles of Olympism and ensure respect for equal rights for all to participate in the 2008 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president urges de-linking referendums from presidential vote

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui appealed Friday for the de-linking of the March 22 presidential election and two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid that will be held on the same day.

"A failure to adequately handle the two referendums will cause the international community to misinterpret the strong desire of Taiwan's people to take part in the United Nations, and it will in turn cause irreversible damage to the country, " Lee told reporters before he was to give a speech to a group of Japanese CEOs at a hotel.
Lee warned that if the two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. bid are not approved by the people, it would bring "extreme danger to the country."

He called on all political party leaders and presidential candidates to put aside their differences and seek a solution to the thorny issue as soon as possible for the sake of Taiwan's future, while suggesting that "it would be best to hold the referendums at a later date."
Lee also questioned the logic of proposing a referendum on joining the United Nations without any certainty of international support.
"If the international community isn't in favor of it, why pursue it?" he asked.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have each initiated a referendum regarding Taiwan's pursuit of U.N. membership. The two referendums will be held alongside the presidential election.

The DPP-initiated question asks voters if they support joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," while the KMT-initiated question asks voters if they support re-entry to the world body under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.
Both China and the United States have voiced objections to the DPP's referendum initiative, which they described as a move toward Taiwan's independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA groups to sell solar power industry overseas

TEXT.P: In view of Taiwan's fast-growing solar opto-electricity industry, the semi- official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will lead groups to promote the domestic industry at exhibitions overseas, TAITRA said Friday.
According to a TAITRA statement, TAITRA will organize several delegations to take part in expositions in Japan, Germany, Spain and the United States this year.
First, a mission composed of 14 top Taiwan companies will take part in Japan's PV EXPO 2008, which will open Feb. 27 in Tokyo, TAITRA said. It will be Japan's first exhibition of its kind, it added.

A second delegation comprising 23 Taiwan businesses, meanwhile, is slated to exhibit their latest and advanced products at Intersolar -- the largest European solar technology fair -- to be held in June in Freiburg, Germany.

According to TAITRA, the EU PVSEC (European Photovoltaic Solar Energy Conference and Exhibition) , scheduled to be held from Sept. 1-5 in Valencia, Spain, and the Solar Power Conference & EXPO 2008 that will kick off from Oct. 13-16 in San Diego, California will also attract Taiwan's professional elites to stage their products.

Apart from these groups, a TAITRA organized group will visit France for the same purpose, while another delegation to will travel to Greece, which provides good access to Taiwanese enterprises keen on exploring the emerging market in eastern Europe, according to the statement.

The solar opto-electricity industry has grown rapidly to become a potential business in Taiwan capable of creating an annual production value of over NT$1 trillion (US$31.75 billion), statistics showed.
The domestic industry posted an output of NT$40 billion in 2007 -- almost double the 2006 figure of NT$21.2 billion. In 2005, its annual production value was only NT$7 billion.
Last year, 24 new corporations started their business in the industry by funneling NT$15 billion -- a large jump from NT$4.1 billion invested by eight new companies in 2006.
In 2005, only five new companies kicked off business in the industry, with a combined investment funds of NT$1.6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: China criticized for blocking tourists from visiting Taiwan

TEXT.P: A high-ranking official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) criticized China Friday for blocking its citizens from visiting Taiwan on a luxury ocean liner less than two weeks after 659 Chinese nationals made the trip.

MAC spokesman Liu Te-hsun condemned China after local travel agents confirmed that the Chinese who planned to visit Taiwan in late February aboard the British-registered ocean liner "Rhapsody of the Seas" canceled their applications.
The travel agents speculated it was due to Chinese obstruction.

A total of 659 Chinese tourists arrived at the northern Taiwan port of Keelung on the luxury ocean liner Feb. 11, after the Cabinet-level MAC relaxed local regulations to allow the entry of Chinese nationals on ships from ports outside China.
It was the largest Chinese tour group ever to visit the island.

With local travel agencies hoping to benefit from the relaxed government policy toward China, the fate of the second trip of the cruise liner from Hong Kong to Taiwan via Okinawa remained unknown because of the cancellation of the Chinese passengers.
Liu also confirmed that several profesional groups from China, including those intending to observe Taiwan's upcoming presidential elections, recently withdrew their applications to visit Taiwan.
Liu urged Chinese authorities not to intervene in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, stressing that elections are regular and normal political activities in a democratic society.
"It is also still uncertain whether a Chinese delegation intending to arrive in Taiwan Feb. 25 to learn more about Taiwan's real estate market will arrive," Liu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Abnormal cold weather wreaks havoc on Penghu's fishery industry

TEXT.P: The abnormal cold spell of the past several weeks has devastated the fishery industry of the Penghu island chain to such a serious extent that it might take years before the industry can fully recover.

The subtropical Penghu island group, also known as the Pescadores, is located about 50 kilometers west of Taiwan proper. The archipelago consists of 90 islands, of which only 19 are inhabited. The area is rich in fishery resources and has been termed a "paradise for scuba divers."

The recent cold weather, with temperatures dipping to below 9 degrees Celsius, has caused massive damage to both the marine ecology in Penghu's coastal waters and the local net cage fish farming industry.

During a beach cleaning campaign led by Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa, county government officials and local residents removed nearly 50 metric tons of fish carcasses from the beaches of Penghu's inhabited islands.

Members of the Penghu Scuba Diving Association who examined the coastal waters around Makung Island, the largest island in the archipelago, delivered a more shocking finding -- there were probably 10 times as many dead fish lying on the bottom of the sea.

Association President Cheng Cheng-kang and two other divers said they saw large numbers of many species of dead fish as they swam around the coastal waters, and that some of the carcasses had already began to rot.

Cheng said he is worried that as the weather gets warmer, the high nutrient levels in the water would cause algal blooms, which could lead to a red tide, with the toxins from the algae contaminating marine lives and posing a hazard to human health.

Tsai Wann-sheng, director of the Penghu Fisheries Research Institute, described the damage to Penghu's fishery industry as "the worst in 30 years." He said the recent cold weather -- unseen since 1978 -- might have seriously affected some 300 fish species.

With the real potential for a red tide, Tsai urged Environmental Protection Bureau officials to monitor the quality of sea water around Penghu's coasts closely and take necessary precautionary measures to prevent algal blooms.

Chen Ying-nan, chairman of the Department of Aquaculture at National Penghu University, said the adverse impact on Penghu's marine ecology will be foreseeable in the next couple of years, although the exact degree of the impact cannot be assessed yet.
"We expect the currents of the ocean to use the power of nature to repair itself," he said.

Meanwhile, statistics compiled by the Penghu county government show that the cold spell killed more than 1,500 metric tons, or over 80 percent, of the fish yields in the county's net cage fish farms, with the losses totaling over NT$180 million (US$5.75 million) . Cobia, a high-value cage culture species, suffered the heaviest losses. If shell fish is included, the total damage will exceed 3,000 metric tons.

At a briefing to Vice President Annette Lu on how to cope with the aftermath of the disaster, Cheng Ming-yuan, director of the Penghu county government's Agriculture and Fisheries Bureau, estimated that the county government would need NT$178 million to help revive Penghu's net cage fish farming industry and NT$58 million to fund marine conservation programs to allow the release of large amounts of young fish of all kinds into the ocean.
According to Chen, another NT$167 million is needed to provide natural disaster relief and low-interest emergency loans to fish farmers in order to help them get back on their feet.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmaker calls for onion import ban during peak season

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) demanded the government Friday strictly prevent Chinese onions from entering the domestic market during peak season of the onion in Taiwan.
Pan Meng-an put forward the emergency request on behalf of a group of farmers from the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung during a question-and-answer session in the Legislative Yuan.
According to Pan, many Pingtung farmers have complained to him about the large quantities of Chinese onions grown in China's Shandong Province that could be found in the Taiwan market.
Such products were imported from China via Hong Kong and Thailand, Pan said.

The entry of the Chinese onions at this time has dealt a heavy blow to the business in the home market and largely affected the livelihoods of local growers -- mostly on the Hengchun Peninsula in Pingtung County, Pan said.
Hengchun is Taiwan's key onion production area and now is its peak season.
Pan said local farmers hope that the Council of Agriculture will allow onion imports only in off-season.
The lawmaker also demanded the government effectively crack down on smuggling as traders might hide onions in shipment of other produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: Egg prices expected to stabilize with warmer weather: COA

TEXT.P: The rising prices of chicken and duck eggs are expected to stabilize and production levels to revert to normal once the weather turns warm, the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA) said in a statement Friday.

The price of chicken eggs has increased to NT$29.5 per 600 grams, or Taiwan catty, the standard unit of measurement in traditional food markets, while the price of duck eggs reached NT$33 per catty, the council said.

According to the Taipei-based China Times daily, the price of chicken eggs was more than double that of a year ago and the second highest in history, trailing only the NT$30 per catty registered in 1996 when local consumers went crazy for Portuguese-style egg tarts.
Duck egg prices, meanwhile, were 43 percent higher than a year ago and the highest in two decades, the report said.

In its statement, the Council of Agriculture attributed the soaring prices to recent cold spells that have dampened egg production and rising international grain prices that have led the cost of feed to skyrocket.

Huang Ying-hao, chief of the COA's Animal Industry Development, said that if the weather remains stable in the coming weeks, falling egg production should return to normal within a month and current egg prices would stabilize.

He said that current egg price levels were "reasonable" based on chicken feed costs that have risen from NT$9 to NT$14 per catty over the past year and duck feed costs that have gone from NT$10 to NT$15 over the same period.

Based on the agency's calculations, the current cost of producing chicken eggs was NT$27 per catty while that of duck eggs NT$31 per catty, Huang said, an indication of how egg farmers' profits are being squeezed by higher feed costs and lower production levels.

The COA official said that the council has taken action to help local farmers face the impact of increasing production costs resulted from rising international prices of feed grain -- mainly corn -- including guiding poultry farmers on how to use other feed formulas.
The COA has also taken moves to encourage farmers to grown sweet corn in an effort to reduce the country's reliance on imports, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First presidential debate to be held Sunday

TEXT.P: Presidential hopefuls of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Frank Hsieh and his opponent Ma Ying-jeou representing the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) are slated to debate on television Sunday to give voters a better picture of how they would lead the nation in the coming four years.

In this first face-to-face debate, which is considered a decisive factor in the presidential campaign that will officially kick off Saturday, Hsieh and Ma will face questions on their administrative policies and social, economic and cultural agenda.

According to the format of the debate, both Hsieh and Ma will first answer the questions from 20 citizens, including Lo Chao-hsun, who is known for heckling President Chen Shui-bian in public, and Su Chien-ho, a convicted murderer whose controversial death sentence is still under review by the Taiwan High Court.

The program -- a presidential debate in which average citizens will quiz the candidates, organized by the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service Foundation and four local newspapers, is to air live on Channel 13 from 2 p.m. to 5:15 p.m.

In the first two sections of the program, according to the rules, Hsieh and Ma have to respond to the 20 videotaped questions selected by the organizers from 456 questions contributed to the PeoPo, a Web site specially set up for the general public to express their concerns on the Internet over the candidates, their policies, and the future of Taiwan during the campaign period.

The 20 people will then question both candidates directly at the debate based on the candidates answers to the 20 videotaped questions, which includes such issues as the identity of Taiwan and its people, Taiwan's participation in the Kyoto Protocol, same-sex marriage, the promotion of Aboriginal culture, social welfare, and the development of the nation's economy.
In the third section of the program, each presidential hopeful will challenge his opponent with three questions and the responses have to be made within a time limit of one minute.
At the end of the program, Hsieh and Ma are expected to each make three-minute remarks concluding their views and perspectives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kenyan runner to defend Tainan International Marathon title

TEXT.P: Kenyan long-distance runner Bernard Mutai will make it to the southern city of Tainan to defend his title in the 2008 Tainan International Marathon, despite widespread violence that has torn his homeland apart, the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) said Friday.

Three other Kenyan athletes will not be able to leave the East African country, which has been mired in violence in which 1,000 people have died following a controversial presidential election, the SAC said in a statement.
Mutai finished first in the mens group in two hours, 21 minutes and 11 seconds while Russian runner Oksana Lokhlova won the womens group in 3:03:09 last year.

More than 6,000 runners will participate in four distances -- the 42.195-kilometer full marathon, the 21-km, half-marathon, the 10 km and the 3 km -- in the annual race. Taiwanese runner Wu Wen-chian, who has qualified for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, will participate in the 10km event as a pre-Olympics warm-up.

DOC.HEADLINE: Emergency injunction eases pressure on debt-ridden FAT

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court issued an emergency injunction Friday barring creditors from taking action in the next 90 days to collect debts owed by domestic carrier Far Eastern Air Transport (FAT) , welcome news for the airline that has filed for bankruptcy protection.
Under the ruling, trading of FAT shares on the Gre Tai Securities Market will also be suspended for a three-month period.

A spokesman for the airline said the injunction relieved pressure on the cash- strapped to service its debts in the coming months and allowed it to focus on flight operations and give the airline time to resolve its financial crisis.
The spokesman reiterated the company's promise to repay its debts and appealed for patience on the part of its creditors.

FAT is trying to settle its financial crisis by selling its investments in other businesses, collecting overdue payments owed by other partner airlines, and seeking the support of its major shareholders, according to the company.

FAT, Taiwan's oldest privately-owned airline that celebrated its 50th anniversary in November 2007, filed for bankruptcy protection last Friday after reporting debts of NT$9.99 billion (US$315 million) at the end of September 2007.

The airline reported a loss of NT$ 3.3 billion as of Sept. 30 in 2007. Like Taiwan's other carriers that primarily fly domestic routes, FAT has been hit hard by a downturn in domestic air travel, partly due to competition from a new high speed rail service launched in January 2007.
The airline's membership in the International Air Transport Association's Clearing House (ICH) was temporarily suspended last Wednesday because of its US$848,000 (NT$27.14 million) in unpaid bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Geneva court to rule on ISO reference to Taiwan in 2 months
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Switzerland, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/22/08 22:44:07 (By Jou Ying-cheng and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A court in Geneva is expected to deliver a verdict within two months on a lawsuit filed by Taiwan against the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) for referring to Taiwan as a part of China.

The Geneva First Instance Court held a second hearing Thursday on the lawsuit filed on July 20 of last year that demanded that the organization correct Taiwan's designation from "Taiwan Province, China" to "Republic of China (Taiwan) " in the ISO 3166 country codes list.
The lawsuit came after the ISO failed to respond positively to Taiwan's repeated requests over the name issue.

In rebutting the organization's doubts about Taiwan's legal standing, Henri- Philippe Sambuc, the lawyer representing Taiwan, argued during the Thursday hearing that Taiwan has all the elements of a country and that Taiwan enjoys an international legal personality, which requires no recognition from other countries.
In addition, Taiwan has inked many valid treaties and agreements with countries, including Switzerland, that do not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Sambuc said.
In many legal cases, courts in countries that are not Taiwan's diplomatic allies have also confirmed Taiwan's legal eligibility, Sambuc noted.
Sambuc further cited as an example a ruling by the Swiss Federal Supreme Court on a kickback scandal involving Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette-class frigates from France.
For its part, the ISO raised a procedural problem during the hearing, saying that many documents presented by Taiwan were not translated into French.
The organization also countered that many of the Swiss institutions with which Taiwan has signed agreements were not official.
Following the hearing, Sambuc told the Central News Agency that he is confident of winning the case, while a ISO lawyer and legal consultant declined to comment.

Prior to the lawsuit, the organization told Taiwan that it created the 3166 list back in 1974 in accordance with the United Nations' practice of calling Taiwan "Taiwan Province, China, " a term not coined by the ISO.
It is the first time that Taiwan has resorted to legal action against a major international organization over the name issue.
The ISO 3166 list has been widely used globally, which has resulted in the use of "Taiwan Province, China" increasingly prevalent among international organizations and multinational business groups.
Taiwan said, however, that such a trend has caused misunderstanding and confusion for itself and undermined its national status and interests.
The Geneva-based ISO is an international standard-setting body comprised of representatives from various national standards organizations.
Founded on Feb. 23, 1947, the organization promulgates world-wide industrial and commercial standards.

While ISO defines itself as a non-governmental organization, its ability to set standards that often become law, either through treaties or national standards, makes it more powerful than most NGOs. In practice, ISO acts as a consortium with strong links to governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to check candidates' nationality: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has sent letters of authorization from Taiwan's two presidential candidates to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), which will enable the ministry to see if they are citizens of other countries.

CEC Secretary-General Deng Tien-yu said that both Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and his rival, Ma Ying- jeou of the Kuomintang, had given written authorization to the commission to have their statuses checked.
The ministry will now ask the United States, Japan and Britain to see if they are citizens of those countries.

He said the CEC had received Ma's authorization earlier in the day along with personal data, including his date of birth, ID number, passport number, English name used on the passport, household address, U. S. social security number and U.S. permanent residence document, or "green card."

The process of checking if either of the candidates have dual citizenships in other countries comes as Hsieh's campaign has pressed Ma over the past two weeks over his possession of a "green card, " questioning his loyalty and integrity.

Ma, who holds a doctoral degree in law from Harvard University, said that he did possess a green card while studying in the United States in the 1980s, but he stopped using it after returning to Taiwan, and the green card had since been invalidated.
Meanwhile, the CEC reminded television and radio programs on political affairs Friday to be "just and equal" to the presidential candidates, and "not to treat them differently."

CEC officials said that the presidential and vice presidential election and recall law stipulates that the TV and radio station could offer paid time slots for presidential candidates and the political parties that nominate them for campaign activities. The stations should provide "just and equal" treatment to the candidates.

The officials said that anyone could submit substantive evidence of possible violations such as video or audio tapes to the CEC within one month after the airing of the programs. Violators will be subject to fines of between NT$200,000 and NT$2 million (US$6,370-63,700).

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Chinese official visits Taiwan only for professional exchanges':MAC

TEXT.P: A former Chinese official arrested on charges of collecting information for Taiwan only visited the country on professional exchanges, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Friday.

Taiwan's United Daily News reported Friday that Li Jian, the deputy head of the Taiwan office under China's transport ministry, was arrested before Chinese New Year's Eve on espionage charges for collecting information for Taiwan.
"Li did come to Taiwan several times but had no controversial stops during his stays in the country, " said Liu, whose agency is responsible for coordinating Taiwan's China policy.
Liu said the council did not have any information on Li's contacts with Taiwan's intelligence circles.
The report said Li was the third and also the highest ranking Chinese official handling cross-strait civilian affairs to be held on spying allegations since 1991.
Li left his post at China's transport ministry in 1999, and the Chinese authorities began investigating him in 2000, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of job seekers on rise after Lunar New Year: report

TEXT.P: The number of people seeking jobs online following the Lunar New Year holidays is 10 percent higher than before the break, an online employment agency said Friday.

According to a report released by the 104 job bank, 300,000 people are looking for jobs through the Web site, up from 270,000 people registered on the site Feb. 12, when the six-day holiday period ended.

The number of job seekers with five to seven years of work experience grew by 15 percent, the most of any experience group, while resumes submitted by those with three to four years of work experience increased by 13.8 percent, the report said.
Regions in central Taiwan, such as Taichung City, Taichung County and Changhu County, saw the highest increases in people searching for new jobs.

The number of job seekers from the three areas rose by an average of 13 percent over the past 10 days -- higher than the 10 percent recorded for the Taipei area in the north and the 8 percent posted in the Kaohsiung area in the south.

In terms of professions, the information/technology sector has attracted 27 percent of the recent job seekers, ahead of nearly 23 percent eyeing jobs in businesses catering to consumer services, and 10 percent interested in the education and government sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate's U.S. green card remains valid: DPP campaign

TEXT.P: The campaign of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh repeated its claim Friday that its rival's U.S. permanent residence status, or green card, remains valid.

Hsu Kuo-yung, a spokesman for the Hsieh campaign, repeated the claim after the campaign of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou announced earlier in the day that Ma had given authorization to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to have his citizenship checked.
Ma's campaign office said it has also sent a request to the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwa asking it to help check Ma's citizenship and U.S. green card status as soon as possible.
According to the Ma campaign, Ma's U.S. green card has been invalidated for more than 20 years following his return to Taiwan after obtaining a doctoral degree from Harvard University.
Hsu, however, challenged Ma to produce the document and date to prove that his green card had indeed been invalidated.

"Ma should follow the example of his fellow KMT loyalist Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, who visited the AIT Taipei Office to fill in an application form declaring his decicion to forgo his U.S. green card before pursuing a public service career, " Hsu said.
If Ma fails to present such a document and give a date on which he gave up his green card, Ma's green card should remain valid, Hsu contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: China agrees to sell corn feed to Taiwan

TEXT.P: China has agreed to sell 200,000 metric tons of corn feed to Taiwan, which may help Taiwan lower its feed costs, according to an official of the National Animal Industry Foundation.
The deal was revealed after the foundation received a faxed notice from Beijing agreeing to export the feed.

In the notice, China agreed to allow China National Cereals, Oils and Foodstuffs Corp. (COFCO) to export the corn feed to two Taiwanese private organizations -- the R.O.C Federation of Swine Cooperatives General Catalogue and the Taiwan Feed Industry Association.

China gave its nod after Taiwan's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs approved last year the import of Chinese corn feed for period limited to between Oct. 1, 2007 and March 31, 2008, the foundation official said.

The bureau approved the deal to help Taiwan cope with soaring international grain prices, which have increased the cost of raising livestock and poultry in Taiwan, and consequently spurred higher local meat prices.
The official said that China's agreement to export corn feed will mainly help Taiwan save in shipping costs.
Taiwan consumes 5 million metric tons of corn feed every year, most of which is imported from the United States at low prices, the official said.

In recent years, however, the price of imported corn feed has risen from NT$5 (US$0.16) to NT$11 per kilo, the official explained. With shipping costs across the Pacific rising, the import deal would help save NT$0.6 to NT$0.7 per kilo in transportation expenses, the official said.
China had been carefully assessing the case because its own demands for the crop have been growing rapidly, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau accredits foreign tourist guides for first time

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai presented "honorary" accreditation to 21 Japanese tour guides Friday who recently passed tests to certify their professionalism in guiding tour groups in Taiwan.

Lai said that this is the first time that the bureau had decided to accredit foreign tourist guides, hoping to encourage them to learn more about Taiwan and therefore be more authoritative in recommending Taiwan's scenic spots and features to their clients.
She noted that Japan is the largest source of overseas tourists to Taiwan, with 1.16 million Japanese visitors coming to Taiwan, 31.39 percent of a total of 3.71 million visitors to Taiwan in 2007.
She said that middle-aged or elder Japanese used to form the lion's share of Japanese tourists visiting Taiwan a decade ago, but in recent years, Japanese youths and women have become the mainstay.
This is why the bureau has now asked pop idol group F4 to become spokesmen for Taiwan tourism in recent years, she continued, although the promotional efforts "were still not efficient."

At the suggestion of the Kinki Nippon Tourist Co. (KNT) , the second largest travel agency in Japan, the bureau began cooperating with the travel agency by offering their staff classes and training courses on understanding Taiwan and accrediting them after tests.

"If you like Taiwan, you will be more able to market Taiwan," Lai said, and this is why the bureau offered training to the staff of the tourist company to enhance their understanding of the tourism products in Taiwan.
The first test had originally hoped to accredit 500 KNT tour guides, but a total of 733 registered for the test and 624, including KNT President Takashi Ota himself, passed the test.

The KNT treated 21 of the tourist guides to a four-day tour in Taiwan, and some of them wrote about their experience in Taiwan during the stay. Among the responses were "I feel I got a good rest in Taiwan, " "Taiwan has so much to see and eat, and I enjoy foot massages, " and "the Taiwan Lantern Festival is spectacular."

Lai said that the bureau will continue to work with other travel agencies in Japan for accreditation, and could expand the program to tourist guides in Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, Hong Kong and Macau, countries that are also major source of tourists to Taiwan.
The bureau has recently launched a plan to promote Taiwan as a tourism destination in 2008-2009, which is coupled with a series of incentive measures.
The Tourism Bureau expects the number of visitors to Taiwan, excluding Chinese tourists, will reach its target of 4 million in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 23, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Forum on China identity or Chinese identity. Date and Time: 02:00 p.m., Saturday, Feb. 23, 2008. Place: Zhongshan Hall, 98, Yenping S. Road, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Lung Ying-tai and other celebrities. Organizers: Lung Ying-tai Cultural Foundation. Press Contact: Tel.2381-3137. Disclaimer:

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Disabled to get financial security with new scheme.
A Government-backed trust-fund scheme is in the works to help provide financial security to the disabled after their caregivers die. Expected to be in place later this year, it will allow parents with disabled children to set aside some money with the Public Trustee's Office to sink into low-risk investments.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore to host 1st Asian Youth Games next year.
Olympic Council of Asia agreed Singapore to host the first Asian Youth Games next year after Singapore won the bid for first Youth Olympic Games in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 23, or the 17th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1743: Meyer Rothschild, a German banker who founded a bank at
Frankfurt am Main, is born. His sons, most notably Salomon and Nathan Meyer, established branches of the bank throughout Europe.
1792: Sir Joshua Reynold, British painter and first president of
the Royal Academy, dies at the age of 69. He is considered one of the most important figures in the history of English painting.
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United
States, who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1863: British explorers John Speke and J.A. Grant announce that they have "discovered" Lake Victoria to be the source of the Nile.
1898: Emile Zola, the French writer and critic who was a leading
proponent of naturalism in fiction, is imprisoned for the publication of his letter "J'accuse, " which accused the French government of anti-Semistism and of wrongly imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are now about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1906: Johann Hoch is imprisoned in Chicago for murdering six of
his 13 wives.
1924: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United
States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, dies at the age of 68. His administration was marked by World War I and the introduction of prohibition.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great
Wall of China.
1942: Australia, Britain, New Zealand and the United States sign
the Master Mutual Aid Agreement.
1942: A Japanese submarine shells an oil refinery near Santa
Barbara, California.
1944: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Chechen republic and forces 1
million Chechens into exile, accusing them of collaboration with Nazi Germany.
1945: U.S. Marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi of Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo, after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the Southeast Asian Treaty
Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Republic of China Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for treating
cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist
Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets
up the Republic of Guyana.
1976: The Association of East Asian Relations and Japan's
Interchange Association open a two-day economic and trade conference.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in
exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting
and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested
after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1995: U.S. President Bill Clinton voices support for a united Canada in a speech to Canada's parliament.
1997: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to Article 4
of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, named "Peace Memorial Day," be deemed a national holiday.
2000: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang
adopts a proposal that Adolfo Sun should succeed Kuo Kang to become the ROC's ambassador to the Dominican Republic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."
