In the first two sections of the program, according to the rules, Hsieh and Ma have to respond to the 20 videotaped questions selected by the organizers from 456 questions contributed to the PeoPo, a Web site specially set up for the general public to express their concerns on the Internet over the candidates, their policies, and the future of Taiwan during the campaign period.

The 20 people will then question both candidates directly at the debate based on the candidates answers to the 20 videotaped questions, which includes such issues as the identity of Taiwan and its people, Taiwan's participation in the Kyoto Protocol, same-sex marriage, the promotion of Aboriginal culture, social welfare, and the development of the nation's economy.
In the third section of the program, each presidential hopeful will challenge his opponent with three questions and the responses have to be made within a time limit of one minute.
At the end of the program, Hsieh and Ma are expected to each make three-minute remarks concluding their views and perspectives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Geneva court to rule on ISO reference to Taiwan in 2 months
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, Switzerland, Feb. 21 (CNA) 02/23/08 10:45:45 (By Jou Ying-cheng and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A court in Geneva is expected to deliver a verdict within two months on a lawsuit filed by Taiwan against the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) for referring to Taiwan as a part of China.

The Geneva First Instance Court held a second hearing Thursday on the lawsuit filed on July 20 of last year that demanded that the organization correct Taiwan's designation from "Taiwan Province, China" to "Republic of China (Taiwan) " in the ISO 3166 country codes list.
The lawsuit came after the ISO failed to respond positively to Taiwan's repeated requests over the name issue.

In rebutting the organization's doubts about Taiwan's legal standing, Henri- Philippe Sambuc, the lawyer representing Taiwan, argued during the Thursday hearing that Taiwan has all the elements of a country and that Taiwan enjoys an international legal personality, which requires no recognition from other countries.
In addition, Taiwan has inked many valid treaties and agreements with countries, including Switzerland, that do not have diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Sambuc said.
In many legal cases, courts in countries that are not Taiwan's diplomatic allies have also confirmed Taiwan's legal eligibility, Sambuc noted.
Sambuc further cited as an example a ruling by the Swiss Federal Supreme Court on a kickback scandal involving Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette-class frigates from France.
For its part, the ISO raised a procedural problem during the hearing, saying that many documents presented by Taiwan were not translated into French.
The organization also countered that many of the Swiss institutions with which Taiwan has signed agreements were not official.
Following the hearing, Sambuc told the Central News Agency that he is confident of winning the case, while a ISO lawyer and legal consultant declined to comment.

Prior to the lawsuit, the organization told Taiwan that it created the 3166 list back in 1974 in accordance with the United Nations' practice of calling Taiwan "Taiwan Province, China, " a term not coined by the ISO.
It is the first time that Taiwan has resorted to legal action against a major international organization over the name issue.
The ISO 3166 list has been widely used globally, which has resulted in the use of "Taiwan Province, China" increasingly prevalent among international organizations and multinational business groups.
Taiwan said, however, that such a trend has caused misunderstanding and confusion for itself and undermined its national status and interests.
The Geneva-based ISO is an international standard-setting body comprised of representatives from various national standards organizations.
Founded on Feb. 23, 1947, the organization promulgates world-wide industrial and commercial standards.

While ISO defines itself as a non-governmental organization, its ability to set standards that often become law, either through treaties or national standards, makes it more powerful than most NGOs. In practice, ISO acts as a consortium with strong links to governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA to check candidates' nationality: CEC

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) has sent letters of authorization from Taiwan's two presidential candidates to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), which will enable the ministry to see if they are citizens of other countries.

CEC Secretary-General Deng Tien-yu said that both Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and his rival, Ma Ying- jeou of the Kuomintang, had given written authorization to the commission to have their statuses checked.
The ministry will now ask the United States, Japan and Britain to see if they are citizens of those countries.

He said the CEC had received Ma's authorization earlier in the day along with personal data, including his date of birth, ID number, passport number, English name used on the passport, household address, U. S. social security number and U.S. permanent residence document, or "green card."

The process of checking if either of the candidates have dual citizenships in other countries comes as Hsieh's campaign has pressed Ma over the past two weeks over his possession of a "green card, " questioning his loyalty and integrity.

Ma, who holds a doctoral degree in law from Harvard University, said that he did possess a green card while studying in the United States in the 1980s, but he stopped using it after returning to Taiwan, and the green card had since been invalidated.
Meanwhile, the CEC reminded television and radio programs on political affairs Friday to be "just and equal" to the presidential candidates, and "not to treat them differently."

CEC officials said that the presidential and vice presidential election and recall law stipulates that the TV and radio station could offer paid time slots for presidential candidates and the political parties that nominate them for campaign activities. The stations should provide "just and equal" treatment to the candidates.

The officials said that anyone could submit substantive evidence of possible violations such as video or audio tapes to the CEC within one month after the airing of the programs. Violators will be subject to fines of between NT$200,000 and NT$2 million (US$6,370-63,700).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate's U.S. green card remains valid: DPP campaign

TEXT.P: The campaign of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh repeated its claim Friday that its rival's U.S. permanent residence status, or green card, remains valid.

Hsu Kuo-yung, a spokesman for the Hsieh campaign, repeated the claim after the campaign of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou announced earlier in the day that Ma had given authorization to the Central Election Commission (CEC) to have his citizenship checked.
Ma's campaign office said it has also sent a request to the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwa asking it to help check Ma's citizenship and U.S. green card status as soon as possible.
According to the Ma campaign, Ma's U.S. green card has been invalidated for more than 20 years following his return to Taiwan after obtaining a doctoral degree from Harvard University.
Hsu, however, challenged Ma to produce the document and date to prove that his green card had indeed been invalidated.

"Ma should follow the example of his fellow KMT loyalist Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, who visited the AIT Taipei Office to fill in an application form declaring his decicion to forgo his U.S. green card before pursuing a public service career, " Hsu said.
If Ma fails to present such a document and give a date on which he gave up his green card, Ma's green card should remain valid, Hsu contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau accredits foreign tourist guides for first time

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai presented "honorary" accreditation to 21 Japanese tour guides Friday who recently passed tests to certify their professionalism in guiding tour groups in Taiwan.

Lai said that this is the first time that the bureau had decided to accredit foreign tourist guides, hoping to encourage them to learn more about Taiwan and therefore be more authoritative in recommending Taiwan's scenic spots and features to their clients.

She noted that Japan is the largest source of overseas tourists to Taiwan, with 1.16 million Japanese visitors coming to Taiwan, or 31.39 percent of a total of 3.71 million visitors to Taiwan in 2007.
She said that middle-aged or elder Japanese used to form the lion's share of Japanese tourists visiting Taiwan a decade ago, but in recent years, Japanese youths and women have become the mainstay.
This is why the bureau has now asked pop idol group F4 to become spokesmen for Taiwan tourism in recent years, she continued, although the promotional efforts "were still not efficient."

At the suggestion of the Kinki Nippon Tourist Co. (KNT) , the second largest travel agency in Japan, the bureau began cooperating with the travel agency by offering their staff classes and training courses on Taiwan and accrediting them after tests.

"If you like Taiwan, you will be more able to market Taiwan," Lai said, and this is why the bureau offered training to the staff of the tourist company to enhance their understanding of the tourism products in Taiwan.
The first test had originally hoped to accredit 500 KNT tour guides, but a total of 733 registered for the test and 624, including KNT President Takashi Ota himself, passed the test.

The KNT treated 21 of the tourist guides who passed the tests to a four-day tour in Taiwan, and some of them wrote about their experience in Taiwan during the stay. Among the responses were "I feel I got a good rest in Taiwan, " "Taiwan has so much to see and eat, and I enjoy foot massages, " and "the Taiwan Lantern Festival is spectacular."

Lai said that the bureau will continue to work with other travel agencies in Japan for "honorary" accreditation, and could expand the program to tourist guides in Singapore, Malaysia, South Korea, Hong Kong and Macau, countries that are also major source of tourists to Taiwan.
The bureau has recently launched a plan to promote Taiwan as a tourism destination in 2008-2009, which is coupled with a series of incentive measures.
The Tourism Bureau expects the number of visitors to Taiwan, excluding Chinese tourists, will reach its target of 4 million in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense minister offers to resign

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu offered to resign in a news release posted on the ministry's Web site Saturday.
Lee, who assumed his post In May 2007, said he felt "deep regret" over the controversy surrounding the establishment of a private arms firm, Taiwan Goal, in which the MND is the largest shareholder.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan can apply to join international climate change network

TEXT.P: The United Nations Environmental Programme (UNEP) has confirmed that Taiwan's cities and companies can apply to join the newly established Climate Neutral Network, opening a new way for Taiwan's future participation in the global campaign against climate change.

UNEP unveiled the Climate Neutral Network (CN Net) at the 10th Special Session of the Governing Council and Global Ministerial Environmental Forum held in Monaco earlier this month, aiming at "catalyzing a transition to a low-carbon world."

Under the program, CN Net will integrate countries, cities and companies all over the world to boost a green economy and "will assist in building confidence through demonstrable action at the national and local level on the art of the possible, " said Achim Steiner, the U.N. under-secretary-general and UNEP executive director.

Climate neutral is the concept of reducing or offsetting greenhouse gases emitted by a country in ways such as planting trees, reducing fuel usage and adopting green energy, to balance the global warming effect.

Asked if Taiwan, which is not a U.N. member, can join the program, UNEP spokesman Nick Nuttall told CNA in a telephone interview Friday that Taiwanese cities and companies can file applications at any time. He stopped short of mentioning whether Taiwan can join the program at the national level.
"It is a positive development, paving a new way for Taiwan to participate in the environmental movement on an international scale," said Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Chairwoman Gloria Hsu.

"What needs to be seen is the Taiwanese people's and government's conscience about environmental protection, " she went on, saying that once Taiwan joins the program, it will have to make commitments to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

So far, CN Net has registered four countries -- Costa Rica, Iceland, New Zealand and Norway -- four cities, including Rizhao, a city in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong, the Norwegian town of Arendal, the Swedish town of Vaxjo and Canada's Vancouver, as well as five companies in Singapore, Brazil, the United States, the United Kingdom and South Africa.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Environmental Protection Administration reserved comments on Taiwan's eventual participation in the program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Popularity of IDCs to benefit Taiwan's contract server system makers

TEXT.P: Shipments by Taiwan's contract server system manufacturers are expected to remain strong in the first quarter of 2008, driven mainly by efforts by server brands such as HP and IBM to promote the establishment of Internet data centers (IDCs) by businesses, the Institute for Information Industry (III) forecast Saturday.

While demand by international Internet service providers and telecommunications operators will continue expanding, the multi-core and virtualization technologies introduced by processor suppliers will also help boost shipments, said Tung Chi-sheng, a senior industry analyst with the III's Market Intelligence Center.

Tung predicted that Taiwan's server system manufacturers will ship a total of 773,000 full systems and barebone systems in the first quarter of 2008, for a quarter-on-quarter increase of 0.3 percent and a year-on-year increase of 8.6 percent.

For the same period, the number of motherboards shipped by Taiwanese manufacturers is expected to amount to 1.126 million units, up 0.1 percent quarter-on-quarter and 7.6 percent year-on-year, Tung said.

In the fourth quarter of 2007, full system and barebone system shipments by Taiwanese manufacturers posted a year-on-year increase of 9 percent to reach 771,000 units, while motherboard shipments rose 8.4 percent year-on-year to 1.126 million units, he said.

Taiwan's server system production amounted to US$618.4 million in the third quarter of 2003, for a quarter-on-quarter increase of 2.6 percent and year-on- year increase of 8 percent, despite a US$2.4 decline in the average selling price, he noted.
During the same quarter, the average selling price of motherboards dropped US$0.7, with the production value amounting to US$219.9 million, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Notebook exports from Greater China to grow by 25.3%: forecast

TEXT.P: Notebook computer exports from the Greater China region are expected to reach 113 million units in 2008, with an annual growth rate of 25.3 percent, an industry analyst for the Market Intelligence Center (MIC) of the quasi-official Institute for Information Industry forecast Saturday.
In general, the output will tend to decline this year due to an expected shortage of battery cells, Huang Yi-chuan predicted.

In 2007, Huang said, the notebook output from the region amounted to 27.55 million units in the fourth quarter, recording an annual rise of 38.7 percent, with the exports shipped mainly to European and North American markets
The notebook output from Greater China reached 90.16 million units last year, representing an annual growth of 40.08 percent, according to MIC statistics.
Greater China is a commonly used term to describe territories administered by China, including Hong Kong and Macau, and those administered by Taiwan.
In terms of production value, the MIC tallies show that the average sales price for one notebook declined from US$529 in the third quarter of last year to US$522 in the fourth quarter.
In the fourth quarter, the output value of notebook computers from Great China totalled US$14.385 billion, with an annual growth of 25.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier approves defense minister's resignation

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has approved the resignation of Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun announced Saturday.
Chen also said he would convene a news conference at the Government Information Office later in the day to explain Lee's resignation.

Lee offered to resign in a news release posted on the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Web site earlier in the day in which he said that he felt "deep regret" over the controversy surrounding the formation of the private arms firm Taiwan Goal.
Lee said he had set his mind to implementing the nation's defense policy and upgrading its defense capability ever since assuming the post last May.

"Although I was instructed to establish Taiwan Goal, I have failed to carry out the plan properly and have caused misgivings among the public about the project, for which I have to step down, " Lee's statement said.
Chang said earlier that same day that whether the MND should continue to invest in Taiwan Goal should be given careful reconsideration.
"I think it is necessary to reconsider whether the MND should go on as scheduled to invest in a 45 percent stake of the company, " Chang said.

"If we think it is improper for the MND to invest in the company, then it should not invest," the premier went on, amid harsh criticism from the opposition- controlled legislature that the formation of the arms firm is aimed at dodging the supervision of the legislature even though most of the funding comes from government agencies and state-owned corporations.

Attending an international seminar on the 228 Incident earlier in the day, Chang said that although the MND plans to hold 45 percent of the company, it has yet to submit an investment proposal to the Executive Yuan and the funding has not been channeled into the project or revived by the public.

Chang noted that until such time that the MND's funds are channeled into the project, the company is still privately owned and that the Cabinet therefore has no legal authority to disband the company.

Taiwan Goal completed registration with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Jan. 28 as a private company, with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million, and with Wu Nai-jen, a DPP heavyweight and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp. -- serving as chairman of the company.
MOEA data shows that Taiwan Goal has a seven-member board of directors, with three seats going to the MND.

Taiwan Goal is registered to deal in a variety of businesses, including the import and export of arms and weaponry systems; sales of garments and accessories, industrial explosives, precision instruments, and batteries of all types; and product design, according to the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: New defense minister appointed

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has appointed former Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming- shian to replace Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, who resigned earlier in the day, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun announced Saturday.
Tsai, 67, who holds a Ph.D. degree from the California Western School of Law, was previously a two-term legislator and has also served as a deputy representative to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times MSDF chief faces ax over collision
Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba will sack the Maritime Self-Defense Force chief over Tuesday's collision between an Aegis destroyer and a fishing boat and for failing to notify him and Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda of the accident in a timely manner, ministry sources said Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles TimesG Gang mayhem cripples big area.
A drive-by attack followed by a wild shootout between gang members and police shut down dozens of blocks of Northeast Los Angeles for nearly six hours Thursday afternoon, stranding thousands of residents, keeping students locked in their classrooms and leaving two people dead. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: China should improve human rights through 2008 Olympics: President

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has said that China should not use the 2008 Beijing Olympics as a pretext for purging political dissent but should use the games as an opportunity to show the world that it has made true improvements to its human rights situation.

Chen made the remarks Friday while meeting at the Presidential Office with foreign delegates attending an international forum titled Human Rights in China and the 2008 Olympics held Feb. 21-22 in Taipei with the aim of pressing China to improve its human rights record prior to the Beijing Olympics scheduled to open Aug. 8.

The forum concluded that the Chinese government has violated the commitment it made to improve its human rights situation before the Olympics and that the human rights situation in China has in fact deteriorated since Beijing was awarded the Olympics.
Addressing the delegates, Chen called on China to stop using the games as a pretext for purging or arresting dissidents.

"The trend of pursuing democracy and liberty cannot be stopped and coercion can only silence people temporarily, " Chen said, adding that independence of Kosovo from Serbia Feb. 17 best illustrates the global trend of seeking democracy and autonomy.
"China's pressure on Taiwan seeking independence excludes itself from the global trend and reveals its lack of confidence, " Chen said.
He pointed out that Taiwan's people enjoy freedom that is the fruit of the country's democracy, while China's 1.3 billion people face life with jeopardized human rights.

Taiwan's democracy should serve as a good example for China and Taiwan's people and government are willing to do their best to help China travel the road of democracy, Chen said. He added that only if China transforms into a democratic country can the Taiwan-China problem be solved and hope be given to regional and world peace.

Chen also expressed the hope that China will follow the global trend, respect its people and protect their rights and dignity, to become a respectful, mature and responsible country instead of one that relies on military power and rapid economic growth.

He pointed out that a Kosovan Web site that lists and expresses gratitude to countries that have recognized Kosovo deleted Taiwan's name because of pressure from China. The Web site gave as the reason for the deletion the fact that it only listed names of U.N. member states, although Taiwan was listed for a short time.

Chen said he understands Kosovo's difficulty but felt sad because of what Taiwan has experienced in terms of being refused entry to the U.N. and being denied even the right to recognize other countries.

"No matter how much time it takes for Kosovo to become a U.N. member, its independence cannot be denied, just as Taiwan's sovereignty will not be affected by the fact that it is not a U.N. member, " Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mistakes of history must not be forgotten: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung voiced the government's concern and care Saturday for the families of the victims of the 228 Incident of 1947 and said the care will continue.

Chang made the remarks when he attended an international seminar to mark the 61st anniversary of the 228 Incident, an uprising against the Kuomintang administration under then-President Chiang Kai-shek that began Feb. 28, 1947 and was followed by a bloody crackdown, resulting in tens of thousands of civilian deaths.
The event was sponsored by the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation, a non-profit organization founded by the Executive Yuan in April 1995 based on the Compensation and Rehabilitation Act.

In his address, Chang said the truth of an authoritarian government's oppression of the people should be revealed. He called on people not to forget the mistakes of history in order to prevent the same mistakes from happening again.

Since the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took power in 2000, the administration has designated Feb. 28 as Taiwan Peace Day and has established a 228 Peace Fund to help finance the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation, Chang said.

In addition, he went on, the legislature passed last March an amendment that replaces the word "compensation" with "indemnification" in a bill related to the 228 Incident -- a long-awaited request made by 228 Incident victims and their families.

Although the change in the official wording will not alter the compensation conditions stipulated in the bill, it is believed that the word "indemnification" connotes the wrongfulness of the then-government's part in the incident.

The Statute for Handling of and Compensation for the 228 Incident enacted in April 1995 details a series of steps that need to be made to make up for what the victims suffered, but falls short of determining legal responsibility for the incident.

Citing the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Chang repeated that the "recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world."
He also expressed hope that the concept will be carried out on Taiwanese soil and in the international community and that Taiwan will always be a nation that embraces human rights and democracy.
The two-day seminar is being held at the National Library, with discussions on topics focusing on human rights in small countries and the hegemony of big countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agricultural losses due to cold weather reach NT$380 million

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural losses due to the recent cold spell have increased to NT$380 million (US$12.1 million), as the fishery losses grew to NT$223 million, according to statistics released by agriculture authorities Saturday.
The increased losses were due to more places reporting crop and fishery losses, including Tainan city and county and Chiayi County in southern Taiwan and Yilan county in eastern Taiwan.

The Council of Agriculture (COA) statistics show that a series of cold snaps over the past several weeks, with temperatures dipping to as low as 7 degrees Celsius, have caused damage to crops including high-grafted pears, grapes, wax apples, peaches, rice seedlings, flowers, plums and leafy vegetables.
Around 2,100 hectares of farmland sustained 33 percent damage, meaning 684 hectares of farmland saw no harvest.

The high-grafted pear buds suffered the heaviest damage, with farmers in Hsinchu County sustaining the largest losses, followed by those in Taichung, Yilan, Miaoli, Changhua, Kaohsiung, Pingtung, Yunlin and Taoyuan counties.
Fishery losses amounted to NT$223 million, with Penghu County alone suffering losses totaling over NT$181 million, the statistics show.
COA officials said the council has launched relief measures, including cash aid and low-interest loans to affected farmers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Washington urged to rebuild bilateral agenda with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 22 (CNA) 02/23/08 17:33:02 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The United States should re-establish a positive bilateral agenda with Taiwan by helping it expand its international participation in order to maintain regional stability, according to a report released Friday by the U.S.-based American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research (AEI).

The report suggests that Washington help Taipei re-orient its foreign policy to emphasize its role as a peaceful, vibrant member of the international community, so that "Taiwan will strengthen its international identity as a responsible stakeholder and face less temptation to press issues that cannot now be resolved."

"A more integrated Taiwan that can share its successes with the rest of the world will be less inclined to force the thorniest cross-Taiwan Strait disputes to the fore, " contends the report titled "Strengthening Freedom in Asia: A Twenty-First Century Agenda for the U.S.-Taiwan Partnership, " which was worked out by the Taiwan Policy Working Group that was formed by AEI and Armitage International, an organization that assists companies in the global marketplace.

While admitting that it will be difficult for China to accept a Taiwan with a higher international profile, the report says Washington should nevertheless end Beijing's expectations that it can "deliver" Taiwan.

"Beijing should talk directly to Taipei about its disagreements and not pressure Washington to pressure the Taiwanese government, " the report says. "America should make clear to Beijing that it has interests in the continued freedom of the Taiwanese people to decide their own fate and the peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences."

The report argues that the issue is urgent now that U.S.-Taiwan relations are "dangerously drifting, " with Beijing using diplomatic isolation and the threat of military force to pressure Taiwan into an unfavorable settlement and Taiwan reacting by forcing intractable disputes to the front of the debate.

Describing Taiwan's democracy as a beacon to other societies seeking peaceful political liberalization, the report warns that if Taiwan is coerced by China into a settlement against the wishes of the Taiwanese people, the United States will lose a valuable international partner and suffer a severe blow to its interests and regional position.

In the event of China taking control of Taiwan, the United States and its allies could be denied access to critical sea areas during conflict and China would also significantly extend its reach in the Asia-Pacific region, it says.

While a U.S.-Taiwan common agenda requires better, more routine high-level contact, the Bush administration has taken a step backward in its exchanges with Taiwan, with not a single Cabinet member or other high-level official having visited Taiwan in the past several years, the report points out.

It suggests that the U.S. secretary of state should be able to call his or her counterpart in Taiwan to clarify American positions, understand Taiwan's policies firsthand and create a climate of mutual trust.

Also, the Department of Defense should use all the tools at its disposal to help Taiwan improve its defense capabilities rapidly and to improve interoperability in case the two militaries ever need to operate together, it continues.
"Taiwan is a flashpoint for war, and the United States must use all means of communication, diplomacy, training and exchange to avert such a catastrophic prospect," the report concludes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most road users satisfied with traffic measures for Chinese New Year

TEXT.P: The majority of road users polled in a recent survey expressed approval for the government's measures to regulate freeway traffic during this year's Chinese New Year holiday, according to the results of the survey released Saturday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The survey revealed that 81 percent of the respondents were satisfied with the MOTC's minimum limit for passengers in vehicles using the freeways at peak times during the holiday.

The second-most welcome policy was suspending toll collection during specific periods, which received an approval rating of 78.2 percent, followed by the use of ramp signals to restrict the flow of traffic entering freeways, which got a rating of 77.1 percent.
Ramp closures were favored by 55.1 percent of respondents and 53.6 percent expressed satisfaction with the measure of opening hard shoulders to freeway users.
The survey was conducted via telephone Feb. 12-14 among 3,509 adults, 1,095 of whom had traveled on freeways during the holiday, which ran from Feb. 6-11.
The results show that 69.9 percent of the respondents were satisfied with the MOTC's traffic control measures for the holiday.
On the sources of information, 71 percent of respondents learned about the measures through television, 28.7 percent through radio and 18.6 percent through newspapers or other print media.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Chinese sportsman runs for human rights

TEXT.P: A former member of China's national men's basketball team who recently completed a run across the United Sates to promote human rights and freedom for China's people took part in an "Olympic Freedom Run" in Taipei Saturday and urged Taiwanese people to "firmly defend the moral responsibility of spreading the conviction of freedom."

Kai Chen, 55, who played for China in the 1970s, has lived in the United States since the early 1980s but continues to follow China's situation concerning human rights. In 1989, shocked by the bloody suppression in Tiananmen Square, he decided to devote himself to speaking for persecuted people in China.

In August 2007, one year before the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games, he set up the "Olympic Freedom Run" in Los Angeles in the hope of drawing the world's attention to the China's deplorable human rights situation.

"Taiwanese people in particular have the moral responsibility to fight for freedom, because you, who are also Chinese-speaking people, live in a free and democratic society, " said Chen. "It is not race or language that assembles all of you in Taiwan, it is because of the conviction of freedom that you share, " he went on.
"But I'm not telling you not to travel in China or participate the Beijing Olympics, " Chen said, adding that "I just hope you can go without forgetting to express your faith in freedom."
Citing the Olympic Games in Berlin in 1936, which he described as an "illusion created and propagandized by the Nazis, " Chen said he does not want to see history repeated in Beijing.
After the press conference, Chen did a symbolic 8-km run in Taipei City.
Even if his name is reportedly on the Chinese authorities' "black list, " Chen said, he is not frightened and will continue to run to raise people's awareness of the universal value of freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: 18-year-old girl's achievement mentioned in junior high school text

TEXT.P: The achievements of an 18-year-old student at a senior high school in southern Taiwan in helping farmers and the disadvantaged has been highlighted in a textbook for first-grade junior high school students in the new semester.

The textbook mentions that Shen Hsin-ling, a student from a debt-laden and poor family at the National Tou-Liu Senior High School in the southern county of Yunlin, made great contributions to society with her computer talents and her passion for helping people in need.

Shen established a Web site when she was only an elementary student to promote pomelos -- amajor crop in her home town -- for her grandfather and neighbors when the fruit became unsaleable due to a glut that year.

In addition to helping farmers, she also set up a Web site in 2002 providing a variety of free resources to facilitate learning for students who cannot afford extra-curricular lessons. The Web site, www.anan1.webnow.biz, also offers free learning resources on languages, local culture and customs for foreign spouses in Taiwan to help them better integrate to society.
Shen's story was included in a social sciences text published by the Kang Hsuan Educational Publishing Group.
"It is a special experience to be mentioned in the textbook, especially when most of the other stories in the textbook are about old or dead people," Shen said.
School Principal Lee Shih-feng said the school is proud of Shen's achievement.

Shen said the publisher contacted her for her approval last March and the Ministry of Education approved the publishing of the text last October. She expressed hope that her story will inspire more young people to dedicate themselves to social welfare services.

Shen was selected as one of the top 10 young people with great potential by the CNA this year for her contributions to social welfare. The CNA awards, now entering their fifth year, awards the winners for their achievements in various fields.

Shen told reporters that she learned how to set up Web sites at the age of 12 and made up her mind to help the disadvantaged at 13. She has already received 33 certificates for her computer proficiency.
Shen said she will continue helping the disadvantaged and lessening the disparity between urban and rural areas, and called on the government to pay more attention in this regard.
She also encouraged young students to believe in themselves and to create their own futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: President acclaims Taiwanese people's vitality

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian acclaimed Saturday the Taiwanese people's ability to stand up and step forward again after sustaining a big fall, referring to the reconstruction of places severely damaged by the 7.3-magnitude earthquake that battered central Taiwan Sept. 21, 1999.

Chen voiced his praise while visiting the Wusiu Bamboo Charcoal Kiln Cultural Park in Luku township, Nantou County. He said this vitality enables the Taiwanese people to "create the best possible future in a challenging living environment with limited resources."
"It is the very spirit of the Son of Taiwan, " Chen said.
The president conducted a tour of the central Taiwan county, the area worst-hit by the biggest earthquake to hit Taiwan in a century, earlier in the day.

On his visit to the park, Chen expressed admiration for bamboo charcoal and various bamboo charcoal-derived products produced at the park, an outlet of the bamboo charcoal industry that was established after the 921 earthquake as part of efforts to rebuild business in the area.
Chen described the charcoal, made of locally grown moso strain of bamboo, as "black diamond" and a miracle born from the ruins of the 921 earthquake.

Each year, the bamboo kiln cultural park attracts over 200,000 visitors and produces a wide variety of bamboo charcoal-derived products ranging from clothing to foods, according to the park's operator.

The epicenter of the 921 earthquake was near Chichi township in Nantou County, 150 km south southwest of Taipei. It caused over 2,400 deaths and more than 11,000 injuries, and destroyed tens of thousands of houses and buildings.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong Chinese culture will reduce identity challenge: scholar

TEXT.P: A visiting academic said in a speech in Taipei Saturday that what is essential regarding the future of Chinese culture is "the quality of the modern culture that China itself can ultimately generate" and that by the time an attractive and well-respected Chinese culture is generated, it will reduce the problem of self-identity to much more manageable proportions.

Wang Guangwu, an expert in Southeast Asian studies who holds a distinguished faculty position at the National University of Singapore, made the remarks in a speech titled "What Kind of Chinese? Southeast Asian Variations, " to share his unique perspective on the topic of identity, an issue that often plagues overseas Chinese in Southeast Asia.
"If China can ultimately generate a culture that is seen by everybody as attractive and is well-respected, then Chinese cultures in any country can be sustained and grow, " Wang said.
According to Wang, there are three kinds of overseas Chinese -- the faithful, the peripheral and the marginal.

The faithful are those who identify themselves as only Chinese and retain close links to China emotionally. The peripherals are those who understand the nature of Chinese culture but enjoy the richness of local cultures, while the marginal are Chinese descendants from settlers who arrived a long time ago and who have moved away from the culture of their ancestors and have developed their own cultures, he said.
Infusing tradition with new modern features that everybody can associate with China would reduce the problem to much more manageable proportions, he said.

Overseas Chinese in Malaysia and Singapore face a series of identity challenges he said, adding that changes within China, as well as the complex interactions with the British colonial authorities, all affect the identity issue.

Since the 1950s, several kinds of nationalism have demanded redefinitions of identity, while globalization, regionalism and the rise of China have each begun to attract those of Chinese descent in different ways.

Wang, a pioneer and leading authority on the study of Southeast Asian Chinese societies who was born in Indonesia and raised in Malaysia, shares the same experience and identity problem that has tugged at thousands of overseas Chinese.
His speech was one of the MediaTek International Lecture Series sponsored by the MediaTek Company and organized by the Lung Yingtai Cultural Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government will not invest in 'Taiwan Goal' defense firm: Cabinet

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has issued an instruction that no government funds will be used to bankroll a controversial joint venture defense company, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said Saturday.

Chen made the remarks in a news conference during which he announced the resignation of Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu, who said he had not "properly" implemented the establishment of Taiwan Goal, a private arms firm set up last month. Chen also announced Lee's successor, Tsai Ming-shian.
Chen noted that the government had originally hoped that the company could help upgrade the nation's defense industry.

But he lamented that opposition lawmakers have "grilled and smeared" Chang and related Cabinet members over what they called a "suspicious source of the company's funds" -- almost entirely from government agencies and state- controlled corporations.
Chen said government funds will not be channeled into Taiwan Goal and that the company will have to depend on itself for funding.
"If the government wants to buy weaponry, it will not commission the company to make the purchases," he said.

"No government funds have yet entered the company, the company has not signed contract with the government and the government has not commissioned it to purchase weaponry," he reaffirmed, adding that the government will "not spend even one dime" investing in the project or any other private arms firms related to the defense industry.

Asked whether Taiwan Goal Chairman Wu Nai-jen, a heavyweight of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and head of the China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of Taiwan-based China Steel Corp. in which the government has more than 20 percent stakes -- will stay in his post, Chen said that is his own business.

Wu issued a news release earlier that day that the controversy surrounding the project, has "switched the focus of helping develop the nation's defense industry, which was the purpose of forming the company."

"The company will not be able to maintain its private enterprise capacity now and its existence has become meaningless under the circumstances, " Wu said, adding that he will soon call a shareholders' meeting to discuss the disbanding of the company.

Chen said the government had acted in accordance with the National Defense Act and the Organic Act of the Armament Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense to cooperate with private enterprises to develop the defense industry.

On an allegation leveled by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chang Hsien- yao that Taiwan Goal negotiated with France last month to buy Rafale jet fighters, Chen said that this kind of information "is not suitable for public disclosure."
He noted that China has continued to squeeze Taiwan by preventing other foreign countries from selling it weaponry, putting the nation into a very difficult plight.
Moreover, the company has only engaged in initial contacts with arms suppliers, he went on, adding that "random speculation may undermine national security."
Taiwan Goal registered with the Ministry of Economic Affairs Jan. 28 as a private company, with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million.

According to information provided by the Executive Yuan, the first-stage capital of the company will be NT$200 million. The initial funding of NT$80 million has been collected, including NT$50 million from China Steel Machinery Corp. and NT$30 million from a subsidiary of Chunghwa Telecom.

But NT$90 million from the Ministry of National Defense, which had planned to hold 45 percent of the company shares and was the largest shareholder under the original plan, and NT$30 million from the Yao Hua Glass Co. -- a company under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- had yet to be injected.

DOC.HEADLINE: New meals to be included in meal delivery service: CEPD

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Saturday that it has commissioned welfare groups to develop health-conscious meals for the elderly and will include them in its delivery service.
CEPD officials said that under the government's "mega warmth" project, they have targeted meal deliveries as the most basic and urgent service for the elderly.
According to Ministry of the Interior statistics, the number of elderly in Taiwan had reached 2.38 million as of the end of October 2007, with about 320,000 living alone.
With the population continuing to age, the government has taken the initiative to help with meal delivery services for these elderly people, the officials said.

The CEPD conducted a survey on meal deliveries to solitary elders in cities and counties around the nation last year and found that the existing operation has problems such as an insufficient volunteer network, while menus, calories and taste have proved unsatisfactory.

The CEPD therefore commissioned the Hondao Senior Citizen's Welfare Foundation in Taichung, central Taiwan, to conduct a project last October to integrate eateries, welfare groups and women wanting to create their own businesses for the meal delivery services.
According to the survey among the elderly in Taichung, they tend to eat out mostly for lunch, and 80.8 percent of them prefer rice-based meals.

When they eat out, they consider the factors of environmental hygiene, food freshness and price, in that order. They also hope that meals delivered to their homes will be priced at between NT$51 and NT$70 (US$1.7-US$2.15).
The 10 newly developed meals, priced between NT$60 and NT$65, will make their debut in early March for test sales, with delivery services starting at a later date.

DOC.HEADLINE: New defense minister to withdraw from presidential campaign

TEXT.P: Defense Minister-designate Tsai Ming-hsian will withdraw from campaigning for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential ticket after assuming his new post, a close friend of Tsai said Saturday.

"Tsai has to stop his involvement in presidential campaign affairs to maintain administrative neutrality and devote himself wholeheartedly to Defense Ministry work, " said Tsai's friend, speaking on condition of anonymity.

Meanwhile, Chang Liao Wan-chien, a Taichung city councilor, described Tsai's appointment as a suitable personnel arrangement, saying he is a man of integrity and diligence who is capable and experienced.

"Tsai is no stranger to defense affairs, as he has served as deputy defense minister and as deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council, " said Chang Liao, who served as top campaign manager of Tsai's unsuccessful bid for a legislative seat in the Jan. 12 elections.

During his two terms as legislator from 1996-2002, Tsai was on the Defense Committee and once served as its convener, an experience that enabled him to get a full grasp of the country's defense posture and military strength, Chang Liao said.

But a political analyst said Tsai, who is now an adviser to the Ministry of National Defense (MND), will face a host of tough tasks as the first defense minister from the DPP, which has a scant support base in the military.
The Executive Yuan announced Tsai's appointment as the new defense minister earlier in the day after Lee Tien-yu abruptly resigned over a dispute surrounding a defense firm.

Lee resigned after opposition lawmakers accused members of the DPP administration of seeking to profit from the defense company, named Taiwan Goal, which is headed by Wu Nai-jen, a DPP heavyweight who maintains close ties with Vice Premier Chiou I-jen.

"I deeply regret that the establishment of Taiwan Goal caused concerns and doubts in various sectors and I hereby tender my resignation, " Lee said in a brief statement posted on the MND Web site late Friday.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung promptly approved Lee's resignation and appointed Tsai as his successor.

The first test for Tsai is to maintain stability in the military ahead of the presidential election, the analyst said, adding that the precarious cross-Taiwan Strait military situation could also be great challenge.

"With less than a month to go before the March 22 presidential poll, Tsai must settle the dust and ripples from the bungled Taiwan Goal project as quickly as possible to boost military morale and maintain combat readiness," the analyst said.

As the main opposition Kuomintang, which now holds an absolute majority in the Legislative Yuan, had attributed its defeat in the 2004 presidential election partly to the alleged MND restrictions on absence of leave on the voting day, the analyst said Tsai will definitely come under intensive supervision by the opposition camp over the MND planning to enable as many service members as possible to return home to cast ballots this time around.
The KMT, who used to be in power for more than 50 years, commands astrong support base in the military.

Although the MND said last week it has not detected any abnormal or unusual movement of the Chinese army amid the heat of presidential campaign in Taiwan, the analyst said, Tsai cannot afford any lapse or negligence in guard against unexpected developments in the Taiwan Strait situation.
"Ensuring military stability and smooth proceeding of the presidential election will be Tsai's top mission before the country's new president takes office on May 20," the analyst said.

In the face of China's continued expansion of its military might, Tsai has consistently advocated closer Taiwan-U.S.-Japan cooperation to maintain East Asian stability and peace, using the U.S.-Japan defense treaty and the Taiwan Relations Act as a platform.

Tsai traveled to the United States to pursue a doctoral degree after graduating from National Taiwan University's Department of Law. As he maintained frequent contacts with political dissidents in Taiwan during his stay in the United States, he was barred from returning to Taiwan to take up a teaching job in 1982 when Taiwan was still under martial law. He did not return until 1990 after the lifting of the martial law.

He started his political career with a seat on the now defunct National Assembly and later won a legislative seat. He switched to the administrative job after the DPP won the presidency in 2000. He first served as the country's deputy representative to the United States before returning to take up the post of deputy defense minister in 2004. He resigned from his post as NSC deputy secretary-general in 2006 to prepare for the legislative race in his hometown of Taichung City, which he lost.

DOC.HEADLINE: Coastal nursery grounds planned to rejuvenate fishery resources

TEXT.P: The Penghu county government plans to set up nursery grounds along its coastline to facilitate rejuvenation of its coastal fishery resources after the recent abnormal cold weather devastated its fishing industry, a local official said Saturday.

Cheng Ming-yuan, director of the county's Fishery Bureau, revealed the plan during a seminar that brought together local and central government officials as well as academics and experts to discuss post-disaster relief measures.
Describing the cold spell-inflicted damage to the offshore county's fishing industry as the "worst in 30 years, " Cheng said regeneration of shallow nursery grounds is urgent and imperative.

"We are pondering to designate certain selected coastal areas as conservation sanctuaries in which fish eels will be released, cultured and protected," Cheng said, adding that the measure is aimed at facilitating growth of fishy resources and recovery of marine ecology in the county's coastal regions.
As a fishing ban will be imposed on the protected waters, Cheng said the nursery grounds regeneration project may draw backlash from local fishermen.

"The county government will launch a publicity campaign after finalizing the rejuvenation plan next Tuesday to seek understanding and support from local fishermen," Cheng said, adding that the Penghu Prosecutor's Office has promised to cooperate with the county government and the Coast Guard Administration in policing the protected areas.

Chen Tien-shou, deputy head of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture, led an 11-member delegation composed on fishing administrators, marine ecologists and fishery experts to attend the seminar and conduct a field survey of the causes of the devastation and the extent of damage to the county's marine ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC official sees slim possibility of changing referendum date

TEXT.P: The possibility of altering the date for two referendums on Taiwan's U.N. membership bid is slim, if not nil, a Central Election Commission (CEC) official said Saturday.

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you made the remarks a day after former President Lee Teng-hui appealed for separating the two controversial referendums from the March 22 presidential election to spare Taiwan a "crisis" that the implementation of the referendums might bring it.

Noting that any change to the date of the two referendums requires the approval of a majority of CEC commissioners, Teng said he has not received any information showing that CEC commissioners are prepared to hold a new round of meeting to address the issue.
Since the CEC officially sanctioned the holding of the two referendums alongside the March 22 presidential election on Feb. 1, Teng said, the CEC has been working on voting preparations.
"We are now ready for printing of referendum ballots and election gazette," Tengs said, adding that judging from this situation, the possibility of changing the referendum date is very low.

Claiming that if the two referendums fail to pass the legal threshold, the international community would have a mistaken interpretation of Taiwan people's willingness to join the U.N., Lee said such a result would cause "irreparable damage" to Taiwan.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) have each initiated a referendum regarding Taiwan's pursuit of U.N. membership. The two referendums will be held alongside the presidential election.

The DPP-initiated question asks voters if they support joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan," while the KMT-initiated question asks voters if they support re-entry to the world body under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.
Both China and the United States have voiced objections to the DPP's referendum initiative, which they described as a move toward Taiwan's independence.

La Repubblica: Great leap of prices.
The inflation rate of high-frequency buys which include supermarket, fuel, bar and restaurant prices, was registered at 4.8 percent in January, a record high in 11 years, according to a report by the national statistics agency ISTAT. The overall inflation rate for the month was 2.9 percent, the highest since July of 2001, it says.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 24, or the 18th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I, who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1885: Chester Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific Fleet during World War II, is born. He halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers.
1891: The Ching court pays an indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese in China. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: U.S. forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in parliament just after declaring war on the Axis powers.
1946: Juan Peron is elected president of Argentina.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced into exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: U.S. and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1972: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with Malta.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1976: A nine-member economic mission of Japan's Sankei Shimbun newspaper led by Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the newspaper, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: U.S. President Jimmy Carter cuts off U.S. aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia because of human rights violations.
1978: Construction of the first-phase of the Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and opened to traffic.
1989: Funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who had reigned since 1926, are held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes the new emperor.
1990: Malcolm Forbes, American tycoon, escort of Elizabeth Taylor and owner of "Forbes Magazine," dies.
1997: A fire at a Hindu pilgrim encampment in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 people.
2000: Chung Jung-chi, a minister without portfolio and a key member of the Kuomintang's election machine, announces his resignation from public office and also from the party in a "consciousness-raising" move.
2004: A Taiwan-developed hybrid car powered by an internal combustion engine and an electric motor is unveiled.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."
