DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: IAEA says Iran yet to come clean
The Bush administration stepped up its campaign for tougher sanctions against Iran on Friday after a U.N. report concluded that Tehran had not fully come clean about past activities that U.S. experts say were part of a secret nuclear weapons program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan tug of war team wins gold medal in world championships

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese women's tug of war team won the title in the senior 520-kg division in the World Indoor Championships 2008 held in Italy Saturday, Chinese Taipei Tug of War Association officials said Sunday.

The team, made up mainly of athletes from the Taipei Physical Education College, beat semi-finalist China in two straight games to win gold in the senior 520 women division held in Faenza, the officials said.

The team, which won world championships in competitions held in Ireland in 2006 and Germany in 2005, was expected to continue its powerful performance to win another champion in the senior 480 women category Sunday, the officials went on.
Saturday's win also gave the team a ticket to take part in competitions in the World Games 2009 in Kaohsiung, the officials added.

All six winning teams in the senior 520 women category in the World Indoor Championships will be eligible to compete in the 2009 World Games, they noted. The five other teams are China, Japan, England, Scotland and Ukraine, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Tibetan Olympics' torch arrives in Taipei

TEXT.P: A group of Tibetans living in Taiwan and and their Taiwanese friends called for support Sunday for a "Tibetan Olympics" in a bid to denigrate Beijing, which has barred Tibet from entering a delegation to the 2008 Olympic Games to be held in Beijing in August.

A ceremony marking the symbolic arrival of the so-called "Tibetan Olympics torch" was held at the Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in Taipei Sunday under the sponsorship of Tibetans living in Taipei and the private group Taiwan Friends of Tibet.
People shouted "Free Tibet" and waved banners reading "Boycott Beijing Olympics" on the Taipei leg of the torch relay, led by Miss Tibet 2006 Tsering Chungtak.

Speaking at a news conference, Chungtak -- who quit a beauty pageant in Malaysia last year over China's pressure to have her "Miss Tibet" sash replaced with one reading "Miss Tibet-China" -- said the Tibetan Olympics torch relay is being carried out to demonstrate the importance of freedom and human rights for Tibetan people and how they have been deprived of their right to take part in international athletic games like the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
Chungtak -- who arrived in Taipei Feb. 19 at the invitation of the Miss Taiwan Beauty Contest organizers -- said Tibetans are peace-loving people who also have good sportsmanship.

Meanwhile, Chou Mei-li, president of the Taiwan Friends of Tibet, said that in order to protest against Beijing's denial of participation by Tibetans in the Olympics, the "Tibetan Olympics" and a worldwide torch relay are designed to let the world know better how the Tibetan people have been discriminated against politically by China.

The "Tibetan Olympics" -- slated to be held May 15-25 in Dharamsala, northern India, where the Tibetan government-in-exile is based -- is an initiative to offer a platform for young Tibetans to celebrate the spirit of the Olympics, according to Chou.

The "Tibetan Olympics torch, " which departed from Delhi Jan. 30, will go around the world, making one full circle touching 10 major cities in five continents, including Sydney, Taipei, Tokyo, Maui, San Francisco, New York City, London and Jerusalem, according to the organizers.

Tsering Chungtak said in Taipei several days ago that she did not regret making the decision to quit the Malaysian beauty pageant in protest against Beijing's bullying. The 22-year-old is a student at the University of Delhi in India.

She said she will follow the Dalai Lama's moderate approach in dealing with China. Tibet is currently officially claimed and administered by China, although many Tibetans place their allegiance with the exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fishery disaster caused by cold water current from China: academic

TEXT.P: The recent massive fish die-off in outlying Penghu County was mainly caused by a cold water current from China rather than by the abnormally cold spell of the past month, as many had previously thought, a local oceanologist said over the weekend.
National Taiwan Ocean University President Lee Kuo-tien aired the view while conducting a field survey of disaster zones in the island county off the southwestern coast of Taiwan.

According to Lee, snowmelt from heavy snowstorms that hit many parts of China in late January and early February flowed into China's southeastern coastal waters, which then drifted through the seas off Penghu.

Noting that the low-temperature, low-salt water flow from China impeded the Kuroshio Current, also known as the Black Stream, which usually flows around Penghu bringing warm, tropical currents northward, Lee said water temperatures in coastal Penghu consequently dropped sharply and led to a massive fish die-off in the county that depends on the fishing industry as the backbone of its economy.

In his observation, Lee said the so-called "M-type" phenomenon in socioeconomic development is also seen in meteorology, meaning that tropical regions have become ever hotter, while cold and polar regions are getting increasingly colder, just as the rich are getting richer and the poor becoming ever poorer.

"And both such climatic phenomena can affect Penghu, as it is located between tropical and colder regions, " Lee said, adding that since the entire global ecosystem has changed, the so-called 30-year cycle of fishery cold disaster in Penghu could also be broken.
He suggested that an efficient alarm and monitoring system be crafted to facilitate prevention of similar disasters in future.

Lee was among a score of scholars and experts in marine ecology, coral reefs, fish species and climatic changes, as well as central government officials, who had traveled from Taiwan proper to the outlying island to study the cause of the recent disaster, the extent of damage to fishing grounds and feasible relief measures.

The group was led by Chen Tien-shou, deputy director of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture. Among the members were Shao Kwang-tsao, director of Academia Sinica's Research Center for Biodiversity, and National Taiwan University professors Chiu Tai-sheng and Tai Chang-feng.
In addition to inspecting the two hardest-hit regions -- Chingwan Bay and Houliao Beach -- the group held a seminar with Penghu county officials, including Magistrate Wang Chien-fa.
Cheng Ming-yuan, director of the county's Fishery Bureau, first gave a briefing on the county's fishery losses.
According to Cheng, 44 tons of dead fish had been cleared from beaches around the county in the past 10 days. "There are also numerous dead fish on the sea bed," he added.
All the academics present at the colloquium agreed that the county government need not bother to clean up the dead fish on the sea bed, saying Mother Nature will dispose of them.
A marine ecologist noted that dead fish become part of the food chain, which will in turn contribute to conservation of fishery resources.

The scholars and experts were also reserved about the county government's plan to release eels into designated coastal waters to spur rejuvenation of fish stocks, saying such moves may sabotage the delicate natural balance among fish species.

They offered many recommendations on how to forge an efficient alarm and monitoring system to prevent recurrence of any massive fishery disaster. They also presented opinions on the formulation of short-, middle- and long-term marine policy to benefit both marine resource conservation and bolster the county's economic development.

Penghu Magistrate Wang said after the meeting that Fisheries Administration Deputy Director Chen Tien-shou had promised to assist the county government in surveying damaged fishing grounds along its beautiful coastline and establishing a monitoring and tracking mechanism.

DOC.HEADLINE: President defends 'private channel' for arms procurement

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Sunday that there are precedents in foreign countries to make arms procurements via privately run companies.

Chen said Taiwan faces difficulties seeking to obtain advanced arms or weaponry systems from industrially advanced countries via official channels, given the country's constrained diplomatic situation.

The president made the remarks in an indirect response to the resignation the day before of Minister of National Defense Lee Tien-yu over the controversy surrounding the formation of the private arms firm Taiwan Goal in the wake of heavy and lengthy complaints by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators. The KMT legislators questioned the legitimacy of Taiwan Goal, which was established with public funds but will be beyond the control of the Ministry of National Defense and the legislature.

Lee said in a news release posted on the Ministry of National Defense Web site a day earlier that he had set his mind on implementing the nation's defense policy and upgrading its defense capability ever since assuming the post last May. "Although I was instructed to establish Taiwan Goal, I have failed to carry out the plan properly and have caused misgivings among the public about the project, for which I have to step down," Lee's statement said.
The president made the remarks during a visit to Chen I-chiu, a former presidential adviser appointed by Chen in 2001, in the southern county of Kaohsiung, according to Chen I-chiu's family.

Chen I-chiu was quoted by his family as having asked the president about how the government will help China-based Taiwanese businessmen relocate their investments back to Taiwan from China now that the Chinese government has imposed new, stricter regulations governing taxation, environmental and labor conditions.
The president said it is only natural that Taiwanese businessmen would choose to return home from China in the wake of the change in the investment climate there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential debate showcases election platforms

TEXT.P: Presidential hopefuls Frank Hsieh and Ma Ying-jeou went head- to-head in the first of two crucial televised debates Sunday with the election less than four weeks away.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Hsieh and Ma, who represents the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), looked confident and prepared in the first segment of the debate, which included 20 pre- recorded questions in video format from citizens.

The debate was seen as an important platform for both to appeal to the electorate for support in the March 22 election, as well as a chance for Hsieh to close the gap between them, as he has been trailing in most public opinion polls since the campaign began last year.

Hsieh and Ma were asked to answer questions from 20 citizens, including Lo Chao- hsun, who is known for heckling President Chen Shui-bian in public, and Su Chien-ho, a convicted murderer whose controversial death sentence is still under review by the Taiwan High Court.
Both candidates only exchanged friendly fire in the first 10 questions, although Hsieh occasionally took jabs at Ma.
The debate was organized by the CNA, the Public Television Service Foundation and four local newspapers.

In the first two sections of the program, according to the rules, Hsieh and Ma had to respond to the 20 videotaped questions selected by the organizers from among 456 questions contributed to PeoPo, a Web site specially set up for the general public to express their concerns on the Internet over the candidates, their policies, and the future of Taiwan.

The 20 people chosen were then given the opportunity to question both candidates directly at the debate, based on the candidates' answers to the videotaped questions, which included such issues as the identity of Taiwan and its people, Taiwan's participation in the Kyoto Protocol, same-sex marriage, the promotion of aboriginal culture, social welfare and economic development.
In the third section of the program, each presidential hopeful challenged his opponent with three questions, with responses requiring to be made within a time limit of one minute.
At the end of the program, Hsieh and Ma were each given three minutes to make concluding remarks.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Consumers to protest against price hike.
Italian consumer groups threaten to take to streets in protest against hike of prices for daily needs. The inflation rate of high-frequency buys was registered at 4.8 percent in January, a record high in 11 years, according to a report by the national statistics agency ISTAT.

DOC.HEADLINE: World fuel crisis slims Taiwan's car market

TEXT.P: Statistics indicate that new car registrations in Taiwan have declined over 30 percent in two years, a clear sign that the country's car market is continuing to shrink as a possible result of soaring global oil prices, according to a press report issued Saturday by the Taipei City Motor Vehicles Office.

In 2007 366,022 new cars were registered nationwide, showing a 9.6 percent decline year-on-year, according to the press report. Compared with the 2005 figure of 545,856, the downsizing could be expanded to a 33 percent decline, the report said.
The report attributed the decline mainly to high crude oil prices and a weakening global economy.
Another possible reason could be that car loans are getting tougher, as banks all over the world tighten their lending policies, the report said.

In contrast, mass transport was given a boost, with passenger numbers hitting a record of high of 1.04 billion in Taipei in 2007, representing an increase of more than 4 percent year-on-year, showing that urban commuters are more inclined to use public transport.

The economic slump has also forced car buyers to turn to the used car market, with a recorded 1.37 million car registration changes in 2007, showing a 20,000 year-on-year increase, the report pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taitra to help Taiwanese companies crack Muslim food markets

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (Taitra) is working to help Taiwanese companies gain a foothold in food markets in Muslim countries around the world, Taitra officials said Sunday.

Taitra is collaborating with the Taipei Grand Mosque in sponsoring a business workshop slated for March 27 in Taipei in which food certification experts from Asian countries in which Muslims are one of the major ethnic groups will be invited to provide consultation to local companies interested in exporting their food products to the Muslim world, the officials said.
Those Asian countries include Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia and Thailand, they added.
Only food products containing no pork or lard and carrying Halal certification can be sold in Muslim food markets, they noted.

They said food products carrying made-in-Taiwan labels enjoy a good reputation in the world market for quality and packaging, while the number of foreign buyers attending international food shows in Taipei and Kaohsiung has also increased steadily year-on-year.
Nevertheless, they said, many buyers from Asian countries have complained that they have seen very few made-in-Taiwan food products carrying Halal certification.
Taiwan thus far has no agency authorized to issue Halal certification, which is recognition that the products are permissible under Islamic law and can therefore be eaten, drunk or used by Muslims.
Halal is an Arabic word meaning "lawful."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign Ministry takes U.S. report as reference

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will take as a reference a U.S. think tank report urging the United States to rebuild a bilateral agenda with Taiwan, and will continue to communicate with Washington, Ministry spokeswoman Phoebe Yeh said Sunday.

Yeh was referring to a report titled "Strengthening Freedom in Asia: A Twenty- First Century Agenda for the U.S.-Taiwan Partnership, " released Friday by the U.S.-based American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research.

The report suggests that Washington relax restrictions on high-level Taiwanese officials communicating directly with the U.S. government and that the two countries establish a task force governing U.S.-Taiwan defense relations.

The report urges the United States to give priority to enacting a free trade agreement with Taiwan and not to succumb to Chinese pressure to snub Taiwan, while also suggesting that Taiwan lift a ban on investment in China.
Yeh said the report stresses the importance of relations between the United States and Taiwan and that a more positive and productive bilateral agenda between the two sides should be forged.
The report also expresses hope for smooth development of U.S.-Taiwan relations, Yeh noted.
In her view, Yeh said, "the bilateral relations between the two countries rely on a solid and consolidated foundation, but there is still ample room for expansion."

As the ministry has its own goals and methods for improving relations with Washington, Yeh said, it will continue to strengthen bilateral communication in addition to taking the report into consideration.

The two main authors of the study -- Randall Schriver, a former deputy assistant secretary of state for Asia-Pacific affairs who now works in the private sector and Dan Blumenthal, a former Pentagon official-- are slated to release the report Feb. 25 at a seminar in Taipei. Foreign Minister James Huang will deliver a speech during the seminar, according to Yeh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet moves to curb consumer price hikes

TEXT.P: A Cabinet-level task force has moved to investigate price manipulation and has adopted various measures to stabilize prices after sharp hikes in consumer prices, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Sunday.
The measures include a halving of tariffs on seven imported commodities for six months and various approaches to maintain low prices for oil, electricity and water, Chang added.

Meanwhile, a price stabilization task force under the Executive Yuan has also intensified its efforts to look into whether there has been artificial manipulation behind soaring prices for necessities.

In addition, the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced last Wednesday a ban on exports of locally produced rebar and small steel billets -- important materials for construction -- for a period of three months to counter a recent domestic shortage, Chang noted.

The Cabinet is also considering to remove the 5 percent business tax on bulk communities by submitting amendments to the Value-Added Business Tax Act to the Legislative Yuan for approval, according to Chang.
Chang made the remarks in response to inquiries about reports that prices of flour, butter and milk powder have more than doubled in a year, causing the closure of more than 600 bakeries.

"How to diminish the impact of soaring consumer prices on the daily lives of the people has always been the primary concern and major administrative goal of the Cabinet, " Chang said, adding that the task force will continue to keep track of price fluctuations of important consumer goods and come up with response measures.

The consumer price index (CPI) is forecast to reach 3 percent for the first half of the year, with 3 percent for the first quarter, 3.1 percent for the second quarter, according to the latest report from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS).
However, the CPI will amount to 1.98 percent, according to the DGBAS report.

The DGBAS forecast was made after taking into account the impact of potentially higher international oil and raw material prices, according to the report, which said that based on a forecast by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the price of crude oil is expected to average US$88 per barrel in January, a 74.3 percent increase over the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential hopefuls stress support for gay rights

TEXT.P: Both presidential hopefuls called Sunday for respect for and tolerance of homosexuals in their first face-to-face televised debate, but fell short of promising to legalize same-sex marriages.

Gay societies and activists, however, expressed dissatisfaction with the two candidates in a press release immediately following the debate, complaining that "their answers lacked foresight and failed to give real and concrete responses to the issue."

In response to questions about gay issues raised by a citizen in the first of two debates, Ma Ying-jeou, representing the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said that "sex orientation is by nature deserving of respect and toleration, " adding that "people need to learn how to tolerate and appreciate homosexuality."
As mayor of Taipei between 1998 and 2006, Ma went on, his administration allocated a special budget for gay activities in 1999.
"Taipei is the freest city in Asia for homosexuals," according to Ma.

Saying that there should not be any discrimination against gay love, Frank Hsieh, the presidential hopeful of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), add that he respects human rights and that society should look at gay issues with an open mind.
Despite expressing sympathy for gay rights, however, neither Ma nor Hsieh committed themselves to legalizing same-sex marriages, saying only that the matter needs to be further reviewed.

Reaffirming his attitude toward human rights and the rights of homosexuals, Ma said same-sex marriage would require an amendment to the Civil Law and that society would need to reach consensus on the issue.
"I respect same-sex marriage, but it has to be cautiously planned, " Ma said, adding that "we still need to struggle for equal rights for gays."
Meanwhile, according to Hsieh, marriage can be diversified, but people should take "culture" and "family" into consideration when talking about same-sex marriage.

Ma and Hsieh made the remarks in the debate organized by the CNA, the Public Television Foundation and four local newspapers. The organizers consider the debate to be a decisive factor in the presidential campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of visitors to Pingtung agriculture fair breaks 300,000 mark

TEXT.P: The Pingtung Tropical Agriculture Exposition greeted its 300,000th visitor Sunday with souvenirs, as the fair organized to promote agricultural products in the southern Taiwan county set a new visitor record in its four-year history.

The lucky visitor, Cheng Yu-chuan, a woman from Taipei in northern Taiwan, was presented with a bicycle, a bouquet of roses and a pumpkin, by the Council of Agriculture Chairman Su Jia-chyuan and Pingtung Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung.

In anticipation of the arrival of the 300,000th visitor since the opening of this year's fair in early February, the Pingtung county government, which organizes the event, invited Su and prepared gifts a day before to welcome the visitor.
Su, who used to serve as the county's magistrate, noted that the fair was launched during his term and thanked the current county government for making it better.
Tsao said this year's fair will run through Feb. 28 and is expected to attract more than 500,000 people, far exceeding the 300,000 from original projections.
This year's event is the first time the fair is open to the public free of charge, except for a clean-up fee of NT$50.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's presidential candidates spar off in first televised debate

TEXT.P: Taiwan's presidential candidates Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh on Sunday tried to point out each other's weaknesses in their first televised debate, with Ma suggesting Hsieh's proposed tax cuts were inadequate and Hsieh raising further questions about Ma's loyalty to the island.

But both candidates presented similar positions on China -- agreeing it was necessary to hold talks with Beijing, and pledging to allow direct charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland within two or three months if elected.

At the first of two head-to-head debates before the March 22 election, both candidates agreed that it will be necessary to negotiate with China and have the two sides call off their battle on the diplomatic front.

Front runner Ma, from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was adamant that China must stop its attempts to suffocate Taiwan in the international arena, while Hsieh, from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , stressed that the ruling and opposition parties must remain united when negotiating with China over this issue.
Hsieh said charter flight services between Taiwan and mainland China could be expanded to become weekly flights between multiple destinations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Ma said in addition to charter flights, he would push for the operation of regular flights through cross-strait negotiation over air traffic rights. Ma added that with direct transport links between the two sides, Taiwanese entrepreneurs would not need to move their production bases to China.
Both candidates agreed that any direct flight services should be based on the premise that Taiwan's security would not be affected.

During the two-hour and 45-minute debate, each candidate was asked to answer 20 questions from pre-recorded video tapes submitted by members of the public. The selected questioners were allowed to ask follow-up questions at the debate. In the second part of the debate, they were required to answer three questions from each other, with the third part allowing each of them three minutes for a conclusion.

The questions covered a wide range of subjects, including relations with China, the national economy, ways to protect Taiwan's farmers, education of the young generation, and punishment for corrupt government officials.
In response to public concerns that wages in Taiwan have failed to keep up with inflation, Hsieh said he favored a reduction in income, sales and in inheritance taxes as a solution.
Ma, however, said tax cuts proposed by Hsieh was not enough.

"Cutting taxes is not the best solution. Economic restrictions must be relaxed. There must be direct transport links between the two sides of the Strait, in order to attract foreign investment to Taiwan," Ma said.

Ma, instead, called for increased public investment, salary raises and increased consumer spending, plus relaxing restrictions on economic relations with China to allow direct transportation between Taiwan and China, in order to attract more foreign investment to Taiwan.

Hsieh, however, criticizes Ma's proposal as deficit spending. "Vote for Ma Ying- jeou, and each household will have to write Ma Ying-jeou aNT$400,000 bounced check, " Hsieh said, referring to how much the deficit budget would cost each household and emphasizing that Taiwan could not afford such spending.

Ma said that his economic blueprint would allow Taiwan to maintain an economic growth rate of at least 6 percent, increase the nation's per capita income to US$20,000 by 2011 and US$30,000 by 2016, and keep the jobless rate below 3 percent. Hsieh said he would attach more importance to the purchasing power, and that he would try to keep the real purchasing power for an average citizen at around US$30,000 or even more per year.

The two candidates also promised to increase financial aid to Taiwan's cultural and creative industries and allow the outlying island chain Penghu, located about 50 kilometers west of Taiwan proper, to set up gambling casinos with appropriate safeguard measures.
Hsieh, who is trailing behind Ma in the opinion polls by up to 20 points according to some polls, spent much of the debate attacking his opponent.

He lost no opportunity to once again raise questions, as he's done recently, about Ma once possessing permanent resident status in the United States -- suggesting lack of loyalty to Taiwan. But Ma explained that although he obtained permanent residence to get a student loan when pursuing his graduate education in the United States in the late 1970s, he gave up the status over 20 years ago after returning to Taiwan.

Ma countered with a question that many of Hsieh's hand-picked officials were indicted on charges of corruption, but Hsieh rebutted that being indicted does not mean they are guilty, because the legal proceedings are not yet complete. Hsieh reminded Ma that he himself was also indicted on charges of misusing his special fees while serving as Taipei mayor.

The Taipei District Court and the Taiwan High court both ruled that Ma is not guilty of graft in 2007, but the prosecutors appealed the case to the Supreme Court in January. Although the Supreme Court has not set a date for hearing the case, it appears unlikely that a ruling might be made before the presidential election.
There were lighthearted moments in the debate - a rare occurrence in Taiwanese politics, but considered by some to be a good step toward democracy.

Asked by the moderator if they could say anything nice about each other, Ma said: "Frank Hsieh is very articulate, funny and humorous. He speaks good Japanese... He is caring towards his wife... He's good at exercising and can play the ceramic flute and the erhu (a Chinese string instrument)."

Hsieh cited Ma's merits, including his administrative experience, his mild temper and love for sports. Asked to name Ma's shortcomings, Hsieh said, "His only shortcoming is that he has too many strong points."

A second debate, scheduled for March 9, between Hsieh and Ma will adopt a different format, with the two candidates responding to questions from the six joint organizers of the two debates: the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential candidates praise each other before trading barbs in debate

TEXT.P: Taiwan's presidential hopefuls Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh took time to praise each other before trading barbs in the first of two crucial televised debates Sunday.

Ma, candidate of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), and Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate, were asked to name three qualities of their rival in the debate, which was something they almost never did since the campaign began last year.
The debate included 20 pre-recorded questions in video format from citizens.

"I can name more than three qualities of Mr. Hsieh, " Ma said, listing humor, Japanese proficiency, communication skills, and cooking as Hsieh's strengths. Ma also said he admired Hsieh's achievement as a high school gymnast.

Hsieh countered with humor: "The only weakness for Mr. Ma is that he has too many strengths." He gave Ma high marks on his language skills, experience as a public official, appearance and mild mannered personality.

The atmosphere, however, changed dramatically after the first segment of the event. Less than 10 minutes later in the question and answer period, both candidates attacked each other over the issue of integrity.

It was not easy to differentiate between Ma and Hsieh's platforms regarding agriculture, same-sex marriages, culture, environmental protection and major infrastructure construction projects, which were among various topics brought up in the 20 questions from citizens.

They had different views on how to stimulate the domestic economy, however, as Ma advocated closer agricultural and trade exchanges, further opening in regulation and market, and direct flights to China, while Hsieh held a more cautious and conservative view.
The debate was organized by the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service Foundation and four local newspapers. The second debate is scheduled to be held on March. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: Integrity issues heat up presidential debate

TEXT.P: In an otherwise unexciting debate with no surprises, presidential hopefuls Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh Sunday found themselves locked in close battle near the end of the first of two televised debates when the two questioned each other's integrity.

As the candidate for Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Hsieh fired the first shot by saying his opponent from Kuomintang (KMT) had failed to realize many of his campaign commitments during his eight- year term as the mayor of Taipei City, from 1998-2006.

Hsieh continued his attack by referring to Ma's rejections to previous charges against him, including embezzling the special mayoral funds and having a U.S. green card. Hsieh said Ma's words have been proven "unreliable and inconsistent" on several occasions.
"If a president-to-be cannot identify what he previously said about things such as whether he had a U.S. 'green card', how can the people ever trust him?" Hsieh said.
Ma has been acquitted by the Taiwan High Court on the embezzlement charges. He explained that he obtained the green card to apply for financial aid while he was a student in the United States.

Ma countered the attacks by challenging Hsieh's integrity as a government leader, pointing out that several former officials under Hsieh 's administration of Kaohsiung City, where he served as mayor, have been charged with corruption charges.
"How can Hsieh be responsible for the voters when his administration was shadowed by scandals?" Ma exclaimed.

Ma also indicated that during the DPP's eight-year administration, some central and local governments were "collectively corrupt, " saying Hsieh was purposely ignoring his and his party's wrongdoings.
Hsieh, like Ma, rejected his opponents' accusations.
Rejecting Ma's attacks, Hsieh said that many of the Kaohsiung officials involved in corruption prosecutions were not convicted.
"I have been very much straightforward in matters of personal morality and policies,... while Ma is the only presidential candidate ever prosecuted in the country's history," Hsieh said.
Ma defended himself by saying that as the mayor of Taipei City, his policies were often blocked by the DPP-ruled central government, and he has made no wrongful use of the mayoral funds.
"For eight years as mayor, none of my officials were prosecuted. As for the charges against me, the legitimacy of those investigations was under scrutiny," he added.
Responding to the green card dilemma, Ma strongly emphasized that neither him nor his family members have valid green cards currently.

DOC.HEADLINE: No negotiations on unification and independence: KMT candidate

TEXT.P: Presidential hopeful of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Ma Ying-jeou emphasized Sunday that he would never negotiate with China on unification and independence during his term if elected, spending much of the a rare televised debate defending his loyalty toward Taiwan.

Ma, who has made such a pledge against negotiating with China before, reiterated his stance in the first televised debate for the March 22 presidential election when asked about Taiwan's national identity.
He said that under his cross-Strait policy --no unification, no independence and no warfare -- he will never talk about unification and independence with China if elected.
"I am Taiwanese, and I am a citizen of the Republic of China," Ma stressed.

In the debate, Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party once again tried to raise doubts about Ma's loyalty toward Taiwan, and Ma, who was born in Hong Kong but was raised in Taiwan from the time he was a small child, once again had to define where his heart lie.
Ma said he is an upright and honest Taiwanese person and said he teaches his offsprings that "Taiwan is our mother land," pointing out that he would want to be buried in Taiwan.

"I am a real Taiwanese who was raised on Taiwan's water and food," Ma said, speaking in the Taiwanese dialect. In defense of his previous possession of a U.S. green card -- an issue his opponent has frequently brought up in recent days to raise doubts about his loyalty, Ma admitted that he once had a green card when he was a student in the U.S., but later gave it up. He said he got the green card to apply for student loans but relinquished his rights to longterm U.S. residency when he moved back to Taiwan about 20 years ago.
"It doesn't affect my recognition of and devotion for Taiwan," Ma claimed.
In response to Ma's claims, Hsieh said Ma's stance was inconsistent and said "I never hesitate to claim myself Taiwanese, and Taiwan is the place for me to live steadily."
According to Hsieh, Ma claimed himself as "a new Taiwanese" only 10 years ago, and then changed to "I am a Taiwanese, and also a Chinese" five years later.
"I never have the trouble to define where I am from," Hsieh said.

Hsieh, however, suggested that everyone should adopt "a broader and a more tolerant view of national identity, " adding that "one has to see himself not only as a Taiwanese but also a citizen of the world."

The debate organized by Taiwan's Central News Agency, the Public Television Foundation and four local newspapers, was aimed at providing two hopefuls, Ma and Hsieh a forum to give voters a better picture of how they would lead the nation in the coming four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientists' speeches now available live on Website

TEXT.P: A program to broadcast speeches by Taiwan's renowned scientists live on a Website was launched Sunday by the National Science Council (NSC) with the aim of fostering the public's, especially youngsters', interest in science.
The program was made possible thanks to software developed by the National Center for High-Performance Computing.

The software, titled Co-Life, enables the speech delivered by master scientists at the National Science Technology Museum in this port city in southern Taiwan to be transmitted instantly around the island on the Internet.

It was a milestone in the five-year-old program set up for students of senior occupational high schools as well as their teachers and the general public with the purpose of inspiring them to have an interest in and dedication to scientific and technological development.

People now are able to listen to and watch the speech via their computer as if they were on the spot, according to Yang Hung-duen, NSC deputy minister who presided over the inauguration of the Website broadcast in Kaohsiung.

Yang said the Website broadcast will provide easy access to these speech for people in the remote areas on the island, especially students in eastern Taiwan who are far away from the island's science hubs in southern and northern Taiwan, and therefore have less access to educational resources.

In order to showcase the benefits of the new system, Yang talked with Tsai Den- mo, president of the National Taitung University in the eastern county of Taitung through computers equipped with the Co-Life software during the inauguration.
Then the program broadcasted live on a Website a speech by Lien Chin-fa, a professor of the Hsinchu-based National Tsing Hua University, about the charms of language.

Under the program, the organizers invite established scientists to give speeches in various disciplines on specific weekends from the National Science and Technology Museum. Twelve speeches are scheduled to be given this year.

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Monday.

The weighted price index was up 120.21 points at 8,228.92 on a turnover of NT$5.99 billion (US$189.18 million) at the open. The index gained 22.78 points, or 0.28 percent, to close at 8,108.71 Friday.

The greenback was trading at NT$31.350 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.145 from Friday.

"I never have the trouble to define where I am from," Hsieh said.

Hsieh, however, suggested that everyone should adopt "a broader and a more tolerant view of national identity, " adding that "one has to see himself not only as a Taiwanese but also a citizen of the world."

The debate organized by Taiwan's Central News Agency, the Public Television Foundation and four local newspapers, was aimed at providing two hopefuls, Ma and Hsieh a forum to give voters a better picture of how they would lead the nation in the coming four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientists' speeches now available live on Website

TEXT.P: A program to broadcast speeches by Taiwan's renowned scientists live on a Website was launched Sunday by the National Science Council (NSC) with the aim of fostering the public's, especially youngsters', interest in science.
The program was made possible thanks to software developed by the National Center for High-Performance Computing.

The software, titled Co-Life, enables the speech delivered by master scientists at the National Science Technology Museum in this port city in southern Taiwan to be transmitted instantly around the island on the Internet.

It was a milestone in the five-year-old program set up for students of senior occupational high schools as well as their teachers and the general public with the purpose of inspiring them to have an interest in and dedication to scientific and technological development.

People now are able to listen to and watch the speech via their computer as if they were on the spot, according to Yang Hung-duen, NSC deputy minister who presided over the inauguration of the Website broadcast in Kaohsiung.

Yang said the Website broadcast will provide easy access to these speech for people in the remote areas on the island, especially students in eastern Taiwan who are far away from the island's science hubs in southern and northern Taiwan, and therefore have less access to educational resources.

In order to showcase the benefits of the new system, Yang talked with Tsai Den- mo, president of the National Taitung University in the eastern county of Taitung through computers equipped with the Co-Life software during the inauguration.
Then the program broadcasted live on a Website a speech by Lien Chin-fa, a professor of the Hsinchu-based National Tsing Hua University, about the charms of language.

Under the program, the organizers invite established scientists to give speeches in various disciplines on specific weekends from the National Science and Technology Museum. Twelve speeches are scheduled to be given this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's presidential candidates spar off in first televised debate

TEXT.P: Taiwan's presidential candidates Ma Ying-jeou and Frank Hsieh on Sunday tried to point out each other's weaknesses in their first televised debate, with Ma suggesting Hsieh's proposed tax cuts were inadequate and Hsieh raising further questions about Ma's loyalty to the island.

But both candidates presented similar positions on China -- agreeing it was necessary to hold talks with Beijing, and pledging to allow direct charter flights between Taiwan and the mainland within two or three months if elected.

At the first of two head-to-head debates before the March 22 election, both candidates agreed that it will be necessary to negotiate with China and have the two sides call off their battle on the diplomatic front.

Front runner Ma, from the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , was adamant that China must stop its attempts to suffocate Taiwan in the international arena, while Hsieh, from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , stressed that the ruling and opposition parties must remain united when negotiating with China over this issue.
Hsieh said charter flight services between Taiwan and mainland China could be expanded to become weekly flights between multiple destinations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Ma said in addition to charter flights, he would push for the operation of regular flights through cross-strait negotiation over air traffic rights. Ma added that with direct transport links between the two sides, Taiwanese entrepreneurs would not need to move their production bases to China.
Both candidates agreed that any direct flight services should be based on the premise that Taiwan's security would not be affected.

During the two-hour and 45-minute debate, each candidate was asked to answer 20 questions from pre-recorded video tapes submitted by members of the public. The selected questioners were allowed to ask follow-up questions at the debate. In the second part of the debate, they were required to answer three questions from each other, with the third part allowing each of them three minutes for a conclusion.

The questions covered a wide range of subjects, including relations with China, the national economy, ways to protect Taiwan's farmers, education of the young generation, and punishment for corrupt government officials.
In response to public concerns that wages in Taiwan have failed to keep up with inflation, Hsieh said he favored a reduction in income, sales and in inheritance taxes as a solution.
Ma, however, said tax cuts proposed by Hsieh was not enough.

"Cutting taxes is not the best solution. Economic restrictions must be relaxed. There must be direct transport links between the two sides of the Strait, in order to attract foreign investment to Taiwan," Ma said.

Ma, instead, called for increased public investment, salary raises and increased consumer spending, plus relaxing restrictions on economic relations with China to allow direct transportation between Taiwan and China, in order to attract more foreign investment to Taiwan.

Hsieh, however, criticizes Ma's proposal as deficit spending. "Vote for Ma Ying- jeou, and each household will have to write Ma Ying-jeou aNT$400,000 bounced check, " Hsieh said, referring to how much the deficit budget would cost each household and emphasizing that Taiwan could not afford such spending.

Ma said that his economic blueprint would allow Taiwan to maintain an economic growth rate of at least 6 percent, increase the nation's per capita income to US$20,000 by 2011 and US$30,000 by 2016, and keep the jobless rate below 3 percent. Hsieh said he would attach more importance to the purchasing power, and that he would try to keep the real purchasing power for an average citizen at around US$30,000 or even more per year.

The two candidates also promised to increase financial aid to Taiwan's cultural and creative industries and allow the outlying island chain Penghu, located about 50 kilometers west of Taiwan proper, to set up gambling casinos with appropriate safeguard measures.
Hsieh, who is trailing behind Ma in the opinion polls by up to 20 points according to some polls, spent much of the debate attacking his opponent.

He lost no opportunity to once again raise questions, as he's done recently, about Ma once possessing permanent resident status in the United States -- suggesting lack of loyalty to Taiwan. But Ma explained that although he obtained permanent residence to get a student loan when pursuing his graduate education in the United States in the late 1970s, he gave up the status over 20 years ago after returning to Taiwan.

Ma countered with a question that many of Hsieh's hand-picked officials were indicted on charges of corruption, but Hsieh rebutted that being indicted does not mean they are guilty, because the legal proceedings are not yet complete. Hsieh reminded Ma that he himself was also indicted on charges of misusing his special fees while serving as Taipei mayor.

The Taipei District Court and the Taiwan High court both ruled that Ma is not guilty of graft in 2007, but the prosecutors appealed the case to the Supreme Court in January. Although the Supreme Court has not set a date for hearing the case, it appears unlikely that a ruling might be made before the presidential election.
There were lighthearted moments in the debate - a rare occurrence in Taiwanese politics, but considered by some to be a good step toward democracy.

Asked by the moderator if they could say anything nice about each other, Ma said: "Frank Hsieh is very articulate, funny and humorous. He speaks good Japanese... He is caring towards his wife... He's good at exercising and can play the ceramic flute and the erhu (a Chinese string instrument)."

Hsieh cited Ma's merits, including his administrative experience, his mild temper and love for sports. Asked to name Ma's shortcomings, Hsieh said, "His only shortcoming is that he has too many strong points."

A second debate, scheduled for March 9, between Hsieh and Ma will adopt a different format, with the two candidates responding to questions from the six joint organizers of the two debates: the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan tug of war team wins 2nd gold medal in world championships

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese women's tug of war team won the title in the senior 480-kg division in the World Indoor Championships 2008 held in Italy Sunday, Chinese Taipei Tug of War Association officials said Monday.

The Chinese Taipei team beat semi-finalist Japan in two straight games to win gold in the senior 480 women division in the World Indoor Tug of War Championships 2008 held in Faenza, the officials said. Teams from Scotland and South Africa won third and fourth place in the senior 480 women competitions.

Sunday's game was another powerful performance after Chinese Taipei trounced China in two straight games to win gold in the senior 520 women division Saturday. Chinese Taipei won world championships in the senior 520 women competitions held in Ireland in 2006 and Germany in 2005, the officials told the CNA.

It was also the first time the Chinese Taipei team -- made up of office workers from the central county of Changhua and athletes from the Taipei Physical Education College in northern Taiwan -- won the championship of the senior 480 women division since the team first participated in the World Indoor Championships six years ago, the officials said.
Saturday's win also gave the team a ticket to take part in the World Games 2009 in Kaohsiung, the officials added.

The top six teams in the senior 520 women category in the World Indoor Championships will be eligible to compete in the 2009 World Games, they noted. The other five teams are China, Japan, England, Scotland and Ukraine, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,200 KMT supporters in New York poised to return to Taiwan to vote
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/25/08 14:53:28 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: At least 2,200 supporters of Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou from the greater New York area are expected to return to their home country next month to vote, a supporter source said Sunday.

The Ma supporters, from the states of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, are expected to return to Taiwan in six groups beginning from March 14 for the presidential election slated for March 22, said Chang Hsieh-hai, a chief secretary of the supporters group of Ma and his running mate Vincent Siew in the greater New York area.
The number would be much greater than those who returned to Taiwan to cast their presidential votes in 2004, said Chang.

A flag presenting ceremony was held at a Chinese restaurant in Flushing, Queens Sunday evening, where Ma Ke-jen, a New York-based KMT adviser; Yu Chin-shan, a chairman-elect of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association in New York; and Huang Ying-han, chairman of the Taishan Chinese Clan Association, presented the supporters' flags -- with the KMT emblem printed on them -- to the leaders of the 2,200 supporters organized into six groups.
More than 500 Ma-Siew supporters attended the KMT supporters' dinner at the restaurant.

Meanwhile, a fund-raising dinner for the presidential ticket of Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party was held the day before also in Flushing, with Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jhy- wey, who traveled from Taiwan to New York Friday, presiding.
A total of US$120,000 were raised at that dinner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 188 points to close at 8,226, with 45,763 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April gained 187 points to finish at 8,208, with 229 contracts traded, while June futures rose 194 points to close at 8,204, with 12 contract transactions.
September futures increased 209 points to finish at 7,999, with 25 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 189 points to close 7,948, with six contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 177.6 points Monday to finish at, 8,286.31, with market turnover of NT$165.39 billion (US$5.25 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at, 8,083 for March, 8,021 for April; 8,010 for June; 7,790 for September and 7,759 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were both higher.
March TE futures rose 5.5 points to close at 312.5, with 4,287 contracts traded, while April TE futures moved up 5.6 points to finish at 311.2, with 19 contract exchanges.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures moved up 20.8 points to close at 1,079, with 5,645 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures rose 22.2 points to finish at 1,077.2, with 19 contracts traded.
June TF futures gained 14.6 points to finish at 1077, with one contract traded. December TF futures moved up one point to close at 1,060, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Railway exchanges represent healthy UK-Taiwan relations: BTCO acting director

TEXT.P: Growing bilateral exchanges in the railway sectors represents avery healthy relationshipbetween the United Kingdom and Taiwan, an official of the British Trade & Cultural Office (BTCO) said Monday at an international seminar in Taipei.
The BTCO Acting Director Charles Garrett said in opening remarks that the number of British experts coming here continues to grow and this is the largest UK rail delegation ever to visit Taiwan.
Garrett added that thisfurther prove[s] it really is a very healthy relationship between Taiwan and the UK."

The seminar titledUK Expertise in Railway Asset Management, Renewal and New Projectswas held by the Taipei-based BTCO with over 120 guests from the UK and Taiwan railway authorities, companies and academics in attendence to share expertise and explore opportunities for further cooperation between the UK and Taiwan railway industries.

The railways of Taiwan and the UK share many similarities that is to provide safe, reliable and essential public transport in crowded islands and both are committed to the best days of the future,Garrett said.

Ho Nuan-hsuan, vice minister of Taiwans Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC), said the UKs railway system, including the London Underground, has been in operation for well over 150 years. With this history, Britain has developed long experience in railway maintenance and in using resources to extend the life cycle of the system.

Taiwan can be well placed to benefit from the UKs experience," Ho said, adding thatthe MOTC will continue to work on the development and integration of all track transportation systems to provide high service quality and effective management.

Jeremy Candfield, director general of the UK Railway Industry Association, is leading a group of fifteen British experts from ten leading British companies, including Atkins, Bombardier Transportation UK, and Balfour Beatty Rail, to present their expertise in railway asset management and land use. This is the 6th UK railway mission to Taiwan since 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were up Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 177.6 points to close at 8,286.31.

Buoyed by a late rally on Wall Street Friday, the local bourse opened at 8,228.92 and fluctuated between 8,307.75 and 8,228.92 during the day's session. A total of 6.32 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$165.39 billion (US$5.25 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks advancing by 5.5 percent, the most of any sector. Cement issues rose by 5.4 percent, construction stocks were up 4.1 percent, food stuffs and paper and pulp issues gained 3.5 percent, plastics and chemicals shares rose 2.3 percent, banking and financial issues grew 2.0 percent, and machinery and electronics shares increased 1.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,526 to 454, with 341 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese consumers urged to avoid mislabeled Chinese caviar

TEXT.P: Taiwanese who plan to travel to Japan were warned Monday to steer clear of China-produced caviar sold there that has been mislabeled as originating from Russia.

Liu Ching-fang, a division chief of the Cabinet-level Consumer Protection Commission, urged local travelers to be careful when buying caviar in Japan and not be fooled by the falsely labeled Chinese product.

Liu's warning came after the economic division of the Taiwan representative office in Japan notified the commission that two Japanese department store chains -- Seibu Department Stores and SOGO Department Store Co. -- were found on Feb. 7 to be marketing Chinese-produced caviar as Russian-made.

Seibu and SOGO had reportedly delivered bottles of the mislabeled caviar as year-end gifts to some 300 people across Japan between Nov. 1 and Dec. 31. The two department stores did not check the origin of the caviar, sourced by the Millennium Retailing Group for the two department stores.
So far, 270 Japanese consumers have asked to have the product replaced, complaining that "it tasted differently."
The Millennium Retailing Group has made detailed reports to Japan's Fair Trade Commission and offered an apology to Japanese consumers, according to Liu.

Although the caviar is not sold in Taiwan, and there have not been any indications that eating the China-made caviar could endanger one's health, Liu said her commission still wanted to warn local travelers about the situation.

In related news, officials from the Taipei City Department of Health said Monday that a brand of frozen Chinese dumplings removed from the shelves of Taipei's Pacific SOGO Department Store last month were found to be free of pesticides.
The department said the distributor would still be fined, however, because the China-made dumplings were labeled as Japanese made.

The dumplings were removed from SOGO Department Store's Zhongxiao Branch in Taipei because they were the same brand as those sold in Japan -- made by Tianyuan Co. in Hebei Province -- that caused 2,000 Japanese in 46 prefectures to fall ill last month.

Taipei's health department said the dumplings removed from the retailer's shelves here had different lot numbers and expiration dates than the contaminated dumplings found in Japan, but still suspended their sale as a precautionary measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market Monday, gaining NT$0.107 to close at NT$31.388.
A total of US$1.728 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.515 and fluctuated between NT$31.250 and NT$31.515.

DOC.HEADLINE: More efforts needed to develop Taiwan into biotech giant: academic

TEXT.P: Taiwan won't be able to develop itself into a world-class biotechnology giant without much greater efforts by the government, private sector and scientists as well as more investment, the head of the country's top research institution Academia Sinica said Monday.

Speaking during a lecture at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, Academia Sinica President Chi-Huey Wong said it takes concerted efforts -- specialists' expertise plus research resources from the biological, medical, engineering and even law fields -- before Taiwan can build a well-established biotech industry.

Wong said that compared to the global medical and pharmaceutical biotech market -- a market valued around US$800 billion which could be a mammoth sector worth US$2 trillion if all other industries related to health were combined -- Taiwan basically "has no biotech industry at all" with its biotech industry constituting only about 0.6 percent of the global market.

Wong attributed Taiwan's "much-to-be-desired" biotech industry to several disadvantages, including a relatively late start, limited resources for development, lack of focus in research directions and insufficient research scale. As a result, Wong said, Taiwan has been surpassed by China and India, which have won business opportunities that could have been directed toward Taiwan.
Taiwan, nevertheless, should not feel dejected or discouraged because of these set backs, given Taiwan's rich pool of talented people, Wong said.

The number of patented products and inventions developed by Taiwanese people ranks the fourth in the world and No. 1 if calculated by population ratio, Wong said, calling Taiwan "a nation with great potential."

To seize opportunities in the global biotech and health market, which is expected to balloon to some US$5 trillion in five years, Wong said Taiwan needs to correct some of the problems its industry faces and rapidly catch up. Taiwan's biotech industrial development will begin to become fruitful in five years if innovations and discoveries are expedited, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate voices praise for those who resisted Japanese

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou on Monday praised those Taiwanese who resisted Japan during the Sino-Japanese War in 1937-1945, telling an association of their family members that they "were models worth admiring."

At the same time Ma also said he felt deeply sorry for these Taiwanese heroes who were treated unjustly during the authoritarian KMT regime's bloody crackdown in the months following the 228 Incident in 1947 and during the "white terror" during the 1950s and '60s when thousands were imprisoned or put to death without cause.

"If elected, I will do everything I can not to emphasize getting revenge or complaining, but rather to build a nation that adheres to the rule of law and respects human rights, " said Ma during his address to a meeting of the founders of the association.
He also hoped that the mistakes of history would not be repeated, and asserted that could be achieved by recording history in textbooks to ensure that following generations learn from it.
At the meeting, Ma received the support of several association members who used to maintain close ties with the pro-independence "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

They said that in the past they could not forgive the KMT's repression of relatives from previous generations, but were supporting Ma in recognition of his efforts and as an expression of their hopes for a Ma administration.
Meanwhile, Ma told Japanese reporters present at the event that he evaluated issues through the prisms of human rights and the rule of law.

Based on those standards, Ma said he saw the conduct of the Japanese in Taiwan's history as "the same as that of the KMT in Taiwan's history and that of the Communist Party in China, " calling human rights and the rule of law universal principles.

Anticipating that some Japanese reporters might brand him as being anti-Japanese because of his attendance at the event, Ma stressed, "I have never been anti- Japanese." He hoped that Taiwan and Japan would be friends forever and work with each other to create a "win-win" future.
Ma was described as "anti-Japanese" during his recent visits to Japan in July 2006 and last November due to his active participation in Taiwan's civil "Defending Tiaoyutai" movement in the 1970s.
The Tiaoyutais are a group of islets some 100 kilometers off Taiwan's northeast coast and are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.

At Monday's event, Ma reiterated the importance of the historical truth, but urged those who made the history, including the Japanese, the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party to maintain good relations with each other in the future in efforts to encourage a long-lasting peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates' answers disappoint those who asked questions in debate

TEXT.P: Many of those who asked questions at Sunday's televised presidential debate said afterwards that they were not satisfied with the answers given by the two candidates.

They were disappointed by what they felt were evasive answers on important issues from the candidates, Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Su Chien-ho -- one of the 20 Taiwanese citizens whose pre-recorded questions were selected by the debate's organizers -- asked the candidates about their platforms on human rights in Taiwan and the legal system.

Both candidates stressed the importance of human rights and pointed out that there is room for improvement for Taiwan's legal system, Su said, but they did not specifically address their future policies.
Su is a convicted murderer whose controversial death sentence is still under review by the Taiwan High Court.

Green Party Taiwan (GPT) Secretary-General Pan Han-shen asked the candidates about Taiwan's participation in the Kyoto Protocol and how they would respond to the expansion of highly polluting industries.
Describing his question as "quite simple, " Pan said he simply wanted to know if both candidates had the courage to say no to big companies that have heavily polluted Taiwan's environment.
"They both failed to respond to the question directly, " Pan lamented.

Huang Chun-chen, a student from Penghu who asked Hsieh and Ma to name three positive attributes of their opponent at the debate, said she felt they did not show enough sincerity in complimenting each other.

Wang Shu-chen, a social service worker who asked the candidates what they would do to stem the decline of Taiwan's birth rate if elected in the March 22 polls, said that while the question addressed a serious issue, Hsieh did not reply in a serious manner.

She said Hsieh was a more skillful debater than Ma, but Ma's answer was more specific, and also noted that Ma's Web site provided a more detailed white paper on the issue than Hsieh's. She concluded that Ma slightly outperformed Hsieh on the topic.

For his part, Lo Chao-hsun, a Taipei County resident who asked the candidates to discuss their agricultural policies, declined to appraise the performance of the candidates but applauded the efforts of the organizers to hold such a debate.

Sunday's event marked the first time in Taiwan that local citizens directly asked presidential candidates questions in a debate. In addition to the pre- recorded questions, the selected citizens were allowed to pose a follow-up question.
In previous debates, questions for presidential candidates were asked by organizers.

The second presidential debate, scheduled for March 9, will adopt a different format, with the two candidates responding to questions from the six joint organizers of the two debates: the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News, and the Apple Daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opinion polls show Hsieh's approval ratings up slightly after debate

TEXT.P: Approval ratings for Taiwan's presidential candidate Frank Hsieh rose slightly following Sunday's debate between the ruling party's candidate and his rival, front runner Ma Ying-jeou from the main opposition party.

Ratings released by two major local dailies after Sunday's debate, however, offered different public views on Ma's performance, with one showing he gained a few percentage points while another showed his support had slipped by several points.

The United Daily News poll showed that support for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) ticket of Hsieh and vice presidential candidate Su Tseng-chang rose by 3 percentage points to 21 percent, while support for the Kuomintang (KMT) ticket of Ma and Vincent Siew -- slipped by 7 percentage points to 49 percent, compared to a poll conducted 10 days ago.

Meanwhile, a poll carried out by the China Times showed that support for both DPP and KMT tickets rose slightly, to 23 percent and 49 percent, respectively, with a margin of error of 2.7 percent. Support for Hsieh went up by one percentage point while that for Ma rose by two percentage points, according to the poll.
Hsieh told reporters Monday that he had expected to gain in approval ratings after the first presidential debate for the March 22 election.
He said that after the debate, voters have "a clear picture" of him and his "consistent stance," unlike his rival Ma who is "shifting stance from time to time."
Debates generally help underdogs. Hsieh has been trailing far behind Ma in opinion polls, and the debate did not appear to have helped him narrow the gap by much.

Hsieh spent much of the two-hour and 45 minute debate trying to point out flaws in Ma, criticizing Ma's plan to revive the economy as deficit spending, and raising doubts about his loyalty to Taiwan by again pointing out that Ma once possessed a U.S. green card.
Ma has said he got the green card to qualify for financial aid while he was studying in the U.S. and gave up the green card after returning to Taiwan.

Hsieh on Monday again lashed out at Ma's economic blueprint for reviving Taiwan's economy, in which Ma said he would help Taiwan achieve an economic growth rate of at least 6 percent, increase the nation's per capita income to U$20,000 by 2011 and US$30,000 by 2016, and keep the jobless rate below 3 percent.
Hsieh said Ma was "being too rash" and warned Ma would be "bringing down the economy," by aggravating the nation's deficit, worsening inflation and increasing the tax burden for the public.

Hsieh on Monday also attacked Ma's calls for investing around NT$4 trillion into the economy, among which the government will spend NT$2.65 trillion and will attract NT$1.3 trillion from the private sector. The money would be spent on 12 major infrastructure projects, according to Ma.
Hsieh repeated what he said on Sunday that this will mean that each household will have to write Ma a NT$400,000 bounced check.

He pointed out that Taiwan's annual budget is only between NT$1.5 trillion and NT$1.6 trillion. Even if Ma can serve two terms with a budget of NT$12 trillion, if the government spends about NT$2.6 trillion on the project, it will squeeze budgets for national defense, social welfare and education, Hsieh said.

For his part, Ma said that he had explained his policy in Sunday's debates, and will leave the details for related government agencies. He has on several occasions criticized Hsieh's DPP party for causing Taiwan's economy to suffer during its eight-year rule.

Ma said that he has noted the poll changes after the debate, but will not "pay special attention," because the polls are "short-term" and he will continue to focus on campaign platforms that will be beneficial to the country.

A second debate, scheduled for March 9, between Hsieh and Ma will adopt a different format, with the two candidates responding to questions from the six joint organizers of the two debates: the Central News Agency, the Public Television Service, the China Times, the Liberty Times, the United Daily News and the Apple Daily.
