DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor taps heavy hitters to help with 2009 Deaflympics preparations

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Monday that he has invited six prominent figures in local cultural and tourism circles to help with preparations for the 21st Summer Deaflympics, to be held in Taipei Sept. 5-15, 2009.

Hau told a press conference that the newcomers have agreed to participate in the organization of the global event in support of the city government's plan to increase Taipei's visibility in the world.

The six are: Stan Lai, an award-winning film director and professor at Taipei National University of the Arts; television producer Wang Wei-chung; popular TV hostess Chang Hsiao-yen; Lilin Hsu, chairwoman of the Xue Xue Institute, a Taipei-based learning platform for creativity and culture; Stanley Yen, president of the Ritz Landis Hotel Group; and Frederick Chien, president of the Cathy Charity Foundation.
They will help the organizers make the 2009 Taipei Summer Deaflympics a memorable event for the 3,600 deaf athletes from over 80 countries, according to Hau.
The city of Taipei won the bid to host the 2009 Summer Deaflympic in 2003. The Deaflympics is held every four years, with the 2005 event taking place in Melbourne, Australia.

Chih-Ho Chen, president of a foundation overseeing the organizing committee for the event, said the foundation will hold several international competitions in football (soccer) , table tennis, karate, taekwondo, and judo for the deaf this year as warm-ups for the 2009 event.
"We will invite elite deaf athletes to compete in these competitions in Taipei," he said.

The 2009 Summer Deaflympics will feature competition in 20 sports: athletics, football (soccer), basketball, badminton, table tennis, bowling, cycling, handball, orienteering, shooting, swimming, tennis, volleyball, beach volleyball, water polo, freestyle wrestling, Greco-Roman wrestling, judo, taekwondo and karate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. should view Taiwan as constructive partner: Foreign Minister

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang urged the United States Monday to view Taiwan as its constructive partner and provide incentives to boost bilateral trade and exchanges at a time when relations are seen to be dangerously drifting.

"We hope that America can base its Taiwan policy on the conception of 'constructive partnership' underpinned by our shared belief in universal values of democracy, freedom, and human rights as well as our common interests in peace and stability in Asia, " Huang said in a keynote speech on the future of U.S.-Taiwan relations at a seminar in Taipei.

While he acknowledged that Taiwan's government should make more of an effort to improve ties, Huang called on America "to provide incentives for both countries to boost bilateral trades on the basis of Free Trade Agreement, to promote exchanges in academic community and industries, and to encourage high-level official visits."
Huang's appeal comes at a time when relations between Washington and Taipei are strained, as reflected in a Taiwan Policy Working Group report unveiled at the seminar.

The report, called "Strengthening Freedom in Asia: A Twenty-First Century Agenda for the U.S.-Taiwan Partnership, " was prepared by the American Enterprise Institute (AEI) and Armitage International, in collaboration with the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
Huang said he concurred with the report's observation that "frequent official contacts are key to healthy Taiwan-U.S. interaction."

The report argues that the issue is urgent now that U.S.- Taiwan relations are "dangerously drifting, " with Beijing using diplomatic isolation and the threat of military force to pressure Taiwan into an unfavorable settlement and Taiwan reacting by forcing intractable disputes to the front of the debate.

"The win-win situation in Taiwan-U.S. relations lies in candid communication to minimize misunderstanding and strengthen mutual trust, " Huang said, reiterating what he said he told Stephen Young when Young took over as the director of the American Institute in Taiwan in 2006.

He said the absence of official ties between Taiwan and America should not become an obstacle to establishing an effective communication mechanism, particularly on critical issues, and "direct contacts at the highest level will be effective in minimizing misunderstanding."

Although Washington has encouraged the promotion of democracy in Taiwan for the past 20 years, it more recently has grown reserved and concerned about the development of Taiwan-centered consciousness, Huang said, citing the countries' differences over Taiwan's two referendums on Taiwan's United Nations membership bid.

Democracy in Taiwan and Taiwan-centered consciousness cannot be separated, Huang said, because it would "not follow the logic of democracy -- that people are free and entitled to speak and pursue happiness for themselves," he said.

Echoing the report's description of Taiwan's democracy as a beacon to other societies seeking peaceful political liberalization, Huang stressed that a strong, thriving and prosperous Taiwan is a concrete manifestation of the sustained success of the free and democratic system.
"Taiwan's democracy and its independent existence and development are therefore an asset of America in the region," he said.
The Taiwan Policy Working Group first convened in January 2007 to discus the status of U.S.-Taiwan political, military, and economic relations.

The working group's co-directors, Dan Blumenthal of AEI and Randall Schriver of Armitage International, investigated areas in which a more positive and productive agenda might be forged and provided advice to both the U.S. and Taiwan government in promoting bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two local stocks expected to outperform market in Greater China

TEXT.P: : Standard & Poor's Equity Research released Monday its "2008 Portfolio of Greater China Picks, " comprising 25 stocks, with only two -- AU Optronics and Chunghwa Telecom Ltd. -- being listed in Taiwan.

According to a report provided by the rating company to the Central News Agency, the other 23 companies are listed in Hong Kong and consist of Hong Kong companies, H-shares (China-based companies listed in Hong Kong) and Red Chips that the rating company believes reflect the sectors of China's economy that are expected to perform well in 2008.
The rating company forecast that the 25 stocks will outperform others in their respective sectors.

The stocks chosen have at least a three-star rating, meaning investors should hold onto the shares. The majority, however, had a four-star (buy recommendation) or five-star (strong buy recommendation) rating.
The 23 Hong Kong-listed companies included Cheung Kong Holdings, Handerson Land Development, China Mobile and the China Construction Bank.

Standard & Poor's Equity Research believes that with Greater China companies on good financial footing and with improved investment discipline following the Asian financial crisis, the current downturn in the global markets should not extend into a prolonged bear market as experienced from 1997 to 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan cautious about joining UN's new group to fight climate change

TEXT.P: The government reacted cautiously Monday on whether it would join the U.N.'s newly-established group to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, participation in which could pave the way for the island to join global efforts to fight climate change, despite it not being a U.N. member.

The group -- Climate Neutral Network (CN Net) -- unveiled last week at a meeting in Monaco, aims to have not only countries, but cities and companies, share successes about how to reduce carbon emissions so as to drastically cut greenhouse gases emitted and spark a global transition to a low-carbon world.

An official from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) told reporters Monday that the government needs to review all aspects of the issue, particularly those involving sensitive relations between Taiwan and its rival China, which objects to Taiwan joining global groups, namely those reserved for nations.

"If Taiwanese cities and companies file applications for CN Net, we cannot be sure that they won't be classified as Chinese ones, " said the official, referring to the fact that Taiwan, not a member of the U.N., is often regarded a part of China under the U.N. system.
He indicated that the EPA will relay all information to local governments and private companies about the new U.N. group, but will advise against taking immediate action.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs official also stressed that the government must have a full assessment before deciding whether to join the group, which falls under the U.N.'s Environment Programme (UNEP).
"We don't want to see any political repercussion after formal application is filed," he said.

However, he said Taiwan's position and record on global warming are evident, citing Taiwan's advocacy of a "Green APEC (Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation)" and Taipei and Kaohsiung cities' membership in the group "Local Governments for Sustainability."

UNEP spokesperson Nick Nuttall told a CNA reporter last Friday that Taiwanese cities and companies are welcomed to file applications to join the group, indirectly ruling out the possibility of Taiwan's participation as a nation.
Climate neutral refers to actions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by in ways such as planting trees, reducing fuel usage and adopting green energy, to balance the global warming effect.

So far, CN Net's members include four countries -- Costa Rica, Iceland, New Zealand and Norway -- four cities, including Rizhao, a city in the eastern Chinese province of Shandong, the Norwegian town of Arendal, the Swedish town of Vaxjo and Canada's Vancouver, as well as five companies in Singapore, Brazil, the United States, the United Kingdom and South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: Senior citizens most likely to commit suicide: psychiatrist

TEXT.P: The suicide rate among the country's senior citizens is high relative to the rest of the population and they are more determined to take their own lives, a psychiatrist said in Tainan City Monday.
Dr. Lin Chung-yi, director of the Psychiatry Department of Tainan City Hospital, said of the 4,406 people who took their own lives in 2006, 884, or 20 percent, were senior citizens aged 65 and above.
The number is quite high considering that the elderly only account for 10 percent of the population, Lin said.
Citing statistics compiled by the government, Lin said the two age brackets at highest risk for suicide are those aged between 25 and 44, and senior citizens, especially those aged above 85.

One of the factors contributing to the higher suicide rate among senior citizens is their 25 percent rate of success in taking their own lives, alarmingly high compared to the 5 percent success rate for all age brackets and 0.5 percent for people aged 24 and below, Lin said.
Seniors who commit suicide "often resort to drastic means which result in a much higher rate of success than people attempting suicide in other age groups," according to Lin.

This indicates that seniors who attempt suicide are "more determined to carry out their decisions, " and underlines the importance of mental health among the elderly as the country's population ages, the psychiatrist said.
Lin said that most senior citizens who ended their lives were suffering from mental diseases, especially depression, which was responsible for 78 percent of the suicide cases in 2006.
Citing statistics from foreign countries, Lin said senior citizens with depression are 60 times more likely to commit suicide than their peers.

In addition to their declining health and loss of financial support, social status, and their spouses, senior citizens are vulnerable to the feelings of social isolation, Lin said, and therefore especially needed the support of their friends and family members.
Lin reminded those with elderly family members to pay more attention to them and provide them with sufficient material support.

DOC.HEADLINE: New defense minister takes office

TEXT.P: Tsai Ming-shian took over as defense minister Monday, making him the first defense chief to be appointed from the ranks of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Tsai took possession of the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) official seal from his predecessor Lee Tien-yu at a changeover ceremony presided over by Minister-without-portfolio Huang Hwui-jen.

On behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, Huang lauded Lee for his dedication to fulfilling his call of duty since assuming office last May, citing Lee's achievements in promoting the restructuring of the nation's defense system, the reduction of armed forces, and adjustments in troop deployments.

Lee was also credited for organizing a rare show of the country's military muscle in a National Day celebration rally last year and completing construction of a new highway on the remote Taiping Island in the South China Sea, which can be used as a runway for emergency relief operations.

Moreover, Huang said, President Chen especially commended Lee for his accomplishments in maintaining neutrality and keeping politics away from military affairs, which compliments Taiwan's progress in democratization.

During Monday's ceremony, Huang also conveyed President Chen's expectations for Tsai, asking him to continue carrying out various military reform projects, strengthen combat readiness and complete military buildup plans with a well- rounded vision.

The ceremony was attended by senior military officials, including Chief of the General Staff Gen. Huo Shou-yeh and two deputy defense ministers, Ko Cheng-heng and Lin Chen-yi, as well as top commenders of the three branches of service.
At the end of the ceremony, Lee gave Tsai a hug and said: "Dear doctor, I hand over the defense ministry to you, " before leaving the ministry.

Lee, who assumed the post last May, resigned Saturday amid mounting controversy over the establishment of a new defense company, named Taiwan Goal, in which the MND was supposed to hold a 45 percent stake.

"I deeply regret that the establishment of Taiwan Goal caused concerns and doubts in various sectors and I hereby tender my resignation to take responsibility for failing to smoothly carry out an order to establish an arms company to boost development of the country's defense industry, " Lee said in a brief statement posted on the MND Web site Saturday.

Tsai, 67, who has a doctorate from the California Western School of Law, served as a legislator for two terms and as a deputy representative to the United States and as a deputy defense minister and as a deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND to allow as many servicemen to vote as possible: new chief

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Defense Minister Tsai Ming-shian said Monday that the ministry will let as many military servicemen as possible exercise their right to vote in the March 22 presidential election.
"We will do our best to ensure the voting rights of the public, " Tsai said, but noted that some military personnel would have to remain at their posts to safeguard national security.

Tsai was responding to questions by Alex Fai, a caucus whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the legislature, on how many military servicemen would be allowed to leave their posts to vote on election day.

The KMT believes that the Ministry of National Defense barred an excessively high number of servicemen from leaving their bases to vote on election day in 2004, one of the factors the party says contributed to its defeat by a razor- thin margin.
The KMT, which was entrenched in power for more than 50 years before 2000, commands a strong support base in the military.

Tsai said that the ministry will act in line with past practice to allow military personnel to exercise their voting rights, although "some definitely will have to remain at their posts for the sake of national security.
"The ratio of military personnel remaining at their posts will vary with each military unit, and the MND will act according to the law," Tsai stressed.
He pledged to get the prior consent of the KMT's legislative caucus on the military's policy.
Responding to questions about the disbanding of a controversial private arms broker to handle Taiwan's military purchases, Tsai referred to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's pledges made Saturday.

The premier, according to Tsai, said unequivocally that the government will not invest "even one dime" in the firm, and that it will soon be disbanded, while promising "everything will follow standard procedures governing companies."

Tsai replaced Lee Tien-yu, who stepped down Saturday for not "properly" handling the project. Tsai said he didn't know when asked if the arms firm, Taiwan Goal, will change its name or operate clandestinely.
But he said that if the government says "it will be disbanded, then it will be disbanded."
He also dismissed the possibility that it will reappear as a company with another name.
KMT lawmakers have questioned the "origins and lineup" of the company, charging that "it was designed to evade the supervision of the Legislative Yuan."

Although the MND has a 45 percent stake in the company and is its largest shareholder, Lee reportedly said the ministry had no control over the company. The remaining shares were mostly held by companies related to state-owned enterprises.

Taiwan Goal completed its registration with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Jan. 28 as a private company, with capital of NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital totaling NT$80 million.

Wu Nai-jen, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party heavyweight and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the formerly state-owned China Steel Corp. -- was listed as chairman of the company.

Taiwan Goal is registered to deal in a variety of businesses, including the import and export of arms and weaponry systems; sales of garments and accessories, industrial explosives, precision instruments, and batteries of all types; and product design, according to the MOEA.

According to information provided by the Executive Yuan, the company's capital in its initial stage of operations will total NT$200 million. Of that amount, NT$80 million has already been collected, including NT$50 million from China Steel Machinery Corp. and NT$30 million from a subsidiary of Chunghwa Telecom.

But NT$90 million from the Ministry of National Defense, which had planned to hold 45 percent of the company's shares, and NT$30 million from the Yao Hua Glass Co. -- a company under the Ministry of Economic Affairs -- had yet to be deposited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green Island asks for experts' help in resolving fishy deaths

TEXT.P: Green Island officials urged environmental authorities Monday to help them determine why massive numbers of fish have perished in recent months near the islet located off Taiwan's southeastern coast.
Residents on Green Island, also known as Lyudao, which is administered by the Taitung County government, spotted large numbers of dead fish on the beach and in waters off the coast two months ago.
Dead fish carcasses have since been seen on a 3-4 kilometer-long stretch along the islet's northern coast, and some are still floating in waters there, officials of the Lyudao Township office said.
Twenty-six different kinds of coral fish were among those that died, authorities said.

A report by the Penghu Marine Biology Research Center, which was commissioned to investigate the mystery excluded a number of factors in the massive die-off, including illegal fishing with explosives or electricity, and natural disasters such as earthquakes and sea water temperature changes.

The township office then sent dead fish samples to the Taiwan Agriculture Chemicals and Toxic Substances Research Institute for a further check on possible toxicity from pesticides used in the agricultural sector.
However, tests found only small traces of some the 250 kinds of pesticides used in Taiwan or cyanide in the fish, not enough to cause their deaths, the officials said.
The only oddity detected during the examination was that the fish had not eaten for a period of time before they died because their stomachs were empty.

Now the township office hopes environmental experts can join the investigation to check whether the death was caused by waste dumped into the seas by international freighters or merchant ships passing by the island, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Candidates' agricultural platforms have been implemented: official

TEXT.P: Many of the agricultural policy prescriptions offered by Taiwan's two presidential candidates in Sunday's debate have already been implemented, a high-ranking agricultural official said after the debate's conclusion.

The two candidates -- Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -- vowed to increase the use of idle farm land, and Ma also promised to increase exports of Taiwan's farm produce.

Lee Chien-chuan, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), said, however, that the council has been pushing to expand the exports of Taiwanese farm products over the years, and described 2007 as a banner year.
Citing local mangoes as an example, Lee explained that following three years of negotiation, Australia agreed to allow the import of mangoes from Taiwan last May.
It marked the first time that Taiwanese fruit had entered Australia, which has strict quarantine standards, Lee said.

In addition, Taiwan exported more than 450 metric tons of mangoes to South Korea last year, three times as much as the year before, while Japan imported over 450 metric tons of Taiwanese mangoes in 2007, with Japanese consumers rating Taiwanese mangoes as their favorite fruit in an online poll.
Lee also noted that some 8,500 metric tons of Taiwan-grown bananas were exported in 2007, 87 percent more than the 4,533 metric tons registered in 2006.
COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan previously touted a project launched by the council in 2006 to help increase the exports of local agricultural products.
Under the project, the council has successfully exported butterfly orchids to the United States, papayas and rice to Japan, and mangoes to New Zealand and Chile, Su said.
In the debate, Hsieh proposed to set up "farmland banks" to boost the use of farmland, but the council already began promoting the establishment of such banks in 2007.

The banks, which have been set up in many cities and counties in Taiwan, serve as platforms to offer legal and loan information to those who intend to rent, buy, or sell farmland, according to Su last year.
The banks will help the government save on subsidies for local fallow land, which amount to NT$10.6 billion (US$337.8 million) every year, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. and Taiwan need high quality dialogue: scholars

TEXT.P: Dialogue between Taiwan and the United States should be strengthened with the involvement of high-ranking officials, and Washington should keep its Taiwan agenda separate from U.S.-China relations, said a visiting American consultant Monday at a seminar.

Randall Schriver, founding partner of Washington-based consulting firm Armitage International, argued that a communication channel of high quality between the U.S. and Taiwan needs to be a priority in searching for a strategy to meet the interests of the two sides.
Speaking at a seminar on the 21st century agenda for the U.S.-Taiwan partnership, Schriver also hoped that with the election
of a new president the U.S government could view the Taiwan issue
independently, without making it a part of the U.S.-China agenda.
"The new U.S. president needs to build up a better relationship with Taiwan without hampering the relationship between the U.S. and China," Schriver said.

Another speaker at the seminar, Dan Blumenthal, resident fellow of the American Enterprise Institute, acknowledged Taiwan's desire to participate in more international organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
"Increasing Taiwan's international recognition and space" is really essential, he said, and Schriver promised to encourage U.S. allies in ASEAN to strengthen their relationship with Taiwan.

The foreign policy experts supported the idea of Taiwan holding direct talks with China to gain more international space, but Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang said that while Taiwan should be aware of such negotiations, it would have to be very careful about not compromising on the issue of sovereignty.
Looking back at direct contacts between Taiwan and China in the early 1990s, Huang said that sovereignty was, and still is, the biggest obstacle in Taiwan- China relations.

Meanwhile, commending Taiwan's achievement in fighting against SARS in 2002-2003 as remarkable, Schriver further said that "we have to raise international awareness of Taiwan to get Taiwan known to the globe."

As for the future of Taiwan, Schriver stressed that every Taiwanese citizen had to "make the decision by themselves about the future, " adding that the "people of Taiwan should determine the future of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's portable microscope draws attention of aviation companies
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/25/08 23:06:34 (By Charles Kang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A portable microscope developed by a Taiwanese company has attracted the attention of 100 companies involved in the aviation field at an airshow in Singapore that concluded Sunday, according to a company executive.

The microscope, developed by Taipei-based Lumos Technology Co. to help precision industries with maintenance and quality control, drew inquiries from many manufacturers of aircraft and related components, including Boeing and Airbus, said company president Yang Chi-yi.

It took the company nearly three and a half years to develop the high- resolution, portable microscope, which helps manufacturers monitor production lines and effectively help them repair and check products, Yang said.

One of its main advantages is that it can be installed on digital cameras, the executive said, because the camera makes it easier for companies to discuss the quality of products with their clients or employees, and keep records.

The company's portable microscope is already being used by major semiconductor companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , as well as European automakers, Yang said.
Defense ministries in the United Kingdom and Germany have also purchased the product to help them repair or check their military equipment, Yang noted.
Japanese companies are the company's main competition, but Yang said Lumos' product costs only half of that offered by its rivals while the quality is the same.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academic group wants a 'real' presidential debate

TEXT.P: An academic group called Monday for a "real" presidential debate, saying that Sunday's first of two battles between the two presidential candidates could hardly be called a genuine debate.
James Chan, president of the Taipei Society, comprised of university professors and academic figures, said the society "was not satisfied with the format and content" of the debate.

During Sunday's two-hour and 45-minute debate, ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his rival Ma Ying-jeou of the Kuomintang were asked 20 questions in pre-recorded videos submitted by members of the public. The selected questioners were allowed to ask follow-up questions at the debate.
In the second part of the debate, the two candidates were required to answer three questions from each other, and in the final part, they each gave a three- minute conclusion.
"Sunday's debate can hardly be called a qualified presidential debate, " Chan said, calling for a real one so that "the two candidates' views on major issues will be clear to the voters."
He cited as an example that the two candidates only touched lightly on the issues of national identity and Taiwan-centric consciousness, but were not able to elaborate their views in depth.
After anticipating the presidential debate for a long time, Chan said the group was very dissatisfied with the performance of both candidates.

He said scholars will pool their strength and form an alliance on March 1 to pose questions on several major issues to "help voters learn the views of the candidates in choosing their leader for the next four years."

DOC.HEADLINE: Solve expressway issue through referendum: Hualien County councilor

TEXT.P: A referendum should be held to determine once and for all whether residents in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien really want an expressway built to link Hualien with Suao in neighboring Yilan County, a member of the Hualien County Council said Monday.

Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and opponent Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang tiptoed around whether they supported the Suao-Hualien Expressway project in their first televised debate, preferring to discuss development in the eastern part of the country.
Noting that the debate over the controversial issue in past years has failed to yield conclusive results, Lin suggested that the best way to solve the issue is through a county-wide referendum.

Lin said the county council would need to complete appropriate legislation first before a referendum could take place. Two previous attempts -- one by the current county council and another by the previous county council -- to pass rules and regulations on local referendums were unsuccessful.

The proposed 86-kilometer four-lane expressway project, mapped out by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in 1994, was approved by the Cabinet in 1998. The expressway, with 40 km of tunnels and 37 km of bridges, would be part of a planned 259-km freeway linking Suao to Taitung in southeastern Taiwan.
Construction was to begin in 2003 and be completed in eight years at a cost of NT$93 billion, but was halted because of strong opposition from some local groups who voiced environmental concerns.
Supporters for the project have contended that mountainous Hualien County, which is relatively underdeveloped compared with counties to its west, needs the expressway to stimulate the local economy.
The debate over the issue has continued since then with both the central and local governments unable to resolve the issue.

To allay the concerns of environmentalists, project planners have changed the route of the expressway to minimize the impact on the local ecology. A committee of the Environmental Protection Administration is expected to meet after the March 22 presidential election to assess the project's impact on Hualien County's environment.

Hualien County is linked to Suao by a 87-km provincial highway expanded in the 1980s. It is often blocked by landslides during the typhoon and rainy seasons. The county is also served by a railway between Hualien and Taipei, but passengers often complain that tickets are hard to get.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA predicts no more drastic rise in commodity price

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Monday that the prices of major commodities are unlikely to drop in the near future, but he also believed that the chances of a new round of drastic price surges are also slim.

Speaking prior to the Executive Yuan's meeting on stabilizing consumer prices Wednesday, Chen said he has asked the ministry's offices abroad to collect information on major commodities, such as the planted area of soybeans, wheat, and corn, the harvest rates, the planted area of biomass crops, and weather conditions around the world.
The MOEA has also begun to collect information concerning the measures taken by other countries in dealing with surging prices of major commodities and raw materials, he said.
"Judging from the present situation, the chances of a resurgence in the prices of major commodities are slim, but it will also be difficult for their prices to fall," he said.
Soaring crude oil prices, higher transportation costs and weather factors have all contributed to the price increases for major commodities.
But if prices continue to soar, consumers will seek other alternative materials, and the free market mechanism will automatically play a role in balancing supply and demand, he said.

The government, however, has taken some short-term measures to try and stabilize the situation. Responding to reports that many local bakeries have been forced to shut down because of the recent surge in wheat prices, Chen said that the government has purchased large volumes of soybeans and wheat to help reduce prices.

Chen noted that the ministry had also imposed a ban on exports of reinforced steel bar, or rebar, and billets for three months. Because only limited volumes of the steel products are exported, the effect of the ban was largely psychological and is not expected to have a big impact on local rebar prices.
Addressing another of the construction sector's concerns on the soaring price of gravel, Chen said that after the ministry had adjusted the supply of gravel, its price had stabilized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not to follow Hong Kong in raising H5N1 alert level: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will not follow Hong Kong's move to raise the bird flu alert level despite the confirmation of yet another H5N1-inflicted human fatality in China, a disease control official said Monday.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC), made the remarks after Hong Kong announced earlier in the day that stricter epidemic control measures will be imposed on its borders with China for four weeks effective immediately.

Hong Kong authorities took the move as Chinese authorities confirmed that a 44 -year-old migrant worker died Monday in the southern province of Guangdong after apparently catching the deadly H5N1 virus.

It was the third H5N1-related human fatality reported in China so far this year. The other two cases were recorded in Hunan and Guangxi provinces. All three victims had been in close contact with poultry before becoming sick, according to Chinese reports.
Lin said it is indeed unusual that China has reported three H5N1 deaths in less than two months since the beginning of this year.
As Hong Kong is adjacent to Haifeng, Guangdong where the latest H5N1 death happened, it is understandable that Hong Kong authorities heightened the alert level, Lin said.

But asked whether the DOH would follow suit, Lin said the CDC had no such a plan at the moment, noting that Taiwan and China are separated by the Taiwan Strait and available medical reports consistently show that all H5N1 human cases involve close contact with poultry.
"Another reason is that the World Health Organization has not yet confirmed that the H5N1 virus has mutated into a strain that can be easily transferred from poultry to humans," Lin added.

Lin said the CDC will nonetheless continue monitoring the bird flu situation in China closely and that fever screening stations at Taiwan's main gateways will remain in place to facilitate early detection of any suspicious cases.
No H5N1 cases in humans or poultry have been reported in Taiwan to date.
Lin reminded local residents intending to visit China and Southeast Asian countries for business or sightseeing purposes to be on guard against contact with poultry and wild birds.
"China- and Southeast Asia-bound travelers should also refrain from purchasing poultry and wild bird products and not to eat raw poultry and eggs, " Lin said.

He added that those who have fever or develop cold-like symptoms should seek medical attention as soon as possible and brief medical professionals on their travel itinerary and history of contact with poultry or wild birds.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical team departs for India to provide service

TEXT.P: A Taiwan medical team departed on a three-week journey to a mountainous region in northern India where they will provide medical services and training, a government-financed fund said Monday.

The Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund said the 11-member team would travel to a Tibetan refugee center in Darjeeling, a town in the Indian state of West Bengal, to provide health care services and clinical training sessions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese pressure behind replacement of envoy to ROK inauguration

TEXT.P: Pressure from China led to the appointment of Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin- pyng rather than National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen as special envoy to attend South Korean President Lee Myung-bak's inauguration, an official said Monday.
The Presidential Office, however, refrained from commenting on the issue.

The government originally planned to name Tan Sun Chen to represent President Chen Shui-bian at the ceremony in Seoul Monday, but premature exposure of the plan by local cable TV stations led to a change of the special envoy, said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Lee, a former mayor of Seoul and former CEO of Hundai Group, was sworn in Monday as South Korea's 17th president and the first "CEO president." As such, he is expected to govern with a management style similar to that of a company head.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb.26, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: President Chen Shui-bian receiving Randall G. Schriver and Dan Blumenthal, co-chairmen of the American Enterprise Institute Taiwan Policy Working Group. Place: Presidential Office. Press Contact: Tel. 2311-3731

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan bourse opens higher

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Tuesday on Wall Street rally.

The weighted price index advanced 93.24 points to 8,379.55 on a turnover of NT$7.25 billion (US$230.89 million) at the open. The index gained 177.6 points, or 2.19 percent, to close at 8,286.31 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 26, or the 20th day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1531: An earthquake rocks Portugal, killing more than 20,000 people.
1791: The Bank of England issues the first-ever pound note.
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" uprising, or the Boxer Rebellion, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking (Beijing), ending two years of unrest over the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang County in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time, at Daventry in England, the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails, but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising, and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagen, literally the "People's Car," in Saxony.
1946: U.S. Secretary of State James Byrnes denies knowledge of a Big Three Agreement authorizing the USSR to remove machinery from Manchuria.
1951: The 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution is passed, limiting presidents to two four-year terms in office.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction on the North- South Freeway.
1974: Members of the International Academy of Trial Lawyers arrive for their 1974 conference in Taipei.
1975: The Republic of China and South Africa sign a trade agreement in Taipei.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara, and the region comes to be called the Western Sahara, which is divided into two parts under the separate control of Morocco and Mauritania, respectively.
1979: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1980: The Ministry of Finance approves the opening of Taipei branches by five European banks: Grindlays Bank (Great Britain), the European Asia Bank (West Germany), the Societe Generale (France), the Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas (France), and Hollandsche Bank-Unie, N.V. (the Netherlands).
1981: A French super-high-speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and El Salvadoran President Alfredo Felix Cristiani Burkard sign a joint communique for closer bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and the mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Communist China and the United States sign an agreement mandating Chinese respect for copyrights, trademarks and patents.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after suffering losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
2000: ROC Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho holds a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the completion of 49 newly-built brick houses in a village in northern Thailand for Nationalist veterans.
2003: The world's oldest Asian elephant living in captivity Lin Wang dies at the Taipei City Zoo at age 86.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO minister visits Los Angeles
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/26/08 13:07:29 (By Lu-Sheng Chu Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Minister Shieh Jyh-wey, who is in the United States on a private visit to campaign and raise funds for the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, lambasted the oppostition Kuomintang (KMT) for failing to reflect on its past wrongdoings in a speech here Sunday.

Shieh said that issues related to transitional justice in Taiwan have yet been dealt with as the 61st anniversary of the 2-28 Incident of 1947, in which thousands of people were massacred by KMT troops, is approaching.
Shieh is in the United States at the invitation of more than 20 pro-DPP expatriate Taiwanese groups to deliver speeches in five U.S. cities. Los Angeles is his third stop.

Claiming that over the past few decades, the KMT has never truely repented for the harm inflicted on individuals during its former authoritarian rule, Shieh said "the KMT still owes an honest apology to the 2-28 Incident victims for their pain and suffering."

Regarding the DPP's attempt to take legal action to retrieve the ill-gotten assets amassed by the KMT during its five decades of rule, Shieh said he does not pin any hopes on the bid as "it is almost impossible, given that the KMT controls an absolute majority, with 81, or nearly three-quarters of the 113 seats, in the legislature."
Mentioning that he was able to see the first televised presidential election debate between Frank Hsieh and his KMT rival Ma Ying-jeou, Shieh gave higer marks to Hsieh.

Meanwhile, Shieh encouraged Taiwanese expatriates to donate funds to the DPP's standard bearer and his running mate Su Tseng-chang, while urging expatriates to "turn their passion for Taiwan into action," through returning to Taiwan to campaign and vote for the DPP ticket.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's portable microscope draws attention of aviation companies
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 24 (CNA) 02/26/08 13:15:52 (By Charles Kang and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: A portable microscope developed by a Taiwanese company has attracted the attention of 100 companies involved in the aviation field at an airshow in Singapore that concluded Sunday, according to a company executive.

The microscope, developed by Taipei-based Lumos Technology Co. to help precision industries with maintenance and quality control, drew inquiries from many manufacturers of aircraft and related components, including Boeing and Airbus, said company president Yang Chi-yi.

It took the company nearly three and a half years to develop the high- resolution, portable microscope, which helps manufacturers monitor production lines and effectively help them repair and check products, Yang said.

One of its main advantages is that it can be installed on digital cameras, the executive said, because the camera makes it easier for companies to discuss the quality of products with their clients or employees, and keep records.

The company's portable microscope is already being used by major semiconductor companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) , as well as European automakers, Yang said.
Defense ministries in the United Kingdom and Germany have also purchased the product to help them repair or check their military equipment, Yang noted.
Japanese companies are the company's main competition, but Yang said Lumos' product costs only half of that offered by its rivals while the quality is the same.

DOC.HEADLINE: Solve expressway issue through referendum: Hualien County councilor

TEXT.P: A referendum should be held to determine once and for all whether residents in the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien really want an expressway built to link Hualien with Suao in neighboring Yilan County, a member of the Hualien County Council said Monday.

Frank Hsieh, presidential candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and opponent Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang tiptoed around whether they supported the Suao-Hualien Expressway project in their first televised debate, preferring to discuss development in the eastern part of the country.
Noting that the debate over the controversial issue in past years has failed to yield conclusive results, Lin suggested that the best way to solve the issue is through a county-wide referendum.

Lin said the county council would need to complete appropriate legislation first before a referendum could take place. Two previous attempts -- one by the current county council and another by the previous county council -- to pass rules and regulations on local referendums were unsuccessful.

The proposed 86-kilometer four-lane expressway project, mapped out by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in 1994, was approved by the Cabinet in 1998. The expressway, with 40 km of tunnels and 37 km of bridges, would be part of a planned 259-km freeway linking Suao to Taitung in southeastern Taiwan.
Construction was to begin in 2003 and be completed in eight years at a cost of NT$93 billion, but was halted because of strong opposition from some local groups who voiced environmental concerns.
Supporters for the project have contended that mountainous Hualien County, which is relatively underdeveloped compared with counties to its west, needs the expressway to stimulate the local economy.
The debate over the issue has continued since then with both the central and local governments unable to resolve the issue.

To allay the concerns of environmentalists, project planners have changed the route of the expressway to minimize the impact on the local ecology. A committee of the Environmental Protection Administration is expected to meet after the March 22 presidential election to assess the project's impact on Hualien County's environment.

Hualien County is linked to Suao by a 87-km provincial highway expanded in the 1980s. It is often blocked by landslides during the typhoon and rainy seasons. The county is also served by a railway between Hualien and Taipei, but passengers often complain that tickets are hard to get.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA predicts no more drastic rise in commodity price

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen said Monday that the prices of major commodities are unlikely to drop in the near future, but he also believed that the chances of a new round of drastic price surges are also slim.

Speaking prior to the Executive Yuan's meeting on stabilizing consumer prices Wednesday, Chen said he has asked the ministry's offices abroad to collect information on major commodities, such as the planted area of soybeans, wheat, and corn, the harvest rates, the planted area of biomass crops, and weather conditions around the world.
The MOEA has also begun to collect information concerning the measures taken by other countries in dealing with surging prices of major commodities and raw materials, he said.
"Judging from the present situation, the chances of a resurgence in the prices of major commodities are slim, but it will also be difficult for their prices to fall," he said.
Soaring crude oil prices, higher transportation costs and weather factors have all contributed to the price increases for major commodities.
But if prices continue to soar, consumers will seek other alternative materials, and the free market mechanism will automatically play a role in balancing supply and demand, he said.

The government, however, has taken some short-term measures to try and stabilize the situation. Responding to reports that many local bakeries have been forced to shut down because of the recent surge in wheat prices, Chen said that the government has purchased large volumes of soybeans and wheat to help reduce prices.

Chen noted that the ministry had also imposed a ban on exports of reinforced steel bar, or rebar, and billets for three months. Because only limited volumes of the steel products are exported, the effect of the ban was largely psychological and is not expected to have a big impact on local rebar prices.
Addressing another of the construction sector's concerns on the soaring price of gravel, Chen said that after the ministry had adjusted the supply of gravel, its price had stabilized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not to follow Hong Kong in raising H5N1 alert level: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will not follow Hong Kong's move to raise the bird flu alert level despite the confirmation of yet another H5N1-inflicted human fatality in China, a disease control official said Monday.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC), made the remarks after Hong Kong announced earlier in the day that stricter epidemic control measures will be imposed on its borders with China for four weeks effective immediately.

Hong Kong authorities took the move as Chinese authorities confirmed that a 44 -year-old migrant worker died Monday in the southern province of Guangdong after apparently catching the deadly H5N1 virus.

It was the third H5N1-related human fatality reported in China so far this year. The other two cases were recorded in Hunan and Guangxi provinces. All three victims had been in close contact with poultry before becoming sick, according to Chinese reports.
Lin said it is indeed unusual that China has reported three H5N1 deaths in less than two months since the beginning of this year.
As Hong Kong is adjacent to Haifeng, Guangdong where the latest H5N1 death happened, it is understandable that Hong Kong authorities heightened the alert level, Lin said.

But asked whether the DOH would follow suit, Lin said the CDC had no such a plan at the moment, noting that Taiwan and China are separated by the Taiwan Strait and available medical reports consistently show that all H5N1 human cases involve close contact with poultry.
"Another reason is that the World Health Organization has not yet confirmed that the H5N1 virus has mutated into a strain that can be easily transferred from poultry to humans," Lin added.

Lin said the CDC will nonetheless continue monitoring the bird flu situation in China closely and that fever screening stations at Taiwan's main gateways will remain in place to facilitate early detection of any suspicious cases.
No H5N1 cases in humans or poultry have been reported in Taiwan to date.
Lin reminded local residents intending to visit China and Southeast Asian countries for business or sightseeing purposes to be on guard against contact with poultry and wild birds.
"China- and Southeast Asia-bound travelers should also refrain from purchasing poultry and wild bird products and not to eat raw poultry and eggs, " Lin said.

He added that those who have fever or develop cold-like symptoms should seek medical attention as soon as possible and brief medical professionals on their travel itinerary and history of contact with poultry or wild birds.

DOC.HEADLINE: China obstructs Taiwan envoys from ROK presidential inauguration

TEXT.P: Taiwan's special envoys were barred from attending South Korean President Lee Myung-bak's inauguration ceremony due to obstruction from the Chinese government, Foreign Affairs Minister James Huang said Tuesday.

Both Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen arrived in Seoul Sunday in preparation to represent Taiwan at Lee's inauguration the following day, Huang said on the sidelines of a legislative floor meeting.
"However, neither of them made it as China's top representative Tang Jiaxuan threatened to pull out of the ceremony if the South Korean government allowed them to attend," Huang said.
For the sake of harmony, South Korean authorities expressed hope that Wang and Chen stay away from the ceremony.
"The incident was yet another stark reminder of the gravity and ubiquity of China's diplomatic suppression of Taiwan," Huang said.
During their stay in Seoul, Wang and Chen made extensive visits to South Korean officials, parliamentarians, and prominent figures, Huang said.

Lee, a former mayor of Seoul and former CEO of Hyundai Group, was sworn in Monday as the Republic of Korea's (ROK's) 17th president and the first "CEO president." As such, he is expected to govern with hard-headed pragmatism and a management style similar to that of a corporate chief executive officer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Healthy lifestyles help Taipei residents live longest:researcher

TEXT.P: Taipei City residents live longer than others in the country because of their healthier lifestyle, but the national health insurance program has increased life expectancy in all parts of the country, a researcher at the non-profit National Health Research Institute said Tuesday.

Reporting the results of a study comparing life expectancies in 365 villages and townships around Taiwan 10 years before the program in 1995 and 10 years after it was launched, Wen Chi-pang said the life expectancy of Taipei City citizens had risen to 81.21 years, from 76.89 years in 1985.

The life expectancy of all Taiwan residents had also been extended over that time, gaining an average of 2.39 years for men and 2.78 years for women, in part because of the national health insurance program, but Wen said stark regional differences remained.

The difference in life expectancy for Taipei City and Taitung County residents was still more than 10 years, even though the gap had been narrowed slightly to 10.03 years from 10.65 years a decade before the program was implemented.

"The study showed that the least healthy residents could not make use of the national health insurance program to narrow the gap in life expectancy between them and their healthier counterparts, " Wen said.
"This has to do with such habits as smoking, drinking and betel nut chewing, which are harmful to one's health," he contended.

Medical resources can only contribute 10 percent to the life expectancy of the public, while poor habits affect 60 percent of one's health, Wen said, with smoking and betel nut chewing typical examples.
In Taipei City, only 36 percent of men and 5.6 percent of women smoke, significantly lower than the 51 percent of Taitung County's men and 15 percent of Taitung County's women who smoke.

Betel nut chewing is also far more more popular in the southeastern county, with 33 percent of the county's men and 20 percent of the county's women chewing betel nut compared to only 6 percent of the men and 0.1 percent of the women in Taipei City doing the same.

"The national health insurance program has contributed more to women than to men in raising life expectancy, mainly because there are fewer women than men who smoke, drink or chew betel nut, " Wen said.
"There are seven times more men than women who have such unhealthy habits," he said.

Based on the study's findings, Wen suggested that the insurance program focus not only on "treating disease, " but also on spending more time and funding to help people "not get sick, " saying such a strategy would truly promote national health and avoid the squandering of medical resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 21.36 points to close at 8,307.67.

Posting gains for the fourth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 8,379.55 and fluctuated between 8,386.54 and 8,258.87 during the day's session. A total of 6.4 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$174.5 billion (US$5.57 billion).
Three major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares rising 0.6 percent, and food and financial issues both increasing an average of 0.4 percent.

The other five stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares and construction stocks falling by 1.4 percent, cement and paper and pulp issues shedding 0.7 percent, and textile shares losing 0.5 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,077 to 865, with 379 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan delegations to attend int'l travel fairs to promote tourism

TEXT.P: The National Youth Commission (NYC) will send delegations to participate in two travel fairs to be held in Singapore and Malaysia promoting youth travel, a NYC official said Tuesday.

At the NATAS (National Association of Travel Agents Singapore) Travel Fair 2008 to be held in Singapore Feb. 29-March 2 and the MATTA (Malaysian Association of Tour and Travel Agents) Fair March 2008 to be held March 14-16 at the Putra World Trade Center, Kuala Lumpur, the NYC delegates will offer young people from around the world detailed information about how to travel around Taiwan through more convenient, thrifty and interesting ways.
The NYC will also select volunteers to serve as travel guides free of charge to young people from abroad who are planning to travel in Taiwan.

According to the official, young people aged 15 to 30 can apply for a Youth Travel Card at the travel fairs, which will offer many attractive discounts in tickets for tourist sites, transportation fees, accommodations and cuisine during their stay in Taiwan.

In addition, young tourists can apply for the Digital Tour Buddy service, in which they would receive a cell phone account and basic equipment for temporary usage, including a cell phone, SIM card, lithium cell battery, battery charger, operation manual, and phone bag that can be used on loan free of charge during their stay in Taiwan. The users of the Digital Tour Buddy will have around-the-clock access to a tourist service hotline providing travel and service information.
To decrease the language barrier, the cell phone has a built-in dictionary for English-Chinese translations, enabling travelers to communicate more easily with the local people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices up on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March moved up 51 points to close at 8,277, with 47,550 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April rose 53 points to finish at 8,261, with 250 contracts traded, while June futures increased 53 points to close at 8,257, with 23 contract transactions.
September futures gained 47 points to finish at 8,046, with 10 contract transactions, while December futures moved up 12 points to close at 7,960, with 11 contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index rose 21.36 points Tuesday to finish at 8,307.67, with market turnover of NT$174.58 billion (US$5.57 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 8,226 for March; 8,208 for April; 8,204 for June; 7,999 for September and 7,948 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.

March TE futures gained 3.5 points to close at 316, with 5,205 contracts traded, while April TE futures increased 3.85 points to finish at 315.05, with 20 contract exchanges. No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.
March TF futures moved up 5.2 points to close at 1,084.4, with 4,277 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures dropped 1.6 points to finish at 1,075.6, with eight contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan group attending meeting of U.N. agency on gender equality

TEXT.P: A nongovernmental group of more than 30 female experts and academics from Taiwan is in New York to attend the annual meeting of the Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) under the United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), which opened Monday and ends on March 7.

The group, composed of female specialists from private groups and foundations, heard U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon deliver the meeting's opening address Monday and will take part in a series of workshops beginning Tuesday.

Ban told the conference that the U.N. will launch a seven-year campaign to help abused women across the world and called on all nations, nongovernmental organizations and private groups to join the movement.

Both the public and private sector should actively take part in the campaign, and men around the world have an absolute responsibility to help bring violence against their female partners to an end, Ban said.

One-third of women around the globe have endured during their lifetimes physical abuse and maltreatment, or are victims of sexual or other kinds of violence at the hands of their husbands or male partners, statistics show. On average, one out of every five women around the world are raped or victims of attempted rapes during their lifetimes.
Taiwan's women rights groups have taken part in meetings organized by the commission in recent years and have set up effective communications channels with many NGO organizations.

The commission is a functional body of the ECOSOC, dedicated exclusively to gender equality and advancement of women. The annual meeting is held to assess progress on gender equality, set global standards and forge concrete policies to advance the status of women around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fishermen in Kaohsiung to be subsidized for not fishing

TEXT.P: Owners of fishing boats based in Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung will be paid subsidies to not fish, as part of a new program to conserve fisheries resources, the city government's Marine Bureau announced Tuesday.

With fuel prices continuing to rise and fishery resources declining due to overfishing and the devastation on Taiwan's marine ecology by a recent cold spell, it might not be worthwhile for fishing boats to remain fully operational through the year.
"Fishing boat owners are welcome to make use of our program to get a subsidy for not going out fishing," an official of the bureau said.
He added that the measure would serve the dual purpose of helping conserve fishing resources and cutting fishing boat owners' operational expenses.

According to the program, owners of licensed fishing boats may apply to the local fishermen's association between May 1 and Oct. 31 to get NT$8,000 for each sampan, NT$10,000 for each fishing raft, and up to NT$100,000 for a fishing boat, depending on the vessel's tonnage.
Recreational fishing boats are excluded from the program.
To qualify for a subsidy, a fishing boat must have spent at least 90 working days fishing at sea and at least 130 days sitting idle at a port from Sept. 1 last year through Aug. 31 this year.
In addition, the boat must not be involved in any criminal cases, such as smuggling contraband or illegal immigrants, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canada hopes to retake Taiwanese market in beef exports

TEXT.P: Canada's beef exporters are hoping to revive its beef exports to Taiwan to a healthy level after a four-year ban stemming from mad cow disease hurt trade, industry officials said Monday.
The industry's Canada Beef Export Federation Taiwan Office, sponsored a beef cuisine promotional event in Taichung City Monday in hopes of boosting beef imports to the island.

The event, launched by a hotel in that central Taiwan City, aims to promote Canadian beef in Taiwan, which imported more than 3,000 tons of the red meat annually until 2003, when the Taiwanese government imposed a ban due to the occurrence of mad cow disease in Canada.
Authorities in Taiwan lifted the ban last June, but annual import volume remain far short of previous demand, reaching around 500 tons last year, according to Ted Haney, president of the federation.

Haney said he is confident of Canadian beef's quality and said he hopes that with the promotion this year's imports of Canadian beef to Taiwan will reach 1,400 tons, or about 3 percent of Taiwan's market for beef imports, which is dominated by Australian beef.
Canadian beef had a nearly 6 percent marketshare before the import ban was imposed in 2003.
The event held at the Landis Taichung Hotel in Taichung City introduces beef cuisines along with other typical Canadian dishes to customers.
Those who attend the event will have a chance at winning prizes such as coupons for a free guest room in Landis Hotels around the island.
Taiwan started importing Canadian beef in 1994. In addition to locally produced beef, Canadian beef also competes with beef imported from the United States, Australia and New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan could be Asia's first death penalty-free country: DPP candidate

TEXT.P: Taiwan could be the first country in Asia that abolishes the death penalty, ruing Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh said Monday.
Describing the abolishment of capital punishment as the global trend, Hsieh said that it will be "a matter of time" for Taiwan to abolish the death penalty.
He added that the government should launch supplementary measures, including life imprisonment, and encourage the public to discuss related issues in an educational manner.
He did not say whether or how he would work toward abolishing the death penalty in Taiwan if elected.
Hsieh also lauded Taiwan's government for having moved in the right direction to minimize the execution of criminals in recent years.
Over the past two years, no prisoner in Taiwan was put to death.
Hsieh's remarks came in response to questions from Lin Hsin-yi, head of the Taiwan Alliance to End the Death Penalty, during a meeting with groups consisting of local lawyers and legal experts.
The groups also invited Hsieh's rival, front-runner Ma Ying-jeou, of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . Ma did not attend the event but promised to meet the groups on another day.
During the meeting, Hsieh said that when he helped draft the DPP's action plans 22 years ago, he proposed the idea of abolishing the death penalty.
Back then, such an issue was very controversial because there was no supplementary measure to satisfy the sense of social justice, he explained.

Besides the death penalty issue, Hsieh promised to use various occasions to help promote several important judicial reform bills that the legislature has failed to pass if he is elected in the March 22 polls.
In a separate matter, Hsieh also said that he would respect the KMT, which controls three-quarters of the 113 legislative seats, in choosing a candidate for premiership.
He added that if elected, he will form a coalition government across the political spectrum.

However, he pointed out that it would be impossible to amend the Constitution to address the defects of the new legislative electoral system of "single constituency, two votes" as the KMT dominates the legislature.
The system, which allows only one seat per constituency area, is widely believed to have favored the KMT in the Jan. 12 legislative elections, even though the DPP pushed for it.

Citing as an example of problems in the system, Hsieh said that on the Taiwan- held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, only several thousand voters were eligible to vote for one legislative seat in their constituency district, while in other parts of Taiwan, tens of thousands of voters voted for one seat.
Hsieh also vowed to promote legislation to establish a national human rights commission if he wins the presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public has low confidence in property values: survey

TEXT.P: Consumer confidence in Taiwan's housing values fell to its lowest level in five years in the fourth quarter of 2007, with many people expecting prices to fall, according to results of a quarterly survey released Tuesday.

According to the poll conducted by the non-profit Institute for Physical Planning and Information (IPPI), the composite housing price confidence index stood at 83 in the fourth quarter, down from 88 in the previous quarter.

The level was the lowest since the survey was first conducted in the second quarter of 2002. Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, said although both presidential candidates from the ruling and opposition parties proposed increasing exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China to give a boost to the domestic housing market up, the latest survey's results indicate the proposal did not raise public confidence about property values.
Meanwhile, the confidence index for housing prices in the future was slightly higher at 87. Confidence that property prices will rise in the near future, however, stood at a low 78.
The figures suggest that consumers are expecting housing prices to rise a year later, but not in the next few months.

The IPPI survey for the fourth quarter of 2007 also found that 63.1 percent of the "home seekers" who are looking to buy a home expected housing prices to drop in the near term, up from the level of 44.9 percent in the third quarter of 2007. For the following year, 47.5 percent of home seekers expected prices to fall, while 40.6 percent of homeowners held the same opinion. Regarding the financial burden on home buyers, the survey results indicate that the average cost of housing in Taiwan in the fourth quarter of 2007 was equal to seven times the average annual income of local people, down from the level of 7.2 times in the previous quarter.

In the capital city of Taipei, the average housing price in the fourth quarter dropped to a level equal to 8.6 times the average annual income of the city residents, from that of 9.9 times in the third quarter.
Home buyers in the city expect to spend an average 36.5 percent of their earnings on mortgage loans every month, down from 43.6 percent in the previous quarter.
Chang said the change does not mean that the financial condition of home buyers has improved, but that rich people have bought more homes.

The survey was carried out from Jan. 1-15 on the clients of 322 branches of 16 banks, 170 branches of nine major real estate brokerage companies and the Tsui Ma Ma Foundation for Housing and Community Services.
A total of 1,963 people responded to the survey with the margin of error at three percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGDepression drugs dont work, finds data review
Millions of people taking commonly prescribed antidepressants such as Prozac and Seroxat might as well be taking a placebo, according o the first study to include unpublished vidence.
The new generation of antidepressant drugs work no better than a placebo for the majority of patients with mild or even severe depression, comprehensive research of clinical trials has found.

DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times:Obama's Support Grows Broader, New Poll Finds
In the past two months, Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters, with especially strong support among men, and is now viewed by most Democrats as the candidate best able to beat Senator John McCain in the general election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The Wall Street Journal: U.S. Pushes Sovereign Funds To Open to Outside Scrutiny
Seeking to head off a political backlash against huge investments in Western companies by Asian and Middle Eastern government-run investment funds, the U.S. is prodding two of the biggest funds to embrace a set of promises that they won't use their wealth for political advantage.

The 2008 presidential campaign has witnessed the rise of a whole arsenal of new political weapons, including Internet fundraising and sophisticated microtargeting of voters. For Sen. Barack Obama, however, the most powerful weapon has been one of the oldest.
The Washington Times:Obama's Africa-trip photo sparks new fight
The Democratic presidential contenders yesterday prepared for a bruising debate here tonight by accusing each other of dirty politics after a photograph surfaced of Sen. Barack Obama wearing a turban and Muslim-style robes.
