DOC.TEXT: Remains of the two little brothers, who were missing in June, 2006, were found in a waterless pit in Gravina, Puglia region, Monday. The rescue of a 13-year- old boy who fell into the same pit by accident led to the discovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's currency appreciation seen as result of healthy economy

TEXT.P: The recent surge in Taiwan's currency relative to the United States greenback reflects the country's strong economic fundamentals and could help dampen inflation concerns, said Thomas Yeh, the vice-chairman of the Council on Economic Planning and Development.

The Taiwan dollar closed Tuesday at NT$31.21 against the U.S. dollar, according to Taipei Forex Inc., and an intraday high of NT$31.12 was the highest level the currency has reached against the greenback since being quoted at NT$31.102 on May 6, 2005.

The currency has risen more than 3.5 percent since the beginning of the year, the most of any Asian currency outside Japan, but Yeh said recently it was the result of a healthy economy rather than the infusion of "hot money" by speculators.

"The Taiwan dollar has not appreciated to its potential, gaining only 3.6 percent in the 10 years from 1997 to 2006, during which time average annual economic growth stood at 4.38 percent, " Yeh said Monday.

That pales compared to the appreciation of other Asian currencies during the same period, with the Japanese yen and Korean won rising against the U.S. dollar by 22 percent and 78.7 percent during that time.

Taiwan's currency averaged NT$32.34 to the U.S. dollar in December 1997 after it having averaged NT$27.5 for much of the year before the Asian financial crisis took hold. It is not gone lower than NT$30 to the greenback since then.
Yeh argued that a rising currency could benefit Taiwan's economy by stemming inflation concerns among local manufacturers, some of whom rely heavily on imported commodities.

"Taiwan's manufacturing-based economy could easily be squeezed by the skyrocketing prices of international raw materials such as oil, " Yeh said, but an appreciating currency could somewhat offset those "import inflation" pressures.
By making imported finished goods cheaper, a stronger Taiwan dollar could also boost the buying power of local consumers, he said, a welcome jolt in an economy where consumer confidence is lagging.

While exporters fear the appreciating currency could hurt their competitiveness, Yeh felt those concerns were exaggerated as the export sector remains strong. Taiwan's trade surplus grew 28.4 percent in 2007 to US$27.38 billion.
Another factor spurring the currency's rise is the prospect of closer economic ties with China, regardless of who wins the March 22 presidential election.

Lee-rong Wang, director of the Center for Economic Forecasting under the Chung- Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) , said the Taiwan dollar has been undervalued as investors have hesitating investing in local capital markets because of restrictions on cross-Taiwan Strait economic activity.
"(The appreciation of the currency) is about rebuilding investor confidence that had been dampened by the tighter cross-strait economic policy," Wang contended.
"The currency is now gaining ground thanks to the cross-strait policies that have been proposed during the presidential campaign, " she said.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate Frank Hsieh and his opposition Kuomintang rival Ma Ying-jeou have both pledged more open policies, including direct flights to China, to strengthen cross-strait economic ties.
A better-than-expected growth rate of 5.7 percent in 2007 has also prompted foreign companies to redirect capital into the local market, she said.

Although Taiwan's stock market is flat for the year, the market's benchmark index has risen about 10 percent in the past two weeks, with foreign investors buying a net of NT$82.35 billion in shares in February, reflecting newfound confidence in the local market.

Other analysts believe Taiwan's interest rates are driving the currency higher. The Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) raised interest rates to 3.375 percent in December for the 14th straight quarter, and they are now higher than those in the United States, discouraging interest in the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has done decent job in mangrove conservation: scholars

TEXT.P: With mangrove coverage having diminished by 20 percent globally from 1980 to 2005, Taiwan, bucking the trend, has done a decent job in mangrove conservation, according to local experts and academics.

A recent report released by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) under the United Nations issued another warning about the rapid disappearance of mangroves, which are important in terms of the ecosystem as they give shelter to many kinds of organisms such as young shellfish and crabs, and protect coastal biodiversity.

According to the report, global mangrove coverage has diminished by 20 percent from 1980 to 2005, which means a disappearance of 3.6 million hectares. In Asia alone, mangroves have suffered a decrease of 1.9 million hectares in 25 years, mainly due to high population pressure and changes in land use.

The deforestation of mangroves may lead to severe losses of biodiversity and livelihood, in addition to salt intrusion in coastal areas and siltation of coral reefs, ports and shipping lanes, pointed out FAO Director Wulf Killmann.

In Taiwan, however, mangroves occupied an area of about 280 hectares 10 years ago, a coverage that has remained stable, said Mei-li Hsueh, a researcher from the Endemic Species Research Institute located in central Taiwan, who added that the stability has been the result of joint efforts by local governments and the private sector.

Taiwan's success is not total surprise. Mangroves in Taiwan suffered great losses in the 1970s, with one species, bruguiera gymnorrhiza, disappearing altogether due to reconstruction work at the port of Kaohsiung in the south of the island.

In the meantime, some non-governmental organizations have tried to prevent mangrove areas from being eradicated because of industrial development. At least four natural reserves for mangroves were designated by the government as natural conservation zones -- in Guandu, Zhuwei and Bali in northern Taiwan, and in Sicao in the south.

Hsueh warned, however, that in addition to the human threat, "now mangroves and other wetlands in Taiwan face another threat, which is the change of the natural coastlines." Land subsidence and shifting coastlines have become problems for the stability of wetland ecosystems, she noted.

"Taiwan is ahead of many countries in the area of ecological evaluation before restoration, " said Chen Zhang- po, a researcher at the Research Center for Biodiversity under Academia Sinica, adding that in general, Taiwan has done a decent job in protecting mangroves.
"Taiwan's conservation of biodiversity has changed its direction from specific species to entire habitats in order to protect various species, which represents real progress," said Hsueh.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges voters to back referendums on U.N. bid

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called on local voters Tuesday to give strong backing to two referendums on Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations that will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.

The president said that petitions backing the referendums collected a significant number of signatures, and that the two votes should be given the "same respect and have the same importance attached to them."

One of the referendums, initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " garnered more than 2.7 million signatures. The other, launched by the Kuomintang (KMT) on returning to the world body under the nation's official name, the Republic of China, or any other practical name, solicited more than 1.5 million signatures.

Saying that the referendum is a "major step toward cementing Taiwan's democracy, " the president said that the passage of the referendum, be it the DPP's, the KMT's, or both, "will definitely be the biggest triumph and achievement of Taiwan's people."
"If the voters split the votes, causing both referendums to fail, then it will be a result that we least want to see, " he said.

"It would also send a very wrong message to the world, leading the world to think that Taiwan's people don't care about joining the United Nations and safeguarding their own basic human rights, " the president said.
It will be the third time referendums have been held since 2004. The previous referendums failed because turnout fell below the 50 percent of eligible voters required.

Chen said that to prevent the two referendums from being defeated, he had sought to work with the legislature to pass a resolution on a "third" referendum proposal that could be accepted by all parties to ensure its success.
Chen said he "was forced to give up the idea, " however, because of various factors.

The United States, one of Taiwan's strongest supporters, voiced strong disapproval of the holding of the DPP-initiated referendum, calling it an "unnecessary provocation, " which will not help the nation.

The president made the remarks while attending an event outside the Presidential Office to promote a procession backing the U.N. bid sponsored by the National Cultural Association, U.N. for Taiwan Alliance and other civic groups.

Chen noted that the 13-day procession featuring statues of deities or people dressed up as traditional deities parading around the island is scheduled to kick off Feb. 29 in Keelung before concluding in Taipei County March 12.
The procession will tour villages and townships with the goal of awakening or rekindling the public's passion for the nation's U.N. bid.
The president said that the campaign was inspired by a Matsu procession in front of U.N. headquarters in New York prior to the opening of the U.N. General Assembly last September.

That event was organized by a group of Taiwanese expatriates supportive of Taiwan's U.N. bid, and the scene "touched the heart of everyone who attended" and attracted a lot of foreign media attention, said the president, who described it as a "successful and significant campaign."

After Matsu was returned to her temple in Taiwan, many temple officials said they also wanted to contribute to the U.N. bid, so the National Cultural Association planned the procession that begins on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exhibition of art treasures from Taiwan opens in Vienna
DOC.DATELINE: Vienna, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/26/08 21:15:52 (By Lin Yu-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An exhibition of ancient Chinese art treasures on loan from Taiwan's National Palace Museum (NPM) opened at the Kunsthistorisches Museum (KHM) in Vienna Tuesday, offering Austrian art lovers an opportunity to admire the beauty and richness of traditional Chinese culture and arts.
Addressing a grand opening ceremony held the previous evening, KHM curator Wilfried Seipel said Austria has overcome many political barriers to make the exhibition a reality.

The Chinese government was not happy about the event, Seipel acknowledged, adding that he met with Chinese officials to convince them that the name of the exhibition is in compliance with Austria's official "one China" policy.
According to Seipel, the KHM originally hoped that the exhibition could feature ancient Chinese art masterpieces from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but that plan did not come to fruition.
With patience, Seipel said he believes that political fences and obstacles between Taiwan and China will eventually be broken down by their common culture.

Speaking on the same occasion, NPM Director Lin Mun-lee said the Vienna exhibition follows similar shows from the NPM treasury in major cities around the world, including New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., Paris, Berlin and Bonn over the past decade.

"Although the collection in this exhibition is not the largest the museum has ever sent abroad, it is the most comprehensive, including masterpieces that connect the 5,000 years of China's history and demonstrate the vitality and fusion of Chinese culture, " Lin added.
Among the precious items, 88 are ancient artifacts, 23 are paintings and calligraphy and five are rare books and documents, Lin explained, adding that 55 of them have never left Taiwan before.

One of the most famous is a scroll painting titled "Along the River on the Chingming Festival." The 11-meter handscroll masterfully depicts life and customs in China's Soong Dynasty capital, Bianjing -- today's Kaifeng.
"The Vienna exhibition marks the first time the 270-year-old painting has ever been shipped abroad," Lin said.
It took four years to prepare for the exhibition, Lin went on, paying tribute to her colleagues and Austrian counterparts for their strenuous efforts to make the show possible.

The exhibition is part of a cultural exchange project between Taiwan and Austria. The first phase of the program was an exhibition of Great Habsburg collectors masterpieces of the Baroque period that opened at the NPM last October and closed Feb. 24.

Austria is the fourth foreign country to engage in cultural exchanges with the NPM, home to the best of the 1,000-year-old art collection of China's emperors. The museum is often compared to leading Western institutions like the Louvre in Paris and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

According to Lin, Belgium has also reached a consensus with the museum on a collaborative exchange program. Belgium has followed the example of the other countries in passing legislation to guarantee that none of the NPM's priceless artworks will be impounded due to China's sovereignty claim over Taiwan, Lin said.

More than 800 Austrian politicians, cultural and media personalities as well as Taiwanese expatriates attended the opening ceremony. Among them was Michael Spindelegger, second president of the Austrian parliament, who has visited Taiwan on many occasions.

The opening ceremony began with Reysi, a Paiwan aboriginal singer, singing a tribal ballad to an accompaniment of drumming. Her performance was followed by Taiwanese folk songs and a classical music performance presented by Taipei Philpharmonic Orchestra, led by violinist Su Hsien-ta.
At the end of the show, Seipel said he had discovered a lot about the diversity and vitality of Taiwanese culture and he expressed hope that the two museums can maintain long-term cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate will push Taiwan toward unification with China: DPP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh claimed Tuesday that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying- jeou will push Taiwan into "de facto" unification status with China if elected president.

Hsieh was quoted by the DPP's International Affairs Department Director Hsiao Bi-khim after meeting with Randy Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs and founding partner of Washington-based consulting firm Armitage International, and Dan Blumenthal, a co-director of the Taiwan Policy Working Group under the American Enterprise Institute (AEI), who visited Hsieh at his campaign headquarters earlier that day.

According to Hsiao, Hsieh said the March 22 presidential election will involve voters' strategic values and therefore the results of the election will have a big influence on the strategic balance in the Asia-Pacific region.

Hsieh noted that the DPP has advocated closer ties with Asian and Pacific nations, as well as with the United States, a policy that he said differs very much from that of Ma, who calls for as close strategic ties with China as with the United States and Japan.
"It would be a tremendous change in Taiwan's diplomatic strategy, " Hsieh was quoted as saying.

Stressing that Taiwan is already an independent and sovereign country, Hsieh said Ma will push Taiwan into the status of unification with China through the establishment of a common market and the mutual recognition of diplomas if he wins the presidential election.

"Once Taiwan and China are on the status of `de facto' unification, it will not be difficult for the KMT to seek `de jure' unification with China, given their absolute majority in the legislature," Hsieh said.

Unlike the DPP's long-term policy of seeking to strengthen Taiwan's national security, Ma has advocated his three noes policy -- no unification, no independence and no use of force -- as his planned approach to China, Hsieh said.

Noting that it is China that refuses to renounce the use of force in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait problems and not Taiwan, Hsieh said Ma's abandoning of the opportunity to boost Taiwan's security forces will cause a big impact on the strategic balance in the Asia-Pacific region.
Hsieh expressed concern over these issues, with his guests saying that America's policy-making sector and congressmen have also expressed similar concern.

According to Hsiao, a Taiwan policy report written by the AEI, which includes suggestions to Taiwan and the United States governments, has much in common with Hsieh's points of view. Hsiao suggested that the DPP and the United States promote mutual trust between the two countries, given their shared views.

Meanwhile, Schriver told Hsieh that although the U.S. government has expressed its opposition to the DPP's plan to hold a United Nations bid referendum alongside the March 22 presidential election as it sees the movement as a step toward Taiwan's de jure independence, that does not mean that the U.S. government has specific affiliation with either of the two campaign rivals in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calling for Taiwan-U.S. security consultative meeting

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called Tuesday for the establishment of a security consultative meeting between Taiwan and the United States patterned on one already in place between Japan and the United States, to help ease possible misunderstandings.
The president made the remarks when he received Randall G. Schriver and Dan Blumenthal, co-directors of the Taiwan Policy
Working Group that was formed by the American Enterprise Institute
(AEI) and Armitage International, an organization that assists
companies in the global marketplace.
The group recently released a report in which it suggested the upgrading of the level of Taiwanese and U.S. officials allowed to visit each other's countries.

The group also suggested the establishment of a bilateral meeting between Taiwan and the United States patterned on the Japan-U.S. Security Consultative Committee, or 2+2 meting, referring to regular meetings between the U.S. and Japanese foreign and defense ministers. These kinds of meetings could help ease bilateral misunderstandings and differences, and will also help resolve other issues of mutual concern," Chen said.

The president said Taiwan and the United States used to have a good high-level dialogue mechanism, especially between national security officials, and Schriver, who has served as deputy assistant secretary for East Asia and Pacific affairs, took part in such meetings.
But the United States has adjusted its mindset and approach after Steve Young, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office, assumed his post in 2006, according to Chen.
The United States seems to think bilateral dialogue conducted between Taiwan's representative office and the AIT are enough, Chen went on.
The AIT is authorized by the United States to handle bilateral relations in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.
The president noted that although Japan and the United States have full diplomatic relations, the security consultative committee still exists.

Chen also noted that the report does not address the issue of sovereignty and said it is an issue that cannot be avoided whether one talks about Taiwan-U.S., cross-Taiwan Strait or U.S.-China relations.

He cited the example of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization and the United Nations, saying that sovereignty is involved in these issues, as it involves the political, health and collective human rights of the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to be showcased on National Geographic

TEXT.P: Viewers in 270 million homes in 166 countries who might be interested in Taiwan's culture and biodiversity will soon be able to discover more of the island on the National Geographic Channel.

National Geographic Channel International (NGCI) and Taiwan's Government Information Office (GIO) announced Tuesday the global premiere of the second season of "Taiwan to the World, " the only documentary production initiative in Taiwan by the NGCI and the GIO that reaches a global audience.
The series of five one-hour documentary films is designed to showcase the island's customs, biodiversity and culture.

In March, National Geographic will lead its viewers on a discovery of Taiwan's transgenic and fluorescent pigs, black bears, kungfu, fighting crickets and conservation of the horseshoe crab, a "living fossil."

The kungfu secrets show traces the story not only of kungfu in Taiwan, but also of a man who can pull an airplane with his penis, while another of the shows features the Formosan black bear, the largest terrestrial animal in Taiwan.
Asked why they chose the topic of fighting crickets -- called "black dragons" in Taiwan -- Spanish director Jose Miguel Garcia Sanchez and producer Sunny Han said they found the custom interesting.

"The two-year production in China and in Taiwan was not only a cultural exchange for us, but also a discovery of the biodiversity in Taiwan. We didn't know there were more than 3,000 kinds of crickets in the world, and more than 100 in Taiwan," Han noted.

Through the documentary films, "we want people to `think again,' echoing the slogan of NGC, about what they think they already know concerning the modern world," said Mindy Lee, the marketing director of NGC's Taiwan office.
Started in 2003, the program has already showcased four shows in late 2005 on Taiwan's cockroaches, butterflies, racing pigeons and local beliefs. A third series is underway.
Broadcast in 34 languages, the series of five films will begin March 2 on NGC in English with a show titled Super Pigs, a documentary about Taiwanese pigs.

DOC.HEADLINE: `China will not lessen oppression of Taiwan': president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian predicted Tuesday that China will not lessen its oppression of Taiwan, no matter who is elected as Taiwan's new president.

Chen said China oppressed Taiwan on anything involving Taiwan's sovereignty, and its oppression can be traced back to the tenure of former President Lee Teng-hui of the now-opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Chen made the remarks while receiving Randall Schriver, founding partner of Washington-based consulting firm Armitage International and Dan Blumenthal, resident fellow with the American Enterprise Institute, at the Presidential Office.
According to Chen, China's pressure does not alter with regard to Taiwan's different political parties.

He noted that Taiwan's special envoys -- Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member, and National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party member -- were both barred from attending South Korean President Lee Myung-bak's inauguration ceremony due to pressure from China.
"As long as Taiwan insists on its sovereignty, regardless of who is the new leader what new name the country has, China will not ease off its oppression on Taiwan," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International archery group to help Taiwan develop computer games

TEXT.P: Visiting International Archery Federation (FITA) Secretary-General Tom Dielen promised Tuesday that the federation will work with Taiwan on developing computer archery games to be used for promotion of the sport around the world.

Dielen made the promise when meeting with Chinese Taipei Archery Association (CTAA) Secretary-General Chiu Ping-kun in the southern port city of Kaohsiung to exchange views on holding world-level archery competitions.

Dielen came to Taiwan to attend the Coordination Commission Meeting for the World Games 2009 in Kaohsiung City Feb. 20. The meeting was attended by board members of the International World Games Association and key executives of the Kaohsiung Organizing Committee for the World Games 2009.

Dielen was impressed by CTAA's combining archery coaching with multimedia technology after listening to a briefing by Chiu on Taiwan's efforts in archery promotion. He told Chiu that the FITA will start a project to help the association with development of computer archery games.
Dielen recognized Taiwan's performance in the promotion of the sport of archery and said Taiwan has shown its ability in organizing world-level games.
Chiu told Dielen that the association also plans to invite local enterprises to sponsor a semi-professional archery league, with the aim of allowing more archery athletes to extend their careers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers unconvinced of Cabinet decision to close defense company

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators said Tuesday they were not convinced by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's assurance that the so-called private company Taiwan Goal, set up with public funds to handle arms deals with other nations, will be wound up.

Answering questions from lawmakmers at the legislature, the premier said the government will stop public funds from being transferred to Taiwan Goal, thus making it impossible for the company to operate.

Chang said the government decided to call it quits on the establishment of Taiwan Goal because internal confidential information about the private company had been exposed, causing the company to lose the trust of its business partners in other countries and making it impossible for the company to serve its purpose.
Claiming that it is beyond the power of the Cabinet to dissolve the company, Chang said the Taipei city government can disband Taiwan Goal because it has jurisdiction over the company.
The premier gave his assurance that there were no irregularities because no further capital had been invested in the company and because Taiwan Goal had not signed any contracts with foreign firms.

However, Legislator Fai Hung-tai, a whip of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, pointed out that Taiwan Goal was registered with the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of the Interior, not the Taipei city government, and that the central government, as the major capital provider, definitely has the right to disband the company.

Data from the Ministry of Economic Affairs shows that Taiwan Goal was set up with capital totaling NT$1 billion (US$31.15 million) and paid-in capital of NT$80 million, with the Ministry of National Defense contributing 45 percent of the investment.

According to the Cabinet, the initial funding of NT$80 million has been collected, including NT$50 million from China Steel Machinery Corp. -- a subsidiary of the former state-owned China Steel Corp. -- and NT$30 million from a subsidiary of Chunghwa Telecom.
Another KMT legislator, Lai Shyh-bao, said the premier should not have told a "blatant lie" that the Cabinet has no power to disband the controversial company.
"Taiwan Goal is a 100 percent state-owned company. Chang Chung-hsiung can dissolve the company by uttering only one word," he said.
"Chang's statement today shows there might still be some kind of trickery involved," Lai said, adding that "it is unclear what tricks they have up their sleeves."
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said it is "ridiculous" that the premier has stated that it is up to the Taipei city government to disband Taiwan Goal.
Yang Hsiao-tung, a spokesman for the Taipei city government, said the central government ought to "clean up its own mess."

Taiwan Goal was set up by registering with the economics ministry in secret Jan. 28. Earlier, on Jan. 21, the company obtained permission from the interior ministry to engage in the import and export trade of weapons, industrial explosives, precision instruments, batteries of all types, and garments and accessories.

The government claimed that Taiwan Goal was established according to law, saying that the private company was necessary to help the nation procure weapons from abroad and obtain foreign technology to help upgrade Taiwan's arms industry.
KMT lawmakers, who hold more than two thirds of the seats in the new legislature, believe Taiwan Goal was founded in an attempt to avoid legislative supervision over arms deals with other countries.
The controversy became so heated that Defense Minister Lee Tien-yu resigned Feb. 23 to take responsibility for being unable to carry out the plan of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government.
Wu Nai-jen, a veteran DPP member and head of China Steel Machinery Corp. who serves as chairman of Taiwan Goal, said he will call a shareholders meeting to discuss disbanding the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu concerned that cold snap could affect tourism

TEXT.P: Tourism-related businesses in the outlying county of Penghu are increasingly concerned that the recent cold snap which is the worst in three decades and has dealt a heavy blow the island's fish farming industry over the past three weeks, might take its toll on the tourism sector.

According to local business sources, tourism-related businesses in the country might be badly affected by the recent cold weather, which has killed a great deal of aquatic produce raised by local aquaculturists and has damaged natural marine resources.

After extensive media reports about the serious damage that the Penghu's fish farming sustained during the Lunar New Year holiday, it will now be harder for the local tourism industry to attract tourists for the coming peak spring season in the months ahead, the sources said.
The negative impression that such reports have caused among the general public might also have affected many tourists' will to visit the islands, famous for seafood, according to the sources.
Fish farming and tourism are the two main businesses on Penghu, lying some 50 km west of Taiwan proper.
Worse yet, sluggish tourism might also affect other sectors on Penghu, the sources indicated, adding that most local shops are pessimistic about business in the coming months.

Yeh Chu-lin, chairman of the Penghu tourism association, said that the central and local governments should tell Taiwan's people that "tourists will be able to enjoy seafood just as they have in the past if they visit Penghu now."

"It is true that some species of Penghu's fish were killed off by the recent cold weather, but some of Penghu's other speciality fishery produce, such as deep-sea fish, have not been affected, " Yeh pointed out.

Tsai Wan-sheng, director of Penghu's marine studies center, also said a few days ago that the damage done by the cold to the county's aquaculture industry and its marine ecosystem has not been as severe as reported.

Chen Tien-shou, deputy director-general of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, inspected Penghu Feb. 23 at the head of 11-member group to explore ways to help the county recover from the fisheries plight.

Chen instructed Cheng Ming-yuan, the county's fishery bureau chief, to step up efforts to make the public realize that "Penghu is not running out of high-end seafood" so as to mitigate the possible impact on local tourism.

According to initial estimates made last week by Penghu's aquaculture industry, the county suffered monetary losses of more than NT$180 million (US$5.6 million) as a result of the fish killed by the cold snap -- about 1,537 metric tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to panic about infectious TB student: health official

TEXT.P: The public has no need to be jittery about reports of a junior high school student confirmed to be an infectious tuberculosis patient but who continued to attend school, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, said Taiwan reports between 15,000 and 16,000 new TB cases annually, so "it is not strange that one of the cases happens to be a junior high school student."
Lin pointed out that there is a standard procedure for dealing with TB cases and that "the public has no need to panic."
Lin said that the family members, classmates and teachers who have had close contact with the infectious student will be given x-ray checkups.

He noted that TB is curable, adding that 7,000 TB patients that are diagnosed as infectious cases annually can undertake two-week treatment in hospitals and then take medicine daily for nine months to be completely cured.
He said that although TB can be transmitted through the air, its transmission is not as fast as a cold or typhus and only those who have close contact can become infected.
If patients wear masks and not stay in enclosed spaces for too long, then the disease can be prevented in over 80 percent of cases, he went on.
Health officials of the Taipei city government said that day that the school attended by the infectious student has conducted an urgent disinfection of the premises.
Health officials were sent to the school to explain the situation to the faculty and the parents and to arrange for their checkups.
The school said the student's class has 35 students and 11 teachers and added that it will work with the health authorities to conduct related checkups.

DOC.HEADLINE: China bars nationals from visiting Taiwan: official

TEXT.P: China bars its nationals from visiting Taiwan despite its offical claim that its has resolved technical problems with Taiwan, a high-ranking Taiwanese official said Monday.

The official of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) made the remarks after the China News Service quoted Dai Xiaofeng, director of the exchange bureau of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, as saying earlier in the day that Beijing's Cross-Strait Tourism Association has reached an agreement with its Taiwanese counterpart on technical problems surrounding visits by Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

The MAC official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that it is the Taiwanese government's policy to allow Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan, adding that they can come either by plane or by boat.

Noting that "it takes two to tango, " the official blamed China for preventing a group of Chinese tourists aboard the British-registered ocean liner Rhapsody of the Seas from landing in Taiwan in late February.

A total of 659 Chinese tourists arrived in the northern Taiwan port of Keelung on the luxury ocean liner Feb. 11, after the MAC relaxed local regulations to allow the entry of Chinese nationals on ships arriving from ports outside China.
The anonymous official further said that if Dai agrees that Taiwan and China have resolved the technical problems, then the Chinese government should "let them come."
"Political reasons should not become barriers to a policy that will favor both sides," the official urged.
Bilateral negotiations over the issue of allowing Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan came to a halt following a negotiation meeting held in Macao last August.
Taipei has repeatedly asked Beijing to restart the negotiations, but has failed to receive any response from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma condemns China for pressuring South Korea over Taiwan envoys

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou condemned China Tuesday for exerting pressure on Seoul to prevent Taiwanese envoys from attending South Korean President Lee Myung-bak's inauguration a day earlier.

"It is very impolite for China to treat people from Taiwan in this manner. It is also unhelpful to cross-Taiwan Strait relations," Ma said, adding that the South Korean government should not have been subjected to such pressure from China.

Ma made the remarks when asked to comment on reports that Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, who arrived in Seoul Sunday, were told to stay away from the inauguration after China's top representative Tang Jiaxuan threatened to pull out of the ceremony if the Seoul allowed Taiwan's envoys to attend.
"Wang Jin-pyng represents Taiwanese public opinion. It is extremely inappropriate for China to humiliate him," Ma said.
"China has gone too far, " Ma continued, adding that Beijing should not use such methods again to hurt the feelings of the Taiwanese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese elderly who live alone wish to have fun: survey

TEXT.P: Taiwanese elderly who live alone would like most to "go out for some fun" and would also like to take the bullet train to Taipei to visit Taipei 101, one of the highest skyscrapers in the world, according to a survey released Tuesday.
The survey on the dreams of elderly people living alone was conducted by Nan Shan Life Insurance Co. and Taichung City's Hongdao Senior Citizen's Welfare Foundation.

The two organizations launched a campaign to express concern for elderly people living alone late last year and asked old people living alone in Taipei, Taichung, Chiayi and Kaohsiung cities to voice their dreams.
Following "going out for fun" is "obtaining necessities related to their lives," such as gas cookers, clothes dryers, clothes, rice, artificial teeth and bicycles.

Rounding out the top five are good health and visits by family and friends, as well as health of their family members, showing that the elderly are afraid of loneliness and long for companionship, according to the survey.

Under the "show concern for the elderly" campaign, volunteers accompanied 23 elderly people living alone in Kaohsiung and Chiayi Tuesday on a trip on the high speed railway to Taipei and a visit to Taipei 101. Some of the old people also got the chance to ride the Maokong gondola, which served its 3 millionth passenger Feb. 17 after its launch July 4, 2007.
According to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior, the population aged 65 and above totaled 2.33 million as of October 2007, among whom, 320,000 lived alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Only Taiwan's people can decide Taiwan's future: ex-U.S. official

TEXT.P: Only the people of Taiwan have the right to decide Taiwan's future, a visiting former U.S. official said Tuesday.

Randall Schriver, co-director of the Taiwan Policy Working Group established by U.S. think tank the American Enterprise Institute and Armitage International, a company that helps other companies enter global markets, made the remarks during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
Schriver is a former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs.
During the meeting, Chen said he noticed that a report delivered by the working group avoided Taiwan's sovereignty issue.
However, Chen said discussions on relations between the United States, Taiwan and China cannot avoid sovereignty issues and focus only on human rights issues.
Chen further said the people of Taiwan have the right to enter the United Nations and the right to join the World Health Organization, describing these rights as facets of human rights.
These rights inevitably involve the issue of Taiwan's sovereignty, he pointed out.
In response, Schriver, co-writer of the report, explained that the report did touch upon Taiwan's sovereignty issue, but in a vague manner.
However, the report indicates that "Taiwan's future political status is the purview of the citizens of Taiwan, " Schriver said, adding that other people have no right to make such a decision.

Schriver said the U.S. has the obligation to defend Taiwan and that no matter what happens in the future, it is hoped that China or other countries in the region will not make any non-peaceful responses.

Taiwan's future belongs to the people of Taiwan, Schriver went on, adding that the U.S. will do its utmost to ensure this principle, which nevertheless does not mean that the options for the future of Taiwan should be thus increased or limited.

Dan Blumenthal, the co-director of the working group who was also present at the meeting, said Taiwan is facing a growing Chinese military threat and that Taiwan remains a potential international flashpoint for conflict.
The U.S. could be dragged into a military conflict between Taiwan and China, Blumenthal noted.
For this reason, it is very important to have high-level dialogue between Taipei and Washington, said the former senior Pentagon official.

Such a dialogue mechanism could help both sides effectively understand or collaborate on military or diplomatic issues, he went on, adding that it is necessary to restore the dialogue mechanism between the two sides.
The lack of a high-level dialogue only puts Taiwan and the U.S. in unnecessary danger, Blumenthal warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks fourth on global transformation index

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks fourth in the world in terms of its political and economic transformation, according to an index compiled by the Germany-based Bertelsmann Foundation.

The Government Information Office said in a statement in Taipei Tuesday that Taiwan only lags behind Zech Republic, Slovenia and Estonia and leads the other 121 countries covered by the 2008 Bertelsmann Transformation Index.

Taiwan ranks seventh in terms of its government's management, which is one of 17 criteria used to grade the world's countries which are moving on the way to democracy and market economy, according to the author of the index.
The Bertelsmann Foundation, founded in 1977 by one of Germany's greatest media groups the Bertelsmann AG, began to compile the index in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Penghu concerned that cold snap could affect tourism

TEXT.P: Tourism-related businesses in the outlying county of Penghu are increasingly concerned that the recent cold snap which is the worst in three decades and has dealt a heavy blow the island's fish farming industry over the past three weeks, might take its toll on the tourism sector.

According to local business sources, tourism-related businesses in the country might be badly affected by the recent cold weather, which has killed a great deal of aquatic produce raised by local aquaculturists and has damaged natural marine resources.

After extensive media reports about the serious damage that the Penghu's fish farming sustained during the Lunar New Year holiday, it will now be harder for the local tourism industry to attract tourists for the coming peak spring season in the months ahead, the sources said.
The negative impression that such reports have caused among the general public might also have affected many tourists' will to visit the islands, famous for seafood, according to the sources.
Fish farming and tourism are the two main businesses on Penghu, lying some 50 km west of Taiwan proper.
Worse yet, sluggish tourism might also affect other sectors on Penghu, the sources indicated, adding that most local shops are pessimistic about business in the coming months.

Yeh Chu-lin, chairman of the Penghu tourism association, said that the central and local governments should tell Taiwan's people that "tourists will be able to enjoy seafood just as they have in the past if they visit Penghu now."

"It is true that some species of Penghu's fish were killed off by the recent cold weather, but some of Penghu's other speciality fishery produce, such as deep-sea fish, have not been affected, " Yeh pointed out.

Tsai Wan-sheng, director of Penghu's marine studies center, also said a few days ago that the damage done by the cold to the county's aquaculture industry and its marine ecosystem has not been as severe as reported.

Chen Tien-shou, deputy director-general of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, inspected Penghu Feb. 23 at the head of 11-member group to explore ways to help the county recover from the fisheries plight.

Chen instructed Cheng Ming-yuan, the county's fishery bureau chief, to step up efforts to make the public realize that "Penghu is not running out of high-end seafood" so as to mitigate the possible impact on local tourism.

According to initial estimates made last week by Penghu's aquaculture industry, the county suffered monetary losses of more than NT$180 million (US$5.6 million) as a result of the fish killed by the cold snap -- about 1,537 metric tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to panic about infectious TB student: health official

TEXT.P: The public has no need to be jittery about reports of a junior high school student confirmed to be an infectious tuberculosis patient but who continued to attend school, an official of the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, said Taiwan reports between 15,000 and 16,000 new TB cases annually, so "it is not strange that one of the cases happens to be a junior high school student."
Lin pointed out that there is a standard procedure for dealing with TB cases and that "the public has no need to panic."
Lin said that the family members, classmates and teachers who have had close contact with the infectious student will be given x-ray checkups.

He noted that TB is curable, adding that 7,000 TB patients that are diagnosed as infectious cases annually can undertake two-week treatment in hospitals and then take medicine daily for nine months to be completely cured.
He said that although TB can be transmitted through the air, its transmission is not as fast as a cold or typhus and only those who have close contact can become infected.
If patients wear masks and not stay in enclosed spaces for too long, then the disease can be prevented in over 80 percent of cases, he went on.
Health officials of the Taipei city government said that day that the school attended by the infectious student has conducted an urgent disinfection of the premises.
Health officials were sent to the school to explain the situation to the faculty and the parents and to arrange for their checkups.
The school said the student's class has 35 students and 11 teachers and added that it will work with the health authorities to conduct related checkups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 27, or the 21st day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
285: Constantine I, Emperor of Rome known as "Constantine the Great," is born. He adopted the Christian faith and suspended the persecution of Christians.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1861: Rudolf Steiner, the Austrian philosopher, educationalist, and founder of anthroposophy, is born.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a U.S. headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a "harangue-the-troops" ceremony in Guilin, Guangxi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to render various elements radioactive.
1933: Japanese troops invade Jehol Province in northeastern China.
1933: Chancellor Adolf Hitler calls for a "God-given signal" that the communists should be crushed, as a mysterious fire guts Berlin's Reichstag, or Parliament.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists given all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1973: Governor Yu Kuo-hwa of the Central Bank of China leaves for Saigon to sign a US$5 million loan contract with the Vietnamese government.
1973: Ronald H.C. Ho assumes office as president of the Bank of Taiwan.
1974: Osamu Itagaki, chairman of the Sino-Japan Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei for talks on ROC-Japan civil aviation relations.
1975: The ROC and Saudi Arabia sign an air agreement in which Saudi Airlines will offer flight services from Jeddah or Riyadh to Taipei or Kaohsiung and China Airlines will offer flight services from Taipei or Kaohsiung to Jeddah or Riyadh via Hong Kong.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Dennis Theike, commander of Pacific Areas of the U.S. Veterans of Foreign Wars.
1980: Taiwan Power Co. signs a syndicated loan of US$100 million with ten foreign banks to finance development projects.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the ROC, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian promises to create 100,000 jobs to benefit 100,000 families and one million people if he is elected president on March 18.
2001: Kuomintang Chairman Lian Chan meets with People First Party Chairman James Soong, with the two agreeing to bolster future cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. secretary of state reiterates opposition to Taiwan referendum
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) 02/27/08 11:42:50 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice reiterated Tuesday Washington's opposition to Taiwan's upcoming referendum on joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan."
Rice, who is currently on a visit to China, said during a news conference held in Beijing that the issue was raised during her meeting with Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs Yang Jiechi.

During the meeting, Rice said, she reassured Beijing that Washington is committed to a one-China policy, opposes unilateral changes in the Taiwan Strait and expects a peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences.

"I also reiterated what I said in December, that the United States opposes the proposed referendum because we believe that this referendum would not be constructive and would, in fact, serve no useful purpose, " Rice said, according to a transcript of the news conference released by the U.S. Department of State.
Asked to comment on Taiwan's decision to go ahead with the referendum in the face of U.S. opposition, Rice said that Taiwan is a democracy and "will have to make its own decisions."
"But I think we've been very clear that we think that this referendum is not going to help anyone and, in fact, it shouldn't be held," she said.
Rice also reiterated Washington's belief that the "best way forward is when there is the prospect for peaceful resolution of differences across the Taiwan Straits."

The United States has encouraged dialogue between Taiwan and China to achieve that, she said, doing so within the context of Washington's commitment to a one- China policy and to a strong belief that no one should try and change the status quo unilaterally.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ranks fourth on global transformation index

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranks fourth in the world in terms of its political and economic transformation, according to an index compiled by the Germany-based Bertelsmann Foundation.
In the 2008 Bertelsmann Transformation Index covering 125 countries, Taiwan ranked fourth in its "Status Index," lagging behind only the Czech Republic, Slovenia and Estonia.

The Status Index, measuring political and economic transformation, explores the state of developed achieved by countries on their way to democracy in terms of the rule of law, a market economy and sociopolitical safeguards based on 12 criteria.

Taiwan ranked seventh in the "Management Index, " which measured the performance of a country's political leadership in steering the country toward democracy and a market economy between 2005 and 2007.
Taiwan's ranking was two places lower than in 2006, leaving it trailing Chile, Estonia, Botswana, Mauritius, Slovakia and South Korea.
The five criteria considered in the Management Index include consensus-building, steering capability, resource efficieny and international cooperation.
The Bertelsmann Foundation, founded in 1977 by Bertelsmann AG, one of Germany's largest media groups, began compiling the index in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Subsidized education for five-year-olds to be expanded

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will further expand its subsidized education program for five-year- olds over the next three years, with 93 percent of children in the age group expected to benefit by 2011, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
The measure is intended to reduce the financial burden of raising children and hopefully act as an incentive to encourage couples to have more children and reverse a declining birth rate, Chang said.

Children from households earning less than NT$600,000 per year were eligible for the program's subsidies starting with the 2007-2008 academic year, but eligibility requirements will be relaxed further under the Cabinet's plan.

Households with annual income below NT$800,000 will receive subsidies beginning with the 2009-2010 academic year and those with incomes below NT$1.1 million can receive subsidies starting with the 2011-2012 academic year, Chang said during a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Under the existing program, children from the targeted households can be enrolled in public kindergartens free of charge or receive subsidies up to NT$20,000 per year.
The Cabinet proposal calls for the maximum subsidy to be raised to NT$60,000 per year starting with the 2009-2010 academic year, Chang said.

A total of 110,000 five-year-olds have benefited from the program in the 2007-2008 academic year, excluding the number of children enrolled in private kindergartens who received education vouchers of NT$5,000 per semester, Chang said.
The government-subsidized education program and private-school voucher program will together benefit an estimated 181,000 children in the 2011-2012 academic year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Railway Station launches public address service in Japanese

TEXT.P: Japanese travelers in Taiwan will now be able to take the train with more confidence of finding their way following the introduction of public address announcements in Japanese at the Taipei Railway Station.

"This new service is expected to benefit as many as 21,000 passengers per month who only understand Japanese but want to travel by train, " said Lee Young-shen, the station master of Taipei Railway Station.

Japanese travelers find traveling by train to be one of the best ways to get around Taiwan, Lee said, but they often run into problems because of a lack of information provided in their native language.
"We decided to announce train information in Japanese because Japanese tourists often got lost, either taking the wrong train or getting off at a wrong destination," Lee said.

Noting that 90,000 passengers pass through Taipei Railway Station every day, which creates a maze-like atmosphere for people not familiar with it, Lee was confident that the station's "multilingual services benefit travelers of other nationalities."

With the introduction of Japanese, the station now announces each train's departure time, platform number, train number, and destinations in five languages -- Mandarin Chinese, Taiwanese, Hakka, English and Japanese.
"The station even reminds Japanese travelers of approaching trains in Japanese for their safety," Lee added.
Train delays are not yet part of the station's Japanese repertoire, but the station master said the service would be improved with time and had already received plaudits from travelers.
"Local passengers are supportive of this service and foreign travelers have also thanked the station for providing it," Lee said.

The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) also hopes in the future to strengthen the language skills of train conductors, Lee said, to help overseas travelers get around Taiwan more easily and take any uncertainty out of their train travel plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Agency calls for protection of ancient stone carving group

TEXT.P: Officials from the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) urged the public Wednesday to help protect 2,000-year-old stone carvings and sculptures in the Central Mountain Range that have recently been damaged by unidentified individuals.

CCA officials, who visited the site with members of the Kaohsiung County Government last week to determine if it should be designated as a national historic site, confirmed that the stone carvings had been damaged by traces of fire and an industrial adhesive, which may have been used to help with stone rubbings.

The officials believed that fires were lit to burn away the 3.3-centimeter-thick moss covering the images cut into the stone, located in a remote area of Maolin Township, Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan.

Tsao Chia-wen, head of a preparatory office for the planned CCA Cultural Assets Management Department, said he and his colleagues could not be certain if the damage was made by members of an academic organization as reported by a media outlet a day earlier.

Tsao said instructions and warning signs will be posted at the entrance of the Wanshan mountain area to remind people of the archaeological and cultural values of the Wanshan stone carvings and the importance of protecting it.

The series of images were first discovered by mountain climbers in 1972, and are believed to have been carved by the Rukais, one of Taiwan's 12 mountain-residing indigenous groups, up to 2,000 years ago.

The 14 groups of carvings include images of human faces, geometric patterns composed of circles, and hundred-pacer snakes, a traditional symbol of the Rukai people and are seen as treasures of aboriginal culture and history.
The Kaohsiung county government designated the site as a county historic site in 2006, but Tsao was unsure Wednesday if the site would be upgraded to a national historic site.
He said a CCA ad hoc committee especially established for the matter recently will meet again soon to discuss the site's archaeological, ethnic, artistic and architectural significance.
A resolution on the site's status is expected to be made in late March, Tsao added.

According to the CCA Cultural Assets Management Department preparatory office, organizations or individuals who are interested in probing or taking impressions of the Wanshan stone carvings should first apply with the Kaohsiung county government for a permit before attempting to enter the mountain.
The site does not offer easy access and can only be reached by crossing mountains and rivers.
Violators could face fines up to NT$1 million or jail terms under five years, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Election charter flights' require negotiations: MAC

TEXT.P: The so-called "election charter flight services" idea is a new issue that needs to be negotiated by authorities from Taiwan and China before it can be launched, Taiwan's top China policy planner said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Taiwan needs to renew its cross-strait charter flight talks with Beijing on the launch of such services prior to and after the March 22 presidential election, as it is a "newly emerged issue."

Noting that talks on technical issues surrounding general cross-strait charter flights have all been completed by the air carriers themselves over the past two years, Chen said that "cross-strait election charter flights could be launched tomorrow if renewed talks on the issue were completed today."
He urged Beijing officials to return to the negotiating table as soon as possible for political talks on cross-strait charter flights for passenger and cargo services.

He said China-based Taiwanese businessmen, known as taishang, could return to Taiwan by direct air routes to vote if political talks on cross-strait charter flights for passengers -- every weekend as proposed by the MAC -- are completed soon, with less than a month to go before the presidential election.
He added that the core of concern among taishang is actually the convenience in travel across the strait on a constant and long-term basis, not just for the presidential election.

Describing passenger charter flight services as an important milestone in terms of the opening of full direct cross-strait air links, Chen said that if passenger charter flight services are implemented as a result of successful cross-strait talks, direct cross-strait air links can be expected to kick off in one year.
According to a local media report, some 250,000 China-based taishang are planning to return to Taiwan to vote in the presidential election.
