DOC.HEADLINE: Amnesty policy to exclude investments in forbidden categories

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has instructed government agencies to study an amnesty for companies that have invested illegally in China, but which might exclude enterprises involved in producing items there not permitted by the government, a Cabinet official said Wednesday.
Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun said the amnesty policy would be based on previous attempts to get companies that violated rules on investment in China to register their investments.

"The government has allowed those Taiwanese businesses to register their China- bound investment in 1993, 1997 and 2002, and the amnesty policy will be based on the regulations set during those three registration periods, " said Chen Chin- jun.
He said the president issued the instructions after attending a gathering with representatives of Taiwan's six major industrial and trade groups Tuesday.

Looking to encourage domestic investment, the president hopes that before he leaves office in May the plan will lure back to Taiwan enterprises that invested in China without the permission of the government.
Without the amnesty, companies in violation of local investment laws could be subject to fines ranging from NT$50,000 to NT$25 million if they were to return to Taiwan.

According to Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chen Ming-tung, some 30,000 Taiwanese businessmen registered their investments in China with the government during the three previous registration periods.
The council has previously said that businesses making products in China that were not among the categories permitted by Taiwan's government would not be eligible for amnesty.
The MAC chairman said Wednesday, however, that his agency was studying possible amnesty for these enterprises as well, but he would not offer a timetable for when a decision would be made.

DOC.HEADLINE: News center set up for foreign media covering presidential election

TEXT.P: A news center especially set up for international news media covering the March 22 presidential election had now begun operations, a Government Information Office (GIO) official said Wednesday, adding that so far, more than 100 foreign journalists have registered to cover the event.
According to Chi Tung-yang, a secretary at the GIO's Information and Liaison Office, the news center will provide foreign media with better access to information about the election.
"Various programs, such as meetings with foreign minister and chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, will also be arranged by the center," Chi added.

Noting that some foreign journalists might be interested in visiting vote counting centers on election day, Chi said that "the Information and Liaison Office will also help them apply for permission to visit such places from the Central Election Committee."
In 2004, around 680 foreign journalists visited Taiwan to cover the presidential election, including 130 reporters stationed in Taiwan who represent some 70 international media outlets.
Pascal Liu, head of the GIO's Information and Liaison Office, said he expects the number of foreign journalists covering this year's race to reach over 700.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:In a Crucial State, aContentious Debate Clinton and Obama Clash Over Tactics In Ohio Showdown
In their final debate before critical primaries in Ohio and Texas, Sens. Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton clashed sharply on familiar ground, arguing over who has the better health- care plan, who has been right about Iraq and who would move most aggressively to rethink trade policy as president.
The Washington Times:Rice tries new tactic on N. Korea
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said the United States should consider future cultural exchanges with North Korea, even if last year's deal to end the North's nuclear programs falls through.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Democrats Clash on Health, Trade and Rival Tactics
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton confronted Senator Barack Obama on health care, Nafta, Iraq and his political tactics on Tuesday night in one of her most pugnacious debate performances of the campaign, as she fought for fresh momentum before four potentially decisive nominating contests next Tuesday.
The Wall Street Journal: Tensions Simmer in Ohio Debate As Clinton, Obama Near Big Test
Several days of political bickering came to a boil last night as Sen. Hillary Clinton faced off with Sen. Barack Obama in a debate that could greatly influence the fate of her presidential bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times: Hotel rates up, as visitor arrivals hit record.
Singapore tourism set two records last month - one good, one worrying.
First, the good bit: 883,000 visitors arrived, an all-time high for January, and up almost 7 per cent from a year ago.
The other record? The average hotel room rate hit an all-time high of $237, fuelling concerns among some industry players that Singapore risks pricing itself beyond the reach of more budget-conscious tourists from the region and China, who form a large part of visitors here.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Missing brothers probably die of hunger and cold.
The two young brothers, whose remains were found Monday in a waterless pit of an abandoned house yard in Gravina, Puglia region, probably died of hunger and cold, according to investigators. The two boys were missing since June, 2006 and the rescue of a 13-year-old boy who fell into the same pit by accident led to the discovery.

TEXT.P: Los Angeles TimesG South Africa to reresume elephant kills.

South Africa announced Monday that it would allow the killing of elephants as a population control, a move strongly condemned by animal welfare groups. Beginning in May, the government will lift a 13-year ban on elephant culls, usually carried out by shooting entire herds, including youngsters, from helicopters. ]By Lu-sheng Chu^

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices surge on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were up Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 154.41 points, or 1.85 percent, to close at 8,462.08.

Posting gains for the fifth consecutive day, the local bourse opened at 8,401.12 and fluctuated between 8,462.08 and 8,362.94 during the day's session. A total of 6.4 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$177.09 billion (US$5.71 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues advancing by 2.3 percent, the most of any sector. Machinery and electronics shares rose 2.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 2.1 percent, cement stocks increased 2 percent, foodstuff issues grew 1.8 percent, construction issues were up 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares advanced 0.8 percent, and textile stocks rose 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,410 to 582, with 354 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwanese workers worried about finances: survey

TEXT.P: The majority of office workers in Taiwan are worried about their finances as their earnings are eroded by inflation, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by 1111 Job Bank.

The results correspond to a report released a day earlier by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics that shows that the real regular earnings of workers declined by 0.03 percent in 2007 after deducting a 1.8 percent increase in the country's consumer price index, marking the third time over the past four years in which negative growth has been recorded.

The survey, conducted Jan. 15-28 among 1,067 workers, reveals that 85.94 percent of respondents are anxious about their financial situation, with 71.51 percent expressing worry about rising consumer prices, 45.74 percent about the lack of opportunities to make money, and 41.33 percent about the sluggish economy.

On average, most respondents think they need assets worth NT$32.94 million to ease their anxiety, while 26.52 percent said they would require NT$10 million and 20.43 percent said they would require NT$100 million.
However, the wealth currently held by the respondents averages only NT$1.31 million, with 38.67 percent having less than NT$500,000 and 40.45 percent being in debt.

On the methods of amassing wealth, 44.89 percent of the respondents are planning to do so through financial management, 20.06 percent through hard work and 18.09 percent through starting their own business.
In addition, 4.05 percent of respondents wish to make a fortune by winning the lottery, 1.69 percent hope to achieve the goal by marrying a rich person and 0.19 percent hope to inherit.

DOC.HEADLINE: New standards for migrant workers to come into force

TEXT.P: The waiting period for migrant workers transferring employers will be greatly shortened and the chances of their finding new employers will be increased based on new standards that will come into force Friday, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) announced Wednesday.
The amended standards governing foreign migrant workers transferring jobs will become effective Feb. 29, with several new regulations that are expected to benefit migrant workers.

The new standards state that as long as consensus is reached among the migrant worker, the old and new employers, or between the new employer and a migrant worker whose old contract has been discontinued because of faults on the part of the old employer, the new employer can skip the step of registering with the employment service center and apply for transfer of the migrant worker directly to the CLA.

"It will shorten the waiting time for migrant workers to find new employers, " a CLA official said, adding that in order to increase the opportunities for migrant workers to transfer to new employers, they can change their jobs from one industry to another, from one region to another and their employment can be continued by new employers who have a recruitment permit or are qualified to hire migrant workers.
According to the new standards, migrant workers will have up to 60 days, as opposed to the original six weeks at most, to find new employers before having to leave.

The Bureau of Employment and Vocational Training under the CLA has established a Web site and database for migrant workers and employers to register and look for related information at http://www.evta.gov.tw, as well as offering the telephone number (02) 8590- 2320 for inquiries.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Ishiba moves to minimize disclosure row
Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba tried Tuesday to contain the political fallout over fresh allegations that his ministry tried to cover up key information concerning the Feb. 19 collision of a warship and a trawler off Chiba Prefecture.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGGordon Brown faces defeat on 42-day anti-terror law
Gordon Brown faces the first major defeat of his premiership as ministers and security chiefs admitted last night that they were losing the battle to detain terror suspects without charge for 42 days. The Government has failed so far to secure the necessary support for the measure, despite the Prime Minister throwing his personal authority behind it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier takes helm of commodity price stabilization task force

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung named himself as convener of the Executive Yuan's commodity price stabilization task force Wednesday and pledged to do his utmost to deal with inflation.

Chang made the announcement at a meeting of the task force, which he attended as host for the first time since taking the helm of the Executive Yuan last May. During the meeting, he called for cooperation among the ruling and opposition parties in addressing the tough challenge of soaring consumer prices.

Chang took the job from Vice Premier Chiou I-jen, who was the previous task force convener, as Taiwan is facing rising inflationary pressure due to soaring core consumer prices, rising grain prices and commodity costs.

Core consumer prices, which exclude vegetables, fruit and fish, as well as energy costs, registered a year-on-year growth of 1.35 percent in 2007, the highest level since 1997, attributed to skyrocketing grain prices on the international market.

The consumer price index has also been projected to rise by more than 3 percent year-on-year in the first and second quarters of 2008 after the U.S. Department of Agriculture predicted that global wheat stocks will drop to the lowest level in 30 years, while Kazakhstan, one of the world's largest grain producers and exporters, has announced a tariff tax on wheat exports, according to Executive Yuan officials.

Facing the impact of soaring international prices of major raw materials and crude oil, a common consensus has been reached among relevant government agencies that restrictions should be imposed on exports of goods and materials crucial to people's livelihoods, the officials said, noting the government's recently announced a three-month ban on rebar and billet exports from March 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: With hardest challenge comes greatest opportunity: researcher

TEXT.P: National Yang Ming University (NYMU) conferred an honorary doctorate Wednesday on world famous AIDS researcher David Ho, who encouraged young students to take the lead in establishing a "safer, purer and healthier" world.

"As a scientist, I feel no fear in the process of exploration because for research to succeed, I have to embrace the hardest challenges and look at them as the greatest opportunities, " said Ho in a speech titled "Reflections of a Physician Scientist."

Ho was conferred the Doctor of Science Honoris Causa by NYMU in a ceremony in which Wan Wan, an HIV-infected child from Taipei's Harmony Home Association -- a non-profit organization devoted to helping people living with HIV/AIDS -- presented him with a pink rose and thanked him for bringing hope to her life.

Born in Taiwan, Ho emigrated at the age of 12 to the United States, where he became one of the first scientists to propose that AIDS was caused by a virus and championed combination antiretroviral therapy that has resulted in dramatic reductions in AIDS-associated mortality in developed countries since 1996. His research team is now devoting its efforts to developing a vaccine to halt the spread of AIDS.
"The more persistent the virus is, the more I want to defeat it," Ho said, adding that "even though there have been frustrations, I have never thought about doing simpler research."

Citing Albert Einstein's quote: "Life is like riding a bicycle. To keep your balance you must keep moving, " Ho encouraged young students to stay young at heart and to nurture uninhibited imagination and creativity.
"Your generation will take the lead to establish a safer, purer, and healthier world full of hope. Any one of you can become a great figure," Ho said.
Ho has been elected as a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and of Taiwan's Academia Sinica. He was Time magazine's 1996 Man of the Year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT presidential candidate unveils platform on national security

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou has proposed his national security policy platform, which is positioned at using wisdom rather than strength to win opportunities for Taiwan's future development.
Ma presented his proposal at a roundtable meeting on national defense that was also an annual assembly of the National Security Improvement Association, composed of retired military officers.
Borrowing from ancient Chinese philosopher Meng Tzu, Ma said Taiwan, as a small country, has to deal with big countries such as China with wisdom instead of strength.

Ma named his policy "SMART" and said it contains ideas for dealing with cross- Taiwan Strait relations, including "Soft Power, " "Military Deterrence, " "Assuring the Status Quo " and "Restoring Mutual Trust," plus the name of Taiwan.

Ma described "soft power" as developments in culture and the economy, saying that efforts to turn Taiwan into an axis of trade and culture in Asia will lead to an improvement in security and to China's lessening its military threat against Taiwan.
He said that if elected, he will try to mend relations between Taiwan and the United States, which he said have been harmed during the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's time in office.

Ma said his defense policy will be governed by the principle of "defensive strategy." Under this principle, he will convince America to sell F-16C/D aircraft to Taiwan as soon as possible, improve facilities at seaports and airports, and strengthen the development of anti-missile systems, Ma said.
He also promised to make national defense expenditure no less that 3 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product and to continue to buy arms from the United States.
Moreover, he vowed to make Taiwan a nuclear-free country and not to allow the development of offensive weapons, although he did not give his definition of this term.

The roundtable meeting, hosted by KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-ming, was also attended by former Premier Tang Fei, former National Security Bureau Director Ting Yu-chou, former Ambassador to South Africa Loh I-cheng, former Defense Minister Wu Shi-wen and Adm. Fei Hung-po, a military advisor to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: Radioactive waste stored on Orchid Island safe: AEC

TEXT.P: The radioactive waste stored on Orchid island is safely contained and there are no risks of harmful radioactive release, the Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Wednesday.

AEC officials said radioactivity monitoring on Orchid Island's storage site over the years has also shown that the environment and ecology around the island, a volcanic island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan, has not been affected.

The officials were responding to reports following an examination by the state- owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) that some barrels of low-level solidified radioactive waste stored in trenches have been seriously corroded and that some have burst.
The officials noted that Taipower started the examination Dec. 13 and had examined 696 barrels of radioactive waste from the first storage trench as of Feb. 20.
Among them, 34 barrels, or 4.88 percent, were seriously damaged, while 577 barrels were slightly damaged and 85 barrels needed to have corrosion removed and be repainted.
The seriously damaged barrels will be smashed and their contents repackaged, they said.
"Although some storage barrels have become corroded or misshapen, they have remained in the sealed trenches and there is no risk of radioactive release," they said.
Taipower officials also assured the public that there is no cause for alarm.
The disposal site on Orchid Island mainly accepts low-level solidified radioactive waste from the medical, agricultural, industrial and academic sectors and from nuclear power plants.
The site began to operate in May 1982 and stopped accepting additional nuclear waste in April 1996. A total of 97,672 barrels are currently stored in 23 trenches on the island.
With the high temperatures, humidity and salt air on the island, some storage barrels had shown signs of corrosion and the AEC had asked Taipower to re- examine them as soon as possible.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Taipower are looking for a final disposal site under a statute governing the establishment of a final disposal site for low-level radioactive waste.
After the inauguration of the final site, the waste currently stored on Orchid Island and at Taipower's three nuclear power plants will be relocated to the final storage site.

Reports by the Taipei-based China Times said Taipower have chosen four possible sites -- Mutan township in Pingtung County, Tajen and Tawu townships in Taitung County and Wanan township on Penghu -- to establish the final storage site.

The first three townships agreed to let Taipower conduct geological exploration surveys, but as the law stipulates that the establishment of the site will require the consent of county citizens through a local referendum and not just the consent of township citizens, Taipower "dared not" conduct the prior geological exploration, the reports said.
Although Taipower has set its sights on Wanan township on Penghu, the county magistrate, councilors and village chief have all voiced vehement opposition to the plan, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese and U.S. scholars cooperate to save coral reefs

TEXT.P: Taiwan's coral reefs are relatively healthier than those in other parts of the world, leading U.S. researchers to team up this week with the island's scientists to study the natural undersea formations, in hopes of saving coral reefs worldwide.

Scholars from California State University (Northridge) and experts from east Taiwan's National Dong Hwa University on Wednesday officially opened the Taiwan Coral Research Center, based in the National Museum of Marine Biology and Aquarium in southern Taiwan's Pingtung county.
The center's scientists will study the unique nature of Taiwan's coral reefs, which are found mostly in southern Taiwan, as well as off its outlying islands.

"Alternate current movements in the western Pacific make the living conditions of Taiwan's coral reefs better than many countries, " Fan Tong-yun, one of the Taiwanese researchers in the team noted, saying that was a key reason why the research center was set up.

Waters off southern Taiwan's coast, such as near Kenting, have a much higher coral cover rate -- 40 percent -- than the average rate of 20 percent in the Indian and Pacific Oceans. The phenomenon of coral bleaching, which turns the normally colorful corals into a dull pale hue, is also less serious here.
Coral bleaching is suspected to be caused by rising water temperatures and pollution as a result of global warming.
According to Fan, coral reefs all over the world, especially those in popular tourist destinations such as Hawaii, Tahiti and the Caribbean Sea, have seriously suffered in 2007 from coral bleaching.

But coral reefs in the sea off Kenting city in southernmost tip of Taiwan has escaped from the problem because there was an upwelling current in the sea, which prevented the sea temperature from rising too much, Fan said.
"Taiwan's know-how in coral conservation is ahead of many countries' in the world, " said Fan, from the marine biology museum, whose experts are also part of the team forming the coral reef center.
"It may even be Noah's Ark of corals, " Fan said. "But to reach that conclusion, we need to raise research on an international scale."
Experts from the coral research center will also study coral reefs in other parts of the world.

The center's researchers will focus their research on the movement of the currents and their influence on coral reefs, as well as coral ecosystems and the symbiosis system between algae and coral reefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet closely watching steel price hikes

TEXT.P: The government is closely watching the situation surrounding skyrocketing steel prices, a ranking Cabinet official said Wednesday, as local builders plan to strike to vent anger over the problem.

Chen Chin-jun, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said the government is paying close attention to the recent hikes in prices of steel products, particularly round steel bars or rebars, in the domestic market.

The government does not want to see an interruption in public construction projects and a compromise of the quality of construction, Chen said, responding to a reporter's question regarding a strike planned by the Taiwan Association of General Contractors.
The association is planning to hold a three-day strike beginning on March 11 to protest steel prices.
The average price of rebars has surged from NT$8,000 (US$258) per ton two months ago to slightly over NT$20,000 per ton currently.

In light of the outcry from the domestic real estate development industry, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Feb. 20 announced a ban on the export of rebars and small billets -- the main material used for the production of rebars for construction.
The ban is expected to last three months after it takes effect in two weeks.
Meanwhile, the ministry will also put exports of H-shaped steel and steel scrap under supervision for three months.
Lai Cheng-yi, chairman of the Shining Group, which is known for building high- priced houses and resorts, complained earlier this month that builders cannot buy steel rebars even if they have money.

Lai expressed hope that the administration will investigate the surging prices and warned that public construction projects and private developers will be forced to suspend operations should the government not intervene in time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi gets nod from Beijing to set up charity foundation in China
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/08 19:51:06 (By Chou Hui-ying and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation has received the green light to set up a Tzu Chi Charity Foundation in China, Chinese authorities confirmed Wednesday.

Answering questions at a regular press briefing, Fan Liqing, spokeswoman for the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, said the Ministry of Civil Affairs had formally approved the application by Tzu Chi to establish the charity foundation in China.

The new organization is the first foundation chaired by a legal representative who is a non-resident of the mainland, Fan said, adding that the foundation will fall under the jurisdiction of the State Bureau of Religious Affairs.
The establishment of the foundation is expected to play an active role in promoting cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in charitable affairs, she said.

The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, founded by Master Cheng Yen, a nun, in 1966, is one of Taiwan's four major Buddhist sects, with its head office located in Hualien, eastern Taiwan. It is actively involved in social services, medical care and education, and disaster relief around the world.
Tzu Chi is funded by donations from the private sector, and its workers are mostly volunteers. Currently Tzu Chi has offices in 40 countries.

The organization's first contact with mainland China was in 1990 when the central and eastern regions were devastated by serious flooding. Tzu Chi's relief programs helped flood victims in Henan province with NT$13.6 million in timely aid, built 945 housing units for homeless flood victims in Anhui province in 1991, and constructed 1,530 housing units for displaced families in Jiangsu province in 1992.
Since then, Tzu Chi's relief work in China has expanded to cover 17 provinces and the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

DOC.HEADLINE: China 'unwise' to ask Seoul to snub Taiwan at inauguration: speaker

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday that it was "unwise" for China to pressure South Korea to bar him from attending South Korean President Lee Myung-bak's inauguration ceremony.
The "oppression and obstruction are very unwise, " Wang told reporters. "Because of that, Taiwanese people feel China's intentional obstruction everywhere."
Beijing's oppression has also created a subject for international criticism, Wang added.

Wang returned from South Korea Tuesday after he and National Security Council Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, upon arriving in Seoul Sunday, were told to stay away from the Monday inauguration after China's top representative Tang Jiaxuan threatened to pull out of the ceremony if the Seoul allowed Taiwan's envoys to attend.
Wang said he had not expected he would be barred from that event. He said he was informed officially last Friday that he may start preparing his trip to Seoul, leading him to embark on the trip.
In the past, Wang said it was not possible for him to visit the neighboring country because of Seoul's denying to grant him a visa, even when he applied to visit his South Korean counterpart.
Wang advised China to act to "let Taiwanese people feel (its) warmth and friendliness" because that will facilitate interactions and exchanges between the two sides.

Meanwhile, the legislative speaker suggested Taiwan and South Korea seek to maintain and promote their exchanges, communications and cooperation through the channel of both countries' legislatures in the absence of diplomatic ties.
Despite being rejected from the presidential inauguration, Wang and Chen made extensive visits to South Korean officials, parliamentarians and prominent figures during their stay in Seoul.

Wang was speaking Wednesday while responding to media inquiries about the recent incident before he prepared to give a speech on the topic of "congressional diplomacy" at the Diplomat Training Institute under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education minister vows to strengthen vocational education

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng vowed Wednesday to strengthen vocational education and expressed hope that students can discover their talents and live happily thanks to vocational education.

Tu made the promise during a citation ceremony in honor of technical professionals involved with vocational education and training programs in cooperation with the Ministry of Education (MOE) for more than 15 years.
"Society attaches too much importance to diplomas and ignores students who have difficulty gaining access to academic institutions but who have technical skills," Tu said.
He expressed hope that the public will show much more respect to teachers and professionals dedicated to vocational education and training in order to deepen the country's vocational education.

According to an official of the MOE's Department of Technological and Vocational Education, the MOE began a program in 2006 to integrate the resources of the industrial and academic sectors, providing vocational training to students interested in the fields of yacht building, aviation, molding, processing and semiconductors.
"The program has attracted the participation of more than 5,000 students from 40 secondary vocational schools and 28 vocational junior colleges, as well as some 100 enterprises, " the official said.

In addition, the MOE also presented a program in cooperation with local enterprises in 2006, offering internships to junior high students from underprivileged families who have difficulty passing entrance examinations for senior high schools.
To date, 10 schools have opened courses for molding, machinery, mechanical, electrical and car repair, with the number of students reaching 480, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urges doctors to be cautious about working in China

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) urged local doctors Wednesday to "exercise caution" before applying to practice medicine in China, as the Chinese government is encouraging them to do.

DOH Deputy Minister Chen Tzay-jinn made the remarks after the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council announced earlier Wednesday that doctors from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau who have legally practiced medicine for at least five years, are certified specialists, and are currently practicing in medical institutions can apply to practice medicine in China.
Chen said local doctors considering applying should take into consideration that they may not enjoy the same legal protections as they do here.

"The professionals going to China should consider the issue of the protection of their interests" Chen said, noting that a lot of Taiwanese businessmen lost all their money investing in China because the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have yet to sign an investment protection agreement.
"The same thing can happen to medical professionals," he warned.
Chen said he was "not at all" worried about a possible exodus of Taiwanese doctors to China.
"The environment in which doctors practice in Taiwan is superior to that in China," he said.
Other officials from Taiwan's medical sector also echoed Chen's advice, urging Taiwan doctors "not to be rash" in going to China.

Lee Yuan-teh, an emeritus professor at the National Taiwan University who had supervised doctors in China before, said China's move could be an attempt by the country "to solve the problem of a serious shortage of Chinese doctors," instead of a "goodwill gesture."
Lee reminded local doctors they may be unfairly targeted for medical malpractice lawsuits in China, saying "it could be worse than in Taiwan," because Taiwan doctors could be treated as "outsiders."
Lee said Taiwanese doctors should not be "rash" in going to China before relevant systems and the medical environment are improved and both sides of the Taiwan Strait sign an agreement.

National Taiwan University Hospital's Superintendent Lin Fang-yu said that as a doctor, he welcomes China's opening to Taiwanese doctors, but he wondered how many Taiwanese doctors would go because of what he called "the lack of incentives."
Lee agreed, saying that medical resources in China are seriously skewed, with most of the resources going to the urban areas while some remote areas did not even have doctors.
Doctors' salaries in China are also generally lower than that in Taiwan, said Lee.

But for some charity groups in Taiwan, such as the Buddhist Tzu Chi Hospital and the Taiwan Root Medical Service Corp., China's putting out the welcome mat for doctors could make it easier for Taiwanese doctors from such groups, who are already interested in helping China's needy, to provide medical service in remote regions in the mainland, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan unveils white paper on increasing birth rate

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved a white paper on its population policy Wednesday, focusing on raising the country's falling birth rate to deal with an aging society.

Speaking at a regular weekly Cabinet meeting after hearing a briefing by Ministry of the Interior officials, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the Cabinet ironed out the white paper -- the first of its kind -- with the aim of resolving several problems arising from the continued dropping fertility rate that dwindled to an average of 1.1 babies born to each woman over the course of her life in 2007.

"The Executive Yuan hopes to increase the average ratio to 1.6 babies per woman by 2015 -- the average fertility rate recorded among the member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development," Chang said during the meeting.
The premier reported that the number of Taiwan's citizens aged 65 and older has hit 10.2 percent of the country's total population.

As society continues to age rapidly, one out of every 9.8 children is born into families composed of Taiwanese citizens and foreign spouses, Chang reported, adding that one in 5.5 marriages in this country is mixed-race.
"Fewer births, a graying population and new immigrants are thorny issues facing Taiwanese society," Chang said.

According to Chang, shortly after he re-assumed the premiership in May last year, he implemented a "10-year nursing system" for senior citizens based on the "Republic of China's population policy guidelines" promulgated in June 2006. Meanwhile, the government has projected to channel funds worth NT$81.7 billion (US$2.6 billion) into the program, he added.
The government has also increased its monthly stipend for elderly farmers to NT$6,000 as part of its efforts to better care for minority groups and the underprivileged, he said.

To fully prepare Taiwan to embrace the global challenges ahead, the Executive Yuan has also adopted a series of measures to help ease the financial burden on households, including providing parents with subsidies for child day-care centers and lowering the financial requirements for foreign spouses to get ROC ID cards, he explained.
In addition, he went on, the government is slated to open a retirement pension system in October to help local society tackle its graying population and secure sustainable growth.

According to the premier, the Executive Yuan will hold public hearings and seminars around Taiwan to explore public opinion on the population policies outlined in the white paper. Chang said he has also asked the Ministry of the Interior to periodically report to the Executive Yuan on how relevant agencies are carrying out the policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei employees enjoy highest salaries: report

TEXT.P: Employees hired by companies registered in Taipei City enjoyed an average monthly salary of NT$41,135 (US$1,326) in 2007 -- the highest level among Taiwan's all administrative areas, a municipal department reported Wednesday.

According to a report from the Department of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Taipei city government, the figure is higher than the average of NT$34,416 recorded by employees working for companies registered in the rest of the country and the average of NT$36,863 registered in the northern region.
The women's labor participation rate in Taipei City in 2007 hit 48.8 percent, lower than their male counterparts' 63.4 percent, the department said.
The labor force participation rate represents the percentage of working people aged between 16-65 in an economy.
Taipei City also had the country's lowest jobless rate of 3.7 percent for 2007 among all cities and counties. The country's largest city posted a 4.6 percent unemployment rate in 2002.

According to the department, a total of 1.16 million employees were hired by Taipei City-based enterprises last year. In terms of professions, as high as 80.67 percent worked in the service sector, followed by 19.11 percent in the industrial sector and 0.22 percent in the fishery, farming and forestry sector.

Last year, some 34.6 percent of job seekers who had their household registration in Taipei City said there were no job opportunities for them in the city -- down by 12.48 percentage points from the 2006 level, the department said.

Some 42.28 percent of job seekers around the rest of Taiwan said they found no employment during the whole of 2007, while 40.5 percent of job seekers in northern regions confessed to having encountered the same situation last year.
The two ratios are higher than Taipei City's 34.6 percent -- an indication that the city provides more jobs, according to the department.

According to the department, 65.4 percent of Taipei's job seekers said they had employment opportunities but did not get work last year due to various reasons. Some 55.3 percent of these people said they did not take a job because of poor pay, ahead of 10.8 percent who cited a lack of interest in the work on offer.

In 2007, employment agencies affiliated to the Taipei city government offered an average 0.94 jobs for each job seeker -- the lowest ratio in recent years and below the ratio of one job for one job seeker for the first time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't promoting urban renovation projects to boost economy:president

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the government is promoting six major urban rejuvenation projects in order to boost the economy, with energy- saving and green buildings covered in incentive programs.
Chen made the remarks during a citation ceremony in honor of outstanding architects.
According to Chen, the six major urban renovation projects are expected to create investment returns worth NT$56.9 billion (US$1.84 billion).

To show the central government's determination in improving the landscape of urban areas, an amendment to urban rejuvenation regulations has been promulgated recently to streamline its process and the Ministry of the Interior has assigned funds to subsidize 80 urban renovation projects presented by local governments.
In addition, "the government will increase floor space ratio for new buildings which are more energy-saving and friendly to physically handicapped people," Chen stressed.

Noting that architecture is not only a locomotive force in a country but is also an art, Chen called on local architects to design more buildings with characteristics from Taiwan's natural environment and culture.

DOC.HEADLINE: New LPG cars to help Taipei County clamp down on littering

TEXT.P: Taipei County Magistrate Chow Hsi-wei inaugurated a fleet of 20 cars powered by liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) Wednesday to help enforce a crackdown on littering.

Each of the new vehicles is equipped with an advanced electronic monitoring system which can record one's littering behavior as proof before a law enforcement agent subjects the violator to a NT$6,000 fine.

According to officials at the county government's Environmental Protection Bureau, Taipei County eventually will have 80 such vehicles to ply the streets of its 29 cities and townships to enforce anti-littering regulations.
Taipei County is plagued by litter bugs who throw cigarette ends on the ground or spit betel nut remnants on sidewalks.

Last year, county government officials handled more than 23,000 complaints related to environmental pollution. Of the total, 7,600 were formally charged with violating the law, according to statistics provided by the county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Official protests opposition criticism of Sino Swearingen case

TEXT.P: A Cabinet official said Wednesday it's unfair to criticize as a "scandal" the government's tentative decision to allow a Middle East company to take a majority stake in an ailing aircraft corporation, saying that the government is simply trying to clean up a mess left over from a previous administration.

Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun made the remarks after opposition Kuomintang lawmakers criticized the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) for planning to allow a venture capital company in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) to control 80 percent of the Texas-based Sino Swearingen Aircraft Corp. (SSAC) 's total stocks with a relatively small investment.
The Republic of China government holds a majority stake in the company.

However, Chen said that the aircraft manufacturer has been operating in the red over the years and that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration is simply working to solve a problem left by the previous KMT administration.

SSAC was established in 1995 as a partnership between Texas-based Swearingen Aircraft Company and Sino Aerospace Investment Corp. of Taiwan, which was managed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

Explaining the reason for seeking foreign investment, Chen noted that a legislative resolution passed in March of 2006 stipulates that if the aircraft company fails to generate profits by 2009, then the MOEA shall not increase its investment in the Taiwan-U.S. joint venture.
In addition, SSAC's private shareholders have no intention of making further investment as they have obtained no returns from the company, Chen pointed out.
The lack of funding will adversely affect SSAC's research and development capabilities for future aircraft models, he added.
Due to these reasons, the government sought foreign investors to help revive the company, Chen said.
Chen urged KMT lawmakers not to smear the government's efforts and mislead the public.
At a news conference held earlier Wednesday, KMT caucus whip Alex Fai and KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao demanded the economics ministry immediately cancel the foreign investment deal.
According to Lai, the UAE buyer only offered an investment of US$50 million and promised an additional future investment of US$100 million.
However, the buyer will be allowed to gain up to 80 percent of the SSAC's total shares, Lai said, describing the deal as "unbelievably cheap."

Furthermore, despite SSAC's promise to give its original shareholders a royalty of US$70,000 per jet after it produces the 101th jet in the future, the agreement did not specify who will get the royalty, Lai noted.

Lai claimed that the DPP government has invested more than US$10 billion in SSAC over the past eight years and that at a time when the company's technologies have finally become mature, the government should not be selling stakes to foreign firms.

Noting that the company has received jet orders worth a combined US$40 billion, Lai further questioned why the government is so eager to sell the company before a new administration will come to power in May following the March 22 presidential poll.
Also, Lai lambasted that the government holds a stake of 91 percent in SSAC, but the company is not subject to the Legislative Yuan's control as it is registered in the United States.
The other KMT legislator Fai asked for an immediate halt to the trade deal, warning that the KMT caucus will otherwise resort to legal action against top economic officials.
The KMT lawmakers made the criticism one day after Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen said that the ministry had planned to announce the bankruptcy of the aircraft maker several times in the past.
Now, the ministry has finally found a new investor who offers what he called "the best deal, " Chen said, stressing that the government is not trying to sell the company regardless of the price.

Chen explained that the ministry began looking for new investors two years ago, rejecting claims that the government was trying to finalize the deal prior to May 20, when the new administration will be sworn in.

The foreign investment deal is expected to help the company generate a production value of NT$20 billion (US$641 million) over the next 10 years, according to Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical team starts service in violence-disrupted Darjeeling
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, India, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/27/08 22:32:23 (By Paul Kuo and Ruth Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan medical team arrived in Darjeeling, a town in the Indian state of West Bengal, Wednesday morning and immediately started providing medical service while the area was still suffering from riots.
The team was organized by Taiwan-based International Cooperation and Development Fund, a government-run organization in charge of development aid to less developed countries.

Team leader Chen Chih-fu, who has visited Darjeeling often, told CNA reporters in a phone interview that the team received a warm welcome on arrival and local authorities sent more than 10 people to assist the team's service.

The team, with its 13 health care members, including doctors, pharmacists and nurses, is expected to help about 500 local people in one day. It will head to India's Himalayan state of Sikkim Thursday and remain there for three to five days before returning to Darjeeling, Chen said. The team will then arrive back in New Delhi March 15, Chen added.

Darjeeling, a popular travel destination for its cool weather and well-known for its production of black tea, is currently experiencing riots stemming from an indefinite strike called by the opposition party Gorkha Janmukti Morcha (GJM) , which is demanding the creation of a separate state comprising Darjeeling and certain contiguous areas from West Bengal.

The GJM is also asking for the removal of Subash Ghising from his position as chairman of the Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council opposition party in Darjeeling. Ghising is also the chairman of the Gorkha National Liberation Front, which the GJM had separated from, according to local media reports.
Riots stemming from the strike have caused economic shutdowns and chaos in the local residents' daily lives. Blockades were set up on the road between Darjeeling and Sikkim by GJM supporters.

Chen said Taiwan's medical team has received a pass approved by the GJM and should be able to get to Sikkim unobstructed. The group sent to assist the Taiwan medical team is not carrying any weapons to help protect the group, Chen said, but he added that he believed the local authorities would ensure their safety.

Khedroop Thondup, local organizer for the medical team's schedule in India, said Darjeeling is currently under curfew and that the team is staying in Darjeeling's Salugara, which is about the same distance from Darjeeling's airport and Siliguri where the strike is taking place.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four nabbed for marketing fake aphrodisiacs

TEXT.P: Police in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung and the central city of Taichung busted an underground medicine factory and its marketing network Wednesday, seizing fake aphrodisiacs in three different packages and arresting four suspects.

A spokesman for the Kaohsiung City Police Bureau said that Lin Chih-lung, 42, and his two accomplices were referred to the Kaohsiung Public Prosecutors Office and charged with violation of the Pharmaceutical Affairs Act for selling fake aphrodisiacs under the brand Love Strong.
Chen Bo-min, 45, who was in charge of the manufacturing of the fake medicine, was also taken into custody and will be prosecuted.

Police investigation showed that the fake aphrodisiacs in capsules would cause such side effects as low blood pressure, headaches, vomiting, dizziness, and blurred vision, although the manufacturer's description claims that the drugs are made of natural herbal ingredients.
Love Strong comes in three different packages and sells for NT$1,600 (US$52) per pack in some retail stores around the island. The fake drugs are also exported to other Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economy holds despite doubts over price inflation: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic outlook stays sound despite government-compiled indications showing a mild slowdown in January mainly because of inflationary pressures from international raw materials and commodity prices, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

The CEPD's monthly monitoring indicators pointed to a slight cut- back in January to 27 from 29 points for last December, CEPD Vice Chairman Thomas Yeh said, adding that the figure represented agreen light rating on the CEPD's evaluation scale that signaled stable growth for the third consecutive month since last November.
The monitoring indicators are composed of nine economic factors, including direct and indirect finance, monetary aggregates (M1B), and wholesale, retail and food services sales.
The last factor represents the largest fall-back in the January indexes with minus 3.2 percent in growth, indicating a shrinking local consumer market due to increasing commodity prices, Yeh noted.
Yeh attributed the decline to the result of global price hikes and the financial turbulence following the U.S. subprime mortgage crisis which raises downside risks to the local economy's prospects.

Referring to economic cycles, in which there occur fluctuations of growth and decline, Yeh noted that countries all over the world are lowering their expectations of economic growth in 2008 after the highs they reached in 2007, as Taiwan's government-projected number was also reduced to 4.8 percent this year despite substantial growth at 5.5 percent in 2007.
Global Insight, an international institute of economic and financial analysis, predicts 4-percent growth for Taiwan's economy in 2008.

As for countering the soaring prices of global commodities and raw materials, Yeh noted Taiwan's recent strong rise in the value of its share prices and currency could offset the rise of the Commodity Price Index (CPI).
Taiwan's CPI in January was up by 3 percent, a relatively stable performance compared with South Korea's 3.9 percent and China's 7.1 percent, he said.

Yeh also said that to maintain the recent foreign fund inflows that are boosting the country's currency and share prices, the government will be making economic structural reforms to strengthen investors' confidence with measures including lowering the corporate income tax to 17.5 percent from the current 25 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA suspends deal with foreign investor in ailing aircraft firm

TEXT.P: A plan to allow a foreign company to take a majority stake in a debt-riddent government-controlled aircraft company will be suspended to allay concerns about the investment deal, a top economic official said Wednesday.

Economics Minister Steve R.L. Chen said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will give a special report on the foreign investment deal to the legislature in late March and that the deal will only proceed with the approval of the legislature.
The Legislative Yuan will soon go into recess and the new legislative session will not open again until after the March 22 presidential poll.

Chen's announcement came one day after the MOEA announced that it has decided to allow a venture capital company in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) to control 80 percent of the Texas-based Sino Swearingen Aircraft Corp.'s (SSAC's) total stocks with a mere investment of US$150 million. The government holds a stake of 91 percent in SSAC.
SSAC was established in 1995 as a partnership between Texas-based Swearingen Aircraft Co. and Sino Aerospace Investment Corp., which is managed by the MOEA.
The decision was aimed at saving the company from bankruptcy, according to Chen.
However, the investment deal soon sparked questions from lawmakers of the Kuomintang (KMT) , the country's largest opposition party, who called it a "cheap deal."
After visiting the KMT caucus, Chen agreed to put the investment deal on hold for the time being.

Tu Tzu-chun, executive-secretary of Yao-Hwa Glass Co. Ltd. Management Commission, which is managed by the MOEA and SSAC's largest shareholder, said that the investment deal has gone through many rounds of negotiations and that some business documents have been signed.
The economics ministry is currently conducting damage assessments if it fails to obtain the legislature's approval, continued Tu.
The new investor has provided US$10 million in financing, which will help SSAC sustain its operations until the end of March, Tu said.
If the investment deal is canceled, SSAC will need to look for other sources of funds, Tu added.

The Middle East investor is the fourth company with which SSAC has sought financial assistance since November 2006, Tu said, noting that the previous three companies disagreed over the investment amount.
SSAC needs US$10 million in capital for three months of operations, Tu said.

SSAC might have to announce bankruptcy because a legislative resolution passed in March of 2006 stipulates that if the aircraft company fails to generate profits by 2009, the MOEA shall not increase its investment in the Taiwan-U.S. venture.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Feb. 28, 2008

TEXT.P: 2. Event: Opening of "New Born with Love" concert. Date and Time: 07:25 p.m., Thursday, Feb. 28, 2008. Place: Liberty Square at National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall, 21, Zhongshan S. Road, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: Vice President Annette Lu. Organizers: Presidential Office. Press Contact: Tel.2311-3731. 3. Event: "Against the Wind, Love Taiwan Most" evening party.
