DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 28, or the 22nd day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, the British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1825: Russia and Britain sign a treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: U.S. opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party. The Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later would become the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, the American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1934 and the Noble Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1921: Russian sailors of the Baltic Fleet and workers at Kronstadt naval base rise up against the communist government.
1922: Britain declares Egypt's independence, while it retains control of the Suez Canal.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Extraterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident in which an old woman was brutally beaten by police for violating the tobacco monopoly by selling untaxed cigarettes.
1951: The Republic of China Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1967: American editor and publisher Henry Robinson Luce dies at the age of 69. He co-founded Time in 1923 and later founded Fortune in 1930 and Sports Illustrated in 1954.
1973: Forty-four additional members of the ROC Legislative Yuan are sworn in.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect Taiwan businesspeople investing in the Philippines.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves a peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui gives an apology to the families of the victims of the Feb. 28 Incident in 1947 during a ceremony at Taipei's New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Russia becomes the 39th member of the Council of Europe.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives, while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
2000: The Philippine government urges Taipei to return to the negotiating table to resolve the fresh aviation dispute between the two sides and proposes that the talks be reopened in Manila between March 1-2.
2000: Chen Li-an, former president of the Control Yuan, formally makes known his intention to support Vice President Lien Chan, the presidential candidate of the ruling Kuomintang.
2001: Taipei and Shanghai authorities agree to further bolster sisterhood exchanges between the two mucipalities, beginning with a student exchange program.
2004: More than 1 million people held hands together to form a human chain that stretched the length of Taiwan from Hoping Island in the northern tip to Pingtung County near the island's southern tip to demonstrate their love for Taiwan and their desire for peace.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When I find a man agrees with me in what I say without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself -- I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan names deputy representative to U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan's current representative to Greece, Tung Kuo-yu, has been designated the country's deputy representative to the United States, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Wednesday.
Tung is filling the vacancy left by Stanley Kao, who already assumed the position of representative to Hungary Feb. 1.

Tung, who had formerly been posted to Houston and New York and had headed the Geneva branch of Taiwan's representative office in Switzerland and MOFA's Department of International Organizations, is familiar with Taiwan-U.S. affairs and the operations of international organizations, the official noted.

As the Taiwan government has been expecting the United States to support Taiwan's bid to participate in international organizations, Tung's background should be very helpful in assisting the government in promoting these efforts, he said.

Meanwhile, Huang Chu-hou, current chief of MOFA's Committee on Japanese Affairs, has been designated director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Los Angeles, replacing Wei Wu-lien who is retiring, the official said.

Chen Ching-chuan, the present deputy representative to Canada, will be appointed director-general of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, while current director-general Mark Liao will be transferred back to Taiwan after serving six years in the position, said the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Taiwan-El Salvador FTA to take effect March 1

TEXT.P: The free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and El Salvador is set to take effect March 1, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said Thursday.
This will be Taiwan's fourth FTA to come into force after those signed with Panama, Guatemala, and Nicaragua, the officials noted.
Taiwan began three-party FTA talks with El Salvador and Honduras in May 2006 and reached an agreement in November the same year.
Taiwan officially signed the FTAs with the two Central American allies in El Salvador on May 7, 2007.
However, the Taiwan-Honduras FTA is still pending the completion of required legal procedures in Honduras before it can be implemented.

After the implementation of the Taiwan-El Salvador FTA, El Salvador will grant tariff-free treatment to 3,590 Taiwanese products, while Taiwan will reciprocate by offering the same treatment to 5,688 El Salvadoran products.

MOEA officials said the implementation of the agreement is expected to strengthen trade, investment and technological cooperation between Taiwan and El Salvador and increase business opportunities for Taiwanese and El Salvodoran businesses.
In addition, the FTA will help Taiwan businesses make in-roads into the American market and assist El Salvodoran businesses gain access to the Asia-Pacific market, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Coast guard not told Ishiba quizzed officer
Japan's Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba admitted Wednesday that he and other top ministry officials questioned the chief navigator of the destroyer involved in last week's collision with a fishing boat without approval from the Japan Coast Guard, which is handling the accident probe.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. House committee adopts resolution in support of Taiwan election
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 27 (CNA) 02/28/08 15:38:05 (By Chiehyu Lin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Committee on Foreign Affairs under the U.S. House of Representatives adopted Wednesday a resolution in support of Taiwan's upcoming presidential election.

The resolution, which will be forwarded to the House for consideration, calls for the U.S. government to reaffirm its unwavering commitment to Taiwan's democracy and security and for the encouragement of international delegations to visit Taiwan to witness the March 22 election -- the fourth direct presidential election to be held in Taiwan.
The resolution notes that Taiwan has made dramatic improvement in terms of its human rights record and routinely holds free and fair elections in a multi-party system.
In particular, the 2000 presidential election marked the first transition of power from one political party to another in Taiwan's history, it says.

An unequivocal supporter of human rights and the democratic ideals of freedom of speech, freedom of the press, rule of law, and free elections, Taiwan is one of the strongest democratic allies of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region, the resolution says.

It also says Taiwan's stable democratic system and impressive economic prowess have made the country stand apart from many equally young democracies whose freedom and liberty have been severely challenged.

The resolution was jointly initiated by the late committee chairman Tom Lantos, who died Feb. 11, and vice chairwoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-Fla.) . It was co- sponsored by more than 40 representatives.

Taiwan's representative to the United States, Joseph Wu, said the passage of the resolution has again highlighted the importance attached by the U.S. Congress to Taiwan-U.S. relations and its support for the Taiwan people's pursuit of democracy and freedom.

In addition to expressing his appreciation to Lantos for the great attention he had paid to Taiwan's democratic development during his life time, Wu also thanked Ros-Lehtinen and Howard Berman (D-Calif.), acting chairman of the committee, for their efforts and contribution to promoting Taiwan-U.S. ties.
Wu said he is confident Taiwan's relations with the United States will grow even closer and stronger in the future with the firm backing of its large number of friends in the U.S. Congress.

Meanwhile, Bob Yang, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), a pro-independence Taiwanese expatriate group based in the United States, said the next presidential election in Taiwan is critical to Taiwan's future development and that the referendum to be held alongside the election on joining the United Nations under the name Taiwan has further increased the importance of the election.

While the United States has risked disagreement with Russia to support Kosovo's recent independence from Serbia, FAPA hopes the Bush administration would also ignore China's opposition to supporting Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, Yang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pitches for consolidation of Taiwan's young democracy

TEXT.P: President Chen shui-bian said Thursday the people of Taiwan should understand their history clearly and learn from past experiences to deepen and consolidate the value of democracy.
Chen made the rmearks while presiding over the opening of an exhibition of 228 Incident-themed artworks and documents at the 228 National Memorial Hall.

Stressing that democracy is not given by past administrations with mercy or through the asking of forgiveness from the victims and their relatives, Chen said that "Taiwan's democracy is gained through the efforts of the champions who sacrificed their lives and well-being."

"People of this land are able to decide their own destiny because of the forerunners' struggles for democracy, freedom and human rights, " Chen said at the occasion commemorating the victims of the 228 Incident which occurred on Feb. 28, 1947.

The incident was an anti-government uprising by local Taiwanese against the Kuomintang government and was suppressed by authorities resulting in thousands of deaths. The number "228" implies the day the incident began, Feb.28.
Chen continued that every person of Taiwan is a part of Taiwan's destiny, adding that "we must walk together without distinction between you and me to adamantly defend our homeland and justice."

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the definition of the 228 Incident in modern society should not be associated solely with political meaning or sadness, adding that "it also implies the strong will and courage of Taiwanese people who are tolerant and want to guard the homeland."

"We should maintain a more positive and honest attitude to face the grief of the past, using a newer and more extensive thinking with different angles to give the 228 Incident a broader meaning, " Chang said.

Pointing to the budget allocated by the Ministry of Education to the Memorial Foundation of 228 that is still pending in the Legislative Yuan, Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng urged the legislature to approve the budget proposal soon to allow the foundation to operate smoothly and educate the public about the facts of the 228 Incident.

In the "Themed Exhibition of 228 Massacre and Art Fare, " organized by the Memorial Foundation of 228 and the 228 National Memorial Hall, the background of the incident, Taiwan's democracy, and the cases of human rights violations in other countries are presented through historical documents, pictures, documentary films, and artistic works to make people better understand the importance of justice in the process of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chances slim to separate referendums from presidential election: CEC

TEXT.P: The chances are slim that two referendums regarding Taiwan's bid to join the U.N., scheduled to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election, would be set to another date, a Central Election Commission (CEC) official said Thursday.

Noting that the decision to hold the referendums simultaneously with the election was made by the commission after deliberate consideration, CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yu said he does not see any necessity for the commission to meet again to change the date unless there is sufficient reason to do so.
Such a change is not recommended especially when preparation for the referendums has entered its final stage and the ballots are being printed, Teng said.

Teng made the remarks in response to recent calls by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-hui that the referendums be postponed to allow more time for the ruling and opposition parties to sort out their differences over the referendums, so as to avoid their failure.

The referendums were initiated respectively by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . While the DPP's version advocates joining the United Nations under the name "Taiwan, " the KMT's initiative calls for regaining U.N. membership under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

However, as all previous referendums failed because the turnout rates did not reach the required 50 percent -- partly due to a boycott by the KMT, there have been concerns that the upcoming referendums would also fail, especially when voters who opt to take part in the KMT-initiated referendum are likely to skip the DPP-backed referendum, and vice versa.

Concerned that a failure of the U.N. bid referendums would mislead the world into doubting Taiwan's desire to join the United Nations, the DPP has recently been calling on the public to take an active part in both referendums to ensure their passage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defense ministry names new head of political warfare bureau

TEXT.P: Lt. Gen. Yang Tien-hsiao, current commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, has been designated as head of the General Political Warfare Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense (MND), according to an MND news release issued Wednesday.
Yang is to succeed Chen Kuo-hsiang, who will be transferred to serve as a presidential strategy adviser. The assignment will take effect March 1 and Yang will be promoted to the rank of general.
It was reported that Chen's job transfer was due to his role in the bungled defense company "Taiwan Goal" project, but the MND would not confirm such a report.
The MND said the replacement is just a normal personnel reshuffle.
Meanwhile, Yu Sy-tue, director of the Office of Military Spokesman, will be appointed to another post, with the vacancy to be filled by Chih Yu-lan, now deputy head of the office.
Chih will be the country's first female military spokesperson. Her new assignment will take effect March 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Convicted banker repatriated from China

TEXT.P: A fugitive former senior executive of the bankrupt Chung Shing Bank convicted in a banking scandal involving some NT$7.4 billion (US$239 million) worth of illegal loans was repatriated from China Thursday, law enforcement authorities said.

Wang Hsuan-jen, a former general manager of the Kaohsiung-based bank who fled to China last May, was repatriated from Fuzhou City in southern Fujian Province to the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu earlier Thursday aboard the Chinese ferry "The Strait."
The repatriation happened under the "Kinmen Agreement" signed between Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and China at the beginning of the 1990s.
After arriving in Matsu, Wang was airlifted aboard a police helicopter from Matsu to Taipei under the escort of Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials.

The repatriation made Wang the first major economic criminal from Taiwan who was repatriated from China since the two sides signed the agreement on Sept. 12, 1990 on the repatriation of hijackers, stowaways and other criminals.

According to CIB Officials, Chinese authorities were originally scheduled to repatriate Wang from Fuzhou to Matsu on Jan. 29, but his repatriation was postponed due to inclement weather and rough seas in the Taiwan Strait.
Wang was arrested in Shanghai on Jan. 24.
Taiwanese prosecutors have expressed appreciation toward China for its good will in taking the initiative to arrest Wang.

The prosecutors said hopefully, China will continue to cooperate with Taiwan in fighting crime by repatriating many more notorious Taiwanese fugitives hiding in China, including former Chung Shing Bank Chairman Wang Yu-yun and his son Wang Chih-hsiung, a board director of the bank. Both the father and son were convicted after the same banking scandal erupted in 2000.

The repatriated Wang Hsuan-jen, who is not related to the other two Wangs, was sentenced to six years and eight months in prison last April for his role the illegal loan case involving Taiwan Pineapple Corp. (TPC) . He fled Taiwan before he was to begin serving his time in prison on May 3, 2007.

Wang Hsuan-jen was convicted of conspiring with the pineapple company's Chairman Huang Tsung-hung to use dummy accounts to borrow money from the bank in violation of an existing regulation that prohibits banks from lending more than 40 percent of their previous fiscal year's net worth to a single customer. The total amount of the illegal loans connected to the scandal exceeded NT$7. 4 billion.
The debt-ridden Chung Shing Bank was auctioned off by the government-run Central Deposit Insurance Corp. to the Union Bank of Taiwan in 2005.

Along with Wang Hsuan-jen, 24 other Taiwanese criminals were also repatriated from Fuzhou to Matsu aboard the same ferry Thursday. The 24 comprised fugitives on wanted lists and convicts who had done their time in China.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's prosecution authorities repatriated a criminal to China Thursday - Chinese hijacker Wong Zhihua, who was sent from Taipei to Fuzhou via Matsu.

He and several Chinese accomplices hijacked a Chinese airplane destined for Hong Kong in the early 1990s, forcing the pilot to fly to Taiwan. After serving time in Taiwan for the hijacking, Wong and three other Chinese hijackers held a Mainland Affairs Council official hostage and injured the official on Feb. 9, 1999 during a flight from Taipei to the outlying island of Kinmen when they were about to be repatriated to China, landing him more time in prison.
Wong recently completed his jail term in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan tourism group hopes to lure 230,000 Singaporean tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/08 19:05:35 (By Charles Kang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) -- a non-profit Taipei-based tourism promotion organization -- will take part in the National Association of Travel Agents Singapore (NATAS) Travel Fair 2008 from Feb. 29 -March 2, in hopes of luring 15 percent more Singaporean tourists to the island this year, compared to last year.

Shao Chung-hua, a TVA adviser and CEO in charge of the Southeast Asian market, said that the group is aiming to attract at least 230,000 visitor arrivals from the city state this year, up from 200,000 in 2007.
The number of tourist arrivals from Singapore to Taiwan in 2007 grew by 12 percent year-on-year, beating the projected growth target of 7 percent set by the TVA.

At the NATAS fair, the association hopes to sell the island as a great travel destination to Singaporeans, by focusing on Taiwan's fine cuisine and its beautiful scenic spots, including those at Ali Mountain and Jade Mountain, as well as Sun Moon Lake.

Traditional art as well as modern Taiwanese attractions will also be used to promote Taiwan, Shao went on, adding that hand puppet theater -- a centuries old form of entertainment on the island -- will be introduced at the association's booths at the fair, as well as dances of Taiwan's many aboriginal tribes.

More modern trends such as Taiwanese nail art will also be showcased to attract tourists, so will long loved offerings from the island, including its famous snacks, such as pineapple cakes, association officials said.

In addition to tourists on package tours, the association hopes to lure more of Singapore's backpackers and other individual travelers who do not join a tour to Taiwan, according to Cheng Chih-hung, director of the association's Singapore office.

Such Singapore tourists who visit Taiwan in 2008 on their own will be offered a free metro or river cruise ticket on a one-day city tour in Taipei and Kaohsiung, in conjunction with the tours designed by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Visitors may also receive a bag of fruits from Taiwan or a free ticket to popular tourist destinations or recreational facilities scattered across the country, Cheng said.

The special tours will lead Singaporean tourists to Taiwan's most popular scenic and resort spots where they will enjoy classic landscapes and typical Taiwanese food, coupled with in-depth travel programs featuring different themes such as either spa, ecology, farming, culture, health, literature and medical or plastic surgery treatment, Cheng explained.
Individual travelers from Malaysia and Hong Kong will also be targeted for the specially designed tours, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tzu Chi wins foreign support for reservoir project in China

TEXT.P: Two internationally well-known companies from England and France, an Israeli vocalist, and some local leading businesses joined the latest project of the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation to build underground reservoirs in western China, an indication that the Taiwanese Buddhist compassion relief organization has won international recognition.

The fundraising concert, called "Hear the Voice of Love" featuring Israeli vocalist David D'or, is organized jointly by Wedgwood, one of England's finest porcelain companies, L'Occitane, the pioneering French retailer of skin care products, Shiatzy Chen, one of Taiwan's top fashion designers, and Taiwan's Hai Pa Wang chain restaurants, in order to assist the Tzu Chi Foundation in providing aid and relief to people in stricken areas due to climate change.

"We'd like to take a cooperative social responsibility in this fundraising concert," said Tom Wedgwood, who lives in Japan and is in charge of the family's business in Asia, quoting his grandfather that "a good business should always serve human beings in other areas, not just in business."

David D'or, deeply inspired by Tzu Chi's ideas and efforts, is the first foreign musician composing songs dedicated to the Buddhist charity, and has already visited Taiwan several times since 2006 for the foundation's humanitarian causes.

According to Charlie Ke, the supervisor of public affairs for the Tzu Chi Humanitarian Center, many of the businesspeople sponsoring the concert are already voluntary workers of the foundation, while Wedgwood supports Tzu Chi's campaign by providing its fine bone china for a charity bazaar.

"All funds raised will be used to help people in need, starting with the people in Gansu province in western China, where the residents endure constant drought and have to carry water barrels from the foot of mountains to their uphill villages, an eight or nine-hour labor," said Ke.

The Tzu Chi Foundation is a non-profit Buddhist charity founded by Master Chen Yen, a nun, in 1966, since then it has been devoted to social and community services, medical care, education, and humanitarian assistance in Taiwan and beyond. Tzu Chi has been active in such places as Tibet and South America, as well as South Asia during the 2004 tsunami disaster, and even New York during the 911 terrorist attacks. It has won the reputation of "Taiwan's conscience" for its contributions to humanitarian aid.
The Chinese authorities confirmed Wednesday that the Taiwanese charity foundation will be the first one conducted by a legal representative who is a non-resident of the Mainland.

Tzu Chi began its humanitarian aid in Gansu in 1998. With the funds raised from the concert, people in Gansu will be able to build reservoirs in their environs to collect rainwater during the short rainy season.

DOC.HEADLINE: Churches in Taiwan commemorate 228 Incident

TEXT.P: Around 1,500 Christians commemorated the 228 Incident Thursday by begging for the victims and their relatives to forgive their persecutors and urging people to cure the wounds left by the incident with love and sympathy.

The 228 Incident, which occurred Feb. 28, 1947, was an anti-government uprising by local Taiwanese against the then-Kuomintang (KMT) government and was brutally suppressed by the authorities, resulting in thousands of deaths.

At the commemoration ceremony held at the Bread of Life Church in Taipei, the believers prayed for better consolidation of all churches followed by an exercise of self- communion in which the participants reflected upon whether hatred of other ethnic groups existed in their minds.
The ceremony was held simultaneously with another organized by the Presbyterian Church.

Pan-Liu Yu-shya, a pastor and the director of the National Prayer Network, reconciled different views on the 228 Incident and said that "only the love and sympathy of Jesus Christ can cure the wounds and heal Taiwan."

Expressing his remorse for not being brave enough to show love to his uncle, a victim of the White Terror persecution that the KMT conducted in the years following the 228 Incident, Chou Shen-chu, pastor of the Bread of Life Church, prayed for help for himself and all Taiwanese people to give assistance and consolation to the victims and their relatives.

Ko Shao-en, chairman of the Good News Broadcasting Association, admitted that he never consoled his parents who also suffered during the White Terror and urged everyone to eliminate indifference with God's help.

Pan-Liu added that the churches have been silent on the incident due to lack of courage and said that "churches in Taiwan should not keep silent anymore." He expressed hope that "from now on, churches will be representatives of truth and justice."

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC develops enterovirus test kit

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) has developed a test kit for the Coxsackie A group viruses, the most common enteroviruses that infect children in the country, with an accuracy rate of up to 97 percent, according to a health official.
The test kit is the result of an eight-year research project aimed at saving time and costs for identifying the viruses, said CDC Deputy Director-General Lin Ting Tuesday.
According to Lin, 22 of the 66 kinds of known enteroviruses are categorized as Coxsackie A group, which infect some 50 percent to 70 percent of Taiwan's children every year.

Up to now, Taiwan has mostly used an imported tester that can only identify certain types of enteroviruses, which results in over 50 percent of the virus samples not being accurately identified, Lin said.
To determine the cause of illness, the samples often need to be further analyzed by local labs, a process that takes a month and costs NT$500 (US$16.2), Lin pointed out.
By contrast, the new test kit will only cost NT$35 and the test result is available in three hours, Lin said, adding that the accuracy rate falls within a range of 83 percent to 97 percent.

The CDC has provided the test kit to 13 of the CDC's contract labs, and plans to sell the kit to Japan and Southeast Asian countries, where the enterovirus epidemic is also mainly caused by the Coxsackie A group viruses, Lin said.
He predicted that the kit could generate an annual production value of at least NT$500 million.

Meanwhile, Lin said that the CDC is currently developing a test kit on enterovirus type 71 (E71) , the deadliest type of all enteroviruses, which infected 405 children, 78 of whom died, in the summer of 1988 in Taiwan.
In another E71 outbreak in 2005, 145 children were infected, with 15 killed.
Symptoms of enteroviruses include fever and rash.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post:Sunni Forces Losing Patience With U.S.
U.S.-backed Sunni volunteer forces, which have played a vital role in reducing violence in Iraq, are increasingly frustrated with the American military and the Iraqi government over what they see as a lack of recognition of their growing political clout and insufficient U.S. support.
The Washington Times:McCain, Obama spar on Iraq
In a sneak preview of the ground that both men would defend if they face each other in the presidential election, John McCain yesterday accused Sen. Barack Obama of misreading the war in Iraq and Mr. Obama accused the Arizona senator of getting it wrong in the first place.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Twists in Chain of Supplies for Blood Drug
With reports of more than 400 patients in the United States suffering serious complications after receiving the blood-thinner heparin, American investigators are trying to determine whether the raw material for the drug, made from pig intestines, became contaminated on the journey that begins in the slaughterhouses of China.
The Wall Street Journal:Paulson Dismisses Mortgage Rescue Plans
The Bush administration is hardening its opposition to the chorus of Democrats, bankers, economists and consumer advocates calling for abig-money government rescue program for struggling homeowners.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
The TimesGContract was a windfall for GPs butnot a good deal for patients
The controversial contract to improve GPs pay and efficiency cost G1.76 billion more than the Goverment expected and NHS productivity has actually fallen, a damning report by auditors concludes. The findings, by the National Audit Office, show that GPs who run their own practices received huge pay rises while giving up responsibility for the 24-hour care of their patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: International headline news
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Dollar falls endlessly, recession fears in U.S.
The U.S. dollar fell to a record low against the euro as investors worried about the U.S. economy. The euro rose to 1.5143 dollars in Wednesday's trading session. There are recession fears in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices of rice will be stable: Council of Agriculture

TEXT.P: A Council of Agriculture official assured Thursday that rice prices will be stable later this year due to more rice crops being cultivated and more imports from abroad.
You Sheng-feng, deputy director of the council's Agriculture and Food Agency, gave the assurance amid recent price hikes in many agricultural products, including rice, wheat, vegetables and fruits.

According to Yu, the prices of different varieties of rice have increased by 5 percent to 10 percent in February compared to the same month last year, due to decreased supply caused by typhoons in the second half of last year.
"To balance the prices of rice, the COA has been releasing 38,000 metric tons of stored rice onto the market and encouraging more farmers to cultivate rice," Yu said.
The area of paddy fields used for this year's first stage crop will reach 157,590 hectares, an increase of 2,129 hectares compared to the same period last year, according to Yu.

Council statistics also showed that the production of the country's two stages of rice crops reached 1.09 million metric tons last year, while this year's first stage of rice crops is expected to reach 800,000 metric tons.

In addition, Taiwan will import 144,720 metric tons of rice from abroad this year in accordance with World Trade Organization practices, Yu said, adding that all these measures will help stabilize the prices of rice.
"Compared to the surging prices of flour, the prices of rice are relatively stable and cheap, and it may become a substitute for flour," Yu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP legislator named Youth Commission chief

TEXT.P: Former ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Tai-hua has been appointed to head the National Youth Commission, a ranking Executive Yuan official said Thursday.

Lin, 35, is expected to assume office next week as the new National Youth Commission minister, replacing Cheng Li-chiun, whose resignation was approved by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Feb. 20, said Executive Yuan Secretary-General Chen Chin-jun.

The premier approved Cheng's resignation after a main opposition Kuomintang legislator charged Cheng for having "occupied herself with campaigning for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh instead of devoting herself to the problems of jobless youth."
Cheng, who took over the post in 2004, said she had tendered her resignation before joining an islandwide walk to campaign for Hsieh.

Chen said Lin, who served two terms as a DPP legislator between 2002-2008, will make an efficient minister, given her good educational background -- with a master's degree in mass communications from the United States -- her close connections with youth, and the positive image she has built during her stint as a lawmaker.

Chen said although Lin's tenure is likely to be short as the administration of President Chen Shui-bian will be bowing out in less than three months, he is positive that Lin would be able to secure the greatest possible benefits for the country's youth in the remaining months.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival to draw over 500,000 visitors

TEXT.P: The 2008 Taiwan Lantern Festival that opened Feb. 21 in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, is expected to attract more than 500,000 visitors during its 11-day run, the Tourism Bureau said Thursday.
Tourism officials urged members of the public who have not yet seen the show to grab the opportunity in the final days before the festival closes March 2.

The festival is being held to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Rat at Solar City, a special zone in the Southern Taiwan Science Park, in a 88-hectare showground. The Tainan county government, organizer of the show, said the exhibition this year is larger than all past festivals in terms of the number of lanterns on display.
There are six theme areas for religious lanterns, artistic lanterns, traditional lanterns, historical lanterns, dynamic lanterns and lanterns submitted for competition.
The centerpiece of the festival is a giant lantern in the shape of a spinous country rat -- a species of rodent endemic to Taiwan.
The 15-meter papier mache rat, standing on its hind legs and holding a gold ingot to its chest, is mounted on a three-meter pedestal and the whole piece weighs 25 metric tons.

Tony Wheeler, founder of Australia's Lonely Planet, one of the largest independently owned travel guidebook publishers in the world, praised the festival as "fantastic." He also said that Tainan, a city with many historical relics, is an ideal place for backpacking tourists.

Chuck Y. Gee, dean emeritus of the School of Travel Industry Management of the University of Hawaii at Manoa, said the festival was well-planned, with each of the six exhibition area having an clear-cut theme, impressing visitors not only with the works' beauty but also with their large numbers.
Over 55,000 red and yellow lanterns have been used to form giant Chinese and English characters that read "Taiwan Peace" -- the central theme of the festival.

A memorial was held Thursday on the exhibition ground to mark the Feb. 28 incident of 1947. The incident, triggered by a dispute between Monopoly Bureau officials and an illegal cigarette vendor, led to the death of an innocent bystander and prompted clashes all over Taiwan between locals and recent immigrants for China. An estimated 30,000 people died during a subsequent crackdown by troops brought in from China by the then-ruling Kuomintang.
In addition to the exhibition of lanterns, the organizers have invited performing arts groups from Japan and France, as well as domestic troupes, to entertain visitors with 42 performances.
A flower show covering 10 hectares is also being held at the same time. Visitors will be treated to a total of 27 fireworks shows and can enjoy a wide range of delicacies on a gourmet food street.
The organizers will have given away 120,000 hand-held lanterns featuring the rat motif as gifts to visitors by the end of the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aviation Police Office promotes weight loss campaign for officers

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Office under the National Police Agency (NPA) is promoting a weight loss campaign in an effort to encourage overweight police officers to slim down for the sake of their health.
Yin Yung-jen, the new director of the office, is helping promote the campaign launched by the NPA earlier this year to press overweight police officers to exercise.
According to the campaign, obese police officers should jog, cycle, hike, or run marathons. Playing badminton, table tennis or basketball are also recommended activities, said Yin.
The agency has also established health-related courses as part of the campaign, Yin added.
Yin recently began leading a group of overweight police officers on an after- work daily six-kilometer jog in the vicinity of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
He also plans to head a police team that will compete in the 2008 Taipei County International Marathon set for Sunday in Wanli township.
Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and heart disease, as well as diabetes, are likely to arise as a result of obesity, according to medical experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Road construction stopped to protect red-crowned cranes

TEXT.P: A construction project to broaden the roads in Jinshan township, Taipei County, has been suspended recently in order to protect endangered red-crowned cranes wintering in the area, according to the Construction and Planning Agency (CPA) under the Ministry of the Interior.

Planning for the roadworks started in 1990, but the CPA did not begin the actual work until December 2007, whereupon it almost immediately encountered unexpected problems when the four cranes were spotted in the area, having migrated there to spend the winter.
The red-crowned crane is found only in eastern Asia and is traditionally considered by Chinese and Japanese people to be a propitious bird, representing longevity and fidelity.

It is now on the "red list" of endangered species compiled by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, which estimates that only 2,400 of the birds remain in the wild.

A migratory bird, it travels in general from Siberia to Japan and southern China and is rarely observed in Taiwan, with the last recorded sighting in 2003, and the previous sighting dating back to 1932.
"We must try to find a win-win solution for both ecological conservation and traffic needs, " Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said after approving the suspension of the roadworks.

"There are already more than 200 bird species that pass through the Jinshan wetlands during the migration season, " said Lin Yao-guo, director-general of the Society of Wilderness, a non- government organization. "If the wetland can be designated as a nature reserve, more migratory birds would stop in Taiwan, " he predicted.

According to the CPA, the wetland is "not an important one recognized by the nation, " but in order to avoid damaging the ecosystem in favor of improved traffic flow, the CPA is willing to suspend the work until an acceptable solution is found by the relevant agencies.

At present, only two wetlands -- one at the mouth of the Tsengwen river and the other in Sicao, both in southern Taiwan -- are designated as international nature reserves, with 39 others designed as national reserves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students in Belgium push Taiwan's U.N. bid
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/08 20:55:44 (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese students studying at a Belgian university have continued making efforts to rally support for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations as a full member.

After launching a "U.N. for Taiwan" drive Feb. 12, members of a Taiwanese student association at the French-language Universite Catholique de Louvain in Belgium, set up a stand Saturday to promote the drive.

The drive is aimed not only at letting Taiwan know that Taiwanese students in Belgium support U.N. membership for the country, but also at soliciting support for the bid from other foreign students studying in Belgium and members of the international community, said members of the student group.

The students will send reports and images that they gather during the drive back to Taiwan in the hope of rekindling the Taiwanese people's passion for seeking U.N. membership for Taiwan -- a passion, they said, that "has increasingly died down as a result of political bickering between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the runup to the March 22 presidential election.

The students want all Taiwanese people to go to the polls March 22 and vote in two U.N.-bid referendums that will be held at the same time -- one proposed by the DPP on joining the U.N. under the name Taiwan, the other proposed by the KMT on rejoining the U.N. under the name Republic of China or any other "suitable name."

As the Republic of China, Taiwan lost its seat in the world body to the People's Republic of China in 1971, and has reapplied unsuccessfully for membership in the body every year since 1993. Last year was the first time Taiwan tried to apply for a U.N. seat under the name Taiwan.

In a written statement that the Taiwanese students issued Feb. 12 when the drive was first launched, they said Taiwan has an independent constitutional system under which its people enjoy free and dynamic political lives.

Claiming that the international community has not fully understood the "collective mindset" of the Taiwanese people, the group said Taiwan's U.N. bid is a first, critical step in getting the world to learn more about Taiwan.

Taiwan's people, whether they live in Taiwan or abroad and irrespective of their political persuasions, should say out loud with a single voice that "Taiwan deserves U.N. membership, " the statement urges.

Should the referendums fail -- which will be the case if 50 percent of eligible voters do not cast ballots on the referendums -- it will send a message to the world that Taiwan's people do not want to enter the U.N. and even worse, that they "want to be ruled by the People's Republic of China government," according to the group.

While some foreign governments do not support Taiwan's holding of the referendums, "many foreign friends here in Brussels support the idea of Taiwan's being admitted into the U.N.," the statement says.

The Louvain student group has printed handouts of "U.N. membership for Taiwan" in Chinese, English, French, German, Dutch, Spanish, Italian, Japanese, Vietnamese and Malaysian to solicit global support for Taiwan's U.N. bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, vice president cheer marching group

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu gave a high-five to each member of a group in Taipei Thursday that started a 500-km walk from Taiwan's southernmost tip to the north in early February.

The group, comprised mainly of young supporters of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , was scheduled to conclude their weeks-long march, dubbed "Against the Wind, Love Taiwan Most," at a DPP election campaign rally later in the day at a stadium in the capital to drum up support for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh.

Hsieh is fighting an uphill battle as public opinion polls show that he is lagging behind his rival, Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , ahead of the March 22 presidential election.
Several other officials also joined a crowd of pro-DPP groups and citizens waiting in the square of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall to welcome the walkers, who arrived an hour late.
The group was led by Cheng Li-chun, a DPP member and former head of the National Youth Commission. Yu Shyi-kun, a former DPP chairman, was also one of the walkers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC welcomes repatriation of Taiwanese criminals from China

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official confirmed Thursday that a group of Taiwanese and Chinese police officers and Red Cross officials conducted the same day an exchange of prisoners from either side of the Taiwan Strait on the outlying island of Matsu.

The official said that during the exchange, the Chinese authorities repatriated 25 Taiwanese criminals, including a former general manager of a bankrupt bank who was involved in a loan scandal, while receiving Chinese airplane hijacker Wong Zhihua and 205 stowaways detained by Taiwanese police. The exchange was conducted based on the principles and spirit of the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross societies on both sides of Taiwan Strait in 1990.
According to the official, the exchange was originally scheduled for late January. However, it was postponed due to the weather and strong winds over the last month.
To date, there are still some 780 Taiwanese fugitives on the run in China, including 80 criminals involved in major economic crimes, the official said.

He expressed gratitude to the Chinese authorities for their cooperation in the repatriation of the Taiwanese fugitives, calling on them to continue the task in the future in accordance with the spirit of the Kinmen Agreement.
The official also expressed hope that the Chinese authorities can discuss with their Taiwanese counterparts concrete ways to jointly fight crime.
MAC statistics show that cross-strait crime has shown a shift from fishing disputes, ilegal immigration and hijacking to smuggling and telephone fraud.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen authority raises county flags on 228 holiday

TEXT.P: Instead of lowering the national flag to half mast to mark 228 Peace Memorial Day Thursday, the outlying Kinmen county government flew three county flags atop its building in a gesture to urge the central government to mark two battles fought on Kinmen against Chinese communists that saved Taiwan.

In defiance of an order issued by the Ministry of the Interior that cities and counties around the country should lower the national flag to half mast, the Kinmen county government, acting on instructions from Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, raised three county flags on the top of its headquarters.
"The central government also should observe two significant battles in which Kinmen residents fought back against Chinese communists at the cost of their lives," Lee told reporters recently.

Lee was referring to the battle of Ku Ning Tou Dec. 25, 1949 and the Aug. 23 Artillery War of 1958 (commonly known as the 823 Artillery Bombardment) , in which Republic of China troops emerged victorious and secured peace for Taiwan for almost 60 years.

"The dates of these two significant battles should also be designated as a national holiday like the 228 Incident, " he said, pointing out that "if the Kinmen people had not made such a huge sacrifice in the two battles, the Chinese communists would have been able to cross the Taiwan Strait and invade Taiwan proper."

"Against such a backdrop, it is pointless to discuss whether the Kinmen county government should fly the national flag at half mast or not mark the 228 Incident should the central government fail to mark the two battles with national holidays, " he argued.
Lee also suggested that the central government organize exhibitions to help Kinmen people gain a better understanding of the 228 Incident.
"In that case, lowering the national flag on Kinmen in commemoration of the tragedy would be much more meaningful, " he explained.

Lee said he fully respects the Taiwan people's need and willingness to heal their souls by commemorating the 228 Incident, in which thousands of Taiwanese elite were killed following an uprising against the then-Kuomintang regime.
Although the Kinmen county government did not fly the national flag at half mast, most schools and public agencies on the island did do so to pay respect to the victims of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: China-based Taiwanese companies forced to change
DOC.DATELINE: Guangzhou, China, Feb. 28 (CNA) 02/28/08 21:28:36 (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: China-based Taiwanese companies, which have felt increasing heat as a result of the changing investment climate in China, are being forced to change in order to survive, Guangdong Province-based Taiwanese businessmen said Thursday.

The businessmen said during an exchange event that in order to survive in China -- often described as the world's factory -- they will have to either upgrade their manufacturing operations in China or head to inner provinces to explore new markets.
Guangdong Province is one of the Chinese coastal provinces that plays host to the greatest number of Taiwanese companies.

An increasing number of Taiwanese businessmen operating in China have returned to Taiwan since late last year to launch new investment projects as China's business climate has become less favorable to them.

They are now facing additional challenges as China has implemented new economic policies, including the cancellation of an export tariff rebate, implementation of a new labor contract act and a new business income tax law.

Yeh Chun-jung, president of a Taiwan investment association based in Dongguan City, said it is hard to speculate on how seriously Taiwanese companies are being impacted by the new, stricter Chinese regulations, adding that "the problems will emerge in six months or one year."
In the face of the adversity, Yeh said, Taiwanese companies have only three ways to go: upgrading their manufacturing operations, getting out of China, or closing down their businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VP candidate: DPP coined `one-China common market' term

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) vice presidential candidate Vincent Siew said in southern Taiwan Thursday that he had never said he wanted to establish a "one- China common market," rebutting a claim made by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Speaking at a ceremony to inaugurate a KMT election campaign office in Chiayi County, Siew said that what he has been calling for is a "cross-Taiwan Strait common market" modeled on the European Union partnership, which he said would create a mutually beneficial situation for both sides of the strait.

Siew, the running mate of KMT presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou, said he had never used the phrase, "one-China common market" and that it was the DPP that coined the phrase and falsely attributed it to him.

A day earlier, DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh, who doubles as DPP chairman, reiterated his opposition to Siew's proposal, claiming that a one- China common market would lead to de facto and de jure unification with China. He also expressed fear that Siew's plan would harm domestic industries and cause Taiwan's unemployment rate to go up.

Hsieh made the remarks after Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chen Ming-tong presented a report on the "one-China common market" at a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, chaired by Hsieh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan repatriates last Chinese hijacker to China

TEXT.P: The government has repatriated the last of 18 Chinese hijackers to China, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a press release Thursday, urging Beijing to start negotiations with Taiwan over cross-Taiwan Strait crime as soon as possible.

The press release came after officials of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China handed over Wang Zhihua, who hijacked a plane to Taiwan in 1993, to their Chinese counterparts at a port on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu.
Wang was one of 18 Chinese citizens who hijacked planes and came to Taiwan between 1993 and 1998, the press release said.
He had been scheduled to be repatriated in 1999 but attacked a SEF official on the flight to his repatriation and was re-arrested, the press release noted.
Wang's final repatriation came Thursday after he finished his prison term for the attack, the press release went on.
Taipei and Beijing have had several rounds of negotiations on fighting cross- strait crime, but have failed to ink an agreement, the press release said.
The trend in cross-strait crime has shifted from fishing disputes, illegal immigration and hijacking to smuggling, fleeing criminals and telephone fraud, the press release continued.
The MAC also called for the establishment of a cross-strait cooperation mechanism for crime fighting.

Despite the absence of an official agreement, Thursday's repatriation was conducted in line with the principles and spirit of the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross societies on both sides of the strait in 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outdoor concert staged in Taipei to mark 228 Incident

TEXT.P: An open air free concert in commemoration of the 228 Incident was staged Thursday at Liberty Square in front of the National Taiwan Democracy Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei, gathering many local and international performers who spread the message of peace and love through their music.

The "Reborn with Love" concert, organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs and the National Taiwan Symphony Orchestra (NTSO) , was aimed at "rekindling the public's passion for reform through music," organizers said.

To make the concert truly memorable, the organizers invited Hungarian conductor Tamas Vasary to conduct performances by the NTSO, the Taipei Philharmonic Orchestra, the Taipei Century Symphony Orchestra and a chorus of more than 1,000.

The concert also featured works from different ethnic groups in Taiwan, including Hakka composer Chen Shu-hsi's Ping Ban, aboriginal musician Kao Yi- Sheng's Train Ride Up the Mountain, and Ode to Jade Mountain, composed by Hsiao Ty-zen, a Taiwanese musician with an international reputation as "Taiwan's Rachmaninov, " with lyrics written by Li Min-yung.

The repertoire also covered Finnish composer Jean Sibelius' Finlandia -- a symbol of Finnish nationalism, and a piece dubbed Taiwan, performed by a chorus of 1,000-plus voices and accompanied by orchestra.
The concert culminated in Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 - Choral which was sung by the chorus in Taiwanese, with Schiller's German lyrics replaced by those of local poet Hsiang Yang.

The 228 Incident, which began Feb. 27, 1947, refers to a brutal crackdown on the local population by the then-ruling Kuomintang regime in March and April of that year that led to the deaths of an estimated 28,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP holds rally to solicit support for candidates

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) drummed up support for its presidential ticket at an evening rally Thursday in Taipei that was opened by members of a walking group and families of the victims of the 228 Incident.

At the rally, kicked off by a "democracy torch, " heads of the walking group -- which had just concluded a 22-day, 500-km walk from the country's southernmost tip to the north -- and the victims' families called for support for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate, Su Tseng-chang.
The group, mainly consisting of young DPP supporters, launched the walk in early February to help raise the profile of the DPP ticket prior to the March 22 election.
Thursday was also a national holiday in memory of the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of Taiwan's elite were killed following an uprising against the then-ruling Kuomintang regime.

The rally came after Hsieh and Su met with the walkers at the DPP election campaign headquarters before leading them, along with tens of thousands of supporters, to Chungshan Soccer Stadium in the city for the evening rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Party chairman calls for boycott of March 22 referendums

TEXT.P: The head of the opposition New Party (NP), an offshoot of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is seeking support from the KMT to urge voters to boycott two referendums to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.
NP Chairman Yok Mu-ming told reporters Thursday that he had met with KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung to discuss the issue but had not received a definite answer from him.

The two referendums -- one introduced by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the other by the KMT -- would ask voters whether they support Taiwan applying for United Nations membership under either the title, the Republic of China, or as Taiwan.
Yok said he will try to convince KMT legislators to support the proposed boycott.

"The New Party has indicated consistently that we will refuse to take part in the referendums, and we expressed our position clearly in a Feb. 26 advertisement, together with other civic groups," he said.
"Failure to pass the referendums would neither cause Taiwan to lose face, nor inflict any harm to the KMT," he added.

Yok disagreed with the concept that failure to pass the referendums would give the world community the impression that the people of Taiwan do not want U.N. membership. He said Taiwan will only lose face when it is still barred from entering the U.N. even after both referendums have passed.

Yok and his party initiated a campaign to boycott two previous referendums tied to the Jan. 12 legislative elections. One of them, proposed by the DPP, was about recovering the KMT's ill-gotten assets, while the other, proposed by the KMT, was about empowering the legislature to investigate government corruption. Both were defeated because only 26 percent of the electorate took part in the voting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate vows to eradicate corruption

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou vowed Thursday to revive the economy and establish a clean government if he is elected in the March 22 election.

Speaking at a campaign rally in Taipei, Ma attributed corruption as the main reason behind the 228 Incident of 1947, in which thousands of Taiwan's elite were killed following an uprising against the then-ruling KMT regime.
The rally also featured a concert in memory of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Aborigines make smoke signals to show resolve for sovereignty

TEXT.P: More than 30 tribal communities from eight of the 13 recognized aboriginal tribes around Taiwan organized a series of ceremonies Thursday in which they sent up smoke signals to underscore their sovereignty claim over their traditional homelands.

Clouds of smoke billowed into the sky in the 30-plus tribal communities, including Pinuyumayan tribe's Kati community in Taitung County, the Paiwan tribe's Majia community in Kaohsiung County, the Rukai tribe's Haocha community in Pingtung County, the Bunun tribe's Namahsia community, the Amis tribe's Tulan community, the Atayal tribe's Smangus community, the Tsou tribe's Tapang community in Alishan and the Tao tribe's homeland Orchid Island or Lanyu.

After the smoke signals, each participating group staged traditional rituals or Christian prayer services at venues where significant events in their respective tribal communities have occurred, to declare their determination to uphold their tribal sovereignty over their homelands.

The release of smoke signals is the first step of a campaign to press the central government to substantiate the Aboriginal Basic Law and underline their sovereignty claim over their traditional homelands, organizers said.

According to the organizers, various aboriginal tribal groups are scheduled to travel to Taipei March 8 to present their appeals to President Chen Shui-bian. If their petition fails to receive a positive response, the organizers said they will take further protest moves until the central government makes a formal apology and recognize their tribal sovereignty over their homelands.

Place: Public Television Service, No. 50, Lane 75, Kang Ning Road, Sec. 3, Taipei City. Host and/or main speakers: DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his KMT rival Ma Ying-jeou. The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday.

The weighted price index was down 94.63 points at 8,367.45 on a turnover of NT$4.5 billion (US$145.49 million) at the open. The index gained 154.41 points, or 1.85 percent, to close at 8,462.08 Wednesday. The market was closed Thursday for 228 Peace Memorial Day, a public holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was lower against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Friday.
The greenback was trading at NT$30.754 at 9:30 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, down NT$0.175 from Wednesday. The market was closed Thursday for 228 Peace Memorial Day, a public holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan repatriates last Chinese hijacker to China

TEXT.P: The government has repatriated the last of 18 Chinese hijackers to China, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said in a press release Thursday, urging Beijing to start negotiations with Taiwan over cross-Taiwan Strait crime as soon as possible.

The press release came after officials of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China handed over Wang Zhihua, who hijacked a plane to Taiwan in 1993, to their Chinese counterparts at a port on the Taiwan-held outlying island of Matsu.
Wang was one of 18 Chinese citizens who hijacked planes and came to Taiwan between 1993 and 1998, the press release said.
He had been scheduled to be repatriated in 1999 but attacked a SEF official on the flight to his repatriation and was re-arrested, the press release noted.
Wang's final repatriation came Thursday after he finished his prison term for the attack, the press release went on.
Taipei and Beijing have had several rounds of negotiations on fighting cross- strait crime, but have failed to ink an agreement, the press release said.
The trend in cross-strait crime has shifted from fishing disputes, illegal immigration and hijacking to smuggling, fleeing criminals and telephone fraud, the press release continued.
The MAC also called for the establishment of a cross-strait cooperation mechanism for crime fighting.

Despite the absence of an official agreement, Thursday's repatriation was conducted in line with the principles and spirit of the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Red Cross societies on both sides of the strait in 1990.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP holds rally to solicit support for candidates

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) drummed up support for its presidential ticket at an evening rally Thursday in Taipei that was opened by members of a walking group and families of the victims of the 228 Incident.

At the rally, kicked off by a "democracy torch, " heads of the walking group -- which had just concluded a 22-day, 500-km walk from the country's southernmost tip to the north -- and the victims' families called for support for DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his running mate, Su Tseng-chang.
The group, mainly consisting of young DPP supporters, launched the walk in early February to help raise the profile of the DPP ticket prior to the March 22 election.
Thursday was also a national holiday in memory of the 228 Incident of 1947 in which thousands of Taiwan's elite were killed following an uprising against the then-ruling Kuomintang regime.

The rally came after Hsieh and Su met with the walkers at the DPP election campaign headquarters before leading them, along with tens of thousands of supporters, to Chungshan Soccer Stadium in the city for the evening rally.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Party chairman calls for boycott of March 22 referendums

TEXT.P: The head of the opposition New Party (NP), an offshoot of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is seeking support from the KMT to urge voters to boycott two referendums to be held alongside the March 22 presidential election.
NP Chairman Yok Mu-ming told reporters Thursday that he had met with KMT Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung to discuss the issue but had not received a definite answer from him.

The two referendums -- one introduced by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the other by the KMT -- would ask voters whether they support Taiwan applying for United Nations membership under either the title, the Republic of China, or as Taiwan.
Yok said he will try to convince KMT legislators to support the proposed boycott.

"The New Party has indicated consistently that we will refuse to take part in the referendums, and we expressed our position clearly in a Feb. 26 advertisement, together with other civic groups," he said.
"Failure to pass the referendums would neither cause Taiwan to lose face, nor inflict any harm to the KMT," he added.

Yok disagreed with the concept that failure to pass the referendums would give the world community the impression that the people of Taiwan do not want U.N. membership. He said Taiwan will only lose face when it is still barred from entering the U.N. even after both referendums have passed.

Yok and his party initiated a campaign to boycott two previous referendums tied to the Jan. 12 legislative elections. One of them, proposed by the DPP, was about recovering the KMT's ill-gotten assets, while the other, proposed by the KMT, was about empowering the legislature to investigate government corruption. Both were defeated because only 26 percent of the electorate took part in the voting.
