DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 29, or the 23rd day of the first month of the Year of the Rat according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
642 AD: St. Oswald, bringer of Christianity to northeastern England, is killed in battle.
1840: John Holland, US inventor of the submarine, is born in Ireland.
1868: Louis I, the king of Bavaria, dies in Munich at the age of 81.
1880: The St. Gotthard tunnel, providing a rail link between Switzerland and Italy, is completed, with a total length of about 14 kms.
1896: Ranchhodji Morarji Desal, Indian prime minister who was imprisoned with Mahatma Gandhi, is born.
1908: Heike Onnes, a scientist from Leyden, the Netherlands, announces he has succeeded in liquefying helium.
1912: A military coup in Peking delays Yuan Shih-kai's trip to Nanking to assume provisional presidency.
1920: Peking University begins to enroll female students.
1944: German troops begin a third major offensive against Anzio beach-head in World War II.
1948: A Jewish Stern Gang bombs a Cairo-to-Haifa train, killing 35 British troops.
1956: The United States announces its decision to enhance its military capability to help defend Taiwan against invasion from communist China.
1956: Pakistan becomes an Islamic Republic.
1956: White segregationist groups are planning demonstrations to protest a US federal court ruling that Autherine Lucy, the first-ever black student at the University of Alabama, be readmitted.
1960: An earthquake rocks Morocco, destroying much of Agadir and killing about 12,000 people.
1960: Huge Hefner opens his new Playboy Club in Chicago.
1976: Chinese golfers Hsu Chi-san and Chang Teh-kuei win the professional and amateur trophies, respectively, at the China Open, the second leg on the 1976 Asian circuit.
1984: Pierre Trudeau resigns as prime minister of Canada.
1984: An explosion on board the Makung, a cargo ship of a Penghu shipping company, kills nine people and injures 17 others.
1984: Fei Hua, former finance minister, dies in a car accident at the age of 72.
1988: Desmond Tutu, South Africa's Anglican archbishop, is arrested for demonstrating outside the parliament building in Cape Town in defiance of a ban on political activity by the white minority government.
1988: The Ministry of National Defense announces that the long-range missile Hsiung Feng II, which was developed and manufactured by the ROC, has been successfully tested and can be used in combination with the Hsiung Feng I as an anti-submarine missile.
1992: Russia establishes diplomatic ties with South Africa, ending more than 30 years of unfriendly relations.
1996: A Faucett Airlines Boeing 737 crashes at the city of Arequipa in the Andes, killing all 117 passengers and six crew members.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To know what you know and know what you don't know is the characteristic of one who knows."

DOC.HEADLINE: 1st CEC-organized TV election forum slated for Friday

TEXT.P: The first of four Central Election Commission (CEC) -organized campaign forums for the two rival presidential tickets will take place Friday evening, with Public Television Service (PTS) providing a live broadcast of the event.

CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-yu said Thursday that the roughly one-hour forum will allow the presidential candidates -- front-runner Ma Ying-jeou of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) standard-bearer -- to expound on their policy platforms and visions in two 15-minute shifts each.

"The forum will begin with the two candidates drawing lots to determine who should deliver a 15-minute policy speech first, " Teng said, adding that it will mark the first time a presidential candidate will have been given the opportunity to give two rounds of policy presentation in a CEC-organized campaign forum.

The forum will be moderated by Lai Hau-min, a CEC commissioner, Teng went on, adding that only the two candidates and CEC staff will be allowed to enter the film studio during the broadcast. Each candidate can be accompanied by up to five aides, who have to stay in the waiting room for the duration.
Meanwhile, TWM Solution, a Taiwan Mobile offshoot, will provide a simultaneous webcast of the forum at http://www.peopo.org/.
The second CEC-organized televised forum is scheduled for March 7 and will be broadcast live on Taiwan Television Enterprise (TTV).

The third, slated for March 10, will be reserved for the two vice presidential candidates -- the DPP's Su Tseng-chang and the KMT's Vincent Siew -- who will also present their policy initiatives and visions, with China Television Co. (CTV) providing the live broadcast.
The final forum for the presidential candidates is scheduled for March 14, with Chinese Television System (CTS) responsible for the live broadcast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No timetable for turning Grand Hotel into corporation: premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that there is no timetable for turning the government-owned Grand Hotel into a private corporation.
Chang also said there is no "legal basis" for the government to compel the hotel, which is operated by a government-controlled foundation, to transfer itself into a corporation.

Chang denied a Taipei-based China Times report Monday that the Duen Mou Foundation of Taiwan -- a non-profit organization founded by the then-ruling Kuomintang in 1952 and now under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications -- is planning to set up a corporation to run the Grand Hotel chain prior to May 20, when a new administration will be sworn in.

The China Times report also speculated that once the corporation is founded, the Duen Mou Foundation of Taiwan, now controlled by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration, is also planning to appoint its chairwoman Christine T.Y. Tsung as head of the new Grand Hotel Company to operate the Grand Hotel chain -- which includes the Grand Hotel Taipei, the Grand Hotel Kaohsiung, the Yuan Shan Club in Taipei and the Yuan Shan Club in Kaohsiung.
Tsung is believed to maintain close connections with members of the DPP administration.

The Grand Hotel Taipei -- built on the orders of the late President Chiang Kai- shek and first lady Soong Mei-ling in the 1950s with public funds, on public land, without having to pay tax -- is a Taipei landmark and used to be a major venue for state banquets.
Describing the Grand Hotel matter as an "issue left behind by history, " Chang said the Executive Yuan is not sure whether if any change could be carried out prior to May 20.

Also commenting on the China Times report, Minister of Transportation and Telecommunications Tsai Duei said it is a "long-established policy" that the Grand Hotel chain be incorporated as privately run companies.
Due to legal difficulties, Tsai said, it will not be easy for the Grand Hotel chain to be privatized anytime soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Inflation affects consumer buying behavior: survey

TEXT.P: Most consumers responding to a recent survey admitted that inflation has affected their buying behavior, with many now preferring to shop at hypermarkets, where prices tend to be cheaper.

The survey was conducted online Feb. 12-14 by Ding Ding Integrated Marketing Service Co. (DDIM) -- an associate company under the Far Eastern Group and the issuer of the Happy Go bonus-point shopping cards -- among 11,459 cardholders.

The survey reveals that 95 percent of respondents have obviously felt a rise in consumer prices or a decrease in the volume of the products they bought, and 82 percent of these respondents said the situation has changed their attitude toward buying daily necessities.

Fifty-seven percent of respondents now make hypermarkets their priority choice when shopping for daily necessities, compared with 22 percent who prefer to shop at convenience stores, 13 percent who favor supermarkets and 8 percent who prefer to buy at traditional markets.

The results show that 75 percent of the respondents spend most of their earnings on daily necessities besides food and transportation, and that 60 percent of respondents will try to save some of their earnings for financial investment.

Cash remains the prize that the largest number of respondents -- 83 percent -- wish to win in a lucky draw, and the percentage far exceeds those preferring a free tour around the world or video/audio home appliances, according to the results.

On the personal data of the respondents, 64 percent of them were men and 36 percent were women, with those aged 25 and under accounting for 17 percent, those aged 26-30 accounting for 26 percent, those aged 31-35 accounting for 24 percent, those aged 36-40 accounting for 15 percent, those aged 41-45 accounting for 9 percent, and those aged 46-50 accounting for 9 percent.

Having attracted 4.5 million members since its launch in 2005, the Happy Go card is now accepted at more than 5,000 stores covering more than 700 brands, including department stores and retail stores owned by the Far Eastern Group and other contracted stores, according to DDIM officials.
Spending by Happy Go cardholders totaled more than NT$12 billion in 2007, with each holder spending NT$25,000 per year and NT$1,500 per transaction on average, company officials said.
A total of 1.3 billion bonus points were awarded to holders in 2007, with 60 percent of the points having been exchanged, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cell phones most common items left in cabs: radio station

TEXT.P: Mobile phones are the items most likely to be left behind in taxis by forgetful passengers, according a Taipei-based broadcasting company Friday.

The Police Radio Station -- the only broadcasting company in Taiwan to offer free lost and found listings and services -- said that about one-third of the lost items handed in by taxi drivers are mobile phones.
According to the radio station, 3,808 lost items were found in taxi cabs by taxi drivers and handed in to the Police Radio Station last year. Of the total, 1,245 items or 33 percent, were cellphones.
Other major items ranged from 660 wallets, representing 17 percent of the total, to bags of all kinds at 604 pieces, or 15 percent, according to the radio station.
Other commonly lost belongings include cameras, notebook computers, certificate cards, keys, spectacles, watches and medications, Public Radio System officials said.

They said that last year, the radio station received phone calls concerning 12,938 belongings left in taxis. Of the total, however, only 3,808 were handed over by taxi drivers, who are allowed by law to keep anything they find in their cabs if it has not been claimed within six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poor air quality forecast due to Chinese sand storm

TEXT.P: The air quality over Taiwan is expected to worsen over the next three days due to a sand storm -- one of the largest to hit Taiwan since 2006 -- the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) forecast Friday.
The EPA advised people with cardiovascular or respiratory disease and those with weak immunity, such as children and the elderly, to avoid being outdoors during the period.

The sand, blown from northern China, will arrive in Taiwan along with a cold air mass this weekend, causing severe pollution, said Chang Shun-chin, a technician at the EPA's Department of Environmental Monitoring and Information Management.

The storm is also expected to bring along a lot of industrial waste from China, increasing the concentration of air pollutants such as particulate matter and sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere, Chang went on.
In particular, the concentration of particulate matter is expected to rise to up to 400 micrograms per cubic meter per hour, 6-10 times as much as normal readings, he said.
The storm will affect the entire country and is unlikely to dissipate until next Monday, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Academia Sinica president to receive Othmer Gold Medal

TEXT.P: Former Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh is to be honored with the U.S.-based Chemical Heritage Foundation's (CHR's) 11th Othmer Gold Medal, Taiwan's top research institute announced in a press release Friday.
The 1986 Nobel Laureate will receive the prestigious award at a presentation ceremony to be held at the foundation's headquarters in Philadelphia May 15.

The Othmer Gold Medal is presented to outstanding individuals who have made multifaceted contributions to humankind's chemical and scientific heritage through outstanding activity in such areas as innovation, entrepreneurship, research, education, public understanding, legislation or philanthropy.

The medal, awarded annually since 1997, is co-sponsored by the CHF and four affiliated organizations: the American Chemical Society, the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the Chemists' Club and the Societe de Chimie Industrielle (American Section).

In a press statement issued recently to announce the awarding of the medal to Lee, CHR President and CEO Thomas R. Tritton lauded the Nobel laureate for his dedication to and accomplishments in the fields of education and scientific research.
"Following three successful decades in the United States, Lee returned to Taiwan to take a leadership role in education, reform and better relations with China," Tritton said.
The Academia Sinica said in its press release Friday that the award represents yet another example of the international recognition that Lee has received for his outstanding lifetime achievements.

Lee, born in Hsinchu in 1936, received his bachelor's degree in science from National Taiwan University before going on to obtain his master's from Tsinghua University and his doctoral degree from the University of California at Berkeley.

In 1967, he joined a Harvard University research group led by Prof. Dudley Herschbach and contributed to the group's success in building a crossed molecular beam apparatus, a milestone in the expansion of chemical reaction research, according to the Academia Sinica press release.
It further said that during his term as Academia Sinica president from 1994 to 2006, Lee performed outstandingly in the fields of education, professional research and academic administration.

Besides being a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, Lee has received countless other honors and awards, such as the Ernest O. Lawrence Award presented by the U.S. Department of Energy, and the Harrison Howe Award and Peter Debye Award, both presented by the American Chemical Society. He has also been made a fellow of numerous societies and institutes, including the American Physical Society and the American Academy of Arts and Science.
Lee has also received honorary doctoral degrees from 34 prestigious universities around the world over the years, according to the Academia Sinica.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP plans to hold round-Taiwan human chain March 16

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) announced Friday that it will hold a "Democratic Taiwan, 100 Action" parade March 16 and that it wants to summon 1 million people to encircle Taiwan before walking along the island and voicing their determination to protect Taiwan with democracy.

Participants will be asked to walk along the coastline in an anti-clockwise direction when the march kicks off at 3: 14 p.m. under the slogan "protecting Taiwan with democracy, joining the U.N. and opposing a one-China market, " DPP Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan said at a press conference.

Lee explained that the planned activity originates from the party's 2004 "Hand- in-Hand To Safeguard Taiwan" and recent "Reversing the Tide: Protecting Taiwan" campaigns. They hope to "walk toward the bright future of Taiwan" and "show the international community Taiwan's existence," Lee said.

"100" means voting for the DPP presidential and vice presidential ticket, which is listed No. 1 on the ballot, while the two zeroes represent the vote to support two referendums related to the nation's bid for its seat in the United Nations, Lee noted.

While March 14 marks the third anniversary of China's adoption of its anti- secession law, which gives Beijing a legal excuse to invade Taiwan by force, Lee added that one of the purposes of holding the event is to declare the party's determination to "protect Taiwan with democracy."

Lee said there will be two 500 kilometer chains separately lining Taiwan's eastern and western coasts. Gathering points for the chains, provisionally named "high five, " will be set up every five kilometers.

Lin Kuo-ching, director of the campaign department of DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh's election campaign headquarters, said the southernmost points of the eastern and western lines will be Fugang, Taitung County, and Donggang, Pingtung County respectively.
The two lines will join up in Taipei.
After the two lines are formed, participants will begin a five-kilometer walk at 3: 14 p.m., moving in a counter-clockwise direction around Taiwan, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan could be leader in clean energy industry: e-Parliament

TEXT.P: Taiwan, with some of the world's best engineers and advanced technologies, could emerge as an important player in the clean energy field, the head of the e-Parliament said Friday in Taipei.

Taiwan is a country that is "perfectly positioned to be a leader" in the area of clean energy, said Nicholas Dunlop, founder and secretary-general of the non- profit organization that links together the world's democratic members of parliament and congress into a single forum.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Dunlop said Taiwan has some of the best wind resources in Asia, and some of the world's best engineers and companies, leaving it well-positioned to compete in the areas of solar power, wind power and other forms of renewable energy.

Renewable energy is one of the group's main issues of interest, along with climate change and freedom of expression on the Internet. It has tried to raise awareness of climate change and provide policy suggestions to decision-makers.

As the consequences of climate change become clear and calls mount for the government to tackle the issue, a debate has raged in Taiwan over how to apply renewable energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions without jeopardizing its economic development.

Dunlop stressed that "in terms of economic growth versus actions on climate change, there is really no contradiction between the two," because the countries and companies that take the lead on clean energy can benefit economically.
Those that fail to do so will have to spend money buying other people's technologies in the years and decades to come, he said.

Taiwan is not a signatory of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and Kyoto Protocol, but has felt pressure from developed countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, even if formal negotiations on mitigating climate change have proceeded at a glacial pace.
Dunlop attributed the slow pace of progress in global negotiations to the "simple lack of political will."
"Not many governments have really understood the importance of a very rapid shift to clean energy if we are going to ensure a stable planet for our future, " he said.
Governments around the world need political vision while citizens need incentives for the two to tackle the problem together, he noted, with many examples of good programs already existing.
Germany enacted a new law to promote renewable energy seven years ago that guaranteed a good price for electricity generated from renewable energy, Dunlop said.
"The result of that law has been that Germany now has 55 percent of the global surface of photovoltaic solar panels just in that country, not even a very sunny but a cloudy country," he said.
Spain also has a similar law to encourage companies to build solar thermal power plants, which use mirrors to concentrate the sun's heat to boil water and drive steam turbines, he added.
"So there are two examples of countries that are not just talking about the problems but really getting on building industries in their countries that can one day help to save the world," he said.

He acknowledged that e-Parliament is not any position to tell Taiwan what to do, but said it wanted to make sure that Taiwanese lawmakers were fully aware of success stories in other parts of the world.

According to Dunlop, one important way to spread public awareness is by working with parliamentarians who constantly communicate with those who elect them, and likewise, citizens can participate and encourage their representatives to do something.
"Instead of a vicious circle of climate change, we can create a virtual circle of mutual education between citizens and representatives," he said.

The mission of e-Parliament, created in 2001, is to bring together legislators from around the world to educate them about the problems and policy options that have been tried in other countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and to make economies more environmentally friendly.

The group will hold a two-day forum in Taipei beginning March 1 focusing on climate change and what it means for Asia, both in terms of the dangers of climate change and the opportunities for building clean energy industries in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cutting business tax is not only measure against inflation: MOEA

TEXT.P: Cutting business tax is only one of the tools that can be used to stabilize currently rising inflation, not the only solution, said Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R.L. Chen Thursday.

Chen said in a statement that some news media misinterpreted his comments at a recent briefing with the opposition party Koumintang (KMT) caucus in the Legislative Yuan, when he asked lawmakers to approve a business tax cut.
The media reports said he intended to contain inflation only with a tax cut, and that he had promised the tax cut will reduce commodity prices within a week.

Chen said what he meant was that if the business tax on imported commodities, such as corn and wheat, is cut to zero from the current 5 percent, his ministry will demand that importers reduce domestic prices accordingly "within one week".

Thomas Yeh, vice chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development, downplayed the effectiveness of the tax cut, as he estimated only a 0.08 percent decline in CPI would be achieved by such a cut in taxes this year.
Yeh added that the real purpose of the tax cut is to boost consumer confidence in the domestic market.
Taiwan's consumers are suffering from sky rocketing global prices of raw materials, with the country's consumer price index (CPI) rising 3 percent since January.
In addition to asking for the tax cut, the economic ministry has asked lawmakers to adopt other measures to control inflation, including imposing export controls on steel, sand and stone.

Some of the measures have already been implemented, including setting up a special fund that offers Taiwan's 4,300 small and medium size enterprises an expanded amount of financing to help them offset their soaring import costs.
Total financing for the enterprises is expected to reach NT$10.7 billion, which will provide a lending equity of up to NT$15 million for each company which applies for the assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei stock exchange

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices were down Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 49.32 points, or 0.58 percent, to close at 8,412.76.

The bourse opened at 8,367.45 and fluctuated between 8,472.32 and 8,367.45 during the day's session. A total of 5.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$166.73 billion (US$5.42 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues advancing 3 percent, the most of any sector. Paper and pulp issues rose 2.3 percent, foodstuff issues increased 0.7 percent, textile stocks advanced 0.6 percent and cement stocks were up 0.3 percent.

The three other major stock categories lost ground. Banking and financial shares fell the most at 1.3 percent, while machinery and electronics shares dropped 0.8 percent and plastics and chemicals shares lost 0.7 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,201 to 758, with 377 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tea dealers convicted of fraud for conning Chinese tourists

TEXT.P: Two tea dealers based in the southern county of Chiayi were convicted of fraud Friday for conning Chinese tourists into buying their tea leaves at unreasonably high prices.

According to judges from the Chiayi District Court, Wang Cheh-chien, 51, a tea dealer based in Leyeh Village of Chiayi County's Alishan Township, was discovered to have purchased ordinary tea leaves that were machine-collected from tea fields in low-lying areas in the central county of Nantou since July 2005.

He paid prices between NT$160 to NT$450 per 600 grams and then, after simply processing the products, sold the tea leaves to visiting Chinese tourists at more than 10 times the price he paid -- between NT$4,000-8,000 per 600 grams.
Wang presented the leaves as hand-picked Oolong tea originating from the Alishan mountains.
Forty-five percent of the proceeds from the sales were paid to travel agents as commissions for bringing the Chinese tourists to his shop, the judges said.

Meanwhile, Pai Ming-hui, 43, another Alishan Township tea dealer, was discovered to have also purchased machine-collected, average tea leaves from low-lying areas at NT$400 per 600 grams since early 2006 and then resold the products to Chinese tourists as "Alishan high mountain Oolong tea" at prices ranging from 400 Chinese yuan (NT$1,550) to 480 yuan per 600 grams.
Both Wang and Pai, who were charged in September 2006, admitted to conning the Chinese tourists, according to the Chiayi judges.

The judges decided to cut the sentence for Wang from one year and 10 months in jail to 11 months, with three years' probation, after he expressed remorse and offered to donate NT$450,000 for public interests.

The 18-month sentence for Pai was also reduced to nine months in prison, with three years' probation after he also expressed remorse and offered to donate NT$300,000 to help the public, the judges said.
Alishan is one of the tourist attractions that the Chinese tourists consider as a "must see" in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP caucus accuses Ma of two-faced approach to 2-28 Incident

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Friday accused main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying- jeou of adopting a "two-faced" approach to dealing with the 228 Incident of 1947.

Speaking at a news conference called by several DPP lawmakers, legislative caucus whip Lai Ching-teh said that Ma's words have not matched his actions on matters related to the 228 Incident, in which tens of thousands of local Taiwanese were massacred in a crackdown by the KMT regime.

Lai pointed out that although Ma has said the KMT should bear responsibility for the 228 Incident and that he has promised to apologize to the family members of the victims, he has still not made public any of his party's documents related to the incident, adding that the party has frozen the Memorial Foundation of the 228 Incident's budget.

Lai further said that Ma has not appointed Chang An-man, a family member of a 228 Incident victim, as a legislator-at-large despite saying that he would do so, and that despite promising to establish a new national 228 memorial hall, his party's lawmakers have frozen two-thirds of the budget for the existing 228 national memorial hall.

Also speaking at the news conference, DPP lawmaker Lin Shu-fen noted that KMT lawmakers have also obstructed the budget for the Statute for the Handling of and Compensation for the 228 Incident and have frozen NT$300 million (US$9.72 million) of the 228 foundation's budget.

In response to Ma's blaming the Cabinet for listing the budget under the Ministry of Education instead of the Ministry of the Interior, Lin noted that the foundation's role according to the spirit of the law is to strengthen education related to the incident and that this is the reason why its budget was listed under the education ministry, claiming that Ma's comments that it was an allocation error on the part of the Cabinet is a lie.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Chen Ting-fei, in response to Ma's remarks that the truth behind the 228 Incident should be revealed, said that "the truth of the matter is that the KMT doesn't want to face reality."

At the time of the 228 Incident, many innocent people, including elite members of society, were blacklisted and consequently victimized, Chen said, urging Ma to make public the party's records so that people can know who compiled the name lists that led to so much pain victims and their family members.
She further urged the KMT to use its assets to provide compensation to the family members of victims of the incident to help bring them peace and closure.

On Ma's remarks the previous day that corruption in the late President Chiang Kai-shek's government led to the 228 Incident, DPP caucus whip Lai said that the massacre did not stem from the authorities' attempt to suppress an uprising, but rather from the KMT's desire to consolidate its control over the country, adding that he suspects Ma may have been intentionally trying to "tamper with historical facts."

DOC.HEADLINE: Prices down on Taipei futures market

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index for March fell 33 points to close at 8,340, with 50,020 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for April lost 31 points to finish at 8,325, with 303 contracts traded, while June futures dropped 33 points to close at 8,302, with 28 contract transactions.
September futures decreased 45 points to finish at 8,096, with 32 contract transactions, while December futures moved down four points to close at 8,100, with eight contract transactions.
The Taiwan stock exchange's benchmark TAIEX index dropped 49.32 points Friday to finish at 8,412.76, with market turnover of NT$166.73 billion (US$5.42 billion).

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 8,373 for March; 8,356 for April; 8,335 for June; 8,141 for September and 8,104 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
March TE futures lost 3.55 points to close at 318.35, with 4,991 contracts traded, while April TE futures decreased 4.1 points to finish at 316.4, with 40 contract exchanges.

June TE futures dropped 4.65 points to close at 316, with one contract traded, while September TE futures moved down two points to finish at 312.55, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for other months.
March TF futures moved down 9.6 points to close at 1,078.6, with 3,073 contracts changing hands, while April TF futures dropped 10.8 points to finish at 1,077.4, with 17 contracts traded.
December TF futures decreased 26.6 points to finish at 1,054.8, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wretch replaces Yahoo Kimo as Taiwan's most popular Web site

TEXT.P: Wretch, a Taiwanese community Web site, has replaced Yahoo Kimo as the most popular site in Taiwan in terms of Internet traffic volume, number of visitors, and stay length of each visit, according to a survey released Thursday by Taiwan's Business Next magazine.
The magazine discovered Wretch's popularity after evaluating Taiwan's Web sites and compiling the Taiwan Web 100 list based on the three criteria.

The Web site at www.wretch.cc replaced Yahoo Kimo, the nation's largest Internet portal, due to offering functions for blogs and online photo albums, both of which help to extend visitor's stay length, according to the magazine.
PC Home Online ranked the third on the list for its online shopping and home delivery services which promise delivery within 24 hours.
A total of 21 community Web sites joined the Top 100 list because of their amazingly high traffic volume and extremely long stay length, as well as their ability to meet the needs of Internet users.

They include online game Web site www.gamer.com.tw, which allows different Internet users to play electronic games simultaneously; the Mobile01 Web site which targets male office workers and offers information concerning 3C products and automobiles; and the iPartment, a female Web site that creates make-belief situations for people in love.
Electronic entertainment Web sites, such as I'mTV, YouTube, and Tudou--meaning "peanut" in Chinese, are also showing rapid growth in popularity among Internet users, according to the survey.

The survey also revealed that enterprises in traditional industries, such as the Uni-President Group, which runs 7- Eleven; VIA Technologies; and Far Eastern Group intend to expand or start their investment in the Internet industry, forecasting a more promising future for development of Taiwan's cyberspace.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electronics, financial experience in demand in China: survey

TEXT.P: Most Taiwanese workers see China as a possible place of employment, with those with backgrounds in the electronics, financial, insurance and medical fields the best positioned to find work there, according to the results of a survey released Friday.

People with experience in the travel and recreation, international trade, wholesale, retail, and information technology sectors were also considered to be in advantageous positions, the results showed.
The survey was conducted Jan. 21-29 by the online employment broker 104 Job Bank among 1,150 Taiwan businesses and 3,078 workers.

The survey found that 18.6 percent of surveyed workers have had experience working in China, 16.9 percent are looking for job opportunities in China and 45.1 percent have thought of working in China but have not made any move because of various concerns. Only 19.4 percent have never considered working in China.

While attracted to China's potential job market, many respondents were worried about the lack of suitable job opportunities for them and about the difficulty of finding information on China's job market, the results showed.
Most respondents agreed that workers with managerial, trade, marketing, project management and human resources expertise are in highest demand in China.
However, although 16.8 percent of surveyed workers believed production and manufacturing talent will remain popular in China, only 10.2 percent of surveyed businesses think so.

While 31.2 percent of surveyed workers thought those experienced in the manufacturing industry enjoy good career prospects in China, only 20.7 percent of surveyed businesses shared this opinion, the survey revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Major Japanese network to put spotlight on Nantou County

TEXT.P: Nantou County has aggressively promoted itself as a relaxing tourist getaway graced with natural beauty and cultural variety, and one of Japan's biggest broadcasters seems to have gotten the message.

A crew from the Tokyo Broadcasting System (TBS) , one of Japan's three major television networks, recently visited one of the county's tea-growing centers, Songboling Recreation Area in Mingjian Township, to film a program that will spotlight Taiwan's tea culture and tea production process.
The two-hour show on "Taiwanese tea" is scheduled to be broadcast in Japan on March 11.

The county's Sun Moon Lake is already a favorite destination of Japanese tourists. But the county's promotion of its tea culture and scenic areas has led even more Japanese and international travel agencies to make Nantou part of their travel itineraries, said Hung Wen-neng, the director of the Nantou County government's Bureau of Tourism.
"Japan's biggest travel agency (JTB) alone expects to arrange tours to Nantou this year for more than 3,000 Japanese travelers," Hung said.
That number could easily go up, Hung said, after Japanese viewers get a good look at the county's mountainous vistas and tea plantations featured in the program.

The tourism official said the program's focus on Taiwanese tea confirmed Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching's belief that, "the best tea in the world is in Taiwan, and the best tea in Taiwan is that produced in Nantou County."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.021 to close at NT$30.950.
A total of US$2.85 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$30.929 and fluctuated between NT$30.677 and NT$30.952.

DOC.HEADLINE: More give-and-take expected in second presidential debate

TEXT.P: Candidates will answer questions from five local media outlets and have a chance to challenge each other in the second presidential debate slated for March 9, debate organizers said Friday.

The organizers agreed at a preparatory meeting Thursday that the second debate between ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and his Kuomintang rival Ma Ying-jeou would adopt the traditional debate format used in the 2004 debate.
The main difference is that media representatives will be asking the questions rather than academics and experts, as was the case in 2004.
Also, unlike in the first presidential debate on Feb. 24, the candidates will not know the questions that are going to be asked beforehand.
The debate, to be held at Public Television Service (PTS) , is expected to last 2 hours and 20 minutes, according to PTS Chairman Cheng Tung-liao.

Based on the drawing of lots, Ma will open the debate with a six-minute introduction and be followed by Hsieh, while at the end of the debate, Hsieh will be the first to present a six-minute conclusion, followed by Ma, said Grace Tu, a senior PTS producer.

Following the candidates' opening statements, the candidates will both be asked five questions, one each from the five media representatives. The candidate to whom the question is directed will have three minutes to answer, with his opponent allowed one minute for a rebuttal.

The questioners will come from five of the six co-organizers of the debate. Those expected to be on the panel are Central News Agency President Liu Chih- tsung, China Times President Lin Sheng-feng, Liberty Times Vice President Yu Kuo-chi, United Daily News Group spokesman Hsiang Kuo-ning and Apple Daily President Tu Nien-chung, Grace Tu said. PTS will moderate the debate.
In the next section of the debate, the candidates will rotate in asking each other five questions, with the person answering having 90 seconds to respond.
The organizers are also taking the perceived shortcomings of the first encounter between the two candidates into consideration in establishing the set for the March 9 debate, Tu said.
There were complaints that a 15-centimeter high stand that Hsieh stood on actually made him appear taller than Ma but also caused him physical discomfort.
"We want to create a more comfortable debate environment for the two cadidates where they can feel free to speak, drink water or take notes," Tu added.
In the first televised debate held Feb. 24, the two presidential candidates answered questions from 20 citizens in 30-second pre-recorded video clips.

DOC.HEADLINE: High incidence of urological problems observed in winter

TEXT.P: Winter is a period of high incidence for urological problems, a health expert said Friday, advising people traveling long-distance, especially the elderly, to make plans to avoid having to withhold urination for a long period of time.
Chou Gu, director of the Department of Urology at the Reshining Clinic in Taipei, told reporters he has treated many cases of urological problems involving mostly old people this winter.
One patient was a 70-year-old man who had difficulty urinating after a five-day overseas trip during which he had to withhold his urine frequently for long periods.

Another factor for the high incidence of urological disorders during winter is that many people tend to hold urine longer than they should under a warm quilt at night, not wanting to brave the cold air to get out of bed to take a leak, Chou said.

The health expert warned that the urinary bladder of an adult can hold about 400 c.c. of urine and that any amount more than that could lead to a urinary retention disorder -- an accumulation of urine within the bladder because of the inability to urinate.
Withholding urination might also lead to renal inflammation or even kidney failure, he said.
Chou advised people who must travel for a long time on a transportation vehicle without a toilet to avoid drinking large amounts of liquid two hours before setting off.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temperatures will tend to be near normal in March-May: forecast

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) forecasted Friday that temperatures in Taiwan will tend to be near normal in the three months between March and May, offering a reprieve after the country experienced abnormally chilly weather in February due to the effects La Nina.
The weather bureau also reported that near normal precipitation will be very likely during the next three months.
However, a high probability of below normal rainfall in March for the central and northern parts of Taiwan may occur, the report said.
Since last fall, the La Nina phenomenon has been dominating the tropical Pacific Ocean, according to the bureau.

Citing historical data, it said an occurrence of La Nina generally causes a stronger winter monsoon in East Asia that may bring about colder weather down south. But such a pattern may give rise to a high probability of a relatively drier environment over Taiwan during early spring.

The weather bureau reminded the public that heavy rainfall and thunderstorms still could occur in March and April as the two months are typically part of Taiwan's spring season and frontal systems with strong convective cells usually form around Taiwan during that time, inducing rain.
Additionally, dense fog would quite likely appear in this season along West Taiwan, the CWB said, reminding drivers to be cautious on the road.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative speaker calls for resolution of U.N.-bid dilemma

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called for bipartisan efforts Friday to deal with the potential dilemmas Taiwan will face regardless of the outcomes of two proposed referendums on the country's bid for United Nations membership.

Wang said that for the sake of safeguarding national interests, he hopes members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) could work together to seek a pragmatic solution to the issue.

As the Republic of China, Taiwan lost its seat in the United Nations to the People's Republic of China in 1971, and has reapplied unsuccessfully for membership in the world body every year since 1993.
Last year was the first time Taiwan tried to apply for a U.N. seat under the name "Taiwan."

Two referendums on the U.N. bid will be held alongside the March 22 presidential election -- one initiated by the DPP on joining the U.N. under the name "Taiwan, " the other proposed by the KMT on rejoining the U.N. under the name "Republic of China" or any other "suitable" name.

Wang said passage of the two referendums would cause jitters around the world, but if the two measures were to fail, the damage would be even greater as the international community would get a message that "Taiwan's people do not want to enter or return to the U.N."
That, Wang said, would give Beijing a fresh excuse to say that Taiwan's people have not demanded sovereignty for the island and see it as merely a province of China.

He disclosed that officials from the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan -- which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal ties between the two countries -- visited him last week to gain a better understanding of the latest developments regarding the holding of the referendums.
The DPP recently called on the KMT to support each other's U.N. bid referendums due to concern that the referendums might fail.
As a result of that concern, there were voices calling for President Chen Shui- bian to initiate a "defensive referendum" as a solution, but the president rejected the idea on Feb. 26.
Another possible option, having the Legislative Yuan initiate a new referendum, is no longer viable because the legal deadline for proposing a new referendum has passed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Student shooter turns himself in to police

TEXT.P: A 22-year-old student, suspected of inadvertently shooting a female college student after firing his gun to prove it worked, turned himself in to the police in Taipei Friday, law enforcement officials said.

The police said that the suspect, a night student at a vocational school in the northern city, fired the shot Tuesday from a classroom as class was in session to prove to a friend that he possessed a workable modified pistol.
The teacher, who saw the gun, thought it was a toy pistol and told the student to put it away.
Ignoring the warning, however, the student fired the gun a few minutes later and then ran from the classroom. The teacher immediately reported the incident to the police.
The vocational school, Kainan High School of Commerce and Industry, is located just across from the street from National Taiwan University's College of Law.
It might be the first gunshot case on campus in the city, said Lin Teng-jiao, the deputy chief of the city's Department of Education, Thursday.

News of the incident emerged after the victim, a female student at National Taiwan University was taken to the hospital after the errant bullet grazed her abdomen, according to the police. They said the bullet was later discovered in the dorm.
The college student was standing by the window and chatting with a classmate in her dorm room when the bullet hit her, police said.
Under fire for the incident, education officials said there was little teachers or schools could do to prevent random shootings.

Wang Fu-lin, director of the Ministry of Education's Department of Military Training Education, said Thursday that to protect students' rights, the ministry bars teachers from searching students' schoolbags unless they have sufficient evidence.
Chen Kuo-liang, head of the city's Military Education Office, also said Thursday that the ministry's regulations make it difficult for schools to prevent campus shootings.
Chen stressed, however, that the office would work to improve campus safety within the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan dollar may follow a gradual uptrend later this year

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar may follow its gradual uptrend in the near future, with a foreign exchange executive predicting Thursday that the currency may close at NT$29 or NT$28 against the U.S. dollar later this year.
The New Taiwan dollar has appreciated significantly during the last two weeks, closing at NT$30.929 against the U.S. dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, the highest level in three years.
Taiwan's currency has increased by NT$1.5 against the U.S. dollar since early January, or 4 percent, a scale that trails only that of the Indonesian rupiah in Asia.
The currencies in Singapore and Malaysia also registered their record highs since 1997.

An executive of the Taiwan branch of a European bank who preferred to remain anonymous attributed the strong New Taiwan dollar to the inflow of international "hot money" to Asia, which pushed up most Asian currencies.
According to statistics released by the Securities and Futures Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission, foreign capital worth US$3.44 billion has poured into Taiwan from Feb. 1-22.

Unlike last year when Taiwan's Central Bank adopted an intervention policy to constrain the appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar, this time the bank adopted a "let go" policy to see its currency up after the Chinese Lunar New Year vacation between Feb. 6-11, as it clearly perceived the rapid flow of speculative capital in the local monetary market, the bank executive said.

In addition to the outside factor of international "hot money, " the executive pointed out, many countries in Asia have been inclined to allow their currencies to appreciate to resist "imported inflation" amid surging prices of imports, such as crude oil, metals and cereals.

Another factor attracting speculative capital to Taiwan is that the average price-earnings ratio of Taiwan stocks stood at only 13.57 as of late January compared to 15.31 registered in late December of last year, which makes investing in Taiwan's stock market more profitable than ever, the executive noted.

"It is expected that we will see a continued strong New Taiwan dollar before Taiwan's March 22 presidential election, but the value of the New Taiwan dollar will still have to depend on the attitude of the Central Bank and international economic environment," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Crime rate in Taichung continues to drop

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Friday that although the crime rate in the central city continued to drop last year, there is still considerable room for further improvement.

Hu told a city government meeting that he was happy to see that Taichung's crime rate in 2007 dropped further to 3,283 cases per 100,000 people after reaching a target in 2006 to reduce the number of criminal cases to below 4,000 cases per 100,000.
Taichung has placed last among all of Taiwan's cities and counties in the past decade, with the highest crime rates.
Hu asked the police force, as well as residents, of Taichung to help realize the city government's goal for this year by reducing the crime rate to below 2,800 cases per 100,000.

Figures compiled by the police bureau show that Taichung recorded 251 criminal cases in January this year, moving the city one notch up from the bottom of the list to surpass the city of Chiayi, which recorded 257 criminal cases per 100,000 over the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural sector calls for peaceful election with Hopemap campaign

TEXT.P: Fifty-six publishers, writers, scholars and art performers, led by Locus Publishing Chairman Rex How, launched a campaign called "Our Hopemap" Friday, in a call for people around the country to refrain from stirring up ethnic conflicts three weeks before the March 22 presidential election.

Tuan Yi-kang, a spokesman for the campaign headquarters of the presidential ticket of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and his counterpart Chiu Shu- ti of the opposition Kuomintang attended a press conference presided over by How to accept the call, promising to undertake peaceful campaigning for their party's respective candidate.

Addressing the campaign, How said a Web site at www.hopemap.net was launched at 2: 30 p.m. Friday on which a "map of Taiwan's future" is under formation with people urged to write down their hopes, opinions and suggestions to the presidential candidates of the two parties.
How said that he wants to raise the consciousness of fellow citizens through the online Hopemap, which is composed of digital light dots.

With the number of people writing down their wishes increasing, the size and shape of the map will change, How said, noting that they hope to collect 3 million hopes from Friday to April 11 and to publish a book compiling the hopes, presenting it to the new president at his inauguration on May 20 as a reference for his future administration.

At the press conference, How voiced three common hopes from all the Hopemap campaign initiators, which include a hope that no one will act to stir up ethnic conflicts; a hope for no war of words and malicious smears during election campaigns and for the two presidential candidates to tell voters concretely how they will help people build a better future if elected; and a hope for a peaceful election on March 22.

After the election, How further said, there are also two common hopes -- one regarding expectations on the president-elect and the other involving giving support to the candidate who loses the election.

The campaign allows "the presidential candidates to hear another kind of voice ahead of the election, and after the election may let us remind each other that we still have a common future that need everyone to create together," How said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT candidate meets with pro-independence TSU stalwarts

TEXT.P: In what was described as a surprise move by many, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou called on two key figures of the pro- independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Friday.

Meeting with surgeon Chien Cheng-shan and his wife and former TSU Legislator Chien Lin Huei-chun in Tainan, southern Taiwan, Ma said the encounter was "not an attempt to undercut the support base" of the "pan-green camp" comprised of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the TSU.
He said that after the March 22 presidential election, a clean government is the top priority.
"Neither the belief in unification or independence will get anywhere," Ma said, adding that "it is better to put one's efforts on common beliefs and values."
"The urgent tasks for Taiwan are to improve the economy, a clean government, social justice and cross-strait peace," Ma said.

The Chiens, who hold considerable sway in the medical sector and at the grassroots level in Tainan County and who maintain close relations with Lee Teng-hui, the former president and the TSU's spiritual leader, have championed Taiwan independence for years.

Their meeting with Ma from the pro-unification KMT, caught many by surprise, but Chien, while presenting Ma with a plaque inscribed with the words "wishing Ma success, " refrained from openly endorsing him.
Chien said that this meeting "was his own, " and he had not reported to Lee, the spiritual leader of the TSU, and the TSU beforehand.

Chien noted that he was the first doctor in Tainan's Doctor Association who took to the streets and joined the DPP, and he had insisted on Taiwan's independence, but with the rapid progress in society, he should not insist on his views of more than 20 years ago.
He said that "the transfer of power between different parties should be a normal practice, and the solution to the root problem of corruption in politics."
He stressed that he was not switching allegiance from "pan-green" to "pan-blue," saying that he belongs to "neither camp, " and that he is "Taiwanese."
DPP presidential candidate Frank Hsieh for his part tried to play down the significance of the meeting, saying that this does not mean that the former president is endorsing Ma.
"If Lee does take sides, many will follow suit, and not just the Chiens will support Ma," Hsieh suggested.
William Lai, caucus whip of the DPP in the legislature, said that the meeting was an "individual act" of the Chiens, and not indicative of who Lee would support.
The KMT's playing up the meeting was a campaign gambit, Lai said.

With more and more influential figures taking sides in the runup to the presidential election, Ku Kuan-min, a former Presidential Office senior adviser, said Lee was a "speculator, " referring to the coattail effects of the KMT winning a huge victory in the Jan. 12 legislative election.
Huang Kun-hu, president of a Lee Teng-hui supporters group, urged Lee to publicly endorse Hsieh.
Huang said that Lee has always advocated Taiwan identity, and Hsieh shared the same view, and which is starkly different from Ma's view.
Lee should not "keep quiet" at this critical time, but "should lend Hsieh support by openly speaking up for him."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign funds on the watch for March 22 election

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan Dollar fell against the U.S. greenback Friday on central bank intervention, but analysts believe that given the fundamentally weak dollar and strong inflow of foreign capital, it may have been but a temporary blip in the local currency's upward trend.

The Taiwan dollar closed at 30.95 against the U.S. dollar (USD) , down 0.021 from its 30.929 close on Wednesday, but analysts believe the local currency will test the 30.5 baseline in the near term. The local currency market was closed Thursday, a national holiday.

In Friday's trading, the Taiwan dollar surged in the morning on a net inflow of foreign funds, hitting a high of NT$30.677 to the U.S. greenback. Turnover for the morning session was US$1.644 billion (NT$50.9 billion), the second-highest this year.
In the afternoon session, however, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) , intervened, buying as much as US$1 billion to reverse the Taiwan dollar's rise for the day.
The intervention by the central bank, which had taken a hands-off position since the beginning of the year, pushed turnover for the day to US$3.498 billion, the second highest in history.
Despite Friday's small setback, the local currency has risen 4.6 percent for the year.

Michael Boyden, managing director of Taiwan Asia Strategy Consulting, a Taiwan- based consulting company, attributed the current surge in the local currency to a potential political shift in Taiwan, saying that the upcoming presidential election could be a decisive factor in whether so-called hot money will remain in the local market.

The Taiwan dollar gained only 3.6 percent from 1997 to 2006, a relatively mild rise compared to Japan's yen and Korea's won against the U.S. dollar, which rose 22 percent and 78.7 percent during the same period of time.

Referring to Taiwan's currency as undervalued by global investors in the past, Boyden also stressed that Taiwan's companies are in fact global players that have begun to catch the world's attention in recent years.
"Taiwan's companies are getting better in a lot of ways including product branding, and have become the leading exporters among Asian countries," he said.
Taiwan's trade surplus grew 28.4 percent in 2007 to US$27.38 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD targets women, people aged 50-64, to join labor market

TEXT.P: With Taiwan becoming an increasingly aging society, women and people between the ages of 50 and 64 will be encouraged to join the labor force and maintain the labor force participation rate, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Friday.

CEPD observed that although Taiwan's population is gradually aging, the overall labor force participation rate has not come down, because more female workers, especially those between 25 and 49 years of age, have joined the labor force than in previous years.

"If we can encourage people to work, the decline in the size of the labor force due to an aging population structure could be held in check, and thus the labor force participation rate could be maintained, " a CEPD official said.
The labor force participation rate is the ratio of the labor force to the overall size of the national population in the same age bracket.

Since 2002, the central government has encouraged women and people between 50-64 years old to join the labor market by creating job opportunities, ensuring expectant mothers' rights and giving parental leave.
The CEPD also vowed to improve vocational training and formulate a system that would help workers to look after both their families and their jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's CPI growth is relatively low: Premier

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the growth of Taiwan's Consumer Price Index (CPI) is relatively low compared to that of other countries.

In response to a question from ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Wang Hsing-nan, Chang indicated that Taiwan's CPI growth was 2.96 percent in January, lower than the 6.6 percent registered in Singapore, 4.4 percent in the United States and 3.9 percent in South Korea.
Citing the example of South Korea, Chang said that although it enjoys a higher per capita annual income than that of Taiwan, its real purchasing power is lower than that of Taiwan.

The premier also noted that while South Korean President Lee Myung-bak had promised to keep South Korea's CPI growth under 3 percent, the DPP government hopes to control Taiwan's CPI growth under 2 percent.

Meanwhile, Chang said the government has adopted several measures to prevent the price of reinforcing steel bars, or rebars, from rising higher, including allowing duty-free treatment for rebar imports and temporarily banning exports of Taiwan-made rebar beginning March 5.
Chang provided the assurance after many builders complained that they were having difficulty continuing their construction projects due to the soaring price of steel products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan County fishery losses reach over NT$16 million

TEXT.P: Amid a cold snap that has lingered in Taiwan for about three weeks, the fish farming industry in the southern county of Tainan has sustained an initial loss of over NT$16 million (US$516,000) in February, the county's agricultural affairs bureau reported Friday.
According to the latest statistics compiled by the bureau, damage of aquatic products has been reported from the county's townships, including Cigu Jiangjyun, Syuejia, Beimen and Madou.
Fish and other sea products died as a result of continuous low temperatures which hit Taiwan since the beginning of this month and still remained.
Among the various species of high-value fish raised by local fish farmers, milkfish, farmed in a total area of about 174-hectare fishing ponds, posted the most serious loss of NT$11.6 million.
Damage sustained by fishermen who raise Taiwan tilapia and grouper meanwhile reached more than NT$1.5 million, the bureau reported.

Farmers who raise other sorts of sea creatures such as perch, blackfish and clam also suffered losses ranging from tens of thousands of New Taiwan dollars to one million New Taiwan dollars, according to the bureau.
The damage suffered by the industry has driven up prices of seafood. The price of a popular Taiwanese dish, oyster omelet, for example, has risen from NT$40 to NT$50 per dish.
Reprieve is unlikely to come soon, as the bureau warned farmers that a fresh cold spell will hit in the coming days.

Taiwan's aquaculture industry is clustered in Yunlin, Tainan and Chiayi counties in central and southern Taiwan, as well as the outlying Penghu Island. The island's losses had amounted to at least NT$180 million by Feb. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia sign natural gas deal valued at US$48.29 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Sydney, Feb. 29 (CNA) 02/29/08 22:14:57 (By Chen Ming-lung & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run petroleum company, CPC Corp., Taiwan, signed a contract Friday to purchase liquefied natural gas from Woodside Co., a leading independent Australian oil and gas company, in a deal that could potentially be worth up NT$1.5 trillion (US$48.29 billion) over 20 years.

Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Steve R. L. Chen, in Australia to witness the signing ceremony, called the deal -- Taiwan's largest natural gas purchasing contract -- an important milestone in trade and economic cooperation between Taiwan and Australia.
CPC Chairman Pan Wenent and Woodside Chief Executive Officer Don Voelte signed the deal at the Sydney Opera House, with Chen and Australian Minister for Trade Simon Crean witnessing the ceremony.

Under the deal, Woodside will begin exporting two million to three million tons of liquefied natural gas a year to Taiwan, which would account for 25 percent of Taiwan's yearly demand. The deal would last for 15-20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC suggests negotiating professional mobility with China under WTO

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China should hold negotiations to facilitate the mobility of professionals, industry and capital under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework to ensure the rights of Taiwan's professionals, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun said Friday.
Liu called for negotiations after China announced Wednesday that it would allow Taiwan's medical professionals to practice in China.

The Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council said that doctors from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau who have legally practiced medicine for at least five years, are certified specialists, and are currently practicing in medical institutions can apply to practice medicine in China.

Liu said, however, that China was unwilling to negotiate details on the movement of professionals, which would leave Taiwan's professionals who want to work in China in the future vulnerable to risks.
The MAC official cited the experiences of many of Hong Kong's doctors who practiced in China after the signing of the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) in 2003.
A number returned to Hong Kong, Liu said, because of disputes caused by the disparity in the salary levels and medical systems of China and Hong Kong.

He also called on the government to be aware of the consequences of allowing medical professionals to work in China, saying it would have the same effect as Taiwan's export of agricultural products across the Taiwan Strait.
Liu said the exports have helped China learn Taiwan's advanced growing techniques, enabling China to crowd out Taiwan's products with its own.
The MAC official said China decided to allow Taiwan's doctors to work there in order to resolve its shortage of medical resources and achieve its political goal of unification with Taiwan.

Liu pointed out that Article 33 of the Statute Governing Relations Between People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area stipulates that Taiwanese people who want to work in Chinese organizations have to obtain permission from the government.
He acknowledged, however, that Taiwan is a democratic country, and it is difficult for the government to impose strict restrictions on the mobility of professionals, industry, or capital.
International organizations such as the WTO can help strive for legal protections and rights that will benefit Taiwan's people, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP candidate urges rival to back U.N. referendums

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Frank Hsieh Friday called on his rival not to boycott referendums supporting membership for Taiwan in the United Nations, saying such a move would be contrary to the Kuomintang (KMT) candidate's profession of his love for the country.

Speaking during the second session of a campaign forum in which the two candidates expound their platforms and attacked their rivals, Hsieh said that KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou should not repeat the KMT's boycott of referendums held alongside the Jan. 12 legislative polls.
The U.N. referendums -- proposed by both the DPP and the KMT, with each supporting using different names for the country's bid -- will be held alongside the March 22 presidential polls.

Ahead of the January polls, the KMT urged eligible voters not to claim referendum ballots, arguing that the DPP government tied the two referendums to the elections to increase turnout among DPP supporters.
The DPP-sponsored referendum early this year was aimed at recovering the "ill- gotten" assets amassed by the KMT during its decades of authoritarian rule in Taiwan.
By contrast, the KMT-proposed referendum was aimed at authorizing the legislature to investigate corrupt top government officials.

In the end, neither referendum had a turnout of 50 percent of eligible voters required for them to be considered valid. The KMT won a landside victory in the legislative polls, garnering 81 seats in the 113-seat legislature, nearly three quarters, while the DPP only took 27 seats.
The forum was the first of four Central Election Commission (CEC) organized campaign forums.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA task force will help Penghu restore eco-marine system

TEXT.P: A task force under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) was set up Friday to help the Penghu Island chain recover from the effects of persistent cold weather, which has dealt a heavy blow to its fish farming industry and eco- marine system.

According to a COA statement, the task force will be led by National Taiwan Ocean University President Lee Kuo-tien and composed of experts and professors from Academia Sinica and local universities and will monitor the marine recovery on the Taiwan-controlled island county.

Many of the task force's members visited Penghu Feb. 23, after the cold spell had ravaged Penghu's fishing industry over the previous three weeks, causing losses to the island chain's fish farming industry of NT$180 million as of last week.

The task force will be divided into six units to periodically monitor ocean productivity off Penghu's coasts, covering six species of sea creatures and plants, such as seaweeds, spineless animals, coral and fish.
Results of the research and investigation will be used as references for measures to be adopted to help in the revitalization of Penghu's coasts, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT hopeful details timetable for China flights, tourist arrivals

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou put forward a concrete timetable of direct airlinks with China Friday, vowing that weekend cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights will be launched starting July 1 if he is elected.
Ma made the pledge in a written statement presented at a meeting with representatives from the local hi-tech sector and investment companies.

Pledging to immediately implement direct charter flights between Taiwan and China from July 1 if he is elected president on March 22, Ma also promised that daily charter flights and normal commercial flights between the two sides will be realized in a piecemeal fashion.

According to Ma's written statement, the KMT presidential candidate stressed that he will begin bilateral negotiations on the opening of direct Taiwan-China airlinks as soon as he assumes the presidency on May 20, if elected.

Apart from direct cross-strait charter flights on weekends from July 1, Ma promised that daily charter flights across the strait will take off by the end of this year and regularly scheduled flights between the two sides by June next year.

During a meeting with representatives from the construction industry and architecture associations later the same day, the KMT presidential candidate also delved into his program on welcoming Chinese tourists to Taiwan.

In conjunction with the establishment of direct airlinks across the strait, his administration will bring about the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists as quickly as possible upon his inauguration, Ma stated.

If elected, Ma said, a maximum level of 3,000 Chinese tourists will be allowed to enter Taiwan each day in the initial stage from July 1 this year. Moreover, he added, the number will be raised to 5,000 people per day in the second year of the opening, 7,000 people per day in the third year of the opening and 10,000 per day in the fourth year.

More than one million Chinese tourists would be allowed to visit Taiwan in the first year, and such an entry would generate NT$60 billion worth of revenues for related businesses in the first year, Ma explained.

Thanks to the opening to Chinese tourists, an additional 40,000 jobs could be created in the first year and an additional 120,000 jobs in the fourth year, Ma said in the statement, adding that Taiwan's economy would grow by at least six percent each year.

With an improved economy, Taiwan's jobless rate will fall below 3 percent within four years from the current level of some 3.9 percent and an annual per-capita income of US$30,000 will be achieved in eight years, up from the current US$17,000, according to the statement.

Ma voiced hope of turning Taiwan into a transportation hub for the Asia-Pacific region and the rest of the world after cross-strait air and shipping links are set up, enabling Taiwan to play a more prominent role for multi-national enterprises and those seeking globalization.

Taiwan's strategic location west of China, east of the United States, south of Japan and north of the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations will turn the country into a key business operations center if direct China links are put in place, he contended.

The KMT presidential candidate also reiterated his plans to improve Taiwan's infrastructure, to ease the tax burden on the public and remove the disputed 40 percent ceiling on investment restrictions by Taiwanese companies in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Alliance to pressure presidential candidates for clear answers

TEXT.P: An alliance of local scholars will be launched Saturday to force the two presidential candidates to offer more specific and clear details of their platforms, a local scholarly group said Friday in a statement.

The establishment of the alliance was proposed by Taipei Society, a local nonpartisan group of intellectuals, and was supported by 30 scholars, including members of the society, Academia Sinica academicians and researchers, and university professors.

The statement said that both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Frank Hsieh and opposition Kuomintang presidential candidate Ma Ying-jeou had not offered clear positions on many important issues related to Taiwan's future, leaving the group worried about the consequences of the upcoming election.
The alliance will ask hard questions of the two candidates in various forms to force them to clearly state their positions and policies, enabling voters to have clear choices.

Questions to be asked include those about the two candidates' ethics, their future teams, national policies, and positions on Taiwan's sovereignty, to let the voters see the difference between the two candidates and their parties.

According to the statement, the "snowball effect" seen in the media following the KMT's massive victory in the legislative elections had prevented the silent majority from having a voice, leading to a "collective anxiety."
The Taipei Society called on intellectuals who have the ability to stand up for silenced voters to join the alliance and challenge the two candidates over their ability to be Taiwan's leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas investment cap raised for insurance companies

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) announced Friday that insurance companies in Taiwan are now allowed to raise their overseas investment ceiling from the current 35 percent of their total funds to 45 percent in two stages within a period of two years.
The FSC said that an insurance company can apply to increase its investment abroad by 5 percent in the first year and another 5 percent in the second year.
Statistics show that Taiwan's life insurance companies currently have total funds of NT$7.5 trillion (US$242.1 billion), with the total growing by over NT$1 trillion each year.
In 2007, Taiwan's insurers invested NT$2.3 trillion abroad, an increase of NT$242 billion over 2006.

Ten life insurance companies and one property insurance company are eligible to apply for a 5 percent increase in their overseas investment ceiling this year. If they all make use of the new policy, their investment abroad in 2008 would increase by NT$275 billion, according to the FSC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan presidential hopefuls differ sharply on major policies

TEXT.P: In their second face-to-face encounter before a national audience, Taiwan's two presidential hopefuls bickered over a number of major issues, from personal integrity, and the viability of their national development plans, to China policy.

Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang and Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party conducted their first of four "policy forums" organized by the Central Election Committee, in which each candidate had two periods of 15 minutes to present their policies.
In their initial presentations, Hsieh focused on "Taiwanese Reformation" while Ma stressed building "a clean and competent government."

Hsieh said that Taiwan's people have repeatedly defied the government throughout the island's history when the island was ruled by the Dutch, the Ching Dynasty, the Japanese and the KMT, because "people could not choose their own fate, nor be the masters of their own."

Describing the president as "the guardian of a country, " Hsieh said that the Taiwanese should stand up together to safeguard their ancestor's dream of freedom and was therefore introducing a "Taiwanese Reformation" modeled on the Japanese Meiji Reformation of the 19th century.
He strongly criticized Ma's policy of a "one-China common market," which he claimed would allow for the free flow of people goods and information.

"Taiwan does not need to sacrifice its dignity for 0.3 percent GDP growth," Hsieh said, saying that the country's 5.7 percent GDP growth in 2007 was only 0.3 percent below the 6 percent growth proposed by Ma.
"Happiness is in our own hands, " Hsieh said, adding that only by uniting can Taiwan have a bright future.

He proposed to reform the tax system by reducing the inheritance tax and corporate income tax rates as well as increasing the standard deductions claimed by taxpayers to help women, the elderly, children and minority groups.
Ma rebutted Hsieh's characterization of the "one-China common market, " denying that he had ever proposed the concept.
What he advocated was forging a "comprehensive economic cooperation agreement" with China and give "six assurances" to guarantee that Taiwan would not be overwhelmed by Chinese laborers or goods.

Among the assurances were promises that Chinese agricultural products would not be allowed to enter Taiwan, Chinese workers would not be allowed to work in Taiwan, and Chinese academic diplomas would not be recognized for people applying for professional licenses.
Ma said his goal was to "normalize" the economic relationship between China and Taiwan and opening up the country to Chinese tourists would be his top priority if he gets elected.

Under Ma's plan, 3,000 Chinese tourists a day would visit Taiwan during the first year, injecting an estimated NT$60 billion (US$1.9 billion) into the economy, and increase 10,000 tourists a day in four years, creating 120,000 job opportunities.
"What we need is a clean and competent government, " Ma said, listing his main priorities as "a vibrant economy, a clean government, a just society and peaceful cross-strait relations."

Ma said that opening up to China can bring great opportunities for Taiwan, stressing that "it is time for change" from an indecisive, corrupt government to one that is honest and just and can lead Taiwan to a brighter future.

The roughly one-hour forum allowed the presidential candidates to make two separate 15-minute presentations. Although there was no direct cross- examination, both candidates seized every possible opportunity to question and attack his opponent.

It was the first of four Central Election Commission -- organized campaign forums for the two rival presidential candidates with Public Television Service providing a live broadcast of the event. The second televised forum is slated for March 7.
The two candidates had already faced off in a debate organized by six media organizations in which Taiwanese citizens asked Hsieh and Ma pre-recorded questions.
